english_grammar.title: かった
english_grammar.explanation: Was, Were (past tense)
english_grammar.structure: ［い］Adjective［い］+ かった Examples おもしろい + かった 新しい + かった
english_grammar.attention: い-Adjectives, whether positive or negative, cannot be used with だ
english_grammar.about: In order to create the past form of い-Adjectives, you must add the auxiliary verb た to the 'past' conjunction form of the い-Adjective. The past conjunction form is created by removing the い and replacing it with かっ. This structure is equivalent to 'was' in English.面白(おもしろ)い - Base (dictionary form)面白(おもしろ)かっ - Form used with た (and several other auxiliary verbs) お風呂(ふろ)が温(あたたか)かった。The bath was lukewarm. 昨日(きのう)の夜(よる)は寒(さむ)かった。 Last night was cold. (Literally 'yesterday's night') From these examples, we can see how the casual past form is constructed. In modern Japanese, simply adding です after た is considered to be the standard polite past form. 京都(きょうと)は涼(すず)しかったです。Kyoto was cool. (In relation to temperature) このケーキは甘(あま)かったです。This cake was sweet. Caution Although this is considered to be polite by most people, using です after かった is not academically correct Japanese. However, considering how common its usage has become, it may be used in almost any situation confidently.

example.japanese: 寒(さむ)かった。[寒(さむ)い]
example.english: It was cold.

example.japanese: それは、高(たか)かった。[高(たか)い]
example.english: That was expensive.

example.japanese: 田中(たなか)さんは強(つよ)かったです。[強(つよ)い]
example.english: Tanaka-san was strong.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の姉(あね)の家(いえ)が古(ふる)かったです。[古(ふる)い]
example.english: My (older) sister's house was old.

example.japanese: 動物園(どうぶつえん)は楽(たの)しかった。[楽(たの)しい]
example.english: The zoo was fun.

english_grammar.title: のは・のが
english_grammar.explanation: Verb nominalizer, The one who..., That which...
english_grammar.structure: Verb + の
english_grammar.about: In Japanese, のは and のが behave in a very similar way to the words 'that' and 'which' in English. This means that they perform a task called nominalization. Nominalization is when a phrase is treated in the same way as a single noun. 沢山(たくさん)食(た)べるのは彼(かれ)です。He is the one that eats a lot. (Literally 'the one that eats a lot, he is') 私(わたし)はバスに乗(の)るのが嫌(きら)いです。I don't like riding the bus. (Literally 'that which is riding a bus, I hate') Rather than a single noun, we can see from these examples that the phrases 沢山(たくさん)食(た)べるのは and バスに乗(の)るのが are behaving in the same way that a single noun would. In English, this can either mean 'that which', or 'the one who/that'.This construction can be used after verbs in any tense, except for the polite ます or ません, which are only used at the end of a sentence, or certain clauses. 彼(かれ)は走(はし)るのが好(す)き。He likes running. お菓子(かし)を全部(ぜんぶ)食(た)べたのは、娘(むすめ)だ。My daughter is the one that ate all of the candy. 山(やま)を登(のぼ)っているのは、今田(いまだ)さんだ。Imada-san is that one who is climbing the mountain. Caution の cannot be used as a substitute for こと in set expressions like ことができる, or ことがある. It also may not be followed by だ, である, or です, as this would become the explanatory ～んです, or のです in that case.

example.japanese: この仕事(しごと)をするのは私(わたし)だ。
example.english: I am the one who does this job.

example.japanese: 読(よ)むのは私(わたし)です。
example.english: I am the one who reads.

example.japanese: 寿司(すし)を食(た)べるのは、彼(かれ)だ。
example.english: He is the one who eats sushi.

example.japanese: 漢字(かんじ)を覚(おぼ)えるのは、彼女(かのじょ)です。
example.english: She is the one who remembers kanji.

example.japanese: 文法(ぶんぽう)を勉強(べんきょう)するのは、私(わたし)です。
example.english: I am the one who studies grammar.

synonym.explanation: Indicates possession
As for... (highlights sentence topic)
Converting a verb into a noun
The 'one' that... (indefinite pronoun, adjective nominalization)
combined particles

english_grammar.title: い-Adjective + (Noun)
english_grammar.explanation: Describing a noun
english_grammar.structure: ［い］Adjective + Noun Examples: かわいい + 猫 新しい + 車 寒い + 冬
english_grammar.about: In Japanese, almost any type of word can be attached to the beginning of a noun to modify the meaning, or describe the qualities of that noun. However, depending on the type of word used, conjugation rules will differ slightly.For い-Adjectives, they are simply attached to the front of the noun in their standard (dictionary) form. 早(はや)い車(くるま)。A fast car. 怖(こわ)い先生(せんせい)。A scary teacher. Caution When identifying what an い-Adjective is, and what is not, remember that an い-Adjective's い will always be outside of any kanji in the word.面白(おもしろ)い - The い is outside the kanji, so it is definitely an い-Adjective.綺麗(きれい) - The い is inside of the kanji, so it is definitely not an い-Adjective.There are some, but very few exceptions.嫌(きら)い - The い is outside of the kanji, but this is actually a な-Adjective.

example.japanese: 新(あたら)しい車(くるま)。
example.english: A new car

example.japanese: 可愛(かわい)い女(おんな)の子(こ)がいる。
example.english: There is a cute girl.

example.japanese: カッコいい先輩(せんぱい)。
example.english: Cool senpai.

example.japanese: 寒(さむ)い夜(よる)。
example.english: Cold night.

example.japanese: 面白(おもしろ)いゲームを買(か)います。
example.english: To buy an interesting game.

english_grammar.title: な-Adjective + (Noun)
english_grammar.explanation: Describing a noun
english_grammar.structure: ［な］Adjective + な + Noun Examples: 静か + な + 夜 元気 + な + 子供
english_grammar.about: In Japanese, almost any type of word can be attached to the beginning of a noun to modify the meaning, or describe the qualities of that noun. However, depending on the type of word used, conjugation rules will differ slightly.For な-Adjectives, they will always need to be followed by な, when used before a noun. This means that adjective (A) is describing qualities/features of noun (B). カーテンオタク：これは綺麗(きれい)なカーテンです。A curtain enthusiast : This is a pretty curtain. 元気(げんき)な赤(あか)ちゃん。A healthy baby. ('Energetic' or 'spirited' would also be accurate translations) Caution Many words can take either な or の when describing a noun. The difference in meaning is usually clear. Let's take a look at both nuances.(A) な (B) means that - (A) is a quality/feature of (B)(A) の (B) means that - (A) is the type/purpose of (B) 有名(ゆうめい)な人(ひと)。A famous person. (A 'quality' of this person is that they have 'fame') 有名(ゆうめい)の力(ちから)。The power of fame. (The 'type' of power is that of 'fame') To avoid making this mistake when using な-Adjectives to describe a noun, it can be helpful to think about whether you are describing a 'quality', or the 'purpose' of something.

example.japanese: ひまな一日(いちにち)。
example.english: A free day

example.japanese: 旭(あさひ)が丘(おか)は静(しず)かな街(まち)です。
example.english: Asahigaoka is a quiet town.

example.japanese: たなかさんは親切(しんせつ)な人(ひと)だ。
example.english: Tanaka-san is a kind person.

example.japanese: これは便利(べんり)なツールです。
example.english: This is a convenient tool.

example.japanese: 綺麗(きれい)なタオルはトイレにある。
example.english: There are clean towels in the bathroom.

english_grammar.title: へ行(い)く
english_grammar.explanation: To go to, To head toward
english_grammar.structure: Place + へ(1) + 行く (1) に
english_grammar.about: へ行(い)く is a common construction used when describing a place that someone/something is 'heading'. The particles に and へ are interchangeable, but there is a slight difference in meaning. に has the nuance of 'going to', while へ has the nuance of 'heading to'. ジョンは学校(がっこう)へ行(い)く。John is heading to school. エルサは病院(びょういん)に行(い)く。Elsa is going to the hospital. In these examples, while they may seem the same at first glance, へ focuses much more on the journey, while に puts more emphasis on the destination. This is true for other uses of に and へ as well. に will always put more focus on the destination of an action, where へ will put more emphasis on the distance traveled/between the origin and destination. 先生(せんせい)へ電話(でんわ)をする。To make a call to the teacher. (Focuses more on the distance between the caller and receiver) 先生(せんせい)に電話(でんわ)をする。To make a call to the teacher. (Focuses more on the destination of the call)

example.japanese: 学校(がっこう)へ行(い)く。
example.english: To go to school.

example.japanese: 駅(えき)へ行(い)く。
example.english: To go to the station.

example.japanese: 東京(とうきょう)へ行(い)く。
example.english: To go to Tokyo.

example.japanese: 教室(きょうしつ)へ行(い)く。
example.english: To go to the classroom.

example.japanese: 道(みち)へ行(い)きます。
example.english: To go toward a road.

synonym.explanation: To ~ and go, To go on, To start
To go ~, To go in order to ~
To, Toward
To come
to be (honorific), to come (honorific), to go (honorific)

english_grammar.title: する
english_grammar.explanation: To do, To make into
english_grammar.structure: する
english_grammar.attention: Although not common, 為る kanji use can be seen
english_grammar.about: する verbs are one of only two verbs in Japanese that do not follow the standard rules of conjugation for Godan and Ichidan verbs. The other primary verb being 来(く)る. する means to do something, or to make something a certain way. 洗濯(せんたく)をする。To do laundry. 料理(りょうり)をする。To cook. (Literally 'to do food') する will almost always have the particle を attached to the thing that is being done (depending on the form of the verb).The reason that する verbs are called さ-column irregular conjugation verbs in Japanese is because the る in する does not conjugate, but is dropped.This will leave す to be the part that conjugates. Because of this, する has qualities of both る-Verbs (the る being dropped), and う-Verbs (the remaining す changing, depending on the conjugation). Here are some examples of how する changes.（さ）せる, （し）ます, （す）る, （せ）よWe will learn more about each of these conjugations of する, and their individual meanings at a later stage. For now, let's take a look at the polite します conjugation. 電話(でんわ)をします。To make a call. 勉強(べんきょう)をします。To study. In a broader sense, する can be thought of as meaning 'to do something that has an external effect'.

example.japanese: サッカーをする。
example.english: To play soccer.

example.japanese: サッカーをします。
example.english: To play soccer.

example.japanese: 何(なに)をしますか。
example.english: What will you do?

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は勉強(べんきょう)をする。
example.english: I will study.

example.japanese: 掃除(そうじ)をする。
example.english: To clean.

synonym.explanation: to do (humble)
to do (honorific)

english_grammar.title: 来(く)る
english_grammar.explanation: To come
english_grammar.structure: くる
english_grammar.about: 来(く)る is one of only two verbs in Japanese that do not follow the standard rules of conjugation for Godan and Ichidan verbs. The other primary verb being する. 来(く)る means 'to come', or 'to be coming'. お前(まえ)もパーティーに来(く)る？Will you come to the party too? サヤの家(いえ)に来(き)ている。I have come to Saya's house. (I'm at Saya's house now) 来(く)る will always have the particle に or へ attached to the location that someone 'will come', or 'has come'.The reason that 来(く)る is called a か-column irregular conjugation verb in Japanese is because the る in 来(く)る does not conjugate, but is dropped. This leaves the く being the part that conjugates. Because of this, 来る has qualities of both る-Verbs (the る being dropped), and う-Verbs (the remaining く changing depending on the conjugation). Here are some examples of how 来(く)る changes.（き）た, （く）る, （こ）ない来(く)る will often be seen as 来(き)ている when someone has come to a place and remains there. This is due to ている meaning 'to exist in the state of an action', rather than being exactly the same as '(A)~ing' in English. Because of this, 来(き)ている can mean either 'to be somewhere that one has come', or 'to be coming'. 今(いま)、駅(えき)に来(き)ている。I have come to the station. (I am at the station now) カナは駅(えき)に来(き)ている？Is Kana coming to the station? (Is Kana on her way to the station now?) Sometimes the difference between these two will not be clear unless there is further context.Caution 来(き)ている (for existing at a place) is only used for places that people 'temporarily' go, so will not be used when you are at your home/work.

example.japanese: トムはここに来(く)る。
example.english: Tom will come here.

example.japanese: バスが来(く)る。
example.english: The bus will come.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はバスで来(き)ます。
example.english: He will come by bus.

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)も来(き)ますか。
example.english: Will your friend come too?

example.japanese: 明日(あした)来(き)ます。
example.english: I will come tomorrow.

synonym.explanation: To go to, To head toward
To come to, To become, To continue, To be starting to, Has been ~ing
to be (honorific), to come (honorific), to go (honorific)

english_grammar.title: る-Verb (Past)
english_grammar.explanation: る - Verbs (past tense)
english_grammar.structure: Examples: ​​食べる + た ​​見る + た ​​寝る + た
english_grammar.about: To make the past form of a る-Verb in Japanese, just like all other conjugations of る-Verbs, you will need to remove the る first. After this, all you need to do is add the auxiliary verb た (casual), or ました (polite). ドアを開(あ)ける。I open the door ドアを開(あ)けた。I opened the door. ドアを開(あ)けました。I opened the door. Fun Factました is actually just ます conjugated with た on the end of it, so it is two (2) auxiliary verbs, not just one. This means that only た gives the meaning of 'past' to a word, while ます keeps it's regular role of making the verb more polite.When た is added to verbs (or any other word), it can have one of three possible meanings.Past: 過去(かこ) - Happened at some point in the past. (Did/Was)Completion: 完了(かんりょう) - An action that has finished 'happening'. (Done)Continuation: 存続(そんぞく) - A new state of something that is continuing. (Has been done) たかしは1994年(ねん)に生(う)まれた。Takashi was born in 1994. (An example of past) 今朝(けさ)、テストを受(う)けた。I took the test this morning. (An example of completion) 彼(かれ)の名前(なまえ)を忘(わす)れた。I forgot his name, and still can't remember. (An example of continuation)

example.japanese: 昨日(きのう)、テレビを見(み)た。昨日(きのう)、テレビを見(み)ました。
example.english: I watched TV yesterday.

example.japanese: 日本(にっぽん)で寿司(すし)を食(た)べた。日本(にっぽん)で寿司(すし)を食(た)べました。
example.english: I ate sushi in Japan.

example.japanese: ひらがなとカタカナを覚(おぼ)えた。ひらがなとカタカナを覚(おぼ)えました。
example.english: I remembered hiragana and katakana.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)はリンクと別(わか)れた。彼女(かのじょ)はリンクと別(わか)れました。
example.english: She broke up with Link.

example.japanese: シャワーを浴(あ)びた。シャワーを浴(あ)びました。
example.english: I took a shower.

english_grammar.title: う-Verb (Past)
english_grammar.explanation: う - Verbs (past tense)
english_grammar.structure: Examples: 座る + った 歌う + った 打つ + った 歩く + いた 泳ぐ + いだ 死ぬ + んだ 飛ぶ + んだ 休む + んだ 話す + した Exceptions: 行く ￫ 行った する ￫ した くる ￫ きた 問う ￫ 問うた 請う ￫ 請うた
english_grammar.about: To make the past form of a う-Verb in Japanese, just like all other conjugations of う-Verbs, you will need to change the last kana, before adding the auxiliary verb た (casual), or ました (polite). This change in kana is a bit different to other conjugations of う-Verbs, so let's take a look at them for the casual form. ５キロ走(はし)った。５キロ走(はし)りました。I ran 5 kilometers. (Example of a verb ending in る) 新(あたら)しいペンを買(か)った。新(あたら)しいペンを買(か)いました。I bought a new pen. (Example of a verb ending in う) 昨日(きのう)は駅(えき)で５分(ふん)待(ま)った。昨日(きのう)は駅(えき)で５分(ふん)待(ま)ちました。I waited for 5 minutes at the station yesterday. (Example of a verb ending in つ) ノートに名前(なまえ)を書(か)いた。ノートに名前(なまえ)を書(か)きました。I wrote my name on the notebook. (Example of a verb ending in く) テイラーは池(いけ)で泳(およ)いだ。テイラーは池(いけ)で泳(およ)ぎました。Taylor swam in the lake. (Example of a verb ending in ぐ) 去年(きょねん)、ペットの金魚(きんぎょ)が死(し)んだ。去年(きょねん)、ペットの金魚(きんぎょ)が死(し)にました。My pet goldfish died last year. (Example of a verb ending in ぬ) 冷蔵庫(れいぞうこ)を台所(だいどころ)に運(はこ)んだ。冷蔵庫(れいぞうこ)を台所(だいどころ)に運(はこ)びました。I carried the refrigerator to the kitchen. (Example of a verb ending in ぶ) 庭(にわ)をフェンスで囲(かこ)んだ。庭(にわ)をフェンスで囲(かこ)みました。I surrounded my yard with a fence. (Example of a verb ending in む) 電気(でんき)を消(け)した。電気(でんき)を消(け)しました。I turned off the lights. (Example of a verb ending in す) As can be seen in these examples, the changes consist of った, いた, いだ, んだ, した (the same as the changes for て form, but using た instead). For the conjugations using だ in place of た, this is simply a sound change in the language that happened over the course of history, to make words easier/smoother to say. It is not the auxiliary verb だ.For the polite past form of う-Verbs, the change in sound is far more consistent. This only requires a change from the う sound, to the い sound within the same column (from う to い, or from く to き, for example). 新(あたら)しい漢字(かんじ)を習(なら)いました。I learned a new kanji. 車(くるま)が動(うご)きました。The car moved. When た is added to verbs (or any other word), it can have one of three possible meanings.Past: 過去(かこ) - Happened at some point in the past. (Did/Was)Completion: 完了(かんりょう) - An action that has finished 'happening'. (Done)Continuation: 存続(そんぞく) - A new state of something that is continuing. (Has been done) 昨日(きのう)、カラオケで歌(うた)を歌(うた)った。I sang a song at karaoke yesterday. (An example of past) 今(いま)、コーヒーを頼(たの)んだ。I ordered coffee (just) now. (An example of completion) 乗(の)った自転車(じてんしゃ)が壊(こわ)れた。The bike I rode broke, and is still broken. (An example of continuation) Caution With う-Verbs, there are a few verbs that are exceptions to the regular conjugation rules. Please check the structure guide for these.

example.japanese: 昨日(きのう)、本(ほん)を読(よ)んだ。昨日(きのう)、本(ほん)を読(よ)みました。
example.english: I read a book yesterday.

example.japanese: 牛乳(ぎゅうにゅう)を飲(の)んだ。牛乳(ぎゅうにゅう)を飲(の)みました。
example.english: I drank milk.

example.japanese: ロンドンへ飛(と)んだ。ロンドンへ飛(と)びました。
example.english: I flew to London.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)たちのチームは勝(か)った！私(わたし)たちのチームは勝(か)ちました！
example.english: Our team won!

example.japanese: メアリーは日本(にほん)に帰(かえ)った。メアリーは日本(にほん)に帰(かえ)りました。
example.english: Mary returned to Japan.

synonym.explanation: Ichidan Verbs
Godan Verbs
Will/Does/Do (not)
And, Then (linking events)
Was, Were (past tense)
Was doing ~

english_grammar.title: 好(す)き
english_grammar.explanation: Like, Fond of
english_grammar.structure: Noun + が + 好き + だ
english_grammar.about: 好(す)き, meaning 'to like', is one of the very common な-Adjectives in Japanese that is used in many different expressions. All な-Adjectives behave similarly to verbs, in that their form changes depending on what comes after them.For 好(す)き, it will be followed by either な, when acting as an adjective, だ, or the more polite です, when acting as a noun. This distinction is made depending on whether it is linked to another noun, or is independent. 私(わたし)はコンビニが好(す)きだ。I like convenience stores. (They are likable, to me) 彼(かれ)はサーフィンが好(す)きです。He likes surfing. (It has likability, to him) 私(わたし)が好(す)きなピザを食(た)べる。I eat the pizza that I like. (The pizza that is likable, to me) In the example with だ, 好(す)き is expressing that the thing is 'likable' (assertion). However, in the example with な, 好(す)き is expressing 'likability' as a quality of the noun it is attached to.Caution 好(す)き is considered quite a strong adjective in Japanese when it is directed towards people, so it may be interpreted as romantic interest. 大(だい)好(す)き is often translated as 'love'. 大(だい)好(す)きだよ！I love you!

example.japanese: 好(す)き？
example.english: Do you like (it)?

example.japanese: うん、好(す)きだ。
example.english: Yeah, I like (it).

example.japanese: 好(す)きな人(ひと)がいますか。
example.english: Is there someone that you like?

example.japanese: はい、山田(やまだ)さんが好(す)きです。
example.english: Yes, I like Yamada-san.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の家(いえ)が好(す)きですか。
example.english: Do you like my house?

synonym.explanation: Dislike, Not fond of

english_grammar.title: 嫌(きら)い
english_grammar.explanation: Dislike, Not fond of
english_grammar.structure: Noun + が + 嫌い 嫌い + な + Noun
english_grammar.attention: Despite ending in い, きらい is a な-Adjective
english_grammar.about: 嫌(きら)い, meaning 'to dislike', is one of the very common な-Adjectives in Japanese that is used in many different expressions. All な-Adjectives behave similarly to verbs, in that their form changes depending on what comes after them.For 嫌(きら)い, it will be followed by either な, when acting as an adjective, だ, or the more polite です, when acting as a noun. This distinction is made depending on whether it is linked to another noun, or is independent. それは嫌(きら)いだ。I don't like that. (That is dislikable) 私(わたし)はスポーツが嫌(きら)いです。I don't like sports. (They are dislikable, to me) 彼(かれ)の嫌(きら)いな食(た)べ物(もの)はピザです。The food he doesn't like is pizza. (The food that is disliked, by him) In the example with だ, 嫌(きら)い is expressing that the thing is 'dislikable' (assertion). However, in the example with な, 嫌(きら)い is expressing 'being disliked' as a quality of the noun it is attached to.In the same way that 好(す)き can often be partnered with 大(だい) to mean 'love', 嫌(きら)い can often be partnered with 大(だい) to mean 'hate'. 大(だい)嫌(きら)いな先輩(せんぱい)が来(く)る。The senpai I hate is coming. Caution Despite ending in い, 嫌(きら)い is one of the few words that is actually a な-Adjective, and needs to be memorized.

example.japanese: パイナップルが嫌(きら)い？
example.english: Do you dislike pineapple?

example.japanese: うん、大(だい)嫌(きら)いだ。
example.english: Yeah, I hate it.

example.japanese: 嫌(きら)いな 食(た)べ物(もの)がありますか。
example.english: Is there a food that you dislike?

example.japanese: はい、納豆(なっとう)が嫌(きら)いです。
example.english: Yes, I dislike natto.

example.japanese: 嫌(きら)いな色(いろ)はありません。
example.english: There is no color that I dislike.

synonym.explanation: Like, Fond of

english_grammar.title: のが好(す)き
english_grammar.explanation: Like doing, Love doing
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ の + が + 好き + だ
english_grammar.about: ～のが好(す)き is a common construction that is used in Japanese to express that you like/love doing something. This particular expression is used with the plain (dictionary) form of verbs only. 私(わたし)は映画(えいが)を見(み)るのが好(す)き。I like watching movies. 私(わたし)はプレゼントを貰(もら)うのが好(す)きです。I like to receive gifts. In these examples, we can see that there is no difference between Ichidan verbs and Godan verbs. Both will be used in their plain forms. In this expression, のが is performing the same function as in the regular のは or のが construction. This function is nominalization (turning a phrase into a noun). However, のは may not be used with this phrase, as が will always appear with adjectives.Caution If you want to express that you liked doing something (in the past), the verb will still remain in the plain form, but 好(す)き will change to past tense. 彼(かれ)は野球(やきゅう)をするのが好(す)きだった。He liked to play baseball. 息子(むすこ)は漢字(かんじ)を書(か)くのが好(す)きでした。My son used to like to write kanjis. This construction can also be used to ask questions about what other people like. This is done through the addition of か. 何(なに)をするのが好(す)きですか。What do you like to do? 映画(えいが)を見(み)るのが好(す)きですか？Do you like watching movies?

example.japanese: 私(わたし)はサッカーをするのが好(す)き。
example.english: I like playing soccer.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は本(ほん)を読(よ)むのが好(す)き。
example.english: I like reading books.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)はラーメンを食(た)べるのが好(す)きです。
example.english: I like eating ramen.

example.japanese: 犬(いぬ)と遊(あそ)ぶのが好(す)き。
example.english: I like playing with dogs.

example.japanese: 旅行(りょこう)に行(い)くのが好(す)きでしょう？
example.english: You like going on trips, don't you?

synonym.explanation: To be good at, Proficient
To be bad at, Poor at, Unskillful
Converting a verb into a noun

english_grammar.title: がある + (Noun)
english_grammar.explanation: Noun (B) that has Noun (A), Noun (B) with Noun (A)
english_grammar.structure: Noun + がある (1) + Noun (1) のある
english_grammar.about: In this expression, がある has the role of describing the noun that follows it. The description that it is giving is '(A) がある (B)' = '(B) has/with (A)'. This type of phrase is called a relative clause (something that describes a noun), and behaves similarly to an adjective. ピアノがあるレストラン。A restaurant with a piano. コンビニがあるビル。A building that has a convenience store. In English, a relative clause would require a pronoun such as 'who' 誰(だれ), 'which' どれ, 'that' それ・あれ, 'where' どこ. However, these types of words are not required in Japanese, and the noun will follow がある directly.Caution In a relative clause, because (A) is describing (B), (B) will be considered the 'main topic/subject'. This means that は cannot be used in place of が. However, の can be used instead of が, as showing a relationship between (A) and (B) is one of the main functions of の. 漫画(まんが)はある本屋(ほんや)。 A book store that has manga. (Unnatural, as it is impossible to tell whether manga is the only thing at one particular bookstore, or if manga is something that bookstores 'in general' have) 綺麗(きれい)な川(かわ)のある山(やま)。A mountain with a beautiful river. (Natural in Japanese, but less common than が)

example.japanese: ベッドがある部屋(へや)。
example.english: A room that has a bed.

example.japanese: たくさん休(やす)みがある５月(がつ)が好(す)き。
example.english: I like the month of May with its many holidays.

example.japanese: 綺麗(きれい)な池(いけ)がある公園(こうえん)。
example.english: A park with a beautiful pond.

example.japanese: 家(いえ)がある人(ひと)。
example.english: People who have a house.

example.japanese: 冷蔵庫(れいぞうこ)がある台所(だいどころ)。
example.english: A kitchen with a refrigerator.

synonym.explanation: To be, There is

english_grammar.title: くない
english_grammar.explanation: Not (adjective)
english_grammar.structure: ［い］Adjective［く］+ ない Examples: おもしろく + ない 新しく + ない
english_grammar.attention: い-Adjectives, whether positive or negative, cannot be used with だ
english_grammar.about: The negative form of い-Adjectives in Japanese is created by using the conjunctive form of the adjective, followed by ない. conjunctive form just means 'agglutinative', or 'conjunctive' in Japanese. For い-Adjectives, this conjunctive form is created by removing い, and replacing it with く. あなたは悪(わる)くない。You are not to blame. (Translates directly to, you are not bad.) 今日(きょう)は暑(あつ)くない。It is not hot today. The ない used with い-Adjectives is considered to be a different word to the ない used with verbs. When used with い-Adjectives, ない itself is also an い-Adjective. This means that it follows the same rules as regular い-Adjectives. Due to ません (the polite negative form) being an auxiliary verb, it cannot be conjugated with い-Adjectives in the same way as verbs. このお茶(ちゃ)は、温(ぬる)くません。This tea don't lukewarm. (Incorrect example, with incorrect English to match!) このお茶(ちゃ)は、温(ぬる)くありません。This tea is not lukewarm. (Natural Japanese) As can be seen here, you must first add the verb ある, and then conjugate it into it's negative form using the auxiliary verb ません. This is how the polite negative is created.Caution As with regular い-Adjectives, you cannot use だ after ない. です is acceptable to create a semi-polite form, but is best used in spoken language only.

example.japanese: 暑(あつ)くないです。[暑(あつ)い]
example.english: It is not hot.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)は寒(さむ)くない。[寒(さむ)い]
example.english: It is not cold today.

example.japanese: これは楽(たの)しくないです。[楽(たの)しい]
example.english: This is not fun.

example.japanese: 新(あたら)しくないコンピューター。[新(あたら)しい]
example.english: A computer that is not new.

example.japanese: それは安(やす)くないです。[安(やす)い]
example.english: That is not cheap.

english_grammar.title: で
english_grammar.explanation: With, By (using)
english_grammar.structure: Noun + で
english_grammar.about: で is a particle that has several different uses in Japanese. At its core, it is always used to highlight something that is 'required' to perform some sort of action/reach some kind of goal. One of these uses relates to 'things'. This comes across as 'by' or 'with' in English. 車(くるま)で空港(くうこう)へ行(い)く。I go to the airport by car. (Required to reach a goal) 電車(でんしゃ)で行(い)く。I go by train. (Required to reach a goal) In these sentences, the item is considered essential for the action to be performed. While other items may be used, で simply highlights the one that was chosen.で is also used when groups of people perform actions together, this is something that many people learning Japanese have trouble with initially (because と may also be used as 'with' for people). However, the use of で is actually the same as this by/with, meaning that the speaker considers the group as the tool used for performing the action. みんなでレストランに行(い)く。I go to the restaurant with everyone. (Being with everyone is what allows/gives purpose to the action) 来年(らいねん)は皆(みんな)でハワイに行(い)く。I will go to Hawaii with everyone next year. (Being with everyone is what allows/gives purpose to the action) The difference between と and で as 'with', is that で is used when everyone in the group has the same objective/end goal. と is used when each person is performing the action toward each other, not toward an external objective. 家族(かぞく)全員(ぜんいん)で沖縄(おきなわ)へ行(い)く。I will go to Okinawa with everyone in my family. (Being with everyone is what allows/gives purpose to the action) お母(かあ)さんとご飯(はん)を食(た)べる。I eat with my mom. (Being together is the objective, eating is just what is happening while being together)

example.japanese: バスで行(い)く。
example.english: I go by bus.

example.japanese: バスで学校(がっこう)に行(い)く。
example.english: I go to school by bus.

example.japanese: 自転車(じてんしゃ)でいいです。
example.english: By bicycle is good.

example.japanese: 自転車(じてんしゃ)で。
example.english: By bicycle.

example.japanese: 電車(でんしゃ)で来(き)ますか。
example.english: Are you coming by train?

synonym.explanation: At, In
by, with, on, by means of, ~ing with

english_grammar.title: ので
english_grammar.explanation: Because, So, Since, The reason being
english_grammar.structure: Verb + ので + Phrase ［い］Adjective + ので + Phrase ［な］Adjective + な + ので + Phrase Noun + な + ので + Phrase
english_grammar.about: ので is a Japanese grammar structure called a conjunction particle. This means that it connects two parts of a sentence 'logically'. The connection that ので makes between (A), and (B), is similar to から, meaning that it is often translated as 'because', or 'since'.When used after な-Adjectives or nouns, な must precede ので. 今日(きょう)は日曜日(にちようび)なので休(やす)みです。Since it's Sunday today, It's a day off. 友達(ともだち)が家(いえ)に来(く)るので、部屋(へや)の掃除(そうじ)をする。Since my friend is coming to my house, I will clean my room. 景色(けしき)が綺麗(きれい)なので、写真(しゃしん)を撮(と)ります。Since the scenery is beautiful, I will take a picture. 今日(きょう)は寒(さむ)いので、コートを着(き)ます。Since it is cold today, I will wear a coat. When used as 'since', ので puts emphasis on the sentence as a whole, or on the effects caused. It then examines those reasons objectively (in a way that is based on facts, rather than feelings or opinions). から tends to be more subjective, and can sound much more vague when used as 'because'. 私(わたし)は弱(よわ)いので、ジムへ行(い)きます。I go to the gym because I am weak. (Being that I am weak) 野菜(やさい)が嫌(きら)いだから、食(た)べません。I don't eat vegetables because I don't like them. (From that vegetables are disliked) We can see here that から is not quite as strong as ので. This relates back to the base meaning of から being 'from', rather than 'because'.Caution ので can sometimes be seen as んで, which is a more casual variation. Also, unlike many grammar points that connect to verbs, ので may be used with the ます form. This is something that is unique to conjunction particles. 今(いま)テストがあるんで、後(あと)で電話(でんわ)します。Because I have a test now, I will call you later. 明日(あした)はお客(きゃく)が来(き)ますので、掃除(そうじ)をします。Since a guest is coming tomorrow, I am going to clean.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は寿司(すし) が好(す)きではないので、食(た)べない 。
example.english: I don’t like sushi, so I don’t eat it.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)は時間(じかん)がないので、明日(あした)に漢字(かんじ)を教(おし)えます。
example.english: Because we don’t have time today, I will teach you kanji tomorrow.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)は先生(せんせい)が休(やす)みなので、授業(じゅぎょう)がなくなった。
example.english: Since the teacher has the day off today, classes were cancelled.

example.japanese: 土曜日(どようび)なので、旅行(りょこう)に行(い)きたい。
example.english: Because it is Saturday, I want to go on a trip.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)は一月(いちがつ)二十日(はつか)なので、彼(かれ)の誕生日(たんじょうび)です。
example.english: Since today is January 20th, it is his birthday.

synonym.explanation: Because, Since
because, the reason is, that is because
because, the reason is

synonym.text: ものですから・もので
synonym.explanation: because, my excuse is, my explanation is
because, cause
and, giving reasons

english_grammar.title: から
english_grammar.explanation: Because, Since
english_grammar.structure: Verb + から ［い］Adjective + から ［な］Adjective + だから Noun + だ + から
english_grammar.about: から can have several different meanings in Japanese, depending on which part of the sentence it is in, and what comes before/after it. It is often translated as 'because', or 'since'. In these cases, it just means 'Because of (A), (B)'. 昨日(きのう)、アイスクリームを沢山(たくさん)食(た)べたから、お腹(なか)が痛(いた)いです。Since I ate so much ice cream yesterday, my stomach hurts. (From that I ate so much ice cream) 彼女(かのじょ)は優(やさ)しいから、好(す)きです。Because she is nice, I like her. (From that she is nice) から may be used with almost any type of word, but when the nuance is 'because', it will require だ before it after a noun or な-Adjective. 大(おお)きい会社(かいしゃ)だから、人(ひと)が沢山(たくさん)いる。Because it is a big company, there are a lot of workers. (From that it is a big company) スマホは便利(べんり)だから、人気(にんき)がある。Since smartphones are useful, they are popular. (From that they are useful) Despite having several different nuances, it may be easier to think of から as meaning 'from' in all situations, as that is the base nuance.From (A as a reason), (B) = Because/SinceFrom (A as a location), (B) = FromFun Factから is a special type of particle in Japanese called a case marking particle. These are particles that describe the relationship that (A) and (B) exist in. We will learn more about these soon!

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は犬(いぬ)が好(す)きですから。
example.english: Because I like dogs.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は毎日(まいにち)勉強(べんきょう)したから、昨日(きのう)のテストは簡単(かんたん) でした。
example.english: Because I studied every day, yesterday’s test was easy.

example.japanese: 明日(あした)は月曜日(げつようび)だから、仕事(しごと)に行(い)く。
example.english: Because tomorrow is Monday, I will go to work.

example.japanese: 学生(がくせい)がいるから、学校(がっこう)があるだろう。
example.english: Because there are students, there is a school, right?

example.japanese: スポーツをしたから、暑(あつ)いです。
example.english: Because I played sports, I am hot.

synonym.explanation: because, the reason is
because, cause
Because, So, Since, The reason being

synonym.text: ものですから・もので
synonym.explanation: because, my excuse is, my explanation is
because, the reason is, that is because
emphasized because, precisely because
therefore・thus, as a result
and, giving reasons

english_grammar.title: から
english_grammar.explanation: From
english_grammar.structure: Starting Point + から
english_grammar.about: から can have several different meanings in Japanese, depending on which part of the sentence it is in, and what comes before/after it. It is often translated as 'from'. In these cases, it just means 'with (A) as a starting location, (B)'. In this grammar construction, から comes directly after the place that is considered the starting point. 彼女(かのじょ)はモロッコから来(き)ました。She came from Morocco. 空港(くうこう)から車(くるま)で来(き)ました。I came from the airport by car. This form of から is the closest to the 'base' meaning of the word in Japanese, as the nuance of から can almost always be thought of as meaning 'from' in some way. Caution This form of から does not require だ when used after nouns or な-Adjectives, as that would change the meaning to 'because'.

example.japanese: 駅(えき)からバスで来(き)た。
example.english: I came from the station by bus.

example.japanese: アメリカから来(き)ました。
example.english: I came from America.

example.japanese: この靴(くつ)はお母(かあ)さんからです。
example.english: These shoes are from my mom.

example.japanese: 学校(がっこう)から、パーティーに行(い)く。
example.english: To go to the party from school.

example.japanese: 仕事(しごと)から帰(かえ)る。
example.english: To return home from work.

synonym.explanation: once...is done, once...happens, after doing

english_grammar.title: けど
english_grammar.explanation: But, However
english_grammar.structure: Verb + けど ［い］Adjective + けど ［な］Adjective + だ + けど Noun + だ + けど
english_grammar.attention: More casual than が
english_grammar.about: けど is one of the common conjunction particles in Japanese. These are particles that function by connecting the (A) and (B) parts of a sentence. けど works very similarly to が, in that it highlights 'while thinking about (A), (B)'. This means that けど will often come across as 'but' in English. 毎日(まいにち)泳(およ)ぐけど、今日(きょう)は泳(およ)がない。I swim everyday, but I will not swim today. 北海道(ほっかいどう)は寒(さむい)いけど、綺麗(きれい)。Hokkaido is cold, but pretty. 田舎(いなか)は静(しず)かだけど、不便(ふべん)だ。The countryside is quiet, but inconvenient. これはステーキだけど、冷(つめ)たい。This is a steak, but it is cold. As can be seen from these examples, just like many other grammatical constructions, だ will be required when using けど after a な-Adjective, or a noun.けど is just a modern (casual) version of けれども. Please see below for a list of the most casual, to the most formal variations.Casual - けど - けども - けれど - けれども - が - Formal 私(わたし)は肉(にく)を食(た)べるけども、野菜(やさい)も好(す)き。I eat meat, but I also like vegetables. 私(わたし)は水(みず)が怖(こわ)いけれど、泳(およ)ぐのが好(す)きです。I am afraid of the water, but I like to swim. お酒(さけ)は飲(の)むけれども、ワインは飲(の)まないです。I drink alcoholic beverages, but I don't drink wine. 沖縄(おきなわ)は綺麗(きれい)ですが、暑(あつ)いです。Okinawa is beautiful, but hot. Caution The phrase after けど will often be omitted if it is obvious, or the speaker does not want to say it. パソコンはないけど。（大丈夫(だいじょうぶ)？）I don't have a computer… (but is that okay?)

example.japanese: 便利(べんり)だけど、高(たか)い。
example.english: It is convenient, but expensive.

example.japanese: その赤(あか)いTシャツが好(す)きだけど、青(あお)いTシャツを買(か)う。
example.english: I like that red T-shirt, but I will buy the blue one.

example.japanese: 毎日(まいにち)シャワーを浴(あ)びるけど、今日(きょう)は浴(あ)びない 。
example.english: I take a shower every day, but today I will not.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)がトムだけど・・・
example.english: I am Tom... (but)

example.japanese: お金(かね)があるけど、買(か)いません。
example.english: I have money, but I won't buy [it].

synonym.explanation: But, However
But, Still, However, Nevertheless
But, Although
even so, however, even though, but

english_grammar.title: が
english_grammar.explanation: But, However
english_grammar.structure: Verb + が ［い］Adjective + が ［な］Adjective + だ + が Noun + だ + が
english_grammar.attention: が can sometimes mean something closer to 'and', or a comma that connects clauses
english_grammar.about: As a particle, が has several different uses in Japanese. However, each of these different uses share a common theme. That theme expresses 'highlighting (A) as important, (B)'. In this use, が comes across as 'but', or 'however' in English.This nuance of が is used directly after any form of verb or い-Adjective, but requires one of the conjugations of だ or です before it when used with a noun or な-Adjective. 毎日(まいにち)走(はし)るが、運動(うんどう)はきらい。I run everyday, but I don't like exercise. このカレーは辛(から)いが、美味(おい)しい。This curry is spicy, but delicious. 車(くるま)は便利(べんり)だが、危(あぶ)ない。Cars are convenient, but dangerous. お金(かね)は大切(たいせつ)だが、時間(じかん)も大切(たいせつ)だ。Money is important, but time is also important. From these examples, we can see that が is simply highlighting that 'while (A) is important, there is extra information'. が with the meaning of 'but' is considered to be very formal, this is due to it sounding quite direct in asserting that there is extra information.Caution Sometimes a statement will end with が. In these cases it just means that more information exists, but it is obvious, so it does not need to be said. まあ、綺麗(きれい)ですが。Well, it is pretty, but… (I still don't like it)

example.japanese: 難(むずか)しいですが、頑張(がんば)ります。
example.english: It is difficult, but I will do my best.

example.japanese: 寒(さむ)いですが、外(そと)へ行(い)きます。
example.english: It’s cold, but I will go outside.

example.japanese: ロイさんの携帯(けいたい)は古(ふる)いですが、速(はや)いです。
example.english: Roy's cellphone is old, but it is fast.

example.japanese: すみませんが、この漢字(かんじ)の意味(いみ)は何(なん)ですか。
example.english: I’m sorry, but what is the meaning of this kanji?

example.japanese: 綺麗(きれい)ですが、危(あぶ)ないです。
example.english: It is beautiful but dangerous.

synonym.explanation: But, However
even so, however, even though, but
But, Although
But, Still, However, Nevertheless
although, but, even though
even though, and yet, despite

english_grammar.title: る-Verb (Negative-Past)
english_grammar.explanation: る - Verbs (negative-past tense)
english_grammar.structure: Examples: ​​食べる + なかった ​​見る + なかった ​​寝る + なかった
english_grammar.attention: When a past negative sentence has a connection with the present, for example, something was expected to happen but has not happened for the moment, the verb[て] + いません construction is used instead
english_grammar.about: In order to form the negative past form of る-Verbs, you will need to remove the る, and then follow it with the auxiliary verb ない (or ます), conjugated into their past forms. This will either be なかった (casual), or ませんでした (polite). 今朝(けさ)ニュースを見(み)なかった。I didn't see the news this morning. ゴミを捨(す)てませんでした。I did not throw the trash away. A semi-polite form may also be used. This is constructed by using なかった, and then simply adding です. This form is not grammatically correct, but is so common that most sources (and native speakers) would consider it correct. ライトが消(き)えなかったです。The light did not turn off.

example.japanese: 寿司(すし)を食(た)べなかった。寿司(すし)を食(た)べなかったです。寿司(すし)を食(た)べませんでした。
example.english: I didn’t eat sushi.

example.japanese: テレビを見(み)なかった。テレビを見(み)なかったです。テレビを見(み)ませんでした。
example.english: I didn’t watch TV.

example.japanese: お金(かね)を借(か)りなかった。お金(かね)を借(か)りなかったです。お金(かね)を借(か)りませんでした。
example.english: I did not borrow money.

example.japanese: 早(はや)く起(お)きなかった。早(はや)く起(お)きなかったです。早(はや)く起(お)きませんでした。
example.english: I didn’t wake up early.

example.japanese: これは教(おし)えなかった。これは教(おし)えなかったです。これは教(おし)えませんでした。
example.english: I didn’t tell you this.

english_grammar.title: う-Verb (Negative-Past)
english_grammar.explanation: う - Verbs (negative-past tense)
english_grammar.structure: 座る + らなかった 歌う + わなかった 歩く + かなかった 話す + さなかった 打つ + たなかった 死ぬ + ななかった 飛ぶ + ばなかった 休む + まなかった 泳ぐ + がなかった Exceptions: ある ￫ なかった
english_grammar.attention: When a past negative sentence has a connection with the present, for example, something was expected to happen but has not happened for the moment, the verb[て] + いません construction is used instead
english_grammar.about: In order to make the negative past form of う-Verbs, you will need to change the last kana of the verb into the あ sound kana from the same column (or わ if the original kana was う). After this, the あ sound kana will be followed by ない (or ます), conjugated into their past forms. This will either be なかった (casual), or ませんでした (polite).For the ませんでした (polite) form, rather than the final kana changing to the あ sound kana from the same column, it will change to the い sound kana from the same column.The negative past form is used to convey that something 'did not happen', or 'was not'. 私(わたし)は公園(こうえん)で遊(あそ)ばなかった。I did not play at the park. あなたの車(くるま)は洗(あら)わなかった。I did not wash your car. そこに置(お)きませんでした。I did not place it there. そこには本(ほん)がありませんでした。The book was not over there. A semi-polite form may also be used. This is constructed by using なかった, and then simply adding です. This form is not grammatically correct, but is so common that most sources (and native speakers) would consider it correct. 彼(かれ)とは話(はな)さなかったです。I did not talk with him. (Notice the use of と and は together. Double particle usage is common when presenting a topic in Japanese) ある is an exception to the regular conjugation rules of う-Verbs. The casual past-negative is not あらなかった, but simply なかった. However, the polite past-negative form conjugates in the same way as would be expected for う-Verbs. ありませんでした. 紙(かみ)がなかった。There was no paper. (Casual Japanese past tense) 紙(かみ)がありませんでした。There was no paper. (Formal Japanese past tense)

example.japanese: 昨日(きのう)、行(い)かなかった。昨日(きのう)、行(い)かなかったです。昨日(きのう)、行(い)きませんでした。
example.english: I didn’t go yesterday.

example.japanese: よく眠(ねむ)らなかった。よく眠(ねむ)らなかったです。よく眠(ねむ)りませんでした。
example.english: I didn't sleep well.

example.japanese: はなこさんは話(はな)さなかった。はなこさんは話(はな)さなかったです。はなこさんは話(はな)しませんでした。
example.english: Hanako didn’t talk.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)は事故(じこ)で死(し)ななかった！彼女(かのじょ)は事故(じこ)で死(し)ななかったです！彼女(かのじょ)は事故(じこ)で死(し)にませんでした！
example.english: She didn’t die in the accident!

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)は帰(かえ)らなかった。今日(きょう)は帰(かえ)らなかったです。今日(きょう)は帰(かえ)りませんでした。
example.english: I did not go home today.

english_grammar.title: ～て (Conjunction)
english_grammar.explanation: And, Then (linking events)
english_grammar.structure: Examples: ［る1］Verb ￫ 見る + て ［る5］Verb ￫ 座る + って ［う］Verb ￫ 歌う + って ［つ］Verb ￫ 打つ + って ［く］Verb ￫ 歩く + いて ［ぐ］Verb ￫ 泳ぐ + いで ［ぬ］Verb ￫ 死ぬ + んで ［ぶ］Verb ￫ 飛ぶ + んで ［む］Verb ￫ 休む + んで ［す］Verb ￫ 話す + して Exceptions: 行く ￫ 行って する ￫ して くる ￫ きて 問う ￫ 問うて 請う ￫ 請うて
english_grammar.attention: ている is often shortened to てる. This applies to all tenses, including てる, てて, てた, and even てます
english_grammar.about: In Japanese, て is a very important conjunction particle that can be used with many different structures. When it is partnered with a verb, it has special conjugation rules, depending on whether it is being added to a る-Verb or a う-Verb. In the case of う-Verbs, it also depends on what the preceding kana is.The most common translation in any situation is just 'and' or 'then', due to (B) being highlighted as something that happens/happened after (A). 山(やま)を登(のぼ)って休(やす)む。To climb a mountain, then rest. (To climb a mountain, and rest) 食(た)べて寝(ね)る。To eat, then sleep. (To eat, and sleep) In these examples, we can see that て basically means '(A) て (B)' = '(A) happened, then (B)'. However, this is only when it is linked to another verb.Sometimes the て form appears as で. This is a change that happened throughout the course of history, in order to make sentences flow more smoothly. Despite this, there is no difference in meaning between て and で as a vocal change. 本(ほん)を読(よ)んで返(かえ)す。To read a book, then return it. (て appearing as で) 遊(あそ)んで帰(かえ)る。To play, then go home. (て appearing as で) The easiest way to identify whether to use て or で is by looking at the preceding kana. If the plain (dictionary) form of the verb finishes in ぐ, ぬ, ぶ, or む, then で will be used. る-Verbs never use で.Caution There are several irregular verbs when it comes to て form conjugation. Let's look at an example of each one. 学校(がっこう)に行(い)って勉強(べんきょう)をする。I go to school, then study. (行(い)く's conjugation with て) ダイエットをして痩(や)せる。To go on a diet, then lose weight. (する's conjugation with て) 公園(こうえん)に来(き)て遊(あそ)ぶ。To come to the park, then play. (来(く)る's conjugation with て) 答(こた)えを問(と)うて書(か)く。To enquire about the answer, then write it down. (問(と)う's conjugation with て) 許可(きょか)を請(こ)うて実行(じっこう)する。To get permission, then act out. (請(こ)う's conjugation with て) Apart from these 5 verbs, the rules for て form conjugation are 100% consistent.

example.japanese: 食(た)べる → 食(た)べて
example.english: To eat

example.japanese: 洗(あら)う → 洗(あら)って
example.english: To wash

example.japanese: 返(かえ)す → 返(かえ)して
example.english: To return [an object]

example.japanese: 歩(ある)く → 歩(ある)いて
example.english: To walk

example.japanese: 泳(およ)ぐ → 泳(およ)いで
example.english: To swim

english_grammar.title: ～ている ①
english_grammar.explanation: Is, Am, Are (~ing)
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］+ いる Verb［て］+ る
english_grammar.attention: ている is often shortened to てる. This applies to all tenses, including てる, てて, てた, and even てます
english_grammar.about: ている is a construction used in Japanese to convey that someone or something is existing in a constant state of 'doing' the verb that comes before て. In English, depending on the verb, this can be translated as 'is (A)', 'am (A), or 'are (A)~ing'. The expression is made by adding いる to the て form of either る-Verbs, or う-Verbs. シャンプーは何(なに)を使(つか)っているの？What shampoo are you using? 今(いま)ラーメンを食(た)べています。I am eating ramen now. Due to いる being one of the verbs for 'existing' in Japanese, the ている form means something closer to 'continuing to exist in a specific state', rather than (A)~ing in English. This is why verbs like 死(し)ぬ, and 知(し)る, appear as the ている form in Japanese, when they would appear as the past form in English. お前(まえ)はもう死(し)んでいる。You are already dead. この人(ひと)誰(だれ)か知(し)っている？Do you know who this is?

example.japanese: 何(なに)をしている？
example.english: What are you doing?

example.japanese: 寿司(すし)を食(た)べている。
example.english: I am eating sushi.

example.japanese: 寿司(すし)を食(た)べています。
example.english: I am eating sushi.

example.japanese: 今(いま)、勉強(べんきょう)していないよ。
example.english: I am not studying now.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は図書館(としょかん)で日本語(にほんご)を勉強(べんきょう)しているだろう。
example.english: He is studying Japanese at the library, right?

english_grammar.title: へ
english_grammar.explanation: To, Toward
english_grammar.structure: Noun + へ
english_grammar.about: へ is a particle used when describing a place that someone or something is 'moving toward', or 'in contact with'. In many cases, the particles に and へ are interchangeable, but there is a slight difference in meaning. へ focuses more on the distance/effort required to get between (A) and (B), while に focuses more on the connection between (A) and (B). へ always comes after the noun signifying the destination. 私(わたし)はフランスへ行(い)く。I will go to France. 明日(あした)東京(とうきょう)に行(い)く。I will go to Tokyo tomorrow. In these examples, while they may seem the same at first glance, へ shows that there is a space between (A) and (B), while に puts the emphasis solely on the destination. This is why common expressions such as 'city/country name へようこそ' sound very polite. It is like saying 'Welcome, and we acknowledge your journey/effort to get here'. 大阪(おおさか)へようこそ！Welcome to Osaka! BPRニュースへようこそ。Welcome to BPR News. In the TV-show example, this commonly means 'thank you for your effort to watch this particular show, out of all the ones you could have chosen'.

example.japanese: 大阪(おおさか)へようこそ。
example.english: Welcome to Osaka.

example.japanese: ここへ？
example.english: To here?

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は電車(でんしゃ)で大阪(おおさか)へ行(い)く。
example.english: I go to Osaka by train.

example.japanese: 神戸(こうべ)へ行(い)く。
example.english: To go to Kobe.

example.japanese: 家(いえ)へ帰(かえ)る。
example.english: To return to one's house.

synonym.explanation: To go to, To head toward

synonym.text: に向かって・に向けて
synonym.explanation: towards, to face, to head to

english_grammar.title: ～に行(い)く
english_grammar.explanation: To go ~, To go in order to ~
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ に + 行く
english_grammar.about: に行(い)く is a grammar construction that is used when someone is going somewhere for the purpose of doing (A). (A) representing the verb that comes before に行(い)く. As with other uses of に, this particle is highlighting an end point or goal of 'going'. 釣(つ)りに行(い)く。To go fishing. (Fishing is the purpose/goal of going) 今(いま)からトレーニングをしに行(い)きます。I am going to go workout now. (Working out is the purpose/goal of going) This grammar point is regularly translated as 'to go in order to (A)'.If you have already 'gone' somewhere for the purpose of doing something, then you would use '(A) に来(き)た', while at the location. さっきあなたの友達(ともだち)が宿題(しゅくだい)を渡(わた)しに来(き)たよ。Your friend came to hand in their homework earlier.

example.japanese: ラーメンを食(た)べに行(い)く。
example.english: To go eat ramen.

example.japanese: サッカーをしに行(い)く。
example.english: To go play soccer.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)を勉強(べんきょう)しに行(い)きます。
example.english: I will go study Japanese.

example.japanese: 公園(こうえん)へ遊(あそ)びに行(い)った。
example.english: I went to play at the park.

example.japanese: 本(ほん)を買(か)いに行(い)きます。
example.english: I will go buy a book.

synonym.explanation: To go to, To head toward
To ~ and go, To go on, To start

english_grammar.title: 誰(だれ)
english_grammar.explanation: Who
english_grammar.structure: だれ Demonstrative
english_grammar.about: 誰(だれ) is a substitute noun that is used in Japanese to describe unknown people. Due to Japanese particles behaving in very specific ways, 誰(だれ) will be translated differently depending on the particle that follows it.誰(だれ)が・誰(だれ)で・誰(だれ)に・誰(だれ)を (who), 誰(だれ)の (whose), 誰(だれ)か (somebody), 誰(だれ)も (any/everybody). 誰(だれ)がくる？Who is coming? お前(まえ)は誰(だれ)で行(い)く？Who are you going with? これは誰(だれ)のノートですか。Whose notebook is this? 部屋(へや)に誰(だれ)かがいる。Somebody is in my room. これは誰(だれ)に送(おく)る？To whom are you going to send this? 誰(だれ)を連(つ)れて来(き)ますか？Who will you bring with you? 誰(だれ)も優(やさ)しいね。Everybody is nice, aren't they? Caution Depending on the style of polite speech, there are several different words that will be used to indicate an unknown person. どなた is used in honorific language, while どちらさま is used in polite speech.

example.japanese: 誰(だれ)ですか。
example.english: Who is it?

example.japanese: 誰(だれ)がいますか。
example.english: Who is there?

example.japanese: 誰(だれ)がしますか。
example.english: Who will do it?

example.japanese: これは誰(だれ)のパソコンですか。
example.english: Whose computer is this?

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は誰(だれ)でしょう。
example.english: I wonder who he is.

english_grammar.title: い-Adjective + です (Predicate)
english_grammar.explanation: い-Adjective (predicate)
english_grammar.structure: Examples: かわいい 新しい 寒い
english_grammar.about: A predicate is a word that describes the topic/subject of a sentence. The Japanese equivalent of this is a 述語(じゅつご), which literally means 'statement word'. As a predicate, い-Adjectives can appear by themselves (when the word they are describing does not need to be stated), or they may be used at the end of a sentence. 丸(まる)い。It's round. 地球(ちきゅう)は丸(まる)い。The earth is round. When there are no other words apart from the adjective itself, it comes across similar to 'It's cute', or 'It's hot', and similar expressions in English. We just have to guess what the 'it' is from context.In many sentences, either は or が could be used to mark the word/words that the predicate is describing. However, which one sounds more natural will depend on many factors. In general, if you are specifically pointing out something as being different from other things in the same category, が will be used. このお風呂(ふろ)は熱(あつ)い。This bath is hot. (In general, it is hot) このお風呂(ふろ)が熱(あつ)い。This bath is hot. (Compared to other cooler baths) In this example, が is distinguishing this specific bath as having a unique level of hotness compared to others (maybe the water system is broken and only boiling water comes out). は would sound unnatural in this type of sentence, as it is not the 'normal' state of the bath.Fun FactAll い-Adjectives are words of Japanese origin.

example.japanese: 暑(あつ)い。暑(あつ)いです。
example.english: It is hot.

example.japanese: 寒(さむ)い。寒(さむ)いです。
example.english: It is cold.

example.japanese: これは楽(たの)しい。これは楽(たの)しいです。
example.english: This is fun.

example.japanese: 猫(ねこ)はかわいい。猫(ねこ)はかわいいです。
example.english: Cats are cute.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の家(いえ)は近(ちか)い。私(わたし)の家(いえ)は近(ちか)いです。
example.english: My house is near (by).

english_grammar.title: な-Adjective + だ (Predicate)
english_grammar.explanation: な-Adjective (predicate)
english_grammar.structure: ［な］Adjective + (だ) Examples: 静か + だ 元気 + だ
english_grammar.about: A predicate is a word that describes the topic/subject of a sentence. The Japanese equivalent of this is a 述語(じゅつご), which literally means 'statement word'. As a predicate, な-Adjectives can appear by themselves (when the word they are describing does not need to be stated), or they may be used at the end of a sentence.It is important to remember that all な-Adjectives can also function as nouns, and therefore tend to sound more like a noun than an adjective, when used as a predicate. 素敵(すてき)。It's wonderful. 彼氏(かれし)は素敵(すてき)です。My boyfriend is lovely. When there are no other words apart from the adjective itself, it comes across similarly to 'It's pretty', or 'It's hated', and similar expressions in English. We just have to guess what the 'it' is from context.Caution Unlike い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives change form depending on where they are in the sentence. At the end of a sentence, they will always be followed by だ, or です (except in casual conversation where だ is omitted). However, when used before the word they are describing, they will always be followed by な. Hence the name な-Adjectives.In many sentences, either は or が could be used to mark the word/words that the predicate is describing. Which one sounds more natural will depend on many factors. In general, if you are specifically pointing out something as being different from other things in the same category, が will be used. 有名(ゆうめい)な駅(えき)は汚(きたな)いです。Popular stations are dirty. (In general) この有名(ゆうめい)な駅(えき)が汚(きたな)いです。This popular station is dirty. (Compared to other popular stations) In this example, が is distinguishing a specific station as having a unique level of dirtiness compared to others. は would sound unnatural in this type of sentence.Fun FactMost な-Adjectives are words of foreign (Chinese/English) origin.

example.japanese: 夜(よる)の海(うみ)は静(しず)かだ。夜(よる)の海(うみ)は静(しず)かです。
example.english: The night sea is quiet.

example.japanese: さいきさんは親切(しんせつ)だ。さいきさんは親切(しんせつ)です。
example.english: Saiki is kind.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は静(しず)かだ。彼(かれ)は静(しず)かです。
example.english: He is quiet.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は暇(ひま)だ。私(わたし)は暇(ひま)です。
example.english: I am free.

example.japanese: 海(うみ)が綺麗(きれい)だ。海(うみ)が綺麗(きれい)です。
example.english: The sea is beautiful.

english_grammar.title: だった・でした
english_grammar.explanation: Was, Were (past tense)
english_grammar.structure: Noun + だった ［な］Adjective + だった
english_grammar.attention: い-Adjectives cannot be used with だった・でした
english_grammar.about: In order to say that something 'was' a certain way in Japanese, you will need to use だった (casual) or でした (polite) attached to the end of a noun or な-Adjective. This is simply a combination of two auxiliary verbs, だ (or です when polite) with た. For だった, we will need to add った to the base form of だ. For です, す will change to し before adding た. あの電車(でんしゃ)は静(しず)かだった。That train was quiet. 富士山(ふじさん)は綺麗(きれい)でした。Mt. Fuji was beautiful. Caution The past form of い-Adjectives cannot be linked with だった or でした, as they have their own set of conjugation rules.

example.japanese: 綺麗(きれい) だった。
example.english: It was beautiful.

example.japanese: トムだった。
example.english: It was Tom.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の車(くるま)の色(いろ)はピンクでした。
example.english: My car was pink.

example.japanese: それは、昨日(きのう)でした。
example.english: That was yesterday.

example.japanese: 猫(ねこ)が大(だい)好(す)きだった。
example.english: I really liked cats. | Cats were loved by me.

synonym.explanation: う - Verbs (past tense)
To be, Is
To be, Is

english_grammar.title: じゃない
english_grammar.explanation: Is not, Isn't
english_grammar.structure: ［な］Adjective + では(1) + ない Noun + では(1) + ない (1)じゃ
english_grammar.attention: Cannot be used with, い-Adjectives
english_grammar.about: じゃない is the casual form of ではない. では is regularly contracted to じゃ in Japanese, so is worth remembering as its own structure. じゃない (casual), or ではない (semi-polite) are the structures used for creating the negative form of nouns and な-Adjectives.These structures are simply added to the base form of the noun or な-Adjective. これは食(た)べ物(もの)じゃない。This isn't food. この携帯(けいたい)は便利(べんり)じゃない。This cell phone is not useful. じゃ and では can also be used with the negative ます form of ある, to create the polite variant. それは飲(の)み物(もの)ではありません。That is not a drink. あなたの部屋(へや)は綺麗(きれい)ではありません。Your room is not clean. ない is sometimes said/written as ね or ねえ. However, this is considered very casual, or even a bit rough. Accordingly, it is best avoided in most conversations. 俺(おれ)は馬鹿(ばか)じゃねえよ。I'm not stupid. Caution じゃない is used very frequently to ask questions. This is similar to じゃないか, a grammar point covered in another lesson. However, the nuance difference is that じゃない as a question is a little bit more blunt, like 'isn't it?' in English. On the other hand, じゃないか is more like 'don't you think?'. これは無理(むり)じゃない？This is impossible, isn't it? (More direct statement) これは無理(むり)じゃないか？Don't you think this is impossible? (More direct question) When じゃない is used as a question, it will usually be obvious, due to a rising tone.

example.japanese: 犬(いぬ)じゃない。
example.english: It is not a dog.

example.japanese: 先生(せんせい)じゃない。
example.english: I am not a teacher.

example.japanese: 牛肉(ぎゅうにく)じゃないです。
example.english: It is not beef.

example.japanese: この絵(え)は、綺麗(きれい)じゃありません。
example.english: This painting is not beautiful.

example.japanese: 好(す)きな スポーツは、サッカーではありません。
example.english: The sport I like is not soccer.

synonym.explanation: Will/Does/Do (not)
isn't it?, is it not?
Was not, Wasn't

english_grammar.title: じゃなかった
english_grammar.explanation: Was not, Wasn't
english_grammar.structure: ［な］Adjective + では(1) + なかった Noun + では(1) + なかった (1)じゃ
english_grammar.about: じゃなかった is the casual form of ではなかった. では itself is regularly contracted to じゃ in Japanese, so is worth remembering as its own structure. じゃなかった (casual), or ではなかった (semi-polite) are the structures used for creating the negative-past form of nouns and な-Adjectives. These structures are simply added to the base form of the noun or な-Adjective. あそこは病院(びょういん)じゃなかった。That place over there wasn't a hospital. この車(くるま)は便利(べんり)じゃなかった。This car wasn't useful. じゃ and では may also be used with the negative-past ます form of ある, to create the polite variant. あれは猫(ねこ)ではありませんでした。That over there was not a cat. あの人(ひと)は綺麗(きれい)ではありませんでした。That person was not pretty.

example.japanese: りんごじゃなかった。
example.english: It was not an apple.

example.japanese: 先生(せんせい)じゃなかった。
example.english: They were not a teacher.

example.japanese: 晩(ばん)ごはんが好(す)きではなかった。
example.english: Dinner was not liked by me.

example.japanese: 朝(あさ)ごはんを作(つく)ったのは、お父(とう)さんじゃありませんでした。
example.english: The person who made breakfast was not (your) father.

example.japanese: その動物(どうぶつ)は、牛(うし)じゃなかった。
example.english: That animal was not a cow.

synonym.explanation: Is not, Isn't

english_grammar.title: くなかった
english_grammar.explanation: Was not, Wasn't (adjective)
english_grammar.structure: ［い］Adjective［く］+ なかった Examples: おもしろく + なかった 新しく + なかった
english_grammar.about: In order to create the negative past form of い-Adjectives, we will need to use the conjugation form. The conjugation form of an い-Adjective is simply created by removing the い, and replacing it with く. く is then followed by ない (conjugated into its past form なかった), or あります (conjugated into its past negative form ありませんでした). 私(わたし)は太(ふと)くなかったよ！I was not fat! 北海道(ほっかいどう)は暑(あつ)くありませんでした。Hokkaido was not hot. The polite negative (past) form requires use of the う - Verb, ある. This is not a unique rule for the negative past, but actually the correct way that all く-form conjugations of い-Adjectives should be constructed. However, in modern Japanese, it is not considered necessary. Instead, the semi-polite form is often used.The semi-polite form is constructed by using なかった, and then simply adding です. この車(くるま)は高(たか)くなかったです。This car was not expensive.

example.japanese: コーヒーは熱(あつ)くなかったです。[熱(あつ)い]
example.english: The coffee was not hot.

example.japanese: それは、安(やす)くありませんでした。[安(やす)い]
example.english: That was not cheap.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の犬(いぬ)は強(つよ)くなかったです。[強(つよ)い]
example.english: My dog was not strong.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の姉(あね)の家(いえ)が高(たか)くなかったです。[高(たか)い]
example.english: My (older) sister's house was not expensive.

example.japanese: 漫画(まんが)を読(よ)むのは難(むずか)しくなかった。[難(むずか)しい]
example.english: Reading manga was not difficult.

english_grammar.title: と
english_grammar.explanation: Quotation
english_grammar.structure: (Quotation) Phrase + と + Verb(*) Verb + と + Verb(*) ［い］Adjective + と + Verb(*) ［な］Adjective + (だ) + と + Verb(*) Noun + (だ) + と + Verb(*) (*) Verbs like 言う、聞く、思う、考える、仮定する and the like are used
english_grammar.about: One of the regular functions of と in Japanese is as a quotation particle. This use is called 引用(いんよう) in Japanese, which basically translates as 'reference', or 'citation'. This way of using と can appear after almost any type of word (or phrase), but requires だ when used after nouns or な-Adjectives. 先生(せんせい)が「危(あぶ)ない！」と叫(さけ)んだ。The teacher yelled, 'Watch out!' 木村(きむら)さんが「3キロ歩(ある)いた」と言(い)った。Kimura san said, 'I walked 3 km.' あれは猫(ねこ)だと思(おも)う。I think that is a cat. 富士山(ふじさん)は綺麗(きれい)だと思(おも)う？Do you think that Mt. Fuji is beautiful? と as a quotation marker will almost always be followed by a verb that shows what type of 'quote' it is. This can be words like 言(い)う, 思(おも)う, 考(かんが)える, 聞(き)く, etc. However, at the end of a sentence, the verb will often be omitted. 生徒(せいと)が先生(せんせい)に「何(なん)で？」と。The students asked the teacher, 'Why?' As with other instances of the particle と being used, this use simply expresses the relationship between (A) 'what was communicated', and (B) 'how it was communicated'.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はとても親切(しんせつ)だと聞(き)きました。
example.english: I heard that he is very friendly.

example.japanese: メモに「私(わたし)は今(いま)から学校(がっこう)に行(い)きます」と書(か)いた。
example.english: I wrote, 'I am going to school now' on a note.

example.japanese: 「彼(かれ)はここに来(き)ますか」と聞(き)いた。
example.english: I asked, 'Is he coming here?'

example.japanese: 「晩(ばん)ごはんを作(つく)った」と言(い)った。
example.english: I said, 'I made dinner'.

example.japanese: 「重(おも)いですか」と聞(き)きました。
example.english: He asked, 'Is it heavy?'

synonym.explanation: Casual quotation
you could say, you might say

english_grammar.title: って
english_grammar.explanation: Casual quotation
english_grammar.structure: Quote + って + Verb
english_grammar.attention: Can replace と
english_grammar.about: って is a casual variation of the と particle that is used for quoting something. This use is called 引用(いんよう) in Japanese, which basically translates to 'reference', or 'citation'. って is almost exclusively used after direct quotations, and will be followed by a verb indicating what type of communication was used. 言(い)った, 思(おも)った, 聞(き)いた, for example. 「行(い)ってきます」ってママが言(い)った。Mom said, 'I'll be back soon'. 「それは危(あぶ)ないよ」って先生(せんせい)が言(い)った。The teacher said, 'That is dangerous'. Just like with と, the verb that comes after って is frequently omitted. This is even more true for って, as many things are omitted in casual language. トムは「今日(きょう)休(やす)む」って。Tom said he was going to take the day off today. Caution Although often heard, due to って being very casual, it can be considered unnatural to use in sentences that also use the です or ます polite structures. However, if the conversation is formal but friendly (like between a senpai and a kouhai), most people would consider it normal.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は「彼女(かのじょ)は綺麗(きれい)な人(ひと)だ」って言(い)った。
example.english: He said, “She is a beautiful person”.

example.japanese: 先生(せんせい)は「おはよう！」って言(い)った。
example.english: The teacher said, “Good morning!”

example.japanese: 「明日(あした)は雨(あめ)が降(ふ)りますか」って聞(き)いた。
example.english: I asked, “Is it going to rain tomorrow?”

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は「晩(ばん)ごはんを捨(す)てた」って言(い)った。
example.english: He said, “I threw away my dinner”.

example.japanese: 「何時(なんじ)からですか」って聞(き)いた。
example.english: I asked, “What time is it from?”

synonym.explanation: Quotation
you could say, you might say
I heard that, He/She said that

english_grammar.title: Verb (Non-Past)
english_grammar.explanation: (non-past)
english_grammar.structure: Examples: 食べる 洗う
english_grammar.about: In Japanese, the non-past form of verbs is identical to the dictionary form/casual form. Unlike English, this form of verbs is able to be used in several cases where conjugation/different constructions would be required in English. 嫁(よめ)は毎晩(まいばん)映画(えいが)を見(み)ます。My wife watches movies every night. 俺(おれ)は明日(あした)の昼(ひる)にピザを食(た)べます。I will eat pizza tomorrow during lunch. 子供(こども)は遊(あそ)ぶ。Kids play. In these examples, we can see the three forms of English verbs that are covered by the single non-past form of Japanese verbs. These are verbs ending with -s (sees, hears, goes), verbs requiring will (will see, will hear, will go), and verbs that do not require conjugation (see, hear, go).Due to this one form of verbs covering several different nuances, it is often important to use expressions of time in the sentence, so that the meaning becomes clear. テイラーは毎朝(まいあさ)走(はし)る。Taylor runs every morning. カホは8時(じ)に寝(ね)る。Kaho will sleep at 8 p.m. If there is no word distinguishing 'time' in the sentence, the nuance will be that of stating a general fact about something that is true at any time. 赤(あか)ちゃんは泣(な)きます。Babies cry. From all of these examples, we can see that the non-past form can be thought of as expressing one of three basic ideas. General facts, habits, or future events.Caution In books, the non-past form will regularly be used for events that are happening 'in the moment', but without any time word being used. In these cases it is usually obvious from context that it is happening then and there.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は９時(じ)にバナナを食(た)べる。私(わたし)は９時(じ)にバナナを食(た)べます。
example.english: I will eat a banana at 9 o’clock. (future event)

example.japanese: ヴァンパイアは血(ち)を飲(の)む。ヴァンパイアは血(ち)を飲(の)みます。
example.english: Vampires drink blood. (general truth)

example.japanese: たなかさんは毎週(まいしゅう)車(くるま)を洗(あら)う。たなかさんは毎週(まいしゅう)車(くるま)を洗(あら)います。
example.english: Tanaka-san washes the car every week. (habit)

example.japanese: 生徒(せいと)は習(なら)う。生徒(せいと)は習(なら)います。
example.english: Students take lessons. (general truth)

example.japanese: 明日(あした)、焼(や)きそばを食(た)べる。明日(あした)、焼(や)きそばを食(た)べます。
example.english: Tomorrow I will eat fried noodles. (future event)

english_grammar.title: ～た + (Noun)
english_grammar.explanation: Verb Modified Noun, relative clause
english_grammar.structure: Verb［た］(*) + Noun Verb［ている］(*) + Noun (*) Only verbs in short (plain) form can modify nouns. Do not use polite-ます.
english_grammar.about: In Japanese, if you want to describe something or someone that is performing an action, one of the ways you can do this is through a relative clause. A relative clause is when two phrases are joined into one sentence, rather than two individual sentences. The た (plain-past), or ている (continuous) form of verbs are usually used. たかしさんは東京(とうきょう)に住(す)んだ男(おとこ)。Takashi-san is a man that lived in Tokyo. 貴方(あなた)が食(た)べたハンバーガ。The hamburger that you ate. 田中(たなか)さんが飲(の)んでいるコーヒー。The coffee that Tanaka-san is drinking. 道(みち)で寝(ね)ている犬(いぬ)。A dog that is sleeping on the road. る-Verbs and う-Verbs follow their regular conjugation rules when making a relative clause. In the first example, we can see that 'Takashi-san is a man that lives in Tokyo', is one sentence, rather than 'Takashi-san is a man. He lives in Tokyo'. In English, words like 'that', and 'which' are used to create a relative clause. However, seeing as though these words do not exist in Japanese, the first phrase is simply attached to the noun.Caution The ます (polite) forms of verbs may not be used when making a relative clause. たかしさんは東京(とうきょう)に住(す)んでいました男(おとこ)。Takashi-san is a man who lived in tokyo. (Unnatural Japanese)

example.japanese: たくさん勉強(べんきょう)をした生徒(せいと)。
example.english: A student who studied a lot.

example.japanese: 日本(にほん)に住(す)んでいる外国(がいこく)人(じん)。
example.english: A foreigner living in Japan.

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)から借(か)りたペン。
example.english: A pen borrowed from a friend.

example.japanese: 洗(あら)った服(ふく)。
example.english: Washed clothes.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)が作(つく)った椅子(いす)。
example.english: A chair I made.

english_grammar.title: の
english_grammar.explanation: Possessive use (Noun omission)
english_grammar.structure: Noun + の + (previously mentioned noun) Note: The previously mentioned noun is dropped.
english_grammar.about: A common pattern in Japanese is referring back to a noun that has already been mentioned, without actually repeating it. This is achieved through the use of the particle の, in a similar way to its standard possessive use. The noun that would usually follow の is dropped, as it has either been said earlier in the sentence, or is understood clearly from context. この本(ほん)はたけしさんのです。This book is Takeshi-san's (book). そのペンは誰(だれ)の？あなたの？That pen, whose (pen) is it? Is it your (pen)? In these examples, it would also be grammatically correct to use the same noun following の, but as can be seen in the English translation, it results in unnecessary repetition. This is called word stacking/redundant words (重(かさ)ね言葉(ことば)) in Japanese, and is considered a poor writing/speech habit. Despite this, it is important to know that this の is exactly the same as the possessive の (with the following word simply being left out).In the following sentence, we can see another common use of の that translates similarly to 'one' in English, when referring to non-specific things. あの車(くるま)、あなたが乗(の)っているのですか。That car, was it the car (one) you drove? ('Car' repeated, when の 'the one' should have been used instead) From this, it is clear that the repeated noun is not needed. Japanese is a language that avoids repeating words in many situations. This example shows noun replacement, rather than noun omission, another common use of の which we will cover in another lesson.

example.japanese: その帽子(ぼうし)は娘(むすめ)の(帽子(ぼうし))です。
example.english: That hat is my daughter's (hat).

example.japanese: あのパソコンは君(きみ)の(パソコン)でしょう？
example.english: That computer is your (computer) right?

example.japanese: 木綿(もめん)のスカーフは私(わたし)の(スカーフ)です。
example.english: The cotton scarf is my (scarf).

example.japanese: 「この本(ほん)は誰(だれ)の(本(ほん))？」「先週(せんしゅう)に来(き)たお客(きゃく)さんの(本(ほん))。」
example.english: 'Whose book is this (book)?''It's the customer's (who came in last week) (book).'

example.japanese: この駐車場(ちゅうしゃじょう)もあなたの会社(かいしゃ)の(駐車場(ちゅうしゃじょう))ですか。
example.english: This parking lot is also your company's (parking lot)?

english_grammar.title: な (Prohibitive)
english_grammar.explanation: Do not, Don't (prohibitive)
english_grammar.structure: Verb + な
english_grammar.about: な is classified as a sentence ending particle in Japanese. When attached to the base (dictionary) form of a verb, it has the nuance of strongly demanding that someone 'not' do something. 危険(きけん)！触(さわ)るな!Danger! Don't touch! 「家(いえ)の中(なか)で走(はし)るな！」とお母(かあ)さんが言(い)った。My mother said, “Don't run in the house!”

example.japanese: 行(い)くな。
example.english: Don’t go.

example.japanese: ここでサッカーをするな。
example.english: Don’t play soccer here.

example.japanese: 泣(な)くな。
example.english: Don’t cry.

example.japanese: 一人(ひとり)でするな。
example.english: Don’t do it alone.

example.japanese: 「これは不味(まず)い！」って言(い)うな。
example.english: Don’t say, 'This tastes bad!'

synonym.explanation: Please don't (polite request)
Without doing, Not ~ and ~

antonym.explanation: (please) do!, ask to・beg to, [order somebody to do something]

english_grammar.title: だけ
english_grammar.explanation: Only, Just
english_grammar.structure: Verb + だけ ［い］Adjective + だけ ［な］Adjective + な + だけ Noun + だけ
english_grammar.about: だけ is used in Japanese in a similar way to 'only' or 'just' in English. The basic meaning of this word is that 'while there are/were several possibilities, only (A) is true/was chosen'. だけ is used by attaching it to the base (dictionary) form of any word, except for な-Adjectives, which require な when being used adjectivally. 今夜(こんや)は食(た)べるだけ、何(なに)も飲(の)まない。Tonight I'm only going to eat, I won't drink anything. 私(わたし)はブロッコリーだけがきらい。I only dislike broccoli. あの人(ひと)は有名(ゆうめい)なだけ。That person is just famous. (Fame is all they have) このスープは辛(から)いだけ。This soup is just spicy. Due to な-Adjectives being able to be used as either a noun or an adjective, the meaning of a sentence will be different depending on whether だけ is used with the noun form, or the adjective form. 私(わたし)の彼女(かのじょ)は綺麗(きれい)なだけです。My girlfriend is just beautiful. (There are no other distinguishing features) 富士山は綺麗(きれい)だけじゃない。As for Mt. Fuji, beauty is not all there is. (There are other distinguishing features) Basically this difference just highlights whether something is being discussed in a measurable way (an adjective), or an immeasurable way (a noun).

example.japanese: 一人(ひとり)だけです。
example.english: Only one person.

example.japanese: それだけです。
example.english: Only that.

example.japanese: サッカーだけが好(す)き。
example.english: I only like soccer.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)だけ行(い)きます。
example.english: Only I am going.

example.japanese: その映画(えいが)は長(なが)いだけ。
example.english: That movie is just long.

synonym.explanation: there's only, nothing but
To emphasize '~only', nothing but
Just by, Just with
not only… but also
just, only, nothing but
only, just, since
not only...but, not just...but, what is more

english_grammar.title: どれ
english_grammar.explanation: Which (of three or more)
english_grammar.structure: Noun + は + どれ どれ + が(1) + Verb どれ + が + ［い］Adjective どれ + が + ［な］Adjective + だ どれ + が + Noun + だ (1) を
english_grammar.attention: どれ follows a noun, どの precedes a noun
english_grammar.about: どれ is from the same family of words as これ, それ, and あれ. These words are called こそあど言葉(ことば) in Japanese. Unlike the other 3, which all point to a specific thing, words starting with ど are designed for enquiring about something unknown. どれ can roughly be translated as 'which' in English, and is used for enquiring about a group (of 3 or more things). どれが飛(と)びますか。Which one of these flies? どれが新(あたら)しいですか？Which one is new? どれが綺麗(きれい)ですか？Which one is beautiful? どれが弟(おとうと)ですか？Which one is your brother? From these examples, we can see that the particle が is often used with どれ, especially when preceding questions. However, when どれ follows a noun, は will be used. あなたの車(くるま)はどれ？Which one is your car? When there are only two choices to select between, どちら + の, or どっち + の will be used instead of どれ. This is a habit that has become part of the language over time, and was not originally how these words were used. どちらのケーキを食(た)べますか？Which cake would you like to eat? (Out of these two choices) どっちのテストが難しい？Which test was hard? (Out of these two choices)

example.japanese: どれがいいですか。
example.english: Which is good?

example.japanese: どれでもいいです。
example.english: Whichever is fine.

example.japanese: どれを選(えら)びますか。
example.english: Which will you choose?

example.japanese: どれが好(す)きですか。
example.english: Which do you like?

example.japanese: どれでも好(す)きだ。
example.english: I like whichever。

synonym.explanation: This
That
That (over there)
Which (of three or more), What (kind)

english_grammar.title: どこ
english_grammar.explanation: Where
english_grammar.structure: Demonstrative
english_grammar.about: どこ is one of the forms of the どれ family of words used to enquire about unknown things. In this case it asks about a place. Just like どれ represents 'which', どこ represents 'which place', or simply 'where'. 明日(あした)はどこに行(い)く？Where do you want to go tomorrow? 牛乳(ぎゅうにゅう)はどこにありますか？Where is the milk located? Caution どこ should not be confused with どっち, a similar word which is also sometimes translated as 'where'. どっち focuses more on the direction that one is/is going, where どこ focuses purely on 'which place'. どっち？右(みぎ)？左(ひだり)?Which way? Right? Left? (Focuses on the direction of movement) ここはどこですか？Where is this place? (Focuses on the location)

example.japanese: どこに行(い)きますか。
example.english: Where are you going?

example.japanese: すみませんが、この本(ほん)はどこにありますか。
example.english: Excuse me, but where can I find this book?

example.japanese: ここはどこ？
example.english: Where is here?

example.japanese: どこがいい？
example.english: Where is good?

example.japanese: 美味(おい)しいレストランはどこですか。
example.english: Where is a delicious restaurant?

synonym.explanation: Here, This place
There, That place
Over there

english_grammar.title: どの
english_grammar.explanation: Which (of three or more), What (kind)
english_grammar.structure: Demonstrative, どの + Noun
english_grammar.attention: どの precedes a noun, どれ follows a noun
english_grammar.about: どの is classified as a 'pre-noun adjectival' in Japanese. These are a special type of word that do not conjugate, which means that they will always appear in the same form. どの comes from the same family of words as どれ and どこ, and is used for asking about 'which' thing someone will choose. どの飲(の)み物(もの)がいい？Which drink would you like? どの色(いろ)でもいいよ。Whatever color is okay. (Literally 'even any of whichever color is good') In these examples, we can see that どの may be used to ask a question, or it may also be used in a similar way to 'whatever', or 'whichever' in English.Caution どの is only used when there are 3 or more possible choices, and どっち（の）・どちら（の） will be used when there are only 2 possible choices. 赤(あか)か青(あお)、どっちがいい？Do you prefer red or blue? どの色(いろ)が好(す)き？What color do you like? In the first example, the speaker is asking specifically about 2 options 'red or blue', so どっち will be used. However, in the second example, since the answer could be any color, どの will be used instead.
