example.japanese: どの寿司屋(すしや)がいいですか。
example.english: Which sushi restaurant is good?

example.japanese: どのレストランに行(い)く？
example.english: Which restaurant will you go to?

example.japanese: どのブランドを選(えら)びますか。
example.english: Which brand will you choose?

example.japanese: どのパソコンが好(す)きですか。
example.english: Which computer do you like?

example.japanese: どのお茶(ちゃ)を飲(の)みますか。
example.english: Which tea will you drink?

synonym.explanation: That (over there)
Which (of three or more)
That
This

english_grammar.title: ～ている ②
english_grammar.explanation: State of being, Has (have) done
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］+ いる Verb［て］+ る(*) (*) The い can be omitted in casual language.
english_grammar.attention: ている is often shortened to てる. This applies to all tenses, including てる, てて, てた, and even てます
english_grammar.about: As mentioned in our first ている lesson, this construction is used to convey that someone or something is existing in a constant state of 'doing' the verb that comes before て. Here we will take a closer look at several of the verbs that will be used with ている, to express 'existing in a state of (A) having been done'. クラスは始(はじ)まっている。The class has already started. (Existing in the state of having started) お母(かあ)さんは今(いま)買(か)い物(もの)に行(い)っています。My mom went out to go shopping. (Existing in the state of having gone) あの犬(いぬ)は死(し)んでいるだろう、悲(かな)しいね 。That dog over there is probably dead… How upsetting. (Existing in the state of having died) 先生(せんせい)がめちゃ怒(おこ)っている。My teacher is very angry. (Existing in the state of having gotten angry) All of these verbs would appear as the past form in English, after the initial thing has 'started', 'come', 'died', or 'gotten angry'. However, this is not the case in Japanese. In Japanese, once something is angry, it exists in the state of being angry, once something has started, it exists in the state of being ongoing, once something dies, it exists in the state of being dead, and so on.Fun FactOne of the easiest ways that you can tell whether a verb will use the ている form, or the past form, is to think about whether it can happen twice. Something cannot 'start' twice, so it will use ている. Something cannot die twice, so it will use ている, etc. This does not work with every verb, but will help with over 90% of the verbs that require this form. ピアノが落(お)ちている。The piano has fallen. (Existing in the state of having fallen) Something has fallen and is already on the ground, so it cannot fall again. ている will be used.

example.japanese: バスは今(いま)大阪(おおさか)に来(き)ています。
example.english: The bus is in Osaka now. (The bus has come to Osaka and is there now.)

example.japanese: パーティーは始(はじ)まっている。
example.english: The party has begun. (The party has begun and is still going on.)

example.japanese: 電車(でんしゃ)は東京(とうきょう)に行(い)っています。
example.english: The train is in Tokyo. (The train has gone to Tokyo and is there)

example.japanese: ななさんのバナナは腐(くさ)っています。
example.english: Nana’s banana is rotten. (Nana’s banana went bad and is rotten.)

example.japanese: 喫茶店(きっさてん)はもう閉(し)まっています。
example.english: The coffee shop is already closed. (The coffee shop has been closed and stays closed.)

synonym.explanation: Is, Am, Are (~ing)
Has/have done, Is ~ing (repetition)
And, Then (linking events)
to continue

english_grammar.title: ～てから
english_grammar.explanation: once...is done, once...happens, after doing
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］+ から
english_grammar.about: In order to specifically express that one thing happens/begins to happen after another thing, てから will be used. This expression is regularly translated as 'once (A) happens, (B)', or 'after doing (A), (B)'. おやつを食(た)べてから、勉強(べんきょう)を始(はじ)める。I will start studying once I eat some snacks. 洗濯(せんたく)をしてから、出(で)かける。After doing the laundry, I will go out. The difference between てから, and the regular て form followed by another verb, is that てから puts more emphasis on the (A) action 'enabling' the (B) action.Caution から can come after almost any form of verb. てから is the only form that translates as 'after (A), (B)'. たから, and るから will translate closer to 'because', or 'since'. 今夜(こんや)は勉強(べんきょう)をするから、遊(あそ)ばない。I won't hang out tonight, because I will be studying. 牛丼(ぎゅうどん)の大盛(おおもり)を食(た)べたから、お腹(なか)いっぱい。I am full because I ate a large serving of gyudon. (After having eaten a large serving of gyudon) 晩(ばん)ご飯(はん)を食(た)べてから、洗(あら)い物(もの)をする。After I eat, I will do the dishes.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)の勉強(べんきょう)をしてから、日本(にほん)に行(い)きます。
example.english: Once I study Japanese, I will go to Japan.

example.japanese: 日本(にほん)に行(い)ってから、日本語(にほんご)の勉強(べんきょう)をします。
example.english: After going to Japan, I will study Japanese.

example.japanese: この本(ほん)を読(よ)んでから、返(かえ)す。
example.english: Once I've read this book, I will return it.

example.japanese: 暇(ひま)になってから、ゆっくり旅行(りょこう)に行(い)きたい。
example.english: After becoming free, I want to take a nice, long trip.

example.japanese: 雪(ゆき)が降(ふ)ってから、スキーに行(い)く。
example.english: Once it snows, I will go skiing.

synonym.explanation: After, Later
When, From when, Just when, If
after, upon
From
for the first time, not until, only after, only when, only because
And, Then (linking events)

english_grammar.title: ～て (Sequence)
english_grammar.explanation: And, And then, After that (sequence)
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］+ (Action) Phrase
english_grammar.about: The て form of a verb, followed by another verb phrase is often translated to 'then', or 'and then', and is how Japanese lists sequences of events that happen one after another. ショッピングセンターに行(い)って、買(か)い物(もの)をします。To go to the mall and then shop. パンを買(か)って、食(た)べた。I bought some bread, then ate it. Caution This grammar construction is used for listing things that happen in order, for example 'I did (A), then (B), then (C)'. Other grammar structures will need to be used if you would like to talk about things that happen/happened in no particular order. For example たり～たりする, which will appear in a sentence like 'I did things like (C), and (A), oh, and (B)!'

example.japanese: 晩(ばん)ご飯(はん)を食(た)べて歯(は)を磨(みが)いた。
example.english: I ate dinner and brushed my teeth.

example.japanese: ともこは鍵(かぎ)をかけて出(で)かけました。
example.english: Tomoko locked up the house and left.

example.japanese: 明日(あした)は９時(じ)に起(お)きて、朝(あさ)ごはんを食(た)べて買(か)い物(もの)に行(い)きます。
example.english: Tomorrow I will wake up at 9 (and), eat breakfast, and go shopping.

example.japanese: 「東京(とうきょう)に行(い)って何(なに)をしたの？」
example.english: 'What did you do after you went to Tokyo?'['You went to Tokyo, and then what did you do?']

example.japanese: ひとみさんのお母(かあ)さんに会(あ)って一緒(いっしょ)に戻(もど)りました。
example.english: I met Hitomi's mother, and we went back together.

synonym.explanation: Non-sequence, and, but (contrast), parallel action/state
And, Then (linking events)
And... (conjunctive)

english_grammar.title: もう
english_grammar.explanation: Already, Anymore
english_grammar.structure: もう + (Past) Phrase もう + (Negative) Phrase
english_grammar.about: In English, もう is regularly translated to 'already', or 'anymore', depending on if it is used in a positive-past (already), or negative (anymore) sentence. The reason that Japanese only requires one word for both of these nuances is due to もう literally meaning 'something has unexpectedly ended'. 朝(あさ)ごはんはもう食(た)べた。I already ate breakfast. (Although you probably didn't expect it, I have already eaten breakfast) もうお金(かね)がない。I don't have any more money. (Although you probably didn't expect it, I have no money) From these sentences we can see that もう can be translated in each case as the following.(Past) - Although expected to not be done, it is. 'Already', in English.(Negative) - Although expected to still be going, it isn't. 'Anymore', in English.This is the opposite of まだ, which means 'something is unexpectedly still going'.もう may also be used to ask questions. This is when the speaker thinks that something 'might' have ended, but wants to confirm. もうデザートを食(た)べた？Did you already eat dessert? Fun Factもう is often used simply as an expression of exasperation (giving up on arguing), to show that someone has already reached the point of not wanting to continue. あ～もう無理(むり)。Ugh, that's enough. (I've had enough, I'm done arguing/continuing)

example.japanese: もう学校(がっこう)に行(い)きましたか。
example.english: Did you already go to school?

example.japanese: もうその本(ほん)を読(よ)んだ。
example.english: I have already read that book.

example.japanese: もうコーヒーを作(つく)りました。
example.english: I already made coffee.

example.japanese: もうしました。
example.english: I already did it.

example.japanese: もう帰(かえ)った。
example.english: They already went home.

synonym.explanation: Already, too late
Still, Not yet

english_grammar.title: まだ
english_grammar.explanation: Still, Not yet
english_grammar.structure: まだ + Verb［ている］ まだ + Noun + が + いる まだ + Noun + が + ある
english_grammar.about: In English, まだ is regularly translated as 'still', or 'not yet', depending on if it is used in a positive non-past, or negative sentence. The reason that Japanese only requires one word for both of these nuances is due to まだ literally meaning 'something is unexpectedly still going'. まだ走(はし)っている。I am still running. (Although you probably didn't expect it, I am still running) まだ親(おや)がいるからゲームできない。My parents are still here, so I can't play games. (Although you probably didn't expect it, my parents are still here) まだ宿題(しゅくだい)があるから、遊(あそ)ばない。I still have homework, so I can't hang out yet. (Although you probably didn't expect it, I still have homework) From these sentences, we can see that まだ may be translated in each case as the following.(Non-past) - Although (A) is expected to not be there/happening, it is. 'Still' in English.(ている) - Although (A) is expected to not still be going, it is. 'Not yet' in English. The negative form of this will be discussed more in まだ～ていません.This is the opposite of もう, which means 'something is unexpectedly finished'.まだ may also be used to ask questions. This is when the speaker thinks that something 'might' be continuing, but wants or needs to confirm. まだ日本語(にほんご)の勉強(べんきょう)しているの？Are you still studying Japanese? Fun Factまだ is often used simply as an expression indicating that something is 'lacking', or 'not yet' where it needs to be. In these cases まだ is frequently repeated as まだまだ, for emphasis. まだまだだねー。You are not ready for this. (You still STILL are not ready)

example.japanese: 冷蔵庫(れいぞうこ)にケーキがまだあります。
example.english: There is still cake in the fridge.

example.japanese: まだ食(た)べていますか。
example.english: Are you still eating!?

example.japanese: お前(まえ)にはまだ早(はや)いよ。
example.english: 'It is still too early for you.'

example.japanese: まだ雨(あめ)が降(ふ)っているの？
example.english: It’s still raining?

example.japanese: まだ足(あし)が痛(いた)い。
example.english: My foot still hurts.

synonym.explanation: Still haven't done (something)
Already, Anymore

english_grammar.title: まだ～ていません
english_grammar.explanation: Still haven't done (something)
english_grammar.structure: まだ + Verb［て］+ いない
english_grammar.about: まだ～ていません is a regular expression that combines the adverb まだ, with the conjunction particle て. The て form will be followed by the verb いる in its negative いません (polite), or いない (casual) form. This expression has the meaning of 'to still not have done (A)'. その映画(えいが)はまだ見(み)ていません。I still haven't watched that movie. (I continue to not have seen that movie) それはまだ生徒(せいと)に教(おし)えていません。I have not taught my student that yet. (I continue to 'not' have taught that to my student) From these examples, it can be seen that this grammatical structure follows the regular rules of conjugation for the て form.

example.japanese: まだ食(た)べていません。
example.english: I still haven’t eaten.

example.japanese: その本(ほん)をまだ読(よ)んでいません。
example.english: I still haven’t read that book.

example.japanese: まだ勉強(べんきょう)していません。
example.english: I still haven’t studied.

example.japanese: この漢字(かんじ)をまだ習(なら)っていません。
example.english: I still haven’t learned this kanji.

example.japanese: 学校(がっこう)にまだ行(い)っていません。
example.english: I still haven’t gone to school.

synonym.explanation: Still, Not yet
try to・attempt to, to be about to

english_grammar.title: ～てもいい
english_grammar.explanation: It is alright/fine/okay even if, Can/may, ~ is also okay
english_grammar.structure: ［い］Adjective［く］+ ても + いい ［な］Adjective + でも + いい Noun + でも + いい
english_grammar.about: Noun, い-Adjective, or な-Adjective + てもいい is a construction in Japanese that is used to express that something is 'okay', or 'alright'. It is also frequently used as a question to ask if you 'can', or 'may' do something. 電車(でんしゃ)でもいい。I am fine even if it is by train. (It does not need to be by car) お茶(ちゃ)冷(つめ)たくてもいい？Is it okay even if the tea is cold? (Would you prefer I heat it?) 肉(にく)が好(す)きでもいい。It is okay even if you like meat. (I won't force you to eat something vegetarian) As can be seen, with い-Adjectives, we will need to use the conjugation form. This is created by removing the い and then replacing it with く.This phrase is also regularly used without the も, but is considered a bit more direct/casual in those cases. It is best to remove the も only when talking to people that you know well.てもいい is an expression that literally means て (noun, etc) も (also) いい (is good).Similarly to the てもいい grammar point that is used with verbs, this variant may also be used as a question. To do this, you simply need to follow てもいい with ですか, or the more casual の. 焼(や)きそばでもいいですか？Is it okay even if it is yakisoba? これ食(た)べてもいいの？Is it okay if we eat this? (Is this one that is okay to eat?)

example.japanese: 高(たか)くてもいい。
example.english: It is fine (even) if it’s expensive.

example.japanese: 何(なん)でもいいです。
example.english: Anything is fine.

example.japanese: 誰(だれ)でもいい。
example.english: Anyone is fine.

example.japanese: 水曜日(すいようび)でもいいですか。
example.english: Is it fine (even) if it is (on) Wednesday?

example.japanese: 冷(つめ)たくてもいい。
example.english: It is fine (even) if it is chilled.

synonym.explanation: It's okay to, It's alright to, Can/may
it doesn't matter if, I don't mind
even if, even though

english_grammar.title: たい
english_grammar.explanation: Want to do
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ たい Verb［ます］+ たくない Verb［ます］+ た かった Verb［ます］+ たくなかった
english_grammar.attention: The object of desire can take either the を or が particle
english_grammar.about: たい is an auxiliary verb that is used to express things that you would like to do (want). To use たい, it needs to be added to the same conjugation base form of a verb that ます would be attached to. 今夜(こんや)はピザが食(た)べたい。Tonight, I want to eat pizza. プロの歌手(かしゅ)と歌(うた)いたい。I want to sing with a professional singer. When using たい, the thing that is 'wanted' can either be marked with を, or が. The difference in nuance is that something marked with が is considered to be wanted more. たい is conjugated in the same way as い-Adjectives, meaning that the negative, past, or past-negative forms may also be used. 虫(むし)は食(た)べたくない。I don't want to eat insects. 警察官(けいさつかん)になりたかった。I wanted to become a police officer. 昔(むかし)は先生(せんせい)になりたくなかった。In the past, I did not want to become a teacher. たい is only used for expressing things that 'you' want, or repeating information/asking questions about what other people want. It may not be used to make guesses about what other people 'may' want, unless asking them directly. 何(なに)が食(た)べたい?What do you want to eat? オレンジジュースを飲(の)みたかったの？Did you want to drink orange juice? Caution たい is not used to tell other people that you want them to do something. This is done with ～てほしい. あなたはご飯(はん)を作(つく)りたい。As for you, I want to make dinner. (This can never mean 'I want you to make dinner for me', and is a fairly unnatural sentence) Caution たい is not usually used when giving invitations (asking someone if they want to do something with you). In these cases ～ませんか is far more natural. アカネも行(い)きたい？Akane, do you want to go too? (Sounds more like a question than an invitation)

example.japanese: 日本(にほん)に行(い)きたい。
example.english: I want to go to Japan.

example.japanese: 来年(らいねん)日本(にほん)に行(い)きたい。
example.english: Next year, I want to go to Japan.

example.japanese: 早(はや)く食(た)べたい。
example.english: I want to eat soon.

example.japanese: サッカーをしたいです。
example.english: I want to play soccer.

example.japanese: 文法(ぶんぽう)を勉強(べんきょう)したいです。
example.english: I want to study grammar.

synonym.explanation: I want you to
To want something, To be in need of
To want to (third person)
To feel, To think, To act as if, To want, To desire

english_grammar.title: たり～たりする
english_grammar.explanation: Things like ~ and ~
english_grammar.structure: Verb［た］り + （Verb［た］り） + する Verb［た］り + ［する］Verb（したり） + する
english_grammar.about: In Japanese, たり is a 'conjunction particle' that is used in exactly the same way as て. However, instead of having the nuance of 'then', or 'and', it has the nuance of 'and things like'. Basically, it is used for listing sequences of events that do not happen in a specific order.The last たり in any sequence will almost always be followed by する (or した for past tense). 休(やす)みの日(ひ)は家(いえ)でテレビを見(み)たり、寝(ね)たりする。On my days off, I do things like watch tv and sleep at home. 飲(の)み会(かい)で食(た)べたり、飲(の)んだりした。At the party, I did things like eat and drink. From these examples we can see that たり will sometimes be said as だり. This happens with the same verbs that usually use だ for past tense (like 読(よ)んだ), or で for the て form ( like 泳(およ)いで). This will not change the meaning at all, and is only to help make the words easier to say.To summarize, the difference between て form, and たり is as follows.Events in order - I did (A) て, (B) て, (C) て, (D) た.Events in no specific order - I did (D) たり, (B) たり, (A) たり, (C) たりした.たり is frequently used when there is only one verb in the sentence. This just means that the speaker did 'things like (A)', without specifically listing anything else. 昔(むかし)あそこの池(いけ)で泳(およ)いだりした。In the past, I used to swim in that lake over there. (Among other things) Caution In cases where a する verb is the last verb in a particular sequence, たり will often be omitted. 勉強(べんきょう)をしたり、おやつを食(た)べたり、掃除(そうじ)もします。I do things like study, eat snacks, and also clean. (In no specific order)

example.japanese: 家(いえ)でゲームをしたり、食(た)べたりした。
example.english: At home, I did things like play video games and eat.

example.japanese: 音楽(おんがく)を聞(き)いたり、本(ほん)を読(よ)んだりしました。
example.english: I did things like listen to music and read books.

example.japanese: 掃除(そうじ)をしたり、洗濯(せんたく)をしたりした。
example.english: I did things like cleaning and doing the laundry.

example.japanese: 雨(あめ)が降(ふ)ったり、止(や)んだりするね。
example.english: It keeps doing things like raining and stopping, doesn't it.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)は、勉強(べんきょう)したり、練習(れんしゅう)したりする。
example.english: Today I will do things like study and practice.

synonym.explanation: whether or, things like, and … so on
Things like, And the like
Among other things, For example, Such as
or, either or

english_grammar.title: 結構(けっこう)
english_grammar.explanation: Quite, A lot, Fairly, Rather
english_grammar.structure: けっこう + Phrase Set Expressions: けっこうだ
english_grammar.attention: けっこう is often used as a set phrase, meaning 'no thanks'
english_grammar.about: 結構(けっこう) is a な-Adjective that is actually used more frequently as a sentence altering adverb, than it is as a な-Adjective. What this means is that it is regularly used before an entire phrase (without な or だ), and it will modify the entire sentence. The most common meaning that 結構(けっこう) has is 'quite' (a bit/a lot). 結構(けっこう)走(はし)ったね。We ran quite a lot, right? 結構(けっこう)高(たか)いですよ。It's quite expensive. 結構(けっこう) can also be used very naturally with の. In these instances, the meaning is similar to 沢山(たくさん). 今日(きょう)は結構(けっこう)の量(りょう)釣(つ)れたね。We could catch quite a lot of fish today, couldn't we? Fun Fact結構(けっこう) is used very similarly in Japanese to 'no thank you', or 'I'm fine thanks' in English. For example, if someone asks you if you want to try a sample in a shop, most people would just say 結構(けっこう)です. 袋(ふくろ)は結構(けっこう)です。I don't need a bag, thank you. (I'm fine without a bag)

example.japanese: いいえ、けっこうです。
example.english: No thank you.

example.japanese: このカバンはけっこう高(たか)いです。
example.english: This bag is quite expensive.

example.japanese: それはけっこう面白(おもしろ)いですね。
example.english: That is quite interesting, isn't it.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は、けっこうです。
example.english: No thank you.

example.japanese: この公園(こうえん)はけっこう広(ひろ)いです。
example.english: This park is quite spacious.

synonym.explanation: very・quite, considerably

english_grammar.title: 沢山(たくさん)
english_grammar.explanation: Many, A lot of, Plenty, Enough
english_grammar.structure: たくさん + Phrase たくさん +（の） + Noun
english_grammar.attention: たくさん often comes directly before verbs
english_grammar.about: There are many cases in Japanese where a noun will appear as an adverb, particularly with words that are describing amounts. たくさん, or 沢山(たくさん) as it is regularly seen, is one of those words. たくさん means 'a lot', or 'many' in Japanese, and can be used before a phrase, or directly before a noun, when separated via の. 沢山(たくさん)食(た)べてよ!Eat a lot! (Eat to your heart's content!) この島(しま)には沢山(たくさん)の猫(ねこ)がいます。On this island, there are a lot of cats. (Unrelated to the sentence, there is actually an island like this in Japan!) Caution たくさん may be used before a noun without also using の. However, in this case, it will feel more like たくさん is describing the whole phrase, rather than just the noun it is in front of. If you strongly want to highlight the noun, using の would be best. あの店(みせ)の前(まえ)に沢山(たくさん)人(ひと)が集(あつ)まっている。There are a lot of people gathering in front of that store. (Focuses on the store. I wonder why there are so many people in front of that store) あの店(みせ)の前(まえ)に沢山(たくさん)の人(ひと)が集(あつ)まっている。There are a lot of people gathering in front of that store. (Focuses on the people. The amount of people gathering up in front of that store is unbelievable) In these examples, the only difference is that the sentence with の feels like the speaker is putting extra focus on the people, rather than the gathering that is happening.

example.japanese: たくさんありますから。食(た)べてください。
example.english: There is plenty. So, please eat.

example.japanese: たくさん(の)雪(ゆき)が降(ふ)りました。
example.english: A lot of snow fell.

example.japanese: たくさん(の)仕事(しごと)をします。
example.english: I will do a lot of work.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)の勉強(べんきょう)をたくさんしました。
example.english: I did a lot of Japanese studying.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はたくさん(の)本(ほん)を読(よ)む。
example.english: He reads a lot of books.

english_grammar.title: 前(まえ)に
english_grammar.explanation: Before, In front of
english_grammar.structure: Verb + 前に Noun + の + 前に
english_grammar.about: 前(まえ)に is used when describing something that is either 'before something' (in time), or 'in front of something' (a location). It is used with verbs (in their non-past form), or nouns. When used with nouns, の is required before 前(まえ)に. 病院(びょういん)の前(まえ)にあるコンビニ。 A convenience store in front of the hospital. 家(いえ)に入(はい)る前(まえ)に靴(くつ)を脱(ぬ)ぐ。I take off my shoes before I enter the house. Caution Another similar construction to 前(まえ)に is 手前(てまえ)に. 前(まえ)に can be used for something that is in front of any location. However, 手前(てまえ)に may only be used when things in front of you (or someone/something else) are being described physically. 銀行(ぎんこう)の前(まえ)にあるラーメン屋(や)。The ramen shop in front of the bank. 私(わたし)の手前(てまえ)にある着物(きもの)は高(たか)いです。The kimono right in front of me is expensive.

example.japanese: 食(た)べる前(まえ)に「いただきます」と言(い)う。
example.english: Before eating we say “いただきます”.

example.japanese: 帰(かえ)る前(まえ)に勉強(べんきょう)をする。
example.english: Before going home I will study.

example.japanese: 前(まえ)にここに来(き)ました。
example.english: I’ve been here before.

example.japanese: 食(た)べる前(まえ)に手(て)を洗(あら)います。
example.english: I will wash my hands before I eat.

example.japanese: テレビの前(まえ)に、机(つくえ)があります。
example.english: There is a desk in front of the TV.

synonym.explanation: before, in front of, from one's standpoint/side
before it becomes, before ~ occurs, without
the former・the latter, the first・the second

english_grammar.title: くらい ①
english_grammar.explanation: About, Approximately
english_grammar.structure: Number/counter + くらい or ぐらい
english_grammar.attention: くらい and ぐらい may be used 100% interchangably, but ぐらい is far more common in speech
english_grammar.about: くらい or ぐらい (more common in spoken language) has several different uses in Japanese, but is often translated as 'about', or 'approximately'. It comes from the kanji 位(くらい), which literally means a 'rank', or 'grade' of something. This use of くらい comes after numbers, or counter words. 後(あと)３分(ぷん)くらいで着(つ)く。I'll arrive in about 3 minutes. ４個(こ)ぐらい欲(ほ)しいな。I want about 4. どのくらいで着(つ)きますか？How long will it take for you to arrive? As can be seen in the last example, くらい may also be used after question words such as どの, when asking about the extent (grade) of something.Due to the original meaning of くらい being 'rank', or 'extent', it may not be used when referring to broad periods of time. ころ will be used in these situations. However, くらい and ころ may be used interchangeably when referring to a specific time (due to a specific time may being able to be thought of as an extent). ８時(じ)くらいでもいい？Is about 8 okay? ８時(じ)ごろでもいい？Is about 8 okay? 子供(こども)のくらいにディズニーに行(い)った。About when I was a kid, I went to Disneyland. (Incorrect example, with unnatural English to match!) 子供(こども)のころにディズニーに行(い)った。I went to Disney when I was a kid. Caution Please see the ころ grammar point if you would like to compare these two structures further.

example.japanese: 何時(なんじ)ぐらいに来(き)ますか。
example.english: Approximately when will you come?

example.japanese: あと３０分(ぷん)ぐらいで行(い)きます。
example.english: I will go/leave in approximately 30 minutes.

example.japanese: 毎週(まいしゅう)コーヒーはどのくらい飲(の)む？
example.english: Approximately how much coffee do you drink per week?

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は１０歳(さい)くらいだろう。
example.english: He’s about 10 years old.

example.japanese: 毎日(まいにち)、一(いち)時間(じかん)くらい本(ほん)を読(よ)みます。
example.english: I read a book for about one hour every day.

synonym.explanation: to the extent that, so…that, about the only thing that...
the more・about, to the extent that, so much… that
Around, About
about the only, to the extent that

english_grammar.title: Noun + まで
english_grammar.explanation: Until, Till, To (but no further than)
english_grammar.structure: Ending Point + まで, Noun + まで
english_grammar.about: まで is a particle that roughly means 'as far as'. Due to this, when used with regular nouns, or words that signify some kind of end point (a time or day), it is often translated as 'until', 'till', or 'to'. 空港(くうこう)まで行(い)く。I go to the airport. (To 'go' until the airport, and then be finished) ９時(じ)まで勉強(べんきょう)する。I always study until 9. When used in relation to a place, まで functions similarly to に. This means that someone or something will go 'to' the place, but not any further. 駅(えき)まで送(おく)るよ。I'll take you to the station. (Until the station is reached) 車(くるま)で駅(えき)に行(い)く。I will go to the station by car. まで may also be used about points in time in the past, where 'up until' would usually be used in English. 昨日(きのう)のパーティーは11時(じ)まで続(つづ)いた。The party last night continued up until 11.

example.japanese: どこまで行(い)く？
example.english: How far will you go? (Until)

example.japanese: ７時(じ)までです。
example.english: Until seven o’clock.

example.japanese: このセールは金曜日(きんようび)までです。
example.english: This sale lasts until Friday.

example.japanese: 朝(あさ)まで寝(ね)ました。
example.english: I slept until morning.

example.japanese: ８時(じ)まで、テレビを見(み)る。
example.english: To watch TV until eight o'clock.

synonym.explanation: By ~, By the time that ~, Before ~
Even, To even, To the extent of
Until (something) happens

english_grammar.title: (Verb) + まで
english_grammar.explanation: Until (something) happens
english_grammar.structure: Verb + まで
english_grammar.about: まで is a particle that roughly means 'as far as (A)', or 'until the point of (A)'. When used with verbs, it is often translated as 'until (A) happens'.Because まで means 'as far as/until the point of', it cannot be used with verbs in past tense, as would usually be the case in English. Due to this, past tense will be made clear by the context of the story, or verbs that come later in the sentence. 友達(ともだち)が来(く)るまで、駅(えき)をウロウロした。Until my friend came, I wandered around the station. (した gives the whole sentence the meaning of past tense) 携帯(けいたい)は壊(こわ)れるまで、使(つか)います。Until my phone breaks, I will use it. When used with a place, まで functions similarly to に. This means that someone or something will go 'to' the place, but not go any further.Caution To get a better idea of how まで is used in relation to the past, let's have a look at another example, and how it would translate in English. 授業(じゅぎょう)が始(はじ)まるまで、先生(せんせい)が来(こ)なかった。The teacher didn't come until the class started. Here we can see that the English sentence will say 'started', but 始(はじ)まる 'start' (non-past tense) is required in Japanese. However, later in the sentence, 来(こ)なかった (past tense) is used. In this way, the overall meaning stays the same, while being slightly different to what an English native speaker would expect.

example.japanese: 映画(えいが)が始(はじ)まるまで、友達(ともだち)と話(はな)した。
example.english: Until the movie started, I talked with my friend.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)が来(く)るまで、日本語(にほんご)を勉強(べんきょう)します。
example.english: Until he comes, I will study Japanese.

example.japanese: カタカナを覚(おぼ)えるまで、私(わたし)は寝(ね)ない。
example.english: Until I memorize katakana, I won't sleep.

example.japanese: その漢字(かんじ)を覚(おぼ)えるまで、辞書(じしょ)を使(つか)う。
example.english: Until I remember that kanji, I will use a dictionary.

example.japanese: お風呂(ふろ)に入(はい)るまで、ゆっくりしたい。
example.english: Until I get in the bath, I want to relax.

synonym.explanation: Until, Till, To (but no further than)
By ~, By the time that ~, Before ~
Even, To even, To the extent of

english_grammar.title: 過(す)ぎる
english_grammar.explanation: Too much, Very
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ すぎる ［い］Adjective［い］+ すぎる ［な］Adjective + すぎる Negative: Verb［ない］+ なさ(1) + すぎる ［い］Adjective ［ない］ + なさ + すぎる ［な］Adjective + では(2)ない + なさ + すぎる (1) な (2) じゃ
english_grammar.attention: 良すぎる = よすぎる, not いすぎる or よさすぎる
english_grammar.about: すぎる is a verb that is used in Japanese to mean 'to exceed', or 'to go past'. It keeps this meaning when it is attached to other words, and creates the Japanese equivalent of saying that something is 'too much'. すぎる can be joined to the ます stem of verbs, the stem form of い-Adjectives (simply remove the い), or the stem form of な-Adjectives (simply remove the な). 頑張(がんば)りすぎるのは身体(からだ)に良(よ)くない。Working too hard is not good for your health. これは熱(あつ)すぎるよ。This is way too hot. 俺(おれ)には田舎(いなか)は静(しず)かすぎる。For me, the countryside is way too quiet. With すぎる, the る is regularly omitted, with すぎ being used by itself. This is a casual language pattern, and something you will hear all the time. This variation may be used with any word that すぎる would usually be used with. この犬(いぬ)、可愛(かわい)すぎ！This dog is too cute! There are a few rules that you will need to be careful about when using すぎる. The first of these unique rules is using すぎる with ない. When linked to ない, the い changes to さ, creating the structure なさすぎる. This means 'too much not (A)', or more naturally in English 'not enough (A)'.As with regular ない forms, では or じゃ will be required when used after な-Adjectives. あの人(ひと)は私(わたし)のタイプじゃなさすぎる。That person is DEFINITELY not type. (Literally 'they are too much not my type') 私(わたし)はお金(かね)がなさすぎる。I don't have enough money. (Literally 'I have too much of no money') この店(みせ)は商品(しょうひん)がなすぎる。This store does not have enough goods. (This store has too much of nothing) In the third example here, we can see that the さ has been omitted. This is technically not correct Japanese, but has become very common among young people, so it still sounds natural.The second unique rule is when using すぎる with いい to mean 'too good'. Because すぎる is used with the stem form of い-Adjectives, you will need to remember that the stem form of いい is not actually い, but よ. This means that よすぎる would be correct, while いすぎる is not. この歌(うた)は良(よ)すぎる。This song is too good. Caution Because すぎる itself is a verb, it can also appear in the negative form, this confuses a lot of learners, and is something that needs to be practiced. Let's have a look at all of the ways that すぎる could possibly appear with ない. 学校(がっこう)に行(い)かなさすぎるから成績(せいせき)が落(お)ちた。Because I don't go to school enough, my grades are going down. (Literally, I don't go too much) 彼(かれ)はトイレに行(い)かなさすぎない。He doesn't not go to the toilet enough. (A double negative that becomes positive) ゲームセンターには行(い)きすぎないでね。Don't go to the arcade too often. (The negative focus is on 'too much', and sounds more like a request) Because the meaning is different in each one of these sentences, depending on where the ない is, and how many ない's there are, you may need to be careful while reading these, until it starts to feel natural.

example.japanese: ここはゴミが多(おお)すぎる。
example.english: There is too much garbage here.

example.japanese: この寿司(すし)は美味(おい)しすぎる。
example.english: This sushi is too delicious.

example.japanese: アイスクリームを食(た)べすぎたからお腹(なか)が痛(いた)い。
example.english: Because I ate too much ice cream, my stomach hurts.

example.japanese: その冗談(じょうだん)は面白(おもしろ)くなさすぎた。
example.english: That joke was not very funny.

example.japanese: いつも週末(しゅうまつ)に寝(ね)すぎます。
example.english: I always sleep too much on the weekends.

synonym.explanation: so much...that
so much...that, (way) too...

english_grammar.title: にする
english_grammar.explanation: To decide on, To choose, To make something into, To view something as
english_grammar.structure: Noun + に + する
english_grammar.attention: Sometimes written as とする, which focuses on the result, rather than the process of 'making'
english_grammar.about: にする is a structure that combines the に particle (a location/target), with the verb する. It means to 'make/decide' something in a certain way. The nuance with にする is that the speaker has direct control over the outcome. This is where the strong feeling of 'choice' comes from. The noun that comes before にする is the thing that is being decided. 俺(おれ)はビールにする。I'm going to decide on this beer. In this example, although the common translation is 'to decide', it is actually much closer to the slang expression 'to do (A)' in English. This means that the literal translation is actually 'I'll do a beer', or 'I'll make it a beer'.Sometimes the particle と is used instead of に. Although this has the same meaning, it changes the nuance slightly. When と is used, it takes away the feeling of being a direct decision. とする tends to be used in more formal situations, but this is only because と is less 'definite', so results in the phrase sounding less pushy. 今日(きょう)はここまでとする。Today, I will decide to make this the end. (Why don't we call it a day, if that's ok) 今日(きょう)はここまでにする。Today, I will decide to end it here. (I'm going to call it a day) If you were going to compare these two to an English equivalent, it would be similar to the difference between the following sentences. に - I'll buy a burger. (A burger is the direct target of 'buy')と - I'll go with a burger. (You aren't 'going' anywhere, it just sounds softer)This grammar point may be used for more abstract nouns, and does not specifically need to be 'items'. ハイキングへ行(い)くの日曜日(にちようび)にする?Is Sunday ok for hiking? (Literally, 'as for heading hiking, will you make it Sunday?')

example.japanese: 何(なに)にする？
example.english: What have you decided on?

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)の晩(ばん)ごはんは何(なに)にする？
example.english: What have you decided on for today's dinner?

example.japanese: このかばんにします。
example.english: To decide on this bag.

example.japanese: 明日(あした)の朝(あさ)ごはんは魚(さかな)にします。
example.english: To decide on fish for breakfast tomorrow.

example.japanese: このレストランにします。
example.english: To decide on this restaurant.

synonym.explanation: surely, bound to, certainly, be decided
It will end up being, It is the result of, It has been decided that
to decide on, have decided to

english_grammar.title: になる・くなる
english_grammar.explanation: To become (adjective)
english_grammar.structure: ［な］Adjective + に + なる ［い］Adjective［く］+ なる Exceptions: いい ￫ よくなる
english_grammar.about: になる (with な-Adjectives), or くなる (with い-Adjectives) is an expression used in Japanese to show that something is 'becoming (A)'. It can be used with any form of なる, to highlight that something will become (non-past), is becoming (continuous), or has become (past). It can even be used with negative forms, to show that something 'will not become (A)'. 早(はや)く食(た)べて、冷(つめ)たくなるよ。Hurry up and eat, it will get cold. お茶(ちゃ)が冷(つめ)たくなっているよ。The tea got cold. コーヒーが温(ぬる)くなった。The coffee has become lukewarm. 私(わたし)は医者(いしゃ)にならない。I won't become a doctor. The adjective いい 'good' is an exception to the regular conjugation rules for い-Adjectives, and will conjugate as よくなる, not いくなる. 勉強(べんきょう)をしているから、頭(あたま)が良(よ)くなる。Because I study, I will become smart. (Literally, 'my head will get good')

example.japanese: 難(むずか)しくなる。
example.english: To become difficult.

example.japanese: 嬉(うれ)しくなる。
example.english: To become happy.

example.japanese: 早(はや)くなる。
example.english: To become fast.

example.japanese: 良(よ)くなる。
example.english: To become better.

example.japanese: 綺麗(きれい)になる。
example.english: To become pretty/clean.

synonym.explanation: To come to, To become, To continue, To be starting to, Has been ~ing

english_grammar.title: の中(なか)で～が一番(いちばん)
english_grammar.explanation: Out of ~, ~ is the best/most ~
english_grammar.structure: (Set of Elements) + の中で一番 その(1) + 中で一番 (1) この
english_grammar.about: In Japanese '(A) の中(なか)で (B) が一番(いちばん) (C)', is a regular expression that is used for showing that something is 'the most (C)', usually an adjective. This structure can be used with almost any adjective, whether it is positive or negative. Each part of this grammar point represents the following:(A) - A group.(B) - A single thing/person within that group.(C) - An adjective, or general description of that thing/person. 食(た)べ物(もの)の中(なか)で寿司(すし)が一番(いちばん)好(す)き。Out of all foods, I like sushi best. (Sushi is the number 1 liked food) 授業(じゅぎょう)の中(なか)で理科(りか)が一番(いちばん)嫌(きら)いです。Out of all classes, I don't like science the most. (Science is the number 1 hated class) This expression is also frequently used with demonstratives such as この and その. この中(なか)でどれが一番(いちばん)好(す)き？Out of all of this, which one do you like best? その中(なか)ではクッキーが一番(いちばん)美味(おい)しい。Out of those, the cookie is the most delicious. The construction '(A) の中(なか)で' is regularly translated by itself as 'among (A)', and may be used in many different expressions. This will be covered in a separate grammar point.

example.japanese: この中(なか)で一番(いちばん)好(す)きな 食(た)べ物(もの)は何(なに)？
example.english: Among these, what is your number one favorite food?

example.japanese: 中華(ちゅうか)料理(りょうり)の中(なか)で何(なに)が一番(いちばん)好(す)きですか。
example.english: Out of all Chinese dishes, what is your number one favorite dish?

example.japanese: 飲(の)み物(もの)の中(なか)で一番(いちばん)好(す)きなのは何(なん)ですか。
example.english: Out of all drinks, what is your number one favorite drink?

example.japanese: お茶(ちゃ)の中(なか)で一番(いちばん)美味(おい)しいのは何(なん)ですか。
example.english: Out of all teas, what is the number one most delicious tea?

example.japanese: 国(くに)の中(なか)で一番(いちばん)人口(じんこう)が多(おお)いのはどれですか。
example.english: Out of all countries, which country has the number one largest population?

synonym.explanation: in, among, within
between ~ which one
although, but・however, for all that・provided that
of the, among(st)

english_grammar.title: より～の方(ほう)が
english_grammar.explanation: To be more ~ than ~
english_grammar.structure: Verb (A) + より + Verb (B) + 方 + が ［い］Adjective (A) + より + ［い］Adjective (B) + 方 + が ［な］Adjective (A) + な + より + ［な］Adjective (B) + な + 方 + が Noun (A) + より + Noun (B) + の + 方 + が
english_grammar.about: より～のほうが can be thought of as similar to the grammar points たほうがいい, and ないほうがいい, in that it expresses that one thing is the 'better (A)', or 'more (A)'. However, unlike ほうがいい based expressions, any pair of adjectives, verbs, or nouns may be compared in this construction, so long as のほうが is followed by an adjective.より translates roughly to 'than', or 'rather than' in this phrase. 田舎(いなか)に住(す)むより、都会(とかい)の方(ほう)がいい。I like living in the city more than the countryside. 彼女(かのじょ)より、私(わたし)の方(ほう)が背(せ)が高(たか)い。I am taller than my girlfriend. 映画(えいが)は怖(こわ)いより、面白(おもしろ)い方(ほう)が好(す)き。I like funny movies more than scary movies. From the examples listed here, we can see that より will always appear after the word that has the lower extent of (A), when used together with のほうが.Caution When より is used by itself, or when it is not linked directly to the previous word, it can seem like it has the opposite meaning. However, in these cases, のほうが just remains unsaid. これがより高(たか)い。This is more expensive. (Compared to other things in general) In this example, because the より is after が, not before これ, it is easy to assume that これ is the thing that is lower. However, this が behaves in the same way as のほうが, meaning that これ itself is the more expensive thing, with より just being used like 'relatively' (compared to many other things).Caution Although の方(ほう)が is the most common construction, the particle を may sometimes replace が. This is especially true when used with markers of desire such as たい and ほしい. The primary difference between these two is that が emphasizes what a person wants or wants to do (the whole statement), while を emphasizes the item or action itself (regardless of the rest of the statement). With たい, both を and が will sound completely natural. However, with ほしい, が will be more natural, while を is accepted. 給料(きゅうりょう)がいい仕事(しごと)より、楽(たの)しい仕事(しごと)の方(ほう)をしたい。I want to do a job that is fun, more than a job that pays better. (Natural Japanese) この小(ちい)さいテレビより、その大(おお)きいテレビの方(ほう)を欲(ほ)しい。I want that big TV rather than this small TV. (Natural Japanese, but が is more common) This use of ほしい only applies to wanting items, as opposed to たい, which indicates the desire to 'do' something.

example.japanese: このパンよりそのパンの方(ほう)が美味(おい)しいです。
example.english: That bread is more delicious than this bread.

example.japanese: バスケットボールよりサッカーの方(ほう)が好(す)き。
example.english: I like soccer more than basketball.

example.japanese: ユキよりリュウトの方(ほう)が賢(かしこ)い。
example.english: Ryuto is smarter than Yuki.

example.japanese: 月曜日(げつようび)より、日曜日(にちようび)の方(ほう)が好(す)き。
example.english: I like Sunday more than Monday.

example.japanese: あそこの 公園(こうえん)より、家(いえ)に近(ちか)い公園(こうえん)の方(ほう)が広(ひろ)い。
example.english: The park near my house is more spacious than that park over there.

synonym.explanation: is not as…as, isn't... like..., not to the extent of...
More than, Over
It'd be better to, Should do

english_grammar.title: 何(なに) + か
english_grammar.explanation: Something, Nothing, Anything, Not anything, Some kind of, Not any kind of
english_grammar.structure: 何か + Phrase 何も + Phrase［ない］
english_grammar.attention: The meaning of these words will change, based on whether the sentence is positive, or negative
english_grammar.about: 何(なに)か and 何(なに)も are constructions that are used in Japanese for expressing 'something', 'anything', or 'nothing'. The main difference between the two being that 何(なに)も is used with negative phrases (phrases that use ない or ありません), while 何(なに)か is used in other cases.To use this expression, we simply need to put 何(なに)か or 何(なに)も before the desired phrase. 何(なに)か食(た)べますか？Do you want to eat something? 冷蔵庫(れいぞうこ)の中(なか)には何(なに)もないです。There is nothing inside the refrigerator. Caution There are several casual forms of these expressions that are used in speech, or in certain dialects. These forms are なんにか, なんか, or なんにも, なんも.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)が何(なに)か嫌(いや)な ことをしましたか？
example.english: Did I do something you didn't like?

example.japanese: いいえ、何(なに)もしていませんよ。
example.english: No, I didn't do anything (wrong).

example.japanese: 日本(にほん)に行(い)って、何(なに)か食(た)べたいものがありますか。
example.english: When you go to Japan, is there something that you want to eat?

example.japanese: 頑張(がんば)って勉強(べんきょう)したけど何(なに)もわからない。
example.english: I studied diligently, but I don't understand anything.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は何(なに)か答(こた)えを探(さが)している。
example.english: He is searching for some kind of answer.

english_grammar.title: 誰(だれ)か
english_grammar.explanation: Someone, Somewhere, Not anyone, Not anywhere
english_grammar.structure: WH-Word(1) + か + Particle(2) WH-Word(1) + Particle(2) + も (1) どこ、誰 (2) へ、に、と
english_grammar.attention: The meaning of these words will change, based on whether the sentence is positive, or negative
english_grammar.about: The constructions 誰(だれ)か, and どこか are used when you want to ask, or answer questions about 'someone', or 'somewhere' (positive sentences). Alternatively, 'no one', or 'nowhere' based statements are made with 誰(だれ)も, and どこも (negative sentences). Structures like this that use 誰(だれ) were briefly discussed in the 誰(だれ) grammar point. 誰(だれ)かがいますか。Is anyone here? 来月(らいげつ)はどこかへ行(い)きますか？Are you going somewhere next month? 俺(おれ)の誕生日(たんじょうび)パーティーには誰(だれ)も来(こ)なかった。No one came to my birthday party. ９時(じ)だからどこも開(あ)いていない。Since it is 9pm, nowhere is open. Using 誰(だれ), or どこ is not limited to the か and も particles. へ, に, or と may also be partnered with か or も, to give a more specific meaning. 休(やす)みの日(ひ)はどこかへ行(い)きましたか？Did you go anywhere during your break? 誰(だれ)かに言(い)った？Did you tell anyone? (Literally, 'did you tell it to anyone?') 誰(だれ)かと電話(でんわ)をしている。He is on the phone with someone. 今日(きょう)はどこへも行(い)かない。I don't want to go anywhere today. (Not even anywhere) 明日(あした)は誰(だれ)にも会(あ)わない。I will not meet anyone tomorrow. (Not even anyone) 私(わたし)は誰(だれ)にも話(はな)す。I talk to anyone. (Even anyone, but less common than でも) As can be seen with these examples, か will always precede any other particle in a positive sentence. However, the opposite is true for も. も will always follow any other particles in negative sentences. This is because か will always attach directly to the noun (when altering the meaning of that noun), but も alters the whole phrase, not just the noun.However, It should be noted that も is not limited to appearing in negative sentences, as can be seen with the final example.

example.japanese: 「どこかに友達(ともだち)がいるのですか。」「どこにもいません。」
example.english: 'Do you have friends somewhere?''I don't have friends anywhere.'

example.japanese: 「誰(だれ)かにそのことを言(い)いましたか。」「いいえ、誰(だれ)にも言(い)っていません。」
example.english: 'Did you tell someone about that?''No, I didn't tell anyone.'

example.japanese: 「どこかにあるでしょう。」「どこにもありませんよ。」
example.english: 'It is probably somewhere.''It is not anywhere (I'm telling you).'

example.japanese: 「紙(かみ)を誰(だれ)かに渡(わた)しましたか。」「誰(だれ)にも渡(わた)していません。」
example.english: 'Did you hand off the paper to someone?''I did not hand off the paper to anyone.'

example.japanese: 「どこかへ出(で)かけますか。」「どこへも行(い)きたくないよ。」
example.english: 'Do you want to go somewhere?''I don't want to go anywhere, man.'

english_grammar.title: ましょう
english_grammar.explanation: Let's, Shall we (polite volitional)
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ ましょう
english_grammar.about: ましょう is one of the conjugations of the auxiliary verb ます, and is a common (polite) way to suggest that something be done 'together' (when used with a verb). It is often translated as 'let's (A)', or 'shall we (A)?'. To use ましょう, we will simply need to change ます to ましょう, when conjugating the verb. モールに行(い)きましょう！Let's go to the mall! 踊(おど)りましょう。Shall we dance? (Said with a rising tone to indicate that it is a question) Despite regularly being translated as 'shall we (A)?', ましょう does not specifically target another person, and can also be used as a declaration that (A) will be done/needs to be done. This use reflects the base meaning of ましょう, which is the polite volitional form (deliberately/purposefully doing something). ５キロ痩(や)せましょう！I will lose 5 kg! (I shall do it!) In this example, the speaker is expressing to themselves that they 'will' do something, and are strongly resolved to make it happen (similar to 'I shall' in English).

example.japanese: サッカーをしましょう。
example.english: Let’s play soccer.

example.japanese: このレストランで寿司(すし)を食(た)べましょう。
example.english: Let’s eat sushi at this restaurant.

example.japanese: ごはんを食(た)べましょう。
example.english: Let’s eat.

example.japanese: バスで行(い)きましょう。
example.english: Let’s go by bus.

example.japanese: 難(むずか)しい漢字(かんじ)を覚(おぼ)えましょう。
example.english: Let’s memorize difficult kanji.

synonym.explanation: Let's, I shall (casual volitional)
Won't you, Would you not (with me)?
Shall we

english_grammar.title: ましょうか
english_grammar.explanation: Shall we
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ ましょうか
english_grammar.about: As covered in our ましょう lesson, ましょう is one of the conjugations of the auxiliary verb ます, and is a common (polite) way to suggest that something be done 'together'.Adding the particle か to this expression simply changes the nuance from 'let's', to 'shall we?', and is more of a direct question than ましょう by itself.Like ましょう, this expression can be added to the ます stem form of any verb. レストランまで車(くるま)で行(い)きましょうか。Shall we go to the restaurant by car? 今夜(こんや)走(はし)りましょうか。Shall we run tonight? One thing to note with these examples is that they are 'suggestions', not 'invitations'. In Japanese there is a slight difference between the two, in the same way that there is in English. If you want to invite someone to do something, the most natural way would be to use ませんか, a phrase that is similar to ましょうか. 一緒(いっしょ)にイタリアに行(い)きませんか？Won't you go to Italy with me? 一緒(いっしょ)にイタリアに行(い)きましょうか。Shall we go to Italy? The difference here is that 'won't you do (A)?' has a stronger nuance of being a direct invitation, while ましょうか is closer to just 'let's do (A)!'

example.japanese: 寿司(すし)を食(た)べに行(い)きましょうか。
example.english: Shall we go eat some sushi?

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)で話(はな)しましょうか。
example.english: Shall we speak in Japanese?

example.japanese: 明日(あした)ビーチに行(い)きましょうか。
example.english: Shall we go to the beach tomorrow?

example.japanese: インド料理(りょうり)を食(た)べに行(い)きましょうか。
example.english: Shall we go for Indian?

example.japanese: ９時(じ)前(まえ)に帰(かえ)りましょうか。
example.english: Shall we go home before nine o'clock?

synonym.explanation: Won't you, Would you not (with me)?
Let's, Shall we (polite volitional)
Let's, I shall (casual volitional)

english_grammar.title: ませんか
english_grammar.explanation: Won't you, Would you not (with me)?
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］ + か
english_grammar.about: ませんか (or ないか more casually) is an expression that is used after verbs as an invitation. It basically translates to 'won't you do (A) with me?'.This expression is a little bit different to ましょうか, in that it sounds directly like in invitation to do (A). ましょうか tends to sound more like a suggestion that (A) should be done. 明日(あした)は温泉(おんせん)に行(い)きませんか。Won't you go to the onsen with me tomorrow? (Polite) 来週(らいしゅう)は釣(つ)りをしに行(い)かないか。Won't you go fishing with me next week? (Casual) It is recommended to use the ませんか version, as ないか would be a bit too casual to use with someone that you are not very close with (and is also technically not correct Japanese).To make it clearer that the speaker wants to do (A) 'with' someone, expressions like 一緒(いっしょ)に 'together' are often added, for clarification. 一緒(いっしょ)にお祭(まつ)りへ行(い)きませんか。Won't you go to the festival with me? To examine the difference between ましょうか and ませんか, let's have a look at how the nuance changes in the same type of sentence. ラーメンを食(た)べに行(い)きましょうか。Shall we go eat ramen? ラーメンを食べに行(い)きませんか。Won't you go eat ramen with me? Here, ませんか will come across as an invitation due to the fact that you are asking the person if they 'wouldn't mind doing (A)' with you. This is the main reason that it is considered a more polite option when inviting someone to do something, than ましょうか.

example.japanese: 寿司(すし)を食(た)べに行(い)きませんか。
example.english: Won’t you go eat sushi (with me)?

example.japanese: サッカーをしませんか。
example.english: Won’t you play soccer (with me)?

example.japanese: 一緒(いっしょ)に文法(ぶんぽう)を勉強(べんきょう)しませんか。
example.english: Won’t you study grammar with me?

example.japanese: お風呂(ふろ)に一緒(いっしょ)に入(はい)りませんか。
example.english: Won’t you take a bath with me?

example.japanese: 金曜日(きんようび)に、買(か)い物(もの)に行(い)きませんか。
example.english: Won't you go shopping (with me) on Friday?

synonym.explanation: why don't you...?, what if you did...?
Let's, Shall we (polite volitional)
Shall we

english_grammar.title: ～てもいい (Verb)
english_grammar.explanation: It's okay to, It's alright to, Can/may
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］+ も + いい
english_grammar.about: Verb + てもいい is a construction in Japanese used to express that something is 'okay', or 'alright'. It can also be used as a question to ask if you 'can', or 'may' do something. その靴(くつ)を買(か)ってもいいよ。It's alright if you buy those shoes. この肉(にく)は食(た)べてもいいです。It is okay to eat this meat. 明日(あした)は家(いえ)に行(い)ってもいいですか？Is it okay if I go to your house tomorrow? ペンを借(か)りてもいいですか？May I borrow your pen? This phrase is also regularly used without the も, but is considered a bit more direct/casual. It is best to remove the も only when talking to people that you know well.This expression is simply a construction that literally means て (verb) も (also) いい (is good).Caution As this grammar point uses the て form of verbs, it is important to remember that some verbs will use で instead of て.

example.japanese: これを見(み)てもいい？
example.english: Is it alright if I look at this?

example.japanese: 質問(しつもん)をしてもいい？
example.english: May I ask a question?

example.japanese: 暑(あつ)いです。水(みず)を飲(の)んでもいいですか。
example.english: It’s hot. Is it alright to drink some water?

example.japanese: あそこで遊(あそ)んでもいいです。
example.english: You may play over there.

example.japanese: ここで本(ほん)を読(よ)んでもいいでしょう。
example.english: It is okay if I read a book here, right?

synonym.explanation: It is alright/fine/okay even if, Can/may, ~ is also okay
even if, even though
it doesn't matter if, I don't mind
And, Then (linking events)
you could say, you might say
If it is alright, if you don't mind, if you would like, if possible

english_grammar.title: ～て下(くだ)さい
english_grammar.explanation: Please do (polite request)
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］+ ください Politeness Levels
english_grammar.attention: In casual speech, ください can be omitted, resulting in the request finishing in て
english_grammar.about: てください is a polite expression that is used for asking people to do something. It is most often translated as 'please do (A)'. 手(て)を洗(あら)ってください。Please wash your hands. これを見(み)てください。Please look at this. ください is actually classified as honorific language, a type of polite speech that is used to refer to the actions of other people. くださる itself is the base form of this verb. While ください is exclusively used for making requests. くださる is the honorific language equivalent of くれる.In friendly conversation, ください can be omitted from this expression, and the て form itself can be used as a very casual way of saying 'please do (A)'. ちょっとテレビを消(け)して。Hey, can you turn off the TV? (ちょっと is often used simply to get the attention of the listener) クッキーを作(つく)ったから食(た)べて。Because I made cookies, you can eat them.

example.japanese: この本(ほん)を読(よ)んでください。
example.english: Please read this book.

example.japanese: 食(た)べてください。
example.english: Please eat.

example.japanese: やめてください。
example.english: Please stop.

example.japanese: このえんぴつを使(つか)ってください。
example.english: Please use this pencil.

example.japanese: 電車(でんしゃ)で来(き)てください。
example.english: Please come by train.

synonym.explanation: please, could you please
(please) try to, (please) look
please do (honorific)
Won't you, Could you please (humble request)
Command to do
Please do for me (casual request)

english_grammar.title: ～ないで下(くだ)さい
english_grammar.explanation: Please don't (polite request)
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ないで］+ ください Politeness Levels
english_grammar.attention: In casual speech, ください can be omitted, resulting in the request finishing in で
english_grammar.about: ないでください is an expression that is used to politely ask someone 'not' to do something. It is a combination of the casual negative form of a verb, the で particle, and ください (the conjunctive form of くださる). これは誰(だれ)にも言(い)わないでください。Please don't tell this to anyone. そこには座(すわ)らないでください。Please don't sit there. ください is classified as honorific language, a type of polite speech that is used to refer to the actions of other people. The ください form of くださる is used almost exclusively for making requests. くださる is the honorific language equivalent of くれる.In friendly conversation, ください may be omitted from this expression, and the で form itself can be used as a very casual way of saying 'please don't do (A)'. それ、お兄(にい)ちゃんのだから、食(た)べないで。Because that's my older brother's, please don't eat it. 後(あと)で電話(でんわ)するから寝(ね)ないでよ。Because I'm going to call you later, please don't sleep. Caution Although ください is the polite form of くれる, ください is considered the base form of this phrase, and ないでくれ (the conjunctive form of くれる) would be considered far too casual in most situations.

example.japanese: 行(い)かないでください。
example.english: Please don’t go.

example.japanese: ここでサッカーをしないでください。
example.english: Please don’t play soccer here.

example.japanese: 泣(な)かないでください。
example.english: Please don’t cry.

example.japanese: 一人(ひとり)にしないでください。
example.english: Please don’t leave me alone.

example.japanese: それを食(た)べないでください。
example.english: Please don’t eat that.

synonym.explanation: Without doing, Not ~ and ~
Do not, Don't (prohibitive)
(Please) do not (for me), Casual request

antonym.explanation: To do something for someone (usually you)
Won't you, Could you please (humble request)

english_grammar.title: ～てはいけない
english_grammar.explanation: Must not, May not
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］+ は + いけない
english_grammar.about: てはいけない is used in Japanese to express that (A) 'cannot', or 'must not' be done. It is the combination of a verb in て form, the は particle, and the negative potential form of 行(い)く (to be able to go). In this way, it literally means '(A) cannot/is not able to go'. タクシーの扉(とびら)を自分(じぶん)で開(あ)けてはいけない。You must not open the taxi door by yourself. 子供(こども)の前(まえ)でタバコを吸(す)ってはいけません。You must not smoke cigarettes in front of children. Although は can be dropped from many phrases and expressions, the は in this particular grammar point is usually not. This is because いけない would then become the second action in a sequence of events (the usual function of て form). However, to make this more casual, ては is often changed to ちゃ (ては becomes ちゃ), or じゃ (では becomes じゃ), as this is easier to say. 危(あぶ)ない場所(ばしょ)に行(い)っちゃいけない。You must not go to dangerous places. 旗(はた)を踏(ふ)んじゃいけないよ。You must not step on a flag. Caution Apart from いけない; ならない and だめ are also frequently used to get across the same meaning. However, they are used in different situations.いけない - Fairly neutral. Used in both spoken and written language.ならない - Fairly formal. Used mostly in written language.だめ - Very casual. Used almost exclusively in spoken language.

example.japanese: そこに入(はい)ってはいけない。
example.english: You must not go in there.

example.japanese: クジラを食(た)べてはいけない。
example.english: We must not eat whale.

example.japanese: このビルに入(はい)ってはいけない。
example.english: You must not go into this building.

example.japanese: 晩(ばん)ごはんの前(まえ)に、お菓子(かし)を食(た)べてはいけない。
example.english: You must not eat candy before dinner.

example.japanese: この池(いけ)で泳(およ)いではいけません。
example.english: You must not swim in this pond.

synonym.explanation: must not, cannot, should not
should not, must not , ought not to
don't have to
do not, must not, should not, cannot (べからざる)

english_grammar.title: なくてはいけない
english_grammar.explanation: Must do, Have to do
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］+ なくては + いけない Verb［ない］+ なくちゃ + いけない
english_grammar.attention: Also used to express duty or necessity.If you are curious about なくて conjugation
english_grammar.about: Much like てはいけない, なくてはいけない states that something 'must not' be done. However, this is where the similarities end. なくてはいけない is an example of a double negative in Japanese, and actually has the meaning '(A) must be done', or 'must do (A)'. While this grammar point is usually translated as 'must do', the literal translation is 'must not, not do (A)'. This double 'not' is where many learners have difficulties. いけない simply means 'cannot go', and comes from the negative potential form of 行(い)く. To use this structure, simply create the negative form of a verb, and then convert ない to なく (the conjunctive form of an い-Adjective), followed by て. After this, は is added, and then finally いけない. 今日(きょう)は９時(じ)に寝(ね)なくてはいけない。 Today, I must sleep at 9. (I must not, not do it) 明日(あした)は彼女(かのじょ)の誕生日(たんじょうび)プレゼントを買(か)わなくてはいけない。 I must buy my girlfriend's birthday present tomorrow. (I must not, not do it) 明日(あした)は友達(ともだち)が来(く)るから、家(いえ)の掃除(そうじ)をしなくてはいけない。 Since my friend is coming tomorrow, I must clean my house. (I must not, not do it) いけない is considered to be the most common structure used with the 'must', and 'must not' grammar points, and is natural in both speech, and written Japanese. Alternatively, ならない may be used in formal speech, but is much better suited to writing. だめ is also acceptable, but much more casual than either いけない or ならない. 朝食後(ちょうしょくご)に薬(くすり)を飲(の)まなくてはならない。 After breakfast, I must drink my medicine. 野菜(やさい)も食(た)べなくてはダメだよ。 You must also eat vegetables. Caution The ては in なくては is often converted to ちゃ, as this is easier to say. なくちゃ may then be followed by いけない, or いけない may be omitted, without changing the meaning. 土曜日(どようび)も会社(かいしゃ)に行(い)かなくちゃいけない。 I gotta go to the company on Saturdays too. 今日(きょう)はスーパーに行(い)かなくちゃ。 Today, I gotta go to the supermarket. These casual structures are very similar to words like 'gotta' in English.

example.japanese: テストの前(まえ)に、よく寝(ね)なくてはいけない。
example.english: Before a test, you must sleep well.

example.japanese: １２月(がつ)になってから、暖房(だんぼう)をつけなくてはいけない。
example.english: Once December comes, you have to turn on the heating.

example.japanese: 来週(らいしゅう)は試合(しあい)があるので、たくさん練習(れんしゅう)しなくてはいけない。
example.english: Because I have a game next week, I must train a lot.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)はいい天気(てんき)だから、外(そと)で遊(あそ)ばなくてはいけない。
example.english: Because the weather is nice today, I have to play outside.

example.japanese: まだやりたいことがあるけど、もう寝(ね)なくてはいけない。

english_grammar.title: なくてはならない
english_grammar.explanation: Must do, Have to do
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］+ なくては + ならない Verb［ない］+ なくちゃ + ならない
english_grammar.attention: Also used to express duty or necessity.If you are curious about なくて conjugation
english_grammar.about: Much like てはならない, なくてはならない states that something 'must not' be done. However, this is where the similarities end. なくてはならない is an example of a double negative in Japanese, and actually has the meaning '(A) must be done', or 'must do (A)'.While this grammar point is usually translated as 'must do', the literal translation is 'must not, not do (A)'. This double 'not' is where many learners have difficulties. ならない simply means 'cannot become', and comes from the negative form of なる.To use this structure, simply create the negative form of a verb, and then convert ない to なく (the conjunctive form of an い-Adjective), followed by て. After this, は is added, and then finally ならない. 私(わたし)は次(つぎ)のバス停(てい)で降(お)りなくてはならないです。I have to get off at the next bus stop. (I must not, not do it) トムはタカにお金(かね)を返(かえ)さなくてはならないです。Tom must give back money to Taka. (He must not, not do it) 今日(きょう)は漢字(かんじ)の勉強(べんきょう)をしなくてはならないです。I have to study kanji today. (I must not, not do it) ならない is considered to be the most formal structure out of ならない, いけない, and だめ. It is regularly used in formal writing, or semi-formal/formal speech. いけない (the most common variation) and だめ (the most casual variation) are also acceptable in many situations. レポートを書(か)かなくてはいけない。I must write a paper. 食(た)べる前(まえ)に手(て)を洗(あら)わなくてはダメ。You must wash your hands before you eat. Caution The ては in なくては is often shortened to ちゃ, as this is easier to say. なくちゃ may then be followed by ならない. However, due to ならない being quite formal, なくちゃ (a casual structure) will not be used with ならない on a regular basis. It is more common to see なくちゃ paired with いけない, or だめ. 今日(きょう)は沢山(たくさん)走(はし)ったからシャワーを浴(あ)びなくちゃならない。Because I ran a lot today, I must take a shower. バーベキューに肉(にく)を持(も)って行(い)かなくちゃいけない。I gotta bring meat to the barbeque. 冬(ふゆ)になる前(まえ)にキャンプに行(い)かなくちゃだめだね。We gotta go camping before it becomes winter, right? These casual structures are very similar to words like 'gotta' in English.

example.japanese: 毎日(まいにち)勉強(べんきょう)をしなくてはならない。
example.english: You must do your studies every day.

example.japanese: ３時(じ)半(はん)までに、銀行(ぎんこう)に行(い)かなくてはならない。
example.english: By 3:30, I have to go to the bank.

example.english: It's already two?! I haven't eaten my bento yet. I have to eat.

example.japanese: 京都(きょうと)で電車(でんしゃ)を降(お)りなくてはならない。
example.english: I must get off the train in Kyoto.

example.japanese: 君(きみ)が決(き)めなくてはならないよ。
example.english: You have to decide.

english_grammar.title: ～た方(ほう)がいい
english_grammar.explanation: It'd be better to, Should do
english_grammar.structure: Verb［た］+ 方 + が + いい
english_grammar.about: In Japanese, there are several ways to express that something 'should' be done. たほうがいい is one of the most common, especially when giving advice. This expression uses the past tense of a verb grouped with 方(ほう), the particle が, and the い-Adjective, いい. 食(た)べる前(まえ)に手(て)を洗(あら)った方(ほう)がいいよ。It would be better if you washed your hands before you eat. (You should wash your hands) 警察(けいさつ)に言(い)った方(ほう)がいい。It would be better if you told the police. (You should tell the police) As 方(ほう) can be translated closely to 'way', or 'direction', this expression is suggesting that one specific choice is simply the better 'way'.This expression is quite direct, and can imply that there may be some sort of negative consequence if (A) is not done. In that respect, this phrase could also be translated as 'It would be better if you did (A)'.たほうがいい may also be used with the base (dictionary) form of a verb, but will sound more like a general opinion in those cases, rather than giving advice. 高(たか)いけど、美味(おい)しいお肉(にく)を食(た)べる方(ほう)がいい。Even though it is expensive, it is better to eat delicious meat. (This is a general opinion) 食器(しょっき)はすぐ片付(かたづ)ける方(ほう)がいい。It is better to put away the dishes as soon as possible. (This is a general opinion) Caution Because this phrase is quite direct, it would be better to use a more polite expression like ばいい, if giving general advice.

example.japanese: お医者(いしゃ)さんに聞(き)いた方(ほう)がいい。
example.english: It would be better to ask a doctor.

example.japanese: 帰(かえ)った方(ほう)がいい。
example.english: It'd be better to go home.

example.japanese: 朝(あさ)ごはんを食(た)べた方(ほう)がいい。

example.japanese: 自分(じぶん)の皿(さら)を洗(あら)った方(ほう)がいい。
example.english: It would be better to wash your own dishes.

example.japanese: それは返(かえ)した方(ほう)がいいだろう。
example.english: It would be better to return that, wouldn't it.

english_grammar.title: ない方(ほう)がいい
english_grammar.explanation: It'd be better not to, Shouldn't do
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］+ 方 + が + いい
english_grammar.about: Like たほうがいい, ないほうがいい is used in Japanese for giving advice. However, this expression suggests that it is better 'not' to do something.This phrase is constructed by using the negative tense of a verb grouped with 方(ほう), the particle が, and the い-Adjective, いい. あそこは危(あぶ)ないから、行(い)かない方(ほう)がいいよ。Because that place over there is dangerous, it would be better not to go there. それは触(さわ)らない方(ほう)がいい。It would be better not to mess with that. (触(さわ)る has the nuance of 'mess around with', whereas 触(ふ)れる is closer to simply 'touch') As 方(ほう) can be translated closely to 'way', or 'direction', this expression is suggesting that one specific choice is simply the better 'way'.This expression is quite direct, and can imply that there may be some sort of negative consequence if the (A) verb is done. 虫(むし)が入(はい)ってくるから、窓(まど)を開(あ)けない方(ほう)がいいよ。Because bugs will come in, it would be better not to open the window. (The negative consequence is that bugs will come inside)

example.japanese: これはお兄(にい)ちゃんが買(か)ったピザだから、食(た)べない方(ほう)がいいよ。
example.english: Since this is pizza my brother bought, it would be better not to eat it.

english_grammar.title: なくちゃ・なきゃ
english_grammar.explanation: Must do, Have to do
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］ + なきゃ(1) + いけない Verb［ない］ + なくちゃ+ いけない (1) なけりゃ
english_grammar.attention: Common abbreviations
english_grammar.about: なくちゃ (short forなくては), and なきゃ (short for なければ) are the most common colloquial abbreviations used to convey that something 'must', or 'has to' be done.Like てはいけない (must not), なくてはいけない (must), and なくてはならない (must), these abbreviation forms can be followed by いけない, ならない, or だめ. However, they are usually omitted, without changing the meaning.Structures like this are referred to as spoken/colloquial language. These casual variations can come across in a very similar way to words like 'gotta' in English. 今日(きょう)は家(いえ)の掃除(そうじ)をしなきゃだめだから、遊(あそ)ばない。Since I must tidy up the house today, I won't hang out. 野菜(やさい)を食(た)べなくちゃいけない。I must eat vegetables. あっ、洗濯(せんたく)をしなきゃ。Oops, I gotta do laundry. 宿題(しゅくだい)をしなくちゃ。I gotta do my homework. In these examples, a variety of forms have been used naturally. There is no 'most natural' form, and it will often depend on the speaker as to which they choose.As with almost all grammatical structures, the shortest variations (not including いけない, etc.) are the most casual/used the most often.There are several other ways that these common abbreviations can appear based on region, or even an individual speaker's preference. An example of this is なけりゃ, which is a (very) casual form of なければ. お前(まえ)がやらなけりゃだめだろ。You must do it! (Why aren't you doing what you must do?) In this example, we can see that some of these less common variations are used specifically by certain genders (in general). なけりゃ itself tends to be used by male speakers, and may be considered a bit rougher than なきゃ, or なくちゃ, which can be used by anybody.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)を勉強(べんきょう)しなくちゃいけない。
example.english: You must study Japanese.

example.english: Since there is a test tomorrow I must study more.

english_grammar.title: や
english_grammar.explanation: Things like, And the like
english_grammar.structure: Noun + や + Noun
english_grammar.attention: Cannot be used after verbs, unlike とか
english_grammar.about: や is a particle that has several different roles in Japanese, with the most common being as an adverbial particle. や is used similarly to と as 'and', but rather than listing specific things in a group, it lists 'things like (A)'.や is always used to group nouns, and simply comes directly after them. このスーパーには果物(くだもの)や弁当(べんとう)がある。This super market has things like fruit and bento's. 飛行機(ひこうき)や船(ふね)は大(おお)きいです。Things like planes and ships are big. To compare how と and や are different, imagine that there is a bowl of fruit. In this bowl there are apples, oranges, and peaches. If と is used to list the apples and oranges, it would give the listener the impression that there are no peaches. This is called an 'exhaustive' list, meaning that all possibilities should be listed. However, if や is used, the listener would know that there are other things in the bowl apart from the apples and oranges. In this way, や is a better choice when you want to say 'and', but don't want to limit the group that you are listing. 昨日(きのう)の飲(の)み会(かい)でビールとワインを飲(の)んだ。Last night at the party, I drank beer and wine. (Only beer and wine) 昨日(きのう)の飲(の)み会(かい)でビールやワインを飲(の)んだ。Last night at the party, I drank things like beer and wine. (There were other things, but it was mainly beer and wine) Caution や cannot be used after verb phrases. This is done with たり, or とか.

example.japanese: コンビニでお水(みず)やおかしを買(か)った。
example.english: I bought things like water and snacks at the convenience store.

example.japanese: ひらがなやカタカナや漢字(かんじ)があります。
example.english: There are things like Hiragana and Katakana and Kanji.

example.english: I went to places like Kyoto and Tokyo and Osaka.

example.japanese: サッカーやテニスをするのが好(す)き。
example.english: I like playing sports like soccer and tennis.

example.japanese: 果物(くだもの)や野菜(やさい)を食(た)べてください。
example.english: Please eat things like fruits and vegetables.

english_grammar.title: ～たことがある
english_grammar.explanation: Have done before
english_grammar.structure: Verb［た］+ こと + が + ある Verb［た］+ こと + が + ない
english_grammar.about: たことがある is a set expression in Japanese that is used for saying that 'there has been a time that I have done (A)'.The auxiliary verb た will be added to the verb indicating what you have done, followed by こと - が - ある. Like の, こと is regularly used for nominalization (creating a noun-like phrase). However, の cannot replace こと in this particular grammar pattern. 富士山(ふじさん)へ行(い)ったことがある？Have you ever been to Mt. Fuji before? 私(わたし)はお菓子(かし)を買(か)ったことが無(な)い。I have never bought snacks. From these examples, we can see that ない (the negative equivalent of ある) may also be used, when you want to express that you have 'never' done something.Caution Just like English, many set phrases cannot be adjusted in Japanese (in the same way that こと cannot be swapped with の in this expression).Fun FactIn expressions where こと is followed by a verb phrase, の may not be used. When used for nominalization, の is almost always followed by a noun or adjective phrase. Here are some examples. 彼(かれ)は踊(おど)ることができる。He can do things like dance. 来週(らいしゅう)は休(やす)みだから旅行(りょこう)へ行(い)くことにする。Because I have no work next week, I have decided to go traveling. 今日(きょう)は帰(かえ)るのが遅(おそ)くなることになる。Today, I will end up coming home late.

example.japanese: ここでサッカーをしたことがありますか。
example.english: Have you ever played soccer here before?

example.japanese: 日本(にほん)に行(い)ったことがありますか。
example.english: Have you ever been to Japan before?

example.japanese: この本(ほん)を読(よ)んだことがある。
example.english: I have read this book before.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の家(いえ)を見(み)たことがありますか。
example.english: Have you ever seen my house before?

example.japanese: ６時(じ)前(まえ)に起(お)きたことがない。
example.english: I have never woken up before six o'clock.

english_grammar.title: ～ている ③
english_grammar.explanation: Has/have done, Is ~ing (repetition)
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］+ いる Verb［て］+ る Verb［て］ + とる
english_grammar.attention: ている is often shortened to てる. This applies to all tenses, including てる, てて, てた, and even てます
english_grammar.about: The 3rd most common meaning (in no specific order) that ている is used for in Japanese, is the repetition of common activities. This is for things that are not 'continuing', but happen so often that they are considered to be continuous (like going to work, having a hobby, and similar things). 私(わたし)は毎日(まいにち)ギターを弾(ひ)いている。I play my guitar everyday. (This is a hobby of the speaker) 毎晩(まいばん)９時(じ)に寝(ね)ている。I sleep at 9 every night. (This is a habit of the speaker) 彼(かれ)は学校(がっこう)で働(はたら)いている。He works at a school. (This is a regular activity of the speaker) Due to いる being one of the verbs for 'existing' in Japanese, the ている form is closer to 'continuing to exist in a specific state', rather than (A)~ing in English. In this construction, it can be thought of as 'to be existing in the state of performing a regular activity'.Caution With this meaning of ている, to make it easier to understand, expressions of time are often used. This can be things like 毎日(まいにち), 毎晩(まいばん), 毎週(まいしゅう), and similar phrases.Fun FactRegularly in novels, manga, and specifically some parts of Japan, とる may be used instead of ている with the same meaning. 俺(おれ)、毎日(まいにち)勉強(べんきょう)しとる。I study every day.

example.japanese: 俺(おれ)は毎週(まいしゅう)金曜日(きんようび)の夜(よる)にスーパーに行(い)っているのだ。
example.english: I go to the supermarket every Friday night. (I am going...)

example.japanese: ふうたろうさんは毎日(まいにち)みくさんと一緒(いっしょ)に歴史(れきし)を勉強(べんきょう)している。
example.english: Fuutarou-san studies history every day with Miku. (Fuutarou-san is studying...)

example.japanese: 魔王(まおう)さまはバーガークイーンで働(はたら)いています。
example.english: The Demon Lord works at Burger Queen. (The Demon Lord is working...)

example.japanese: この公園(こうえん)では毎週末(まいしゅうまつ)多(おお)くの人(ひと)が走(はし)っています。
example.english: Many people run in this park every weekend. (Many people are running...)

example.japanese: どうしてスティーブンはいつも黒(くろ)いタートルネックを着(き)ているのですか。
example.english: Why does Steven always wear a black turtleneck? (Steven is wearing...)

english_grammar.title: ～て (Adjectives and Nouns)
english_grammar.explanation: And... (conjunctive)
english_grammar.structure: ［い］Adjective［い］ + く + て おもしろい + く + て 新しい + く + て ［な］Adjective + で しずか + で 好き + で Noun + で 先生 + で 仕事 + で Exceptions: いい→よくて
english_grammar.about: The て form of an い-Adjective, or で form of a noun (or な-Adjective) is exactly the same as the て form of a verb, in that it carries the meaning of 'and', and is used for linking. It will allow us to list multiple qualities/traits of something.For い-Adjectives, we will need to change the last い to く (the form used for conjugation), and then simply add て.For nouns and な-Adjectives, we will need to add で to the base form (not な or だ). このパソコンは新(あたら)しくて早(はや)い。This computer is new and fast. あの自転車(じてんしゃ)は便利(べんり)で軽(かる)い。That bicycle is useful and light. 音楽(おんがく)を作(つく)るのは仕事(しごと)で趣味(しゅみ)だ。Making music is both work, and my hobby. It should be noted that て and で are different structures here. て is the same conjunction particle that is used with verbs (meaning that い-Adjectives are similar to verbs), while で is actually a form of だ that is used for conjugation. It is the same で as the one that is used in the formal version of だ, である. Which we will learn later.Caution Like other て forms (ている 1, ている 2, and ている 3), the て (or で) form of other words can have several possible meanings. These meanings are as follows.Linking - Like 'and' in English.Reasons - Like 'with (A)', or 'because of (A)' in English.Manner - Like 'to do (B) in an (A) way' in English. あの人(ひと)は綺麗(きれい)で優(やさ)しい。That person is beautiful and nice. 大雨(おおあめ)でバスが止(と)まりました。The bus stopped with rain. (With rain as the reason) 私(わたし)はご飯(はん)を急(いそ)いで食(た)べる。I eat food in a hurry. Caution As with all other conjugations of いい, remember that it will be よくて, and not いくて.

example.japanese: 新(あたら)しい → 新(あたら)しくて
example.english: New → New and...

example.japanese: 大(おお)きい → 大(おお)きくて
example.english: Big → Big and...

example.japanese: 嫌(きら)い → 嫌(きら)いで

example.japanese: 静(しず)か → 静(しず)かで
example.english: Quiet → Quiet and...

example.japanese: 病気(びょうき) → 病気(びょうき)で
example.english: Disease → Disease and...

synonym.explanation: And..., Both and (conjunctive)
and・and so, due to, because of, since, conjunctive
