english_grammar.title: 頃(ころ)
english_grammar.explanation: Around, About
english_grammar.structure: Noun + ごろ, Noun + の + ころ
english_grammar.about: ころ, or ごろ (the colloquial pronunciation) is a word which carries the meaning of 'around', or 'about'. It is utilized in a similar way to くらい, but has a few differences. When ごろ is used, it will need to be attached to the end of a noun, or a noun followed by の. 11時(じ)頃(ごろ)に帰(かえ)ってくる。I will be home around 11. 私(わたし)は大学生(だいがくせい)の頃(ころ)に富士山(ふじさん)を登(のぼ)りました。I climbed Mount Fuji around when I was a college student. The main difference between ころ and くらい is that ころ can be (and often is) used to express a broad point in time, while くらい is limited to expressing timeframes that are more specific. 子供(こども)のくらいはよく親(おや)と動物園(どうぶつえん)へ行(い)きました。When I was approximately a child, I often went to the zoo with my parents. (Unnatural Japanese, as being a child is a broad time frame) 子供(こども)のころはよく親(おや)と動物園(どうぶつえん)へ行(い)きました。Around when I was a child, I often went to the zoo with my parents. (Natural Japanese) Conversely, ころ will not be used when expressing approximate distances/lengths. 2メートルくらいの所(ところ)に印(しるし)をつけてください。Please make a mark around the 2 meter point. (Natural Japanese, as an approximation is being discussed) 2メートルごろの所(ところ)に印(しるし)をつけてください。Please make a mark within the span of 2 meters. (Unnatural Japanese, as the listener would think that marking a line anywhere within the two meter space is fine) The primary reason for this is that ころ expresses a span of something, while くらい expresses an extent. In this way, ころ could also be translated as 'within the span of (A)', while くらい is closer to 'at the point of (A)'. As an easier way to think about it, if we have a one meter ruler, ころ could express anywhere between 1 to 100 centimeters (the span), but くらい can only express somewhere between 90 and 100 centimeters (the extent).Just like with English, if the 'time' expressed is very specific, then either くらい or ころ could be used naturally. This is due to the 'span', and the 'extent' already being something that is a 'precise point' in these cases. 今日(きょう)は12時(じ)くらいに帰(かえ)る。I will be home around 12. 今日(きょう)は12時(じ)頃(ごろ)に帰(かえ)る。I will be home around 12. Caution The kanji form of 頃(ころ) is also very common, so it is worth learning as soon as possible, to save any confusion while reading.

example.japanese: ８時(じ)ごろに帰(かえ)りました。
example.english: I went home around eight o'clock.

example.japanese: 東京(とうきょう)に行(い)った友達(ともだち)は今(いま)ごろ着(つ)いているでしょう。
example.english: My friend who went to Tokyo is probably arriving around now...

example.japanese: 月曜日(げつようび)の夜(よる)ごろに、雨(あめ)が降(ふ)ります。
example.english: It will rain around Monday night.

example.japanese: 何時(なんじ)ごろ帰(かえ)って来(く)る？
example.english: Around what time will you come home?

example.japanese: 11時(じ)ごろに帰(かえ)って来(く)るから、ご飯(はん)はいらないです。
example.english: I will get home about 11, so I don't need dinner.

synonym.explanation: About, Approximately
When, At the time of

english_grammar.title: 後(あと)で
english_grammar.explanation: After, Later
english_grammar.structure: Verb［た］+ あとで Noun + の + あとで 後で + Phrase Verb + のは + あとで
english_grammar.about: In Japanese, あとで is a combination of the noun 後(あと) (behind), and the particle で (with). When these words are linked, they form an adverbial phrase which is used to express 'after', or 'later'. As with で's standard meaning of 'with', あとで is simply highlighting that something will happen, 'with' the 'after/behind' part of something.To use あとで, attach it to the end of any past-tense verb, noun followed by の, or verb followed by のは (nominalization). 勉強(べんきょう)するのは食(た)べた後(あと)でいいよ。You can study after you finish eating. (With the time after eating) 仕事(しごと)の後(あと)で、飲(の)み会(かい)に行(い)きます。I will go to the party after work. (With the time after work) コピーを取(と)るのは後(あと)でいいから、今(いま)は上司(じょうし)に電話(でんわ)して。Since it's fine to make the copies later, please call the boss right now. (With the time after calling the boss) Fun FactThe reason that 後(あと) is translated as both 'after', and 'behind', is because sequences of events in Japanese behave similarly to a train. When the head of the train (one action) passes a specific point, there are still potentially many carriages (other actions) coming 'after', or 'behind' it.後(あと)で may also be used to alter the meaning of an entire phrase, by appearing at the front. This nuance is just that (A) will happen (at some point) after now. 後(あと)で洗濯(せんたく)もの干(ほ)してね。Please hang the laundry later.

example.japanese: 勉強(べんきょう)した後(あと)で、遊(あそ)んでもいいよ。
example.english: It is ok to play after you study.

example.japanese: 食事(しょくじ)の後(あと)で、お皿(さら)を洗(あら)わなくてはいけない。
example.english: I have to wash dishes after a meal.

example.japanese: また後(あと)で、会(あ)いましょう。
example.english: Let's meet again later.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)はアルバイトの後(あと)で、疲(つか)れている。
example.english: I am tired after my part time job.

example.japanese: 後(あと)で買(か)い物(もの)に行(い)きます。
example.english: I will go shopping later.

synonym.explanation: once...is done, once...happens, after doing
When, From when, Just when, If
after, upon
the former・the latter, the first・the second

english_grammar.title: ～ていた
english_grammar.explanation: Was doing ~
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ている］+ た
english_grammar.about: To convey that '(A) was happening', or that somebody 'was doing (A)' in Japanese, ていた (or ていました) will be used. ていた is a construction which uses the conjunction particle て, and the ichidan verb いる (to exist), in its past tense form いた. シャワーが壊(こわ)れていたから2日間(かかん)もシャワーを浴(あ)びれなかった。Because the shower was broken, I was not able to take a shower for 2 days. (Was in the state of being broken) 昨日(きのう)は夜遅(よるおそ)くまでカラオケで歌(うた)っていたので、のどが痛(いた)いです。I was singing until late last night at karaoke, so my throat hurts. (Was doing karaoke) 昔(むかし)はパーマをかけていました。In the past, I used to have my hair permed. (Was getting perms) 窓(まど)が割(わ)れていました。The window was smashed. (Was in the state of being smashed) Sometimes ていた is used to express things that are still ongoing, but the speaker is not sure about, or would like to politely advise the listener about. This is very similar to the way in which English uses '(A) was doing (B)'. お父(ちち)さんがその椅子(いす)に座(すわ)っていたから、こっちに座(すわ)りな。Dad was sitting there, so sit here please. In this example, although the action of 'sitting' is not finished, we can imagine that the speaker is suggesting that 'dad was sitting here, and he still is, but he just went to get a drink'.The same kind of sentence could be used when the speaker has walked away from where their dad was sitting, and doesn't actually know if he is still sitting there or not.

example.japanese: 勉強(べんきょう)をしていたけど、今(いま)は休(やす)んでいる。
example.english: I was studying but am taking a break right now.

example.japanese: 音楽(おんがく)を聴(き)いていたから、電話(でんわ)が聞(き)こえなかった。
example.english: Because I was listening to music I couldn't hear the phone.

example.japanese: 昨日(きのう)１時(じ)ごろに寝(ね)ていた。
example.english: Yesterday around one o'clock I was sleeping.

example.japanese: ４時間(じかん)も椅子(いす)に座(すわ)っていたから、お尻(しり)が痛(いた)い。
example.english: I was sitting for as much as four hours, so my butt hurts.

example.japanese: お母(かあ)さんが帰(かえ)って来(き)た時(とき)私(わたし)はご飯(はん)を作(つく)っていた。
example.english: When my mom came home I was making food.

synonym.explanation: And, Then (linking events)
う - Verbs (past tense)

english_grammar.title: に (Frequency)
english_grammar.explanation: Times (in each time period), Every, Frequency of
english_grammar.structure: Timeframe + に + Number of Times
english_grammar.about: When the case marking particle に is used, sometimes it has the nuance of 'frequency'. This means that it can be utilized to describe how often something happens/is done. In this grammatical construction, the 'time frame' is followed by に, then followed by the number of times that you would like to say that something happens.In this way, に keeps its regular nuance of being a 'goal', or 'destination', within which something else takes place. 私(わたし)は一(いっ)ヶ月(かげつ)に一回(いっかい)友達(ともだち)と遊園地(ゆうえんち)に行(い)く。I go to the amusement park with my friend every month. (One time per month) 彼(かれ)は一週間(いっしゅうかん)に2回(かい)しか歯(は)を磨(みが)かないから、口(くち)が臭(くさ)い。Because he only brushes his teeth twice every week, his mouth stinks. Caution This use of に should not be confused with で in relation to time. When で is used for 'time', it is expressing the amount of time that is required to do something, or how much time something is expected to take. It is not used for frequency. 2年間(ねんかん)で50万円(まんえん)も貯(た)めた。In two years, I saved up ￥500,000. (Natural Japanese, as this expresses the amount of time that something took) Due to this, you can think of に as marking a portion (or portions) of time inside of a larger space of time, within which something happens. However, で marks a whole space of time, within which something can be/is completed.

example.japanese: 一年(いちねん)に三回(さんかい)ぐらい海外旅行(かいがいりょこう)に行(い)く。
example.english: I take trips abroad about three times in a year.

example.japanese: 一日(いちにち)に六時間(ろくじかん)は寝(ね)る必要(ひつよう)がある。
example.english: It is necessary to sleep for six hours every day.

example.japanese: 一時間(いちじかん)に十本(じゅっぽん)の電車(でんしゃ)がある。
example.english: There are ten trains every hour.

example.japanese: 公務員(こうむいん)は一年(いちねん)に一回(いっかい)ボーナスをもらう。
example.english: Public servants get a bonus every year. [once each year]

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はタバコを1日(にち)に40本(ぽん)ぐらい吸(す)う。
example.english: He smokes about 40 cigarettes every day. [40 each day]

synonym.explanation: Each, Every, At intervals of
repeated at intervals, every other, every, at intervals of

english_grammar.title: 到頭(とうとう)
english_grammar.explanation: Finally, After all
english_grammar.structure: とうとう + Phrase
english_grammar.about: とうとう is an adverb that is used to express that something 'finally' happens. In Japanese, there are a few ways to do this, but とうとう is one of the more common. Coming from the kanji 到頭(とうとう), this structure literally means 到 (to arrive at), 頭 (the head of/crux of) something. Due to this, 'finally', and 'after all' are the two most common translations of とうとう. Like many other adverbs in Japanese, とうとう is often used at the beginning of a phrase/sentence. とうとうお前(まえ)が大学生(だいがくせい)か...So you're finally a college student... (After all this time, have you finally become a college student?) とうとうロシアに行(い)く。I will finally go to Russia. (After all this time, I can finally go to Russia) While とうとう is written in hiragana the majority of the time, knowing the kanji will help when trying to remember the expression's nuance. That nuance is that something has 'ended', usually after some sort of long journey/effort.This adverb may be used to express either positive or negative outcomes, as it focuses more on the time required to achieve the result, rather than the result being good or bad. とうとう夏休(なつやす)みだ！It's finally summer break! (Good result) とうとう夏休(なつやす)みが終(お)わる日(ひ)が来(き)た。The day that summer break ends has finally arrived. (Bad result) Caution とうとう is not used in situations where you expect something to happen/start, but there has not actually been a period of time in which some sort of effort was made to achieve a result.A good example of this is the changing of seasons. You might want to say 'finally, it's summer!', but this is not something that anyone has done anything to achieve. Rather, it came naturally. In these cases, いよいよ will be used, and has the nuance of 'finally', or 'at last' (in relation to something starting/happening). いよいよ夏(なつ)来(き)た。Finally, summer has come. (Natural Japanese)

example.japanese: とうとう休(やす)みだ。
example.english: Finally it is my day off.

example.japanese: とうとう彼(かれ)は注射(ちゅうしゃ)を打(う)った。
example.english: He administered the shot after all. | He finally administered the shot.

example.japanese: それをとうとう捨(す)てた。
example.english: I finally threw that away. | I threw that away after all.

example.japanese: とうとう漢字(かんじ)の勉強(べんきょう)ができる。
example.english: I can finally study kanji.

example.japanese: とうとう日本(にほん)に着(つ)いた。
example.english: I have finally arrived in Japan.

synonym.explanation: at last, finally, more and more
finally, at last

english_grammar.title: より
english_grammar.explanation: More than, Over
english_grammar.structure: Noun/Verb + より + Adjective
english_grammar.about: In N5, we learned about the use of より that is seen when making comparisons in より～のほうが. However, in this lesson, we will take a look at how this case marking particlecan be used by itself. When used alone, this particle expresses that (A) (a noun or verb) is being compared to (B) (a noun or verb that is regularly paired with an adjective). The word that より is directly attached to will always be 'less than' the comparison being made. However, the overall expression is used to describe that (B) is 'more' (something) than (A). パンダはバナナより重(おも)い。Pandas are heavier than bananas. 太陽(たいよう)はロウソクより明(あか)るい。The sun is brighter than a candle. Caution In many textbooks, より is taught as meaning 'more', but the word that より is attached to will actually be the thing that is 'less' (something). The word/quote that has が attached to it will be the thing that is 'more' (adjective). This is particularly confusing when より is not directly attached to a word, something which is common in casual spoken language. これがより高(たか)いものになります。This is the thing that would be more expensive. (Compared to everything else that is here) In this sentence, because the が is attached to これ, これ is the thing that is 'more expensive'. As より is not actually directly connected to any other word, it therefore means that これ is expensive, compared to 'other things'. When you see より like this, just pretend that it says 'other things' before it.

example.japanese: あなたの絵(え)は私(わたし)の絵(え)より上手(じょうず)。
example.english: Your paintings are better than mine.

example.japanese: 月曜日(げつようび)より日曜日(にちようび)がいい。
example.english: Sunday is better than Monday.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)は英語(えいご)より話(はな)しにくい。
example.english: Japanese is harder to speak than English.

example.japanese: いつも飲(の)んでいる水(みず)より好(す)き。
example.english: I like this (drink) more than the water that I usually drink.

example.japanese: スポーツをするより、ゲームの方(ほう)が楽(たの)しい。
example.english: Video games are more exciting than sports.

synonym.explanation: is not as…as, isn't... like..., not to the extent of...
To be more ~ than ~
...is more of a... than a..., rather than saying that...
more than, no less than, even more
for sure, for certain, even more so, underlined/bolded text
more than (or equal to), over・(and) above, any more・greater, exceeding

english_grammar.title: 毎(ごと)に
english_grammar.explanation: Each, Every, At intervals of
english_grammar.structure: Verb + ごとに Noun + ごとに
english_grammar.about: ごとに is an combination of the noun ごと, and the particle に. Together, they are used adverbially to express that something happens 'every (A)', or 'at intervals of (A)'. ごとに may be used after any verb (usually in non-past form), or noun. 私(わたし)は彼(かれ)に会(あ)うごとに、「何(なに)を食(た)べたい？」と聞(き)かれます。Everytime I see him, he asks me 'What do you want to eat?' 私(わたし)は3時間(じかん)ごとにお菓子(かし)を食(た)べます。I eat snacks every 3 hours. Although ごとに may be used after verbs, the most common use is with nouns, or phrases that finish with nouns.Caution ごと is the 訓読(くんよ)み (Japanese reading) of the kanji 毎(まい), which means 'every'. This fact will be important when trying to remember the difference between ごとに, and おきに, a similar grammar point which also means 'every', but focuses more on 'intervals'. Due to おきに focusing on the space between 'each', there are sentences where おきに and ごとに will have different meanings. 私(わたし)は一週間(いっしゅうかん)ごとに実家(じっか)に帰(かえ)ります。I go to my parents' home every week. (Every single one) 私(わたし)は一週間(いっしゅうかん)おきに実家(じっか)に帰(かえ)り ます。I go to my parents' home every other week. (Every single interval of one) Here, we can see that ごとに will mean 'every week', but おきに will mean 'every second week'. due to there being a 'one week interval' when おきに is used. To make things easier, these two expressions can be remembered in the following way.(A) ごとに = Every (A)(A) おきに = Every spaced repetition of (A)Fun FactMany native speakers make mistakes with the difference between おきに and ごとに, so there are quite a large number of people (especially in the younger generation) that will consider them completely interchangeable.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)は運転中(うんてんちゅう)、赤信号(あかしんごう)ごとに、携帯(けいたい)を見(み)る。
example.english: She looks at her phone at every red light while driving.

example.japanese: 出(で)かけるごとに忘(わす)れ物(もの)をする。
example.english: Every time I go out I forget something.

example.japanese: 夏(なつ)ごとにアメリカに帰(かえ)ります。
example.english: Every summer I go back to America.

example.japanese: 生徒(せいと)ごとに紙(かみ)を渡(わた)した。
example.english: I gave a paper to every student. [each]

example.japanese: 二日(ふつか)ごとに友達(ともだち)とサッカーをする。
example.english: I play soccer with my friend every two days.

synonym.explanation: Times (in each time period), Every, Frequency of
Almost every ~, Nearly every ~, On a ~ basis
each time, every time, whenever
repeated at intervals, every other, every, at intervals of
whenever, every time something happens

english_grammar.title: なるべく
english_grammar.explanation: As ~ as possible, Wherever practicable
english_grammar.structure: なるべく + (Action) Phrase
english_grammar.about: Combining 成(な)る (to become), and 可(べ)く (to be permissible), なるべく is an expression that literally means 'as each opportunity becomes permissible/presents itself'. This is often simply translated as 'as much as possible', or 'whenever possible'.なるべく (usually written in hiragana) is regularly used before an entire phrase, to express that (A) should happen as much as possible. 外(そと)に出(で)かけるときはなるべくドアのカギをかけてください。When you go out, lock your doors as often as possible. 仕事(しごと)で疲(つか)れていても、なるべく夕食(ゆうしょく)は食(た)べてください。Even if you are tired from work, please eat dinner whenever possible. Due to なるべく expressing the 'possibility', or 'having the opportunity' to do something, it will sound considerably softer/more polite than できるだけ. できるだけ is a similar expression which more directly states that something will be done 'to the full extent possible'. 明日(あした)はできるだけ早(はや)く来(き)てね。Tomorrow, please make sure to come as early as possible. 明日(あした)はなるべく早(はや)く来(き)てね。Tomorrow, please come as early as possible.

example.japanese: インフルエンザにかかった時(とき)は、なるべくゆっくり休(やす)むほうがいい。
example.english: When you catch the flu, you should rest as much as possible.

example.japanese: なるべく早(はや)めに連絡(れんらく)してください。
example.english: Please contact me as soon as possible.

example.japanese: なるべく正直(しょうじき)に話(はな)してください。
example.english: Please speak as honestly as possible.

example.japanese: 日本(にほん)に行(い)く前(まえ)になるべくお金(かね)を貯(た)めた方(ほう)がいい。
example.english: Before going to Japan you had better save as much money as possible.

example.japanese: 運転(うんてん)している時(とき)は、なるべく注意(ちゅうい)してください。
example.english: While driving, please be as careful as possible.

synonym.explanation: If possible

english_grammar.title: ～る所(ところ)だ
english_grammar.explanation: About to, On the verge of
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］ + ところ + だ
english_grammar.attention: In this use, ところ means stage/level/situation
english_grammar.about: The noun ところ (sometimes shortened to とこ) is often used to describe the 'place' or 'situation' in which something happens. The primary determining factor for the nuance of ところ, is the tense of the verb it follows. When it is in the non-past form, ところ means 'about to (A)', or 'on the verge of (A)'. 彼(かれ)は手紙(てがみ)を書(か)いてるところだ。 He is writing a letter. 今(いま)から友達(ともだち)と会(あ)うところです。 I'm on my way to meet my friend. Caution When the kanji form of 所(ところ) is used, it is often referring to an actual physical location, rather than a situation/standpoint. However, this is something that native speakers will sometimes mistake. Therefore, seeing the kanji form, and the hiragana form, are both relatively common. いまの所(ところ)... This current place… いまのところ... This current situation…

example.japanese: 今(いま)から帰(かえ)るところです。
example.english: I am just about to go home.

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)が話(はな)し手(て)を待(ま)っている時(とき)、電話(でんわ)：「家(いえ)から出(で)るところだから、もうすぐ着(つ)くよ。」
example.english: When friends are waiting for the speaker, phone call: "I am about to leave home, so I will be there soon."

example.japanese: ちょうど出かけるところだ。
example.english: I am about to leave right now.

example.japanese: 宿題(しゅくだい)をするところで、友達(ともだち)から電話(でんわ)が入(はい)った。
example.english: Just when I was about to do my homework I got a call from a friend.

example.japanese: パソコンの電源(でんげん)を切(き)るところで、あの音(おと)を聞(き)いた。
example.english: Just as I was about to turn off my computer, I heard that sound.

synonym.explanation: Almost・nearly, about to, on the verge of
try to・attempt to, to be about to
half-, not yet finished, about to, begin to
just finished doing, was just doing

english_grammar.title: のに
english_grammar.explanation: Despite, Although, Even though
english_grammar.structure: Verb + のに ［い］Adjective + のに ［な］Adjective + な + のに Noun + な + のに
english_grammar.about: Although のに is often thought of as a simple combination of the particles の and に, it is actually its own particle, with the meaning of 'despite', or 'in order to'. In this lesson, we will focus primarily on the 'despite' nuance.Due to のに being a conjunction particle, it can be linked to almost any word type, to show that 'despite (A), (B)'. As with many conjunction particles, な will be required after a noun/な-Adjective, but before のに. 明日(あした)テストがあるのに彼(かれ)は勉強(べんきょう)をしないでゲームをしている。Despite having a test tomorrow, he is playing games without studying. 何(なん)で納豆(なっとう)は臭(くさ)いのに美味(おい)しいの？Why does natto taste good, despite smelling bad? 彼(かれ)はイケメンなのにいつも汗臭(あせくさ)い。Even though he is a good looking guy, he always smells like sweat. この車(くるま)はスポーツカーなのに遅(おそ)い。Despite being a sports car, this car is slow. It is also possible to see だのに, instead of なのに, but this is something that is only seen in certain dialects, and would be considered incorrect by the vast majority of native speakers. 虫歯(むしば)だのに、チョコレートを食(た)べたから歯(は)が痛(いた)い。My tooth hurts because I ate chocolate, despite having a cavity. Fun FactRegardless of having two quite different translations ('despite', and 'in order to'), のに always functions in the same way. In the situation of '(A) のに, (B)', (B) is/will be the result.The only difference between how the nuance will be read, is whether the (B) statement is a logical conclusion, or an illogical one. When logical, the meaning is usually 'in order to', when 'illogical', the meaning is usually 'despite'.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は忙(いそが)しいのに、ゲームをしている。
example.english: Despite being busy, he is playing video games.

example.japanese: 天気予報(てんきよほう)は悪(わる)かったのに、晴(は)れた。
example.english: Despite the weather forecast being bad, it was sunny.

example.english: Even though I said it was impossible, you're still going to do it?

english_grammar.title: と思(おも)う
english_grammar.explanation: I think
english_grammar.structure: Verb + と思う(1) ［い］Adjective + と思う(1) ［な］Adjective + だ + と思う(1) Noun + だ + と思う(1) (1) と思っている
english_grammar.about: To express that you 'think' something in Japanese, the common expression と思(おも)う is regularly used. As you can probably guess, this is just a combination of the particle と, plus the う-Verb 思(おも)う. とおもう can be used after any verb, い-Adjective, な-Adjective, or noun, but will require だ after a noun or な-Adjective. ごめん、ちょっと遅(おく)れると思(おも)う。Sorry, I think I'm going to be a little late. その言(い)い方(かた)は酷(ひど)いと思(おも)うよ。I think the way you said that was harsh. 俺(おれ)はあの人(ひと)が綺麗(きれい)だと思(おも)う。I think that person looks pretty. これはフランス語(ご)だと思(おも)う。I think this is French. Although this structure usually requires だ after nouns and な-Adjectives, it is often omitted in casual speech. 私(わたし)は日本(にほん)が安全(あんぜん)と思(おも)う。I think Japan is safe. (Ungrammatical Japanese, but quite common) Caution If you want to express what somebody else is thinking, と思(おも)っている will be used. This is due to と思(おも)う having a sense of 'permanence', and thus not something that the speaker could know about another person. と思(おも)っている can also be used to express your own thoughts when they are currently happening. ジェームスは自分(じぶん)が賢(かしこ)いと思(おも)っている。James thinks he is smart. 来年(らいねん)に新(あたら)しいオートバイを買(か)いたいと思(おも)っている。I am thinking that I want to buy a new motorcycle next year.

example.japanese: 明日(あした)は、映画(えいが)を見(み)に行(い)くと思(おも)う。
example.english: I think I will go see a movie tomorrow.

example.japanese: このズボンはいいと思(おも)います。
example.english: I think these pants are good.

example.japanese: あの店(みせ)に行(い)ったことがあると思(おも)う。
example.english: I think that I have been to that store before.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)、雨(あめ)が降(ふ)ると思(おも)った。
example.english: I thought that it was going to rain today.

example.japanese: このスーツ、君(きみ)に似合(にあ)うと思(おも)う。
example.english: I think this suit looks good on you.

synonym.explanation: I think I will, I think I shall, Going to, Gonna (volitional + と思う)

english_grammar.title: 等(など)
english_grammar.explanation: Such as, Things like, Etc., And so on
english_grammar.structure: Noun + など Noun + など + の + Noun
english_grammar.about: など is an adverbial particle that is used to express that something is being presented as an example, but that other things in the same category also exist. In this way, it is regularly translated as 'such as', 'things like', or 'and so on'.など may be used after nouns, to describe that (A) is being presented as an example from within a group. Alternatively, など can be followed by の (B), to show that (A) is only one type of thing from the broader category, (B). この公園(こうえん)では石(いし)などを投(な)げないでください。Do not throw rocks and so on in this park. 彼(かれ)はいつもルームメイトなどの悪口(わるぐち)を言(い)っています。He is always badmouthing people, like his roommates. など is regularly seen in its kanji form, 等(など). This kanji itself has a similar meaning to 'etc' in English. Fun FactThe kanji for 等(など) is also used in the pluralizing suffix, ら. Due to this, we can see that this kanji is regularly utilized to highlight something that exists as part of a larger group. 鞄(かばん)や靴(くつ)等(など)を川(かわ)に捨(す)てはならない。You mustn't discard things such as bags and shoes into the river. あいつら本当(ほんとう)にうるさいね。Those people are very noisy, don't you think. In the first sentence, など presents (A) as being part of a larger group of similar things. This is exactly the same thing that happens in the second sentence with ら.Fun Factなど is also sometimes written as なんか, and has an interchangeable meaning in many situations. However, なんか will never use the kanji form of 等(など).

example.japanese: イタリアやアメリカなどに行(い)きたい。
example.english: I want to go to places such as America and Italy.

example.japanese: 宿題(しゅくだい)をしてから、ゲームなどをゆっくりする。
example.english: After doing my homework, I relax with things like video games.

example.japanese: フルーツはぶどうなどが好(す)きです。
example.english: As for fruits, I like fruits such as grapes.

example.japanese: 趣味(しゅみ)などを教(おし)えてください。
example.english: Please tell me things like your hobbies.

example.japanese: 明日(あした)から、準備(じゅんび)などをするつもりです。
example.english: From tomorrow, I plan on doing things like preparing.

synonym.explanation: Among other things, For example, Such as
such as, like, so much as
such as, things like, emphasis

english_grammar.title: みたい
english_grammar.explanation: Like, Similar to, Resembling
english_grammar.structure: Verb + みたい + だ ［い］Adjective + みたい + だ ［な］Adjective + みたい + だ Noun + みたい + だ
english_grammar.attention: Conversational, Less formal than ようだ
english_grammar.about: In Japanese, there are many ways to express that something happens in a way that is 'like' something else, or 'resembles' something else. One of these ways is through the use of the な-Adjective, みたい. みたい can be used after any word that a な-Adjective would usually follow, to express that something is 'like (A)', or 'similar to (A)'. 明日(あした)は雪(ゆき)が降(ふ)るみたいだ。It seems like it will snow tomorrow. そこのプールは浅(あさ)いみたいだ。That pool over there seems shallow. 彼(かれ)は地下鉄(ちかてつ)が嫌(きら)いみたいだ。It seems like he does not like subways. その携帯(けいたい)はパソコンみたいだ。That cellphone looks like a computer. In the above examples, we can see that みたい should always be followed by だ (or です) when it is at the end of a statement, however, this is frequently omitted. 先輩(せんぱい)は今日(きょう)は来(こ)ないみたい。It seems like senpai is not coming today. みたい is also often used to describe another noun, but needs to be followed by な in these cases. In this type of sentence, it is just expressing that something is '(B), but resembles (A)'. 彼(かれ)はスポーツ選手(せんしゅ)みたいな体をしている。He has a body like an athlete. みたい is used most often in conversational situations, and is based on direct, reliable information. It is far less formal than its counterpart, ようだ.Caution Despite みたい meaning 'to resemble', and being based on (usually) visual stimulus, it should not be confused with 見(み)たい 'to want to see'. This is a common mistake that learners make, as みたい itself does not have a kanji form.Fun Factみたいだ is originally an abbreviation of the more formal phrase を見たような. As a result of this, we can see that ようだ kept its formal meaning, while みたい became the casual equivalent.

example.japanese: この犬(いぬ)は熊(くま)みたいです。
example.english: This dog looks like a bear.

example.japanese: あの人(ひと)は有名人(ゆうめいじん)みたいです。
example.english: That person resembles/seems like a famous person.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)の昼(ひる)から雨(あめ)が降(ふ)るみたいです。
example.english: It looks like it will rain this afternoon.

example.japanese: あの雲(くも)は馬(うま)みたい。
example.english: That cloud resembles a horse. [looks like]

example.japanese: あのビルは会社(かいしゃ)じゃなくて病院(びょういん)みたい。
example.english: It seems like that building is a hospital, and not a company.

english_grammar.title: こと
english_grammar.explanation: Converting a verb into a noun
english_grammar.structure: Verb + こと
english_grammar.attention: Can also express something that is concrete - a fact.
english_grammar.about: In a very similar way to のは, こと is used in Japanese for nominalization (creating a noun-like phrase). However, unlike のは, which is a combination of two particles, こと is a noun. To use こと, just add it to the end of a verb in its dictionary form.こと (or 事(こと) in its kanji form) is a noun that is often translated as 'thing', and in this way, literally means 'the thing that is (A)' when used for nominalization. 近所(きんじょ)の迷惑(めいわく)になることをしてはいけない。You should not do things that will cause annoyance to your neighbors. (That which is 'causing a problem in the neighborhood') ファックスをすることが嫌(きら)い。I dislike things like faxing. (That which is 'faxing') お金(かね)を使(つか)い過(す)ぎないことが大事(だいじ)です。It is important to not use too much money. (That which is 'not using too much money') As we can see from these examples, ない can also be used between the verb and こと, to form a 'not' statement. There are other auxiliary verbs that may be used with こと in this way, but ない is the most common.Although this lesson discusses こと pairing with the dictionary form of verbs, it can actually pair with any standard verb form. Standard form just means anything that does not finish with the polite ます.Fun FactUnlike もの (another noun used to describe 'things'), こと is a noun that is frequently used to describe things that are 'intrinsic'. This basically means things that are describable, but not necessarily always observable (feelings, conditions, events, etc.).Caution When a sentence (usually short) finishes with こと, it quite often has the nuance of being a rule, or command. This こと is not actually a noun, but a sentence ending particle. 1．クラスメイトをいじめないこと。1. Do not bully your classmates. こと as a particle will almost never be written in the kanji form. However, it does originate from the same word.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)を話(はな)すことは難(むずか)しい。
example.english: Speaking Japanese is difficult.

example.japanese: スポーツをすることが好(す)き。
example.english: I like playing sports.

example.japanese: ダンスをすることは楽(たの)しい。
example.english: Dancing is fun!

example.japanese: 大(おお)きい声(こえ)で喋(しゃべ)らないこと。
example.english: Not talking loudly.

example.japanese: フォークじゃなくて、お箸(はし)を使(つか)うこと。
example.english: Not using a fork, using chopsticks.

english_grammar.title: そう
english_grammar.explanation: Look like, Appear, Seem, Have a feeling that
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ そう + だ ［い］Adjective［い］+ そう + だ ［な］Adjective + そう + だ Negative: Verb［ない］+ な + そう + だ ［い］Adjective ［ない］ + なさ + そう + だ ［な］Adjective + では(1)ない + なさ + そう + だ Exceptions: いい ￫ よい + さそう + だ ￫ よさそうだ (1) じゃ
english_grammar.attention: Do not confuse withそうだ(I heard that...).
english_grammar.about: そうだ is one of the 18 primary auxiliary verbs in Japanese, and can be used in two (2) different ways. The broad meaning in each of its applications is that something 'seems' to be a certain way. Due to this, そう is regularly translated as 'seems like', 'looks like', or 'appears as though'.In this lesson, we will focus on the form that is used with the conjunctive (stem) form of words. Please examine the structure guide to see these forms. 彼女(かのじょ)は毎日(まいにち)走(はし)りそうだ。She seems like she runs everyday. これは正(ただ)しそうだ。This seems correct. あの店員(てんいん)は丁寧(ていねい)そうだ。That clerk seems like he is attentive. Caution そう may also be used when attached to the い-Adjective, ない. In this case, there is a unique conjugation rule which we will need to be careful of. As always, い will be removed from ない before attaching そう. However, さ will be inserted between な, and そう. This creates the expression なさそう. 彼(かれ)の部屋(へや)は汚(きたな)くなさそうだ。His room doesn't seem messy. あの車(くるま)は小(ちい)さくて便利(べんり)じゃなさそう。That car is small, and looks inconvenient. Note that this addition of さ does not happen with verbs. This is due to the ない that is used with negative verbs being an auxiliary verb, and not an い-Adjective. With the auxiliary verb ない, simply remove the い, before adding そう directly to the stem. 彼(かれ)はもうイギリスに帰(かえ)らなそうだ。It appears that he is not going back to England. Caution This そう is utilized exclusively to make predictions/guesses about something based on visual information. It is relatively low confidence, so should not be used for things that are obvious. In these cases, みたい would be used instead. 明日(あした)は朝(あさ)から雨(あめ)が降(ふ)るみたいだ。It looks like it is going to start raining tomorrow morning. (Higher confidence) 明日(あした)は朝(あさ)から雨(あめ)が降(ふ)りそうだ。It seems like it is going to start raining tomorrow morning. (Lower confidence)

example.japanese: 雪(ゆき)が降(ふ)りそうです。
example.english: It looks like it is going to snow.

example.japanese: 先生(せんせい)の仕事(しごと)は難(むずか)しそうです。
example.english: The job of being a teacher looks hard.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)の宿題(しゅくだい)は簡単(かんたん)そうだ。
example.english: Today's homework looks easy.

example.japanese: その食(た)べ物(もの)は食(た)べやすそう。
example.english: That food looks easy to eat.

example.japanese: この教科書(きょうかしょ)はとても難(むずか)しそうです。
example.english: This textbook seems very difficult.

english_grammar.title: さ
english_grammar.explanation: Converting adjectives to nouns
english_grammar.structure: ［い］Adjective［い］+ さ ［な］Adjective + さ
english_grammar.about: さ is a suffix in Japanese that can be attached to the stem form of い-Adjectives and な-Adjectives. When this happens, it transforms the target adjective into a noun that illustrates the 'amount' of that particular adjective. This commonly translates as '-ness' in English (sweetness, tallness, spiciness, etc), but is referred to as degree in Japanese. 私(わたし)が道(みち)の長(なが)さを測(はか)ります。 I will measure the length of the road. (The road's lengthiness) 大人(おとな)になってから家族(かぞく)の大切(たいせつ)さが分(わ)かってきた。 After becoming an adult, I came to understand the importance of family. (Family's importantness) Fun Fact It is thought that this suffix originally stemmed from the kanji 差(さ) (meaning 'distinction'), and was used for highlighting things that were distinctive features of something. In this way, さ is also sometimes used after the dictionary form of verbs, to highlight a distinct point in time that something happens. 学校(がっこう)からの帰(かえ)るさにお金(かね)を拾(ひろ)った。 On the way back from school, I picked up some money. (At the 'point' of returning home) 行(い)くさで家(いえ)に忘(わす)れ物(もの)をしたことを思(おも)い出(だ)した。 When I was on my way there, I remembered that I had left something at home. (At the 'point' of going somewhere) However, this use of the suffix is far less common in modern Japanese, and is known as 'poetic language'. It was primarily used during Japan's 'middle ages', which spanned from (around) 1100, until close to the end of the 1500's.

example.japanese: この美(うつく)しさは初(はじ)めてです。
example.english: This beauty is a first for me.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)の元気(げんき)さは子供(こども)みたい。
example.english: His energy is like that of a child.

example.japanese: この甘(あま)さは美味(おい)しい。
example.english: This sweetness is delicious.

example.japanese: この景色(けしき)の綺麗(きれい)さは言葉(ことば)では説明(せつめい)できない。
example.english: I am unable to explain the prettiness of this scenery with words.

example.japanese: 箱(はこ)の重(おも)さを測(はか)ってください。
example.english: Please weigh the heaviness of the box for me?

synonym.explanation: ~ness, used to indicate conditions or nature

english_grammar.title: とか
english_grammar.explanation: Among other things, For example, Such as
english_grammar.structure: Verb (A) + とか + Verb (B) + （とか） Noun (A) + とか + Noun (B) + （とか）
english_grammar.attention: Fornon-exhaustive lists
english_grammar.about: とか is a word that belongs to a unique family of particles in Japanese called listing particles. As the name suggests, these particles are used for listing groups of items that share similarities. とか can be used after verbs, or nouns, to express 'among other things, (A)'. 健康(けんこう)のために野菜(やさい)を食(た)べるとか水(みず)を飲(の)むとかをしています。For my health, I do things like eat vegetables and drink water. 亀(かめ)とかすっぽんとかは美味(おい)しいんですか。Are things like turtles and snapping turtles delicious? When multiple things are listed, the last item in the list can (and often does) have とか omitted. かぼちゃとかサツマイモとか白菜(はくさい)とかシイタケが入(はい)っている鍋(なべ)が好(す)き。I like hot pots that include things like pumpkin, sweet potatoe, cabbage, and shiitake. Caution とか is used to list items in a non-exhaustive way. What this means is that the listener will assume that there are other items in the list, apart from what is stated directly. The speaker is just providing a few examples of a (potentially much larger) category.Fun FactAs we have seen, とか may be used with verb phrases. This is in contrast to や, a similar grammar point that can only be used for listing nouns. 冷蔵庫(れいぞうこ)の中(なか)にあるものを食(た)べるとかしてください。Eat what's in the refrigerator or something. (Natural Japanese) 冷蔵庫(れいぞうこ)の中(なか)にあるものを食(た)べるやしてください。Eat things in the refrigerator or something. (Unnatural Japanese, as や cannot be used with verbs)

example.japanese: 青(あお)とか水色(みずいろ)が好(す)き。
example.english: I like colors such as blue and light blue.

example.japanese: 明日(あした)とか今(こん)週末(しゅうまつ)とか、暇(ひま)なら、映画(えいが)を見(み)に行(い)こう。
example.english: If you are free tomorrow or, for example this weekend, let's go watch a movie.

example.japanese: トム・クルーズとかブラッド・ピットとかがかっこいいと思(おも)う。
example.english: I think people like Tom Cruise for example, or Brad Pitt are cool.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は色々(いろいろ)なフルーツが好(す)きだけど、苺(いちご)とか、リンゴとかは嫌(きら)いです。
example.english: I like a variety of fruits, but I don't like (fruits) such as strawberries and apples.

example.japanese: 日本(にほん)とか、韓国(かんこく)とかに行(い)ってみたいですね。
example.english: I want to go to places such as Japan and Korea.

english_grammar.title: そういう
english_grammar.explanation: Like that, Kind of
english_grammar.structure: こういう + Noun そういう + Noun ああいう + Noun どういう + Noun
english_grammar.about: Coming from the こそあど言葉(ことば) family of words, こう, そう, ああ, or どう may be used with the verb 言(い)う to form an expression which literally means 'in the way of (A)'. (A) being 'this' これ, 'that' それ, 'that over there' あれ, or 'what' どれ (in questions). As with all pre-noun adjectival words, this expression will be used directly before a noun. こういう映画(えいが)は始(はじ)めてみる。This is my first time watching a movie like this. (This 'kind' of movie) そういう人(ひと)は嫌(きら)い。I don't like people like that. (That 'kind' of people) ああいう車(くるま)に乗(の)ってみたい。I want to try to drive a car like that one. (That 'kind' of car) あなたはどういう音楽(おんがく)を聴(き)きますか？What kind of music do you listen to? Although こう, そう, ああ, and どう share a relationship with これ, それ, あれ, and どれ, they are their own individual words, which each have a meaning similar to 'as such'. These words are all adverb when used by themselves.Caution そう (the adverb), should not be confused with そう, the auxiliary verb. そう (the adverb) comes from the kanji 然(そ)う, while the auxiliary verb does not have a kanji form.

example.japanese: そういう人(ひと)もいるよ。
example.english: There are also people like that (you know).

example.japanese: どういう意味(いみ)ですか。
example.english: What do you mean? [lit. What kind of meaning?]

example.japanese: ああいう消(け)しゴムが好(す)き。
example.english: I like erasers like that[over there].

example.japanese: こういう人形(にんぎょう)がほしい。
example.english: I want a doll like this.

example.japanese: こういう仕事(しごと)をしなくちゃいけない。
example.english: I have to do this kind of job.

synonym.text: そんな・こんな・あんな・どんな
synonym.explanation: such a・kind of, something like ~

english_grammar.title: う・よう (Volitional)
english_grammar.explanation: Let's, I shall (casual volitional)
english_grammar.structure: Examples: ［る1］Verb ￫ 見る + よう ［る5］Verb ￫ 座る + ろう ［う］Verb ￫ 歌う + おう ［く］Verb ￫ 歩く + こう ［す］Verb ￫ 話す + そう ［つ］Verb ￫ 打つ + とう ［ぬ］Verb ￫ 死ぬ + のう ［ぶ］Verb ￫ 飛ぶ + ぼう ［む］Verb ￫ 休む + もう ［ぐ］Verb ￫ 泳ぐ + ごう Exceptions: する ￫ しよう くる ￫ こよう
english_grammar.about: よう (and う) are grammar constructions that function in a similar way to ましょう, or to be more precise, ましょう is the polite (conjugated) form of these auxiliary verbs. They are used as a casual way of expressing 'let's' when making suggestions, or 'I shall' when making statements.よう is only one of the potential forms of this grammar point, and can actually be divided into two separate auxiliary verbs, う (used with う-Verbs), and よう (used with る-Verbs, する, and くる). When attaching う to う-Verbs, simply replace the last kana with the equivalent お sound kana from within the same column (く becomes こ, う becomes お, す becomes そ, etc.), before adding う. For る-Verbs, replace る with よう. 今夜(こんや)は先輩(せんぱい)の試合(しあい)を見(み)に行(い)こう！Tonight, let's go watch the senpais tournament! 早(はや)く食(た)べよう。Let's eat already! As with many other verb conjugations, する and くる behave in a slightly different way to regular う-Verbs and る-Verbs. する will become しよう, while くる will become こよう. 私(わたし)が運転(うんてん)しようか？Shall I drive? 今日(きょう)はお金(かね)が無(な)いから明日(あした)こよう。I don't have money today, so let's come tomorrow. The type of statements that う, and よう can be used for in Japanese are usually divided into three categories.推量(すいりょう) - Expresses guesses (has a similar meaning to だろう, which itself is the よう form of だ)意志(いし) - Expresses intentions (has a similar meaning to ～するつもりだ)勧誘(かんゆう) - Expresses invitations or encouragement (has a similar meaning to 誘(さそ)う 'to invite')Caution Although よう is used with る-Verbs, する, and くる, it should not be confused with ようだ, another auxiliary verb that is used when describing likeness (in a similar way to そうだ).

example.japanese: 毎日(まいにち)スポーツをしよう。
example.english: Let's play sports every day.

example.japanese: 朝(あさ)ご飯(はん)を食(た)べに行(い)こう。
example.english: Let's go out to eat for breakfast.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)は早(はや)く帰(かえ)ろう。
example.english: Let's go home early today.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)を勉強(べんきょう)しなくてはいけない。頑張(がんば)ろう！
example.english: We have to study Japanese. Let's do our best!

example.japanese: 天気(てんき)は雨(あめ)でも晴(は)れでもハイキングに行(い)こうね。
example.english: Rain or shine, let's go hiking.

english_grammar.title: 様(よう)だ
english_grammar.explanation: it seems that, it appears that, it looks like
english_grammar.structure: Verb + よう + だ ［い］Adjective + よう + だ ［な］Adjective + な + よう + だ Noun + の + よう + だ
english_grammar.attention: More formal than みたい
english_grammar.about: In a similar way to みたい, ようだ is used when making observations about something in Japanese. This auxiliary verb is used to express three primary things.たとえ - Using (A) as an example to highlight the way that (B) looks/is acting.推定(すいてい) - Using (A) as a reason for an assumption made about (B).例示(れいじ) - Presenting (A) as an example of what (B) is.ようだ is usually based on direct information/experience, and shows that the speaker has high confidence in what they are saying. It may also frequently appear in its kanji form, 様(よう)だ.ようだ can be used with any verb, い-Adjective, な-Adjective, or noun. However, it requires な before it when used with な-Adjectives, or の when used with nouns. ここに大(おお)きなビルが出来(でき)るようだ。It seems like a big building will be made here. あそこのプールは深(ふか)い様(よう)だ。It seems like the pool over there is deep. 彼(かれ)は明日(あした)のテストに自信(じしん)があると皆(みんな)に言(い)っているが、本当(ほんとう)は不安(ふあん)なようだ。He is telling everyone that he is confident about the test tomorrow, but it seems like he is actually worried. ヨーダは宇宙人(うちゅうじん)のようだ。Yoda appears to be an alien. Although ようだ and そうだ are often used in similar situations, そうだ shows that the speaker has a lot less confidence in their statement than ようだ. Because of this, ようだ is a much better choice when stating things that are obvious/observable by anyone.Caution ようだ is considerably more formal than みたい, and is therefore less common in casual conversation.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はここに来(こ)ないようだ。
example.english: It seems like he won't come here.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)の天気(てんき)は台風(たいふう)のようだ。
example.english: Today's weather looks like a typhoon.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)の話(はな)し方(かた)は歌(うた)っているようだ。
example.english: His way of speaking seems like singing.

example.japanese: ほとんど無(な)くなっているようだ。
example.english: It seems that most of it is gone.

example.japanese: あの人(ひと)はお金(かね)を持(も)っていないようだが、本当(ほんとう)はお金持(かねも)ち。
example.english: That person looks like he doesn't have any money, but he really is rich.

english_grammar.title: 全然(ぜんぜん)
english_grammar.explanation: (not) at all
english_grammar.structure: ぜんぜん + Phrase ぜんぜん + (Negative) Phrase
english_grammar.attention: Slang: totally・completely, exceptionally
english_grammar.about: In Japanese, there are several adverbs that are traditionally used exclusively with negative expressions (containing ない). 全然(ぜんぜん) is one of them. When used at the beginning of a ない (or ません) containing phrase, 全然（ぜんぜん) has the meaning of 'completely not (A)', or 'not (A) at all'. やばい、トイレットペーパーが全然(ぜんぜん)ない。Oh shoot, I don't have any toilet paper at all. 彼女(かのじょ)は家事(かじ)の手伝(てつだ)いを全然(ぜんぜん)しなかったので別(わか)れました。I broke up with her because she didn't help out at all with house chores. In writing, it is equally as natural to use either 全然(ぜんぜん) as kanji, or hiragana only, so both forms may be used confidently.ぜんぜん is more flexible (and friendly sounding) in casual conversation than 全(まった)く, a similar expression which has a formal (often negative) nuance. 今月(こんげつ)もお金(かね)が全然(ぜんぜん)無(な)いからパンだけを食(た)べる。I don't have any money this month either, so I am only eating bread. 昨日(きのう)後輩(こうはい)からもらったお土産(みやげ)は全(まった)く美味(おい)しくありませんでしたね。The souvenir we got from our junior member yesterday was not tasty at all, don't you think? While both of these sentences have the meaning of 'not (A) at all', まったく could give the listener the impression that you are not pleased with the situation. This will depend quite a bit on tone of voice, though.Caution Despite originally being used only with negative expressions, it is becoming more and more common for ぜんぜん to appear with positive expressions as well. In these cases, it just has the meaning of 'totally (A)', or 'completely (A)'. 明日(あした)？全然(ぜんぜん)いいよ！Tomorrow? That's completely fine! Although this is technically not grammatically correct, it is becoming so frequently used that it is considered correct by most people (especially the younger generation).

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は全然(ぜんぜん)英語(えいご)を話(はな)せないです。
example.english: I can't speak English at all.

example.japanese: あなたは全然(ぜんぜん)理解(りかい)が出来(でき)ていないね。
example.english: You don't understand at all do you?

example.japanese: 今(いま)、機嫌(きげん)が悪(わる)くて、全然(ぜんぜん)嬉(うれ)しくならない。
example.english: I'm in a bad mood right now and there's no way at all I'll become happy.

example.japanese: 今(いま)の髪型(かみがた)は全然(ぜんぜん)好(す)きじゃないから、明日(あした)切(き)りに行(い)く。
example.english: I don't like my current hair style at all, so I'll go get my hair cut tomorrow.

example.japanese: 事故(じこ)にあったけど、私(わたし)は全然(ぜんぜん)大丈夫(だいじょうぶ)。
example.english: I was in an accident, but I am completely fine.

synonym.explanation: not ~ at all, cannot ~ at all
not even a little, not at all, not in the least, never
not~at all

english_grammar.title: かな
english_grammar.explanation: I wonder
english_grammar.structure: Sentence + かな
english_grammar.about: Originally a mixture of the sentence ending particles か, and な, かな evolved over time to become its own (singular) sentence ending particle, which roughly translates as 'I wonder if (A)?'.As it is a sentence ending particle, かな can be added to the end of almost any sentence. あの人(ひと)が道(みち)の真(ま)ん中(なか)で倒(たお)れてるけど、大丈夫(だいじょうぶ)かな。That person over there is laying collapsed in the middle of the street, but I wonder if they are okay. このコンロにこの魚(さかな)が入(はい)るかな？I wonder if the fish will fit in this stove. Combining the meanings か and な, we can see where かな gets its original meaning. か presents questions (usually to other people), while な shows that a statement is related purely to the speaker's own thoughts/opinions. In this way, かな expresses that the speaker's own thoughts are being questioned.Fun FactIn the past, かな was thought of as being a fairly feminine way to express 'I wonder', and males tended to use phrases like だろうか to express the same type of statement. However, in modern day Japanese, かな is used by both men and women equally. この通帳(つうちょう)はお母(かあ)さんのだろうか。I wonder if this is my mother's checkbook. (Slightly masculine) あの人(ひと)は本当(ほんとう)に弁護士(べんごし)なのかな。I wonder if that person is really a lawyer. (Commonly used by anybody)

example.japanese: もうすぐ食(た)べに行(い)くかな。
example.english: I wonder if we will go eat soon...

example.japanese: 明日(あした)は運動(うんどう)をした方(ほう)がいいかな。
example.english: I wonder, if I should exercise tomorrow...

example.japanese: 今(こん)週末(しゅうまつ)は友達(ともだち)と会(あ)えるかな。
example.english: I wonder if I can meet my friends this weekend...

example.japanese: 冷蔵庫(れいぞうこ)にケーキまだあるかな。
example.english: I wonder if there is still cake in the fridge.

example.japanese: お母(かあ)さんは何(なに)をくれるかな。
example.english: I wonder what my mom will give me.

synonym.explanation: I wonder
I wonder...
wonder if/how ~ really?, wonder if/how ~ actually?, sure enough, as expected

english_grammar.title: 余(あま)り～ない
english_grammar.explanation: Not very, Not much, Not really, Hardly
english_grammar.structure: あまり(1) + Verb［ない］ あまり(1) + ［い］Adjective［ない］ あまり(1) + Noun + ではない(2) あまり + ［な］Adjective + ではない(2) (1) あんまり (2) じゃない
english_grammar.about: あまり is a very flexible word in Japanese, that is used in several different grammar points. When paired with the ない form of a word, it translates to 'not very (A)', or 'hardly (A)'. To pair あまり (or the casual form, あんまり) with another word, we just need to place it at the beginning of a phrase, or directly before the ない statement. 今(いま)の時間(じかん)だったらあまり並(なら)ばないと思うよ。At this time, I think we would not have to stand in line for very long. 私(わたし)には犬(いぬ)がいるからあまり寂(さび)しくない。I have a dog, so I don't feel lonely very much. 最近(さいきん)はどこもあまり平和(へいわ)ではない。Recently, nowhere has been very peaceful. そこの肉屋(にくや)の肉(にく)はあまりいい肉(にく)ではない。Meat from that butcher over there is hardly good. Fun FactAlthough あまり～ない is regularly translated as 'not very' the literal translation is closer to 'not excessively (A)'. This is due to 余(あま)り (the kanji which this word comes from), meaning 'excessive', or 'to be in excess'.あまり has this meaning of 'excessive' in all of its grammar points, and the nuance will only change based on whether the sentence itself is positive (does not use ない), or negative (uses ない).

example.japanese: このケーキはあまり美味(おい)しくない。
example.english: This cake isn't very delicious.

example.japanese: あまり肉(にく)を食(た)べない。
example.english: I don't eat very much meat.

example.japanese: あまりいい車(くるま)ではないけど、走(はし)れるからいいんじゃない？
example.english: This car isn't that great, but it runs so that's good enough, right?

example.japanese: あまり大変(たいへん)なことではないから、心配(しんぱい)いらないよ。
example.english: It isn't that big of a deal, so you don't have to worry.

example.japanese: 寿司(すし)をあまり食(た)べたいと思(おも)わない。
example.english: I don't really think I want to eat sushi.

synonym.explanation: so much...that
so (much), that much, like that
not even a little, not at all, not in the least, never
not~at all
not really, hardly, not easily/readily, by no means, far from
not really, not particularly, it's not like...
hardly, rarely, seldom

english_grammar.title: ば
english_grammar.explanation: if… then, [conditional]
english_grammar.structure: ［い］Adjective［い］+ ければ ［な］Adjective + なら（ば） Noun + なら（ば） Verbs: ［る1］Verb ￫ 見る + れば ［る5］Verb ￫ 座る + れば ［う］Verb ￫ 歌う + えば ［く］Verb ￫ 歩く + けば ［す］Verb ￫ 話す + せば ［つ］Verb ￫ 打つ + てば ［ぬ］Verb ￫ 死ぬ + ねば ［ぶ］Verb ￫ 飛ぶ + べば ［む］Verb ￫ 休む + めば ［ぐ］Verb ￫ 泳ぐ + げば Exceptions: する ￫ すれば くる ￫ くれば Negative Forms: Verb［ない］+ なければ ［い］Adjective［ない］+ なければ ［な］Adjective + で + なければ Noun + で + なければ
english_grammar.attention: Hypothetical
english_grammar.about: There are several different ways to express 'if' in Japanese. One of these is through using the conjunction particle ば. ば presents hypothetical situations (possibilities), and pairs with verbs using an う to え sound-change conjugation method on the terminal (last) kana. Let's examine this with a few verbs first. 仕事(しごと)を辞(や)めれば自由(じゆう)時間(じかん)が増(ふ)えるけど、お金(かね)が無(な)くなる。If I quit work, I will have more free time, but I will have no money. 雨(あめ)が止(や)めれば、今日(きょう)も釣(つ)りに行(い)くつもりです。If it stops raining, I intend to go fishing today also. そこの信号(しんごう)で右(みぎ)に曲(ま)がれば病院(びょういん)に着(つ)きます。If you turn right at the light just there, you will get to the hospital. 店(みせ)に電話(でんわ)をすれば、すぐに予約(よやく)ができるよ。If you call the store, you will be able to make a reservation immediately. あいつがくればパーティーが楽(たの)しくなると思(おも)う。If he comes to the party, I think it will be more fun. As we can see with these verbs, the final kana will change to an え sound, from its original う (る to れ, う to え, く to け, す to せ, etc.) before adding ば. It is important to practice these, to not get them mixed up with verbs that use れる, and られる. Unlike with these verbs, the base form of する and くる will not change when using ば.To conjugate い-Adjectives with ば, the い will be replaced with けれ, one of the standard い-Adjective conjugation forms. After this, just add ば. 頭(あたま)が痛(いた)ければ、薬(くすり)を飲(の)んで寝(ね)た方(ほう)がいい。If your head hurts, it would be better if you take some medicine and then sleep. ラーメン屋(や)のチャーハンが不味(まず)ければ、そこのラーメンも不味(まず)いだろう。If a ramen shop's fried rice tastes bad, then the ramen probably tastes bad too, right? For な-Adjectives, and nouns, なら (another standard conjugation form of these words) will be added, before attaching ば. 刺身(さしみ)が嫌(きら)いならば 、寿司(すし)も嫌(きら)いでしょう。If you do not like sashimi, then you probably don't like sushi either, right? バイクならば、バイク専用(せんよう)の駐輪場(ちゅうりんじょう)に止(と)めてください。If it's a motorcycle, please park it in the designated bike parking lot. In the negative form (using ない), both the auxiliary verb ない, and the い-Adjective ない will conjugate in the same way. Simply replace い with けれ, and then add ば. 私(わたし)が作(つく)ったクッキーを食(た)べたくなければ、捨(す)ててもいいよ。If you don't want to eat the cookie that I made, you can throw it away. カレーが辛(から)くなければ、いっぱい食(た)べれる。If the curry isn't spicy, I can eat a lot of it. トラックの運転手(うんてんしゅ)でなければ、この仕事(しごと)の辛(つら)さが分(わ)からない。If you aren't a truck driver, then you wouldn't understand the hardships of this job. Fun FactThe なら in ならば is often used by itself to mean 'if', and is an abbreviation of the classical auxiliary verb なり 'to be'. In its hypothesis form, なり will become ならば. However, なり is very irregularly used by itself in modern Japanese, with なら, and ならば being far more common.Caution So that you do not mix up the conjugation rules for ば, and passive verbs, remember that the last kana of the verb will change to an あ sound, before adding れる with passive verbs. However, this change is to an え sound with ば. 運動(うんどう)をすれば痩(や)せるよ。If you exercise, you will lose weight. 夜(よる)遅(おそ)くに電話(でんわ)をされると迷惑(めいわく)です。It is very inconsiderate of you to call this late at night.

example.japanese: 明日(あした)雨(あめ)が降(ふ)れば、映画(えいが)を見(み)に行(い)くつもり。
example.english: If it rains tomorrow, then I will go watch a movie.

example.japanese: 毎日(まいにち)サッカーの練習(れんしゅう)に行(い)けば、プロのサッカー選手(せんしゅ)になれる。
example.english: If you go to soccer practice every day, then you can become a professional soccer player.

example.japanese: 今週(こんしゅう)の金曜日(きんようび)までにできなければ、来週末(らいしゅうまつ)に終(お)わらせなくてはいけない。
example.english: If (you) cannot do it by this Friday, then (you) have to finish it next weekend.

example.japanese: ヘルメットを被(かぶ)らなければ、バイクに乗(の)れない。
example.english: If (you) do not wear a helmet, then (you) cannot ride a motorbike.

example.japanese: 展覧会(てんらんかい)に行(い)けば、色々(いろいろ)なことを学(まな)べる。
example.english: If (you) go to an exhibit, then (you) can learn a variety of things.

synonym.explanation: When, From when, Just when, If
If, If it's the case, As for (conditional)
if・when, whenever, and, [conditional]
If [for emphasis]
the more…the more

english_grammar.title: なら
english_grammar.explanation: If, If it's the case, As for (conditional)
english_grammar.structure: Verb＋（の）＋なら（ば） ［い］Adjective＋（の）＋なら（ば） ［な］Adjective＋なら（ば） Noun＋なら（ば）
english_grammar.attention: なら replaces だ when used with nouns or な-adjectives
english_grammar.about: As mentioned in our lesson about ば, なら is often used by itself to mean 'if'. This is considered to be an abbreviation of ならば, the hypothesis form of なり, a classical auxiliary verb that is not used much in modern Japanese.Because なり originally meant 'to be', it functions in a similar way to the auxiliary verb だ. This means that it regularly pairs with nouns, or phrases that have been nominalized (become noun-like), though the use of の. 田舎(いなか)に住(す)むのならば、車(くるま)を買(か)ったほうがいい。If you are going to live in the countryside, it would be better to buy a car. 寒(さむ)いのならば、ジャケットを着(き)るといいだろう。If it is cold, you should wear a jacket. 無理(むり)ならいいよ。If it is not possible, it's okay. デザートなら何(なん)でも食(た)べられます。If it is a dessert, I can eat anything. (If it is dessert, I like anything) However, unlike だ (or です), なら is also regularly used without the extra help of の for nominalization, and can be attached directly to verbs or い-Adjectives. 私(わたし)の車(くるま)を使(つか) うなら、いつ使(つか)うか教(おし)えてください。If you are going to use my car, please let me know when. 暑(あつ)いなら、その上着(うわぎ)を脱(ぬ)いでください。If you are hot, please take off that jacket. Caution Because なら is an abbreviation of ならば, it is strictly used when making guesses about what 'may', or what 'could' happen in certain situations. This means that it will not be used as 'if' in statements about results that are produced through some sort of effort/training. 練習(れんしゅう)をするなら、漢字(かんじ)を書(か)くのが上手(じょうず)になる。If you are going to practice, you will get good at writing kanji. (Unnatural Japanese, as becoming 'good' is a natural result of practicing) Fun FactAlthough なら comes from the classical auxiliary verb なり, it should not be confused with the particle なり, which often has the meaning of 'as soon as', or 'just after'. Thankfully, the particle なり is also quite uncommon in modern Japanese.

example.japanese: 旅行(りょこう)に行(い)くなら、おみやげを買(か)ってきてください。
example.english: If you are going on a trip, please buy me some gifts.

example.japanese: 宿題(しゅくだい)が難(むずか)しいなら、一緒(いっしょ)にしよう。
example.english: If the homework is hard, let's do it together.

example.japanese: 君(きみ)なら、できる。
example.english: As for you, you can do it.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)のことなら、先生(せんせい)に聞(き)いた方(ほう)がいい。
example.english: As for Japanese, it would be better if you asked the teacher.

example.japanese: また行(い)くなら、帰(かえ)って来(こ)ないでください。
example.english: If you are going to go again, please don't come back.

english_grammar.title: がる
english_grammar.explanation: To feel, To think, To act as if, To want, To desire
english_grammar.structure: ［い］Adjective［い］+ がる ［な］Adjective + がる
english_grammar.attention: がる is used inたがるconstruction, which is simplyたい+ がる.
english_grammar.about: がる is a う-Verb that is primarily used as a suffix in Japanese. When used in this way, it means 'to act like (A)', or 'to show signs of being (A)', where (A) is the word that it is attached to.To use がる, you will need to link it to the stem form of an い-Adjective (simply remove the い), or to the stem form of a な-Adjective (do not include the な). 彼(かれ)はいつも女(おんな)の子(こ)の前(まえ)では強(つよ)がるけど友達(ともだち)の中(なか)では彼(かれ)は一番(いちばん)の怖(こわ)がりだ。He always acts tough in front of girls, but amongst our friends he is the biggest scaredy-cat. 犬(いぬ)が嫌(いや)がる事(こと)をしてはいけない。You must not do anything that the dog would not like. がる is a verb which means 'to give the impression of (A)', or 'to act like (A)'. This is very important in Japanese, as you would not usually say how somebody else feels, unless they told you directly and you are simply repeating what you heard (in which case you would use the quotation particle と). トムはこの新(あたら)しいゲームを欲(ほ)しいと思(おも)うよ。I think Tom would want this new game. When you want to express the way you 'think' that someone else feels, but don't have any direct information about it, that is when がる would be natural to use. For example, if you see someone shivering in the cold, you would say something like the following. あの人(ひと)、寒(さむ)がっている。ジャケット着(き)ればいいのに。That person seems like they are cold. It would be better if he wore his jacket. (Natural Japanese, as がる shows how he 'appears to be acting', rather than what he is actually feeling) The main difference between がる, and がっている, is that がる will be used when a person usually/always acts a certain way, whereas がっている is more about the way someone/something is acting in any specific moment. この子(こ)はいつも新(あたら)しいおもちゃを欲(ほ)しがる。This kid always wants new toys. キムは新(あたら)しいパソコンをほしがっている。Kim is wanting a new computer. Caution がる may also be used to describe yourself (in the third person). This is when you want to express the way you think that you act/are acting, or a way you assume other people view your behavior. 俺(おれ)はいつも人(ひと)の前(まえ)では強(つよ)がる。I always act tough in front of people. (I probably always appear to act tough) 私(わたし)は今(いま)、犬(いぬ)をほしがっているけど、マンションに住(す)んでいるからまだ飼(か)えない。Right now, I am wanting a dog, but since I live in an apartment, I can't get one yet. (I am currently acting like I want a dog) Fun FactThe use of がっている to express an 'in the moment' way that someone is acting, is slowly becoming less and less common in modern Japanese. Regularly, そう will be used instead, to express that someone (or something) 'seems' a certain way. あの人(ひと)、暑(あつ)がっているね。That person looks like they are hot, don't you think. (They're acting like they're hot) あの人(ひと)、暑(あつ)そうだね。That person looks like they are hot, don't you think. (They seem hot)

example.english: To watch a movie and show signs of interest.

english_grammar.title: がする
english_grammar.explanation: To give off, Smell, Sound, Taste, Sensation
english_grammar.structure: Noun + が + する
english_grammar.about: In Japanese, describing things that can be experienced with the senses (excluding visual), is a little bit different to the way that we would convey it in English. Traditionally, we would use unique verbs for each of these situations, such as 'smells like (A)', 'tastes like (A)', 'feels like (A)', etc. While this is still possible in Japanese, it is not the most common way.がする is a grammar construction that focuses on the source of the smell, sound, taste, or feeling, and makes the sensory experience itself the subject of the sentence. To use がする, simply attach it to the end of any phrase that expresses which type of 'sense' is being created/given off by the subject. この石鹸(せっけん)はバラの匂(にお)いがするから好(す)きです。I like this soap because it smells like roses. (Literally, 'it gives off a rose smell') 誰(だれ)かが階段(かいだん)を上(あ)がっている音(おと)がする。I hear someone coming up the stairs. (Literally, 'the sound of someone coming up the stairs is being made') このバナナが変(へん)な味(あじ)がする。This banana tastes weird. (Literally, 'it gives off a strange flavor') 誰(だれ)かに見(み)られている感(かん)じがする。It feels like I'm being watched by someone. (Literally, 'the feeling of being watched is happening') Fun FactJapanese often uses 気(き) 'energy', 'spirit', as something that can be perceived with the senses. Due to this, there are many phrases which use ～気(き)がする in the same way as this grammar point. ヤバい、鍵(かぎ)をかけるのを忘(わす)れた気(き)がする。Shoot, I feel like I forgot to lock my door. (Literally, 'my attention is being drawn to that I may have forgotten to lock the door') なんか忘(わす)れた気(き)がする。I feel like I forgot something. (Literally, 'my attention is being drawn to that something was forgotten')

english_grammar.title: たがる
english_grammar.explanation: To want to (third person)
english_grammar.structure: Verb［たい］+ がる
english_grammar.about: As we explored in our lesson about がる, this verb can be used with adjectives, to express the way in which people are acting. However, it can also be partnered with the auxiliary verb たい, to form たがる. This grammar construction is used when expressing that someone is acting like they 'want' to do something.To use this structure, attach たい to the ます stem form of any verb, then replace the い in たい with がる. ジョンはなんでいつも悪口(わるぐち)を言(い)いたがるんだろう。I wonder why John always wants to talk badly about people. 皆(みんな)は彼(かれ)が作(つく)ったケーキを食(た)べたがる。Everyone always wants to eat the cakes that he makes. Caution たがる is in contrast to てほしい which means 'to want someone to do (A)'. These differences will need to be practiced, and memorized. 彼(かれ)はこのステーキを食(た)べたがる。He will want to eat this steak. (He will act like he wants to) 彼(かれ)にこのステーキを食(た)べてほしい。I want him to eat this steak. (I want him to) This is also in contrast to the い-Adjective 欲(ほ)しい 'to want (A)'. To describe that someone seems like they want something (rather than that they want to 'do' something), がる will be paired with this adjective. 田中君(たなかくん)は新(あたら)しいゲームを見(み)つけると、そのゲームをほしがる。When Tanaka-kun sees a new game, he always wants it.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は動物園(どうぶつえん)に行(い)きたがる。
example.english: He is acting like he wants to go to the zoo.

example.japanese: 娘(むすめ)はいつもスポーツをしたがる。
example.english: My daughter always wants to play sports.

example.english: My girlfriend wants to see a recently released movie.

example.english: If that kid wants to go home, that's alright, isn't it?

example.english: He wanted to buy a PC, so (and) he even worked weekends.

english_grammar.title: かもしれない
english_grammar.explanation: Might, Maybe, Probably
english_grammar.structure: Verb + かもしれない ［い］Adjective + かもしれない ［な］Adjective + かもしれない Noun + かもしれない
english_grammar.attention: Colloquial: かも or かもしらん, Polite: かもしれません
english_grammar.about: かもしれない is an expression in Japanese that is often treated as a single word, but is actually the combination of the particle かも, and the potential form of the う-Verb 知(し)る (to know) with the auxiliary verb ない attached. かもしれない is regularly translated simply as 'might', or 'maybe', but the literal translation is much closer to 'even (A), we cannot know'.To use かもしれない, attach it to the end of any verb, noun, な-Adjective or い-Adjective, in their non-polite (keigo) forms. 来年(らいねん)から観光客(かんこうきゃく)が増(ふ)えるかもしれない。From next year, the number of tourists might increase. あの建物(たてもの)は教会(きょうかい)かもしれない。That building might be a church. 今日(きょう)は無理(むり)かもしれない。It might not be possible today. そこの池(いけ)は深(ふか)いかもしれないから気(き)を付(つ)けてね。That lake over there might be deep, so please be careful. As the う-Verb 知(し)る is part of this construction, it may also be altered to its polite-potential form, creating かもしれません. 明日(あした)は休(やす)むかもしれません。I might take the day off tomorrow. Due to かもしれない being such a common grammar pattern in daily speech for expressing uncertainty about various things, several colloquial forms also exist. These are かも, かもしらん, and かもしれん. 明日(あした)は休(やす)みだからドライブするかも。I have a day off tomorrow, so I might go for a drive. 財布(さいふ)を家(いえ)に忘(わす)れてきたかもしらん。I might have left my wallet at home. 明日(あした)は夜(よる)遅(おそ)くまで仕事(しごと)があるから、行(い)かないかもしれん。 I have to work late tomorrow night, so I probably won’t go. かも is by far the most common of these colloquial forms, with かもしらん potentially sounding a little bit rough/boyish.

example.japanese: 来年(らいねん)アメリカに行(い)くかもしれない。

english_grammar.title: みたいに
english_grammar.explanation: Like, Similar to, Resembling
english_grammar.structure: Verb + みたいに + Verb(1) Noun + みたいに + Verb(1) Noun(2) + みたいな + Noun (1) Adverb、［い］Adjective、［な］Adjective (2) Verb
english_grammar.about: As learned in our previous lesson about みたい, it is a な-Adjective. This means that it can be used in conjunction with nouns, or with verbs. In each of these cases, it will carry the meaning of 'like (A)', or 'resembling (A)'. The difference between みたい describing a verb or a noun can be identified by whether it is followed by な (describes a noun), or に (describes a verb). Let's take a look at some examples. プロみたいに泳(およ)ぎたい。I want to swim like a professional. 先生(せんせい)みたいになりたい。I want to be like my teacher. 先生(せんせい)みたいな人(ひと)になりたい。I want to become someone like my teacher. 関西(かんさい)みたいな所(ところ)に住(す)みたい。I want to live in a place like the Kansai region. This difference is important to know, as (B), the thing that みたい is describing, does not always come directly after みたい. 彼(かれ)はイルカみたいに泳(およ)ぎたいと言(い)っている。He is saying that he wants to swim like a dolphin. 彼(かれ)はイルカみたいに、早(はや)く泳(およ)ぎたいと言(い)っている。He is saying that he wants to swim fast like a dolphin. In the second example sentence, we can see that 泳(およ)ぐ (the verb that に is linked to), does not actually come until later in the sentence. This is quite a regular occurrence, especially in longer passages.Caution Despite みたい meaning 'to resemble', and being based on (usually) visual stimulus, it should not be confused with 見(み)たい 'to want to see'. This is a common mistake that learners make, as みたい itself does not have a kanji form.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)はあの女(おんな)の人(ひと)みたいになりたい。
example.english: I want to become like that woman.

example.japanese: それは城(しろ)みたいな家(いえ)です。

example.english: They are easy to put on, just like sandals.

english_grammar.title: そうに
english_grammar.explanation: Seem, Look like, Sound
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ そうに + Verb(1) ［い］Adjective［い］+ そうに + Verb(1) ［な］Adjective + そうに + Verb(1) Verb［ます］(2) + そうな + Noun (1) Adverb、［い］Adjective、［な］Adjective (2) ［い］Adjective［い］、［な］Adjective
english_grammar.attention: Negative Verb[ない] +そう, い-Adj [ない] +さ+そう
english_grammar.about: そうだ is one of the 18 auxiliary verbs in Japanese, and can be used in the same way as な-Adjectives (may be followed by な when acting as an adjective, or に when acting as an adverb). This is a unique characteristic of そうだ and ようだ. It is not something that can be done with all auxiliary verbs. As with そうだ, そうに and そうな carry the meaning of 'seeming like (A)', or 'looking like (A)'. さっき、先輩(せんぱい)が怒(おこ)りそうになってた。Earlier, it seemed like senpai was going to get angry. 彼(かれ)は忙(いそが)しそうに仕事(しごと)をしている。He is working like he is busy. 彼女(かのじょ)はどんな仕事(しごと)でも簡単(かんたん)そうにやるからうらやましいです。She does all her work like it is easy, so I am very jealous of her. つまらなそうなパーティーには行(い)きません。I don't go to parties that seem like they would be boring. Caution そう may also be used when attached to the い-Adjective, ない. In this case, there is a unique conjugation rule which you will need to be careful of. As always, い will be removed from ない before attaching そう. However, さ will need to be inserted between な, and そう. This results in the construction なさそう. すごい！辛(から)くなさそうに食(た)べるね。Wow! You eat it like it's not spicy. 大事(だいじ)じゃなさそうな物(もの)は捨(す)ててもいいよ。You can throw away anything that does not look important. Note that this addition of さ does not happen with verbs. This is due to the ない that is used with negative verbs being an auxiliary verb, and not an い-Adjective. With the auxiliary verb ない, simply remove the い, before adding そう directly to the stem. あの人(ひと)は怒(おこ)らなそうな顔(かお)をしているけどいつも怒(おこ)っている。He does not look like he gets angry alot, but actually he is always angry. 彼(かれ)は美味(おい)しくなさそうにご飯(はん)を食(た)べている。He is eating his food like it does not taste good.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)は雨(あめ)が降(ふ)りそうな日(ひ)ですね。

example.english: The classes that teacher teaches look like fun classes.

example.japanese: これが入(はい)りそうな箱(はこ)ってある？
example.english: Is there a box that looks like it might fit this?

example.japanese: 優(やさ)しそうに犬(いぬ)を撫(な)でた。
example.english: She pet the dog in a way that seemed affectionate.

english_grammar.title: の様(よう)に
english_grammar.explanation: Like (noun), Similar to (noun)
english_grammar.structure: Noun + のように + Verb(1) Noun + のような + Noun (1) Adverb、［い］Adjective、［な］Adjective
english_grammar.attention: This is a version using nouns, みたい(に・な)→appearance of, のよう(に・な)→in the manner of
english_grammar.about: The auxiliary verb ようだ is used for making observations. It states that something is 'in the manner/way of (A)'. Like the auxiliary verb そうだ, ようだ may be used in a similar way to な-Adjectives (can be followed by な when acting as an adjective, or に when acting as an adverb). の is required before these constructions when it is describing a noun. ナオミはプロの歌手(かしゅ)のように歌(うた) う。Naomi sings like a professional singer. この先生(せんせい)は鬼(おに)のように怖(こわ)い。This teacher is as scary as a demon. (Literally, 'scary like a demon') 私(わたし)は鳥(とり)のように自由(じゆう)だ。I am free as a bird. (Literally, 'free like a bird') 最近(さいきん)はタブレットのようなスマホが売(う)られています。Recently, tablet-like smartphones are being sold. Because よう (coming from the kanji 様(よう)) usually expresses the 'manner' in which something is existing/happening, it is regularly used when the speaker has direct personal experience from which they are drawing a comparison. This means that よう will sound far more confident than みたい, or そう.Fun FactWhen ようだ is describing another word (in its ような, or ように form), this is known as 'presenting an example' (例示(れいじ) in Japanese), and means that '(A) is an example of (B)'.

example.japanese: お箸(はし)はこのように使(つか)います。
example.english: Chopsticks are used like this.

example.english: Currently, there are many smartphone-like cell phones.

english_grammar.title: う・よう + と思(おも)う
english_grammar.explanation: I think I will, I think I shall, Going to, Gonna (volitional + と思う)
english_grammar.structure: Verb［おう］ + と思う(1) (1) と思っている
english_grammar.about: The combination of a verb with the auxiliary verb う, or よう, followed by the う-Verb 思(おも)う gives us the common expression ようと思(おも)う. This expression is often translated as 'I think I will (A)', or 'I shall (A)'. It is also close to the casual expression 'I'm gonna (A)'.Remembering that う and よう can have one of three possible meanings in Japanese (as discussed in the よう grammar point), ようと思(おも)う is usually only used to express one of those three. That 'one' is as follows:意志(いし) - Expresses intentions (has a similar meaning to ～するつもりだ） このゲームはもうあきらめようと思(おも)う。I think I will give up on this game already. (I have arrived at the conclusion that I will give it up) 私(わたし)は明日(あした)から電車(でんしゃ)で通(かよ)おうと思(おも)う。I think I shall commute by train from tomorrow. (I have arrived at the conclusion that I will do it) 来月(らいげつ)、バイクを買(か)おうと思(おも)う。I think I will buy a bike next month. (I have arrived at the conclusion that I will buy one) This expression is also often used with 思(おも)っている. In these cases, it highlights that the intention of the speaker is something that they regularly think, or have been thinking about for some time. 今晩(こんばん)はレストランで美味(おい)しいものを食(た)べようと思(おも)っているけど、ナオミも来(く)る？I am thinking of eating something delicious at a restaurant tonight, but do you want to come too, Naomi? 思(おも)っている may also be used when describing the intentions of another person, as discussed in our lesson about と思(おも)う. タケル、お前(まえ)は絶対(ぜったい)サチコと別(わか)れようと思(おも)っているでしょう。Takeru, you are definitely thinking of breaking up with Sachiko, aren't you? Caution Let's be careful to remember the difference between the auxiliary verbs よう, and ようだ. They are different constructions that have different meanings, and behave in unique ways grammatically.

example.japanese: 明日(あした)、勉強(べんきょう)をしようと思(おも)う。
example.english: I think I will study tomorrow.

example.english: I think I will start studying grammar from today.

english_grammar.title: にする・くする
english_grammar.explanation: Adjective + する, To make something/someone (more)
english_grammar.structure: ［な］Adjective + に + する ［い］Adjective［く］+ する
english_grammar.about: When combined with a な-Adjective, にする (or くする in the case of い-Adjectives) carries the meaning of 'to make more (A)'.Just like the にする grammar point that is used for highlighting decisions, this にする construction implies that the speaker has a high level of control over the action. この建物(たてもの)をもっと丈夫(じょうぶ)にする方法(ほうほう)がありますか？Is there any way to make this building more durable? 汚(きたな)い部屋(へや)を綺麗(きれい)にするのは大変(たいへん)だ。It is difficult to make a dirty room clean. 風呂(ふろ)を熱(あつ)くするよ。いい？I'm going to make the bath hot. Is that okay? このコーヒーを甘(あま)くするために、砂糖(さとう)をください。Please give me sugar to make this coffee more sweet. Basically, this changes the adjective into an adverb, and then uses する to show that the adjective itself is the thing that is being done.Fun Factにする is one of four regularly repeating grammar patterns in Japanese that highlight the level of control that the speaker has over the action/result of an action. From highest to lowest level of control, these are as follows:にする - High level of control, the speaker/subject can perform this action themselves.になる - High level of control, the speaker/subject can perform this action themselves, but there is no external target.とする - Medium level of control, the speaker/subject can perform this action, but some outside factors may need to be considered (difficulty, other people, time, etc.).となる - Low level of control, the speaker/subject has almost no control over these actions, and something that came about purely due to external factors is being discussed.

example.japanese: 頑張(がんば)って部品(ぶひん)を小(ちい)さくしてください。
example.english: Please try your best to make the parts smaller.

example.japanese: 布団(ふとん)を新(あたら)しくしたから気持(きも)ちいい。
