example.english: You should make yourself warm when going to a flower-viewing party.

example.japanese: この部屋(へや)を大(おお)きくしたいです。
example.english: I want to make this room bigger.

english_grammar.title: といい
english_grammar.explanation: I hope, I wish, You should, It would be good
english_grammar.structure: Verb + と + いい ［い］Adjective + と + いい ［な］Adjective + だ + と + いい Noun + だ + と + いい Wishing for others: (Desired Outcome) Phrase + といい + ね Wishing for oneself: (Desired Outcome) Phrase + といい + なぁ (Desired Outcome) Phrase + といい+んだ(1) + けど(2) (1) のだ (2) けれど、けども、けれども、が
english_grammar.about: One of the regular uses of the と particle is to express 'if'. However, unlike some other structures (like なら, たら, and ば), と implies that the 'if' result of と is something that will definitely happen, or is a natural consequence of (A) happening. When combined with the い-Adjective いい, it means 'if (A), it would be good'.This construction may be used with any phrase ending in a word in its standard form. 明日(あした)は学校(がっこう)に行(い)きたくないな~、雪(ゆき)が降(ふ)るといいな。I don't want to go to school tomorrow. It would be great if it snows. 今夜(こんや)のパーティーは楽(たの)しいといいね！I hope your party tonight is fun! (Hoping for someone else's sake) 先輩(せんぱい)が言(い)っていることが本当(ほんとう)だといいね！If what senpai is saying is true, it would be good! 「今夜(こんや)の夕食(ゆうしょく)は魚(さかな)だといいな~」と弟(おとうと)が言(い)っていました。My little brother was saying 'I hope dinner tonight is fish'. Because と expresses a 'certain' outcome, the 'good' in this grammar construction often sounds quite strong, leading to といい regularly being translated closer to 'I hope (A)', or 'I wish (A)'.There are several situations in which this grammar point can be used to express that you are hoping something for yourself, or hoping something for someone else. This is primarily determined by the use of な, or んだけど (hoping for yourself), or ね (hoping for others/mutual benefit). 明日(あした)は晴(は)れるといいな。I hope it clears up tomorrow. (Hoping for your own benefit) 明日(あした)の試合(しあい)で勝(か)つといいんだけど相手(あいて)が強(つよ)いから自信(じしん)がない。I hope to win the tournament tomorrow, but since my opponent is formidable, I am not confident. (Hoping for your own benefit) 来週(らいしゅう)は彼氏(かれし)が来(く)るといいね。I hope your boyfriend comes next week. (Hoping for another's benefit) Caution When this expression finishes with けど, けれども, or が, it can imply that there are some external factors that will make the desired result difficult to achieve. 明日(あした)の朝(あさ)に荷物(にもつ)が届(とど)くといいんだけど。（今夜(こんや)から雪(ゆき)が降(ふ)るから配達(はいたつ)が大変(たいへん)そう）I hope my package arrives tomorrow morning. (However, it is going to start snowing tonight, so delivery seems like an issue) 宝(たから)くじに当(あ)たるといいんだが。（一枚(いちまい)しか買(か)っていないから当(あ)たらないと思(おも)う）I hope I win the lottery. (But since I only bought one ticket, I don't think I will)

example.japanese: 試合(しあい)で勝(か)つといいですね。
example.english: I hope that you can win the game.

example.japanese: あなたはもっと果物(くだもの)を食(た)べるといいです。
example.english: You should eat more fruit.

example.english: I hope it is fun.

example.english: I have been busy lately, so I hope I have this weekend off.

english_grammar.title: 様(よう)になる
english_grammar.explanation: to reach the point that, to come to be that, to turn into
english_grammar.structure: Verb［できる］(1) + ように + なる (1) Verb［ない］、Verb［る］
english_grammar.about: When combined with the particle に, and the う-Verb なる, よう expresses that a particular action has reached the point of being completed/able to be completed. Because of this, ようになる is regularly translated as 'to reach the point that (A)', or 'to turn into (A)'.To use ようになる, it will need to be added to the plain-potential, non-past form of a verb. 毎日(まいにち)、漢字(かんじ)の練習(れんしゅう)をすれば綺麗(きれい)に漢字(かんじ)を書(か)けるようになります。If you practice kanji everyday, you will reach the point where you can write them neatly. 早(はや)く走(はし)れるようになりたい。I want to reach the point where I can run faster. Caution When using this grammar construction, we will need to remember that する does not have a potential form. Therefore, できる will be used with words that usually act as する verbs. 髪(かみ)を綺麗(きれい)にカット出来(でき)るようになるのが夢(ゆめ)です。It is my dream to reach the point where I can cut my hair nicely. 自分(じぶん)から行動(こうどう)が出来(でき)るようになってください。Please turn into someone who can act on their own. (Please become more self sufficient) However, ようになる is not limited to being used in affirmative sentences, and may also be used after a verb with ない. This shows that something has reached the point of 'not' being able to be completed. 来年(らいねん)から現金(げんきん)が使(つか)えないようになる。From next year, it will reach the point where you will not be able to use cash.(Starting next year, you will not be able to use cash) 来月(らいげつ)から会社(かいしゃ)で喫煙(きつえん)できないようになります。Starting next month, it will reach the point where you will not be able to smoke at the company. (Starting next month, smoking will be banned)

example.japanese: ちゃんと英語(えいご)を勉強(べんきょう)すれば、話(はな)せるようになる。
example.english: If you study English diligently, then you will reach a point where you can speak it.

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)と相談(そうだん)してから、決(き)めるようになった。
example.english: After discussing it with a friend, we have reached the point that we can decide.

example.japanese: 料理(りょうり)ができるようになりたい。
example.english: I want to reach a point where I can cook.

example.japanese: 理解(りかい)出来(でき)るようになった。
example.english: I reached the point that I could understand.

example.japanese: 100mを10秒(びょう)で走(はし)れるようになった。
example.english: I reached the point that I could run 100 meters in 10 seconds.

synonym.explanation: To try to, To make sure to, To endeavor to
It will end up being, It is the result of, It has been decided that

english_grammar.title: 毎(まい)～の様(よう)に
english_grammar.explanation: Almost every ~, Nearly every ~, On a ~ basis
english_grammar.structure: 毎 + Time Expression + のように
english_grammar.about: In a similar way to のように, まい～のように states that something is happening 'in the manner/way of (A)'. まい means 'every' (coming from the kanji 毎(まい)), and will always be followed by (A). (A) being a word that expresses some kind of measurement (usually time). まい～のように is often translated as 'almost every (A)', 'nearly every (A)', or 'on an (A) basis'. 毎(まい)日(にち)のようにポテトチップス食(た)べてるから太(ふと)ってきた。Because I eat potato chips almost everyday, I am starting to gain weight. 渋谷(しぶや)には毎(まい)週(しゅう)のように行(い)っているよ。I go to Shibuya almost every week. 彼(かれ)は八月(はちがつ)になると毎(まい)年(とし)のように平和記念資料館(へいわきねんしりょうかん)へ行(い)く。When August comes, he goes to the peace memorial museum almost every year. Because よう (from the kanji 様(よう)) usually expresses the 'manner' in which something is existing/happening, this phrase literally highlights that something occurs 'in the manner of every (A)', and is therefore up to the interpretation of the listener as to whether the speaker means 'every', or 'almost every'.Caution Although みたいに and のように are regularly interchangeable, that is not the case with まい～のように. This is because みたいだ is originally an abbreviation of the more formal phrase を見たような, and therefore can sound unnatural when used to describe things that cannot be seen, like time.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)は彼(かれ)に出会(であ)う前(まえ)は、毎(まい)日(にち)のように高校(こうこう)をサボっていた。
example.english: Before she met him, she used to skip school almost every day.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はその後(あと)、故郷(ふるさと)に 毎(まい)月(つき)のように帰(かえ)った。
example.english: After that, he returned to his hometown almost every month.

example.english: There is at least 1 earthquake in Japan nearly every year.

example.japanese: 子供(こども)の頃(ころ)、雨(あめ)に濡(ぬ)れてひどい風邪(かぜ)を引(ひ)いたので、出(で)かけるときは毎(まい)回(かい)のように傘(かさ)を持(も)っていく。
example.english: Since I caught a terrible cold after getting soaked when I was a kid, I take an umbrella with me almost every time I go out.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は毎(まい)日(にち)のように砂糖(さとう)を食(た)べすぎたので、病気(びょうき)になった。
example.english: He fell ill because he ate too much sugar nearly every single day.

english_grammar.title: じゃないか
english_grammar.explanation: isn't it?, is it not?
english_grammar.structure: Phrase + じゃない + か
english_grammar.about: When learning じゃない and ではない, we briefly mentioned that these constructions are regularly partnered with the particle か, in order to form a (usually casual) question. In this lesson, we will further explore this usage.Unlike じゃない and ではない (which need to come after a noun or な-Adjective), じゃないか is able to to be attached to the end of almost any phrase, to indicate a question. This is very similar to finishing a sentence with 'isn't it?' in English. キヨコはもうすぐ来(く)るんじゃないか。Isn't Kiyoko coming soon? そのカメラは高(たか)いじゃないか。That camera is expensive, isn't it? この着物(きもの)は綺麗(きれい)じゃないか。This kimono is beautiful, isn't it? あなたの車(くるま)は私(わたし)の車(くるま)より速(はや)いじゃないか。Your car is faster than my car, isn't it? When じゃないか is too casual, ではないか will be used instead. Despite being more formal, this may sound a bit stiff at times, so is best only used when politeness is expected. これは台風(たいふう)の影響(えいきょう)ではないか。This is the typhoon's effect, isn't it? 遊(あそ)んでないで明日(あした)のテストの勉強(べんきょう)をした方(ほう)がいいんではないか。Without mucking around, wouldn't it be better if you studied for the test tomorrow?

example.japanese: 待(ま)ち合(あ)わせに来(く)るのが早(はや)いじゃないか。
example.english: You came a little early for the meeting, didn't you?

example.english: It is scary crossing this bridge, isn't it?

example.english: It was about that, wasn't it?

example.english: It will finish already, won't it?

english_grammar.title: らしい ①
english_grammar.explanation: Seems like, Apparently, I heard
english_grammar.structure: Verb + らしい ［い］Adjective + らしい ［な］Adjective + らしい Noun + らしい
english_grammar.about: The auxiliary verb らしい is very similar to the auxiliary verbs そうだ and ようだ, in that it expresses something that the speaker 'thinks' is true. This use is known as 推定(すいてい) (presumption) in Japanese. However, despite being a presumption/assumption, らしい usually sounds relatively confident.らしい is regularly translated as 'it seems like (A)', or 'I heard that (A)'.To use らしい, attach it to end of any (non-polite) verb, adjective, or noun. ねえ、聞(き)いた？タケシ君(くん)がキヨミちゃんにプロポーズするらしいよ。Hey, did you hear? It seems that Takeshi-kun is proposing to Kiyomi-chan. カシキさんの彼氏(かれし)はカッコいいらしいよ。I heard that Kashiki-san's boyfriend is handsome. タカギ先輩(せんぱい)がさっき言(い)っていた事(こと)は本当(ほんとう)らしいですよ。Apparently the thing that Takagi senpai was talking about earlier is true. あの人(ひと)はフランス人(じん)らしいよ。I heard that person is French. In these examples, らしい indicates that the speaker has some reason to believe that (A) is true. This could be that they heard, saw, or read something, but are still not 100% sure whether their understanding is correct or not. In this way, it sounds very similar to 'it appears as though (A)' in English. 今朝(けさ)、新聞(しんぶん)で読(よ)んだんだけど、明日(あした)から雪(ゆき)が降(ふ)るらしいよ。I read this in the newspaper this morning, but It appears as though it is going to start snowing tomorrow. Caution There are 2 main forms of らしい in Japanese. The auxiliary verb usage mentioned above, and the 形容詞(けいようし)の一部(いちぶ) (auxiliary adjective), a type of adjective that must be attached to another word for it have have any meaning usage. らしい has the meaning of something that is 'typical of (A)', when used as an auxiliary adjective. あなたは本当(ほんとう)に男(おとこ)らしいね。You are really manly, aren't you. (You exhibit the typical qualities of a man) やっと11月(がつ)らしい天気(てんき)になったね。The weather is finally becoming November-like, don't you think? (Weather that is typical of November) This い-Adjective use of らしい will be covered more in our second らしい lesson.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はダイエットを続(つづ)けるらしいです。

example.english: I heard that the president is going to Cuba. [It appears that he is going]

english_grammar.title: ～ておく
english_grammar.explanation: to do something in advance
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］+ おく Verb［て］ +とく
english_grammar.about: When the conjunction particle て is followed by the う-Verb 置(お)く in Japanese, it regularly has the meaning of 'to do (A) in advance'. 置(お)く as a verb itself means 'to place something' (down), but also has the nuance 'to leave something alone', or to 'drop something' (like a topic). In this way, ておく can be thought of as meaning 'to do (A) and leave it (until later)'. 寝(ね)る前(まえ)に食器(しょっき)を洗(あら)っておく。Before sleeping, I will wash the dishes in advance. (So that it does not need to be done later) あなたの財布(さいふ)を鞄(かばん)に入れておきます。I am going to put your wallet in your bag. (So that you won't forget it later) 予約(よやく)しておくね。I am going to make a reservation in advance. (So that the bookings don't fill up while we wait) When using ておく, the 'future event' that the (A) action is being done for may be something that is coming soon, or may be something that the speaker doesn't want to ever come. Due to this, ておく is also regularly used when the speaker is doing something specifically to prevent another thing from happening. 毎日(まいにち)歯(は)を磨(みが)いておくと、虫歯(むしば)が防(ふせ)ぎます。If you brush your teeth everyday, you will be able to prevent cavities. (That may or may not come in the future) Caution ておく is sometimes contracted to とく (or どく in verbs where て would usually be said as で). Although this is not excessively common in conversation, it is very common in drama, manga, and similar media. 机(つくえ)の上(うえ)に明日(あした)の旅行(りょこう)に必要(ひつよう)なパスポートを置(お)いとくね。I am going to leave the passport we need for the trip tomorrow on top of the table in advance. (So that I won't forget it later) 水筒(すいとう)に水(みず)を汲(く)んどくね。I am going to fill this thermos up with water in advance. (So that it is available when I am thirsty)

example.japanese: 明日(あした)のパーティーのためにジュースを買(か)っておきました。
example.english: I bought juice (in advance) for the party tomorrow.

example.japanese: 今夜(こんや)明日(あした)のお弁当(べんとう)を作(つく)っておいてくれますか。
example.english: Will you make tomorrow's bento (in advance) for me tonight?

example.japanese: ちょっと調(しら)べておきます。
example.english: I will do a little research in advance.

example.japanese: 旅行(りょこう)に行(い)く前(まえ)にトイレに行(い)っておく。
example.english: Before going on a trip I will go to the bathroom in advance.

example.japanese: アメリカに帰(かえ)る前(まえ)に円(えん)をドルに変(か)えておく。
example.english: Before returning to America, I will change my yen into dollars in advance.

synonym.explanation: something is done, has been done, remaining state

english_grammar.title: が欲(ほ)しい
english_grammar.explanation: To want something, To be in need of
english_grammar.structure: Noun + が + ほしい
english_grammar.attention: Do not confuse:,ほしくなかった[past negative], with,ほしくなった=> ほしい+なる
english_grammar.about: To say that you want something in Japanese, the が particle will be combined with the い-Adjective 欲(ほ)しい 'to want (A)', or 'to desire (A)'. This is exactly the same way as other い-Adjectives behave when describing nouns. 新(あたら)しい車(くるま)が欲(ほ)しいけど、今(いま)はお金(かね)が無(な)いから買(か)えない。I want a new car, but I don't have any money right now, so I can't buy one. 犬(いぬ)が欲(ほ)しいけどスペースが無(な)い。I want a dog, but I don't have space. Caution This use of 欲(ほ)しい is only used for saying that you want 'things' (nouns). The auxiliary verb たい will be used when saying that you want to 'do' something (verbs). あそこのラーメン屋(や)の餃子(ぎょうざ)を食(た)べたい。I want to eat gyoza from that ramen shop over there. However, ほしい may be used with verbs to express that you want another person to do something. This is done through the use of ほしい after the conjunction particle, て. 私(わたし)の彼氏(かれし)に大事(だいじ)にしてほしい。I want my boyfriend to treat me like I am important. For more detail about this, please see ourてほしい lesson.

example.japanese: 誕生日(たんじょうび)にお金(かね)がほしい。
example.english: I want money for my birthday.

example.japanese: 新(あたら)しい靴(くつ)より、新(あたら)しいカバンの方(ほう)がほしい。
example.english: More than new shoes, I want a new bag.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)はいい服(ふく)などがほしいです。
example.english: I want things such as nice clothes.

example.japanese: 使(つか)いやすい箸(はし)がほしい。
example.english: I want chopsticks that are easy to use.

example.japanese: あの綺麗(きれい)な着物(きもの)がほしい。
example.english: I want that beautiful kimono.

synonym.explanation: Want to do
To feel, To think, To act as if, To want, To desire
To want to (third person)
I want you to
Want ~ to ~ like ~, Want ~ to be able to ~, Want ~ to ~ in the way of ~

english_grammar.title: ～て欲(ほ)しい
english_grammar.explanation: I want you to
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］+ ほしい
english_grammar.about: As mentioned in our lesson about 'saying that you want something' with がほしい, sometimes ほしい can be used as auxiliary adjective (an adjective that needs to be connected to another word in order to have meaning). In these cases, it will follow the conjunction particle, て. When used this way, てほしい expresses that the speaker 'wants somebody to do something'.To use てほしい, simply change the verb that you 'want someone to do' into its て-form, and then add ほしい. もう一回(いっかい)説明(せつめい)してほしいです。I want you to explain it one more time. 皆(みんな)に俺(おれ)が書(か)いた漫画(まんが)を読(よ)んでほしい。I want everyone to read the manga that I wrote. Caution てほしい can also be used to ask questions/explain about what other people want you (or somebody else) to do. Due to this, we will need to be careful when trying to identify who wants who to do what. 手伝(てつだ)ってほしいの？You want me to help you? キヨミがタケルに家事(かじ)を手伝(てつだ)ってほしいと言(い)っていた。Kiyomi told Takeru that she wants him to help with chores.

example.japanese: 一緒(いっしょ)に勉強(べんきょう)してほしいです。
example.english: I want you to study together with me.

example.japanese: コーラを買(か)ってほしいです。
example.english: I want you to buy [me] a cola.

example.japanese: 毎日(まいにち)お弁当(べんとう)を作(つく)ってほしいです。
example.english: I want you to make me a bento every day.

example.japanese: 一緒(いっしょ)にサッカーをしてほしい。
example.english: I want you to play soccer with me.

example.japanese: 一緒(いっしょ)に食(た)べに行(い)ってほしいんです。
example.english: I want you to go out to eat with me.

synonym.explanation: Want to do
To want something, To be in need of
To want to (third person)
To feel, To think, To act as if, To want, To desire
Want ~ to ~ like ~, Want ~ to be able to ~, Want ~ to ~ in the way of ~

english_grammar.title: と聞(き)いた
english_grammar.explanation: I heard that
english_grammar.structure: Phrase + と聞いた Verb + と聞いた ［い］Adjective + と聞いた ［な］Adjective + （だ） + と聞いた Noun + （だ） + と聞いた
english_grammar.about: When the particle と is used for citation in Japanese, it is regularly partnered with other verbs, to form set phrases. One of these set expressions is と聞(き)いた, which means 'I heard that (A)'.と聞(き)いた may be used after any phrase expressing the thing that was heard. 来年(らいねん)から先輩(せんぱい)が私(わたし)と同(おな)じマンションに住(す)むと聞(き)いた。I heard that starting next year, my senpai is going to live in the same apartment that I do. 北海道(ほっかいどう)の冬(ふゆ)は、沖縄(おきなわ)の冬(ふゆ)より寒(さむ)いと聞(き)いた。I heard that winter in Hokkaido is colder than winter in Okinawa. 友達(ともだち)からあなたは歌(うた)うのが上手(じょうず)だと聞(き)いた。I heard from a friend that you are good at singing. 社長(しゃちょう)の息子(むすこ)がもう大学生(だいがくせい)だと聞(き)いた。I heard that the son of the company president is already a college student. Caution だ is often omitted after nouns and な-Adjectives when used with ときいた in casual conversation. While this sounds perfectly normal, it is technically not correct Japanese. あなたは泳(およ)ぐのが下手(へた)と聞(き)いたけど、本当(ほんとう)なの？I heard that you are bad at swimming, but is that true? あれが世界一(せかいいち)高(たか)い山(やま)と聞(き)いた。I heard that that mountain over there is the tallest in the world.

example.japanese: 明日(あした)はテストがあると聞(き)いた。
example.english: I heard that there is a test tomorrow.

example.japanese: これは無理(むり)だと聞(き)いた。
example.english: I heard that this is impossible.

example.japanese: トムは旅館(りょかん)に行(い)ったことがないと聞(き)いた。
example.english: I heard that Tom has never been to a ryokan.

example.japanese: 市内(しない)にあるスーツ屋(や)が安(やす)いと聞(き)いた。
example.english: I heard that suit shops in the city are cheap.

example.japanese: 近(ちか)くの映画館(えいがかん)のスクリーンが一番(いちばん)大(おお)きいと聞(き)いた。
example.english: I heard that the screens at the movie theater nearby are the biggest.

synonym.explanation: Seems like, Apparently, I heard
I heard that, it is said that
it seems that, it appears that, it looks like
I heard that, He/She said that
I heard/was said・because/cause・but・even/also・even if/even though

english_grammar.title: 聞(き)こえる
english_grammar.explanation: To be audible, to sound (like), (can) hear, to be heard
english_grammar.structure: Noun + が + 聞こえる ［い］Adjective［く］+ 聞こえる ［な］Adjective + に + 聞こえる Noun + に + 聞こえる
english_grammar.attention: 聞こえる was originally a conjugation of 聞く、but nowadays it is treated as a standalone intransitive verb
english_grammar.about: 聞(き)こえる is a verb that is often used to describe things that can be heard, or the way in which something is heard. Because of this, the most common translations of this verb are 'to be audible', or 'to sound like (A)'. 聞(き)こえる is an intransitive verb, and literally means 'to give off sound'.When using 聞(き)こえる, (A) will always be followed by が. (A) is considered to be the 'source' of the sound (a noun). However, the 'way that something sounds' will be marked adverbially. This means that an い-Adjective will be changed to its く form, and な-Adjectives/nouns will be followed by に. 車(くるま)の音(おと)が聞(き)こえる。I can hear the sound of a car. アニメに出(で)てくる女(おんな)の子(こ)の声(こえ)は可愛(かわい)く聞(き)こえるけど、声優(せいゆう)はいつもおばさんだ。Voices of girls that appear in anime sound cute, but the voice actor is always an old lady. こう歌(うた)うと上手(じょうず)に聞(き)こえる。If you sing like this, you will sound good. 電車(でんしゃ)に聞(き)こえるけどあれは隣(となり)の人(ひと)のいびきだ。It sounds like a train, but that is the neighbor's snoring. Fun FactThe primary difference between 聞(き)こえる, and 聞(き)ける (the potential form of 聞(き)く), is that 聞(き)こえる is used to identify things that do not require the active concentration of the listener to be heard. In other words, ambient noise. However, 聞(き)ける is used when the speaker is trying to concentrate on some specific sound, and refers to their 'ability' to hear it. 静(しず)かな部屋(へや)にいると聞(き)こえるよ。You can hear it if you are in a quiet room. (Without effort) 静(しず)かな部屋(へや)にいると聞(き)けるよ。If you are in a quiet room, you can hear it. (If you focus and try to hear the sound)

example.japanese: 「西山(にしやま)さんは生(う)まれつき耳(みみ)が聞(き)こえないんです。」
example.english: 'Nishiyama has been deaf since birth.'

example.japanese: 隣(となり)のせきくんはうるさすぎるわよ。彼(かれ)が音楽(おんがく)を聴(き)くときいつもあたしのアパートに聞(き)こえるわ！
example.english: My neighbor Seki is too loud! Whenever he listens to music, I can hear it in my flat!

example.japanese: 「教師(きょうし)の声(こえ)が小(ちい)さすぎるから何(なに)も聞(き)こえないんだよ。」
example.english: 'The teacher is too quiet, so I cannot hear anything.'

example.japanese: 「外(そと)がうるさいからテレビの音(おと)がよく聞(き)こえない。」
example.english: 'Since it is loud outside, I cannot hear the TV very well.'

example.japanese: 「滝(たき)の音(おと)はすごく大(おお)きくてここからでも聞(き)こえます！」
example.english: 'The sound of the waterfall is really loud, and we can hear it even from here!'

synonym.explanation: To be able, Can (potential)

english_grammar.title: 見(み)える
english_grammar.explanation: to be visible, to seem, to be in sight
english_grammar.structure: Noun + が + 見える
english_grammar.attention: 見える was originally a conjugation of 見る, but nowadays we treat it as a standalone intransitive verb. It is also used in honorific speech, meaning “to come.”
english_grammar.about: In the same way that 聞(き)こえる is used to describe things that are 'audible', 見(み)える can be used to describe things that are 'visible'. 見(み)える itself is an intransitive verb, meaning that the object that is 'visible' will be marked with が. この部屋(へや)からは富士山(ふじさん)が見(み)えます。Mount Fuji can be seen from this room. 遠(とお)くに建物(たてもの)が見(み)えるけどあれは何(なに)？I can see a building in the distance, but what is it? パンツが見(み)えるくらいを下(さ)げて、先生(せんせい)に怒(おこ)られた。My pants were sagging to the point where my underwear was visible, and I got scolded by my teacher. When using 見(み)える, (A) will always be followed by が. However, the 'way that something looks' will be marked adverbially. This means that an い-Adjective will be changed to its く form, and な-Adjectives/nouns will be followed by に. ここからだと小(ちい)さく見(み)えるけど、あのビルは130メートルもある。From here, the building looks small, but it is 130 meters tall. あの仕事(しごと)は大変(たいへん)に見(み)えるけど、簡単(かんたん)らしいよ。That job looks difficult, but I heard that it is easy. This usage of 見(み)える will be covered more in our focused lesson on this particular grammar structure.Fun FactThe primary difference between 見(み)える, and 見(み)られる (the potential form of 見(み)る), is that 見(み)える is used to identify things that do not require the active concentration of the spectator to be seen. In other words, seeing it is unavoidable (if looking in its direction of course). However, 見(み)られる is used when the onlooker, is trying to concentrate on some specific object, and is referring to their 'ability' to see it. 部屋(へや)を暗(くら)くして外(そと)を見(み)たら、星(ほし)が見(み)えるよ。If you make your room dark and look outside, you will see the stars. (Even without trying, you will see them) 部屋(へや)を暗(くら)くして外(そと)を見(み)たら、星(ほし)が見(み)られるよ。If you make your room dark and look outside, you will see the stars. (If you focus past the clouds, and give your eyes some time to adjust) Fun Fact見(み)える is also sometimes used to describe the 'sense' of sight, and refers to whether anything is visible at all for the speaker. 若(わか)い時(とき)に大(おお)きな怪我(けが)があったからなにも見(み)えない。Because of a big injury when I was young, I cannot see.

example.japanese: 「あの看板(かんばん)は大(おお)きいので、どこからでもよく見(み)える。」
example.english: "Since that signboard is big, it can be seen from anywhere."

example.japanese: 「富士山(ふじさん)はとても大(おお)きいから遠(とお)くからでもよく 見(み)える！」
example.english: "Mount Fuji is very big, so it can be clearly seen even from afar!"

example.japanese: 雨(あめ)がやんで、今(いま)でははっきりと見(み)えるよ♪
example.english: I can see clearly now, the rain is gone♪

example.japanese: 田舎(いなか)は都会(とかい)より明(あ)かりが少(すく)ないから星(ほし)がよく見(み)える。
example.english: There is less light in the countryside than in cities, so stars are clearly visible.

example.japanese: 目(め)が見(み)えない人(ひと)は聴覚(ちょうかく)が鋭(するど)い。
example.english: Blind people (lit. people who cannot see) often have a sharp sense of hearing.

synonym.explanation: To be able, Can (potential)
can see, can be seen, can observe, can be observed, be evident, chance to see something

english_grammar.title: 出(だ)す
english_grammar.explanation: to suddenly begin, to start doing
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ だす
english_grammar.about: だす, or 出(だ)す in its kanji form is a verb that is regularly attached to the conjunctive form of other verbs. When it is connected in this way, it has the meaning of 'to suddenly do (A)', or 'to burst into (A)'.To use this construction, simply add だす to the ます stem (conjunctive form) of the verb that you want to highlight as happening 'suddenly'. 最初(さいしょ)から速(はや)く走(はし)りだすのは体(からだ)に良(よ)くない。It is not good for your body if you suddenly start running fast. 転(ころ)んだ息子(むすこ)が泣(な)きだす前(まえ)に、あめをあげる。After falling, I give my son candy before he bursts into tears. Caution Unlike はじめる, another common structure which means 'to begin', だす quite often has the nuance of being unintentional, or something that the subject cannot avoid doing (or cannot be controlled). On the other hand, はじめる expresses the direct intention of the subject to do (A). コンサートで歌手(かしゅ)が歌(うた)を歌(うた)い始(はじ)める。At the concert, the singer will start singing. (Something that has been planned to be started) 最近(さいきん)、友達(ともだち)が授業(じゅぎょう)中(ちゅう)に歌(うた)いだした。Recently, my friend suddenly burst into song during class. (Something that happened without any prior plan/expectation)

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は答(こた)えを言(い)い出(だ)す時(とき)に、くしゃみをした。
example.english: He sneezed just as he started to say the answer.

example.japanese: あの子(こ)は急(きゅう)に泣(な)き出(だ)した。
example.english: That child suddenly started crying .

example.japanese: 面白(おもしろ)いことを今(いま)思(おも)い出(だ)した。
example.english: I suddenly remembered something funny.

example.japanese: 夜中(よなか)に夫(おっと)が急(きゅう)に餃子(ぎょうざ)を作(つく)り出(だ)した。
example.english: My husband suddenly started to make dumplings in the middle of the night.

example.japanese: 何(なに)も言(い)わないで走(はし)りだした。
example.english: Without saying a word, he suddenly began running.

synonym.explanation: To start, To begin to
for no reason, suddenly, all of a sudden
half-, not yet finished, about to, begin to

english_grammar.title: 代(だい)
english_grammar.explanation: Teens, Twenties, Thirties, 1910s, 20s/30s
english_grammar.structure: Decade of age + 代だい, Decade + 年代ねんだい
english_grammar.about: The suffix ～代(だい) is used for several different things. One of the most common uses is for highlighting someone's decade of age. In the same way that English says teens, twenties, and thirties. All that is required is adding 代(だい) after the age (in tens), in Japanese. 10代(だい)の頃(ころ)によく怒(おこ)られたよ。 I was scolded often when I was in my teens. 私(わたし)は20代(だい)の頃(ころ)に沢山(たくさん)旅行(りょこう)をしました。 I traveled a lot in my twenties. 六十(ろくじゅう)代(だい)の方(かた)はこちらにお並(おなら)びください。People in their sixties, please line up over here. In addition to someone's decade of age, ～代(だい) can be used to express a chronological decade, such as the 1960's, 70's, or 80's. In these cases, 年(ねん)代(だい) will be used after the decade. 70年(ねん)代(だい)の音楽(おんがく)が好(す)きです。I like music from the 70s. 80年(ねん)代(だい)のファッションはかっこいい。Fashion from the 80s is cool. Fun Fact代(だい) is also regularly seen when marking eras of time, or generations of people within a specific family/political position. 新生(しんせい)代(だい)は哺乳類時(ほにゅうるいじ)代(だい)とも言(い)われています。The Cenozoic era is also known as the era of mammals. 第(だい)5代(だい)将軍(しょうぐん)徳川綱吉(とくがわつなよし)はとても有名(ゆうめい)な将軍(しょうぐん)です。The fifth shogun, Tokugawa Tsunayoshi, is a very famous shogun.

example.japanese: 街頭(がいとう)インタビュー、通行人(つうこうにん)：「1980年(ねん)代(だい)ころからここに住(す)んでいます。」
example.english: Street interview, passerby: "I have been living here since (around) the 1980s."

example.japanese: 証人(しょうにん)が警察官(けいさつかん)に言(い)う：「泥棒(どろぼう)は３０代(だい)半(なか)ばだったと思います。」
example.english: A witness speaks to a policeman: "I think that the thief was in their mid-thirties."

example.japanese: 新聞記事(しんぶんきじ)：「Xさんは昭和(しょうわ)５０年(ねん)代(だい)の終(お)わりごろにお金持(かねも)ちになった。」
example.english: Newspaper article: "Mr. X became rich toward the end of the 50s of the Showa era."

example.japanese: 漫画(まんが)のナレーター：「イラめぐみは３０代(だい)前半(ぜんはん)次長(じちょう)になった。」
example.english: Manga narrator: "Megumi Ira became vice-director in her early thirties. "

example.japanese: 新聞記事(しんぶんきじ)：「２０１０年(ねん)代(だい)の終(お)わりからハイエンドスマホの値段(ねだん)が上(あ)がり始(はじ)めた。」
example.english: Newspaper article: "High-end smartphone prices started growing since the late 2010s."

english_grammar.title: Number + も
english_grammar.explanation: Emphasis, As ~ as, Not even
english_grammar.structure: Number + Counter + も
english_grammar.about: The adverbial particle も is often used for labeling (A) as part of a category, when it would not usually be considered part of that group. In this way, it emphasizes that (A)'s inclusion is something that is surprising/unexpected in some way. When も is used after a specific number + counter, it shows that the number itself is surprising. This can be when the actual number is lower, or higher than what was expected. Due to this, も can translate as 'as much as (A)', or 'not even (A)', and other similar phrases in this expression. 12時間(じかん)も仕事(しごと)をしたから疲(つか)れた。I worked as long as 12 hours, so I am tired. その携帯(けいたい)20万円(まんえん)もしたの？！That cellphone cost you as much as 200,000 yen?! 私(わたし)は一回(いっかい)も地下鉄(ちかてつ)に乗(の)ったことが無(な)い。 I have never taken the subway, not even once. At first glance, this may seem different than も's translation as 'too' or 'also', but in those cases, も is also just pointing out the something unexpected is part or whatever group was initially highlighted. 私(わたし)も行(い)きたい。I want to go too. The above sentence just shows that the (B) speaker is unexpectedly putting themselves in the group that the (A) speaker initially only considered themselves to be a part of.

example.japanese: １０万円(まんえん)も払(はら)わなくてはいけない。
example.english: I have to pay as much as 100,000 yen!

example.japanese: １０回(かい)もやったけど、できなかった。
example.english: I did it as many as 10 times but couldn't do it!

example.japanese: アメリカまで１５時間(じかん)もかかりました。
example.english: It took as long as 15 hours to get to America!

example.japanese: 10時間(じかん)も運転(うんてん)したけど、あまり疲(つか)れていない。
example.english: I did as much as 10 hours of driving, but I am not really that tired.

example.japanese: 「掃除(そうじ)をして」って何回(なんかい)も言(い)ったでしょう。
example.english: I told you to clean many times, right?

english_grammar.title: 殆(ほとん)ど
english_grammar.explanation: Almost all, Most, Hardly any, Few (adverbial noun)
english_grammar.structure: ほとんど + Phrase ほとんど + (Negative) Phrase
english_grammar.attention: generally written in kana, though 殆ど form can also be seen
english_grammar.about: The adverb ほとんど is used in many situations in Japanese, and often translates as 'most', 'hardly any', 'almost all', and similar expressions. The nuance will always depend on the rest of the sentence. The most accurate translation for the word ほとんど itself is simply 'almost', where the thing that it is describing is always considered to be a full group, rather than a single thing.As with many other adverbs that highlight an 'amount' in Japanese, ほとんど can modify a whole phrase, or can be used before の, to further specify a single noun. 宿題(しゅくだい)はほとんど終(お)わっているよ。Most of my homework is done. 弁当(べんとう)はほとんど食(た)べてないけど、おやつは全部(ぜんぶ)食(た)べた。I didn't eat most of my lunch, but I ate all the snacks. ほとんどの人(ひと)は私(わたし)の名前(なまえ)を読(よ)めません。Most people can't read my name. ほとんどの大学生(だいがくせい)は親(おや)と住(す)んでいます。Most college students live with their parents. In negative sentences, ほとんど translates as 'hardly any'. This is mainly due to the 'full group' that ほとんど is describing being highlighted as almost 'not' existing. 今年(ことし)は屋台(やたい)がほとんどないね。There are hardly any food stalls this year. 週末(しゅうまつ)に出(で)かけることはほとんどないです。I hardly go out during the weekends.

example.japanese: みんなは、ほとんど帰(かえ)りました。
example.english: Almost everyone has gone home.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)は宿題(しゅくだい)がほとんどない。
example.english: There is hardly any homework today.

example.japanese: この湖(みずうみ)はほとんど浅(あさ)いと思(おも)う。
example.english: This lake is mostly shallow, I think.

example.japanese: えっ！この魚(さかな)ほとんど匂(にお)いがない。
example.english: Huh?! This fish hardly has any smell.

example.japanese: 締(し)め切(き)りまでに出(だ)す生徒(せいと)がほとんどいなかった。
example.english: Hardly any students submitted (the paper) before the deadline.

synonym.explanation: hardly, rarely, seldom

english_grammar.title: そんな
english_grammar.explanation: such a・kind of, something like ~
english_grammar.structure: そんな + Noun, こんな + Noun, あんな + Noun, どんな + Noun
english_grammar.about: One of the most common ways to convey that something is 'like' something else in casual conversation, is through the use of そんな, こんな, あんな, or どんな (when asking a question). These are not officially words themselves, but are abbreviations that come from そのような, このような, あのような, and どのような.To use this casual expression, simply say it directly before the noun that you are describing, or enquiring about. そんな言(い)い方(かた)してはいけません。You should not phrase it like that. こんな高(たか)いものはもらえないよ。I can't accept a gift this expensive. あんな大人(おとな)にはなりたくない。I don't want to become an adult like that. どんな靴(くつ)が欲(ほ)しい？What kind of shoes do you want? Because these abbreviations originally come from a longer (more formal) variation, that form may also be used in situations where you would like to sound a little bit more polite. そのような商品(しょうひん)はないです。 We don't have a product like that. このような場合(ばあい)にはどうすればいいですか。What should we do in a situation like this? あのような運転(うんてん)をしないでください。Please do not drive like that. どのような商品(しょうひん)をお探(さが)しですか？What kind of product are you looking for?

example.japanese: こんな畳(たたみ)が大体(だいたい)寝(ね)やすい。
example.english: Tatami mats like these are generally easy to sleep on.

example.japanese: あんな駐車場(ちゅうしゃじょう)は使(つか)いにくい。
example.english: A parking lot like that [over there] is hard to use.

example.japanese: そんな技術(ぎじゅつ)は珍(めずら)しい。
example.english: A skill such as that is rare.

example.japanese: そんなことを言(い)わないでくれませんか。
example.english: Could you not say such things please. [close to listener]

example.japanese: どんな車(くるま)がいい。
example.english: What kind of car is good?

synonym.explanation: Like that, Kind of
so (much), that much, like that
what kind of, no matter what kind of, no … (with a negative verb); any... (with a negative verb)

english_grammar.title: 各(かく)
english_grammar.explanation: each, every, respective, various
english_grammar.structure: 各 + Noun
english_grammar.about: One of the slightly more formal ways to say that something is happening 'each', or 'every' (A) in Japanese, is by using the prefix 各(かく). While there is no strict rule for when this prefix can be used, it is almost always seen before words of Chinese origin (kanji compounds), or katakana words. このエレベーターは各(かく)階(かい)で止(と)まります。This elevator will stop at each floor. このホテルは各(かく)部屋(へや)に洗濯機(せんたっき)がついている。This hotel has a washing machine in every room. ここは正月(しょうがつ)になると日本(にほん)各(かく)地(ち)からの観光客(かんこうきゃく)でいっぱいになる。When it becomes New Year's, this place is filled with tourists from each and every place in Japan. Although this kanji is used to mark 'each', it is very rarely used to mark units of time. The most common/natural usage of 各(かく) is for identifying things that are part of a sequence. For example: Each/Every stop, on a train line that has many stops.Each/Every page, in a book that has many pages.Each/Every floor, in a building that has many floors.Each/Every house, in a street of many houses.Fun FactThis kanji is used in another word, 各々(おのおの), which also means 'each', but is primarily used for identifying people. 弁当(べんとう)は各々(おのおの)で用意(ようい)してきてください。Please come prepared with your own lunch. (Each person should bring their own lunch)

example.japanese: ここに並(なら)んでいる各(かく)製品(せいひん)はアルミ製品(せいひん)です。
example.english: Each product lined up here is an aluminum product.

example.japanese: 各(かく)ファイルを各(かく)自(じ)アップロードする必要(ひつよう)がある。
example.english: It is necessary to upload each file individually.

example.japanese: このバスは各(かく)バス停(てい)に止(と)まります。
example.english: This bus stops at each station.

example.japanese: 各(かく)自(じ)で弁当(べんとう)を持(も)ってきてください。
example.english: Please bring your own respective bento (individually).

example.japanese: この書類(しょるい)の各(かく)ページをプリントアウトしてください。
example.english: Please print each page of this document.

english_grammar.title: 以上(いじょう) ①
english_grammar.explanation: more than (or equal to), over・(and) above, any more・greater, exceeding
english_grammar.structure: Noun + Amount + 以上 それ(1) + 以上 (1) これ、あれ
english_grammar.attention: Actual Amount ≥ Amount + Counter
english_grammar.about: In order to mark something as 'equal to, or more than (A)', 以上(いじょう) will be used. This is simply a combination of the kanji 以(い) which means 'by means of', and 上(じょう) 'above'. This expression may also be translated as 'greater than (A)', or 'exceeding (A)'.To use 以上(いじょう), attach it to the amount that you want to highlight as the 'minimum' amount. 70歳(さい)以上(いじょう)の人(ひと)は運転(うんてん)をしない方(ほう)がいい。It would be better if people over the age of 70 didn't drive. コンサートには500人(にん)以上(いじょう)のファンが集(あつ)まった。More than 500 fans gathered at the concert. 以上(いじょう) is also regularly used as a statement that translates roughly as 'the end', or 'that's it', and is a very common way to say that something has finished. え～っと、ビッグマックのセットとクォーターパウンダーの単品(たんぴん)とナゲットの30ピースを下(くだ)さい。以上(いじょう)です。Uhhh, Can I have a Big Mac meal, a quarter pounder, and 30 nuggets? That's all. Although saying 'the end' would sound a bit rude in English in this situation, it is completely natural in Japanese, and literally means 'the above (list of things I said) is all'.

example.japanese: その時(とき)に100人(にん)以上(いじょう)も参加(さんか)した。
example.english: At that time, more than 100 people attended.

example.japanese: 六(ろく)歳(さい)以上(いじょう)
example.english: Ages 6 and over.

example.japanese: カタカナを全部(ぜんぶ)覚(おぼ)えたけど、２週間(しゅうかん)以上(いじょう)かかりました。
example.english: I memorized all of the katakana, but it took over two weeks.

example.japanese: これ以上(いじょう)はもう聞(き)きたくない。
example.english: I don't want to listen to this any more (than this).

example.japanese: 明日(あす)までに漢字(かんじ)100個(こ)以上(いじょう)覚(おぼ)えなくてはならない。
example.english: I have to memorize over 100 kanji by tomorrow.

synonym.explanation: More than, Over
more than, no less than, even more
as much as, as many as, at least

antonym.explanation: Less than (or equal to), under・(and) below, any less・fewer, not exceeding

english_grammar.title: 以下(いか)
english_grammar.explanation: Less than (or equal to), under・(and) below, any less・fewer, not exceeding
english_grammar.structure: Noun + Amount + 以下 それ(1) + 以下 (1) これ、あれ
english_grammar.attention: Actual Amount ≤ Amount + Counter
english_grammar.about: In order to mark something as 'equal to, or less than (A)', 以下(いか) will be used. This is simply a combination of the kanji 以(い) which means 'by means of', and 下(か) 'below'. This expression may also be translated as 'under (A)', or 'fewer than (A)'.To use 以下(いか), attach it to the amount that you want to highlight as the 'maximum' amount. 17歳(さい)以下(いか)の方(かた)は保護者(ほごしゃ)の方(かた)と来(き)てください。For those under the age of 17, please come with a guardian. この車(くるま)は30万円(まんえん)以下(いか)だった。This car was under 300,000 yen. Similarly to the way that 以上(いじょう) can be used to mark 'everything up until now', 以下(いか) can and often is used to highlight 'everything after now', 'the rest', or 'the following'. 以下(いか)同文(どうぶん)。The rest is the same. (Usually seen in documents to notify the reader that the rest of the document basically repeats what has already been said) 空港(くうこう)には以下(いか)のものを持(も)って来(き)てください。Please bring the following to the airport.

example.japanese: この家(いえ)は２０００万(まん)円(えん)以下(いか)です。
example.english: This house costs less than 20 million yen.

example.japanese: 日本(にほん)では１７歳(さい)以下(いか)の人(ひと)は運転(うんてん)が出来(でき)ない。
example.english: In Japan, those 17 or younger cannot drive.

example.japanese: ８０点(てん)以下(いか)なら、もう一回(いっかい)テストを受(う)けなくてはいけない。
example.english: If you get 80 points or less, you have to take the test one more time.

example.japanese: 5000円(えん)以下(いか)のコーヒーメーカーがないんですか。
example.english: Are there no coffee makers below 5000 yen?

example.japanese: これ以下(いか)の値段(ねだん)がありません。
example.english: There are none under this price.

synonym.explanation: more than (or equal to), over・(and) above, any more・greater, exceeding

english_grammar.title: 以外(いがい)
english_grammar.explanation: except・besides, other than, with the exception of
english_grammar.structure: Verb + 以外 Noun + 以外
english_grammar.about: In order to mark something as 'except (A)', or 'besides (A)', 以外(いがい) will be used. This construction is a combination of the kanji 以(い) which means 'by means of', and 外(がい) 'outside'. This expression can most accurately be translated as 'with the exception of (A)', or 'everything outside of (A)'.To use 以外(いがい), attach it to the thing that you want to highlight as being the 'all inclusive' amount/area. 今日(きょう)は和食(わしょく)いがいのものが食(た)べたい。Today I want to eat something other than Japanese food. タロウはゲームいがいに趣味(しゅみ)はあるの？Taro, do you have any other interests besides gaming? Fun Fact以外(いがい) is also regularly used simply as an expression of surprise, when someone sees, hears, or reads something that is 'outside' of what they expected. However, in these cases, the more correct kanji construction is 意外(いがい) 'out of mind'. This is a regular mistake that even native speakers make, so in many cases, either 意外(いがい) or 以外(いがい) would be understandable. たかし君(くん)もアニメ好(す)きなの？ちょっといがいだね。Takashi-kun, do you like anime too? I'm a little surprised. 俺(おれ)こう見(み)えても意外(いがい)に肉(にく)を食(た)べないの。It may come off as a surprise based on how I look, but I don't eat meat.

example.japanese: メアリー以外(いがい)、誰(だれ)も来(こ)なかった。
example.english: No one except Mary came.

example.japanese: 今(いま)まで漢字(かんじ)以外(いがい)、何(なに)も勉強(べんきょう)していなかった。
example.english: Until now, I haven't been studying anything except kanji.

example.japanese: それ以外(いがい)、聞(き)いてないよ。
example.english: I haven't heard anything other than that.

example.japanese: 納豆(なっとう)以外(いがい)何(なん)でも食(た)べられる。
example.english: I can eat anything other than natto.

example.japanese: そのこと以外(いがい)気(き)がついていなかった。
example.english: I didn't notice anything other than that.

synonym.explanation: other・another, any other・anything else, as well as・besides・in addition
setting aside, apart from
except, with the exception of, unless
no...but, nothing else but, none other than

english_grammar.title: ずっと ①
english_grammar.explanation: continuously, all throughout, entire time, ever (since), the whole time, all the way
english_grammar.structure: ずっと + Phrase
english_grammar.about: The adverb ずっと has two primary meanings in Japanese. The first is that something keeps going in a constant state, without ever stopping/resting, and the second is to emphasize an amount of something. We will examine the first meaning in this lesson.To use ずっと, add it to the beginning of the phrase that you want to highlight as being ongoing. ずっとゲームをしないでたまには勉強(べんきょう)もする。Instead of continuously gaming, I occasionally also study. ずっと立(た)ってたから足(あし)が痛(いた)い。I was standing the whole time, so my feet hurt. Alternatively, ずっと can be used after から, to express that something has been continuing 'ever since' some specific event/point in time. 昨日(きのう)からずっと寝(ね)てないからメチャ眠(ねむ)い。I haven't slept at all since yesterday, so I am extremely tired. 朝(あさ)からずっと何(なに)も食(た)べていないからお腹(なか)が空(す)いたよ。I haven't eaten anything at all since morning, so I am hungry. Fun Factずっと literally means that something is 'unwavering', or 'unfaltering'. Due to this, the statement that ずっと is attached to will always be perceived as being 'far more (A)', or 'to the maximum amount possible for (A)', regardless of whether it is highlighting a noun, verb, or an adjective.

example.japanese: 朝(あさ)からずっと忙(いそが)しいですよ。
example.english: I have been continuously busy since morning.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は子供(こども)の頃(ころ)から彼(かれ)にずっと会(あ)っていません。
example.english: I have not met him ever since I was a child.

example.japanese: 私達(わたしたち)は結婚(けっこん)してからずっとここに住(す)んでいます。
example.english: Ever since we got married, we have always lived here.

example.japanese: 冬休(ふゆやす)みはノートパソコンを買(か)えるようにずっと働(はたら)いていた。
example.english: I worked all throughout winter vacation in order to be able to buy a new laptop.

example.japanese: 警察(けいさつ)：「昨日(きのう)の晩(ばん)、何(なに)をしていたのですか。」容疑者(ようぎしゃ)：「ずっと家(いえ)にいました。」
example.english: Policeman: "What did you do last evening?"Suspect: "I was at home the whole time."

synonym.explanation: by far, way, far...er, far...more

english_grammar.title: 大体(だいたい)
english_grammar.explanation: most・mostly, adequately・generally, for the most part, roughly・approximately, in the first place
english_grammar.structure: だいたい + Phrase だいたい + Number(1) だいたい + の + Noun (1) Degree
english_grammar.about: 大体(だいたい) is an adverb that is used to highlight the 'main point' of something in Japanese, and therefore has several different nuances. 大体(だいたい) will regularly be translated as 'mostly', 'generally', or 'for the most part'.As with other adverbs that highlight amounts, 大体(だいたい) can be used to modify entire phrases, or can be used directly before a noun as 大体(だいたい)の + noun. だいたいでいいから何時(なんじ)くらいに着(つ)くか教(おし)えて。Since a general time is okay, can you let me know around when you will arrive? 水曜日(すいようび)はだいたい5時(じ)に起(お)きています。On Wednesdays, I generally wake up at 5 am. だいたいの人(ひと)たち薔薇(ばら)という漢字(かんじ)を書(か)けません。Most people do not know how to write the kanji 'bara'. (薔薇(ばら) is the kanji for 'rose') In a similar way to そもそも, a noun/adverb which means 'in the first place', 大体(だいたい) can also have this meaning. This nuance is frequently quite obvious, as the rest of the sentence will highlight a desired outcome that unfortunately did not happen. だいたいなんでお前(まえ)がここにいるの？Why are you here in the first place? (No one wants you here) Although these 2 primary uses of 大体(だいたい) may seem quite different, they are both just expressing what is 'essentially' correct, most common, the original, etc.Fun FactA common synonym for 大体(だいたい) is 根本(ねもと), a noun which means 'the source', or 'the origin' or something. In this way, 大体(だいたい) just expresses the way something is, without receiving any alterations (regardless of whether any subsequent alterations are positive or negative). This is where the 'in essence' meaning comes from. と言(い)うことは私(わたし)たちが言(い)っていることはだいたい一緒(いっしょ)なのね。In that case, what we are both saying is the same in essence.

example.japanese: 「日本語(にほんご)がだいたい分(わ)かる。」
example.english: "I roughly understand Japanese."

example.japanese: 焼(や)きたてパンについて話(はな)しているカップル：彼女(かのじょ)：「どう？」彼氏(かれし)：「だいたいいいと思(おも)うんだけど、」
example.english: Couple talking about freshly baked bread: Girlfriend: "How is it?"Boyfriend: "I think it is mostly good, but…" [adequately]

example.japanese: 「彼女(かのじょ)はだいたいの状況(じょうきょう)を知(し)っています。」
example.english: "She has the general idea of the situation."

example.japanese: 「父(ちち)はだいたい５時(じ)ごろ帰(かえ)ります。」
example.english: "Father will be back approximately around 5."

example.japanese: このサイトにいる人(ひと)は、だいたい真面目(まじめ)な人(ひと)だと思(おも)う。外国語(がいこくご)を学(まな)ぶときはそれが必要(ひつよう)だからね。
example.english: I think that people on this site are mostly diligent. Because you need that when learning a foreign language.

english_grammar.title: の中(なか)で
english_grammar.explanation: in, among, within
english_grammar.structure: Noun + の + 中で その(1) + 中で (1) この
english_grammar.about: Just like the grammar point の中(なか)で～が一番(いちばん)～, this grammar point may be used when marking one thing from within a group, and then further describing it. The only difference is that の中(なか)で by itself simply marks something as being 'among (A)', or 'within (A)', rather than being the 'most (A)'. ラーメンの中(なか)では味噌(みそ)ラーメンが好(す)き。Among ramen, I like the miso type. このバンドの中(なか)では誰(だれ)が好(す)き？Who do you like in this band? の中(なか)で is also frequently used to describe things that are happening within a place, and will translate simply as 'in (A)', in these cases. 車(くるま)の中(なか)で夕食(ゆうしょく)を食(た)べました。I ate dinner in my car.

example.japanese: この三(みっ)つの中(なか)では、赤(あか)色(いろ)が好(す)き。
example.english: Among these three, I like the red one.

example.japanese: フルーツの中(なか)で、イチゴとかパインが好(す)き。
example.english: Among all fruits, I like strawberries and pineapple.

example.japanese: ひらがなとカタカナと漢字(かんじ)の中(なか)で、ひらがなしか書(か)けない。
example.english: Among hiragana, katakana, and kanji, I can only write hiragana.

example.japanese: この中(なか)で一(ひと)つを選(えら)んでください。
example.english: Please choose one from among these.

example.japanese: 公園(こうえん)の中(なか)で子供(こども)達(たち)が遊(あそ)んでいた。
example.english: The children were playing in the park. [within]

synonym.explanation: Out of ~, ~ is the best/most ~
fellow・with each other, mutually, between・among, together・with
of the, among(st)
very・quite, considerably

english_grammar.title: 様(よう) + に・な
english_grammar.explanation: as・like, just like
english_grammar.structure: Verb + よう + に + Verb(1) Verb + よう + な + Noun (1) Adverb、［い］Adjective、［な］Adjective
english_grammar.about: We have seen many cases now where the auxiliary verb ようだ may be modified slightly to show that something is being done 'in a way' that will bring about a specific outcome. In this lesson, we will look at how ような (when used with nouns), or ように (when used with verbs) may be used with almost any noun/verb, to show that they are being done/existing in a particular manner. 彼(かれ)は亀(かめ)のように走(はし)る。He runs like a turtle. バケツをひっくり返(かえ)したように雨(あめ)が降(ふ)っている。It is raining like a bucket was flipped over. (It's pouring rain) 彼(かれ)の車(くるま)は工場(こうじょう)のような臭(にお)いがする。His car smells like a factory. (His car has an industrial smell) キトウ先生(せんせい)は鬼(おに)のような怒(おこ)り方(かた)をする。The way Kito-sensei gets mad is like a demon. Sometimes, this structure is used purely to express the speaker's uncertainty about whether (B) really is being done/existing in the way of (A). In these cases, ように (or ような) will be translated as 'as if', or 'as though'. 彼(かれ)は今(いま)、人(ひと)を殺(ころ)すような目(め)をしている。Right now, his eyes look as if he is about to kill someone.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は食(た)べすぎたような顔(かお)をしている。
example.english: He looks like he ate too much.

example.japanese: あなたが言(い)ったように、事故(じこ)が起(お)こった。
example.english: An accident happened just like you said.

example.japanese: １０代(だい)に戻(もど)ったように楽(たの)しかった。
example.english: It was fun, just like being in my teens again.

example.japanese: 君(きみ)が言(い)うように綺麗(きれい)ですね。
example.english: It is beautiful, just like you say.

example.japanese: 想像(そうぞう)できないようなアイディアが沢山(たくさん)ありました。
example.english: I had ideas like you couldn't imagine.

synonym.explanation: Like (noun), Similar to (noun)
Seem, Look like, Sound
Like, Similar to, Resembling
Like, Similar to, Resembling
Look like, Appear, Seem, Have a feeling that

english_grammar.title: (Amount) + は
english_grammar.explanation: at least, sort of, or so
english_grammar.structure: Number/Amount + Counter + （くらい(1)） + は Noun + くらい(1) + は (1) ぐらい
english_grammar.attention: は is pronounced "わ"
english_grammar.about: The は particle has two primary functions. The first is to mark the topic of a sentence, as learned very early in our Japanese language journey. However, the second common usage of は is to highlight contrast (making a comparison). When は is used after a number/counter, it regularly has this comparison meaning. This can be translated as 'or so', or 'at least'. ディズニーランドには年(ねん)に5回(かい)は行(い)っている。I go to Disneyland at least 5 times a year. 私(わたし)は毎日(まいにち)、テレビを5時間(じかん)は見(み)ている。Every day, I watch TV for 5 hours or so. Before は, the counter is regularly followed by くらい (or ぐらい). This just softens the statement, and further highlights the 'or so' meaning. 2キロくらいはあると思(おも)う。I think it is at least 2 kilograms. 倉敷(くらしき)には1回(かい)ぐらいは行(い)った方(ほう)がいいよ。You should go to Kurashiki at least once. Despite being translated as 'at least', the comparative meaning of は itself is what creates the nuance of this grammar structure. The thing before は is being highlighted as an amount, while also implying that there are other amounts. This implication of another amount makes は sound as if it could mean 'as opposed to (B)'. So in essence, this grammar structure sounds like 'As for (A), as opposed to (B)', where (B) is not usually mentioned.

example.japanese: この食(た)べ物(もの)は少(すく)なくとも床(ゆか)に3秒(びょう)は落(お)ちていたから食(た)べられない。
example.english: This food was on the floor for at least 3 seconds, so I can't eat it.

example.japanese: 付(つ)き合(あ)っているんだから手(て)ぐらいはつないだでしょうね？
example.english: Since you are going out, you were at least holding hands, right?

example.japanese: 彼氏(かれし)は１日(にち)８回(かい)は電話(でんわ)をかける。
example.english: My boyfriend calls at least 8 times a day.

example.japanese: 心配(しんぱい)な母親(ははおや)：「肉(にく)ぐらいは少(すこ)し食(た)べてよ。」
example.english: Worried mother: "Please eat some meat at least!"

example.japanese: スティーブン・ホーキングに一回(いっかい)は会(あ)いたかったのに…
example.english: (But) I wanted to meet Stephen Hawking at least once…

synonym.explanation: As for... (highlights sentence topic)

english_grammar.title: 何(なん) + (Counter) + か
english_grammar.explanation: some, several, a few
english_grammar.structure: 何 + Counter + か いく + Counter + か いくつか
english_grammar.about: The expression なん + counter + か in Japanese is a way of highlighting an uncertain number of something, and comes across similarly to 'some', 'several', or 'a few' in English. Literally, the meaning is much closer to 'what + counter + I wonder?', as it shows the speaker's uncertainty about the number. そこには何(なん)回(かい)か行(い)ったことがあると思(おも)う。I think I have been there several times. ごめん、紙(かみ)を何(なん)枚(まい)かちょうだい。Sorry, may I have some paper? In addition to なん; いく, from the kanji 幾(いく) (how many/much) may be used as part of this construction. While both are fairly common, 幾(いく) is more common as part of set expressions, like 幾(いく)ら (how much) and 幾(いく)つ (how many/old), while なん is more common for counting specific things, like people. この車(くるま)はいくらですか？How much is this car? マリちゃんは幾(いく)つになったの？How old did Mari-chan turn? Both 何(なん) and 幾(いく) are regularly seen in plain hiragana and their kanji forms, so it is worth remembering both.Caution Despite having the same kanji as 何(なに), なん will almost always be used to count things, while なに will be used to identify things. いらない本(ほん)を何冊(なんさつ)か妹(いもうと)にあげた。I gave several books that I didn't need to my sister. お前(まえ)は何者(なにもの)だ！Who are you! (What kind of person are you)

example.japanese: 選手(せんしゅ)の何人(なんにん)かが負傷(ふしょう)した。
example.english: Some athletes were wounded.

example.japanese: 何冊(なんさつ)かの本(ほん)が山(やま)のように床(ゆか)に積(つ)まれていた。
example.english: Some books were piled on the floor like a mountain.

example.japanese: 何本(なんぼん)かの高級(こうきゅう)な木(き)の幹(みき)を製材所(せいざいしょ)に届(とど)けた。
example.english: I sent some high grade tree trunks to the sawmill.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は何匹(なんびき)かの猫(ねこ)を撫(な)でるように命(めい)じられた。
example.english: He was ordered to pet several cats.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)らの写真(しゃしん)を何枚(なんまい)か撮(と)れてよかった。
example.english: I am glad that I was able to take a few photos of them.

english_grammar.title: 真(ま)っ
english_grammar.explanation: Completely, exactly, right
english_grammar.structure: 真ま(っ) + ［い］Adjective［い］ 真ま(っ) + Noun 真まん + ま(*)・な(*): 真まん中、真まん前、真まん丸 真まっ + か(*)・さ(*)・しゃ(*): 真まっ黄色、真まっ白、真まっ先、真まっ正直 真まっ + は(*)(**): 真まっ平ぴら、真まっ裸ぱだか Exceptions: 青あおい ￫ 真まっ青さお 赤あかい ￫ 真まっ赤か (*) column in the kana chart (**) H sound becomes P sound
english_grammar.about: The prefix ま, coming from the kanji 真(ま) (true), is attached to words in Japanese to express that something is 'completely', 'exactly', 'genuinely' (A). Depending on the word that follows 真(ま), several different conjugation patterns will be used. This conjugation depends on which column the first kana of the word after 真(ま)comes from. ま comes from the ま, み, む, め, も column, for example.When linked with a ま column, or な column word, 真(ま) will become 真(ま)ん. この猫(ねこ)は真(ま)ん丸(まる)していてかわいい。This cat is completely circular and cute. (This cat is so fat that it is cute) 真(ま)ん中(なか)にある本(ほん)をとってください。Please take the book in the middle. When linked with a か column, さ column, or しゃ sound word, 真(ま) will become 真(ま)っ. 体(からだ)が真(ま)っ赤(か)になるくらい お風呂(ふろ)が熱(あつ)かった。The bath was so hot that my body went completely red. サルが木(き)から真(ま)っ逆(さか)さまに落(お)ちた。The monkey fell completely upside down from the tree. 道(みち)が雪(ゆき)で真(ま)っ白(しろ)になった。The road turned completely white with snow. When linked with a は column, 真(ま) will become 真(ま)っ, and the first kana of the following word will change to a 'P' sound. ちょっと、何(なん)で真(ま)っ裸(ぱだか)なの？Wait, why are you completely naked? 真(ま)っ昼間(ぴるま)からこんな話(はな)をするの？You are going to talk about this in the middle of the day? (Are you seriously going to talk about something like this in the middle of the day?) Caution There are several exceptions to the standard changes that happen when using 真(ま) as a prefix. These are as follows.When linked with 青(あお)い, 真(ま) will become 真(ま)っ, and 青(あお)い will become 青(さお). 空(そら)が真(ま)っ青(さお)できれいだね。The sky is completely blue and beautiful. When linked with 赤(あか)い, 真(ま) will become 真(ま)っ, and 赤(あか)い will become 赤(か). 顔(かお)が真(ま)っ赤(か)になってるよ、大丈夫(だいじょうぶ)？Your face is completely red, are you okay?

example.japanese: 道(みち)の真(ま)ん中(なか)に鹿(しか)がいた。
example.english: There was a deer right in the middle of the road.

example.japanese: この道路(どうろ)を真(ま)っ直(す)ぐ行(い)ってください。
example.english: Please go (exactly) straight down this street.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は竹(たけ)を刀(かたな)で真(ま)っ二(ぷた)つに切(き)った。
example.english: He cut the bamboo right in two with a sword.

example.japanese: 急(きゅう)に立(た)ったから、目(め)の前(まえ)が真(ま)っ黒(くろ)になってしまった。
example.english: Because I stood up suddenly, everything went completely black.

example.japanese: 可愛(かわ)い女(おんな)の子(こ)に声(こえ)をかけられたの？顔(かお)が真(ま)っ赤(か)！
example.english: Did a cute girl talk to you? Your face is completely red.

english_grammar.title: (Number) + しか〜ない
english_grammar.explanation: no more than, not exceeding, as few as・as little as, only
english_grammar.structure: Number + しか + Verb［ない］
english_grammar.about: The adverbial particle しか is often compared to だけ, in that it also expresses 'only'. However, unlike だけ, しか can only be used in negative statements. Due to this, しか～ない is regularly translated as 'there's only (A)', or 'there's nothing but (A)'. しか～ない may be used to express numbers, or nouns. In this lesson we will examine numbers.To use this construction, the number that you want to express as being 'all that exists' will go before しか, then しか will be followed by a verb in its ない, or ありません form. 今日(きょう)は5キロしか走(はし)れない。I can only run 5 km today. 今日(きょう)は100円(えん)しか持(も)っていない。I have nothing but 100 yen on me. 今日(きょう)はたくさんの宿題(しゅくだい)があるから2時間(じかん)しか遊(あそ)べない。I have a lot of homework today, so I can only hang out for 2 hours. Fun FactThe main difference between しか and だけ, is that だけ suggests that (A) was 'chosen' from among a group where several other choices exist. しか on the other hand implies that there are no other choices, and (A) is the only possibility/thing that exists. 冷蔵庫(れいぞうこ)の中(なか)には色々(いろいろ)な物(もの)が入(はい)っていたけど、リンゴだけを取(と)り出(だ)した。 There were a lot of things in the refrigerator, but I just took out an apple. 冷蔵庫(れいぞうこ)の中(なか)にはリンゴしかなかったから、リンゴを食(た)べた。Apples were all that was in the refrigerator, so I ate an apple.

example.japanese: お金持(かねも)ちなのに現金(げんきん)は1000円(えん)しか持(も)っていない。
example.english: Even though (they) are rich, (they) have no more than 1000 yen in cash.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)にはまだ1回(いっかい)しか会(あ)っていない。
example.english: I have met her no more than once.

example.japanese: 計画書(けいかくしょ)は1枚(まい)しか提出(ていしゅつ)できない。
example.english: You can submit only one plan.

example.japanese: 髪(かみ)の毛(け)が3本(ぼん)しか生(は)えていない。
example.english: (He) has no more than three hairs (on his head).

example.japanese: 一(いっ)ヶ月(かげつ)しか期間(きかん)がないのに、あなたは変(か)われるの？
example.english: You only have (the period of) one month. Can you change?

synonym.explanation: there's only, nothing but

english_grammar.title: は～の一(ひと)つだ
english_grammar.explanation: 〜 is one of (many) 〜
english_grammar.structure: Noun (A) + は + (Category) Noun (B) + の一つ + だ
english_grammar.about: In order to express that something is only one thing from within a larger category, the construction ～は～の一(ひと)つだ will be used. In this expression, (A), the thing that there is one of, will be followed by は. After this, (B) + の一(ひと)つだ will highlight the broader category to which (A) belongs. アンドロイドはスマートフォンのOSの一(ひと)つだ。Android is one of (many) smartphone operating systems. 電車(でんしゃ)は乗(の)り物(もの)の一(ひと)つです。Trains are one of (many) vehicles. In this grammar point, の一(ひと)つ is a standard counter. This means that other counters can and will be used, when they are more appropriate than 一(ひと)つ. 彼(かれ)も家族(かぞく)の一人(ひとり)だ。He is also one member of my family. トマトはフルーツの一種(いっしゅ)だ。Tomatoes are one of many types of fruits. このクレヨンはこのセットの一本(いっぽん)だ。This crayon is part of this set.

example.japanese: ホンダは車(くるま)のメーカーの一(ひと)つだ。
example.english: Honda is one of (many) car makers.

example.japanese: アイフォンはスマートフォンの一(ひと)つだ。
example.english: iPhone is one of (many) smartphones.

example.japanese: 文法(ぶんぽう)は大事(だいじ)な勉強(べんきょう)の一(ひと)つです。
example.english: Grammar is one of (many) important things to study.

example.japanese: コカコーラはコーラの一(ひと)つだ。
example.english: Coca-cola is one of many colas.

example.japanese: 寿司(すし)は日本(にほん)の有名(ゆうめい)な食(た)べ物(もの)の一(ひと)つだ。
example.english: Sushi is one of many famous Japanese foods.

synonym.explanation: of the, among(st)

english_grammar.title: ない～はない
english_grammar.explanation: There is not ~ that is not/does not
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］+ Noun + は + ない ［い］Adjective［ない］+ Noun + は + Verb［ない］ ［な］Adjective + じゃない(1) + Noun + は + Verb［ない］ (1) ではない
english_grammar.about: ～ない～はない is an example of a double negative in Japanese, and is a grammar construction that requires careful attention in order not to incorrectly interpret. Both the い-Adjective (形容詞(けいようし)), and auxiliary verb forms of ない may be used in this construction, depending on what type of word is being negated. Let's take a look at a few examples. 彼(かれ)にはピアノで弾(ひ)けない曲(きょく)ない。There is no song that he can't play on the piano. 私(わたし)は美味(おい)しくない食(た)べ物(もの)は食(た)べない。I don't eat food that does not taste good. 彼(かれ)は安(やす)くない靴(くつ)は買(か)わない。He doesn't buy shoes that aren't cheap. Literally, this grammar pattern is very similar to 'there isn't an (A) that doesn't (B)' in English.Caution This term is not to to be confused with なくはない, a more advanced grammar pattern which means 'It's not that it isn't (A)'. 私(わたし)に書(か)けない漢字(かんじ)はない。There is no kanji that I cannot write. 私(わたし)は漢字(かんじ)を書(か)けなくはないけど...It's not that I can't write kanji, but…

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の友達(ともだち)の中(なか)でピザが好(す)きじゃない 人(ひと)は一人(ひとり)もいない。
example.english: There is not a single person in my group of friends that doesn't like pizza.

example.japanese: この大学(だいがく)で日本語(にほんご)を勉強(べんきょう)していない人(ひと)はいません。
example.english: There is not a person who does not study Japanese at this university.

example.japanese: 紙(かみ)を使(つか)わない会社(かいしゃ)は一(ひと)つもありません。
example.english: There is not a single company that does not use paper.

example.japanese: あそこのカフェで美味(おい)しくないコーヒーは絶対(ぜったい)ない。
example.english: There is no coffee at that cafe that is not delicious.

example.japanese: 夢(ゆめ)を見(み)ない人(ひと)は居(い)ないだろう。
example.english: There is not a single person who doesn't dream, right?

synonym.explanation: unless you do something
is not impossible, it doesn't mean that it isn't

english_grammar.title: 少(すこ)しも～ない
english_grammar.explanation: not even a little, not at all, not in the least, never
english_grammar.structure: すこしも + Verb［ない］ すこしも + ［い］Adjective［ない］ すこしも + ［な］Adjective + ではない(1) (1) じゃない
english_grammar.about: Coming from the word 少(すこ)し (a little bit), すこしも～ない is an expression which translates almost exactly to 'not even a little bit (A)' in English. Due to this, it indicates that there is 'no (A)', '(A) never happens', or 'not (A) at all', depending on whether a verb or an adjective is the word that is being negated. すこしも can come at the beginning of the sentence, or directly before the word/statement it is referring to. 今日(きょう)は人(ひと)が多(おお)いからすこしも離(はな)れないでね。There are a lot of people today, so don't stray off. Not even a little bit. 何(なに)このケーキ、すこしもおいしくない！What is this cake, it's not even a little good! 彼女(かのじょ)の彼氏(かれし)はすこしもイケメンではない。Her boyfriend is not even a little handsome. Fun FactThis construction is another example of how the も particle expresses that the word before it is surprising in some way, or unexpected. This was briefly discussed in the Number + も grammar point. 今月(こんげつ)もお金(かね)がすこしもない。I don't have any money this month either. Here we can see that も is highlighting 少(すこ)し as being 'surprising'. This is where the 'not even!' meaning comes from.

example.japanese: あなたは子供(こども)の話(はなし)をすこしも聞(き)いてあげてない。
example.english: You never listen to what your kid has to say.

example.japanese: この景色(けしき)はすこしも綺麗(きれい)ではない。
example.english: This scenery is not pretty at all.

example.japanese: あの店(みせ)のケーキはすこしも美味(おい)しくない。
example.english: That store's cake is not delicious in the least.

example.japanese: 少(すこ)しも暑(あつ)くないのに、汗(あせ)をかいている。
example.english: It is not in the least bit hot, but I am sweating.

example.japanese: ガソリンの値段(ねだん)が少(すこ)しも下(さ)がらないね。
example.english: The price of gasoline has not dropped in the least.

synonym.explanation: Not very, Not much, Not really, Hardly
(not) at all
not~at all
not really, hardly, not easily/readily, by no means, far from
there is no need to, never happens
not ~ at all, cannot ~ at all
never, by no means

english_grammar.title: 少(すく)なくない
english_grammar.explanation: quite a few, quite a lot, many, not a few, not a little
english_grammar.structure: Noun + は(1) + 少なくない (1) が、も
english_grammar.about: Another expression that utilizes the 少(すく) kanji (meaning 'few'), in its い-Adjective form, is 少(すく)なくない. This is an example of a double negative in Japanese, as 少(すく)ない 'a few' is being negated in 少(すく)なくない. Therefore, the meaning is 'not a few', and translates more closely to 'quite a few', or 'quite a lot'.To use this expression, simply pair a noun with は, が, or も, and then follow it with 少(すく)なくない (or 少(すく)なくありません). 漢字(かんじ)を書(か) くのが嫌(きら)いな子(こ)は少(すく)なくない。There are quite a few children that dislike writing kanji. 私(わたし)は好(す)き嫌(きら)いが少(すく)なくないんです。I have many things that I like and dislike. 寝(ね)る前(まえ)にお菓子(かし)を食(た)べる人(ひと)も少(すく)なくない。There are also many people that eat snacks before they sleep. Caution The ない in 少(すく)ない is not the い-Adjective ない, but part of the word 少(すく)ない itself. There are several い-Adjectives like this in Japanese, and they will need to be remembered. 今年(ことし)は去年(きょねん)よりも雨(あめ)が降(ふ)る日(ひ)が少(すく)ない。Compared to last year, there are fewer days with rain this year. 天気(てんき)が悪(わる)い時(とき)に釣(つ)りに行(い)くのは危(あぶ)ない。It is dangerous to go fishing when the weather's bad. 手(て)が汚(きたな)いから手(て)を洗(あら) う。My hands are dirty so I will wash them.

example.japanese: アニメと漫画(まんが)が好(す)きな人(ひと)は少(すく)なくないですよ。
example.english: There are quite a few people that like anime and manga.

example.japanese: ハセガワ：「僕(ぼく)は友達(ともだち)が少(すく)なくないよ。」
example.english: Hasegawa: "I have quite a few friends."

example.japanese: 朝(あさ)ごはんを食(た)べない人(ひと)も少(すく)なくないです。
example.english: There are quite a few people who do not eat breakfast.

example.japanese: そう思(おも)っている人(ひと)も少(すく)なくない。
example.english: Quite a few people think like that.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)の欲(ほ)しがっているものが少(すく)なくないんだ。
example.english: There are many things that she wants.

english_grammar.title: 場合(ばあい)は
english_grammar.explanation: In the event of, In the case of
english_grammar.structure: Verb + 場合(は) ［い］Adjective + 場合(は) ［な］Adjective + な + 場合(は) Noun + の + 場合(は)
english_grammar.about: 場合(ばあい)は is a phrase in Japanese that is often translated to 'in the event of (A)', or 'in the case of (A)'. It can be used with almost any type of word, but will require な when following a な-Adjective, or の when following a noun. オートバイに乗(の)る場合(ばあい)はヘルメットをかぶってください。In the event that you will ride a motorbike, please wear a helmet. 咳(せき)がひどい場合(ばあい)はマスクをしてください。In the case that you have a bad cough, please wear a mask. 仕事(しごと)が大変(たいへん)な場合(ばあい)は私(わたし)に電話(でんわ)をしてください。In the case that your work is difficult, call me. 私(わたし)の場合(ばあい)は冬(ふゆ)が好(す)きです。In my case, I like winter. (Personally I like winter) 場合(ばあい) by itself is usually translated as 'case', or 'situation'. It is frequently used to highlight a hypothetical situation, or a viewpoint/characteristic of another person. 浅草駅(あさくさえき)に行(い)く場合(ばあい)はどの電車(でんしゃ)で行(い)った方(ほう)がいいですか？If I were to go to Asakusa station, which train would be the best to take? あなたの場合(ばあい)、こういう時(とき)はどうする？In a situation like this, what would you do? When 場合(ばあい)は is highlighting a viewpoint/characteristic of another person, this is almost always in contrast/comparison to something that is already being discussed. This is an example of the contrastive nuance of the は particle.Caution In relation to a situation, because 場合(ばあい) means 'to encounter (A)', it has a nuance of randomness. Due to this, 場合(ばあい)は will not be used to describe events that regularly occur, or events that can be planned/controlled. 学校(がっこう)に行(い)く場合(ばあい)は早(はや)く起(お)きます。If I were to go to school, I would wake up early. (Unnatural Japanese, unless going to school is an unusual thing for this person) 学校(がっこう)に行(い)くときは早(はや)く起(お)きます。When I go to school, I wake up early. (Natural Japanese, if going to school is a regular thing for this person) あしたのパーティーに来(く)る場合(ばあい)はビールを持(も)って来(き)てください。In the event that you will come to tomorrow's party, please bring some beer. (Focuses on the possibility of coming) あしたのパーティーに来(く)るときにビールを持(も)って来(き)てください。When you come to the party, bring some beer with you. (Focuses on the request)

example.japanese: 危険(きけん)な場合(ばあい)はここに電話(でんわ)をしてください。
example.english: In the event that it is dangerous, please call me.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の犬(いぬ)の場合(ばあい)は家族(かぞく)と一緒(いっしょ)です。
example.english: In the case of my dog, he is like family.

example.japanese: 遊(あそ)んでいる場合(ばあい)は、危(あぶ)ないことをしないで。
example.english: In the case that you are playing, don't do anything dangerous.

example.japanese: この商品(しょうひん)が売(う)り切(き)れの場合(ばあい)は買(か)えないよ。
example.english: You cannot buy this product in the event that it is out of stock.

example.japanese: 山(やま)が崩(くず)れている場合(ばあい)は運転(うんてん)をしないでください。
example.english: In the event of the mountain crumbling, please do not drive. [In the event of a landslide]

If, If it's the case, As for (conditional)

english_grammar.title: ～て (Casual Request)
english_grammar.explanation: Please do for me (casual request)
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］。
english_grammar.about: In casual speech, てください is often shortened to て. This usually comes across as being a friendly way to say 'please do (A)', but may sound like a very soft order, so is best used with friends/toward people of lower status.This nuance of て is usually able to be identified by appearing at the end of a sentence. 午後(ごご)からお客(きゃく)さんが来(く)るから部屋(へや)を片付(かたづ)けて。We have guests coming over during the afternoon so please clean up your room. (Said by a parent to a child) ペン貸(か)して。Can you please lend me a pen? Caution Sometimes, other forms of て may appear at the end of a sentence. This happens most often when the speaker has not actually finished speaking, but is thinking about what they want to say next. In these cases, the pronunciation of て will usually be extended (to highlight that the person is thinking). 駅(えき)まで走(はし)っていって...I ran to the station and… When emphasizing an apology, て may also be used. For this nuance to be conveyed, て will be attached to the 'reason' that the person is apologizing, and may be either positive or negative. 約束(やくそく)を守(まも)れなくてすみません。I am sorry that I wasn't able to keep my promise. タケシのジャケットに水(みず)をこぼしちゃってごめん。Takeshi, I am sorry that I spilled water on your jacket.

example.japanese: 「こしょうを取(と)って。」
example.english: "(Please) pass me the pepper."

example.japanese: 「ちょっと待(ま)って。まだ聞(き)きたいことがあるよ。」
example.english: "(Please) wait a second. I still have questions!"

example.japanese: 「誰(だれ)か助(たす)けて！」
example.english: "(Please) somebody help me!"

example.japanese: 母親(ははおや)：「部屋(へや)を片付(かたづ)けてね。」子供(こども)：「うん。」
example.english: Mother: "(Please) tidy up your room, okay?"Child: "Okay."

example.japanese: 「このポスターを貼(は)っておいて。」
example.english: "(Please) put up this poster."

synonym.explanation: Please do (polite request)
And, Then (linking events)

english_grammar.title: ～てよかった
english_grammar.explanation: I'm glad that
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］+ よかった Verb［なくて］(*) + よかった Verb［ないで］(**) + よかった (*) Mostly found in literary/written language (**) Mostly found in spoken language
english_grammar.about: When て (or で when following ない) is paired with the past form of the い-Adjective, いい; てよかった, なくてよかった, or ないでよかった will have the meaning of 'I'm glad that (A)' (when positive), or 'I'm glad that I didn't (A)' (when negative). やっぱり今日(きょう)来(き)てよかったね。Actually, I'm glad that we came today, don't you think? あの携帯(けいたい)を買(か)わなくて良(よ)かった。I'm glad that I didn't buy that cellphone. あの時(とき)にお前(まえ)と別(わか)れないで良(よ)かった。I'm glad that we didn't break up that one time. The primary difference between なくてよかった and ないでよかった in this expression, is that ないでよかった will be used far more frequently in casual speech. Comparatively, なくてよかった tends to be reserved for books, and may even be considered old-fashioned by some people. 先輩(せんぱい)、今日(きょう)の会議(かいぎ)で余計(よけい)なことを言(い)わなくて良(よ)かったですね。Senpai, aren't you glad that you didn't say anything more at the meeting today? (A bit more formal, focuses on expressing reasons or results) 行(い)った人(ひと)皆(みんな)が風邪(かぜ)引(ひ)いたの？昨日(きのう)のパーティーへ行(い)かないでよかった！Everyone that went caught a cold? I'm glad that I didn't go to last night's party! (A bit more casual, focus more on 'not doing' something)

example.japanese: 勉強(べんきょう)をしてよかったです。
example.english: I am glad that I studied.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)はデザートを食(た)べなくてよかったです。
example.english: I am glad that I didn't eat dessert today.

example.japanese: このバスに間(ま)に合(あ)ってよかったです。
example.english: I am glad that I made it in time for this bus.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)運動(うんどう)してよかった。
example.english: I'm glad that I exercised today.

example.japanese: 要(い)らないと思(おも)っていたけど、持(も)って来(き)てよかった。
example.english: I didn't think that I needed it, but I'm glad that I brought it.
