This construction is regularly translated as 'so much', 'that much', or simply 'like that'.As a word, そんなに is used adverbially. This means that it may come before any verb, い-Adjective, or な-Adjective. そんなに食(た)べたらお腹(なか)を壊(こわ) すよ。If you eat that much, you are going to break your stomach. (Natural Japanese for 'stomach ache') そんなに暑(あつ)いと思(おも)うならエアコンをつければいい。If you think it's that hot, you should turn on the air conditioner. そんなに嫌(きら)いなら、無理(むり)して食(た)べなくてもいい。If you dislike it that much, you don't have to force yourself to eat it. Almost any そんなに based sentence can be translated literally as 'to an extent like (A)', where (A) is the word that comes after そんなに, and に indicates 'to'.As そんなに is another example of こそあど言葉(ことば) (words like これ, それ, あれ, and どれ), it means that こんなに, あんなに, and どんなに may also be used. こんなにもらってもいいんですか？Is it okay to receive this much? (Are you really giving me all of this?) あんなに食(た)べたのにまだお腹(なか)が空(すい)いているの？You are still hungry, even after eating that much? どんなに頑張(がんば)っても、私(わたし)は先輩(せんぱい)みたいにはなれないと思(おも)う。No matter how hard I try, I don't think that I can become like my senpai. Despite this, そんなに is almost considered a set phrase, and is therefore the most common out of all of the possibilities (except for どんなに, which is often used when explaining/giving reasons for something).

example.japanese: このケーキはそんなに甘(あま)いんですか。
example.english: Is this cake really that sweet?

example.japanese: そんなに痛(いた)いなら、病院(びょういん)に行(い)ったほうがいいんじゃないですか。
example.english: If it hurts that much, shouldn't you go to the hospital?

example.japanese: そんなに頑張(がんば)っても、彼(かれ)みたいに出来(でき)ない。
example.english: Even if I tried that hard, I couldn't do it like he can.

example.japanese: そんなに日本(にほん)に行(い)きたいなら、行(い)って来(き)たら？
example.english: If you want to go to Japan that much, why don't you?

example.japanese: そんなに水泳(すいえい)が嫌(きら)いなら、泳(およ)がなくていいんじゃない？
example.english: If you hate swimming so much, why don't you just not swim?

synonym.explanation: Not very, Not much, Not really, Hardly

synonym.text: そんな・こんな・あんな・どんな
synonym.explanation: such a・kind of, something like ~

english_grammar.title: 必要(ひつよう)がある
english_grammar.explanation: it is necessary to
english_grammar.structure: Verb + 必要 + が + ある
english_grammar.about: Like が必要(ひつよう), 必要(ひつよう)がある is an expression which is used to highlight the 'need' or 'necessity' of something. The primary difference being that 必要(ひつよう)がある highlights the need to 'do (A)', and will therefore be used with verbs (without the need for nominalization). To use 必要(ひつよう)がある, just attach it after the plain form of the verb that you want to highlight the 'need' for. 明日(あした)にテストがあるから、勉強(べんきょう)をする必要(ひつよう)がある。Because I have a test tomorrow, it is necessary to study. 息子(むすこ)はまだ小(ちい)さいので、いつも一緒(いっしょ)にいる必要(ひつよう)がある。Since my son is still little, it is necessary for me to be with him at all times. As we can see, this construction is simply the combination of a verb + 必要(ひつよう) (creating a verb modified noun), the case marking particleが, and the う-Verbある. In this way, it just means 'the need of doing (A) exists'.Naturally, this grammar pattern may also be used negatively, to highlight that there is 'no need to do (A)', or that 'doing (A) is not necessary'. カイルは日本語(にほんご)が分(わ)かるので、書類(しょるい)を英語(えいご)に訳(やく)す必要(ひつよう)がない。Since Kyle understands Japanese, there is no need to translate the documents into English. 娘(むすめ)は元気(げんき)になったので、病院(びょういん)に行(い)く必要(ひつよう)がありません。Since my daughter got well, there is no need to go to the hospital.

example.japanese: 朝(あさ)ご飯(はん)を食(た)べる必要(ひつよう)がある。
example.english: It is necessary to eat breakfast.

example.japanese: 海外(かいがい)旅行(りょこう)に行(い)きたいなら、パスポートを持(も)っていく必要(ひつよう)がある。
example.english: It is necessary to take a passport with you if you want to go overseas.

example.japanese: それを明日(あした)までに終(お)える必要(ひつよう)がある。
example.english: It is necessary to finish that by tomorrow.

example.japanese: ホテルに泊(と)まるならカミソリを持(も)って行(い)く必要(ひつよう)がある。
example.english: If you are going to stay at a hotel, it is necessary to bring a razor.

example.japanese: テストに合格(ごうかく)したかったら、先生(せんせい)の話(はなし)を聞(き)く必要(ひつよう)がある。
example.english: If you want to pass the test, it is necessary to listen to the teacher's instruction.

synonym.explanation: Need, Necessary

antonym.explanation: there is no need to, never happens

english_grammar.title: 例(たと)えば
english_grammar.explanation: For example
english_grammar.structure: たとえば + Phrase
english_grammar.about: たとえば (or 例(たと)えば in its kanji form) is an adverb in Japanese that is used at the beginning of a sentence, or an individual statement, in order to present an example. It can be translated almost directly as 'for example'. たとえば、ドイツとかは？For example, how about Germany, or something? たとえば、冷(つめ)たい物(もの)を食(た)べたときに歯(は)が痛(いた)いです。For Example, my teeth hurt when I eat cold things. Fun Fact例(たと)えば should primarily be used when the 'example' that is being given is as simple as possible. If you want to explain something in further (in-depth) detail, 詳(くわ)しく 'in full' would be used as the adverb instead. 詳(くわ)しく言(い)うと、トマトのように種(たね)がいっぱいある食(た)べ物(もの)が嫌(きら)いです。More specifically, I don't like foods that have a lot of seeds, like tomatoes.

example.japanese: 例(たと)えば、「英語(えいご)が好(す)きですか。」と聞(き)いてみたら？
example.english: For example, why don't you ask 'Do you like English?'

example.japanese: 例(たと)えば毎日(まいにち)日本語(にほんご)を話(はな)すなら、日本語(にほんご)のレベルが上(あ)がる。
example.english: For example, if you speak Japanese every day, your Japanese level will rise.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は、例(たと)えばあそこにあるイタリアンレストランのような店(みせ)を作(つく)りたい。
example.english: For example, I want to make a restaurant like that Italian restaurant over there.

example.japanese: 色々(いろいろ)な国(くに)に行(い)ってみたい。例(たと)えば、ベトナム。
example.english: I want to go to a variety of countries. Vietnam for example.

example.japanese: 子供(こども)のころ何(なん)でも食(た)べることが出来(でき)た。例(たと)えば、納豆(なっとう)が好(す)きだった。
example.english: When I was a child, I could eat anything. I liked Natto for example.

synonym.explanation: Among other things, For example, Such as

english_grammar.title: れる・られる (Potential)
english_grammar.explanation: To be able, Can (potential)
english_grammar.structure: Examples: ［る1］Verb ￫ 見る + られる(1) ［る5］Verb ￫ 座る + れる ［う］Verb ￫ 歌う + える ［く］Verb ￫ 歩く + ける ［す］Verb ￫ 話す + せる ［つ］Verb ￫ 打つ + てる ［ぬ］Verb ￫ 死ぬ + ねる ［ぶ］Verb ￫ 飛ぶ + べる ［む］Verb ￫ 休む + める ［ぐ］Verb ￫ 泳ぐ + げる Exceptions: する ￫ できる (1) 見れる、ら抜き言葉 (casual). Some may consider it not grammatical.
english_grammar.attention: In Japanese, the potential is considered to be something beyond the control of a person.
english_grammar.about: In addition to 'passive' verbs, れる and られる (the auxiliary verbs) are used when expressing possibility '可能(かのう)'.られる will be attached to the base form of る-Verbs (the form after る has been removed). 明日(あした)までに届(とど)けられる？Can you deliver it by tomorrow? (Natural Japanese, and may express 'potential', 'passivity', 'respect', or 'spontaneous occurrence') 一人(ひとり)で全部(ぜんぶ)食(た)べられる？Can you eat all of this on your own? (Natural Japanese, and may express 'potential', 'passivity', 'respect', or 'spontaneous occurrence') A common sight in modern Japanese is words where the ら may be removed, 'ラ抜(ぬ)き言葉(ことば)', and れる may be used by itself. However, this is not technically correct Japanese, and may cause confusion in cases where ら is required (with る-Verbs and くる, when られる is expressing 'passivity', 'respect', or 'spontaneous occurrence'). トムはすぐに新(あたら)しい文法(ぶんぽう)を覚(おぼ)えれる。Tom is able to remember new grammar immediately. (Natural Japanese only when expressing 'potential', not 'passivity', 'respect', or 'spontaneous occurrence') 彼(かれ)はなんでも食(た)べれる。He can eat anything. (Natural Japanese only when expressing 'potential', not 'passivity', 'respect', or 'spontaneous occurrence') For う-Verbs, they will behave a little differently. Instead of the final kana of the verb changing to an あ sound, and then adding れる (as would be the case with passive verbs), the final kana of the verb will change to an え sound (る will become れ, う will become え, す will become せ, etc.) before adding る. この歌(うた)は弾(ひ)けますか？Are you able to play this song? この池(いけ)では色々(いろいろ)な魚(さかな)が釣(つ)れます。You can catch many kinds of fish in this lake. Interestingly, する verbs do not have a 'potential' form, and the verb できる will be used in its place. サリーはほとんどの漢字(かんじ)を書(か)くことができる。Sally is able to write most kanji. Caution ことができる and られる (when used in its 'potential' meaning) have exactly the same nuance. However, many people consider ことができる to be slightly more polite.Fun FactWhen using the potential form, either を or が may be used to mark the 'object'. You will need to be careful though, as this does not apply to できる, which may only ever use が. やっとシャワーを浴(あ)びられる！I can finally take a shower! あなたは何(なに)が食(た)べられるの？What can you eat? トムは日本語(にほんご)とフランス語(ご)と英語(えいご)を話(はな)すことができる。Tom is able to speak Japanese, French, and English.

example.japanese: あの山(やま)が見(み)られますか。
example.english: Can you see that mountain over there?

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は夏休(なつやす)みごろ、旅行(りょこう)に行(い)ける。
example.english: I can take a trip around summer vacation.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の妹(いもうと)は１００字(じ)の漢字(かんじ)が書(か)ける。
example.english: My little sister is able to write 100 kanji.

example.japanese: 10分(ぷん)待(ま)てますか。
example.english: Can you wait 10 minutes?

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は力(ちから)が強(つよ)いからあの重(おも)いテレビ台(だい)を一人(ひとり)で持(も)てます。
example.english: He is strong, so he can pick up that heavy TV stand by himself.

synonym.explanation: is able to, can, possible
Was done to ~ by ~, Done without consent, Done to one's dismay
Can, Be able to
To be audible, to sound (like), (can) hear, to be heard
to be visible, to seem, to be in sight

english_grammar.title: んだけど
english_grammar.explanation: But..., And...
english_grammar.structure: Phrase (A) + のだ(1) + が(2) + Phrase (B) (1) んだ (2) けれども、けれど、けども、けど
english_grammar.attention: Versions without ん/の are also acceptable but ん/の version is more common nowadays.
english_grammar.about: んだけど is an expression that combines んだ (explaining/giving cause), with けど (but). Together they translate simply as 'but...', although the nuance is actually closer to 'but with (A) as the reason… (B)', while (B) is sometimes left unsaid. This implies that the speaker is looking for a reply, or does not want to say the (B) part of the sentence out of politeness/awkwardness. 助(たす)かるんだけど一人(ひとり)でできるから帰(かえ)ってもいいよ。I feel like you are being helpful, but I can handle it by myself, so you can go home. 私(わたし)は明日(あした)に釣(つ)りに行(い)くのですが先輩(せんぱい)も行(い)きませんか？I am going to go fishing tomorrow, but senpai, do you also want to go? 新(あたら)しいパソコンを買(か)いたいのだけど...どれを買(か)えばいいか分(わ)からない。I want to buy a new computer, but… I don't know which one to buy. There are several different forms of this construction that are mostly interchangeable with each other. From most casual, to most formal, they are as follows:んだけど、んだけれど、んだけれども、んだが、んですがん may be replaced with の in any of the above expressions. However, it will again make it slightly more formal.Caution んだが, or simply だが is probably the 'strongest' out of these possibilities, and is considered quite masculine. If you are going to use this form, we recommend making sure that your tone is a bit softer, so that it does not sound too authoritative.Fun Factん (or の) may sometimes be omitted completely, but this is not so common in modern Japanese. 顔(かお)はいいのだけど...性格(せいかく)は悪(わる)い。He has a good looking face, but… his personality is bad.

example.japanese: 「明日(あした)映画館(えいがかん)に行(い)かない？」「行(い)きたいんだけど (明日(あした)試験(しけん)があるから、行(い)けない）。」
example.english: "Won't you go to the cinema tomorrow?""I'd like to go, but… (I have an exam tomorrow, so I can't)."

example.japanese: 新(あたら)しい時計(とけい)を買(か)いたいのですが (どちらがいいでしょうか) 。
example.english: I would like to buy a new watch, but… (which one would be good?)

example.japanese: 「昨日(きのう)の告白(こくはく)はどうなったの？」「こくはくしたんだけど (ふられた) 。」
example.english: "How did yesterday's confession go?""I confessed but… (I was rejected)."

example.japanese: 窓(まど)が開(あ)いているからちょっと寒(さむ)いんですが (どうか窓(まど)を閉(し)めていただけませんか？) 。
example.english: Since the window is open, it is a bit cold (and…) (I wonder if you wouldn't mind closing it?).

example.japanese: 「あの男(おとこ)、顔(かお)がいいね。」「顔(かお)はいいんだけど (なんか性格(せいかく)がわるそう) 。」
example.english: "That guy, he has nice features, don't you think?""He has nice features, but… (It seems that he has a bad personality)."

english_grammar.title: 筈(はず)だ
english_grammar.explanation: bound to (be), expected to (be), should be (able)
english_grammar.structure: Verb + はず + だ ［い］Adjective + はず + だ ［な］Adjective + な + はず + だ Noun + の + はず + だ
english_grammar.attention: There is also another, even less used kanji for はず：弭。
english_grammar.about: はず, coming from the kanji 筈(はず), is a word in Japanese that is very similar to 'bound' in English. This means that it expresses something that the speaker is 'quite sure is true', but cannot confirm. The most common translations of はず are 'bound to be (A)', and 'should be (A)'.As はず is a noun, it may be used in any place that a noun would usually be used. It will often be followed by だ, or です. 今日(きょう)は雨(あめ)が降(ふ)るはずだ。It is supposed to rain today. (But I am not 100% sure if it will) 新幹線(しんかんせん)で行(い)った方(ほう)が速(はや)いはずだ。It is bound to be faster if we go by shinkansen. (But I am not 100% sure if it will) 彼(かれ)は魚(さかな)が嫌(きら)いだから寿司(すし)は嫌(きら)いなはずだ。He does not like fish, so he is sure to dislike sushi. (But I am not 100% sure if he will) 頼(たの)んだのはコーヒーのはずだったけどお茶(ちゃ)が来(き)た。I was sure that I ordered coffee, but tea came. (But I am not 100% sure if I did) Caution Despite はず sometimes being translated as 'should', this is only when you think that something 'should be true', and cannot be used when making suggestions/giving advice. Due to this, 'bound' is the more accurate translation of 筈(はず), in almost all situations.Fun FactThe だ (or です) in はずだ may be omitted. This usually makes はず sound a little less certain, like 'bound to be (A)... probably'. In the same way, speakers may sometimes add はず to the end of their sentences in a similar way to 多分(たぶん), in order to show that they are not 100% certain about whether what they just said is accurate or not. ハリーも今日(きょう)のパーティーに行(い)く…はず。Harry will go to the party today… Probably. 出(で)かける前(まえ)に家(いえ)の中(なか)の電気(でんき)は全部(ぜんぶ)消(け)した… はず。I turned off all the lights in my house before I left… I'm pretty sure.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は借(か)りたペンを返(かえ)すはずだ。
example.english: He is bound to return the pen he borrowed.

example.japanese: 妻(つま)は夜(よる)七時(しちじ)までに、帰(かえ)ってくるはずだ。
example.english: My wife is expected to return home by seven o'clock.

example.japanese: 夏(なつ)だから、暑(あつ)いはずだ。
example.english: Because it is summer, it is supposed to be hot.

example.japanese: ここから富士山(ふじさん)が見(み)えるはずだ。
example.english: One should be able to see Mt. Fuji from here.

example.japanese: この港(みなと)には船(ふね)があるはずだ。
example.english: There are bound to be boats in this harbor.

synonym.explanation: for that reason, no wonder, as you'd expect, naturally, thus, this is why
To plan to, To intend to
to be expected to, to be scheduled to

must, should , ought to
it would be nice if, it would be good if, should・I hope

english_grammar.title: かどうか
english_grammar.explanation: whether or not, if...or not
english_grammar.structure: Verb + か + どう + か + Phrase ［い］Adjective + か + どう + か + Phrase ［な］Adjective + か + どう + か + Phrase Noun + か + どう + か + Phrase
english_grammar.about: かどうか is an expression in Japanese which combines the 'or' meaning of か, with the 'how' meaning of どう. (A) かどうか (B) is regularly translated as 'whether or not (A), (B)'.To use かどうか, simply attach it to the end of any phrase that you want to express the 'or' use of か about, then add the (B) phrase. サチコと付(つ)き合(あ)うかどうか分(わ)からない。I don't know whether or not I will go out with Sachiko. 水(みず)が汚(きたな)いからこの川(かわ)が深(ふか)いかどうか分(わ)からない。Since the water is dirty, I don't know whether or not this river is deep. この携帯(けいたい)が便利(べんり)かどうか分(わ)からない。I don't know whether or not this cell phone is useful. 目(め)が悪(わる)いからあそこにいるのが父親(ちちおや)かどうかわからない。Because I have bad eyes, I don't know whether or not the person over there is my father. Although 'whether or not' is the standard translation, the more literal translation of かどうか is 'if it's (A), or however it is, (B)'.

example.japanese: 旅行(りょこう)に行(い)けるかどうかわからない。
example.english: I don't know whether or not I can go on a trip.

example.japanese: この食(た)べ物(もの)は美味(おい)しいかどうかわからないので、食(た)べてみたい。
example.english: Because I don't know whether or not it is delicious, I want to try eating this food.

example.japanese: サンタさんがいるかどうか探(さが)しています。
example.english: People are searching for whether or not Santa exists.

example.japanese: まだ日本(にほん)に行(い)けるかどうか、分(わ)からない。
example.english: I don't know whether or not I still can go to Japan.

example.japanese: 今(いま)の動物(どうぶつ)は犬(いぬ)かどうか分(わ)からないけど、怖(こわ)かった。
example.english: I don't know whether or not the animal I just saw was a dog, but it was frightening.

synonym.explanation: or something, or something like that
including questions within sentences
Whether ~ or, Neither ~ or
Whether ~ or not
regardless of whether
even though, even if, even when, also
whether… or
whether or not

english_grammar.title: と
english_grammar.explanation: if・when, whenever, and, [conditional]
english_grammar.structure: Verb + と ［い］Adjective + と ［な］Adjective + だ + と Noun + だ + と
english_grammar.about: In the same way as the case marking particleと means 'and', sometimes it is translated as 'if'. In these cases, it is considered to be far stronger than ば, なら, or たら (which express hypothetical outcomes). This is because one of the primary uses of と is highlighting a result. In these cases, と is actually a conjunction particle, and shows one of three things.仮定(かてい)の順接(じゅんせつ) - A result that is assumed to be true, and obvious.確定(かくてい)の順接(じゅんせつ) - A result that is known to be true.仮定(かてい)の逆接(ぎゃくせつ) - The opposite of a result that is assumed to be true.Due to this, the (B) part of a phrase using と as 'if', will always occur when (A) happens, as it is considered to be the result of (A). 甘(あま)いものをいっぱい食(た)べると、太(ふと)る。If you eat a lot of sweet things, you will gain weight. 部屋(へや)が汚(きたな)いと、お母(かあ)さんに怒(おこ)られる。If my room is messy, my mother will yell at me. 部屋(へや)が静(しず)かだと、眠(ねむ)れない。If my room is quiet, I can't sleep. 地下鉄(ちかてつ)だと、5分(ふん)早(はや)く着(つ)く。If it's the subway, you will arrive 5 minutes faster. と may not be used in situations where the (B) result 'might' happen. It must be definite (or close to definite). 走(はし)るとけがをする。If I run, I will injure myself. (Unnatural Japanese, unless this person always injures themselves while running for some reason) In this particular nuance of と, despite being translated as 'if', the actual meaning is much closer to 'and', as と is expressing that (A) and (B) will always go together. 目(め)を閉(と)じると、何(なに)も見(み)えない。I close my eyes, and I can't see.

example.japanese: 勉強(べんきょう)をすると、テストは簡単(かんたん)になる。
example.english: If you study, the test will be easy.

example.japanese: この石(いし)を磨(みが)くと、綺麗(きれい)になる。
example.english: If you polish this rock, it will become beautiful.

example.japanese: ここから見(み)ると、富士山(ふじさん)が全然(ぜんぜん)見(み)えない。
example.english: If you look from here, you can't see Mt. Fuji at all.

example.japanese: 水着(みずぎ)を持(も)って来(く)るのを忘(わす)れると海(うみ)に入(はい)れないよ。
example.english: If you forget to bring your swimsuit, you won't be able to swim in the ocean.

example.japanese: 週(しゅう)に3回(かい)トレーニングをするとだんだん強(つよ)くなる。
example.english: Whenever you workout three times a week, you gradually get stronger.

synonym.explanation: if… then, [conditional]
In the event of, In the case of
When, From when, Just when, If
If, If it's the case, As for (conditional)
If [for emphasis]
having done..., if...is done..., (and/just) then, thereupon, if so
having done that..., if that is done..., (and/just) then, thereupon, if so

english_grammar.title: ないと
english_grammar.explanation: must, have to
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］+ と + （いけない(1)） (1) だめ
english_grammar.attention: ないとならない is generally not used and is best avoided
english_grammar.about: As an extension of the 'if' meaning of と, attaching the auxiliary verb ない to the verb before it will express 'if (A) is not done, (B)'. (B) is most frequently いけない 'cannot go', which makes ないといけない a double negative phrase, which translates to 'must do (A)', or 'have to do (A)'.いけない may be replaced with だめ, to make the phrase more casual, but ならない is generally not used with ないと. ライト君(くん)が悪(わる)いんだから、リュウ君(くん)に謝(あやま)らないといけないでしょう。Raito-kun, you are in the wrong, so you have to apologize to Ryu-kun, right? 今日(きょう)は勉強(べんきょう)しないとだめだから、明日(あした)は？I have to study today, so how about tomorrow? ないといけない is regularly abbreviated to ないと, but has exactly the same meaning in these cases. 明日(あした)はテストがあるの？！勉強(べんきょう)しないと。There is a test tomorrow!? I have to study. もう7時(じ)じゃん？準備(じゅんび)しないと。Oh, it's already 7? I need to get ready. Caution As と has the 'and' nuance, it gives ないと a level of strength that is not seen in similar phrases like なければいけない, or なくてはいけない. Because of this, ないと is often used to highlight things which absolutely 'must' be done (obeying the law, adhering to customs, using common sense, etc.). 歩行者(ほこうしゃ)も信号機(しんごうき)を守(まも)らないといけない。Even pedestrians have to obey traffic lights.

example.japanese: 「約束(やくそく)を守(まも)らないといけません！」
example.english: "You have to keep your promise!"

example.japanese: 「なぜ、税金(ぜいきん)を払(はら)わないといけないのですか？」
example.english: "Why do I have to pay taxes?"

example.japanese: 「子(こ)沢山(だくさん)だから、一週間(いっしゅうかん)に三十回(さんじゅうかい)は洗濯(せんたく)しないとだめ。」
example.english: "There are lots of children, so I have to do laundry thirty times a week."

example.japanese: 「ほたるちゃん、うちに遊(あそ)びにきてくれるの？」「すみません。明日(あした)までに宿題(しゅくだい)を済(す)ませないといけないのです。」
example.english: "Hotaru, will you come and hang out at my house?""I am sorry. I have to finish doing my homework by tomorrow."

example.japanese: 「合格(ごうかく)したらまず両親(りょうしん)や先生(せんせい)に伝(つた)えないと。」
example.english: "If I pass, I have to tell my parents and teacher first!"

synonym.explanation: Must do, Have to do
must do, have to do
Must do, Have to do
must do, have to do
Must do, Have to do
must, should , ought to

english_grammar.title: 筈(はず)がない
english_grammar.explanation: hardly possible, cannot be, highly unlikely, improbable
english_grammar.structure: Verb + はず + が + ない ［い］Adjective + はず + が + ない ［な］Adjective + な + はず + が + ない Noun + の + はず + が + ない
english_grammar.about: Like はず, coming from the kanji 筈(はず), which suggests that something is 'bound' to be true, はずがない suggests that something is 'not bound' to be true. This expression is usually translated as 'hardly possible', 'improbable', or 'unlikely', but in reality, it is a bit weaker than these, and translates more literally to '(A) is not the only possibility'.As はずがない (a combination of 筈(はず), the case-marking particle が, and the い-Adjective ない) is a phrase that starts with a noun, it may be used after any word that could usually connect with a noun. 1時間(じかん)も早(はや)くに家(いえ)を出(で)たから遅(おく)れるはずがない。Because I left the house an hour early, it is improbable that I will be late. (That I am bound to be late is not true) この箱(はこ)は重(おも)いはずがない。It is hardly possible that this box is heavy. (It is not the case that this box is bound to be heavy) サリーの家(いえ)は立派(りっぱ)なはずがない。It is highly unlikely that Sally's house is splendid. (That Sally's house is sure to be splendid is not the case) あそこにいる人(ひと)はトムのはずがない。It is highly unlikely that the person over there is Tom. Caution There is a big difference in nuance between ないはずだ 'bound not to', and はずがない 'not bound to'. ないはず strongly negates the (A) statement, and expresses the speaker's opinion that it is almost definitely not true. はずがない on the other hand, simply suggests that (A) being almost 100% true is not the case. 彼(かれ)の車(くるま)は高(たか)くないはずだ。His car would not be expensive. (His car is bound to not be that expensive) 彼(かれ)の車(くるま)は高(たか)いはずがない。It is hardly possible that his car is expensive. (That his car is bound to be expensive is not true)

example.japanese: 夏(なつ)に雪(ゆき)が降(ふ)るはずがない。
example.english: It is hardly possible for it to snow in the summer.

example.japanese: あのビルは古(ふる)すぎなので、病院(びょういん)のはずがない。
example.english: Because that building is so old, it is hardly possible that it is a hospital.

example.japanese: 有名人(ゆうめいじん)は人気(にんき)だから、寂(さび)しいはずがない。
example.english: Famous people are popular so it seems hardly possible for them to be lonely.

example.japanese: それはあなたのカバンのはずがない。
example.english: It is highly unlikely that that is your bag.

example.japanese: 少年(しょうねん)の部屋(へや)だから、綺麗(きれい)なはずがない。
example.english: Since it's a boy's room, it is highly unlikely that it is clean.

english_grammar.title: しか～ない
english_grammar.explanation: there's only, nothing but
english_grammar.structure: Noun + しか + Verb［ない］
english_grammar.about: The adverbial particle しか is often compared to だけ, in that it also expresses 'only'. However, unlike だけ, しか can only be used in negative statements. Due to this, しか～ない is regularly translated as 'there's only (A)', or 'there's nothing but (A)'. しか～ない may be used to express numbers, or nouns. In this lesson we will examine nouns.Like しか～ない, the construction used for expressing numbers, when used before a noun, this expression will mean that nothing apart from that one 'thing' exists. Any verb may be used after しか, but it must be in its ない (or ありません) form. 犯人(はんにん)はまだ3人(にん)しか捕(つか)まていない。Only 3 of the criminals have been caught so far. この店(みせ)は牛丼(ぎゅうどん)しか置(お)いていない。This store only has gyudon. 釣(つ)りに行(い)って、一匹(いっぴき)しか釣(つ)れないと悲(かな)しくなる。I get sad when I go fishing and only catch one fish. Caution when しかない directly follows a verb, the translation is a little bit different, and means that 'nothing apart from (A) can be done'. This is a separate grammar point that we will study a bit later. 明日(あした)から雨(あめ)が降(ふ)るから、今日(きょう)に行(い)くしかない。Since it will start raining tomorrow, we have no choice but to go today.

example.japanese: 遠(とお)いので、車(くるま)で行(い)くことしかできない。
example.english: Because it is far away, you can only go by car.

example.japanese: 「はい」と「いいえ」しか言(い)わない人(ひと)と話(はな)しにくい。
example.english: It is difficult to talk to people who only respond with 'yes' and 'no'.

example.japanese: すみませんが、午後(ごご)しか空(あ)いてないみたいです。
example.english: I am sorry, but it looks like there is only space open in the afternoon.

example.japanese: 冷蔵庫(れいぞうこ)に牛乳(ぎゅうにゅう)しか残(のこ)っていない。
example.english: There is nothing but milk in the fridge.

example.japanese: 手袋(てぶくろ)を一枚(いちまい)しか見(み)つけられない。
example.english: I can only find one glove.

english_grammar.title: だけでなく
english_grammar.explanation: not only… but also
english_grammar.structure: Verb + だけ + でなく(1) ［い］Adjective + だけ + でなく(1) ［な］Adjective + な + だけ + でなく(1) Noun + だけ + でなく(1) (1) ではなく（て）、じゃなく（て）
english_grammar.attention: It is often used together with second noun + particle も (meaning "also") in main clause.
english_grammar.about: だけでなく (an abbreviation of だけではなく) is a common construction in Japanese which translates to 'not only (A), but also (B)'. Sometimes the (B) statement may be left unsaid. This expression may connect to any (A) phrase that だけ would usually be able to connect to. 痩(や)せるためには運動(うんどう)をするだけでなく、食(た)べるものにも気(き)を付(つ)けなくてはいけない。To lose weight, not only should you exercise, but you must also be careful of what you eat. 名古屋(なごや)の夏(なつ)は暑(あつ)いだけでなく、湿気(しっけ)もひどい。Summer in Nagoya is not only hot, but the humidity is terrible too. 田舎(いなか)は静(しずか)かなだけでなく、空気(くうき)もきれいだ。The countryside is not only quiet, but the air is also clean. トーマスは車(くるま)だけでなく、バイクとボートも持(も)っている。Not only does Thomas own a car, but he also has a bike, and a boat. Caution The で in では is not the particle で, but the auxiliary verb だ in its conjunctive form. は is regularly dropped from では expressions, or it may also be changed to じゃ, for ease of pronunciation. タケルはピアノだけじゃなくギターも弾(ひ)けると聞(き)いた。I heard that Takeru can not only play the piano, but also the guitar. The conjunction particle て should follow なく, as it is the conjunctive form of the い-Adjective ない. However, the て in this particular construction is very often omitted. トムは日本語(にほんご)だけでなくて、中国語(ちゅうごくご)も話(はな)せる。Not only can Tom speak Japanese, but also Chinese. Caution In writing, if there is no comma (known as a 読点(とうてん) in Japanese) after なく, the full なくて construction will be required. When a comma is present, both forms are grammatically correct. 角(かど)にあるラーメン屋(や)はおいしいだけでなくて量(りょう)も多(おお)い。The ramen shop on the corner is not only delicious, but the portions are large too.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)だけでなく、私(わたし)の友達(ともだち)も日本語(にほんご)が喋(しゃべ)れる。
example.english: Not only me, but also my friends can speak Japanese.

example.japanese: あの人(ひと)は日本語(にほんご)だけでなく、韓国語(かんこくご)、中国語(ちゅうごくご)とタイ語(ご)も話(はな)せる。
example.english: That person can speak not only Japanese, but also Korean, Chinese, and Thai.

example.japanese: ジョニー・デップはカナダだけでなく、日本(にほん)も訪(おとず)れたことがある。
example.english: Johnny Depp has not only visited Canada, but has visited Japan as well.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)だけでなく、私(わたし)もこの映画(えいが)が好(す)きだよ。
example.english: Not only does she like this movie but I do too.

example.japanese: 彼氏(かれし)が料理(りょうり)だけでなく、家事(かじ)も出来(でき)るから、凄(すご)い助(たす)かる。
example.english: Not only can my boyfriend cook, but he can also do housework, so it is really helpful.

english_grammar.title: ことが出来(でき)る
english_grammar.explanation: Can, Be able to
english_grammar.structure: Verb + こと + が + できる Noun + が + できる
english_grammar.about: Like ことがある, ことができる is an expression that nominalizes what comes before it (turns it into a noun-phrase), and then highlights something about that (A) phrase. In the case of ことができる, the thing being highlighted about (A) is that it is 'possible'. This translates as 'can do (A)', or 'to be able to do (A)'. 魚(さかな)のように泳(およ)ぐことができるように毎日(まいにち)練習(れんしゅう)する。I practice everyday so that I will be able to swim like a fish. 彼(かれ)は料理(りょうり)をすることができる。He is able to cook. However, こと is only required when the (A) phrase needs nominalization (is not a noun to begin with). Due to this, ができる may be used by itself when following a noun, without changing the meaning. 運転(うんてん)ができる彼氏(かれし)が欲(ほ)しい。I want a boyfriend that can drive. 力仕事(ちからしごと)ができる人(ひと)を探(さが)しています。We are looking for a person that is able to do physical labor. Fun Factのが (or のは) is also frequently used for nominalization, but this is rarely the case when a verb follows it. Some other expressions where のが may not be swapped for こと are as follows:ことがある - For (A) to exist.ことにする - To make something (A).ことになる - For (A) to come to be.

example.japanese: 馬(うま)に乗(の)ることができる。
example.english: I can ride a horse.

example.japanese: 泳(およ)ぐことができますか？
example.english: Can you swim?

example.japanese: 初(はじ)めて、漢字(かんじ)を書(か)くことができた。
example.english: I was able to write kanji for the first time.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の子供(こども)は一人(ひとり)で買(か)い物(もの)ができる。
example.english: My kid can go shopping by himself.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の姉(あね)は歌(うた)うことが出来(でき)る。
example.english: My older sister can sing.

synonym.explanation: To be able, Can (potential)

english_grammar.title: かい
english_grammar.explanation: question marker
english_grammar.structure: Verb + （の） + かい ［い］Adjective + （の） + かい Noun + （なの） + かい ［な］Adjective + （なの） + かい
english_grammar.attention: strongly masculine
english_grammar.about: The sentence ending particle かい is a grammar structure that is used in Japanese to highlight a question. Despite commonly being thought of as one word, it is actually the combination of か (the sentence-ending particle) and い, another sentence-ending particle that is primarily used by men (in a similar way to ね and よ).かい will usually be used directly after the word/phrase that it is highlighting. In the case of verbs and い-Adjectives, の may be inserted before かい. For な-Adjectives and nouns, なの may be inserted directly before it. However, の (or なの) are frequently omitted, due to how casual かい is. このドーナッツを食(た)べたいのかい？Do you want to eat this donut? このおもちゃが欲(ほ)しいのかい？Do you want this toy? 彼女(かのじょ)は綺麗(きれい)なのかい？Is your girlfriend pretty? 彼(かれ)はいい人(ひと)なのかい?Is he a good person? When it is not omitted, の (or なの) may be shortened to ん (or なん）. This is in the same way that の and なの would behave in the のです and なのです grammar structures. お前(まえ)も一緒(いっしょ)に行(い)きたいんかい？Do you also want to come with me? 大学生(だいがくせい)なんかい。中学生(ちゅうがくせい)だと思(おも)った。You are a college student? I thought you were a middle schooler. Although there are some exceptions, かい will almost always be used to ask simple yes/no questions. 勉強(べんきょう)してるのかい？Are you studying? Caution Because かい is very casual, and quite direct, it often sounds like an accusation. Due to this, care should be taken with your tone of voice, so as not to be taken the wrong way. また鍵(かぎ)をなくしたんかい。You lost your keys again, didn't you? Fun FactOutside of かい, the sentence ending particle い is not commonly used in modern Japanese, and therefore will only appear in a few very specific structures (like だい). Despite being similar to ね, い is considered to be fairly ぞんざい 'rough', and should only be used with people that you are very familiar with, and never to someone above you.

example.japanese: 本当(ほんとう)に行(い)きたいのかい？
example.english: Do you really want to go?

example.japanese: これだけで十分(じゅうぶん)なのかい？
example.english: Is just this enough?

example.japanese: その帽子(ぼうし)を被(かぶ)って行(い)くのかい？
example.english: Are you really going to go wearing that hat?

example.japanese: どうしたの？恥(は)ずかしいのかい？
example.english: What's wrong? Are you embarrassed?

example.japanese: この番組(ばんぐみ)を見(み)たくないのかい？
example.english: You don't want to watch this TV program?

synonym.explanation: Question marking particle

english_grammar.title: もし
english_grammar.explanation: If [for emphasis]
english_grammar.structure: もし + Phrase［たら］(1) (1) Phrase［ば］、Phrase［と］、Phrase［ても］
english_grammar.about: もし is an adverb used to emphasize the nuance of 'if', with expressions like と, ば, なら, たら, and ても. Literally, the meaning of もし is close to 'while slight', or 'while small'.To use もし, simply add it to the beginning of any phrase that uses one of the conditional expressions listed above. もし彼(かれ)を動物(どうぶつ)に例(たと)えると、猫(ねこ)に似(に)ています。If we were to compare him to an animal, he resembles a cat. (Even if you only slightly compared him) もし今日(きょう)来(こ)れれば来(き)てね。If you can come today, please do. (If, on the slight chance you can come) もしまだ頭(あたま)が痛(いた)いなら、医者(いしゃ)に行(い)った方(ほう)がいいよ。If your head still hurts, you should go to the doctors. (If, on the slight chance it does hurt) もし買(か)い物(もの)に行(い)ったら、お菓子(かし)を買(か)って来(き)て。If you go shopping, can you buy some snacks? (If, on the slight chance you do go) もし雨(あめ)が降(ふ)っても遊園地(ゆうえんち)に行(い)きます。Even if it rains, we will still go to the amusement park. (If, on the slight chance it does rain) Fun Factもし is sometimes seen written as 若(も)し, a kanji which has the meaning of 'low in (A)', (also seen in the word 若(わか)い 'young'). It is from this kanji that もし gets its meaning of 'while low in (probability, number, age, experience)'.

example.japanese: もしこのパソコンを彼女(かのじょ)にあげるなら、説明書(せつめいしょ)も渡(わた)してね。
example.english: If you are going to give this computer to her, (make sure to) give her the manual too.

example.japanese: もし君(きみ)が文法(ぶんぽう)を勉強(べんきょう)したら、日本語(にほんご)を喋(しゃべ)れるようになるでしょう。
example.english: If you study grammar, you will become able to speak Japanese, right?

example.japanese: もしコーヒーを買(か)ってくれたら、嬉(うれ)しい。
example.english: If you bought coffee for me, I would be happy.

example.japanese: もし雨(あめ)が降(ふ)ったら、車(くるま)で行(い)く。
example.english: If it rains, I will go by car.

example.japanese: もし鉛筆(えんぴつ)を持(も)って来(く)るのを忘(わす)れたらテストを受(う)けられなくなる。
example.english: If you forget to bring a pencil you will not be able to take the test.

synonym.explanation: If, If it's the case, As for (conditional)

synonym.text: もしも～なら・もしも～でも

When, From when, Just when, If

english_grammar.title: し (Reasons)
english_grammar.explanation: and, giving reasons
english_grammar.structure: Verb (A) + し + （Verb (B) + し） ［い］Adjective (A) + し + （［い］Adjective (B) + し） ［な］Adjective (A) + だ + し + （［な］Adjective (B) + だ + し） Noun (A) + だ + し + （Noun (B) + だ + し）
english_grammar.attention: The last し in a sentence can be replaced with から or ので
english_grammar.about: Like て, し is a conjunction particle. This means that it is used for linking the (A) and (B) parts of a sentence, and describing that link in some way. The 'description' that し will highlight is 'reasons'. Regularly it is translated simply as 'and'.し may be connected to the end of almost any word, but will require a だ before it when it comes after nouns or な-Adjectives. し will follow every 'reason' that is being listed in a sentence. However, the last し may be replaced with から or ので, before the 'result' is stated. 彼女(かのじょ)はピアノが弾(ひ)けるし、スポーツができるし、彼女(かのじょ)に出来(でき)ないことはないと思(おも)う。She can play the piano and she can do sports. I think there isn't anything she can't do. このレストランは高(たか)いし、まずいし、何(なに)もいいところがない。This restaurant is expensive and doesn't taste good. There are no good parts. 彼(かれ)は真面目(まじめ)だし、親切(しんせつ)だし、彼(かれ)と友達(ともだち)でよかった。He is serious and nice. I am glad that he is my friend. 今日(きょう)は休(やす)みだし、晴(は)れだし、今日(きょう)は公園(こうえん)に行(い)こう。Today is my day off, and it's sunny, so let's go to the park. Using し will indicate that each 'reason' being listed is of equal weight/importance. Because of this, it would not be appropriate to use in sentences where one of the reasons clearly far outweighs everything else. 昨日(きのう)は雨(あめ)が降(ふ)ってたし、おばあちゃんも亡(な)くなったし、悲(かな)しいな。It was raining yesterday and my grandmother also passed away, so I'm sad. (Unnatural Japanese, as the level of sadness between losing your grandmother, and it being a rainy day would be completely different) Fun FactIn all of its uses, し indicates things that are 矛盾(むじゅん)無(な)く共存(きょうぞん)する, which basically means 'things that coexist, without contradicting each other'. This is the primary reason why each thing listed must be of equal importance (in terms of the overall story that the speaker is trying to convey).

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は掃除(そうじ)ができるし、料理(りょうり)も作(つく)れるし、結婚(けっこん)してよかった。
example.english: He can clean and cook. I am glad that I married him.

example.japanese: この赤(あか)が可愛(かわい)いし、デザインがいいし、この帽子(ぼうし)を買(か)いたい。
example.english: This red is cute and the design is good. I want to buy this hat!

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)は親切(しんせつ)だし、綺麗(きれい)だし、本当(ほんとう)に大好(だいす)き。
example.english: She is kind and beautiful. I really love her.

example.japanese: この近所(きんじょ)は治安(ちあん)がいいし、スーパーが近(ちか)いし、人(ひと)が優(やさ)しいからここに住(す)んでみたい。
example.english: This neighborhood is safe and the store is close and the people are nice, so I wouldn't mind living here.

example.japanese: 僕(ぼく)は全然(ぜんぜん)やりたくないし、やることが多(おお)すぎるし、諦(あきら)めようと思(おも)っています。
example.english: I have absolutely no desire to do it and there are too many things to do, (so) I am thinking about giving up.

english_grammar.title: でできる
english_grammar.explanation: made of, made from, produced from, come from
english_grammar.structure: Noun + で(1) + できる (1) から
english_grammar.attention: できている → more specific, できる → more general
english_grammar.about: でできる, or からできる are two structures that share very similar meanings. Basically, they both mean '(B) was made from/out of (A)'. These constructions highlight the 'ingredients', or 'materials' that something is/was made out of. Let's look at some examples. 今日(きょう)は卵(たまご)と鶏肉(とりにく)でできる料理(りょうり)を紹介(しょうかい)します。Today we will introduce a food that is made from eggs and chicken. 味噌(みそ)が苦手(にがて)なので、味噌(みそ)からできるものは食(た)べれません。Because I don't like miso, I can't eat things made from it. から and で are both case marking particles in this grammar point, and while they express much the same thing when translated into English, there is a slight nuance difference. These differences are as follows:から - Literally 'prepared from'. Tends to be used more frequently when the material is not obvious at first glance. May also put focus on the ingredients/materials before there was any alteration. で - Literally 'prepared with'. Tends to be used more frequently when the materials are more obvious.Despite this, recent generations use で in most situations, regardless of if the material is visible at first glance or not. As a result, でできる and からできる are almost indistinguishable in modern Japanese.Caution There is also a small nuance difference between できる, and できている, when used as part of this construction. できる is usually used when talking about something broadly 'everything in category (B) is made from (A)', while できている is used more frequently when examining a specific item 'this particular (B) is made from (A)'. Like the difference between で and から though, they are largely interchangeable. 最近(さいきん)はコンクリートでできる家(いえ)が人気(にんき)だ。Recently, houses made of concrete are popular. (Houses in general) この箸(はし)は竹(たけ)でできている。These chopsticks are made from bamboo. (This specific pair of chopsticks)

example.japanese: 裏面(りめん)がガラスでできるスマホは最近(さいきん)売行(うれゆ)きがいい。
example.english: Recently there has been demand for smartphones with the back made of glass.

example.japanese: このワインはトップクラスのブドウからできています。どうぞ飲(の)んでください。
example.english: This wine is made from top-class grapes. Please, try it.

example.japanese: スーパーは木曜日(もくようび)にミルクからできる製品(せいひん)のセールをするよ！
example.english: The supermarket is having a sale of products made from milk on Thursday!

example.japanese: このスマホの裏面(りめん)はプラスチックでできているみたいだけど、実(じつ)は塗装(とそう)したメタルです。
example.english: The back of this smartphone seems to be made of plastic, but in reality, it is made from painted metal.

example.japanese: 飛行機(ひこうき)は軽(かる)い物質(ぶっしつ)からできる必要(ひつよう)がある。
example.english: It is necessary to build planes from light materials.

english_grammar.title: ながら
english_grammar.explanation: while ~ing, during, as
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ ながら
english_grammar.attention: The subject of A and B must be the same.
english_grammar.about: ながら is another conjunction particle in Japanese that has two primary different meanings. These meanings are as follows:同時(どうじ)の動(うご)き - Two things that are existing/happening simultaneously.確定(かくてい)の逆説(ぎゃくせつ) - Two things that are unexpectedly existing/happening simultaneously.We will focus purely on the 同時(どうじ)の動(うご)き meaning in this grammar point. To use ながら, simply add it to the ます stem of verb (A), and then highlight verb (B) as part of the following clause. This may be translated simply as 'while' in English. 私(わたし)は毎日(まいにち)、音楽(おんがく)を聴(き)きながら走(はし)ります。I run every day, while listening to music. 運転(うんてん)しながら携帯(けいたい)を使(つか)っていたら、前(まえ)の車(くるま)にぶつかった。When I was using my phone while driving, I crashed into the car in front of me. Grammatically, the (B) action is considered to be the 'important' action, while the (A) action expresses the timeline within which (B) takes place.Caution Due to the (B) action being considered the 'primary' action of something that (A) is related to, (A) and (B) must have the same subject. 高校(こうこう)の頃(ころ)はサッカーの練習(れんしゅう)をしながら漢字(かんじ)の勉強(べんきょう)もした。When I was in high school, I studied kanji while also practicing soccer. (Natural Japanese, as the overall timeline of the sentence is 'while in high school') 漢字(かんじ)の勉強(べんきょう)をしながらアニメを見(み)る。I watch anime while studying kanji. (Natural Japanese, as the speaker is doing both things at the same time) 大学(だいがく)に通(かよ)いながら、トランプ氏(し)がアメリカの大統領(だいとうりょう)だった。Trump was the president of America while I was going to university. (Unnatural Japanese. Although the events happen at the same time, they share no common subject/place) Fun FactWhen used to express 確定(かくてい)の逆説(ぎゃくせつ), ながら will be followed by も. ながらも is a separate grammar point that we will learn more about later. In this construction, も is expressing surprise about the fact that (A) and (B) coexist. あそこの病院(びょういん)は古(ふる)いながらも中(なか)は綺麗(きれい)だと聞(き)いた。I heard that that hospital looks nice inside, even though it is old.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は晩(ばん)ご飯(はん)を食(た)べながら、一番(いちばん)好(す)きな番組(ばんぐみ)を見(み)る。
example.english: I watch my favorite TV show while eating dinner.

example.japanese: 赤(あか)ちゃんが寝(ね)ながら、おならをした 。
example.english: The baby farted while sleeping.

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)を待(ま)ちながら、コーヒーを飲(の)もう。
example.english: Let's get coffee while we wait for our friends.

example.japanese: 運転(うんてん)しながら携帯(けいたい)を使(つか)ってはいけない。
example.english: You must not use a cellphone while driving.

example.japanese: 犬(いぬ)と散歩(さんぽ)をしながら、本(ほん)を読(よ)んでいた。
example.english: While I was walking my dog, I was reading a book.

english_grammar.title: ～た所(ところ)だ
english_grammar.explanation: just finished doing, was just doing
english_grammar.structure: Verb［た］(1) + ところ + だ (1) Verb［ていた］
english_grammar.attention: ところ can be contracted to とこ in casual conversations. In this use ところ means "stage/level/situation"
english_grammar.about: In a similar way to how ところ (sometimes shortened to とこ) means 'about to (A)', or 'on the verge of (A)', when following the non-past form of a verb, when following the auxiliary verb た, ところ will mean 'just did (A)'.To use this structure, make the past tense of any verb, and then add ところ. 今(いま)、先生(せんせい)に聞(き)いたところ。I just asked the teacher. 仕事(しごと)は今(いま)終(お)わったところ。もうすぐ帰(かえ)る。I just finished work. So I'll head home soon. While this expresses 'just did (A)', ていた may be used when you would like to express that you were 'just doing (A)'. 休(やす)みを楽(たの)しんでいたところで上司(じょうし)から電話(でんわ)が来(き)た。I got a call from my boss just as I was enjoying my day off. Caution When the kanji form of 所(ところ) is used, it is often referring to an actual physical location, rather than a situation/standpoint. However, this is something that native speakers will sometimes mistake. Therefore, seeing the kanji form and the hiragana form are both relatively common.

example.japanese: 今(いま)食(た)べ終(お)わったところです。
example.english: I just finished eating.

example.japanese: 服(ふく)を脱(ぬ)いでいたところに、母(はは)が部屋(へや)に入(はい)ってきた。
example.english: My mom came into the room just as I was taking my clothes off.

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)はたまたま友達(ともだち)に会(あ)う：「君(きみ)に会(あ)いたいと今(いま)思(おも)っていたところだわ！」
example.english: Friend meets a friend by accident: "I was just thinking that I want to see you!"

example.japanese: 改札(かいさつ)に入(はい)ったところで電車(でんしゃ)の扉(とびら)が閉(し)まった。
example.english: Just as I went through the ticket gate, the train doors closed.

example.japanese: いつも勉強(べんきょう)し始(はじ)めたところで何(なに)かが邪魔(じゃま)してくる。
example.english: Whenever I have just started studying, something gets in the way.

synonym.explanation: About to, On the verge of
just did, something just happened
the instant・moment, as soon as, just as
freshly ~ed, just ~ed

english_grammar.title: ～ている所(ところ)だ
english_grammar.explanation: in the process of doing ~ right now/at this moment
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ている］+ ところ + だ
english_grammar.attention: In this use ところ means "stage/level/situation"
english_grammar.about: In the previous grammar point, we learned that たところ (or ていたところ) will mean 'just did (A)', or 'was just doing (A)'. ているところ works in a similar way, but expresses that someone is right in the middle of doing something. It is regularly translated as 'doing (A) right now', or 'in the process of (A)'. 仕事(しごと)をしているところだから後(あと)で電話(でんわ)するね。I am in the middle of work right now, so I will call you later, okay? 昨日(きのう)は近所(きんじょ)で泥棒(どろぼう)が警察(けいさつ)から逃(に)げているところを見(み)た。Yesterday, I saw a burglar running away from the police in my neighborhood. Caution Using ているところ will indicate that someone is 'busy with (A)', and would therefore not be used when changing actions suddenly. In these cases ているところだった would be used, before the (B) phrase would further explain what happened next. 映画(えいが)を見(み)ているところだったから電話(でんわ)に出(で)れなかった。I was in the middle of watching a movie, so I couldn't answer the phone. ギターを弾(ひ)いているところだったからメッセージに気付(きづ)かなかった。I was in the middle of playing my guitar, so I didn't notice your message.

example.japanese: 今(いま)、映画(えいが)を見(み)ているところです。
example.english: I am in the process of watching a movie right now.

example.japanese: 今(いま)、お父(とう)さんは富士山(ふじさん)を登(のぼ)っているところです。
example.english: My dad is in the process of climbing Mt. Fuji right now.

example.japanese: 今(いま)、先生(せんせい)に聞(き)いているところです。
example.english: I am in the process of asking the teacher right now.

example.japanese: 僕(ぼく)は今(いま)日本語(にほんご)を勉強(べんきょう)しているところだけど。
example.english: I am in the process of studying Japanese right now. [annoyed that he is being interrupted]

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)がスターバックスに入(はい)って来(き)た時(とき)、私(わたし)はコーヒーを飲(の)んでいるところだった。
example.english: When he came into Starbucks, I was in the process of drinking coffee (at that moment).

english_grammar.title: と～と～どちらが
english_grammar.explanation: between ~ which one
english_grammar.structure: Noun (A) + と + Noun (B) + （と） + どちら(1) + が Verb1 + こと(1) + と + Verb2 + こと(1) + （と） + どちら(1) + が (1) どちらのほう、どっち、どっちのほう
english_grammar.about: と～と、どちらが is an expression in Japanese that is made from the following parts:と - The particle (x2) in its meaning of 'and'.どちら - Thepolite speech form of 誰(だれ) 'who', and a slightly newer form of どっち that basically means 'which'.が - The case marking particleThis structure is used when the speaker is asking a question about whether someone will choose (A) or (B). It is only used when there are no more than two possible choices. ピザとラーメンとどちらが好(す)きですか。Between pizza and ramen, which do you prefer? 漢字(かんじ)を書(か)くことと漢字(かんじ)を読(よ)むこととどちらが得意(とくい)ですか。Between writing and reading kanji, which are you more confident with? 遊園地(ゆうえんち)に行(い)くのと動物園(どうぶつえん)に行(い)くのとどちらがいいですか。Between going to the amusement park, and going to the zoo, which is better? As can be seen above, verbs may be used as part of this structure if they are nominalized with こと, or の. Additionally, the polite form does not specifically need to be used, and どっち may be used instead. 辛(から)い物(もの)と甘(あま)い物(もの)とどっちが好(す)き？Between something spicy and something sweet, which do you like more? The second と itself is quite often omitted, as どちら (or どっち) implies that both (A) and (B) are part of the same structure. 私(わたし)と彼女(かのじょ)どっちが好(す)き？Between me and her, who do you like? Fun FactAs どちら is the polite speech form of 誰(だれ), it is also frequently used as a polite way to ask questions about unknown people. すみません、どちら様(さま)ですか？I'm sorry, who are you? Caution どちらのほう (or どっちのほう) may also be used, but this does not really change the overall nuance. It merely puts slightly more emphasis on the 'direction' of the choice. This is similar to expressions like 'which one are you leaning towards?' in English. ワインとビールとどちらの方(ほう)が飲(の)みたいですか？Between wine and beer, which would you want to drink more?

example.japanese: コーヒーとお茶(ちゃ)とどちらがほしいですか。
example.english: Between coffee and tea, which do you want?

example.japanese: マンガを読(よ)むことと、新聞(しんぶん)を読(よ)むこと、どちらが好(す)きですか。
example.english: Between reading manga and reading the newspaper, which do you like?

example.japanese: スポーツすることと、ゲームすること、どちらが上手(じょうず)ですか。
example.english: Between playing sports and playing video games, which are you better at?

example.japanese: ひらがなとカタカナとどちらが覚(おぼ)えにくいですか。
example.english: Between hiragana and katakana, which one is more difficult to remember?

example.japanese: エベレストとK2とどちらが高(たか)い？
example.english: Between Everest and K2, which one is taller?

synonym.explanation: Out of ~, ~ is the best/most ~

english_grammar.title: 様(よう)にする
english_grammar.explanation: To try to, To make sure to, To endeavor to
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］(1) + ように + する (1) Verb［ない］
english_grammar.attention: Specifies end goals
english_grammar.about: (A) ようにする is an expression in Japanese which combines the auxiliary verb ようだ, with する (indicating that you will 'try' to do something). As ようだ is being linked to the verb する, it will take on its adverbial form, ように. This structure emphasizes that the (A) action (always a verb) is something that the speaker is going out of their way to do, and implies effort. 最近(さいきん)太(ふと)ってきたので、毎日(まいにち)走(はし)るようにしています。Recently, I have been gaining weight, so I try to run everyday. 次(つぎ)の試合(しあい)で勝(か)てるようにする。I will try to be able to win the next tournament. Naturally, this structure may also be used with a negative verb, to imply that (A) being done is something that is actively being avoided. This translates as 'to make sure not to do (A)'. 「空気(くうき)が汚(よご)れるので乗(の)り物(もの)に乗(の)らないようにする」と弟(おとうと)が言(い)いました。My brother said 'I try not to ride vehicles, because it pollutes the air'. 成績(せいせき)が悪(わる)いから学校(がっこう)を休(やす)まないようにする。Because my grades are bad, I will try not to miss school. Fun FactBecause ようだ comes from the kanji 様(よう) 'manner', it carries the nuance that the 'way' that someone is doing (A) is specifically in a way that has success as the goal. Literally it translates quite closely to 'to do (A) in the manner of getting it done', and therefore just strengthens the (A) action, by using 'to do' twice.

example.japanese: 毎日(まいにち)野菜(やさい)を食(た)べるようにしないといけない。
example.english: You have to try to eat vegetables every day.

example.japanese: 予約(よやく)に間(ま)に合(あ)うようにしましょう。
example.english: Let's try to be on time for the reservation.

example.japanese: そのコップを落(お)とさないようにしてください。
example.english: Please try not to drop that cup.

example.japanese: あまり音(おと)が出(で)ないようにしてください。
example.english: Please try not to make much noise.

example.japanese: 綺麗(きれい)に包(つつ)むようにします。
example.english: I will try to wrap it beautifully.

english_grammar.title: なければいけない
english_grammar.explanation: must do, have to do
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］ + なければ + いけない Verb［ない］ + なきゃ + いけない
english_grammar.attention: Verb[ない]+と+いけない/ならないis also used to express duty or necessity.
english_grammar.about: Like なくてはいけない, なければいけない is a structure that implies that something 'must be done'. However, it is important to remember that this is actually a double negative, and therefore means 'If (A) is not done, it cannot go', or more simply '(A) cannot not be done'.To make this construction, the auxiliary verb ない will need to be conjugated with ば, creating なければ (if not). After this, いけない (to not be able to go) will be added to the end. 来月(らいげつ)に友達(ともだち)の結婚式(けっこんしき)に行(い)かなければいけない。Next month, I have to go to my friend's wedding. (Not going to the wedding is not going to work) 車(くるま)は駐車場(ちゅうしゃじょう)に止(と)めなければいけない。Cars have to be parked in parking lots. (Not being parked in a parking lot is unacceptable) As learned in the なきゃ lesson, なければ may be shortened to なきゃ. This structure is frequently used either with or without the added いけない. ここで話(はな)している場合(ばあい)じゃない。息子(むすこ)を迎(むか)えに行(い)かなきゃ。This is not the time to talk here, I have to go pick up my son. 宿題(しゅくだい)で、調(しら)べなきゃいけない事(こと)があるから、パソコン貸(か)して。Since I need to look up something for my homework, would you please lend me your computer? Caution While いけない (to not be able to go) and ならない (to not become) are quite similar, ならない will rarely be used outside of formal situations, or in writing. Due to this, いけない will be heard much more frequently in speech (when it is not omitted).

example.japanese: 仕事(しごと)に行(い)かなければいけない。
example.english: I have to go to work.

example.japanese: 冬(ふゆ)になったら、暖房(だんぼう)をつけなければいけません。
example.english: When winter comes, I will have to turn on the heater.

example.japanese: 覚(おぼ)えにくいけど、覚(おぼ)えなければいけません。
example.english: It is difficult to remember, but I must (remember).

example.japanese: 兄(あに)みたいに大学(だいがく)に行(い)かなければいけないと言(い)われました。
example.english: I was told that I have to go to college like my older brother.

example.japanese: 頭(あたま)が痛(いた)すぎて、薬(くすり)を飲(の)まなければいけない。
example.english: My head hurts so much that I must take medicine.

english_grammar.title: なければならない
english_grammar.explanation: must do, have to do
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］ + なければ + ならない Verb［ない］ + なきゃ + ならない
english_grammar.attention: Verb[ない]+と+いけない/ならないis also used to express duty or necessity.
english_grammar.about: Like なければいけない, なければならない is a structure that implies that something 'must be done'. However, it is important to remember that this is actually a double negative, and therefore means 'If (A) is not done, it cannot become', or more simply '(A) cannot not be done'.To make this construction, the auxiliary verb ない will need to be conjugated with ば, creating なければ (if not). After this, ならない (to not become) will be added to the end. 仕事(しごと)はしなければならない。I must do my work. 先輩(せんぱい)が部屋(へや)に入(はい)って来(き)たら立(た)って挨拶(あいさつ)をしなければならない。If your senpai comes into the room, you must stand and greet them. As we learned in the なきゃ lesson, なければ may be shortened to なきゃ. This structure is frequently used, either with or without the added ならない. 今日(きょう)も帰(かえ)りが遅(おそ)くなったら妻(つま)に怒(おこ)られるから、もうすぐ帰(かえ)らなきゃ。My wife is going to scold me if I come home late today too, so I have to go home soon. 今日(きょう)は家事(かじ)をやらなきゃならないから出(で)かけられない。I have to do some chores today, so I can't go out. Caution While いけない (to not be able to go) and ならない (to not become) are quite similar, ならない will rarely be used outside of formal situations, or in writing. Due to this, いけない will be heard much more frequently in speech (when it is not omitted).

example.japanese: したくない時(とき)でも、宿題(しゅくだい)をしなければならない。
example.english: Even when you don't want to, you have to do your homework.

example.japanese: 飛行機(ひこうき)に乗(の)りたいなら、空港(くうこう)に行(い)かなければならない。
example.english: If you want to ride an airplane, you have to go to the airport.

example.japanese: 先生(せんせい)の話(はなし)を聞(き)かなければならないよ。
example.english: You have to listen to the teacher (talk).

example.japanese: 髪(かみ)の毛(け)が長(なが)いから、切(き)らなければならない。
example.english: My hair is long, so I have to cut it.

example.japanese: 新(あたら)しいノートを買(か)わなければならないかもしれない。
example.english: I might have to buy a new notebook.

english_grammar.title: 続(つづ)ける
english_grammar.explanation: to continue
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ 続ける
english_grammar.about: By attaching the verb 続(つづ)ける 'to continue' to theconjunctive form of another verb, we will be able to express that '(A) is continuing'. Let's have a look at a few examples of this structure. サリーは暗(くら)くなるまで走(はし)り続(つづ)ける。Sally will continue to run until it gets dark. 私(わたし)は漢字(かんじ)を覚(おぼ)えるまで、同(おな)じ漢字(かんじ)を書(か)き続(つづ)ける。I will continue to write the same kanji until I memorize it. Caution There is a difference in nuance between connecting one verb to another verb through the conjunctive form, or through the use of the conjunction particle て. The former implies that '(A) is being done in the way of (B)', while the latter implies that '(A) is being done, and then (B)'. 日本語(にほんご)は難(むずか)しいけど、勉強(べんきょう)を頑張(がんば)って続(つづ)ける。Japanese is difficult, but I will give it my best and continue with study. (Emphasis on the continuation of studying) 日本語(にほんご)は難(むずか)しいけど、勉強(べんきょう)を頑張(がんば)り続(つづ)ける。Japanese is difficult, but I will continue giving it my best with study. (Emphasis on the continuation of giving it one's best)

example.japanese: テレビを見(み)つづけるつもりですか。
example.english: Do you plan to continue to watch TV?

example.japanese: 文法(ぶんぽう)の間違(まちが)えを直(なお)し続(つづ)けてみたらどうだ？
example.english: Why don't you try to continue to fix your grammar mistakes?

example.japanese: あの警察官(けいさつかん)は一時間(いちじかん)以上(いじょう)見回(みまわ)り続(つづ)けた。
example.english: That police officer continued to patrol around for over one hour.

example.japanese: 大(おお)きい魚(さかな)を釣(つ)るまで釣(つ)り続(つづ)けます。
example.english: I will continue to fish until I catch a big fish.

example.japanese: まっすぐ見(み)て、歩(ある)き続(つづ)けなさい！
example.english: Look straight, and continue walking!

english_grammar.title: 様(よう)に言(い)う
english_grammar.explanation: To tell/request/order to do (in such a way)
english_grammar.structure: Verb + ように + 言う (1) 頼たのむ、命めいじる
english_grammar.about: ようにいう is an expression which combines the auxiliary verb ようだ, with the う-Verb 言(い)う. This indicates that something is being said in a way that instigates (A). As ようだ is being linked to the verb 言(い)う, it will take on its adverbial form, ように. 子供(こども)に水(みず)をこぼさないように言(い)う。I tell my child not to spill his water. (To tell them in a way that 'not spilling the water' is the focus) 弁護士(べんごし)が犯人(はんにん)に警察(けいさつ)に話(はな)さないように言(い)う。The lawyer told the criminal to not talk to the police. (To tell them in a way that 'not talking to the police' is the focus) As ようにいう means 'to be said in the way of (A) being done', it is regularly translated as 'to tell', 'to request', or 'to order'. In the case of requesting, 頼(たの)む may substitute for 言(い)う. For ordering, 命(めい)じる may substitute for it instead. 俺(おれ)の漫画(まんが)を借(か)りてもいいけど、破(やぶ)らないように頼(たの)むよ。It is okay for me to let you borrow my manga, but I request that you not rip it. 総理(そうり)は国民(こくみん)に海外旅行(かいがいりょこう)に行(い)かないように命(めい)じる。The prime minister will order citizens to not travel abroad. 言(い)う itself is the most versatile of these three verbs, as it may imply 'to order', or 'to request'. This will depend on the tone of the speaker/overall context of the request/order.

example.japanese: お弁当(べんとう)を持(も)って行(い)くことを忘(わす)れないように言(い)った。
example.english: I told you not to forget to take your lunchbox with you.

example.japanese: トムに手伝(てつだ)いをするように頼(たの)んだよ。
example.english: I requested that Tom help out.

example.japanese: 子供(こども)らが怖(こわ)がらないように頼(たの)むよ。
example.english: I ask that you not scare the kids. [in such a way]

example.japanese: 卵(たまご)を買(か)うように言(い)ったはずだ。
example.english: I most definitely told you to pick up some eggs. [in such a way]

example.japanese: 明日(あした)試合(しあい)があるので、今夜(こんや)よく眠(ねむ)るように言(い)った。
example.english: Since we have a game tomorrow, I told them to get a good night's sleep tonight. [in such a way]

so that, in order to, in such a way that

english_grammar.title: 予定(よてい)だ
english_grammar.explanation: plan to, intend to
english_grammar.structure: Verb + 予定 + だ Noun + の + 予定 + だ
english_grammar.about: 予定(よてい)だ is an expression that functions very similarly to つもりだ 'to intend to do'. The primary difference being that 予定(よてい) is a 'plan', rather than an 'intention'. Due to this, 予定(よてい) is used far more frequently for things that you have formal plans to do (like meeting a friend for lunch).To use 予定(よてい), just attach it to the non-past form of a verb, or to a noun (after inserting の). 今夜(こんや)は先輩(せんぱい)たちと飲(の)みに行(い)く予定(よてい)だ。I plan to go drink with my senpai tonight. 休(やす)みは来週(らいしゅう)からの予定(よてい)だ。My break is planned to start from next week. Caution If だ or です is not added after 予定(よてい), it will imply that 予定(よてい) is simply modifying the verb/noun that comes before it, rather than being a standalone 'plan'. This is similar to the difference between saying something like 'I have plans to eat with a friend' (natural), vs 'I have an eating with a friend plan' (unnatural). 明日(あした)は友達(ともだち)とステーキを食(た)べる予定(よてい)だ。I have plans to eat a steak with a friend tomorrow. (Natural Japanese) 明日(あした)は友達(ともだち)とステーキを食(た)べる予定(よてい)。I have an 'eating a steak with a friend' plan tomorrow. (Unnatural Japanese)

example.japanese: 会議(かいぎ)は月曜日(げつようび)の予定(よてい)です。
example.english: The meeting is planned for Monday.

example.japanese: 学校(がっこう)で研究(けんきゅう)をする予定(よてい)です。
example.english: I plan to do research at school.

example.japanese: 卒業(そつぎょう)してから、仕事(しごと)を探(さが)す予定(よてい)です。
example.english: After graduating, I plan to look for a job.

example.japanese: 大学(だいがく)で2年間(ねんかん)勉強(べんきょう)して、日本(にほん)に留学(りゅうがく)する予定(よてい)だ。
example.english: I plan to study two years at university, then study abroad in Japan.

example.japanese: 電気代(でんきだい)が高(たか)くなるけど、エアコンを点(つ)けておく予定(よてい)だ。
example.english: The electric bill might be high, but I plan to leave the air conditioner on.

with the intention of doing, instead of..., act as if/pretend, believing that..., thinking that...

english_grammar.title: 様(よう)に祈(いの)る
english_grammar.explanation: pray that/for, hope that/for, keep fingers crossed that
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］ + ように + 祈る Verb［ない］ + ように + 祈る
english_grammar.about: As we have seen several times now, the auxiliary verb ようだ is frequently used with verbs, to express that the 'completion' of an action is the specific goal/wish of the speaker. It does this implicitly through the meaning of the kanji 様(よう) 'manner of doing'.ようにいのる (or 祈(いの)る in its kanji form) is no different, and will imply that the speaker is praying for (A) to be done/completed. This comes from the meaning of the う-Verb 祈(いの)る itself, which can be translated as 'to pray', or 'to beg'. Despite being able to be used when actually praying, this grammar point is used most often to express a 'hope'. 明日(あした)に雪(ゆき)が降(ふ)って学校(がっこう)が休(やすみ)みになるように祈(いの)る。I hope that it snows tomorrow and school gets canceled. 世界(せかい)が平和(へいわ)になるように祈(いの)る。I hope that the world becomes a peaceful place. In a similar way to other ように structures, ないように may also be used with 祈(いの)る, to show that someone is praying for something 'not' to happen. 授業中(じゅぎょうちゅう)に先生(せんせい)に呼(よ)ばれないように祈(いの)る。I hope that the teacher doesn't call on me during class. 友達(ともだち)の車(くるま)に乗(の)る前(まえ)に死(し)なないように祈(いの)る。I hope that I don't die before I get to ride in my friend's car. Caution However, 'unlike' other ように structures, ように祈(いの)る will sometimes be shortened to ように by itself. This is especially true after ます. 今年(ことし)は国(くに)に帰(かえ)れますように。I pray that you can go back to your country this year. 明日(あした)のテストで合格(ごうかく)できますように。I pray that I can pass tomorrow's test. This is the only ように structure that will have the verb that comes after it omitted. Therefore, ように (by itself) will always mean 'to hope for', and should not be confused with ようにする, ようになる, ようにいう, and other similar grammar points.Fun Factといい is also used to express 'to hope for (A)', or 'to wish for (A)'. However, unlike ように祈(いの)る, the person that the speaker is praying for with といい will mainly be determined by the use of ね (praying for someone else), or な (praying for themselves). 行(い)きたい大学(だいがく)に行(い)けるといいね。I hope that you get into the college that you want to get into. (Hope for your sake) 来年(らいねん)は海外旅行(かいがいりょこう)に行(い)けるといいな。I hope I can travel abroad next year. (Hope for my own sake)

example.japanese: 生(い)きてここを出(で)られるように祈(いの)っているんだ。
example.english: I am praying that I can leave this place alive.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)が安全(あんぜん)に帰(かえ)れるように祈(いの)ろう！
example.english: Let's pray that he can come home safely.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)能力試験(のうりょくしけん)に合格(ごうかく)できるように毎日(まいにち)祈(いの)っているわよ。
example.english: I am praying every day for the ability to pass the JLPT.

example.japanese: うまく行(い)くように祈(いの)って(ください)ね。
example.english: Please pray that it will go well.

example.japanese: 親(おや)：「マルちゃんは何(なに)を祈(いの)っているの？」娘(むすめ)のマルちゃん：「ワシみたいに飛(と)べるように祈(いの)っているのだ！」
example.english: Parent: "What are you praying for, Maru-chan?"Daughter, Maru-chan: "I am praying for the ability to fly like an eagle!"

english_grammar.title: ～たばかり
english_grammar.explanation: just did, something just happened
english_grammar.structure: Verb［た］+ ばかり
english_grammar.attention: ばっかり, ばっか, ばかし, and ばっかし are all fairly common casual variations of ばかり
english_grammar.about: As an adverbial particle, ばかり usually has one of three basic meanings.Degree: 程度(ていど) - Highlights the 'rough' amount/degree of something (similar to くらい).Limit: 限定(げんてい) - Highlights the 'limit' of something (similar to だけ).Completion: 完了(かんりょう) - Highlights the 'end', or 'completion' of something.In this lesson, we will focus primarily on the completion meaning. When connecting ばかり to the past form of a verb (using た), it will imply that a specific action has 'just finished', 'just stopped', or 'just been completed'. 駅(えき)に着(つ)いたばかりに友達(ともだち)から「やっぱり今日(きょう)は遊(あそ)べない」とメッセージが来(き)た。Just as I got to the station, I got a message from my friend saying, 'Actually, I can't hang out today'. 一回(いっかい)遅(おく)れたばかりで先生(せんせい)に怒(おこ)られた。I got scolded by my teacher for being late just once. さっき食(た)べたばかりだから、お腹(なか)はまだ空(す)いていない。I just ate earlier, so I am still not hungry. Fun FactDespite having three different meanings, ばかり can be thought of as always highlighting how close one thing is to another.Degree: 程度(ていど) - Highlights (A)'s degree of closeness (to a stated amount).Limit: 限定(げんてい) - Highlights (A)'s degree of closeness (to a description).Completion: 完了(かんりょう) - Highlights (A)'s degree of closeness (to a point in time).

example.japanese: 今(いま)、家(いえ)を出(で)たばかりです。
example.english: I just left home.

example.japanese: 電車(でんしゃ)に乗(の)ったばかりで携帯(けいたい)を落(お)とした。
example.english: Just when I got on the train, I dropped my phone.

example.japanese: ユミに彼氏(かれし)が出来(でき)たと聞(き)いたばかり。
example.english: I just heard that Yumi got a boyfriend.

example.japanese: また海外(かいがい)行(い)くの？先週(せんしゅう)台湾(たいわん)に行(い)ったばかりじゃない？
example.english: You are going abroad again? Didn't you just go to Taiwan last week?

example.japanese: その漢字(かんじ)を習(なら)ったばかりなのに、もう忘(わす)れた。
example.english: Even though I just learned that kanji, I already forgot it.

the instant・moment, as soon as, just as

english_grammar.title: 化(か)する
english_grammar.explanation: -ification, -ization, to make something, to change, to become, transform into
english_grammar.structure: Noun + 化（する） Noun + 化 + する(1) + Noun (1) した、の
english_grammar.about: 化(か) by itself is a suffix in Japanese which means 'to change', or 'to transform'. When paired with する, it means 'to transform into (A)', where (A) is the noun that 化(か) is connected to. This structure is regularly translated as '~ification', or '~ization', and similar suffixes in English. あと数年(すうねん)で運転(うんてん)は自動(じどう)化(か)する。In a few years driving will become automated. 私(わたし)は仕事(しごと)で書類(しょるい)をデータ化(か)する。At work, I digitize documents. When the する is connected to another noun, it may occasionally appear as した, or with の attached to the end of it. This will indicate that there is a relationship between (B) and (A). 劣(れっ)化(か)した家(いえ)を立(た)て直(なお)す仕事(しごと)をしたい。I want a job rebuilding deteriorated homes. 日本(にほん)は紙社会(かみしゃかい)なので仕事(しごと)をオンライン化(か)するのは厳(きび)しい。Since Japan is a paper society, digitalization of work is difficult. However, in formal/scientific writing, the する (and の) may sometimes be dropped. 日本(にほん)では高齢(こうれい)化(か)が進(すす)んでいる。In Japan, the population is aging progressively.

example.japanese: それは単純(たんじゅん)化(か)した英語(えいご)のように見(み)える。
example.english: It appears to be simplified English.

example.japanese: 20世紀(せいき)には経済(けいざい)成長(せいちょう)の原因(げんいん)の一(ひと)つは自動(じどう)化(か)だと考(かんが)えられている。
example.english: It is considered that automation is one of the sources of economic growth in the 20th century.

example.japanese: お父(とう)さん、アプリはこうやって最小(さいしょう)化(か)するの。
example.english: Dad, you minimize apps like this.

example.japanese: その新(あら)たなタイプの電池(でんち)が商品(しょうひん)化(か)する計画(けいかく)があると言(い)われている。
example.english: It is said that there are already plans to commercialize that new type of battery.

example.japanese: プラスチックを液(えき)化(か)する方法(ほうほう)はエネルギ産業(さんぎょう)を一変(いっぺん)させるかもしれない。
example.english: The plastic liquefaction method might revolutionize the energy industry.

english_grammar.title: 命令形(めいれいけい)
english_grammar.explanation: verb!, do (something)!
english_grammar.structure: Examples: ［る1］Verb ￫ 見る + ろ(1) ［る5］Verb ￫ 座る + れ ［う］Verb ￫ 歌う + え ［く］Verb ￫ 歩く + け ［す］Verb ￫ 話す + せ ［つ］Verb ￫ 打つ + て ［ぬ］Verb ￫ 死ぬ + ね ［ぶ］Verb ￫ 飛ぶ + べ ［む］Verb ￫ 休む + め ［ぐ］Verb ￫ 泳ぐ + げ Exceptions: する ￫ しろ2 くる ￫ こい くれる ￫ くれ (1) よ (2) せよ
english_grammar.attention: Avoid using this conjugation since it might sound rude and threatening.
english_grammar.about: In Japanese, there are numerous ways to express an order, command, or instruction. The most direct, abrasive, and therefore least used method is called the imperative form, which happens to be one of the basic conjugations of verbs. Without particles following it, the imperative form is fairly uncommon in daily life, but will often be seen on traffic signs, posters, or banners. In addition, it can be also heard shouted at demonstrations, when cheering at sports events, or in urgent situations, such as an officer yelling at a suspect to stop. Verbs are conjugated into the imperative form in the following way. For う-Verbs, simply replace the last kana of any verb with the equivalent え sound kana from the same row. For る-Verbs, replace る with either ろ or よ. 道路標識(どうろひょうしき)：「止(と)まれ！」 Road sign: 'Stop!' 警察官(けいさつかん)：「手(て)を上(あ)げろ。」 Policeman: Raise your hands! The imperative form may sometimes be softened with the particle よ. This is a pattern which is mostly used by men that are familiar with each other, in order to offer advice or encouragement. Women tend to use the more polite て-form of verbs instead. 元気(げんき)出(だ)せよ。 Cheer up! 頑張(がんば)れよ。 Just give it your all! Any verb except for ある and いる may be conjugated to the imperative form, due to their meanings being based on existence and nothing more. Fun-fact- The なさい, polite imperative that comes from なさる is mostly used by teachers and parents talking to their children. It is also often used in instructions on test papers. When speaking to animals, the polite prefix お plus the ます-stem will also occasionally be used. テスト：「１・２・３・４から一つ選(えら)びなさい。」Test: 'Choose one answer out of 1, 2, 3, and 4.' 犬(いぬ)へ：「お座(すわ)り。」To a dog: 'Sit!' Fun FactOriginally, よ was used instead of ろ with る-Verbs. Despite this, with time it has been gradually losing popularity, and nowadays it is considered to be a more formal, written variant.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の携帯(けいたい)を返(かえ)せ！
example.english: Give back my cellphone!

example.japanese: もっと飲(の)め！
example.english: Drink more!

example.japanese: ゴミはゴミ箱(ばこ)に捨(す)てろ！
example.english: Throw away your trash in the trash can!

example.japanese: 早(はや)く寝(ね)ろ！
example.english: Sleep already!

example.japanese: 先生(せんせい)が「皆(みな)静(しず)かにしろ！」と言(い)った。
example.english: The teacher said, 'Everyone, be quiet!'

english_grammar.title: 様(よう)に
english_grammar.explanation: so that, in order to, in such a way that
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］(1) + ように + Phrase Verb［できる］(2) + ように + Phrase (1) Verb［ない］ (2) Verb［できる］［ない］
english_grammar.about: When partnered with verbs in the potential form, or in the negative form, the auxiliary verb ようだ (in its adverbial form ように) implies that the speaker has a lack of direct control over an outcome, and therefore is 'trying to do (B) in the manner of (A)', but cannot guarantee the result. This grammar point is usually translated as 'to do (A) in such a way that will enable (B)', or 'in order to allow (B)'.To use ように in this way, simply add it to the non-past form of any verb in its negative, potential, or standard conjugation. お母(かあ)さんから離(はな)れないように手(て)をつなぐ。I hold my mothers hands so that I won't get separated from her. 泥棒(どろぼう)が入(はい)れないように家(いえ)のカギを閉(し)める。I lock my house, so that burglars can't come in. マイケルジャクソンみたいに踊(おど)れるように毎日(まいにち)ダンスの練習(れんしゅう)をする。I practice dancing everyday, so that I can dance like Michael Jackson. 日本語(にほんご)をペラペラに話(はな)せるように毎日(まいにち)近所(きんじょ)の人(ひと)と日本語(にほんご)で話(はなし)をしている。I speak Japanese with my neighbor everyday, so that I can speak Japanese fluently. As mentioned in our lesson about potential verbs, する does not actually have a potential form, and therefore できる will be used instead. 勉強(べんきょう)ができるように机(つくえ)の上(うえ)を掃除(そうじ)した。I tidied up my desk so that I could study. 平日(へいじつ)にスキーが出来(でき)るように仕事(しごと)を休(やす)んだ。I took the day off of work, in order to be able to ski on a weekday.

example.japanese: 例(たと)えば風邪(かぜ)を引(ひ)かないように、暖(あたた)かい服装(ふくそう)をする。
example.english: For example, I wear warm clothes so that I won't catch a cold.

example.japanese: 目(め)が悪(わる)いので、字幕(じまく)が見(み)えるように椅子(いす)をテレビに近(ちか)づけた。
example.english: Because I have bad eyes, I moved the chair closer to the TV so that I can see the subtitles.

example.japanese: 子供(こども)がナイフなどに近(ちか)づかないようにキッチンキャビネットを閉(し)める必要(ひつよう)がある。
example.english: It is necessary to close the kitchen cabinets so that children won't get near knives and the like.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)が理解(りかい)できるように説明(せつめい)しようと思(おも)っている。
example.english: I plan to explain it in such a way that he will be able to understand.

example.japanese: 大事(だいじ)なことを忘(わす)れないようにいつもメモをしている。
example.english: I always take notes so that I won't forget important things.

english_grammar.title: かしら
english_grammar.explanation: I wonder
english_grammar.structure: Phrase + かしら
english_grammar.about: Originally, かしら was an abbreviation of か知(し)らぬ, or かしらん, which are both ways of expressing 'whether it's (A), I don't know'. These days, かしら is a standalone sentence ending particle that works in a similar way to かも, by expressing the speaker's uncertainty about the previous statement.かしら may be attached to the end of almost any phrase that the speaker wants to express doubt about. あそこにいるのはタケル君(くん)かしら。I wonder if that person over there is Takeru-kun. 明日(あした)は晴(は)れるかしら。I wonder if it will clear up tomorrow. Caution Although the original forms of か知(し)らぬ, or かしらん were useable by anybody, かしら is thought to be very feminine in modern Japanese, and therefore is not often used by men.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)は雨(あめ)が降(ふ)るかしら。
example.english: I wonder if it will rain today.

example.japanese: すぐ冷房(れいぼう)をつけてくれないかしら。
example.english: I wonder if they won't turn on the air conditioning for us soon.

example.japanese: ここで食(た)べてもいいかしら。
example.english: I wonder if it is ok to eat here.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は飛(と)ぶのが怖(こわ)いので、飛行機(ひこうき)に乗(の)れるかしら。
example.english: He is terrified of flying, I wonder if he can board the plane.

example.japanese: 納豆(なっとう)は変(へん)な匂(にお)いがするから、食(た)べれるかしら。
example.english: Since natto has a strange smell, I wonder if I will be able to eat it.

synonym.explanation: I wonder
I wonder...

english_grammar.title: らしい ②
english_grammar.explanation: typical of, -ish・like, appropriate for, becoming of, befitting
english_grammar.structure: Noun + らしい。 Noun + らしく + Phrase Noun + らしい + Noun
english_grammar.about: In our first らしい lesson, we discussed the auxiliary verb use of らしい. In this lesson we will focus on the 形容詞(けいようし)の一部(いちぶ) (auxiliary adjective) usage. An auxiliary adjective is a type of adjective that must be attached to another word for it to have any meaning.To use らしい in this way, it must be attached to the end of a noun, and will imply that something is 'typical of (A)', where (A) is the noun that comes before it. As this らしい behaves like an い-Adjective, it may also be conjugated to らしく, before a (B) phrase will explain more about 'what' is/was typical of (A). トムは本当(ほんとう)に男(おとこ)らしいね。Tom, you are really manly. タケル君(くん)はもうお兄(にい)ちゃんなので、お兄(にい)ちゃんらしくしなさい！Takeru, you are already an older brother, so you should act like an older brother! やっと10月(がつ)らしい天気(てんき)になったね。It has finally become October-like weather, don't you think? The primary use of this らしい is to express that (A) has some feature or trait that is expected of itself. It can be used for people, 'studying all night is so typical of Tanaka', or it can be used for things like seasons 'this heat is so typical of the Japanese Summer'. Other common translations are 'to be befitting of (A)', or 'to be appropriate for (A)'. However, it may also be used negatively, to show that something is (often surprisingly) 'uncharacteristic of (A)'. トムがこんなに勉強(べんきょう)をしているのは見(み)たことがない、トムらしくない。I've never seen Tom study this much. It's very uncharacteristic of him. 今日(きょう)は8月(がつ)らしくないです。涼(すず)しいです。Today is not typical of August. It's cool. 彼女(かのじょ)は女(おんな)らしくない人(ひと)だ。She is an unladylike person. Fun FactWhen the noun that appears in (A) and (B) are the same, it will imply that (A) is the 'prime example of (B)', or 'the most (A), (B)'. 今年(ことし)の8月(がつ)は夏(なつ)らしい夏(なつ)だね。August this year is the prime example of summer. (Literally, 'the most summery summer')

example.japanese: 父親(ちちおや)：「学校(がっこう)に行(い)きたくなくなることは子供(こども)らしい。オレもそうだったよ。」
example.english: Father: "Not wanting to go to school is typical of children. I was also like that."

example.japanese: スコット：「これは一番(いちばん)だいこんらしいだいこんだよ！」
example.english: Scott: "This is the most radish radish among radishes!"

example.japanese: スーツの色(いろ)で一番(いちばん)人気(にんき)なのは黒(くろ)だと思(おも)っている。一番(いちばん)サラリーマンらしいし、他(ほか)の服(ふく)にも合(あ)いやすいから。
example.english: I think that the most popular suit color is black. Because it is (the color) most typical of company employees and easily matches other clothes.

example.japanese: トモちゃんは女(おんな)の子(こ)だけど、女(おんな)らしくない。
example.english: Tomo-chan is a girl, but she is unladylike.

example.japanese: 「もっと大人(おとな)らしくしなさいよ！」
example.english: "Behave more like an adult!"
