english_grammar.title: 滅多(めった)に〜ない
english_grammar.explanation: hardly, rarely, seldom
english_grammar.structure: めったに + Verb［ない］ Noun + は + めったにない
english_grammar.about: めったに～ない is an expression that may be translated as 'hardly', 'seldom', or 'rarely'. Originally, 滅多(めった) is a な-Adjective that means 'thoughtless', or 'reckless'. Due to this, as an adverb, 滅多(めった)に literally means 'thoughtlessly' or 'recklessly'.めったに～ない will usually be paired with a verb in the negative form, or following a noun, and the adverbial particle は. 大人(おとな)になってから駄菓子屋(だがしや)にはめったに行(い)かない。Ever since I became an adult. I hardly go to candy stores. 親(おや)とは正月(しょうがつ)以外(いがい)にはめったに会(あ)わない。Other than New Years, I hardly see my parents. こんなチャンスはめったにないぞ！A chance like this is very rare. パーティーに行(い)くことはめったにない。I hardly do things like go to parties. Caution It is far more common to see めったに written without kanji, than with. However, both are used.Fun FactAs めったに originally means 'thoughtlessly', when appearing in a negative statement, the nuance becomes 'to not (A) thoughtlessly' (mindlessly, or aimlessly). This simply expresses that the speaker will not do (A) unintentionally, or (A) will not happen unless there is some special reason for it. 私(わたし)は何(なに)か大事(おおごと)なことが起(お)きない限(かぎ)り、電話(でんわ)はめったに掛(か)けない。Unless something big happens, I don't mindlessly make phone calls. 家(いえ)の誰(だれ)かがテレビを見(み)ていない限(かぎ)り、自分(じぶん)からはテレビをめったに見(み)ない。Unless someone in my house is watching TV, I don't aimlessly watch TV on my own.

example.japanese: 父(ちち)はめったにテレビを見(み)ない。
example.english: My father rarely watches TV.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)についての悪口(わるぐち)をめったに聞(き)かない。
example.english: I seldom hear bad things about her.

example.japanese: せっかく日本語(にほんご)を勉強(べんきょう)したけど、めったに話(はな)さないね。
example.english: After going through all the trouble of studying Japanese, you hardly speak it.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はめったに忘(わす)れないのに、今日(きょう)はどうしたんだろう？
example.english: He rarely forgets, I wonder what happened today?

example.japanese: めったに泣(な)かない彼(かれ)が泣(な)いていた。
example.english: He, who hardly cries, was crying.

synonym.explanation: not well/properly, not much/enough, barely・hardly
Not very, Not much, Not really, Hardly
Almost all, Most, Hardly any, Few (adverbial noun)
not really, hardly, not easily/readily, by no means, far from

english_grammar.title: 割(わり)に
english_grammar.explanation: although・despite, rather...for, unexpectedly, comparatively, considering
english_grammar.structure: Verb + わりに ［い］Adjective + わりに ［な］Adjective + な + わりに Noun + の + わりに
english_grammar.about: As an adverb, 割(わり)に is usually used in a similar way to 'although', 'despite', or 'comparatively' in English.割(わり)に may be used at the beginning of a sentence, or after any word/phrase that it is highlighting as being 'comparative'. When following な-Adjectives or nouns, な or の will be required. この肉(にく)、高(たか)い割(わり)には味(あじ)がないね。Although this meat is expensive, it is not flavorful. 太(ふと)っている割(わり)には運動(うんどう)神経(しんけい)がいいんだね。Although you are fat, you are very athletic, aren't you? この機械(きかい)のパワーは強(つよ)い割(わり)にめちゃくちゃ遅(おそ)いです。Although this machine is very powerful, it is very slow. この部屋(へや)は綺麗(きれい)な割(わり)には臭(くさ)いね。Although this room is clean, it smells bad. ラッシュアワーの割(わり)には空(す)いていますね。Although it is during rush hour, the road is very clear. 割(わり) itself is a noun meaning 'proportionate', and is primarily used as a suffix. 割(わり)に may be thought of as a direct extension of this use, as 'proportionately' is its closest literal meaning.Fun FactWhile 割(わり)に is often thought to make comparisons between things, it actually only ever compares something to itself (or things within the same category). The 'proportion' that is then highlighted is something that is not common within the category of (A).Caution Both 割(わり)と and 割(わり)に are quite common expressions. However, 割(わり)と is used far more often in casual speech to show that something is 'unexpectedly (A)'. It will also frequently be used as a stand-alone expression, appearing directly before the word (usually an adjective) that is of a 'considerable' amount. これ割(わり)と美味(あい)しいよ。This is unexpectedly tasty. 昨日(きのう)買(か)った包丁(ほうちょう)は割(わり)といい。The knife I bought yesterday is quite good.

example.japanese: 高(たか)い食(た)べ物(もの)のわりに、美味(おい)しくなさそう。
example.english: The expensive food looks unexpectedly unappetizing.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)はたくさん勉強(べんきょう)したわりに、テストの点数(てんすう)が悪(わる)かった。
example.english: Although I studied a lot, I got a bad score on the test.

example.japanese: あの人(ひと)は頭(あたま)が良(い)いわりに、コミュニケーションが苦手(にがて)です。
example.english: Although that person is smart, he is bad at communication.

example.japanese: 疲(つか)れているわりには、かなり動(うご)けた方(ほう)だと思(おも)います。
example.english: I think he is rather quite active for how tired he is.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)は冬(ふゆ)のわりに暖(あたた)かい。
example.english: Today is rather warm for winter.

synonym.explanation: (even) considering, (even) for
compared to, when compared to
even
although, but, even though
rather・instead・over

english_grammar.title: う・よう + とする
english_grammar.explanation: try to・attempt to, to be about to
english_grammar.structure: Verb［おう］ + とする
english_grammar.attention: Verb[Volitional]としても(even if someone attempts to) can be contracted to Verb[Volitional] + たって/ったって。
english_grammar.about: When combined with the auxiliary verb う (or よう), とする carries the meaning of 'to try to do (A)', or 'to be about to do (A)'. The case marking particle と in this expression highlights a 'result'.To use おうとする, modify the (A) verb into its う or よう receiving form, and then add とする. この子(こ)はなんでも食(た)べようとするから、お菓子(かし)は隠(かく)してね。This one will try to eat anything, so please hide any snacks. 先生(せんせい)が話(はな)している間(あいだ)に帰(かえ)ろうとすると、先生(せんせい)に怒(おこ)られる。If you try to go home while the teacher is talking, he will yell at you. As う and よう mark volition (the express intent to do something), とする adds the nuance that the express intent has been decided, and all that remains is to 'do' the action. This translates quite closely to 'to endeavor to do' in English, where the past form 'endeavored to do' will suggest that the attempt was unsuccessful. 今年(ことし)は毎日(まいにち)日本語(にほんご)の勉強(べんきょう)をしようとしたが、時間(じかん)がなくて出来(でき)なかった。I tried to study Japanese everyday this year, but I couldn't because I didn't have time. クラスメイトのスズキさんに話(はな)しを掛(か)けようとしたけど、緊張(きんちょう)し過(す)ぎて話(はな)せなかった。I tried to talk to my classmate, Suzuki-san, but I got so nervous that I couldn't. Caution ようとする is also regularly used to indicate when one action interrupts another. In these cases, the nuance is not quite 'to have endeavored', but more '(A) was already underway, when (B)'. Again, it will just show that the (A) action was decided upon 100%, when something caused an unexpected change. 家(いえ)を出(で)ようとしたら、急(きゅう)に雨(あめ)が降(ふ)り始(はじ)めた。It suddenly started to rain when I was about to leave the house. 部屋(へや)が暗(くら)かったから電気(でんき)を点(つ)けようとしたら、妻(つま)に電気(でんき)を点(つ)けるなと言(い)われた。As I tried to turn on the lights in my room because it was dark, my wife told me not to.

example.japanese: 見(み)て！子犬(こいぬ)がしっぽを捕(つか)まえようとしている！とてもかわいい！
example.english: Look! The puppy is trying to catch its tail! It's so cute!

example.japanese: 犯人(はんにん)は、逃(に)げようとした時(とき)に、警察(けいさつ)に捕(つか)まえられた。
example.english: Just as the culprit tried to escape, he was caught by police.

example.japanese: 「鬱(うつ)」の書(か)き順(じゅん)が何回(なんかい)覚(おぼ)えようとしても、覚(おぼ)えられない。
example.english: No matter how many times I try to remember the stroke order of "鬱" I cannot remember it.

example.japanese: 一度(いちど)に２つのことをしようとするな。
example.english: Don’t try to do two things at once.

example.japanese: ひよこは親(おや)のように飛(と)ぼうとしても、できなかった。
example.english: Even though the chick attempted to fly like its parents, it couldn't.

synonym.explanation: Let's, I shall (casual volitional)
Still haven't done (something)
About to, On the verge of
To try to, To make sure to, To endeavor to
To try to
tried to ~ but ~, was about to ~ but ~, was going to ~ but ~

antonym.explanation: not willing to, not make an effort to, to not attempt to/try to, volitional + としない

english_grammar.title: う・よう + としたが
english_grammar.explanation: tried to ~ but ~, was about to ~ but ~, was going to ~ but ~
english_grammar.structure: Verb［おう］ + としたが(1) + Result Verb［おう］ + としたら + Result (1) けれども 、けれど、けども、けれども、けど
english_grammar.attention: けど、けれど、けども、けれども are all acceptable.
english_grammar.about: As mentioned in our ようとする lesson, when combined with the auxiliary verb う (or よう), とする carries the meaning of 'to try to do (A)', or 'to be about to do (A)'. The case marking particle と in this expression highlights a 'result'.However, the addition of structures like the conjunction particles が, or たら, to the past tense of する will indicate that something interrupted (A), and therefore it was unable to be completed. In these cases, the translation becomes 'to have tried to do (A), but (B)', 'was about to (A), but (B), or 'was on the verge of (A), but (B)'. クライアントに電話(でんわ)を掛(か)けようとしたが、夜(よる)遅(おそ)かったので朝(あさ)まで待(ま)つことにした。I tried to make a phone call to our client, but it was late at night so I decided to wait until morning. 池(いけ)で泳(およ)ごうとしたら、警察(けいさつ)に止(と)められた。I was stopped by the police when I was about to swim in the lake. 逃(に)げようとしたけど、捕(つか)まったら大変(たいへん)なことになるから逃(に)げなかった。I was about to run away, but if I got caught, it would have become a bigger deal, so I didn't. う and よう mark volition (the express intent to do something), while とする adds the nuance that the express intent has been decided, and all that remains is to 'do' the action. Due to this, when something interrupts a ようとする verb, it strongly suggests that (B) is/was highly unanticipated.

example.japanese: 僕(ぼく)と彼(かれ)は同時(どうじ)にジャンプしようとしたけれど、失敗(しっぱい)した。
example.english: He and I both tried to jump at the same time, but messed up.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は彼女(かのじょ)の手伝(てつだ)いをしようとしたが、断(ことわ)られた。
example.english: I tried to offer my help, but was rejected.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は徹夜(てつや)しようとしたけれど寝(ね)てしまった。
example.english: He tried to pull an all-nighter, but fell asleep.

example.japanese: 犯人(はんにん)は逃(に)げようとしたが、すぐに警察(けいさつ)が犯人(はんにん)を取(と)り押(お)さえた。
example.english: The criminal tried to run, but the police subdued him.

example.japanese: 勉強(べんきょう)しようとしたが、あまりにも疲(つか)れていたのでやめました。
example.english: I tried to study, but I was too tired and I gave up.

synonym.explanation: try to・attempt to, to be about to

english_grammar.title: 言(い)うまでもない ②
english_grammar.explanation: it goes without saying, it is needless to say, of course, obviously
english_grammar.structure: 言うまでもない + こと(1) + だが + Phrase (Phrase (A)) + 言うまでもなく + Phrase (B) (Phrase (A)) + 言うまでもない + が(2) + Phrase (B) (1) の (2) けれども 、けれど、けども、けど
english_grammar.about: Unlike は言(い)うまでもない, which usually comes after other phrases, 言(い)うまでもない tends to come at the beginning. It is a structure that combines the う - Verb 言(い)う, two (2) adverbial particles まで and も, and the い-Adjective ない. This is regularly translated as 'it goes without saying that (A)', or 'it is needless to say (A)', where (A) is whatever comes later in the sentence.言(い)うまでもない is often followed directly by ことだが, が, けど, and similar expressions, to add the nuance of 'but'. 言(い)うまでもないことだが、毎日(まいにち)漢字(かんじ)の勉強(べんきょう)をすれば、どんどん漢字(かんじ)を覚(おぼ)えることができる。It goes without saying that if you practice kanji everyday, you will steadily memorize them. 電化(でんか)製品(せいひん)を使(つか)っている間(あいだ)、言(い)うまでもないが、濡(ぬ)れた手(て)や水(みず)の周(まわ)りで使(つか)うのは危険(きけん)だ。While you are using electronics, it is needless to say that you should not use them with wet hands or around water. 言(い)うまでもないけど、君(きみ)に会(あ)えて良(よ)かった。It goes without saying, but I am glad that I met you. Fun Fact言(い)うまでもない is a polite way to express that something is 'obvious', without unintentionally sounding arrogant. 言(い)うまでもないことだが、お酒(さけ)を飲(の)んで運転(うんてん)をしてはいけない。Obviously, you should not drink and drive.

example.japanese: A：「あのさ近(ちか)づいちゃいけない動物(どうぶつ)っているの？」B:「う～ん....ライオンやヘビみたいなのは言(い)うまでもないけどカバも危(あぶ)ないよ。」
example.english: A: "Hey, are there any animals I shouldn't approach?"B: "Hmm, lions and snakes go without saying, but hippos are also dangerous."

example.japanese: 言(い)うまでもないことだが、文章(ぶんしょう)を読(よ)みやすくするために、括弧(かっこ)は使(つか)われている。
example.english: It goes without saying that brackets are used to make reading easier.

example.japanese: さだおさんの妻(つま)のえみさんは英語(えいご)は言(い)うまでもなく、韓国語(かんこくご)も話(はな)せます。
example.english: Sadao-san's wife, Emi-san can speak Korean, not to mention English.

example.japanese: 言(い)うまでもないけど、それが恋(こい)だった。
example.english: It goes without saying, but that was love.

example.japanese: 言(い)うまでもないことだが、アルコールを飲(の)んで泳(およ)いだら、溺(おぼ)れて死(し)んでしまうかもしれない。
example.english: It goes without saying that if you drink and go swimming, then you might drown.

synonym.text: は言うまでもない ①
synonym.explanation: it goes without saying (that), (it is) needless to say, I don't need to remind you

english_grammar.title: そうもない
english_grammar.explanation: very unlikely to, does not seem that, does not appear that
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ そうもない
english_grammar.attention: Less likely than そうにない
english_grammar.about: そうもない is an expression used with verbs in Japanese, to indicate that some particular action is very unlikely. It is a combination of the auxiliary verb そう, the adverbial particle も, and the い-Adjective ない.To recap, one of the primary uses of そう is to highlight appearance. Therefore, そうもない literally means 'to not even appear like (A)'. This structure will be used after verbs in their conjunctive form. 腕(うで)がまだ治(なお)っていないから、あと一週間(いっしゅうかん)ぐらい運動(うんどう)が出来(でき)そうもない。My arm hasn't healed yet, so it is very unlikely that I will exercise for another week. 今日(きょう)は雷(かみなり)が酷(ひど)いから、釣(つ)りに行(い)けそうもない。Since the thunder is very bad today, it does not even appear like I can go fishing. Caution そうもない is very similar to そうにない. The primary difference being that そうもない is stronger. This is due to も expressing something that is surprising (or for emphasis), while に simply marks a location (or state) within which something does or does not exist. The difference can be understood as follows:(A) そうもない - To not even look like (A), where 'even' emphasizes (A).(A) そうにない - To not be looking like (A), where 'be' marks where (A) is 'not' existing.Caution そうもない is an expression that is very commonly used with potential verbs, in order to convey that the 'possibility' of something cannot be observed. While this translates as 'to not appear as if (A) can be done', realistically it comes across quite strongly, similar to 'to not stand a chance of doing (A)'. こんな量(りょう)、食(た)べられそうもない。This amount, it doesn't even seem like I can eat it! (There is way too much to even seem possible to eat) 今日(きょう)は11時(じ)まで帰(かえ)って来(こ)ないかもしれないから、いつも見(み)ているテレビ番組(ばんぐみ)が見(み)られそうもない。Today, I might not be coming home until 11, so I might not be able to watch the show I always watch.

example.japanese: あんまり雪(ゆき)が降(ふ)っていないから、スキーができそうもない。
example.english: It's very unlikely that we’ll be able to ski since it didn’t snow very much.

example.japanese: ごめんね、今(こん)週末(しゅうまつ)は忙(いそが)しくて遊(あそ)べそうもない。
example.english: Sorry, it’s very unlikely that I’ll be able to hang out this weekend because I’m so busy.

example.japanese: このテーブルは重(おも)たいから、一人(ひとり)で運(はこ)べそうもない。
example.english: Since this table is so heavy, it’s very unlikely that I’ll be able to carry it by myself.

example.japanese: あの人(ひと)、僕(ぼく)の意見(いけん)を聞(き)いてくれそうもない。
example.english: It is very unlikely that that person will listen to my opinion.

example.japanese: そんなすごい技(わざ)、僕(ぼく)にはできそうもない。
example.english: It’s very unlikely that I will be able to perform such a cool trick.

synonym.explanation: there is no chance of/no way of・impossible
hardly possible, cannot be, highly unlikely, improbable
there is no way, there is no reason, it is impossible, cannot be

synonym.text: ようがない・ようもない
synonym.explanation: there's no way to, it's impossible to
unlikely to, showing no signs of

antonym.explanation: is not impossible, it doesn't mean that it isn't
Look like, Appear, Seem, Have a feeling that

english_grammar.title: ない事(こと)はない
english_grammar.explanation: is not impossible, it doesn't mean that it isn't
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］+ ことはない(1) ［い］Adjective［ない］+ ことはない(1) ［な］Adjective + ではない(2) + ことはない(1) (1) こともない (2) じゃない
english_grammar.about: ないことはない is an expression that utilizes either the auxiliary verb ない, or the い-Adjective ない, depending on what type of word it is used with. This structure may literally be translated as something similar to 'not (A) is not all there is'. However, the common translations are '(A) is not impossible', or 'it doesn't mean that it isn't (A)'.This expression may be used with the ない form of any verb, い-Adjective, or な-Adjective. Let's have a look at a few examples before exploring the meaning further. 映画(えいが)は見(み)ないことはないが、詳(くわ)しくもない。It's not that I don't watch movies, but I am just not knowledgeable about them at all. ここは危(あぶ)ないことはないけど、気(き)をつけた方(ほう)がいい。It's not that this place isn't safe, but you should be careful. 元気(げんき)ではないことはないけど、すごく元気(げんき)なわけでもない。It doesn't mean that I am not healthy, but it is not the case that I am very fit. By itself, ことはない highlights something that is unneeded, or never happens. This is partly due to the adverbial particle は expressing something as being 'complete'. In this way, 'there is no situation in which (A)', is quite an accurate translation of ことはない. By adding ない to the (A) verb, all ないことはない is doing is simply changing this nuance to 'there is -not- no situation in which (A)', a double negative expressing that (A) is actually possible.Fun Factないことはない often appears with verbs in the potential form. This usually implies a lack of effort, or feelings of half heartedness toward the completion of (A). It is similar to 'it's not like I can't (A)' in English. 納豆(なっとう)は食(た)べられないことはないけど、自分(じぶん)から買(か)って食(た)べようとは思(おも)わない。It's not that I don't like natto, it's just that I don't think I will buy it myself to eat. 歩(ある)いていけないことはないけど、歩(ある)いたら6時間(じかん)ぐらいかかるよ。It's not that you can't walk there, but if you did, it would take about six hours.

example.japanese: スクルージ：「オレはオジサンになったから新(あたら)しいことを全然(ぜんぜん)学(まな)べない。」 ヒューイ：「どんなに歳(とし)を取(と)っても新(あたら)しいことを学(まな)べないことはないよ。」
example.english: Scrooge: "I got old, so I can't learn new things at all." Huey: "No matter how old you get, it is not impossible to learn new things!"

example.japanese: A：「お金(かね)がないから君(きみ)と一緒(いっしょ)に旅行(りょこう)にいけないんだ。」 B：「お金(かね)がなくても旅行(りょこう)にいけないことはないよ。」
example.english: A: "I don't have money so I can't go on a trip with you." B: "It is not impossible to take a trip without any money."

example.japanese: A：「浅(あさ)いからここで泳(およ)ごう！」 B：「浅(あさ)いけど、あぶなくないことはない。」
example.english: A: "It's shallow so let's swim here!" B: "It is shallow, but that doesn’t mean that it isn’t dangerous."

example.japanese: 吉田(よしだ):「 あなたは誕生日(たんじょうび)ケーキをカットしてみたい？」山田(やまだ):「 僕(ぼく)にもできないことはないけど、君(きみ)がやった方(ほう)がいいと思う。」
example.english: Yoshida: "Do you want to cut the birthday cake?"Yamada: "It's not that I can't do it, but I think it would be better if you did it."

example.japanese: 清水(しみず):「昨年(さくねん)買(か)ったドレスを着(き)たら、どう？」木村(きむら):「着(き)れないことはないが、少(すこ)しサイズが小(ちい)さいな。」
example.english: Shimizu: "What about wearing the dress you bought last year?"Kimura: "It's not that I can't wear it, but it's a bit too small…"

english_grammar.title: なんて
english_grammar.explanation: such as, things like, emphasis
english_grammar.structure: Verb + なんて ［い］Adjective + なんて ［な］Adjective + なんて Noun + なんて(1) (1) なんか
english_grammar.attention: Notice that なんか generally follows nouns
english_grammar.about: なんか is an expression in Japanese that is frequently associated with the adverbial particle など. They are thought to have overlapping meanings in many circumstances, and なんか itself may be considered an adverbial particle. なんて is an extension of this, and may be considered an abbreviation of などという 'to say something like'.Both なんか and なんて are used in the same way as など, having translations like 'such as', and 'things like' in English. The primary difference between なんか and なんて is that なんて is far more common after 用言(ようげん) (conjugatable words). This includes verbs, い-Adjectives, and な-Adjectives. On the other hand, なんか is almost exclusively used after 体言(たいげん) (unconjugatable words). In other words, nouns. こんな嵐(あらし)の中(なか)走(はし)るなんて、頭(あたま)おかしいんじゃない。You are going to do something like run in the storm? You must be crazy. 北海道(ほっかいどう)がこんなに寒(さむ)いなんておもわなかった。I didn't think Hokkaido would be this cold or anything. 心配(しんぱい)なんてしている場合(ばあい)じゃない。This is no time for things such as worrying. テレビなんか叩(たた)けばだいたい直(なお)るだろ。Things like TV's will be fixed most of the time if you hit them, right? Despite the 体言(たいげん) and 用言(ようげん) tendency, most native speakers will not consider it incorrect to use either なんか or なんて with any type of word.Fun FactBoth なんか and なんて are often used to show a low evaluation of the word that they follow. This can come across as humility when used in relation to oneself, or as an insult when used in relation to others. 私(わたし)なんか5年間(ねんかん)スペイン語(ご)の勉強(べんきょう)をしているのにまだ全然(ぜんぜん)会話(かいわ)ができないです。 (Humility)I have studied Spanish for 5 years, but I can't speak it at all yet. お前(まえ)なんてどうせ、家(いえ)でゴロゴロしているだけだろ。 (Insult)Someone like you probably just loafs around the house, don't you? Don't let this point stop you from using なんか or なんて though, as many native speakers use it simply to fill the silence in modern Japanese. 酷(ひど)いことを言(い)ったのは分(わ)かるんだけど、なんか、情熱的(じょうねつてき)になって言(い)っちゃった。I am aware that I said something mean, but, you know, I said it because I got emotional.

example.japanese: あの強(つよ)いチームに勝(か)つなんて思(おも)わなかった。
example.english: Things like winning against that good team didn't even cross my mind.

example.japanese: 紹介(しょうかい)なんていりません。自分(じぶん)で恋人(こいびと)を見(み)つけます。
example.english: I don't need things like referrals. I can find my own lover.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)が太(ふと)っているなんて言(い)わないで。
example.english: Don't say things like I am fat.

example.japanese: 嘘(うそ)なんかつかないよ。信(しん)じてよ。
example.english: I would never do something like lie to you. Trust me.

example.japanese: 雨(あめ)なんかに負(ま)けている場合(ばあい)じゃないですよ。
example.english: Now is not the time to give in to something like rain.

english_grammar.title: 又(また)〜も
english_grammar.explanation: moreover, additionally, and also, in addition, furthermore, or
english_grammar.structure: Phrase、また + Noun +（も） Phrase。また + Noun +（も）
english_grammar.attention: また + ても・でも adds more emphasis
english_grammar.about: 又(また)～も is a combination of the adverb 又(また), a noun, and the adverbial particle も. It can be translated as 'moreover', 'additionally', or 'furthermore'. As も is being used, whatever is being said in (B) will usually be new information.To use 又(また)～も, an (A) phrase will be stated, before 又(また) will open the (B) phrase, and then be followed by a noun + も. このキーボードはピアノの音(おと)が出(だ)せる。また、ギターの音(おと)も出(だ)せる。This keyboard can make piano sounds. Additionally, it can produce guitar sounds. この電子(でんし)レンジはオーブンとして使(つか)えて、またトースターとしても使(つか)える。This microwave can be used as an oven, additionally, it can be used as a toaster. Instead of も, でも or ても may be used for extra emphasis. ササキ先生(せんせい)は理科(りか)の先生(せんせい)です。また、地理(ちり)の先生(せんせい)でもある。Sasaki-sensei is a science teacher. She is also a geography teacher. 私達(わたしたち)は何(なん)でも買(か)います。また、古(ふる)くても買(か)い取(と)ります。We will buy anything. Moreover, we will buy it even if it's old. Fun FactThe kanji 又(また) and 叉(また) share an interesting relationship. 又(また) is used to refer to things that reach a point of separation, but then fold back on themselves (being translated as 'again', or 'in addition'). On the other hand, 叉(また) refers to things that reach a point of separation, and then split (being translated as 'a fork in the road', or 'crotch').

example.japanese: 「から」は理由(りゆう)や原因(げんいん)を表(あらわ)す。また、「スマホの画面(がめん)はガラスからできている。」のように何(なに)かの起源(きげん)やソースも表(あらわ)すことがある。
example.english: "から" indicates reason or cause. Additionally, there are also times when it indicates an origin or source of something like "Smartphone screens are made from glass.".

example.japanese: 犬(いぬ)はイヌ科(か)である。また、狐(きつね)もイヌ科(か)である。
example.english: Dogs are canidae. Additionally foxes are also canidae.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は有名(ゆうめい)な歌手(かしゅ)であり、また、腕(うで)のいい外科医(げかい)でもある。
example.english: He is a famous singer, additionally, he is also a skilled surgeon.

example.japanese: このおもちゃは１０～１５歳(さい)のお子様(こさま)向(む)けです。また、６歳(さい)以上(いじょう)のお子様(こさま)なら保護者(ほごしゃ)同伴(どうはん)でご使用(しよう)いただけます。
example.english: This toy is suitable for children between the ages of 10 and 15. Additionally, it can also be used by children over six, under the supervision of the guardian.

example.japanese: 最近(さいきん)のスマートフォンはポータブルコンピュータとして使(つか)えるし、また、コンパスなどの機能(きのう)もある。
example.english: Modern smartphones can be used as portable computers, furthermore, they also have functions like compass, etc.

synonym.explanation: moreover, furthermore

english_grammar.title: 序(つい)でに
english_grammar.explanation: while you are at it, on the occasion
english_grammar.structure: Verb + ついでに Noun + の + ついでに Phrase。ついでに + Phrase
english_grammar.about: 序(ついで)に is an adverb in Japanese that is used in a similar way to 'while you're at it', or 'on the occasion of (A)' in English. 序(ついで) itself is a noun that means 'precedence' (in terms of being the first thing to happen). Due to this, the literal meaning of 序(ついで)に may be thought of as 'with (A) as the precedence, (B)'.序(ついで)に is commonly used with verbs, or nouns. In the case of nouns, it will need to be preceded by the case marking particle の. 買(か)い物(もの)に行(い)くついでに、郵便局(ゆうびんきょく)に行(い)ってこの荷物(にもつ)を出(だ)しておいてくれる？Can you bring these packages to the post office while you go shopping? 散歩(さんぽ)のついでに寄(よ)って行(い)ってください。Please come visit while you are on a walk. お母(かあ)さんの所(ところ)にテレビを返(かえ)しに行(い)くのでしょう？序(ついで)にこの、私(わたし)が作(つく)った梅酒(うめしゅ)を持(も)って行(い)って。You are going to go to your mothers place to give back the TV you borrowed, right? While you're at it, can you take the Umeshu I made? Fun FactJust like 'precedence' in English, 序(ついで)に implies that (A) is the instigator for (B). Because of this, 序(ついで)に is a good way to convey that something is not urgent, but, if (A) is happening, it is the perfect chance to do (B) as well.Caution 序(ついで)に is more formal than 間(あいだ)に or 時(とき)に, so has more of a tendency to be used for 'one-off' things, rather than regular occurrences. Despite this, it still may be used to describe regular occurrences at times, especially when speaking formally or politely, such as to a senpai. 友達(ともだち)を家(うち)に送(おく)ったついでに、床屋(とこや)に行(い)った。 On the way back from driving my friend home, I went to the barber. (One-off occurrence) 旦那(だんな)はいつも、私(わたし)が寝(ね)てる間(あいだ)に帰(かえ)ってくる。 My husband always comes back while I am sleeping. (Regular occurrence) 私(わたし)は晴(は)れているときに出(で)かける。 I go out when it is sunny. (Regular occurrence)

example.japanese: 東京(とうきょう)に行(い)ったついでに、ディズニーランドへ行(い)った。
example.english: While I was in Tokyo, I went to Disneyland.

example.japanese: 散歩(さんぽ)のついでに、郵便局(ゆうびんきょく)に寄(よ)って切手(きって)を買(か)いました。
example.english: While taking a walk, I stopped by the post office and bought stamps.

example.japanese: 毎日(まいにち)仕事(しごと)から帰(かえ)るついでに、コンビニでコーヒーを買(か)う。
example.english: While coming home from work, I always get a coffee at the convenience store.

example.japanese: ついでに君(きみ)の車(くるま)も洗(あら)ってあげようか？
example.english: While I am at it, do you want me to wash your car too?

example.japanese: お風呂(ふろ)に入(はい)るついでに、お風呂(ふろ)掃除(そうじ)もしてしまおう。
example.english: While I am in the bath, I will clean it.

english_grammar.title: と共(とも)に
english_grammar.explanation: together with, at the same time, as well as
english_grammar.structure: Verb + と共に ［い］Adjective + と共に ［な］Adjective + である + と共に Noun + と共に
english_grammar.about: 共(とも) is a noun in Japanese that is frequently used as a either a prefix, or a suffix. In the case of と共(とも)に, it is used in conjunction with the case marking particle と as an adverb. と共(とも)に expresses that (A) will happen 'together with (B)', or 'at the same time as (B)'.と共(とも)に may be used after verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives or nouns. With な-Adjectives, it will sometimes be preceded by である. 風(かぜ)が強(つよ)くなると共(とも)に雨(あめ)が降(ふ)ってきます。As the wind gets strong, it will start to rain. あの先生(せんせい)は厳(きび)しいが、厳(きび)しいと共(とも)に優(やさ)しい。That teacher is strict, but as strict as he is, he is also very kind. 僕(ぼく)が住(す)んでいる場所(ばしょ)は静(しず)かであると共(とも)に、空気(くうき)が綺麗(きれい)だ。The place I live is very quiet, together with the air being clean. 私(わたし)と共(とも)に人生(じんせい)を歩(あゆ)んでくれませんか。Would you please walk together with me forever. (歩(あゆ)む is a poetic way of saying 'to walk' that often means 'to travel a passage') Fun Factと共(とも)に is a structure that is used when two things are 'existing' in the same way. This means that it may be used to show mutual actions, or that it may be used to show mutual qualities (states of existence). Because of this nuance 'to be mutually (A)' is one of the closest literal translations of と共(とも)に. (A) may be an action, an adjective, or even a noun! 年(とし)を取(と)ると共(とも)に、身体(からだ)がどんどん硬(かた)くなってきた。As I get older, I am starting to get less flexible. この池(いけ)は綺麗(きれい)であると共(とも)に、危険(きけん)である。This lake is beautiful and dangerous at the same time.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)と共(とも)に論文(ろんぶん)の発表(はっぴょう)をしてくれませんか。
example.english: Would you mind presenting the paper with me?

example.japanese: 息子(むすこ)が日本(にほん)に住(す)んでいるので、寂(さび)しいと共(とも)に、誇(ほこ)りもあります。
example.english: Since my son lives in Japan, I feel sad but also proud.

example.japanese: 年(とし)を取(と)ると共(とも)に、体(からだ)が動(うご)きにくくなる一方(いっぽう)だ。
example.english: As we grow older, it becomes more and more difficult to move our bodies.

example.japanese: そのシリーズ本(ぽん)は怪奇(かいき)であると共(とも)に、恐(おそ)ろしいと考(かんが)えられている。
example.english: This book series is considered mysterious, as well as terrifying.

example.japanese: 夜明(よあ)けと共(とも)に旅立(たびだ)った。
example.english: (I) departed with the break of dawn.

english_grammar.title: に連(つ)れて
english_grammar.explanation: as…then, in proportion to, (along) with
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ につれ（て） Noun + につれ（て）
english_grammar.about: につれて, or に連(つ)れて when using kanji, is an expression that may be translated as 'as (A), then (B)', or 'in proportion to (A), (B)'. It is formed through the use of the case marking particle に, the る - Verb 連(つ)れる 'to take along', and the conjunction particle て. Literally, the translation is similar to 'being taken along with (A), (B)', or 'in tow with (A), (B)'.につれて will be used after the plain, non-past form of verbs, or nouns. 毎日(まいにち)運転(うんてん)をするにつれて、どんどん運転(うんてん)が嫌(きら)いになってきた。Along with driving everyday, I am starting to dislike it more and more. 夏(なつ)になるにつれて、日(ひ)が昇(のぼ)るのが早(はや)くなってきた。Along with it becoming summer, the time the sun comes up is getting earlier. 犬(いぬ)の成長(せいちょう)につれて、食欲(しょくよく)が変(か)わる。As the dog grows, how much he eats changes. 時代(じだい)の変化(へんか)につれて、食文化(しょくぶんか)も変(か)わる。As the times change, food culture also changes. As 連(つ)れる is a transitive verb, (A) につれて (B) implies that (A) is causing (B) to happen simultaneously. This does not have to be something that (A) is purposely doing (although it may be), just a 'domino' type effect, where (A) is considered the instigator. 冬(ふゆ)になるにつれて、太陽(たいよう)が沈(しず)む時間(じかん)が早(はや)くなる。Along with it becoming winter, the time the sun sets gets earlier. (Natural, as winter directly affects the time the sun sets) 冬(ふゆ)になるにつれて、犬(いぬ)が成長(せいちょう)していく。In tow with it becoming winter, the dog grows more. (Unnatural, as there is no relationship)

example.japanese: こちらの木(き)が大(おお)きくなるにつれて、影(かげ)が広(ひろ)がる。
example.english: As these trees grow tall, their shade spreads.

example.japanese: 子供(こども)の成長(せいちょう)につれて、性格(せいかく)が変(か)わる。
example.english: Along with their growth, the personality of children changes.

example.japanese: 結婚式(けっこんしき)を挙(あ)げる日(ひ)が近(ちか)づくにつれて、色々(いろいろ)と不安(ふあん)になってきた。
example.english: With our wedding day drawing nearer, I am starting to feel anxious about various things.

example.japanese: 日(ひ)がたつにつれて、怪我(けが)が悪化(あっか)してきた。
example.english: As the days go by, my injury gets worse and worse.

example.japanese: 進(すす)むにつれて道(みち)がどんどん狭(せま)くなるから心配(しんぱい)になってきた。
example.english: As I continued on, the road grew increasingly more narrow, so I started to feel anxious.

english_grammar.title: 直(ただ)ちに
english_grammar.explanation: At once, Immediately, As soon as
english_grammar.structure: 直ちに + Phrase
english_grammar.about: The adverb 直(ただ)ちに is commonly used in Japanese to convey that something is happening 'immediately', or 'at once'. Like many adverbs, it will regularly appear at the beginning of a sentence. 直(ただ)ちに避難所(ひなんじょ)へ向(む)かってください。Please head to the evacuation point immediately. この山(やま)から、 直(ただ)ちに出(で)て行(い)ってください。ここは私有地(しゆうち)です。Please leave this mountain at once. This is private property. 地震(じしん)が起(お)きたら 直(ただ)ちに家(いえ)を出(で)てください。If an earthquake occurs, please leave the house immediately. Fun FactComing from the kanji 直(じき), meaning 'direct', 直(ただ)ちに often carries the nuance that something is done 'directly' (and purposely). This is usually after something happens, or after something is completed. To indicate things that happen immediately, but not intentionally, 忽(たちま)ち may be used. 計画(けいかく)が変(か)わったら、 直(ただ)ちに報告(ほうこく)してください。 (Intentional)If the plan changes, please notify me immediately. このファッションは忽(たちま)ち世界(せかい)で広(ひろ)まった。 (Unintentional)This fashion spread around the world immediately.

example.japanese: 効果(こうか)は直(ただ)ちに現(あらわ)れるわけではありません。
example.english: The effect will not become immediately apparent.

example.japanese: 直(ただ)ちに安定(あんてい)した仕事(しごと)を見(み)つけなければ。
example.english: I must find a stable job at once.

example.japanese: 締(し)め切(き)りが迫(せま)っているので、直(ただ)ちに印刷(いんさつ)してください。
example.english: The deadline is swiftly approaching. Please print it at once.

example.japanese: 直(ただ)ちに車(くるま)を移動(いどう)させてください。そこは駐車(ちゅうしゃ)禁止(きんし)です。
example.english: Please move your car immediately. This is a no parking zone.

example.japanese: 判決(はんけつ)は直(ただ)ちには出(で)ません。裁判(さいばん)は何年(なんねん)もかかるかもしれません。
example.english: The judgement won’t be given immediately . The trial might take several years.

english_grammar.title: た途端(とたん)に
english_grammar.explanation: the instant・moment, as soon as, just as
english_grammar.structure: Verb［た］+ とたん(に)
english_grammar.attention: Cannot be used after Nouns or Adjectives
english_grammar.about: たとたんに, frequently seen using its kanji form た途端(とたん)に is a structure used to convey that something happens 'the instant', or 'the moment' that something else occurs. It is a combination of the auxiliary verb た (indicating the completion of a verb), and the noun 途端(とたん) 'on the tip of' used adverbially (with に).(A) た途端(とたん)に (B) is used to express (B) things that are beyond the control of the speaker, and may be considered strange, or unexpected. 高速(こうそく)に乗(の)った途端(とたん)に、タイヤがパンクした。The moment I got on the highway, my tire got punctured. 布団(ふとん)に入(はい)った途端(とたん)に先輩(せんぱい)から電話(でんわ)がかかってきた。The moment I got into my futon, I received a call from my senpai. As 途端(とたん) literally means 'on the tip of', any (B) action is considered to happen either directly upon (A), or even simultaneously with (A).

example.japanese: 出(で)たとたんに、雨(あめ)が降(ふ)り始(はじ)めた。
example.english: The instant I went outside, it began to rain.

example.japanese: 窓(まど)を開(あ)けたとたん、鳥(とり)が部屋(へや)の中(なか)に入(はい)ってきた。
example.english: As soon as I opened the window, a bird flew into the room.

example.japanese: 帰(かえ)ろうとしたとたん、仕事(しごと)を頼(たの)まれた。
example.english: Just as I was about to leave, I was given more work to do.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)は随分(ずいぶん)大人(おとな)になっていたが、見(み)たとたんあの子(こ)だと分(わ)かった。
example.english: She had grown up a lot, but I knew that child was her the moment I saw her.

example.japanese: 青(あお)になったとたんに飛(と)び出(だ)すのは危(あぶ)ないよ。
example.english: It's dangerous to speed off the instant (the traffic light) turns green.

english_grammar.title: 置(お)きに
english_grammar.explanation: repeated at intervals, every other, every, at intervals of
english_grammar.structure: Number + Counter + おきに
english_grammar.about: While 置(お)きに may appear to be an adverb, it is actually a combination of 置(お)き, a suffix meaning 'opening', and the case marking particle に. 置(お)きに (often without kanji) is an expression used to show that something happens 'every (A)', or 'at intervals of (A)'.As おきに is technically a suffix, it will be attached to the end of numbers or counters that it is highlighting as being an 'opening'. この薬(くすり)は一日(いちにち)おきに飲(の)んでください。Please drink this medicine every other day. (Every second day) 一(い)か月(げつ)おきに病院(びょういん)に来(く)るように先生(せんせい)に言(い)われました。I was told by the doctor to come to the hospital every other month. (Every second month) 二日(ふつか)おきに部屋(へや)の掃除(そうじ)をしないと気(き)が落(お)ち着(つ)かない。I can't relax if I don't clean my room every two days. Caution It is very common to get ごとに, and おきに mixed up. While ごとに has the literal meaning of 'every', おきに has the literal meaning of 'opening'. Due to this, おきに will not always mean 'every'. Let's look at some examples of when these two expressions are the same, and when they are not.Discrete variables (things that are usually measured upon completion) - Only ごとに may be used to express 'every'. For example, a day, a week, or a month may easily be divided, but they are usually counted as whole units. Due to this, ごとに will mean 'every week', while おきに would actually mean 'every second week' (because there is an opening of one week). 一日(いちにち)おきに目薬(めぐすり)を差(さ)す。I use my eye drops every other day. 私(わたし)は出(で)かけるおきに、忘(わす)れ物(もの)をする。Every other time I go out, I forget something. Continuous variables (things that are usually measured in fractions) - Either ごとに or おきに may be used. For example, seconds, minutes, and hours are usually measured by fractions, especially considering sports and racing. In this case ごとに will mean 'every second', while おきに will mean 'every opening of one second' (disregarding all of the milliseconds, this means every second). 毎日(まいにち)2時間(じかん)ごとに体(からだ)を動(うご)かしている。I move my body every 2 hours, everyday. 毎日(まいにち)2時間(じかん)おきに体(からだ)を動(うご)かしている。I move my body every other 2 hours, everyday. Fun FactThis is a topic that native speakers frequently get wrong themselves, so don't worry if it is a bit tricky! If you are unsure about which one to use, think of 置(お)きに as 'every other' for most purposes.

example.japanese: 1時間(じかん)おきに温度(おんど)を測(はか)ってください。
example.english: Please check the temperature every other hour.

example.japanese: 1週間(しゅうかん)おきに、水槽(すいそう)の水(みず)を換(か)えています。
example.english: We change the water of the fish tank every other week.

example.japanese: 30分(ぷん)おきに休憩(きゅうけい)しよう。
example.english: Let's take a break in intervals of 30 minutes.

example.japanese: 金魚(きんぎょ)には餌(えさ)を一日(いちにち)おきにやればいいらしい。
example.english: I’ve heard that you can feed goldfish every second day.

example.japanese: この地域(ちいき)はだいたい一軒(いっけん)おきに新聞(しんぶん)をとっている。
example.english: In this area, every other house is subscribed to the newspaper.

synonym.explanation: Times (in each time period), Every, Frequency of

whenever, every time something happens

english_grammar.title: 度(たび)に
english_grammar.explanation: each time, every time, whenever
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ たびに Noun + の + たびに
english_grammar.about: 度(たび)に is the adverbial form of the noun 度(たび), meaning 'time' (as in 'at the time of'). たびに is frequently paired with either verbs, or nouns, in order to show that something happens 'whenever (A)', or 'each time (A)'.After nouns, the case marking particle の will be required before たびに. タナカ君(くん)と飲(の)みに行(い)くたびに、二日(ふつか)酔(よ)いになる。Every time I go out to drink with Tanaka-kun, I get a hangover. 牛乳(ぎゅうにゅう)を飲(の)むたびにお腹(なか)が痛(いた)くなる。Every time I drink milk, I get a stomach ache. 私(わたし)は休(やす)みのたびにハワイへ行(い)きます。Whenever I have a holiday, I go to Hawaii. 彼(かれ)は洗(あら)い物(もの)のたびに指(ゆび)を切(き)る。Every time he does the dishes, he cuts his finger. Fun FactLike ごとに, たびに means 'every'. However, たびに is most often used to convey the nuance of するごとに 'every time doing'. Due to this, たびに will almost always be used to highlight some kind of action or event, rather than random amounts of time. 仕事(しごと)を休(やす)むたびに、雨(あめ)が降(ふ)って予定(よてい)が台無(だいな)しになる。 Every time I take a day off, it rains and messes up my plans. 2週間(しゅうかん)たびに、実家(じっか)に帰(かえ)る。Every two weeks, I go to my parents house.

example.japanese: この映画(えいが)を見(み)るたびに、泣(な)いてしまう。
example.english: Every time I watch this movie, I cry.

example.japanese: 旅行(りょこう)のたびに、いい思(おも)い出(で)を作(つく)ろう。
example.english: Let's make good memories each time we take a trip.

example.japanese: 買(か)い物(もの)へ行(い)くたびに、いらないものを買(か)っちゃう。
example.english: Whenever I go shopping I buy things I don't need.

example.japanese: 何(なに)かが起(お)こるたびに呼(よ)び出(だ)されて大変(たいへん)です。
example.english: I am called in every time something happens, and it is driving me nuts.

example.japanese: 検査(けんさ)のたびに何(なに)か病気(びょうき)が見(み)つかるのは年(とし)のせいかな。
example.english: Every time I get a medical check up, some kind of illness is discovered. I wonder if it has to do with my age.

synonym.explanation: Almost every ~, Nearly every ~, On a ~ basis
Each, Every, At intervals of
repeated at intervals, every other, every, at intervals of
whenever, every time something happens

english_grammar.title: 或(あ)るいは
english_grammar.explanation: or ・ possibly・maybe・perhaps・or possibly
english_grammar.structure: Verb + か + あるいは ［い］Adjective + か + あるいは ［な］Adjective + か + あるいは Noun + （か） + あるいは あるいは + Phrase + かもしれない
english_grammar.about: あるいは is a construction in Japanese that is used as a 接続語(せつぞくご) (conjunction). It usually appears after statements that have been marked with the adverbial particle か. あるいは may be loosely translated as 'possibly', 'maybe, or 'or'. 運動(うんどう)をさせるかあるいは餌(えさ)を減(へ)らしてください。Please make them exercise or possibly lessen the amount of food. パソコンの動作(どうさ)が遅(おそ)いかあるいは電源(でんげん)が点(つ)かなくなった場合(ばあい)は、私達(わたしたち)が直(なお)します。In the event that the computer gets slow or doesn't turn on, we will fix it. 有名(ゆうめい)かあるいは綺麗(きれい)であれば誰(だれ)でも入(はい)れるらしい。I heard that if you are famous or maybe beautiful, anyone can get in. 土曜日(どようび)かあるいは日曜日(にちようび)までには終(お)わらせておきます。I will try to have it finished by either Saturday or possibly Sunday. Although usually being treated as a single word, あるいは is actually a combination of the attributive form of 或(あ)る, a verb meaning 'a certain', the suffix character い (used for making い-Adjectives), and the adverbial particle は. Due to this, the literal meaning of あるいは is just 'another possibility', as it highlights a certain something existing within the same area/category as (A). 牛乳(ぎゅうにゅう)あるいはチーズが使(つか)われている料理(りょうり)は食(た)べられません。I can't eat anything that uses milk, or another possibility is cheese. 月曜日(げつようび)あるいは火曜日(かようび)に新(あたら)しい生徒(せいと)が来(き)ます。A new student will come on either Monday, or another possibility is Tuesday.

example.japanese: 月曜日(げつようび)あるいは火曜日(かようび)であれば、参加(さんか)できます。
example.english: If it is Monday or Tuesday, I can attend.

example.japanese: 植物(しょくぶつ)あるいは昆虫(こんちゅう)を観察(かんさつ)しましょう。
example.english: Let's observe some plants or bugs.

example.japanese: 晴(は)れあるいは曇(くも)りであれば、お祭(まつ)りに行(い)きましょう。
example.english: Whether it is sunny or cloudy, let's go to the festival.

example.japanese: 今年(ことし)あるいは来年(らいねん)には、そちらに行(い)けるかと思(おも)います。
example.english: I think I will be able to go there this year or next year.

example.japanese: 動画(どうが)あるいは写真(しゃしん)でもいいので送(おく)ってください。
example.english: Please send me video or pictures, anything is ok.

synonym.explanation: Or
perhaps, maybe, possibly

english_grammar.title: ながらも
english_grammar.explanation: but, even while, even though, despite, although
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ ながら(も) ［い］Adjective + ながら(も) ［な］Adjective + ながら(も) Noun + ながら(も)
english_grammar.attention: Unlikeながら、ながら(も) is preceded only by verbs that express state
english_grammar.about: ながらも is a combination of the conjunction particle ながら, and the adverbial particle も. Coming from the kanji 乍(なが)ら, with the meaning of 'while', ながら almost always keeps this nuance. Because of this, ながらも can be translated as 'even while (A), (B)', or 'although (A), also (B)'. ながらも usually expresses surprise at the coexistence of (A) and (B), and may be used after い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives, nouns, or the conjunctive form of verbs. 才能(さいのう)を持(も)ちながらも、彼(かれ)は色々(いろいろ)と努力(どりょく)した。Although he is talented, he worked hard in many aspects. 彼女(かのじょ)は悲(かな)しみながらも、笑顔(えがお)で友達(ともだち)に話(はな)しました。Even while she was upset, she talked with her friends with a smile on her face. 彼(かれ)はカレーが嫌(きら)いながらも、我慢(がまん)して間食(かんしょく)しました。Although he does not like curry, he gritted his teeth and ate the whole thing. 私達(わたしたち)は貧乏(びんぼう)ながらも、仲(なか)がいい。Although we are broke, we have a good relationship. ながらも is used to highlight a thing that comes after the existing state of (A) 'そのままで後(あと)に続(つづ)く事(こと)'. Due to this, ながらも may only be used with verbs that highlight states of existence (like feelings), rather than ongoing actions. 「こんなことしちゃだめだ」と思(おも)いながらもやってしまった。 (Action)Even while I thought to myself, 'I shouldn't do something like this,' I did it. 緊張(きんちょう)しながらも、初(はじ)めての舞台(ぶたい)で歌(うた)えた。 (Feeling)Although I was nervous, I was able to sing at my first concert.

example.japanese: お金(かね)を沢山(たくさん)持(も)ちながらも、彼(かれ)は幸(しあわ)せではないらしい。
example.english: Despite having a lot of money, I heard that he isn't happy.

example.japanese: 文法(ぶんぽう)の勉強(べんきょう)をしなければいけないと知(し)っていながらも、遊(あそ)んでしまう。
example.english: Despite knowing that I have to study grammar, I still unfortunately goof off.

example.japanese: 緊張(きんちょう)しながらも、300人(にん)の前(まえ)で発表(はっぴょう)をした。
example.english: Despite being nervous, I gave a presentation in front of 300 people.

example.japanese: 「やらなきゃいけない」と思(おも)いながらもダラダラしてしまう。
example.english: Despite thinking "I have to do it", I just end up idling around.

example.japanese: 微力(びりょく)ながらも、協力(きょうりょく)させていただきます。
example.english: Although I can’t do much, let me help you.

Despite, Although, Even though

english_grammar.title: に於(お)いて
english_grammar.explanation: in・on・at, regarding, in terms of
english_grammar.structure: Noun + において Noun + における (1) + Noun (1) においての
english_grammar.attention: に於いて・に於て・に於ける are all correct forms.Why におく and においた are not used to modify nouns.
english_grammar.about: において is a combination of the case marking particle に in, and the 接続語(せつぞくご) (conjunction) おいて. Either 於(お)いて, or 於(お)ける may be used, with no difference in meaning. において itself is usually translated as 'at', 'in', 'on', or 'regarding'.において (or における) will be used after nouns, or when connecting one noun to another. In the case of connecting one noun to another, における, or においての will be required. 現代(げんだい)において、インターネットなしの生活(せいかつ)は考(かんが)えられない。In this day and age, it is impossible to think of a life without the internet. 自分(じぶん)の住(す)んでいる地域(ちいき)における、井戸(いど)水(みず)の汚染(おせん)について研究(けんきゅう)をしている。I am doing research regarding pollution in wells in the area that I am living in. これはこの工事(こうじ)においての難(むずか)しい作業(さぎょう)になります。This is the most difficult work in terms of this construction. 田舎(いなか)における高齢化(こうれいか)の問題(もんだい)は深刻(しんこく)です。The aging population in the countryside is very serious. においての (and における) are primarily used in formal language, and will not commonly be used in daily speech.Fun Fact於(ああ) is quite an interesting kanji, and has a meaning similar to 'within the scope of'. Basically, it highlights all possible things that exist within a given topic/space. This is what enables the very broad range of meanings that においての and における may be used for. 日本(にほん)においての、電車(でんしゃ)やバスなしの生活(せいかつ)は考(かんが)えられない。Within the scope of Japan, it is impossible to think of a life without buses or trains. 会社(かいしゃ)においての、パワハラについてのミーティングが行(おこな)われた。A meeting was held regarding power harassment within the scope of our company.

example.japanese: 現代(げんだい)において、電気(でんき)のない生活(せいかつ)は考(かんが)えられない。
example.english: In this day and age, it is impossible to think of life without electricity.

example.japanese: 東京(とうきょう)における環境(かんきょう)についての会議(かいぎ)を行(おこな)います。
example.english: A meeting concerning the environment will take place in Tokyo.

example.japanese: アクメ・コーポレーションの商品(しょうひん)は価格(かかく)においては一流(いちりゅう)だが、品質(ひんしつ)においては三流(さんりゅう)だ。
example.english: Acme Corporation products are top grade in terms of price, but poor in terms of product quality.

example.japanese: 日常(にちじょう)生活(せいかつ)において、必要(ひつよう)なものはすべてそろっています。
example.english: In daily life, I have gathered everything necessary.

example.japanese: この文脈(ぶんみゃく)においての「空」は、「そら」ではなく「から」だと思(おも)う。
example.english: I think this kanji is read 'kara' rather than 'sora' in this context.

concerning, about, regarding

At, In

english_grammar.title: 第一(だいいち)
english_grammar.explanation: start, first (point), foremost, to begin with
english_grammar.structure: 第一に + Phrase 第一 + の + Noun だいいっ + Noun (Chapter) Phrase + 第一 + だ
english_grammar.attention: Be careful when combining 第一 with chapter or section numbers (see Structure)
english_grammar.about: 第一(だいいち) is an expression in Japanese which may be used either as an adverb, or as a noun. As a noun, it will carry the meaning of 'foremost', or 'most important'. As an adverb, it can mean 'first', or 'above anything'.To use 第一(だいいち) adverbially, pair it with に. As a noun, it will usually be followed by の (when connecting nouns), or by the auxiliary verb だ, when at the end of a sentence. 第一(だいいち)に彼(かれ)は何(なん)であんな時間(じかん)にここにいたんだ。First of all, why was he here at that time? これはここの第一(だいいち)のルールだ。This is the number one rule here. お金(かね)よりも健康(けんこう)でいることが第一(だいいち)だ。More than money, being healthy is the most important thing. Occasionally, まず 'first of all' will be paired with 第一(だいいち). This may seem redundant, but is like saying 'the very first' in English. まず第一(だいいち)にこの計画(けいかく)を担当(たんとう)する人(ひと)を決(き)めましょう。Firstly, let's pick the person that will be in charge of this plan. Fun Fact第(だい) is a kanji that is often translated as 'number'. However, the literal meaning is a bit closer to 'position', as it refers to the place that something has within a sequence of numbers. As such, 第一(だいいち) simply means '1st position'.

example.japanese: 安全(あんぜん)は第一(だいいち)だ。
example.english: Safety first.

example.japanese: 筋肉(きんにく)をつけたい場合(ばあい)は筋力(きんりょく)のトレーニングではなくてダイエットを第一(だいいち)にするべきだ。
example.english: If you want to gain muscle, rather than training you should prioritize your diet.

example.japanese: 第一(だいいっ)節(せつ)第一(だいいっ)款(かん)検察官(けんさつかん)の義務(ぎむ)等(など)。
example.english: Section 1, Subsection 1, Duties of public prosecutor, etc.

example.japanese: ハグ・クラブルールの第一(だいいち)、ハグ・クラブのことを明(あ)かすな。
example.english: The first rule of Hug Club is: you do not talk about Hug Club.

example.japanese: 調査(ちょうさ)によると事故(じこ)が起(お)こったまず第一(だいいち)の原因(げんいん)はヒューマンエラーということだ。
example.english: According to the investigation, the foremost reason for accidents is human error.

english_grammar.title: 益々(ますます)
english_grammar.explanation: increasingly,more and more,decreasingly,less and less, keep -ing
english_grammar.structure: ますます + Phrase
english_grammar.about: When using the adverb ますます, it will have the meaning of 'increasingly', 'more and more', or even 'to keep (A)ing'. It is used to emphasize continuous trends, and will regularly be seen at the beginning of a sentence. 良(い)いにおいだね。この匂(にお)いを嗅(か)いでるとますますお腹(なか)が空(す)いてくる。That smells good, doesn't it? I am going to get more and more hungry if I keep smelling it. 彼女(かのじょ)はますます友達(ともだち)を失(うしな)っていっている。She is losing more and more of her friends. 年(とし)を取(と)るにつれて、益々(ますます)目(め)が悪(わる)くなっていくよ。As I get older, my eyes are getting worse. Occasionally, the kanji form 益々(ますます) will be used. This will not change the nuance at all. The kanji 益(えき) simply means 'gain'.Fun FactDespite sometimes being seen as 益々(ますます), this expression originally comes from the stacking of 増(ま)す, a う - Verb meaning 'to increase'. Due to this, ますます is most often used to highlight verbs that indicate some sort of change, or with adjectives that can increase in intensity. 毎日(まいにち)日本語(にほんご)の勉強(べんきょう)をしているので、ますます日本語(にほんご)が話(はな)せるようになってきた。Because I am studying Japanese everyday, I am able to speak more and more. 冬(ふゆ)になってから、ますます涼(すず)しくなった。Since becoming winter, it has become more and more brisk. Caution ますます is sometimes translated as 'less and less', but this situation is still actually considered as 'increasing' (increasingly negative). 仕事(しごと)が忙(いそが)しくて、ますます子供(こども)と過(す)ごす時間(じかん)が減(へ)っていく。Because work is so busy, I have less and less time to spend with my children. コロナのせいで観光客(かんこうきゃく)がますます減(へ)って行(い)く。Because of Covid, the number of tourists becoming less and less.

example.japanese: 水(みず)不足(ぶそく)がますます深刻(しんこく)になってきている。
example.english: The water shortage is growing more and more severe.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はますます信用(しんよう)を失(うしな)っている。
example.english: He is losing more and more faith.

example.japanese: 時間(じかん)が経(た)つと共(とも)に、ますます頭痛(ずつう)がひどくなってきた。
example.english: As time goes on, my headache gets worse and worse.

example.japanese: 益々(ますます)寒(さむ)さが厳(きび)しくなってまいりました。
example.english: It's growing increasingly colder.

example.japanese: 父(ちち)は60を過(す)ぎ、益々(ますます)元気(げんき)になっているからすごい。
example.english: My dad is past 60, and he is getting more and more energetic. It's amazing.

english_grammar.title: 一方(いっぽう)だ
english_grammar.explanation: more and more, continue to, keep on, -er and -er
english_grammar.structure: Verb + 一方だ Verb + 一方で + Phrase
english_grammar.attention: The verb must express change (e.g. 増える、下がる、or verbs ending with …なる、…てくる、…ていく etc.)
english_grammar.about: 一方(いっぽう) is a noun that is often seen after verbs, in order to convey the meaning of 'more and more (A)', 'continuing to (A)', or 'getting (A)er and (A)er'.一方(いっぽう) will be paired with the auxiliary verb だ (at the end of sentences), or で, だ's conjunctive form when it will be followed by some sort of explanation. アメリカとロシアの関係(かんけい)は悪化(あっか)する一方(いっぽう)だ。The relationship between the US and Russia keeps on getting worse. 仕事(しごと)の量(りょう)が増(ふ)える一方(いっぽう)で、休(やす)みが取(と)れない。Because the amount of work keeps on increasing, I can't take a day off. As the literal meaning of 一方(いっぽう) is 'single direction', it may be used with things that are increasing, decreasing, intensifying, or weakening, so long as the shift is all in a single direction.Caution 一方(いっぽう) may only be used with verbs that express some kind of change, as 一方(いっぽう) itself does not express change, just a continuing direction. 高齢化(こうれいか)が進(すす)んで、人口(じんこう)が減(へ)る一方(いっぽう)だ。 (Natural)Because of the aging society, the population continues to decline. 子供(こども)が怪我(けが)をして泣(な)く一方(いっぽう)だ。 (Unnatural)The child cries in one direction because he got injured.

example.japanese: 上昇(じょうしょう)し続(つづ)ける物価(ぶっか)のせいで生活(せいかつ)は苦(くる)しくなる一方(いっぽう)だ。
example.english: Due to the continuous growth of prices, life keeps on getting harder and harder.

example.japanese: 残念(ざんねん)ながらこんな事件(じけん)が増(ふ)える一方(いっぽう)だ。
example.english: Unfortunately, there are more and more cases like these.

example.japanese: 皆(みんな)が何(なに)もしようとしないから、地球(ちきゅう)温暖化(おんだんか)が悪(わる)くなる一方(いっぽう)だ。
example.english: Because no one is doing anything about it, global warming is continuing to get worse.

example.japanese: このままだと借金(しゃっきん)が増(ふ)える一方(いっぽう)だ。
example.english: If I keep going on like this, my debts will continue to increase.

example.japanese: 景気(けいき)は悪(わる)くなる一方(いっぽう)だから、ボーナスは出(で)ないかもしれないですよ。
example.english: We might not get a bonus because the market keeps getting worse and worse.

Progressively, Rapidly increasing, More and more
at last, finally, more and more
to continue
the more…the more
