english_grammar.title: 上(あ)がる
english_grammar.explanation: something is finished, to finish something, something has come to an end, to do something completely, to do something through
english_grammar.structure: （Noun + が） + Verb ［ます］ + 上がる （Noun + を） + Verb ［ます］ + 上げる
english_grammar.attention: 上がる is intransitive, 上げる is transitive
english_grammar.about: When used after the conjunctive form of a verb, either of the verbs 上(あ)げる 'to raise', or 上(あ)がる 'to rise' may be used. They will convey that something has been done 'to the limit'. 上(あ)がる will be used for actions that take place by themselves (intransitive), while 上(あ)げる will be used for actions that have an instigator (transitive).Although 上(あ)げる and 上(あ)がる show that something has been done 'to the limit', the nuance is usually 'to do (A) to the point of completion', or 'to do (A) through to the end'. Therefore, the 'limit' that is being highlighted is usually a natural ending, and not due to running out of some kind of resource. Let's have a look at some examples. レポートは書(か)きあがった？Did you finish writing the paper? この炊飯器(すいはんき)を使(つか)えば20分(ぷん)でご飯(はん)が炊(た)きあがるよ。If you use this rice cooker, your rice will finish cooking in 20 minutes. 明日(あした)の朝(あさ)までに書(か)き上(あ)げるのは無理(むり)かな？頑張(がんば)らなきゃ。Is it impossible to finish up writing this paper by tomorrow? I should give it my all. 彼(かれ)は砂(すな)を使(つか)って小(ちい)さな街(まち)を作(つく)り上(あ)げた。He used sand to build up a small city. 上(あ)げる and 上(あ)がる are most commonly used when some kind of effect or product is produced as a result of the (A) action. In these cases, the literal meaning of 'to (A) up' is very similar to 'to finish up (A)' in English. 彼(かれ)の作品(さくひん)は5分(ふん)で書(か)きあがる。His pieces are drawn up in 5 minutes. 古(ふる)いコンピューターは立(た)ち上(あ)がるのに10分(ぷん)かかる。It takes an old computer 10 minutes to finish up booting. Caution 仕上(しあ)がる is a very common expression that is used for many things. Usually it conveys that something has been completed after some involved or time consuming process. ラッピングが仕上(しあ)がったら番号(ばんごう)でお呼(よ)びします。We will call you by your number once we finish wrapping it. あれはどんな風(ふう)に仕上(しあ)がるかな。I wonder how that will be completed.

example.japanese: ところで、やっと絵(え)が描(えが)きあがったよ。
example.english: By the way, the picture has finally been completely painted.

example.japanese: その日(ひ)のうちに部屋(へや)の壁(かべ)を塗(ぬ)り上(あ)げた。
example.english: I finished painting the room walls before the day was over.

example.japanese: 作品(さくひん)が仕(し)上(あ)がる。
example.english: The piece will be finished.

example.japanese: なんとかドレスを縫(ぬ)い上(あ)げました。
example.english: I have somehow managed to finish sewing the dress.

example.japanese: ご飯(はん)が炊(た)き上(あ)がる。
example.english: The rice will finish up cooking.

synonym.explanation: To finish, To end
to do something by accident, to finish completely・totally, unfortunately
to do something completely to the end, utterly, resolutely
all~, completely, see through, overcome, to the bitter end

antonym.explanation: being unable to finish or complete

english_grammar.title: 切(き)る
english_grammar.explanation: to do something completely to the end, utterly, resolutely
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ 切る
english_grammar.about: Another verb that is often seen used after the conjunctive form of other verbs is the う - Verb 切(き)る 'to cut'. 切(き)る will give the (A) verb the nuance of being done 'to completion'. However, the 'completion' that is being conveyed with 切(き)る is usually caused by the running out of some kind of resource, like energy. Due to this, 切(き)る is often translated as 'to do (A) to the point of being unable to continue' (or not needing to continue), or 'to totally and utterly do (A)'. 自分(じぶん)は全部(ぜんぶ)使(つか)い切(き)るまで、新(あたら)しいのを買(か)わない。Personally, I don't buy new ones until I use everything up. 今日(きょう)はライトノベルを2冊(さつ)も読(よ)み切(き)った。I finished reading 2 light novels today. 水筒(すいとう)の水(みず)を飲(の)み切(き)ったがまだのどが渇(かわ)いている。I finished drinking the water in my bottle, but am still thirsty. Occasionally, 切(き)る may also be used to show that (A) is being done at 'full pelt', 'full steam', or 'full capacity'. In these cases, it is similar to 'to resolutely do (A)', and just means that 100% effort is being put into the action. このカーブではスピードを落(お)とさずに走り切(き)るのが重要(じゅうよう)だ。At this curve, it is important to drive at full pelt without slowing down. 今回(こんかい)の大会(たいかい)で全力(ぜんりょく)を出(だ)し切(き)ることができて良(よ)かったです。I am happy that I was able to do the best that I can do at this tournament. (Full capacity of power)

example.japanese: 先週末(せんしゅうまつ)、三冊(さんさつ)のマンガを読(よ)み切(き)った。
example.english: I finished reading three manga last weekend.

example.japanese: 給料(きゅうりょう)をもらった日(ひ)に使(つか)い切(き)ってしまった。
example.english: I completely used up my entire paycheck the day I got it.

example.japanese: 疲(つか)れ切(き)っていたから、私(わたし)の代(か)わりに兄(あに)をお母(かあ)さんの迎(むか)えに行(い)かせた。
example.english: Because I was completely worn out, I had my brother go pick up my mother in my place.

example.japanese: 使(つか)い切(き)ってから次(つぎ)のジャムを買(か)ってよ。
example.english: Buy another jar of jam after you use one up completely.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はウィスキーを水(みず)のように一気(いっき)に一本(いっぽん)飲(の)み切(き)った。
example.english: He completely drank an entire bottle of whiskey like it was water.

synonym.explanation: remain, to do thoroughly, deeply, intensely
to do something by accident, to finish completely・totally, unfortunately
something is finished, to finish something, something has come to an end, to do something completely, to do something through
all~, completely, see through, overcome, to the bitter end
To finish, To end

antonym.explanation: being unable to finish or complete

english_grammar.title: 切(き)れない
english_grammar.explanation: being unable to finish or complete
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ 切れない
english_grammar.about: In the negative-potential form, 切(き)れない will attach to the conjunctive form of other verbs, to express that a particular action is 'unable to be completed'. Let's look at some examples. 大盛(おおもり)頼(たの)むの？いくらあなたでもここの大盛(おおもり)は食(た)べきれないと思(おも)うよ。Are you going to order the large one? I don't think you can possibly finish the portion they serve here. あの山(やま)は一日(いちにち)では登(のぼ)り切(き)れない。You can't possibly finish climbing this mountain in one day. Unlike 切(き)る, which usually attaches to verbs to show that something was done to the point of running out, 切(き)れない often implies the exact opposite. This means that the (A) verb cannot be completed specifically because there is too much/many of something in order to finish it. 宇宙(うちゅう)には数(かぞ)え切(き)れないほどの星(ほし)がある。 There are too many stars in space to count. この肉(にく)は厚(あつ)すぎて歯(は)では噛(か)み切(き)れない。 This meat is so thick that it is not possible to chew with your teeth. 切(き)れない may also imply that something cannot be done 'to the point of satisfaction'. In this case, the feeling of dissatisfaction is what the speaker considers too much to overcome. 私(わたし)のこの気持(きも)ちは言葉(ことば)では表(あらわ)しきれない。 I cannot possibly explain this feeling of mine with words. (Cannot explain satisfactorily) 楽(たの)しみ過(す)ぎて待(ま)ちきれない。I am so excited that I can't wait. (Cannot wait satisfactorily)

example.japanese: 空(そら)の星(ほし)の数(かず)が数(かぞ)え切(き)れない。
example.english: You can't completely count the number of stars in the sky.

example.japanese: お皿(さら)が多(おお)すぎて、洗(あら)い切(き)れない。
example.english: There are too many dishes. I will be unable to finish washing them.

example.japanese: 辛(から)かったから、食(た)べ切(き)れなかった。
example.english: Because it was spicy, I was unable to finish eating the food.

example.japanese: この溢(あふ)れる思(おも)いを抑(おさ)え切(き)れない。
example.english: I am unable to completely control my emotions from overflowing.

example.japanese: 貨物(かもつ)、多(おお)すぎて載(の)せ切(き)れない。一部(いちぶ)を置(お)いていくしかないな。
example.english: There is too much cargo and I cannot load it completely. There is no choice but to leave part of it.

synonym.explanation: cannot・be unable to, hard to, hesitant to
unable to, cannot

antonym.explanation: to do something by accident, to finish completely・totally, unfortunately
something is finished, to finish something, something has come to an end, to do something completely, to do something through
to do something completely to the end, utterly, resolutely

english_grammar.title: きり
english_grammar.explanation: only, just, since
english_grammar.structure: Verb［た］ + きり(1) Noun + きり これ(2) + きり(1) Number + Counter + きり(1) (1) っきり (2) それ
english_grammar.attention: っきり is more casual than きり
english_grammar.about: Often used as an adverbial particle, きり may convey that (A) being done resulted in it being the 'first and last time'. This is frequently translated as 'only', 'just', or 'since'. きり comes from the う - Verb 切(き)る 'to cut'. きり may also express that something is happening with (A) as the limit 'nothing more, nothing less'.きり is often used after the plain past form of verbs, with nouns, or with counters. Let's look at verbs first. 昨日(きのう)、晩(ばん)ご飯(はん)食(た)べたきり何(なに)も食(た)べてないから、めちゃお腹(なか)が空(す)いた。I haven't eaten anything since last night, so I am extremely hungry. お祖母(ばあ)ちゃんは去年(きょねん)病気(びょうき)で倒(たお)れて、寝(ね)たきりになった。Grandma got sick last year, and has become bedridden. With verbs, きり is primarily used to show that (A) occurring was all that was required for (B). Usually, this results in some permanent consequence, or permanent change of opinion. In almost every situation, (A) is something that has only happened once, and きり can be interpreted as 'ever since'. 一人(ひとり)きりになれる時間(じかん)が欲(ほ)しい。I want some time where I can be alone. 彼(かれ)とは一度(いちど)きりしか会(あ)えていない。I was only able to meet him just once. 二人(ふたり)っきりの時間(じかん)はいいね！A time just for the two of us is nice, isn't it! With nouns and counters, きり usually shows that (A) is all that will be included in some particular situation/action.Caution きり may also be seen as っきり or キリ. There is no specific change in nuance, but っきり is the most common casual form.

example.japanese: やっと二人(ふたり)っきりになれたね。
example.english: It is finally just the two of us.

example.japanese: その店(みせ)に一回(いっかい)行(い)ったきり、行(い)っていない。
example.english: I went to that store only one time and haven't gone again.

example.japanese: 寂(さび)しい時(とき)、一人(ひとり)っきりで泣(な)く。
example.english: When I am sad, I cry alone.

example.japanese: 父(ちち)がついに寝(ね)たきりになってしまった。
example.english: My dad has become completely bedridden.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)とは喧嘩(けんか)したっきり会(あ)っていません。
example.english: I haven't seen my girlfriend since we had a fight.

synonym.explanation: To emphasize '~only', nothing but
there's only, nothing but
Only, Just
as is, while remaining, left in a state
while... ~ing, remaining, not/ever since, keep/leave

english_grammar.title: 掛(か)け
english_grammar.explanation: half-, not yet finished, about to, begin to
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ かけだ Verb［ます］+ かける Verb［ます］+ かけの + Noun
english_grammar.about: Being an unofficial helper verb, かけ is what is known as a 造語(ぞうご) (neologism), and carries one specific meaning when used in conjunction with other words. This is similar to 向(む)け. かけ comes from the verb 掛(か)ける 'to suspend', and may be attached to the conjunctive form or other verbs, in order to convey that they are 'unfinished'. Usually this translates as 'half (A)', 'about to (A)', or 'not yet finished (A)'.かけ behaves like a noun, so may be followed by the case marking particle の when attached directly to another noun, or by だ when at the end of a sentence. 俺(おれ)の食(た)べかけだけど大丈夫(だいじょうぶ)？This is half-eaten by me, is that okay? これは私(わたし)の飲(の)みかけだ。This is my half-drunken one. 彼(かれ)は死(し)にかけの子犬(こいぬ)を救(すく)った。He saved a puppy that was about to die. (Half dead) 彼女(かのじょ)は壊(こわ)れかけのパソコンを買(か)って直(なお)すのが趣味(しゅみ)だ。Her hobby is to buy half-broken computers and fix them. (Computers on the verge of breaking) Occasionally, the verb 掛(か)ける itself may be used instead of the noun form, かけ. やばい、死(し)にかけるところだった。Wow, I was about to be dying right there. (Almost on the verge of dying) 飲(の)みかけた水(みず)を捨(す)てる。I will throw away my half drunk water. Fun FactAs the literal meaning of 掛(か)ける is 'to suspend', it expresses that something is stuck somewhere in the process of happening. This is similar to taking a photo of someone that is jumping. In the photo it will look like they are 'suspended', but that is only because one particular moment has been captured, somewhere between the start and the finish. かけ conveys exactly the same meaning, and therefore may be interpreted differently, depending on the verb it is paired with.With verbs that express a momentary action (something that cannot be 'half' done), かけ will convey that the action was 'on the verge of' happening. 先週(せんしゅう)の事故(じこ)で死(し)にかけそうになった。I was on the verge of dying in an accident last week. 壊(こわ)れかけていた椅子(いす)に座(すわ)ったら、椅子(いす)が壊(こわ)れた。When I sat on a chair that was on the verge of breaking, it broke. However, with verbs that are ongoing actions, かけ will simply imply that they are 'in the process' of being done. 終(お)わりかけだからちょっと待(ま)って。I'm in the process of finishing, so can you wait a little.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)の宿題(しゅくだい)はもう終(お)わりかけです。
example.english: Today's homework is about to be finished.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は、何冊(なんさつ)も読(よ)みかけの本(ほん)がある。
example.english: I have a lot of books that are half-read.

example.japanese: 食(た)べかけのケーキでも良(よ)ければありますよ。
example.english: I have some half-eaten cake, if you would like.

example.japanese: 描(か)きかけの絵(え)を早(はや)く完成(かんせい)させたい。
example.english: I want to finish this half-drawn picture quickly.

example.japanese: この時計(とけい)壊(こわ)れかけだけど、ないよりはいいか。
example.english: This watch is half-broken, but is still better than nothing.

synonym.explanation: About to, On the verge of
To start, To begin to
to suddenly begin, to start doing

english_grammar.title: に掛(か)けて
english_grammar.explanation: over (a period), from ~ until・through
english_grammar.structure: Noun + にかけて(は)
english_grammar.attention: There is another use ofにかけてはthat indicates that someone/something is remarkable in a certain field
english_grammar.about: Coming from the る - Verb 掛(か)ける 'to suspend', にかけて conveys that something is happening 'over a period of time', 'from (A) until (B)', or 'all through (A)'. This grammar structure is a combination of the case marking particle に, and 掛(か)ける combined with the conjunction particle て. Literally, the meaning can be thought of as follows:に - Marks (A) as the location/state.掛(か)けて - States that something is 'suspended' (in an ongoing process) in that location/state.The 'something' that is an ongoing process will usually be indicated by a (B) part of the sentence. This expression will primarily be used with nouns. 今夜(こんや)から朝(あさ)にかけて大雨(おおあめ)が降(ふ)るでしょう。It looks like it will rain from tonight through til the morning. 毎年(まいとし)、3月末(さんがつまつ)から5月(がつ)の頭(あたま)にかけて多(おお)くの人(ひと)が引(ひ)っ越(こ)しをします。Every year, a lot of people move from the end of March through the beginning of May. にかけて is primarily used in written language, although it appears quite often in the news as well, indicating that some weather pattern is expected to continue for a set period of time.Caution Occasionally, the adverbial particle は is used after にかけて. This transforms the meaning of 'all through (A)', to something similar to 'limited to within (A)'. Any (B) phrase in these types of sentences will be contrasting (B) with (A), rather than saying (B) is occurring within (A). 今(いま)は雨(あめ)が降(ふ)っているが、朝(あさ)にかけては晴(は)れるでしょう。 It is raining right now, but it seems like it will clear up during the morning. (Limited to the extent of tomorrow morning) 今月(こんげつ)から来月(らいげつ)にかけては忙(いそが)しい時期(じき)になるので、無理(むり)せずに頑張(がんば)ってください。Limited from this month through until next month, it is going to be a busy season, so please do your best without overworking yourself. As we can see by these examples, this is an extension of the standard use of は, which shows that everything before it is a 'set state'. Therefore '(A) は (B)', means that 'only (A) defines (A), (B) is a separate entity/discussion'.

example.japanese: 今(こん)週末(しゅうまつ)にかけて、雨(あめ)が降(ふ)るでしょう。
example.english: It looks like it is going to rain over the weekend.

example.japanese: あのスーパーは今日(きょう)から、明日(あす)にかけて、セールがあるらしい。
example.english: I heard that that supermarket is having a sale from today through tomorrow.

example.japanese: この一年(いちねん)にかけて、いろいろなことを経験(けいけん)したい。
example.english: I want to experience a variety of things over this next year.

example.japanese: 先週(せんしゅう)にかけて降(ふ)った大雪(おおゆき)が、まだ全然(ぜんぜん)溶(と)けない。
example.english: It kept snowing all through last week, and it hasn't melted yet.

example.japanese: 来年(らいねん)にかけての目標(もくひょう)を立(た)ててください。
example.english: Please establish your goals over the next year.

synonym.explanation: when it comes to, regarding, concerning
across, throughout, extends, over (a period of time or range)

english_grammar.title: 立(た)て
english_grammar.explanation: freshly ~ed, just ~ed
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ たて Verb［ます］+ たて + の + Noun
english_grammar.about: たて, coming from the verb 立(た)てる 'to stand' is a suffix in Japanese that is often used after the conjunctive form of verbs. たて conveys that something has 'just been finished', or is 'freshly finished'.As a suffix, たて transforms verbs into nouns. This means that they may be followed by a (B) phrase, or followed directly by the case marking particle の and a noun. ここにあるのは全部(ぜんぶ)揚(あ)げたてですよ。Everything here is freshly fried. 釣(つ)りたてだから新鮮(しんせん)だよ！It is just fished up, so it is fresh! 私(わたし)は出来(でき)立(た)てのパンを食(た)べるのが大好(だいす)きです。I like to eat freshly baked bread. 生(う)まれたての赤(あか)ちゃんっておさるさんみたいじゃない？Don't newborn babies look like monkeys? Fun Factたて is a suffix that is used to convey the moment in time directly after something has been finished, rather than the fact that it 'is' finished. Due to this, たて is most frequently used with verbs that indicate some sense of time based importance, where (A) will degrade in quality over time after completion. 取(と)り立(た)ての野菜(やさい)で作(つく)るサラダは美味(おい)しい。 Making salad with freshly picked vegetables is delicious. この靴(くつ)は濡(ぬ)れたてだから、乾(かわ)かすのに少(すこ)し時間(じかん)がかかると思(おも)う。These shoes got freshly wet, so it will take some time to dry.

example.japanese: 釣(つ)りたての魚(さかな)を食(た)べるのは最高(さいこう)！
example.english: Eating freshly caught fish is the best!

example.japanese: このベンチはペンキ塗(ぬ)りたてのため、気(き)を付(つ)けてください。
example.english: This bench has been freshly painted, so please be careful.

example.japanese: この魚(さかな)は焼(や)きたてです。
example.english: This fish has been freshly cooked.

example.japanese: できたてのお菓子(かし)を食(た)べたのは初(はじ)めてだ。
example.english: It's my first time eating freshly made sweets.

example.japanese: この農場(のうじょう)は毎日(まいにち)、産(う)みたての卵(たまご)を出荷(しゅっか)する。
example.english: This farm is shipping freshly laid eggs every day.

synonym.explanation: just finished doing, was just doing
just did, something just happened

antonym.explanation: half-, not yet finished, about to, begin to

english_grammar.title: 込(こ)む ①
english_grammar.explanation: to go into, to put into
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］ + 込む
english_grammar.about: In Japanese, the う - Verb 込(こ)む 'to jam into' is frequently used as a suffix to convey several different meanings. The primary meanings are as follows:(A) 込(こ)む - To enter completely into doing (A), or the state of being in (A).(A) 込(こ)む - To enter a state of doing (A) that will not be considered complete until 'success'.(A) 込(こ)む - To enter a state of doing (A) that cannot be escaped from.In this lesson, we will exclusively focus on the first meaning, which is usually translated as 'to put into (A)', or 'to go into (A)'. This form will be attached to the conjunctive form of other verbs. ピンを壁(かべ)に押(お)し込(こ)む。 To push a pin into a wall. 薬(くすり)を飲(の)み込(こ)むのが苦手(にがて)です。I am not the best at drinking down medicine. (I am not the best at swallowing medicine) 電車(でんしゃ)のドアが閉(し)まる前(まえ)に、電車(でんしゃ)に走(はし)り込(こ)んだ。Before the train door closed, I ran in. サウナから出(で)て、水風呂(みずぶろ)に飛(と)び込(こ)むように入(はい)った。I came out of the sauna and went into the water bath as if I was leaping into it. Despite the multiple meanings, 込(こ)む can almost always be thought of as 'jamming (B) into (A)'. This means that whatever the (A) action is, will be something that is not easily entered, but also not easily escaped from.

example.japanese: ライトノベル、クラスメートとの話：「ドラゴンをクラスに持(も)ち込(こ)むのはルール違反(いはん)じゃないか？」
example.english: Light novel, chat between classmates : "Taking a dragon into class, isn’t that breaking the rules?"

example.japanese: 行列(ぎょうれつ)で：「（列(れつ)に）割(わ)り込(こ)むなんて、図々(ずうずう)しいですよ！」
example.english: In the queue: "Cutting into (the line), how impudent!"

example.japanese: ライトノベル、勇者(ゆうしゃ)たちの会話(かいわ)：「一人(ひとり)で魔王(まおう)の城(しろ)に乗(の)り込(こ)むおつもりですか？おやめ下(くだ)さい！」
example.english: Light novel, chat between heroes: "Do you plan to march into the demon king’s castle alone? Please, stop!"

example.japanese: ライトノベル、ナレーター：「コタカが突然(とつぜん)、部室(ぶしつ)に走(はし)り込(こ)んで来(き)て、彼女(かのじょ)の隣(となり)に席(せき)を取(と)った。」
example.english: Light novel, the narrator: "Kotaka has suddenly run into the club room, and taken a seat next to her."

example.japanese: 教師(きょうし)：「教科書(きょうかしょ)に答(こた)えを書(か)き込(こ)んでください。」
example.english: Teacher: "Please fill in your textbooks with answers."

synonym.explanation: remain, to do thoroughly, deeply, intensely

english_grammar.title: 込(こ)む ②
english_grammar.explanation: remain, to do thoroughly, deeply, intensely
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ 込む
english_grammar.about: In Japanese, the う - Verb 込(こ)む 'to jam into' is frequently used as a suffix to convey several different meanings. The primary meanings are as follows:(A) 込(こ)む - To enter completely into doing (A), or the state of being in (A).(A) 込(こ)む - To enter a state of doing (A) that will not be considered complete until 'success'.(A) 込(こ)む - To enter a state of doing (A) that cannot be escaped from.In this lesson, we will exclusively focus on the second and third meanings, which are usually translated as 'to remain in (A)', 'to thoroughly do (A)', 'to do (A) deeply', or 'to do (A) intensely'. This form will be attached to the conjunctive form of other verbs. 警察(けいさつ)が道(みち)の真(ま)ん中(なか)で座(すわ)り込(こ)んでいる人(ひと)に話(はな)しかけた。 The police went to talk to the person that remained seated in the middle of the road. もうこんな時間(じかん)か、話(はな)し込(こ)んじゃったな。It's already this time, we got lost in talking, didn't we? そんなに考(かんが)え込(こ)まなくてもいいよ。 You don't have to think so deeply about this. 今(いま)は取(と)り込(こ)み中(ちゅう)なので手(て)が空(あ)いたらかけなおします。I am held up working right now, so I will call you back once my hands are free. Despite the multiple meanings, 込(こ)む can almost always be thought of as 'jamming (B) into (A)'. This means that whatever the (A) action is, will be something that is not easily entered, but also not easily escaped from.

example.japanese: みんないっせいに黙(だま)り込(こ)んでいた。
example.english: At once, everyone sunk into an intense silence and remained silent.

example.japanese: 疲(つか)れていたので、シャワーを浴(あ)びずに眠(ねむ)り込(こ)んだ。
example.english: I was tired, so I fell deeply asleep without taking a shower.

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)との話(はなし)：「何(なに)を長々(ながなが)話(はな)し込(こ)んでたの？」
example.english: Chat between friends: "What were you so intently talking about for so long?"

example.japanese: エッセイ：「熱心(ねっしん)にひとつの事(こと)に打(う)ち込(こ)むことが必要(ひつよう)だと思(おも)っている。」
example.english: Essay: "I think that devoting oneself intensely to one thing is important."

example.japanese: 小(ちい)さな花(はな)の写真(しゃしん)を撮(と)るためにしゃがみ込(こ)む。
example.english: To squat down deeply (with their face between their legs) in order to take a picture of a small flower.

synonym.explanation: to do something completely to the end, utterly, resolutely
to go into, to put into
To finish, To end

english_grammar.title: 振(ふ)りをする
english_grammar.explanation: to pretend, to act as if
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ている］(1) + ふりをする ［い］Adjective + ふりをする ［な］Adjective + な + ふりをする Noun + の + ふりをする (1) Verb［ない］、Verb［た］
english_grammar.about: ふりをする is an expression in Japanese that is used to show that someone is 'pretending to be (A)', 'putting on airs of (A)', or 'acting as if (A)'. This construction comes from a combination of the noun 振(ふ)り 'a shake', the adverbial particle を, and する. It can be thought of as meaning 'to give off the impression of (A)', or 'to shake off the impression of (A)'.As ふり itself is a noun, this expression may be used with the attributive form of any other word. この蛇(へび)は人(ひと)等(など)大(おお)きな動物(どうぶつ)が近(ちか)づくと死(し)んだ振(ふ)りをするらしい。I heard that this snake pretends to be dead when humans and bigger animals approach it. 僕(ぼく)は子供(こども)の頃(ころ)、よく寝(ね)ている振(ふ)りをした。When I was a child, I would often pretend to sleep. 欲(ほ)しいのはこれではなかったけど、せっかく買(か)ってくれたから嬉(うれ)しい振(ふ)りをする。This is not what I wanted, but since they went out of their way and bought it for me, I will pretend that I am happy. 俺(おれ)の前(まえ)ではそんな、元気(げんき)な振(ふ)りをしなくていいよ。You don't have to pretend that you are happy in front of me. カケル君(くん)はカエルが好(す)きだからいつもカエルの振(ふり)りをして遊(あそ)んでいる。Because Kakeru-kun likes frogs, he always pretends to be a frog when he plays. Fun FactThe noun 振(ふ)り has several different nuances in Japanese, with only one of them being used in this particular expression. That meaning is 'to show a certain behavior pattern on the outside'. Due to this, ふり doesn't specifically mean 'to pretend', just that what is happening on the outside may be different to what is happening within a person (either mentally or physically).

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の犬(いぬ)は寝(ね)たふりをすることがある。
example.english: There are times when my dog pretends to sleep.

example.japanese: 子供(こども)は、注意(ちゅうい)された時(とき)に、聞(き)こえないふりをした。
example.english: The child pretended not to hear while she was being scolded.

example.japanese: どんなことについても知(し)っているふりをする人(ひと)は信頼(しんらい)ができない。
example.english: I don’t trust people who act as if they know everything.

example.japanese: 病気(びょうき)のふりをして会社(かいしゃ)を休(やす)んだ。
example.english: Pretending to be sick, I took the day off work.

example.japanese: 熊(くま)に遭遇(そうぐう)した時(とき)、死(し)んだふりをしてもあまり意味(いみ)がないと聞(き)いた。
example.english: I have heard that when you encounter a bear, even if you pretend to be dead, it won’t make much difference.

synonym.explanation: -ish・-like, characteristic of, typical of, tendency to

english_grammar.title: できれば
english_grammar.explanation: If possible
english_grammar.structure: できれば + Phrase できたら + Phrase
english_grammar.about: Remembering that する has no potential form, the replacement る - Verb できる 'to amount to' will often be used in conjunction with particles, to indicate whether the possibility of amounting to something exists. The conjunction particles ば or たら will most frequently be used. できれば and できたら are usually translated simply as 'if possible'.Both できれば and できたら will come at the start of a sentence, before the following statement will express some (desired) outcome. 出来(でき)れば車(くるま)で行(い)きたいけど、電車(でんしゃ)で行(い)った方(ほう)が早(はや)いかもしれない。If possible, I would love to go by car, but it might be faster by train. 出来(でき)たら薬局(やっきょく)に行(い)って頭痛(ずつう)薬(やく)を買(か)って来(き)てくれる？If possible, can you go to the chemist and buy me some headache medication? Caution As ば and たら are the only 'hypothetical' indicators that can express the process toward potential outcomes, using なら or と would be be illogical. This can be visualized as follows:(A) できると - Will express the result after achieving (A), not what is required to get there.(A) できるなら - As なら is just the hypothetical form of だ, It is used to make guesses about what could happen if the situation of (A) exists, not how that situation can be used to produce some other result.

example.japanese: できればお弁当(べんとう)を作(つく)って欲(ほ)しいな。
example.english: If possible, I would like you to make me a bento.

example.japanese: できれば本人(ほんにん)と会(あ)って話(はなし)がしたい。
example.english: If possible, I would like to talk with him directly.

example.japanese: それができたら嬉(うれ)しいんですけど。
example.english: If it's possible for you to do that, I would appreciate it.

example.japanese: この仕事(しごと)、できれば今日中(きょうじゅう)に終(お)わらせたい。
example.english: If possible, I want to get this done today.

example.japanese: できればあの会社(かいしゃ)で働(はたら)きたい。
example.english: If possible, I want to work at that company.

synonym.explanation: As ~ as possible, Wherever practicable
if, if one could, if something would be possible

english_grammar.title: で良(よ)ければ
english_grammar.explanation: If it is alright, if you don't mind, if you would like, if possible
english_grammar.structure: Noun + でよければ
english_grammar.about: でよければ is an expression that is constructed with the case marking particle で, and the potential form of the い-Adjective いい, よければ. The literal meaning of 'if with (A) is good/fine', or 'if by (A) is good/fine' is quite similar to the standard translation, which is 'if (A) is ok'.でよければ will always follow nouns or noun-phrases. 焼(や)き肉(にく)でよければ、うちの近(ちか)くに美味(おい)しいところがあるから、そこに行(い)かない？If yakiniku is fine, there is a good yakiniku place near my house, so do you want to go there? 中古(ちゅうこ)で良(よ)ければいいのが沢山(たくさん)ありますよ。If used ones are fine, we have many good options. でよければ is a phrase that is often used in relation to oneself, in order to politely offer some sort of help, advice, or service. 私(わたし)でよければ手伝(てつだう)うよ。If you don't mind, I can help you. (If I am a suitable option, I can help you) 先生(せんせい)でよければ、先生(せんせい)が写真(しゃしん)を取(と)ってあげるよ。If you don't mind, I can take a picture for you. As で is being used in its standard meaning of 'with' or 'by', でよければ implies that the speaker is enquiring whether the quality/ability of (A) is good enough to achieve some specific result.

example.japanese: ウェルギリウス：「私(わたし)でよければ案内(あんない)しますが。」
example.english: Virgil: "If you don't mind (me), I can be your guide."

example.japanese: この籠(かご)でよければ作(つく)れますよ。
example.english: If this is the basket that you would like, I can make it.

example.japanese: 水曜日(すいようび)でよければ、一緒(いっしょ)に行(い)けます。
example.english: If you do not mind Wednesday , I can go with you.

example.japanese: 賃貸(ちんたい)でよければ、いい家(いえ)を見(み)つけた。
example.english: I have found a good house, if you don't mind renting.

example.japanese: 中古車(ちゅうこしゃ)でよければ、安(やす)い車(くるま)があります。
example.english: There are cheap cars, if you don't mind used ones.

synonym.explanation: it doesn't matter if, I don't mind
It's okay to, It's alright to, Can/may

english_grammar.title: 次第(しだい)
english_grammar.explanation: as soon as
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ 次第 ［する］Verb + 次第
english_grammar.about: 次第(しだい) is a noun that is often translated in different ways, depending on what type of word it follows. In this lesson, we will look at the meaning associated with the conjunctive form of standard verbs, and the stem of する verbs. Although it is a noun, 次第(しだい) may also be classified simply as a suffix in many cases.Basically, 次第(しだい) means 'next in sequence after (A)', and is often translated to 'as soon as (A)'. 用意(ようい)が出来(でき)次第(しだい)、僕(ぼく)に声(こえ)をかけてください。As soon as you get ready, please let me know. ミュージカルが終(お)わり次第(しだい)、連絡(れんらく)をください。Please call me as soon as the musical ends. 待(ま)ち合(あ)わせ場所(ばしょ)に到着(とうちゃく)し次第(しだい)、私(わたし)に連絡(れんらく)してください。Please give me a call as soon as you arrive at the meet up spot. Fun FactOne of the most important things to keep in mind with 次第(しだい), is that the literal meaning in almost every situation is 'determining sequence'. This is unlike any standard phrase in English, but simply expresses that (A) is what will govern (B). Let's look at how this translates with different word types.Verb 次第(しだい) - Verb determines the sequence of (B). Since a verb is not capable of making a choice, (A) simply 'happening' will result in (B). 計画(けいかく)が決(き)まり次第(しだい)、あなたに報告(ほうこく)します。I will notify you as soon as we decide on the plan. Living noun 次第(しだい) - Noun determines the sequence of (B). Since living things can make choices, (B) will depend on (A). 行(い)くか行(い)かないかは君(きみ)次第(しだい)だよ。Whether you go or not will depend on you. Inanimate/abstract noun 次第(しだい) - Noun determines the sequence of (B). Since inanimate/abstract things cannot make choices, (A) will determine (B)'s course of action. (B) will usually involve some kind of decision. 6人(にん)も乗(の)れるかは車(くるま)のサイズ次第(しだい)だね。Whether or not 6 people can fit will depend on the size of the car.

example.japanese: 映画(えいが)が終(お)わり次第(しだい)、連絡(れんらく)して。迎(むか)えに行(い)くからね。
example.english: Let me know as soon as the movie is over because I’ll go pick you up.

example.japanese: 宿題(しゅくだい)の答(こた)えが分(わ)かり次第(しだい)、教(おし)えてください。
example.english: Please tell (teach) me the homework answers as soon as you know them.

example.japanese: 雨(あめ)が止(や)み次第(しだい)、大会(たいかい)は再開(さいかい)される。
example.english: The rally will resume as soon as the rain stops.

example.japanese: 平日(へいじつ)、妻(つま)の仕事(しごと)が終(お)わり次第(しだい)、迎(むか)えに行(い)ってあげている。
example.english: On weekdays, as soon as my wife gets off work, I pick her up.

example.japanese: 準備(じゅんび)が出来(でき)次第(しだい)出発(しゅっぱつ)しますよ。
example.english: We will depart as soon as you are ready.

synonym.explanation: as soon as, the moment, when
At once, Immediately, As soon as
the instant・moment, as soon as, just as
to relate to, to have to do with, concerning, depends on
by means of, according to, depending on, because of, due to
depending on, so

english_grammar.title: 通(とお)り
english_grammar.explanation: in that way, exactly・precisely, just as
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］(1) + とおり Noun + どおり Noun + の + とおり (1) Verb［た］
english_grammar.about: Often, the noun とおり carries the meaning of 'in that way', or 'just like that'. In its kanji form, とおり will be written as 通(とお)り, and literally means 'street', or 'way'. However, it is regularly used to indicate the level of 'sameness' one thing has with another. This 'sameness' meaning appears when とおり is used as a suffix.とおり (or どおり) may be used with verbs or nouns. In the case of verbs, it is common to see it being used after both the plain form, and the simple-past form. お客様(きゃくさま)のおっしゃる通(とお)りです。Honored guest, the thing you say is precisely correct. (That's exactly right) 彼(かれ)は僕(ぼく)の思(おも)った通(とお)りの時間(じかん)に帰(かえ)ってきた。Just as I expected, he came back when I thought he would come back. Both どおり and のとおり may be used directly after nouns. However, とおり will only be used when the case marking particle の comes between the noun and とおり. 計画(けいかく)どおりに進(すす)めて行(い)きます。We will continue as the plan suggests. ご覧(らん)の通(とお)り、私(わたし)の手(て)には何(なに)もありません。As you can see, I have nothing in my hands. While both of these structures may be used interchangeably, どおり is more common, especially in speech.Fun FactConstructions like 言(い)った通(とお)り and その通(とお)り are used very frequently, simply as a polite way to agree with what has been said by another. In these cases, it translates similarly to 'that's exactly right', or 'that's it!'. リカの言(い)った通(とお)りだった！あそこのパン屋(や)さんはすごくおいしかった！It was exactly as you said, Rika! The bakery over there was very delicious! 本当(ほんとう)にその通(とお)りです！何(なん)でいつも私(わたし)たちがやらないといけないんですか。That's honestly exactly it! Why do we have to do it all the time?

example.japanese: 思(おも)ったとおりでした。
example.english: It was just as I thought.

example.japanese: 今(いま)、卒業(そつぎょう)論文(ろんぶん)が順調(じゅんちょう)です。予定(よてい)どおりに完成(かんせい)させられそうです。
example.english: Right now my graduation thesis is coming along nicely. I can finish it as planned.

example.japanese: あなたのおっしゃるとおりです。
example.english: It will be just as you say.

example.japanese: 合格者(ごうかくしゃ)は次(つぎ)のとおりです。
example.english: Those who passed are as follows...

example.japanese: お察(さっ)しのとおり、彼(かれ)は病気(びょうき)です。
example.english: Just as you may guess, he is quite ill.

synonym.explanation: as・like, just like
do as (one is told/ordered…), in accordance with, in compliance with, just like
as (one likes/feels/pleases), spur of the moment, wherever one fancies, spontaneously, on a whim

english_grammar.title: でもある
english_grammar.explanation: be also, it also is
english_grammar.structure: Noun + でもある ［な］Adjective + でもある
english_grammar.about: As an extension of the formal version of the auxiliary verb だ, である, でもある simply conveys that something 'is also (B)'. However, as も often shows something that is surprising or unexpected, でもある will primarily be used to describe additional facts about (A) that may be unexpected. Due to this, でもある usually fills the (B) role in sentences like 'while (A), it is also (B)', or 'in spite of (A), it is also (B)'.でもある may be used after nouns, or な-Adjectives. タナカさんは英語(えいご)の先生(せんせい)だし、休(やす)みの日(ひ)は船(ふね)の船長(せんちょう)でもあるから休(やす)む時間(じかん)がない。While Tanaka-san is an English teacher, he is also the captain of a ship on his days off. これは洗濯機(せんたっき)でもあるけど、同時(どうじ)に乾燥機(かんそうき)でもある。In spite of this being a washing machine, it is also a dryer. バンジージャンプは楽(たの)しいけれども、同時(どうじ)には危険(きけん)でもある。In spite of bungee jumping being fun, it is also dangerous at times. この機械(きかい)は重(おも)くて邪魔(じゃま)だけど、同時(どうじ)に便利(べんり)でもある。While this machine is heavy and a nuisance, it is also useful.

example.japanese: 語学(ごがく)を学(まな)ぶことは楽(たの)しい。しかし、自分(じぶん)との戦(たたか)いでもある。
example.english: Learning languages is fun. However, it is also a fight with oneself.

example.japanese: この車(くるま)は少(すこ)し狭(せま)いけれども、快適(かいてき)でもある。
example.english: This car is a bit small, but it is also comfortable.

example.japanese: オーストラリアは国(くに)であり、大陸(たいりく)でもある。
example.english: Australia is a country. It is also a continent.

example.japanese: 「ずっと」というのは何(なに)かが長(なが)い間(あいだ)続(つづ)いているということである。「よりずっと速(はや)い」のように、比(くら)べているものとの間(あいだ)に大(おお)きな隔(へだ)たりがあるということでもある。
example.english: 'ずっと' means that something continues for a long time. It also means that there is a wide gap between things you are comparing, like in 'よりずっと速い'.

example.japanese: ハイブリッド車(しゃ)はガソリンエンジンを持(も)ちながら、電気(でんき)自動車(じどうしゃ)でもある。
example.english: Hybrid cars have a gasoline engine, but are also electric.

english_grammar.title: どうしても
english_grammar.explanation: regardless of, no matter what
english_grammar.structure: Verb + と + どうしても どうしても + Phrase
english_grammar.about: どうしても is a construction in Japanese that is often considered to be a stand-alone adverb meaning 'no matter how', or 'regardless of anything'. Originally, it is a combination of the adverb どう 'how', and the ても form of する, しても 'even doing'.どうしても will regularly be used at the beginning of sentences before conveying something that is considered by the speaker to be 'absolutely true'. どうしても欲(ほ)しいのなら、自分(じぶん)で買(か)いなさい。If you want it no matter what, buy it yourself. どうしても我慢(がまん)ができなくて買(か)っちゃった。I accidentally bought it because I couldn't resist no matter what. Alternatively, どうしても may be used after verbs, following the case marking particle と. This will express that 'if (A) happens, (B) is unavoidable'. 牛乳(ぎゅうにゅう)飲(の)むとどうしてもお腹(なか)が痛(いた)くなるんです。Regardless of anything, If I drink milk, I get a stomach ache. 寝(ね)る前(まえ)にお腹(なか)いっぱいに食(た)べるとどうしても寝(ね)れなくなっちゃうんだよね。When I eat till I'm full, before I sleep, I am unable to sleep no matter what. Fun FactAs the closest literal meaning of どう in English is 'any', どうしても also translates quite accurately as 'in any case'. どうしてもヘリコプターには乗(の)りたくない。In any case, I don't want to ride a helicopter.

example.japanese: どうしてもお土産(みやげ)を買(か)いたい。
example.english: I want to buy a souvenir no matter what.

example.japanese: 食(た)べるとどうしても眠(ねむ)たくなる。
example.english: If I eat, I get sleepy no matter what.

example.japanese: どうしてもアイスクリームが食(た)べたい。
example.english: I want to eat ice cream no matter what.

example.japanese: 君(きみ)にどうしても伝(つた)えたいことがある。
example.english: There is something I want to tell you, no matter what.

example.japanese: この癖(くせ)はどうしても治(なお)らない。
example.english: No matter what I do, this habit won't go away.

synonym.explanation: no matter how
even if, even though, no matter how
regardless of, whether or, no matter, with or without
even if, even though, no matter, whether… or
regardless of, whether or not, no matter, with or without
even if, no matter
no matter how (much)
regardless of whether

english_grammar.title: もしも～なら
english_grammar.explanation: if, supposing
english_grammar.structure: もしも + Phrase［なら］(1) (1) Phrase［ば］、Phrase［と］、Phrase［ても］
english_grammar.about: もしも is an adverb in Japanese that strengthens the base meaning of もし 'a bit'. Therefore, the literal meaning of もしも is 'even a bit'. Despite this, as もし and もしも are almost exclusively paired with sentences that use some sort of assumption, or 'hypothesis' based expression, もしも will often be translated as 'supposing that'.もしも will be used at the beginning of sentences that include almost any form of hypothesis expression. For example, ば, と, なら, or ても. もしも、今年(ことし)中(じゅう)に引(ひ)っ越(こ)すのならば、僕(ぼく)が手伝(てつだ)ってやるよ。Supposing that you move within this year, I will help you. もしも仕事(しごと)で怪我(けが)をすると、現場(げんば)が止(と)まるので気(き)をつけてください。Supposing that you get hurt at work, the site will be shut down, so please be careful. もしも明日(あした)休(やす)みなら、一緒(いっしょ)に博物館(はくぶつかん)へいかない？Assuming you have a day off tomorrow, do you want to go to the museum with me? もしも彼(かれ)がいたとしても、今日(きょう)中(じゅう)には終(お)わらなかっただろう。Supposing he even were here, don't you think we would not have been able to complete it by today? Although もしも is considered a stand-alone adverb, it is just a combination of もし, and the adverbial particle も.Caution もし and もしも are most often used to express some type of result. This means that (B) will happen if (A) happens, or if (A) is true. However, たとえ is contrastive, and therefore asks 'what the result' of a specific situation may be. もし、また宿題(しゅくだい)を忘(わす)れたら親(おや)に電話(でんわ)をします。Assuming you forget your homework again, I will call your parents. (Calling their parents will be the result of forgetting their homework) たとえ、テストが難(むずか)しくても最後(さいご)まで諦(あきら)めないで頑張(がんば)ってください。If, for example, the test is hard, don't give up, and do your best until the very end. (If the test is difficult, doing your best is not a result, just one of many choices that could be made)

example.japanese: もしもドラえもんがいたなら、助(たす)けてもらえるのに。
example.english: If Doraemon were here, he would help us.

example.japanese: もしも僕(ぼく)がドラえもんでも助(たす)けられない。
example.english: Even if I were Doraemon I would be unable to help.

example.japanese: もしも戦(たたか)うなら囲碁(いご)がいい。
example.english: If we are going to battle, I say we settle it with a game of Go.

example.japanese: もしもこの計画(けいかく)が実現(じつげん)したなら、この街(まち)はもっと住(す)みやすくなるでしょう。
example.english: If the plan becomes a reality, this town will become much easier to live in.

example.japanese: シリクス：「もしも生(う)まれ変(か)わるなら、その時(とき)も僕(ぼく)と結婚(けっこん)してくれる？」
example.english: Sirix: "If you were reborn, would you marry me again?"

synonym.explanation: even if…is the case, supposing that
If, If it's the case, As for (conditional)
If [for emphasis]
Or something, Any... (with question words), No matter (who)

english_grammar.title: 同士(どうし)
english_grammar.explanation: fellow・with each other, mutually, between・among, together・with
english_grammar.structure: Noun + 同士 Noun + 同士 + の + Noun
english_grammar.about: 同士(どうし) 'fellow' is a noun that may be used in the same way as a suffix. When used this way, it conveys things that are 'mutually (A)', 'fellow (A)', or '(A) together'.To use 同士(どうし), attach it directly to the end of another noun, before expressing further information about that 'mutual' relationship. Alternatively, (noun + 同士(どうし) + の + noun) is also common, and expresses that noun (B) is a grouped form of noun (A). これは弁護士(べんごし)同士(どうし)の話(はな)しなので勝手(かって)に入(はい)って来(こ)ないで下(くだ)さい。This is a conversation between lawyers, so please don't barge in. 家族(かぞく)同士(どうし)で会話(かいわ)をするときはほとんど日本語(にほんご)です。When we talk between family members, we mostly use Japanese. 彼(かれ)は友達(ともだち)同士(どうし)の約束(やくそく)を破(やぶ)った。He broke a promise that was made between friends. お互(たが)い大人(おとな)同士(どうし)なんだから、落(お)ち着(つ)いて話(はな)し合(あ)おうよ。We are fellow adults, so let's calm down and talk about this. 同士(どうし) is used most often to express two different types of 'mutuality'. These are as follows:種類(しゅるい) - Type. (A) is the same type as (B).関係(かんけい) - Relationship. (A) shares the same relationship as (B). あなたたちは本当(ほんとう)に似(に)たもの同士(どうし)ね。You guys are really similar (in personality). それは兄弟(きょうだい)同士(どうし)の問題(もんだい)でしょ？私(わたし)を巻(ま)き込(こ)まないで。 That is an issue between siblings, isn't it? Don't pull me into it. Caution 同士(どうし) is most frequently used to highlight 'people', or 'living things' that share some type of relationship, rather than inanimate objects. An easy way to remember this is that the 士(し) kanji in this word means 'gentleman'. However, it may occasionally be seen in reference to inanimate objects as well. この糊(のり)は紙(かみ)同士(どうし)だとよくくっつきますがプラスチック同士(どうし)だとあまりくっつかないです。This glue sticks really well between paper, but between plastic, it does not stick well. (Natural, but not very common) プロの格闘家(かくとうか)同士(どうし)の戦(たたか)いは見(み)ていて楽(たの)しい。Watching a fight between two professional martial artists is fun. (Natural)

example.japanese: キリンは雄(おす)同士(どうし)が喧嘩(けんか)をする時(とき)互(たが)いに長(なが)い首(くび)で打(う)ち合(あ)う。
example.english: When male giraffes fight among themselves they hit each other with their long necks.

example.japanese: そのため、日本(にほん)の企業(きぎょう)会社(かいしゃ)同士(どうし)の協力(きょうりょく)が以前(いぜん)よりも必要(ひつよう)だ。
example.english: Because of that, cooperation among Japanese companies is needed more than before.

example.japanese: 負(ま)けた者(もの)同士(どうし)で飲(の)みに行(い)こうよ！
example.english: Those among us who have lost, let's go drinking!

example.japanese: 「だって」は家族(かぞく)や友達(ともだち)同士(どうし)などで使(つか)う、くだけた表現(ひょうげん)なので、上司(じょうし)などとの話(はな)し合(あ)いのときは使(つか)わないでください。
example.english: “だって” is an informal expression used among family and friends, therefore please do not use it when discussing with superiors and the like.

example.japanese: このように紐(ひも)でページ同士(どうし)を結(むす)びつけることができます。
example.english: You can connect pages together with a string like this.

synonym.explanation: of the, among(st)
in, among, within

english_grammar.title: がたい
english_grammar.explanation: hard to, difficult to
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ がたい
english_grammar.about: Coming from the same kanji as 難(むずか)しい 'difficult', 難(がた)い is a suffix that also means 'difficult'. However, in the case of がたい, it will be attached to the conjunctive form of verbs, and conveys that '(A) is difficult to do'. がたい is almost always written without kanji in this meaning. あいつが言(い)う事(こと)は信(しん)じがたいが、今(いま)は信(しん)じるしかない。It is hard to believe what he says, but we have no choice but to trust him. 言(い)いがたかったから言(い)わなかったけど、シャツ反対(はんたい)だよ。I didn't say this because it's hard to say, but your shirt is inside out. Compared to にくい, which can simply imply that something is 'uncomfortable' to do, がたい refers almost exclusively to 困難(こんなん)であること 'things that involve a high degree of difficulty, distress, or infeasibility'. Due to this, がたい will come across as far stronger than にくい, and may imply that a certain task is almost impossible. 彼(かれ)の声(こえ)は聞(き)こえにくい。His voice is a bit tricky to hear. (It is kind of hard to hear his voice, based on my ability/feeling) この話(はなし)が信(しん)じがたいのは分(わ)かるが、信(しん)じてくれ！ I understand that this story is impossible to believe, but please believe me! (Believing something like this is not easy) Summed up, these nuances basically translate as the following:にくい - Something is difficult based on someone's opinion, experience, or general feeling.がたい - Something is difficult based on the task itself having a high level of difficulty.

example.japanese: 皆(みんな)から近寄(ちかよ)りがたいってよく言(い)われます。
example.english: I am often told that I am hard to approach.

example.japanese: あの人(ひと)の言(い)っていることは信(しん)じがたいですね。
example.english: It’s hard to believe what that person is saying.

example.japanese: 皆(みんな)はその映画(えいが)が面白(おもしろ)いって言(い)っているけど、僕(ぼく)はその映画(えいが)が成功(せいこう)するとは言(い)いがたい。
example.english: Everyone is saying that that movie is interesting, but I find it hard to say that it will succeed.

example.japanese: 忘(わす)れがたい出来事(できごと)に遭遇(そうぐう)した。
example.english: I encountered an event that is nearly impossible to forget.

example.japanese: その人(ひと)は信(しん)じがたいほど勇敢(ゆうかん)だった。
example.english: That person was brave to the point that was nearly impossible to believe.

synonym.text: ようがない・ようもない
synonym.explanation: there's no way to, it's impossible to
Difficult to, Hard to

english_grammar.title: まさか
english_grammar.explanation: I never dreamed, never・no way, don't tell me・you don't say
english_grammar.structure: まさか + Phrase
english_grammar.about: Almost always written purely in hiragana, まさか is a combination of まさ, a noun meaning 'precise', or 'exact', and the adverbial particle か. In modern Japanese, まさか is thought of as a single adverb meaning 'it can't be true', 'no way', or 'don't tell me'.As it is treated primarily as an adverb, まさか will most often appear at the beginning of a sentence, before some statement about what the speaker is shocked/surprised about. まさかタナカ君(くん)もこのジムに通(かよ)っているとは思(おも)っていなかったよ。I never would have believed that you also came to this gym. まさか彼(かれ)がキャプテンなんて。Don't tell me that he is the captain! Fun Factまさ comes from 正(まさ), meaning 'precise' or 'actual'. However, this noun is very rarely used in modern Japanese. まさに is an adverb used to mean 'precisely', while まさか is another adverb used to mean 'no way!'. However, the literal meaning of まさか is closer to 'is it true?', or 'is it actually?', due to か's role in creating questions. 全然(ぜんぜん)待(ま)っていないですよ。僕(ぼく)も今(いま)まさに着(つ)いたところです。I didn't wait at all. I actually just arrived now. まさかリアがフランスに帰(かえ)るって本当(ほんとう)なの？ Is it actually true that Lia is going back to France?

example.japanese: まさかこんなところで君(きみ)に出会(であ)えるなんて⁉︎
example.english: I never dreamed I would meet you in a place like this!

example.japanese: まさかこの問題(もんだい)が出(で)るなんて予想(よそう)していませんでした。
example.english: I never would have thought that this problem (on a test) would come up.

example.japanese: まさかこんな賞(しょう)をいただけるなんて、夢(ゆめ)にも思(おも)いませんでした。
example.english: I never even dreamed that I would receive this prize.

example.japanese: まさかこんな大雪(おおゆき)が降(ふ)るなんて思(おも)わなかった。
example.english: I never dreamed it would snow this much.

example.japanese: 最近(さいきん)羽振(はぶ)りがいいね。まさか…宝(たから)くじでも当(あ)たったの？
example.english: Recently, things really turned around for you. Hey...You don't say, did you win the lottery or something?

english_grammar.title: 前者(ぜんしゃ)は～後者(こうしゃ)は
english_grammar.explanation: the former・the latter, the first・the second
english_grammar.structure: 前者は + (Comment) 後者は + (Comment)
english_grammar.about: Used in almost exactly the same way as 'the former' and 'the latter' in English, 前者(ぜんしゃ) and 後者(こうしゃ) are two nouns that appear frequently in Japanese. The adverbial particle は will appear after these words, to express contrast between the two.前者(ぜんしゃ) will be used for 'the former', while 後者(こうしゃ) will represent 'the latter'. Both 前者(ぜんしゃ) and 後者(こうしゃ) appear at the beginning of their own statements, with a specific comment about each being made after は. どの大学(だいがく)に行(い)くか迷(まよ)っています。前者(ぜんしゃ)は家(いえ)に近(ちか)いが学費(がくひ)が高(たか)い、後者(こうしゃ)は家(いえ)から遠(とお)いが学費(がくひ)が半分(はんぶん)ぐらい安(やす)い。I am undecided on which college to go to. The Former is close to my house, but the tuition is expensive. The latter is far from my house but the tuition is almost half the price. 地下鉄(ちかてつ)と新幹線(しんかんせん)、前者(ぜんしゃ)は地下(ちか)をゆっくりとはしり、後者(こうしゃ)は速(はや)いスピードで地上(ちじょう)を走(はし)る。Subways and bullet trains. The former runs slowly underground, and the latter runs above ground at a high speed. Caution Statements made that use 前者(ぜんしゃ) and 後者(こうしゃ) require some sort of relationship in what is being compared. Usually, this will be obvious within the context of the sentence, but is something that you will need to be careful of when making your own sentences. こっちの車(くるま)とこっちの車(くるま)どっちを買(か)おう。前者(ぜんしゃ)は安(やす)くて古(ふる)くて、後者(こうしゃ)は高(たか)くて新(あたら)しい。 (Natural)This car and this car, which should I buy? The former is cheap and old, and the latter is expensive and new. 明日(あした)動物園(どうぶつえん)に行(い)くか今夜(こんや)本(ほん)を読(よ)むかで、迷(まよ)っています。前者(ぜんしゃ)は動物(どうぶつ)がいて空(す)いている、後者(こうしゃ)は寝(ね)る前(まえ)にゆっくりできる。 (Unnatural)I am undecided on whether to go to the zoo tomorrow, or to read a book tonight. The former has animals and isn't crowded, but the latter is relaxing before bed.

example.japanese: A社(しゃ)とB社(しゃ)、どちらに就職(しゅうしょく)するか迷(まよ)っています。前者(ぜんしゃ)は給料(きゅうりょう)がよく、後者(こうしゃ)は環境(かんきょう)がいいのです。
example.english: I am having trouble deciding between company A and company B. The former's pay is good and the latter has a good working environment.

example.japanese: 宿泊(しゅくはく)場所(ばしょ)の候補(こうほ)が二(ふた)つあります。前者(ぜんしゃ)は温泉(おんせん)があり、後者(こうしゃ)はご飯(はん)がおいしいです。
example.english: There are two choices for places to stay. The first has hot springs, the second has delicious food.

example.japanese: 交通(こうつう)の札(ふだ)には切符(きっぷ)と整理券(せいりけん)の２つがあります。前者(ぜんしゃ)は電車(でんしゃ)に乗(の)るために必要(ひつよう)なもので、後者(こうしゃ)はバスに乗(の)るときに取(と)るものです。
example.english: There are two types of transportation tickets: “kippu’ and “seiriken”. The former is a thing needed for getting on a train, and the latter is taken when boarding on a bus.

example.japanese: どちらのパソコンがいいですか？前者(ぜんしゃ)は安(やす)いが性能(せいのう)は一般(いっぱん)向(む)け、後者(こうしゃ)は高(たか)いが高性能(こうせいのう)。
example.english: Which laptop is better? The former is cheap, but the specifications are average. The latter is expensive, but has better performance.

example.japanese: どちらの家(いえ)にするか迷(まよ)っています。前者(ぜんしゃ)は駅(えき)から近(ちか)いが家賃(やちん)が高(たか)い、後者(こうしゃ)は駅(えき)から遠(とお)いが家賃(やちん)も安(やす)く部屋(へや)も広(ひろ)い。
example.english: I can’t decide which house to rent. The former is close to the station, but expensive. The latter is far from the station, but cheap and spacious.

synonym.explanation: After, Later
Before, In front of

english_grammar.title: つい
english_grammar.explanation: accidentally, unconsciously, against one's better judgement
english_grammar.structure: つい + Phrase
english_grammar.attention: Usually ends with てしまう
english_grammar.about: Appearing most frequently at the beginning of sentences, つい is an adverb that may be translated as 'accidentally', 'unconsciously', 'absentmindedly', or 'against one's better judgment'. つい will often be paired with statements that use てしまう, to emphasize that something was unintentional. ごめんタケシ君(くん)のクッキーが目(め)の前(まえ)にあったからつい食(た)べてしまった。Sorry Takeshi-kun, your cookie was right in front of me, so I absentmindedly ate it. 先生(せんせい)に怒(おこ)られると、つい笑(わら)っちゃうんだよね。When I am being scolded by the teacher, I accidentally laugh. 運転中(うんてんちゅう)に携帯(けいたい)を使(つか)ったらだめなのは分(わ)かっているんだけど、メールが来(く)るとつい携帯(けいたい)を見(み)ちゃう。I know that I shouldn't use my phone while driving, but when I get a text I unconsciously look at my phone. Fun FactAlthough 'accidentally' is the most common meaning of つい, it actually may be used to convey three different nuances. These are as follows:はからず - Something that is uncalculated.思(おも)わず - Something that is not thought about.距離(きょり)がわずかなさま - A small gap/interval.In each of these meanings, つい keeps a sense of time being the most important factor. Due to this, つい will give the impression that whatever resulted in the 'accidental' action, will be something that happened momentarily. This is very close to the meaning of 'lapse' in English. 'a lapse in time', 'a lapse in judgment', 'a lapse in forethought'. 早(はや)く起(お)きて準備(じゅんび)をしても、つい遅(おく)れてしまう。Even if I wake up early to get ready, I'll be late due to a lapse of time. 電車(でんしゃ)が遅(おく)れると、ついイライラしてしまう。When the train is late, I'll get angry due to a lapse in judgment. お腹(なか)が空(す)いていなくても、目(め)の前(まえ)に食(た)べ物(もの)があるとつい食(た)べてしまう。Even if I am not hungry, if there is food in front of me, I will eat it due to a lapse of forethought.

example.japanese: ダイエット中(ちゅう)なのに、ついアイスクリームを食(た)べてしまう。
example.english: Against my better judgement, I eat ice cream while on a diet.

example.japanese: 笑(わら)ってはいけないのに、つい笑(わら)ってしまうことになる。
example.english: Since I am not supposed to laugh, it feels like I might accidentally laugh.

example.japanese: 運転(うんてん)中(ちゅう)、ついよそ見(み)をしてしまう。
example.english: While driving, I become unconsciously inattentive.

example.japanese: 「つい食(た)べ過(す)ぎてしまう」なんて言(い)い訳(わけ)だ。
example.english: Saying things like: "I unconsciously eat too much" is just an excuse.

example.japanese: 仕事(しごと)中(ちゅう)でもついスマホをいじってしまう。
example.english: I always find myself unconsciously fiddling with my smartphone while I am working.

synonym.explanation: suddenly, unnoticed, without noticing, too soon
to do something by accident, to finish completely・totally, unfortunately

english_grammar.title: せいで
english_grammar.explanation: because of, due to, blame
english_grammar.structure: Verb + せいで ［い］Adjective + せいで ［な］Adjective + な + せいで Noun + の + せいで
english_grammar.attention: Can express blame or fault, で can be omitted at the end of a sentence
english_grammar.about: Although written almost exclusively in hiragana, せい is a noun that may be better understood from its kanji, 所為(せい), meaning 'doings'. せい is used to convey negative results that occurred due to the behavior or actions of another person/thing. Because of this, common translations of せい are 'fault', 'due to', or 'because of'.As せい is a noun, it may be used after the attributive form of any other word. The case marking particle で will also regularly be seen after せい, especially when conveying the (B) result that occurred 'with' or 'by means of' those 'doings'. 昨日(きのう)夜(よる)遅(おそ)くまで起(お)きていたせいで寝坊(ねぼう)した。Because I stayed up late last night, I overslept today. 外(そと)が寒(さむ)いせいで風邪(かぜ)を引(ひ)いた。Because it is chilly outside, I caught a cold. 犬(いぬ)の手術(しゅじゅつ)の事(こと)が心配(しんぱい)なせいで今日(きょう)は寝(ね)れなさそう。Due to me being worried about my dog's surgery, it doesn't seem like I am going to be able to sleep. 大雪(おおゆき)のせいで道(みち)が渋滞(じゅうたい)してる。Because of the heavy snow, the road is congested. Fun FactThe 'doings' that 所為(せい) represents is similar to the negative 'doings' that is used in English to place blame. This can be seen in phrases such as 'it was the weather's doings', or 'ah, so the missing cookies were your doings!' 遅刻(ちこく)したのは渋滞(じゅうたい)のせいだ！Me being late is the traffic's doing! 台風(たいふう)のせいでまた予定(よてい)が変(か)わったよ。 Due to the typhoon's doings, my plans have changed again.

example.japanese: トムは暑(あつ)さのせいで気(き)を失(うしな)った。
example.english: Tom passed out because of the heat.

example.japanese: トムがお皿(さら)を割(わ)ってしまったせいで、私(わたし)は怪我(けが)をしてしまった。
example.english: I got injured because Tom broke a plate.

example.japanese: 気分(きぶん)が悪(わる)くなったせいで、仕事(しごと)を休(やす)んでしまった。
example.english: Because I wasn't feeling well, I took the day off.

example.japanese: 雨(あめ)のせいでせっかくの遠足(えんそく)が中止(ちゅうし)になってしまった。
example.english: The long awaited trip was cancelled because of the rain.

example.japanese: 湿気(しっき)のせいでカビがひどい。
example.english: The mold is out of control because of the humidity.

synonym.explanation: due to, because of, as a result of
thanks to, because of
due to, on account of, each/every
For that reason, because of that, to that end

english_grammar.title: 癖(くせ)に
english_grammar.explanation: even though, and yet, despite
english_grammar.structure: Verb + くせに ［い］Adjective + くせに ［な］Adjective + な + くせに Noun + の + くせに
english_grammar.about: 癖(くせ) is a noun that means 'habit' or 'tendency'. However, as it usually refers to a negative thing, 'vice' is another accurate translation. くせに (usually appearing without kanji) is the combination of くせ, and the case marking particle に. This structure is often used to criticize the actions of others, and is used in a similar way to 'despite', 'even though', or 'and yet' in English.As くせ is a noun, くせに may be used after the attributive form of any other word. さっき寝(ね)るって言(い)ってたくせにまだ起(お)きてるの？Even though you said that you are going to sleep earlier, are you still up? 若(わか)いくせに何(なに)ダラダラしているんだ。Why are you working so sluggishly even though you are young? 自分(じぶん)だって下手(へた)なくせに何(なに)偉(えら)そうに言(い)ってるんだ。Despite you also being no pro, why are you talking so high and mighty. この子(こ)は犬(いぬ)のくせにニャーと鳴(な)く。Even though he is a dog, he meows. Fun Fact癖(くせ) is a word that has developed a 'negative' meaning over time. Originally, 癖(くせ) was used to convey a preference, or the side that someone or something tended to lean toward (due to it being favorable for some reason). When adding the case marking particle に to this, it merely expressed that (A) was the preferable state/location, so (B) not being/not acting in a way appropriate for (A) is less than desirable.

example.japanese: 給料(きゅうりょう)を沢山(たくさん)もらうくせに、貯金(ちょきん)がないらしい。
example.english: Despite getting paid a lot, I have heard that he has no savings.

example.japanese: 休(やす)みのくせに、家(いえ)の手伝(てつだ)いを何(なに)もしない。
example.english: Even though it is your day off, you don't help at all with the housework.

example.japanese: 暑(あつ)いくせに、あの人(ひと)は毎日(まいにち)セーターを着(き)て仕事(しごと)に行(い)く。
example.english: It is hot and yet, that person wears a sweater to work everyday.

example.japanese: あの人(ひと)は先輩(せんぱい)のくせに、いつも僕(ぼく)におごらせようとする。
example.english: Despite being my senior, he/she always tries to make me pay.

example.japanese: 何(なに)も知(し)らないくせに、偉(えら)そうなことを言(い)うのはやめてください。
example.english: Despite not knowing anything, you surely act high and mighty. Please just stop.

synonym.explanation: Despite, Although, Even though
but still, and yet, even so, nevertheless
but, even while, even though, despite, although
and yet, despite this
despite, in spite of, regardless, nevertheless
even while ~ing, even though ~ing, despite ~ing, although ~ing
But, However

english_grammar.title: がち
english_grammar.explanation: apt to do, tend to do, prone to do
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ がち Noun + がち Noun (1) + がち + な(2) + Noun (1) Verb［ます］ (2) の
english_grammar.about: がち is a suffix in Japanese that will be used after nouns, or the conjunctive form of verbs. It conveys that someone is 'apt to (A)', 'tends to (A)', or 'is prone to (A)'. Although not always negative, がち is most frequently used to express negative tendencies. ここに来(く)るといつもパフェを頼(たの)みがちだけど、今日(きょう)はパンケーキを頼(たの)む。When I come here I always tend to order parfait, but today I am getting a pancake. うちの子(こ)は病気(びょうき)がちなので、週(しゅう)に二(に)、三(さん)日(にち)ぐらいは学校(がっこう)を休(やす)みます。My son tends to get sick a lot, so he will take 2 to 3 days off of school. サボりがちな人(ひと)はだいたい成績(せいせき)が悪(わる)い。People who tend to skip school usually have bad grades. Fun Factがち as a grammar structure comes from the word 勝(が)ち, meaning 'a win'. 勝(が)ち in itself is used to express something that appears 'repeatedly', or 'again and again'. Due to this, がち may be thought of as similar to 'to win out' in English, meaning that 'although there are many possibilities, (A) winning out is the most likely'. This 'winning out' may be due to preference, or sheer good/bad luck. 暇(ひま)なときはテレビを見(み)がちだけど、忙(いそが)しい時(とき)には全然(ぜんぜん)見(み)ない。Watching TV wins out when I am bored, but when I am busy I don't watch it at all. 俺(おれ)が回(まわ)すと当(あ)たりがちだから、俺(おれ)にやらせてみろ。Hitting the jackpot wins out when I spin it, so why don't you let me do it. 釣(つ)れないことはありがちだから、落(お)ち込(こ)まなくてもいいよ。そういう日(ひ)もあるさ。 Times that you cannot catch anything often win out, so don't be so upset. It happens.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の息子(むすこ)は病気(びょうき)がちだ。
example.english: My boy is apt to get sick.

example.japanese: サボりがちな生徒(せいと)を家(いえ)まで迎(むか)えに行(い)って、学校(がっこう)へ連(つ)れてきた。
example.english: I went to the house of the student who tends to skip school, and brought him back.

example.japanese: あの人(ひと)はすぐ、痩(や)せることを諦(あきら)めがちだ。
example.english: That person is prone to quickly give up on losing weight.

example.japanese: 車(くるま)ばかり乗(の)っていると、運動(うんどう)不足(ぶそく)になりがちだ。
example.english: If you are always riding around in a car, you tend to not get enough exercise.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は元気(げんき)だと思(おも)われがちですが、実(じつ)は体(からだ)が弱(よわ)いんです。
example.english: I am prone to be considered energetic, but I actually have a delicate constitution.

synonym.explanation: -ish・-like, characteristic of, typical of, tendency to
Have a tendency to, tend to, be slightly~

english_grammar.title: 気味(ぎみ)
english_grammar.explanation: looking, feeling a little, touch of, tending to, slightly
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ 気味 Noun + 気味
english_grammar.about: Coming from the noun 気味(きみ) meaning 'sensation', ぎみ is a suffix that is used to convey weak signs of (A). ぎみ may be used with nouns, or the conjunctive form of verbs. Often, ぎみ is translated as 'looking (A)', 'a touch of (A)', 'feeling a little (A)', or 'slightly (A)'. 最近(さいきん)太(ふと)り気味(ぎみ)だから、ダイエットしなきゃ。I feel slightly fat, so I should go on a diet. 今週(こんしゅう)は色々(いろいろ)と忙(いそが)しかったから疲(つか)れ気味(ぎみ)だ。Because I have been busy this week with various things, I am feeling a little tired. 今朝(けさ)は風邪(かぜ)気味(ぎみ)だったので、学校(がっこう)を休(やす)んだ。Because I felt a little sick this morning, I took a day off of school. ぎみ refers to the senses of the person who is experiencing them, and therefore may be used to refer to feelings about other people/things, or feelings about oneself. 現場(げんば)の人(ひと)がほとんどバテ気味(ぎみ)だったので、作業(さぎょう)を中断(ちゅうだん)した。Most of the people on the site seemed a little worn out, so we stopped work. 電車(でんしゃ)が遅(おく)れ気味(ぎみ)だから、待(ま)ち合(あ)わせ時間(じかん)まで間(ま)に合(あ)わないかも。Because the train seems a bit late, I might not be able to make it by our agreed time. 風邪(かぜ)気味(ぎみ)なのかな？身体(からだ)がだるい。I feel like I have a cold, my body feels heavy. As ぎみ expresses 'weak signs of (A)', it is often used to soften a statement, so that the speaker does not appear overconfident. タカシ君(くん)疲(つか)れ気味(ぎみ)じゃない？ちゃんと休憩(きゅうけい)取(と)った？Takashi-kun, you look a bit tired, did you take a proper break? Caution Although it comes from 気味(きみ), ぎみ will always be said with a ぎ, and not a き. This is a sound change used to distinguish the noun and the suffix.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)は風邪(かぜ)気味(ぎみ)だと言(い)った。
example.english: She said she was feeling a little sick.

example.japanese: 最近(さいきん)、彼女(かのじょ)は太(ふと)り気味(ぎみ)らしい。
example.english: I heard that lately, she is a bit plump.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は発表(はっぴょう)前(まえ)に緊張(きんちょう)気味(ぎみ)で倒(たお)れてしまった。
example.english: I was feeling a little nervous before my presentation and fainted.

example.japanese: 貧血(ひんけつ)気味(ぎみ)なので、採血(さいけつ)はやめておきましょう。
example.english: Since you are looking somewhat anemic, let's not draw any blood.

example.japanese: 最近(さいきん)疲(つか)れ気味(ぎみ)だから、少(すこ)し休(やす)んだ方(ほう)がいい。
example.english: You should rest for a bit, because recently you are looking a little tired.

synonym.explanation: ~ly・~like・~al, typical
have a feeling that
-ish・-like, characteristic of, typical of, tendency to
seemingly, giving appearance of, [expresses emotions or feelings]

english_grammar.title: っぽい
english_grammar.explanation: -ish・-like, characteristic of, typical of, tendency to
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ っぽい ［い］Adjective［い］+ っぽい ［な］Adjective + っぽい Noun + っぽい
english_grammar.attention: Often has negative connotation.
english_grammar.about: っぽい (occasionally also seen as ぽい) is a suffix that may be attached to many different types of words, in order to create new い-Adjectives. In all cases, っぽい indicates something that is 'exhibiting characteristics of (A)'. This is most often in reference to the way (A) is acting, or the way (A) looks. In English, っぽい may be translated as '(A)ish', '(A)like', or 'tendency to (A)'. っぽい quite often carries a negative connotation. As っぽい creates い-Adjectives from other words, it may be used with the conjunctive form of verbs, or the 語幹(ごかん) (stem form) of any other word. 私(わたし)は飽(あ)きっぽいから、何(なに)も続(つづ)かない。Because I have a tendency to get sick of things, I can't continue with anything. 白(しろ)っぽいやつをください。Please give me the whiteish one. タナカ君(くん)はファッション業界(ぎょうかい)では有名(ゆうめい)っぽいよ！Apparently Tanaka-kun is popular in the fashion industry! 今(いま)の話(はなし)は嘘(うそ)っぽいけど本当(ほんとう)の話(はなし)なの。The story I just told you sounds like a lie, but it is actually true. Caution As っぽい creates new い-Adjectives, っぽい itself may be conjugated in exactly the same way as regular い-Adjectives. 昔(むかし)は紫(むらさき)っぽかったのに今(いま)はなぜか赤(あか)っぽい。Back in the day, it was purpleish, but now for some reason it is reddish. この靴(くつ)なんか安(やす)っぽくない？Don't these shoes look cheapish? Caution The fundamental meaning of っぽい will change depending on what type of word it is being used with. The general rules are as follows:Verb + っぽい - To have a tendency to do (A).Adjective + っぽい - To exhibit all the signs of being (A).Noun + っぽい - To obviously not be (A), although show signs of being (A).From this, we can see that っぽい is generally based on the opinion of the speaker, rather than the innate qualities of what is being observed. Thus, with verbs, adjectives, and nouns, the speaker feels like (A) is in excess, compared to what would be expected. This 'being in excess of what is normal' in the opinion of the speaker is what creates the negative connotation.

example.japanese: トムは記憶力(きおくりょく)がいいどころか、忘(わす)れっぽいよ。
example.english: Let alone having a good memory, Tom is forgetful.

example.japanese: このカバンは安(やす)っぽいけど、タグを見(み)たら高(たか)かった。
example.english: This bag looks cheap, but I looked at the tag and it was expensive.

example.japanese: 唐揚(からあ)げは油(あぶら)っぽくて、食(た)べたいと思(おも)わない。
example.english: I don't even think about wanting to eat deep-fried chicken because it looks too greasy.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は飽(あ)きっぽいから、趣味(しゅみ)を始(はじ)めてもすぐにやめてしまう。
example.english: Because he has tendency to lose interest and give up, he quits soon after starting a new hobby.

example.japanese: 寅(とら)さんは惚(ほ)れっぽく、飽(あ)きっぽい。
example.english: Tora-san has the tendency to fall in love, and also has the tendency to lose interest.

synonym.explanation: typical of, -ish・like, appropriate for, becoming of, befitting
~ly・~like・~al, typical
to pretend, to act as if
apt to do, tend to do, prone to do
looking, feeling a little, touch of, tending to, slightly

Look like, Appear, Seem, Have a feeling that
Seems like, Apparently, I heard

english_grammar.title: っぱなし
english_grammar.explanation: leaving something in a certain state, left as is, keep on -ing
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ っぱなし
english_grammar.about: っぱなし is a suffix that originally comes from the う - Verb 放(はな)す 'to let loose'. When attached to the conjunctive form of verbs, it is used to indicate that something has been 'left' in a certain state. っぱなし is almost exclusively used negatively. また電気(でんき)点(つ)けっぱなしじゃん！何回(なんかい)言(い)えば消(け)してくれるの？You left the light on again! How many times do I have to tell you to turn it off? 冷蔵庫(れいぞうこ)を開(あ)けっ放(ぱな)しにしないで下(くだ)さい。Please don't leave the refrigerator open. 歯(は)を磨(みが)いている間(あいだ)、水(みず)を出(だ)しっぱなしにしていたら、お母(かあ)さんに怒(おこ)られた。Because I left the water on while I was brushing my teeth, my mother scolded me. Fun FactAlthough 放(はな)す means 'to let loose', っぱなし conveys a feeling that is closer to 'being unchecked'. This means っぱなし can be used to convey that 'the act of (A)' is continuing without anyone there to stop it, or that the 'state of (A)' is continuing without anyone there to stop it. Which meaning is conveyed will depend mostly on the (A) verb. 勝(か)ちっぱなしだとつまらないね、たまには負(ま)けを味(あじ)わいたい。Don't you think it is boring to keep winning? I want to taste defeat sometimes. (I want to lose sometimes) 秋(あき)の間(あいだ)は窓(まど)を開(あ)けっぱなしにして寝(ね)ています。During autumn, I sleep with the windows left open.

example.japanese: 誰(だれ)かがそのドアを開(あ)けっぱなしにした。
example.english: Someone left the door open.

example.japanese: ライトをつけっぱなしにしないで。
example.english: Don't leave the light on.

example.japanese: 渋滞(じゅうたい)のせいで、１０分(ぷん)間(かん)止(と)まりっぱなしだった。
example.english: Because of the traffic, I was at a standstill for ten minutes.

example.japanese: 電話(でんわ)が鳴(な)りっぱなしだけど…大丈夫(だいじょうぶ)？
example.english: Your phone keeps ringing... Is that not a problem?

example.japanese: 3時間(じかん)も立(た)ちっぱなしで、足(あし)が棒(ぼう)になってしまいました。
example.english: I kept standing for 3 hours, now my legs feel as heavy as lead.

synonym.explanation: as is, while remaining, left in a state

english_grammar.title: わざわざ
english_grammar.explanation: expressly・especially, go out of one's way, take the trouble to
english_grammar.structure: わざわざ + Phrase
english_grammar.attention: わざと means "on purpose!"
english_grammar.about: わざわざ is an adverb that is used to express when someone has gone out of their way to achieve a certain result. It may be translated as 'expressly', 'especially', or 'to go out of one's way to (A)'.わざわざ will usually be used at the beginning of sentences, before some statement will be made about an active that was intentionally done. わざわざ私(わたし)が好(す)きな饅頭(まんじゅう)を買(か)いに行(い)ってくれたの？ありがとう！You went out of your way to buy me my favorite manju? Thank you! わざわざ会社(かいしゃ)に行(い)って仕事(しごと)しなきゃいけない理由(りゆう)がわからない、別(べつ)に家(いえ)でも出来(でき)るのに。I don't understand the reason to go out of my way to go into an office to work, I can work from home. わざわざ has a tendency to be used positively, although it may be used with negative connotations as well. わざわざここまで来(き)てくれてありがとうございます。 Thank you very much for going out of your way to come here. (Positive) 何(なん)でわざわざそういうひどいこと言(い)うの？Why do you go out of your way to say something so mean? (Negative) Fun FactAlthough almost never used, 態態(わざわざ) may be seen in this kanji form. 態(わざ) is a kanji used to express 'purpose', or 'intent'. Generally, it refers to someone's 'willingness' to do something. As such, わざわざ just expresses that (A) is something that the speaker has as a strong goal. How it will be translated depends more on whether the actual result is positive, negative, or undecided.Positive result - To purposefully do (A), with the result of (A).Negative result - To have every intention of (A), with the actual result of (B).Undecided result - To be intent on (A), with (A) hopefully happening.Caution わざと is a construction that comes from the same kanji as わざわざ. わざと generally only conveys 'on purpose', while わざわざ has many more potential meanings (due to being stronger). わざと押(お)したでしょ？あんた最低(さいてい)。You pushed me on purpose, didn't you? You are the worst. 何(なん)でわざわざ邪魔(じゃま)しに来(く)るの？Why do you come here especially to bother me?

example.japanese: わざわざここまで働(はたら)きに来(き)ているんですね。
example.english: I see you came here expressly to work.

example.japanese: わざわざ批判(ひはん)しなくてもいいのに。
example.english: You didn't have to go out of your way to criticize.

example.japanese: わざわざ独(ひと)りで行(い)くんですか？
example.english: You will go out of your way just to go by yourself?

example.japanese: こんな遠(とお)くまでわざわざ来(き)てくださってありがとうございます。
example.english: Thank you for going out of your way to come so far.

example.japanese: わざわざ傘(かさ)を返(かえ)しに来(き)てくれたの？
example.english: Did you come all the way here expressly to return the umbrella?

english_grammar.title: 一体(いったい)
english_grammar.explanation: (what) the heck?, (who) in the world?, (where) on earth?, (how many) f*ing...
english_grammar.structure: いったい + Question Word + Phrase
english_grammar.about: In order to convey the feeling of 'what the heck', with any 'how', 'what', 'where' or 'why' type question, the adverb 一体(いったい) will be used in Japanese. いったい appears frequently both with, and without kanji.いったい will usually be seen at the beginning of sentences, before some statement about what the speaker finds unbelievable. 一体(いったい)ここで何(なに)が起(お)きたんだ！What the heck happened here? これは一体(いったい)どういうことだ。What is the meaning of this? The literal meaning of いったい is 'one body', or 'one form'. In this way, when paired with questions, いったい can be thought of meaning 'in a way that can be understood, what is (A)', or 'in a way that makes sense, what is (A)'. 一体(いったい)なんでこんな事(こと)になったの？Explain to me in a way that makes sense, why something like this happened? 一体(いったい)なんであんな奴(やつ)と付(つ)き合(あ)ようと思(おも)ったの？In a way that I can understand, why did you think of dating someone like him? Fun FactLike the 'one body', or 'one form' meaning mentioned above, 一体(いったい) is sometimes used to mean 'in general', or 'generally' when seen as 一体(いったい)に. However, this use is slowly becoming less common, partly due to how often 一体(いったい) is used simply to express surprise or shock. アメリカ人(じん)は一体(いったい)に親切(しんせつ)です。Americans are generally polite.

example.japanese: いったいいつになったら外出(がいしゅつ)の準備(じゅんび)ができるんだろう。
example.english: When on earth are you going to be ready to go out?

example.japanese: 今年(ことし)納(おさ)める税金(ぜいきん)はいったいいくらになるかしら。
example.english: I wonder how much freaking tax I will pay this year.

example.japanese: この牧場(ぼくじょう)にはいったい何(なん)匹(びき)の牛(うし)がいるかな。
example.english: I wonder how many freaking cows there are on this farm.

example.japanese: この気持(きも)ちの悪(わる)い生(い)き物(もの)はいったい何(なん)ですか？
example.english: What on earth is this ugly creature?

example.japanese: 僕(ぼく)たちの未来(みらい)はいったいどうなるんだろう…
example.english: What on earth will become of us in the future?

synonym.explanation: how…what..., god knows...

english_grammar.title: 折角(せっかく)
english_grammar.explanation: with trouble, at great pains, take the trouble, might as well..., rare/long-awaited occasion
english_grammar.structure: せっかく + Phrase せっかく + の + Noun (of Event)
english_grammar.about: 折角（せっかく) is an idiomatic adverb that is often used to express doing something 'with trouble', 'at great pains', or 'to be a rare/long-awaited occasion'. Being an adverb that often modifies the meaning of a whole sentence, it will commonly appear at the beginning of a statement. When 折角(せっかく) is nominating an event as being long awaited, it will appear directly before the event, separated only by the case marking particle の. せっかく君(きみ)が欲(ほ)しかった靴(くつ)を買(か)ってあげたのに友達(ともだち)にあげたの？最悪(さいあく)。I took great trouble to get you the shoes that you wanted, but you gave them to your friend? How inconsiderate. せっかく休(やす)みを取(と)ったのに雨(あめ)が降(ふ)ったから予定(よてい)が台無(だいな)しだ。I went through the trouble to get a day off, but it rained, so my plans were ruined. せっかくの誕生日(たんじょうび)会(かい)を台無(だいな)しにしてごめんなさい。Sorry for ruining your long awaited birthday party. 台風(たいふう)のせいで、せっかくの休暇(きゅうか)が中止(ちゅうし)になった。Due to the typhoon, my long awaited vacation has been canceled. Fun FactThere are several guesses for where 折角(せっかく) originates. One of the most common is that it is an abbreviation for 頭巾(ずきん)の角(つの)を折(お)る 'to fold the horn (tail) of a hood'. This was something that a famous confucian did intentionally to protect his hood from getting wet in the rain. The people of the time started to copy the act, and 折角(せっかく) also came to be used as an idiom to mean 'intentionally', or 'to go out of one's way to do something'.

example.japanese: せっかく日本語(にほんご)を毎日(まいにち)数時間(すうじかん)勉強(べんきょう)したのに、日本語(にほんご)能力試験(のうりょくしけん)に落(お)ちたかと心配(しんぱい)して落(お)ち込(こ)んだ。
example.english: I took great trouble to study Japanese for hours each day, but I got worried about whether I had passed the JLPT or not, and got depressed.

example.japanese: せっかく異世界(いせかい)に転移(てんい)したのに、チートをもらうどころか、ただの自動販売機(じどうはんばいき)になった。
example.english: Even though I went through the trouble of being transported to a parallel universe, instead of getting cool powers, I became a simple vending machine.

example.japanese: せっかくのデートが風邪(かぜ)でつぶれた。ちょっと残念(ざんねん)だよ。
example.english: A long-awaited date was spoiled because I caught a cold. It is a little disappointing.

example.japanese: 妻(つま)のためにせっかく家(いえ)を構築(こうちく)したけど、離婚(りこん)した。努力(どりょく)はみんな無駄(むだ)だった。落(お)ち込(こ)んでいる。
example.english: Even though I went through great pains to build a house for my wife, we divorced. All of my efforts were in vain. I feel down.

example.japanese: せっかくの友達(ともだち)との遠足(えんそく)だから、たくさん遊(あそ)びたい。
example.english: Since this trip with friends is a rare occasion, I want to have a lot of fun.

english_grammar.title: っけ
english_grammar.explanation: what is…again?, was it... that... ?, did you say...?
english_grammar.structure: Verb［た］+ っけ Verb［る］+ ん(1)だ + っけ ［い］Adjective［た］+ っけ ［な］Adjective + だった(2) + っけ Noun + だった(2) + っけ (1) の (2) だ
english_grammar.attention: While Verb[る] + ん/の + だ/だった + っけ should be used, younger generation of Japanese simply uses Verb[る] + っけ
english_grammar.about: け is a sentence ending particle in Japanese that is used to convey when the speaker is trying to either remember, or confirm information that they have forgotten. In this way, it is very similar to the 'again' in 'what is (A) again?'け may only be used after the past form of the auxiliary verbs だ or た. This means that け (should) only be seen as だっけ or たっけ. 今日(きょう)の朝(あさ)は朝(あさ)ご飯(はん)を食(た)べたっけ。Did I eat breakfast this morning? あれ、テイラーの車(くるま)って青(あお)かったっけ。Um, Taylor, was your car blue, again? 土曜日(どようび)って暇(ひま)だっけ。Was I free on Saturday, again? あの人(ひと)誰(だれ)だっけ。やばい、思(おも)い出(だ)せない。Who was that again? Shoot, I can't remember. It is also common to see のだ and んだ utilized to make verb tenses a possibility. クミコって納豆(なっとう)食(た)べれるんだっけ。Kumiko, were you able to eat natto again? レポートの修正(しゅうせい)は君(きみ)がやってるんだっけ。You are the one editing the paper, right? Caution Despite the grammar rules related to っけ, the younger generation quite often uses it without the addition of んだ (especially with verbs). トムって日本語(にほんご)話(はな)せるっけ。Tom, were you able to speak Japanese again? この道(みち)って通(とお)れるっけ。Were we able to take this road again? While it is important to understand that this is still っけ, it is not a grammatically correct form that may be used in writing (or formal speaking).Fun Factけ will sound equally natural when asking a rhetorical question to yourself, or when directly asking another person about something that you have forgotten. あれ、カギ掛(か)けたっけ。 Umm, did I lock the door?
