(Asking oneself) あそこのレストランって犬(いぬ)を連(つ)れていけるっけ。Do you remember if we could take our dogs to that restaurant over there? (Asking another)

example.japanese: トムの友達(ともだち)って、会(あ)ったことあったっけ？
example.english: Did you say that you had met Tom's friend?

example.japanese: 日本(にほん)の文化(ぶんか)について発表(はっぴょう)をしたのは誰(だれ)だったっけ？
example.english: Who was it that gave the talk about Japanese culture?

example.japanese: そんなもの家(いえ)にあったっけ？
example.english: Was it that you had something like that at home?

example.japanese: 沖縄(おきなわ)には行(い)ったことないんだっけ？
example.english: Did you say that you had never been to Okinawa?

example.japanese: 明日(あした)って晴(は)れるんだっけ？
example.english: Was it that it will be sunny tomorrow?

synonym.explanation: Question marking particle

english_grammar.title: 代(か)わりに
english_grammar.explanation: instead of, in place of, in exchange for
english_grammar.structure: Verb + 代わりに ［い］Adjective + 代わりに ［な］Adjective + な + 代わりに Noun + の + 代わりに
english_grammar.about: 代(か)わり 'a substitute' is a noun that is used to convey when (B) is acting as a replacement or substitute for (A). The case marking particle に will come after 代(か)わり, before a (B) statement will highlight who the replacement is, and possibly what they are doing.As 代(か)わり is a noun, it may be used after the attributive form of any word. 俺(おれ)が社長(しゃちょう)に電話(でんわ)する代(か)わりに、お前(まえ)はお客(きゃく)さんに電話(でんわ)をしておいて。In exchange for me calling the boss, can you call the client in advance? あのプールは古(ふる)い代(か)わりに安(やす)い。That pool is cheap, to substitute for it being old. 仕事(しごと)は大変(たいへん)な代(か)わりに楽(たの)しい。Work is fun, in exchange for it being difficult. 私(わたし)の代(か)わりにやってください。Can you do it in my place? Occasionally, 替(か)わり 'to exchange' may be used instead of 代(か)わり 'to substitute'. However, within the context of this particular grammar structure, there is little to no change in nuance.Fun Fact代(か)わりに is often used at the beginning of sentences, simply to express a more preferable option for something. In these cases, it comes across as 'rather than that, (A)', or 'instead, (A)'. 代(か)わりに行(い)ってくれない？As a replacement, can you go for me? 代(か)わりにこれを持(も)って行(い)って。Instead of that, can you go take this?

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の代(か)わりにこの問題(もんだい)を解(と)いてください。
example.english: Please solve this question instead of me.

example.japanese: バナナが嫌(きら)いで食(た)べれないからビタミンが取(と)れない。バナナの代(か)わりに何(なに)を食(た)べたらいい？
example.english: I don't like bananas so I don't eat them and can't get those vitamins. What should I eat in place of a banana?

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)が遅刻(ちこく)をしてしまったので、彼(かれ)の代(か)わりに発表(はっぴょう)した。
example.english: Since he was late, I presented instead of him.

example.japanese: 先生(せんせい)が風邪(かぜ)をひいて休(やす)んだので、代(か)わりに校長(こうちょう)先生(せんせい)が授業(じゅぎょう)をした。
example.english: Because the teacher caught a cold and took the day off, the principal taught the class in his place.

example.japanese: コーヒーの代(か)わりに紅茶(こうちゃ)では駄目(だめ)ですか？
example.english: Is tea in place of coffee not good enough?

synonym.explanation: rather・instead・over
in place of, on behalf of, to succeed

english_grammar.title: に代(か)わって
english_grammar.explanation: in place of, on behalf of, to succeed
english_grammar.structure: Noun + に代わって(1) (1) に代わり
english_grammar.about: に代(か)わって is an expression that will only appear with nouns, conveying that (B) is doing something 'in place of (A)', or 'on behalf of (A)'. This is a combination of the case marking particle に, the う - Verb 代(か)わる 'to substitute', and the conjunction particle て. 妹(いもうと)に代(か)わって、私(わたし)が買(か)い物(もに)に行(い)くことに決(き)まった。It has been decided that I am going to go shopping in place of my sister. 私(わたし)が彼女(かのじょ)に代(か)わって会議(かいぎ)に出(で)ます。I will be attending the meeting in place of her. に代わり may also be used, as this is the formal conjunctive. Also known as the conjunctive form. タナカさんに代(か)わり、今日(きょう)は私(わたし)があなたたちの担当(たんとう)をします。In place of Tanaka-san, today, I am going to be in charge of you guys. 世界中(せかいじゅう)ではファックスに代(か)わりメールが主流(しゅりゅう)になったが、日本(にほん)ではまだファックスしか使(つか)わないところが多(おお)い。All around the world, fax has been replaced by email as the main form of communication, but there still are places in Japan that only use fax. Fun FactIn this construction, に is acting as a location marker, rather than specifically meaning 'for (A)'. What this means is that に代(か)わる is the act of removing (A) from its place, and exchanging it for (B). This is why に代(か)わって may also be used in the meaning of 'to succeed', or 'to replace', as switching (A) to (B) may be permanent. 今日(きょう)は社長(しゃちょう)に代(か)わって、私(わたし)が会議(かいぎ)を進(すす)めます。Today, I will take charge of the meeting in place of the CEO. 父(ちち)に代(か)わって、皆(みんな)に挨拶(あいさつ)をした。In place of my father, I greeted everyone.

example.japanese: あなたが私(わたし)に代(か)わって説明(せつめい)をしてくれてありがとう。
example.english: Thank you for explaining it on my behalf.

example.japanese: 社長(しゃちょう)に代(か)わって、山田(やまだ)さんが乾杯(かんぱい)の挨拶(あいさつ)をします。
example.english: On behalf of the CEO, Mr. Yamada will do the toast.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)に代(か)わって、あなたが発表(はっぴょう)をすることになった。
example.english: It has been decided that you will do the presentation instead of me.

example.japanese: 弁護士(べんごし)：依頼人(いらいにん)に代(か)わって手続(てつづ)きを進(すす)めます。
example.english: Lawyer: I will proceed with the formalities on behalf of my client.

example.japanese: 欠席(けっせき)の課長(かちょう)に代(か)わって私(わたし)が会議(かいぎ)に参加(さんか)しました。
example.english: I attended on behalf of the absent section manager.

synonym.explanation: instead of, in place of, in exchange for

english_grammar.title: どころか
english_grammar.explanation: far from, anything but
english_grammar.structure: Verb(1) + どころか ［い］Adjective + どころか ［な］Adjective + な + どころか Noun + どころか (1)Verb［ない］
english_grammar.about: どころか is a combination of the noun ところ 'place', and the sentence ending particle か. The change from ところ to どころ is a consistent sound change that is seen regularly in sentences that use 所(ところ) negatively.どころか may be translated as 'far from', 'let alone' or 'anything but'. It strongly negates any statement before it, while also emphasizing what comes after it.どころか may be paired with the attributive form of any other word. However, this is not a strict rule, as it can also be seen with the 語幹(ごかん) stem form of な-Adjectives, and directly attached to nouns. このカレーは甘(あま)いどころか、辛(から)かった。Far from being sweet, this curry was spicy. 北海道(ほっかいどう)は寒(さむ)いどころか、暑(あつ)かった。Far from being cold, Hokkaido was hot. 昨日(きのう)の仕事(しごと)は楽(らく)などころか、めちゃくちゃ大変(たいへん)だったよ。Far from being easy, work yesterday was hectic. 彼女(かのじょ)は酎(ちゅう)ハイどころかビールも飲(の)まない。Let alone Chuhai, she doesn't even drink beer. Sentences that use どころか must always have a part (B) that emphasizes some type of far more important information (in the speaker's opinion).Fun FactAs か simply transforms どころ into either a question, or a statement of doubt, the literal translation of どころか is similar to 'it's not even remotely (A)' as a statement, or 'do you honestly think it's (A)!?', when asking a direct question. そんなにゆっくりしているどころか。 This is not the time to be even remotely that relaxed! 俺(おれ)がやるどころか？そんなことをやるのは弟(おとうと)しかいないだろ！Do you honestly think I would do such a thing? My brother is the only person who would do that.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は休(やす)むどころか、全力(ぜんりょく)を出(だ)し切(き)った。
example.english: Far from taking a break, he gave everything he had.

example.japanese: そのケーキは甘(あま)いどころか、酸(す)っぱかった。
example.english: Far from being sweet, that cake was sour.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はヨーロッパまで行(い)くどころか、玄関(げんかん)から一歩(いっぽ)も出(で)ていない。
example.english: Far from going to Europe, he hasn’t even taken a step outside.

example.japanese: 健康(けんこう)にいいものでも、食(た)べすぎたら健康(けんこう)になるどころか病気(びょうき)になりますよ。
example.english: Eating in excess even if it's healthy food is not good for you. Far from that, it will make you ill!

example.japanese: こんなに勉強(べんきょう)しているのに、成績(せいせき)は良(よ)くなるどころか悪(わる)くなっている。
example.english: Despite studying so much, far from getting better, my grades got worse.

synonym.explanation: Definitely not, absolutely not, impossible, do you really think~?
this is not the time for…, far from, out of the question

english_grammar.title: と言(い)う理由(りゆう)で
english_grammar.explanation: For (that) reason; on the grounds of (that), with the reasoning, under the pretext of, due to
english_grammar.structure: (Reason) + という理由で + Phrase (Reason)。 そういう理由で + Phrase
english_grammar.about: という理由(りゆう)で is a phrase that is used when giving reasons for (A). (A) may be a range of different things, from what happened, to what one's opinion is. Due to という quoting the previous statement as being the 'reason', という理由(りゆう)で puts quite a bit of emphasis on the reason itself. Because of this, the expression is quite similar to 'being that' in English.The case marking particle で will be used after 理由(りゆう) to show that 'with' or 'by means of' that reason, (B). コストコは安(やす)く沢山(たくさん)買(か)い物(もの)が出来(でき)るという理由(りゆう)で人気(にんき)がある。At Costco, you can shop for many things at a cheap price. For that reason it is popular. 大変(たいへん)だという理由(りゆう)で彼(かれ)は仕事(しごと)を辞(や)めた。Being that his job was a hassle, he resigned. Fun FactAlmost all cases where という理由(りゆう)で will be used may be replaced by というわけで. However, the reverse is not true. 安(やす)くて美味(おい)しいという理由(りゆう)で、この店(みせ)の前(まえ)にはいつも行列(ぎょうれつ)ができています。Being that this place is cheap and delicious, they always have a long line in front of the store. 一人(ひとり)で行(い)きたくないという訳(わけ)では無(な)いです。一人(ひとり)で行(い)くのは危(あぶ)ないと言(い)いたいのです。It is not so that I don't want to go alone. I am saying that it is dangerous to go alone. という理由(りゆう)で、この企画(きかく)はキャンセルすることにします。 (Unnatural)For that reason, we are going to cancel this plan. というわけで、この企画(きかく)はキャンセルすることにします。 (Natural)Well with that, we will decide on canceling this plan. The reason that わけ may be used for 理由(りゆう), but 理由(りゆう) cannot always be used for わけ (especially at the beginning of sentences) is because 理由(わけ) is another way of reading the kanji for 理由(りゆう). However, the more common kanji for 訳(わけ) will never be read as りゆう.

example.japanese: メアリーさんは仕事(しごと)中(ちゅう)に映画(えいが)を見(み)がちという理由(りゆう)で首(くび)になるかもしれない。
example.english: Mary might be fired on the grounds of her having the tendency to watch movies while at work.

example.japanese: 仕事(しごと)がとても大変(たいへん)だった。そういう理由(りゆう)で、今日(きょう)はゆっくりしたい。
example.english: Work was really rough. For that reason, I want to take it easy today.

example.japanese: 「一方(いっぽう)で、冬(ふゆ)にはお客様(きゃくさま)が来(こ)ないから」という理由(りゆう)で、その頃(ごろ)の店(みせ)はほとんど閉(し)められている。
example.english: "On the other hand," with the reason being that "customers do not come during the winter," most shops are closed.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はともこさんが自分(じぶん)の妻(つま)を殺(ころ)したという理由(りゆう)でともこさんを訴(うった)えた。
example.english: On the grounds of Tomoko-san killing his wife, he is taking Tomoko-san to court.

example.japanese: やまださんは年寄(としよ)りだという理由(りゆう)で、詐欺師(さぎし)によってターゲットによくされている。
example.english: Mr. Yamada is often targeted by con-artists on the grounds that he is elderly.

synonym.explanation: For that reason, because of that, to that end

english_grammar.title: は～となっている
english_grammar.explanation: it is (has been), have/has become, happen to be, has been established
english_grammar.structure: ［な］Adjective + となっている Noun + となっている
english_grammar.about: (A) は (B) となっている is a common expression used to show that '(A) is becoming (B)', or (more commonly) '(A) has become (B)'. This expression will only appear with nouns, or な-Adjectives in their 語幹(ごかん) (stem form). (A) は (B) となっている is often translated as '(A) happens to be (B)', '(A) has been established as (B)', or 'it has been decided that (A) is (B)'. Let's have a look at some examples, and then how this structure is formed. 鬼滅(きめつ)の刃(やいば)は非常(ひじょう)に人気(にんき)となっている。It happens to be that Demon Slayer is very popular. 日本(にほん)ではドラッグは法律上(ほうりつじょう)、違法(いほう)となっている。In Japan, it has been established that drugs are illegal, by law. このプールでは、飛(と)び込(こ)みが禁止(きんし)となっている。At this pool, it happens to be that jumping in is not allowed. Despite the different translations, (A) は (B) となっている always has the same meaning, which can be understood as follows:(A) は - (A) is a constant unchanging thing.(B) と - (B) is a result. (coming form the case marking particle と's role in highlighting results.なっている - (A) is existing in the state 'having arrived at the result of (B)'. 今(いま)の時代(じだい)にはインターネットは必要(ひつよう)となっている。 It is now that the internet is necessary in the present age. この高校(こうこう)ではアルバイトが禁止(きんし)となっている。 It is now that working part-time at this school is prohibited. Due to this, the literal translation may be thought of as 'it is now that (A) is (B)' in almost all situations.Caution (A) は (B) となっている may be rephrased to (A) は (B) になっている. However, に will remove much of the feeling of a 'result', or 'finality'. Due to this, it will just sound like (A) is becoming (B), but is not necessarily that way yet. 今(いま)の時代(じだい)にはインターネットは必要(ひつよう)になっている。It is now that the internet is becoming necessary in the present age. Caution In writing, おる is not always considered a 'formal' equivalent of いる, especially in set phrases. となっている is often seen as となっており, instead of となっていて. This is particularly common in news articles. このイベントは来月(らいげつ)5日(か)からとなっており、明日(あした)から前(まえ)売(う)り券(けん)を買(か)うことができる。It is now that next month's event from the 5th has pre-order tickets that are purchasable from tomorrow.

example.japanese: いくつかの州(しゅう)では21才(さい)未満(みまん)の子供(こども)たちや若者(わかもの)がアルコールを消費(しょうひ)することは違法(いほう)となっている。
example.english: In some states, it has been established that the consumption of alcohol by children and young adults under 21 is illegal.

example.japanese: フランツ・フェルディナント大公(たいこう)の暗殺(あんさつ)が開戦(かいせん)の原因(げんいん)の一(ひと)つとなっている。
example.english: The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand has been established as one of the causes of war.

example.japanese: アメリカをはじめとして、電気(でんき)は主要(しゅよう)な光源(こうげん)となっている。
example.english: Starting with the USA, electricity has become the main source of light.

example.japanese: 中国(ちゅうごく)では男性(だんせい)の女性(じょせい)に対(たい)する割合(わりあい)は１１８対(たい)１００となっている。
example.english: The proportion of men to women in China happens to be 118 to 100.

example.japanese: 納期限(のうきげん)は４月(がつ)３１日(にち)までとなっています。
example.english: The due date of the tax payment has been established as April 31st.

english_grammar.title: 左右(さゆう)する
english_grammar.explanation: influence, impact, control
english_grammar.structure: 左右 + する(1) 左右 + する(1) + Noun (1) される
english_grammar.about: 左右(さゆう) is a noun that may literally be translated as 'left and right'. This particular noun is quite often used as a する verb, in order to convey the level of control someone has over a specific situation. This control may be translated as 'influence', 'impact', 'dictate' or simply 'control'.左右(さゆう)する may be used by itself, when describing a whole clause, or it may be followed directly be another noun, to show exactly what is being controlled/influenced. 新(あたら)しくできる法律(ほうりつ)によって国民(こくみん)の自由(じゆう)が大(おお)きく左右(さゆう)するかもしれません。Depending on the new law that is being made, it may influence the freedom of its citizens. 砂糖(さとう)を入(い)れるか入(い)れないかで、味(あじ)が大(おお)きく左右(さゆう)することがある。Depending on whether you put in sugar or not, there are times where it influences the flavor greatly. 商品(しょうひん)の値段(ねだん)はお客(きゃく)さんが商品(しょうひん)を買(か)うか買(か)わないかを左右(さゆう)することがある。There are times when the price of a product dictates whether the customer will buy it or not. 肉(にく)を焼(や)いてからタレをいれることは、味(あじ)を大(おお)きく左右(さゆう)する原因(げんいん)の一つだ。Cooking the meat before you add the sauce is a factor that will greatly impact the flavor. 左右(さゆう)する is frequently seen in the passive form 左右(さゆう)される. This is used most often when the noun following される is the thing that is being controlled itself, rather than こと or もの referring back to an earlier statement. この人(ひと)は話(はな)す人(ひと)に意見(いけん)を左右(さゆう)されることが多(おお)いです。This person's opinions are easily dictated by those they talk to. 農業(のうぎょう)は天気(てんき)に大きく左右(さゆう)される仕事(しごと)です。Farming is a job that is largely controlled by the weather. Caution 左右(さゆう)する implies direct (A)'s direct control of (B), and is far stronger than to affect '影響(えいきょう)'. Due to this, 左右(さゆう) may be thought of as being closer to 'to dominate' in English. In Japanese though, the most basic description is 思(おも)うままに動(うご)かす 'to move exactly as one wishes'.

example.japanese: 流行(りゅうこう)についてのサイト、記事(きじ)のタイトル：「靴磨(くつみが)きが靴(くつ)の寿命(じゅみょう)と美(うつく)しさを左右(さゆう)する」
example.english: Website about fashion, title of an article: "Polishing shoes influences the shoe’s lifespan and beauty."

example.japanese: 歴史書(れきししょ)：「古代(こだい)ギリシャ人(じん)は自分(じぶん)たちの生活(せいかつ)が神々(かみがみ)に左右(さゆう)されると信(しん)じていた。」
example.english: History book: "Ancient Greeks believed that their lives were influenced by gods."

example.japanese: ビジネス記事(きじ)：「新(あたら)しい法律(ほうりつ)が電気(でんき)自動車(じどうしゃ)の需要(じゅよう)を左右(さゆう)するかもしれない。」
example.english: Business article: "The new law may influence the demand for electric cars."

example.japanese: 教科書(きょうかしょ)：「裁判官(さいばんかん)は賄賂(わいろ)などによって左右(さゆう)されないよう良(い)い給与(きゅうよ)が保証(ほしょう)されている。」
example.english: Textbook: "Judges are guaranteed a decent salary so that they won’t be swayed (influenced) by bribes and the like. "

example.japanese: 記事(きじ)：「平均余命(へいきんよめい)を大(おお)きく左右(さゆう)するのは食生活(しょくせいかつ)や睡眠時間(すいみんじかん)だと考(かんが)えられている。」
example.english: Article: "One’s eating habits and the amount of sleep one gets are thought to have a huge influence on life expectancy."

english_grammar.title: 得(え)る
english_grammar.explanation: is able to, can, possible
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ える(1) Exceptions: Verb［ます］+ えない(*) Verb［ます］+ えた(*) Verb［ます］+ えなかった(*) (1) うる (*) For negative, past and negative past forms, only conjugations of える are used
english_grammar.about: 得(え)る is a る-Verb that has the meaning of 'to gain', or 'to acquire'. When attached to the conjunctive form of verbs, it takes on the nuance of 'for (A) to be possible', or 'to be able to (A)'. もし出来(でき)得(え)るならば、2年後(ねんご)に会社(かいしゃ)を立(た)ち上(あ)げたいと思(おも)っている。If it's possible, I'm thinking of starting a company in two years. いくら気(き)をつけていても、交通(こうつう)事故(じこ)は起(お)こり得(え)るものだ。No matter how careful you are, it's possible for a car accident to occur. Compared to できる, meaning that the potential to do something exists. 得(え)る means something closer to 'there is a possibility that (A) can be done', or 'the possibility to do (A) has been gained'.Caution - 得(え)る may be seen as either える or うる. The primary difference between the two being that うる is a relatively old form that is often seen in literature, and spoken far less frequently than える. Despite this, there is a tendency for うる to be the preferred spoken choice when the kana that appears before it is え, such as 教(おし)える becoming 教(おし)えうる, rather than 教(おし)ええる. そういう事(こと)はセクハラにもなりえるので、そういう事(こと)はやらない方(ほう)がいい。Things like that can be considered as sexual harassment, so you shouldn't do that. 考(かんが)えうる事(こと)は、すべてこの企画書(けいかくしょ)に書(か)いておきました！I wrote everything I can think of on this proposal! Fun-fact - 得(え)る is far more formal/bookish than できる. However, there are several set phrases that are very common in daily speech that use this particular grammar point, such as あり得(え)る 'possible', and あり得(え)ない 'impossible'. うん、それもあり得(え)るね...Yeah, that is also a possibility... 電気代(でんきだい)がまた値上(ねあ)がりするみたいだよ。マジあり得(え)ない。It looks like the electricity bill is going to go up again. There's no way.

example.japanese: 消防士(しょうぼうし)は信頼(しんらい)しうる人(ひと)です。
example.english: Firefighters are people you can trust.

example.japanese: その対策(たいさく)は考(かんが)えうる。
example.english: It is possible to consider that countermeasure.

example.japanese: 耕(たがや)しうる土地(とち)を持(も)っている方(かた)は田植(たう)えができます。
example.english: People who own arable land can plant rice. (can be farmed)

example.japanese: それはありえる。
example.english: That can be possible.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は群衆(ぐんしゅう)の目(め)にも耐(た)えうる精神(せいしん)力(りょく)の持(も)ち主(ぬし)だ。
example.english: He possesses the force of will to be able to endure the piercing eyes of the crowd.

synonym.explanation: unable to, cannot
To be able, Can (potential)

english_grammar.title: 得(え)ない
english_grammar.explanation: unable to, cannot
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ えない
english_grammar.about: 得(え)る is a る-Verb that has the meaning of 'to gain' or 'to acquire'. When attached to the conjunctive form of verbs, it takes on the nuance of 'for (A) to be possible', or 'able to (A)'. In addition to this, when 得(え)る is combined with ない, that nuance switches to 'unable to (A)', or 'cannot (A)'. 我(わ)が社(しゃ)に出来(でき)得(え)ないことなどありません。There is nothing that our company can't do. 警察官(けいさつかん)は信頼(しんらい)し得(え)ないと思(おも)っている人(ひと)たちが増(ふ)えて来(き)た。More people are coming to believe that police officers cannot be trusted. Compared to できない, meaning that the potential to do something does not exist, 得(え)ない means something closer to 'there is no possibility that (A) can be done', or 'the possibility to do (A) has not been gained'.Caution - 得(え)る may be seen as either える or うる. The primary difference between the two being that うる is a relatively old form that is often seen only in literature, and almost never spoken. Despite this, うる is never used in the negative form with ない. そんな大(おお)きな災害(さいがい)は起(お)こりえないと思(おも)います。I think that it's impossible for a disaster that big to happen. (Natural Japanese) そんな大(おお)きな災害(さいがい)は起(お)こりうないと思(おも)います。I think that it's impossible for a disaster that big to happen. (Unnatural Japanese) Fun-fact - 得(え)る is far more formal/bookish than できる. However, there are several set phrases that are very common in daily speech that use this particular grammar point, such as あり得(え)る 'possible', and あり得(え)ない 'impossible'. まあ、それもあり得(え)るかもしれないけど...Well, that is possible, but… 田中(たなか)さんはすごく頭(あたま)がいいので、不合格(ふごうかく)になるなんて絶対(ぜったい)あり得(え)ない。Tanaka-san is very smart, so it is absolutely impossible for him to fail.

example.japanese: 一般(いっぱん)の犯罪者(はんざいしゃ)は信頼(しんらい)し得(え)ない人(ひと)だ。
example.english: The average criminal is a person you can't trust.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)の態度(たいど)があり得(え)ない。
example.english: His attitude is unbelievable.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)がその夢(ゆめ)を叶(かな)えることはあり得(え)ない。
example.english: It is not possible for me to achieve that dream.

example.japanese: 本来(ほんらい)、水(みず)と油(あぶら)は混(ま)ざり得(え)ない。
example.english: Naturally, you cannot mix water and oil.

example.japanese: 二次元(にじげん)のキャラクターは実際(じっさい)に存在(そんざい)し得(え)ないからこそ、人々(ひとびと)の目(め)に魅力(みりょく)的(てき)に映(うつ)るのだ。
example.english: It is precisely because two dimensional characters cannot exist in reality, that they fascinate people.

synonym.explanation: is able to, can, possible
cannot・be unable to, hard to, hesitant to
being unable to finish or complete

english_grammar.title: ざるを得(え)ない
english_grammar.explanation: can't help doing, have no choice but
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］+ ざるを得ない
english_grammar.attention: する→せざるを得ない, くる→こざるを得ない
english_grammar.about: ざる is the 連体形 (attributive form) of the old-fashioned auxiliary verb ざり. ざり carries the same meaning as the modern ない, in negating what comes before it.When joined with a combination of the る-Verb 得(え)る 'to gain', or 'to acquire', and the auxiliary verb ない, it becomes a double-negative structure meaning that one 'cannot help doing (A)', or 'there is no choice but to (A)'. More literally, it means that one 'can't not (A)'.For the most part, this structure will conjugate with other verbs in exactly the same way as ない. 山(やま)の頂上(ちょうじょう)まで登(のぼ)りたかったが、天候(てんこう)が悪(わる)くなって来(き)たので諦(あきら)めざるを得(え)ない。I wanted to hike to the peak of the mountain, but the weather was getting worse so we had no choice but to give up. 先輩(せんぱい)に指示(しじ)されたので従(したが)わざるを得(え)ない。Because my senpai told me to do it, I had no choice but to obey. Caution - As ざり is an old-fashioned structure, it conjugates a little bit differently with する than the regular ない. フランスの大学(だいがく)へ行(い)くため、フランス語(ご)を勉強(べんきょう)しざるを得(え)ない。In order to go to a college in France, I have no choice but to study French. (Unnatural Japanese) フランスの大学(だいがく)へ行(い)くため、フランス語(ご)を勉強(べんきょう)せざるを得(え)ない。In order to go to a college in France, I have no choice but to study French. (Natural Japanese) Notice here that instead of しない changing to しざる, せざる will be used instead.

example.japanese: 田中(たなか)さんはとても忙(いそが)しかったのでゴルフの誘(さそ)いを断(ことわ)らざるを得(え)なかった。
example.english: Mr. Tanaka was so busy he had no choice but to turn down an invitation to play golf.

example.japanese: 今(いま)まで使(つか)った顕微鏡(けんびきょう)が壊(こわ)れたから、新(あたら)しいのを買(か)わざるを得(え)ない。
example.english: The microscope I have been using until now broke, so I have no choice but to buy a new one.

example.japanese: 工場(こうじょう)の排気(はいき)を低(ひく)くせざるを得(え)ない。
example.english: We have no choice but to lower exhaust in the factory.

example.japanese: 話(はな)し合(あ)いが終(お)わらない。会議(かいぎ)室(しつ)を借(か)りる時間(じかん)を延長(えんちょう)せざるを得(え)ない。
example.english: The discussion is not coming to an end. We have no choice but to extend the amount of time allotted to use this meeting room.

example.japanese: 地元(じもと)のチームではないが、甥(おい)っ子(こ)が入団(にゅうだん)したから応援(おうえん)せざるを得(え)ない。
example.english: The team isn't from my home town, but my nephew joined the team so I can't help but cheer for them.

synonym.explanation: very, extremely, can't help but do

synonym.text: ないわけにはいかない
synonym.explanation: Can't not, No way to avoid
can't help but want to, very, extremely
extremely, very・really, it can't be helped
have no choice but, only・just
cannot help doing something, cannot resist doing something

english_grammar.title: つもりで
english_grammar.explanation: with the intention of doing, instead of..., act as if/pretend, believing that..., thinking that...
english_grammar.structure: Verb + つもりで ［な］Adjective + な + つもりで Noun + の + つもりで Act as if・pretend・be convinced: Verb［た］+ つもりで
english_grammar.about: つもりで, being a combination of the noun つもり 'intention', and the case marking particleで 'with', this structure is used in several different ways, depending on what comes before it. When combined with verbs, な-Adjectives or nouns in their plain forms, it implies that (A) is being done with the intention of (B).As つもり is a noun, の will be required before it when grouped with other nouns, while な will be required when linked to な-Adjectives. 何(なに)も買(か)わないつもりで新(あたら)しく出来(でき)たショッピングモールへ行(い)ったが、色々(いろいろ)買(か)ってしまった。I went to the newly built shopping mall without any intention of buying anything, but I ended up purchasing various things. この魚(さかな)新鮮(しんせん)なつもりで買(か)ったのに、パックから出(だ)したらものすごいにおいがした。 I bought this fish intending for it to be fresh, but when I took it out of the package, it smelled unbelievably bad. 冗談(じょうだん)のつもりで言(い)っただけなのに、相手(あいて)を傷付(きずつ)けてしまった。Despite saying it as a joke, I ended up hurting their feelings. However, when paired with verbs in the past form, つもりで implies that the speaker is 'acting as though (A)', 'pretending that (A)', or 'is convinced that (A)'. 今度(こんど)は、主人公(しゅじんこう)になったつもりで読(よ)んでみてください。Next, try reading it as if you were the main character. パーティーでダンサーになったつもりで、みんなの前(まえ)で踊(おど)った。At a party, I danced in front of everybody, as if I was a dancer. This meaning simply comes from the intention of something being contrary to what is actually true.

example.japanese: 日本(にほん)に行(い)ったつもりで、日本語(にほんご)を勉強(べんきょう)しています。
example.english: I am studying Japanese as if I went to Japan.

example.japanese: 今月末(こんげつまつ)までに完成(かんせい)させるつもりで、毎日(まいにち)努力(どりょく)をした。
example.english: With the intention of finishing by the end of the month, I worked on it every day.

example.japanese: お土産(みやげ)のつもりで買(か)ったが、食(た)べてしまった。
example.english: I bought it with the intention of (giving it) as a gift, but ended up eating it.

example.japanese: ご馳走(ちそう)するつもりで行(い)ったのに、おごってもらうことになった。
example.english: Despite going with the intention of treating everyone, they treated me.

example.japanese: こっそり返(かえ)すつもりでペンを借(か)りたのに、返(かえ)すところを見(み)られてしまった。
example.english: Despite borrowing the pen with the intention of returning it secretly, just as I was returning it, I was seen.

synonym.explanation: plan to, intend to
To plan to, To intend to

english_grammar.title: どうせ
english_grammar.explanation: anyhow・ at any rate, in any case, I have no doubt that, probably
english_grammar.structure: どうせ + Phrase
english_grammar.about: どうせ is a 副詞(ふくし) (adverb) used in Japanese to express that some particular state or condition of (A) will result in (B). Usually, there is no way to stop (B) from happening, and it is considered a natural consequence of (A). In English, this translates closely with phrases like 'at any rate', or 'in any case'.Being an adverb, どうせ most often appears at the beginning of sentences, before going on to describe the inevitable situation. どうせまたパチンコに行(い)くんでしょ。In any case, you are going to the pachinko parlor, aren't you? どうせ私(わたし)のことなんて好(す)きじゃないんでしょ。In any case, you probably don't even like me. どうせ often carries the nuance of frustration or resignation that (A) cannot be changed. In these cases, it is often paired with other grammar structures such as なら or だから. This shows that if (A) cannot be changed, then (B) is a good idea. This usage translates similarly to 'if (A), you might as well (B)'. どうせ新(あたら)しいスマホを買(か)うならもうちょっといい奴(やつ)買(か)いなよ。If you're going to buy a new smartphone, you might as well buy something a little better. どうせまた負(ま)けるんだから頑張(がんば)っても時間(じかん)と体力(たいりょく)の無駄(むだ)だよ。We're going to lose again anyway, so trying our best would be a waste of time and energy. Fun-fact - This grammar structure comes from a combination of どう 'how', and the imperative form of する, せよ. In this way, it is just emphasizing that no matter 'how (A) is done', the result cannot be changed.

example.japanese: どうせ車(くるま)を買(か)うのなら、ヒーターシートが付(つ)いているのを買(か)おう！
example.english: If we are buying a car anyway, let's buy one with heated seats.

example.japanese: この試験(しけん)の難(むずか)しさから考(かんが)えると、どうせ失敗(しっぱい)するに決(き)まっている。
example.english: Judging from the difficulty of the exam, I have no doubt that my failure has been decided.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)がどう謝(あやま)っても、どうせ彼(かれ)は許(ゆる)すつもりはないだろう。
example.english: No matter how much I apologize, I have no doubt that he won't forgive me.

example.japanese: どうせ｢ウドの大木(たいぼく)だ｣と悪口(わるぐち)を言(い)われるのがオチだ。
example.english: I have no doubt that it will just end with me being called "big and useless".

example.japanese: どうせダイアモンドなんて買(か)ってもらえない。
example.english: I have no doubt I won't be able to get them to buy me diamonds.

synonym.explanation: no wonder, after all, in fact, because, at any rate
By any account, all the same, no doubt
It is a fact that ~, There is no doubt that

english_grammar.title: せめて
english_grammar.explanation: at least
english_grammar.structure: せめて + Phrase
english_grammar.about: Coming from the verb 責(せ)める, meaning to have the 'onus to do (A)', せめて is an adverb that indicates that doing (A) is the minimum expected in order to achieve some desired outcome. It is often translated simply as 'at least' in English.せめて usually alters the meaning of an entire phrase, and will appear at the beginning of sentences. ご飯(はん)は残(のこ)しても良(い)いから、せめて刺身(さしみ)だけは全部(ぜんぶ)たべて。You can leave the rice, but at least finish the sashimi please. せめて国語(こくご)の宿題(しゅくだい)はやっておきなさい。At least finish your Japanese homework in advance. Stemming from 責(せ)める, this structure usually implies that there is some sort of onus or responsibility to do (A), rather than (A) simply being a minimum amount. Due to this, it is often used with grammar points that express desire or opinions such as たい, ほしい, てほしい, べき, and others. せめてこの曲(きょく)だけでも弾(ひ)けるようになりたい。I want to be able to play this song, at least. えっ... たったの5千円(せんえん)だけ？せめて1万(まん)は欲(ほ)しいよ。What…only five-thousand yen? I want at least ten-thousand yen. 別(べつ)に毎日(まいにち)洗濯(せんたく)をしろっては言(い)わないけど、せめて晩御飯(ばんごはん)だけは毎日(まいにち)作(つく)ってほしい。I'm not telling you to do laundry everyday, but I want you to at least make dinner every night. 1日(にち)にせめて1リットルの水(みず)を飲(の)むべきだ。You should drink at least 1 liter of water a day.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)はせめてドアくらい閉(し)めて行(い)けばいいのに…
example.english: She could have at least closed the door...

example.japanese: 親(おや)：せめておかずだけ食(た)べて。
example.english: Mother: At least eat your sides (side dish).

example.japanese: マラソンで勝(か)つのは無理(むり)だけど、せめて、完走(かんそう)したい…
example.english: I realize it is not possible to win the marathon, but I want to finish it at least...

example.japanese: ライトノベルの主人公(しゅじんこう)：君(きみ)は居候(いそうろう)だから、せめて自分(じぶん)の料理(りょうり)は自分(じぶん)でするべきだよ。
example.english: The protagonist of a light novel: You are a freeloader, so at least you should cook your own food!

example.japanese: かつてのようなパワーに達(たっ)せないけど、せめて半分(はんぶん)に達(たっ)せればいいんだけど。
example.english: I cannot reach the level of power I had before, but I hope I can attain at least half of it.

english_grammar.title: どうやら
english_grammar.explanation: apparently, looks like, seems like
english_grammar.structure: どうやら + Phrase + みたいだ(1) (1) ようだ、そうだ 、らしい、って 感じだ
english_grammar.about: どうやら can be translated as 'apparently', or 'it seems like', and is often grouped together with other phrases of speculation such as ようだ, そうだ, and らしい. Due to this, どうやら simply strengthens the uncertainty of things that the speaker is already unsure about. This is in a similar fashion to phrases like 'in some way it seems like (A)'.Like many adverbs that express amount or speculation, どうやら will appear at the beginning of sentences and modify the meaning of the entire phrase. 鈴木(すずき)くんはいるか？居(い)ないのかな？どうやら今日(きょう)も休(やす)んでいるみたいだね。Is Suzuki-kun present? Maybe he's not here? It seems like he's taking today off as well. どうやら私(わたし)は彼女(かのじょ)には必要(ひつよう)がないようだ。It seems like I am not needed by her. どうやら彼(かれ)は結婚(けっこん)しているらしいよ。I heard that he is apparently married. Fun-fact - While classified as a standalone adverb, どうやら is originally a combination of どう 'how' and やら, a 助詞(じょし) (particle) that is used for denoting uncertainty about singular things or lists. With this in mind, it is similar to the way that 'or whatever', or 'or some such' may be added to a sentence in English in order to emphasize that (A) is not certain. お隣(となり)の鈴木(すずき)さんがどうやら来月(らいげつ)からイギリスに行(い)くらしいですよ。Our neighbor, Suzuki-san, is apparently going to England next month, or something.

example.japanese: どうやら、俺(おれ)は電気(でんき)をつけっぱなしにしたらしい。すみません。
example.english: It looks like I was the one that left the light on. I'm sorry.

example.japanese: 知(し)ってた？ どうやら田中(たなか)さんは彼氏(かれし)と別(わか)れて、今(いま)はフリーらしいよ。
example.english: Did you know? Apparently, Tanaka broke up with her boyfriend and is single now!

example.japanese: 結婚式(けっこんしき)の客(きゃく)１：あれは誰(だれ)？結婚式(けっこんしき)の客(きゃく)2：どうやら花嫁(はなよめ)の兄(あに)みたいだな。
example.english: Wedding Guest 1: Who is that? Wedding Guest 2: Apparently, it is the bride's elder brother.

example.japanese: NHK 集金人(しゅうきんにん)：どうやら、私(わたし)はこの辺(あた)りでは歓迎(かんげい)されないようだ...
example.english: NHK Collector: Apparently, I am not welcome here.

example.japanese: あの二人(ふたり)、どうやら 結婚(けっこん)してる感(かん)じだよ。
example.english: It seems like those two are married.

english_grammar.title: より他(ほか)ない
english_grammar.explanation: to have no choice but, no other way than, have to
english_grammar.structure: Verb + より + ほか + （は(1)）+ ない (1) に、には
english_grammar.about: Used in a similar way to しかない, より他(ほか)ない is a structure that emphasizes that only (A) is possible, when attached to the end of verbs. This grammar pattern is a combination of the case marking particleより 'than', or 'from', the noun 他(ほか) 'other', and the い-Adjective, ない. From this it can be translated directly as 'there is nothing other than (A)'. However, the emphasis is usually on the impossibility of doing anything other than (A), rather than the existence of nothing else.Common interpretations include 'to have no choice but to (A)', 'there is no other way than (A)', or simply 'have to (A)'. 人身(じんしん)事故(じこ)のせいで電車(でんしゃ)が止(と)まったので、会社(かいしゃ)までタクシーで行(い)くよりほかはなかった。Because the train stopped due to an accident, I had no choice but to take a taxi to work. 靴(くつ)に穴(あな)が空(あ)いたので、新(あたら)しいのを買(か)うよりほかない。I have no choice but to buy a new pair of shoes because there's a hole in mine. Occasionally, the particles に, は, or a combination of both as には may come between 他(ほか) and ない. While this does not change the meaning, it does further emphasize the point that there is no choice but (A). 被害者(ひがいしゃ)が無事(ぶじ)であることを祈(いの)るよりほかにない。There is nothing we can do other than pray that the victims are safe. 誰(だれ)もお婆(ばあ)さんを助(たす)けようとしなかったので、私(わたし)が助(たす)けるよりほかはなかった。No one was trying to help the old lady, so I had no choice but to help her. 仕事(しごと)をクビになったので新(あたら)しい仕事(しごと)を探(さが)すよりほかにはない。I got fired from my job, so I have no choice but to look for a new one.

example.japanese: 部長(ぶちょう)：そのプロジェクトは時間(じかん)とお金(かね)の無駄(むだ)だったので、融資(ゆうし)を諦(あきら)めるよりほかはない。
example.english: Department Head: Because the project was a waste of time and money, there is no choice but to give up on financing it.

example.japanese: 車(くるま)を出(だ)せなかったので、自転車(じてんしゃ)で行(い)くよりほかはなかった。
example.english: Because I couldn't get my car out, I had no choice but to ride my bike.

example.japanese: 急(きゅう)に田中(たなか)さんはキスしてくれたので、驚(おどろ)くよりほかはなかった。
example.english: Because Tanaka-san suddenly kissed me, there was no choice but to be surprised.

example.japanese: 泥棒(どろぼう)の攻撃(こうげき)から守(まも)るためだったため、相手(あいて)を撃(う)つよりほかにはなかった。
example.english: Since it was in order to defend myself against the thief, I had no choice but to shoot him.

example.japanese: ここまでびしょ濡(ぬ)れになったら、服(ふく)を買(か)って着替(きが)えるよりほかない。
example.english: If you become drenched to this extent, there is no choice but to buy clothes and change.

synonym.explanation: there is no choice but, can't be helped, inevitable
have no choice but, only・just
nothing but, none other than, simply

english_grammar.title: 確(たし)かに
english_grammar.explanation: surely, certainly
english_grammar.structure: 確かに + Phrase
english_grammar.about: 確(たし)かに is the adverbial use of the な-Adjective 確(たし)か, meaning 'to be certain', or 'to be assured'. It may be used in the same way as 'certainly' or 'surely' in English, especially when the speaker wants to highlight (A) is definitely the case. 確(たし)かに彼(かれ)はイケメンですが、マナーが悪(わる)いです。He is certainly handsome, but he has bad manners. 確(たし)かにさっきのは言(い)い過(す)ぎだった。ごめん。What I said earlier was certainly out of line. I'm sorry. Caution - 確(たし)かに as 'certainly' is only used for verifying information, and does not carry the nuance of giving permission, as it does in English. 確(たし)かに結構(けっこう)難(むずか)しいね。ちょっと甘(あま)く見(み)てたわ。This is certainly difficult. I underestimated it. (Natural Japanese) 確(たし)かに！宿題(しゅくだい)が終(お)わってるならゲームをしてもいいよ。Certainly! You may play video games if you finish your homework. (Unnatural Japanese) Caution - When the に is removed, 確(たし)か is often used in a similar way to 'if I remember correctly', 'if I'm not mistaken', or 'now that you mention it'. あの人(ひと)は確(たし)かたくやくんのおじさんだったような気(き)がする。If I recall correctly,I feel like that person is Takuya-kun's father. そう言(い)えば、前(まえ)いくら借(か)りたっけ？確(たし)か３千円(ぜんえん)だったよね？ By the way, how much money did I borrow the other day? If I remember correctly, it was three-thousand yen, correct?

example.japanese: 確(たし)かに彼(かれ)は信頼(しんらい)できます。
example.english: You can certainly rely on him.

example.japanese: 確(たし)かにその服(ふく)はあなたに似合(にあ)う。
example.english: Those clothes certainly look good on you.

example.japanese: 学校(がっこう)の規則(きそく)上(じょう)、確(たし)かに生徒(せいと)は先生(せんせい)に従(したが)うべきだ。
example.english: From the standpoint of the school's rules, students should certainly obey their teacher.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)のうちは音楽(おんがく)一家(いっか)らしいが、確(たし)かに楽器(がっき)がうまい。
example.english: I heard he is from a musical household, but he is certainly skilled with an instrument.

example.japanese: 移籍金(いせききん)はかなりの額(がく)だったが、確(たし)かに活躍(かつやく)している。
example.english: The fee for transferring (to another team) was a considerable amount, but (he) is certainly actively participating.

english_grammar.title: 一応(いちおう) ①
english_grammar.explanation: just in case, just to be sure
english_grammar.structure: 一応 + Phrase
english_grammar.about: When used as a 副詞(ふくし), 一応(いちおう) can often carry the nuance of (A) not being perfect, but the minimum required in order to prevent (B). This particular nuance of 一応(いちおう) may be interpreted as 'just in case, (A)', or 'just to be sure (A)'. 今日(きょう)はずっと晴(は)れって天気(てんき)予報(よほう)で言(い)ってたけど曇(くも)ってきたから 一応(いちおう)傘(かさ)を持(も)って行(い)ったほうがいいかも。They said it was going to be sunny all day today on the forecast, but it's starting to get cloudy so it might be better to bring an umbrella just in case. これで大丈夫(だいじょうぶ)だと思(おも)うけど、 一応(いちおう)チェックしておいてくれない？I think this is fine, but just to be sure, can you please double check it for me? When 一応(いちおう) is used this way, it frequently highlights that (B) happening is unlikely, but the precautionary measure of (A) might be a good idea to avoid it. This is in contrast to another common use of 一応(いちおう) which can be translated as 'more or less', or 'for the time being'. However, in both of its uses, it simply indicates the minimum amount of (A) which is fulfilling some requirement. 田中(たなか)：「仕事(しごと)慣(な)れてきた？」鈴木(すずき)：「はい、 一応(いちおう)...」Tanaka: 'Have you gotten used to work?' Suzuki: 'Yes, more or less…' 一応(いちおう)はよくなってるみたいですけど、また来週(らいしゅう)病院(びょういん)まで来(き)てください。For the time being, it seems like you're getting better, but please come to the hospital again next week.

example.japanese: 何(なに)かをテストする前(まえ)の、従業員(じゅうぎょういん)の間(あいだ)での話(はなし)：「（そんなことには気(き)にしないと思(おも)うが）一応(いちおう)伝(つた)えておきます。」
example.english: Before testing something, a conversation between employees: "(I don’t think they really care, but) Just in case, I will tell them in advance."

example.japanese: ルームメイトの間(あいだ)での話(はなし)：「Facebookアカウントは一応(いちおう)持(も)ってるけど、あまり使(つか)ってない。」
example.english: Chat between roommates: "I have a facebook account just in case, but I don’t use it much."

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)の間(あいだ)での話(はなし)：「彼(かれ)は私服(しふく)でいいと言(い)っていたけど、一応(いちおう)スーツを着(き)ていた。」
example.english: Conversation between friends: "He said that plain clothes are okay, but just in case, he wore a suit."

example.japanese: 教師(きょうし)が生徒(せいと)に：「ハサミは必要(ひつよう)じゃないと思(おも)うけど、一応(いちおう)用意(ようい)してください。」
example.english: Teacher, to students: "I do not think that we will need scissors, but just in case, please prepare them."

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)は助言(じょげん)する：「引越(ひっこ)ししたら、一応(いちおう)、隣近所(となりきんじょ)に挨拶(あいさつ)しないとね。」
example.english: A friend is giving advice: "If you move, just in case, greet the neighbors."

synonym.explanation: more or less, for the time being, tentatively・roughly
just in case, in the worst-case scenario, in the unlikely event, by any chance

english_grammar.title: 一応(いちおう) ②
english_grammar.explanation: more or less, for the time being, tentatively・roughly
english_grammar.structure: 一応 + Phrase
english_grammar.about: When used as a 副詞(ふくし), 一応(いちおう) can often carry the nuance of (A) not being perfect or ideal, but the minimum required in order to satisfy some requirement. This 'requirement' is frequently related to the time or amount of something. When used this way, 一応(いちおう) may be interpreted as 'more or less, (A)', 'for the time being, (A)', or 'tentatively (A)'. 一応(いちおう)私(わたし)が店長(てんちょう)ですが、どうかなされましたか。I'm more or less the manager. Did something happen? 今日(きょう)は一応(いちおう)ここまでにしておきましょう。For the time being, let's call it a day for today. 周(まわ)りの人(ひと)たちが立(た)ち始(はじ)めたので、僕(ぼく)も一応(いちおう)立(た)った。People around me started to stand up, so tentatively, I also stood up. This use of 一応(いちおう) is in contrast to the other common use of 一応(いちおう), which can be translated as 'just in case', or 'just to be sure'. In these cases, the speaker is usually indicating that (A) is being done in order to avoid or prevent (B). However, in both of its uses, it simply indicates that (A) is the minimum amount which is fulfilling some requirement. 今夜(こんや)は寒(さむ)くなるかも知(し)れないから、一応(いちおう)ジャケットかなんか持(も)ってきな。 Why don't you take a jacket or something, just in case, since it might get cold tonight. 一応(いちおう)言(い)っておくけど私(わたし)は踊(おど)るのが下手(へた)だからね。Just to be sure, I want to let you know that I am not a good dancer.

example.japanese: 転(ころ)んだ友達(ともだち)１に話(はな)しかける友達(ともだち)２：「大丈夫(だいじょうぶ)？」友達(ともだち)１：「一応(いちおう)。」
example.english: Friend2 talks to Friend1 who has fallen: "Are you ok?"Friend1: "More or less."

example.japanese: 就職(しゅうしょく)の面接(めんせつ)、面接官(めんせつかん)：「英語(えいご)ができますか？田中(たなか)さん。」田中(たなか)さん：「私(わたし)は日常的(にちじょうてき)な英会話(えいかいわ)ぐらいなら一応(いちおう)できますが、ビジネスで英語(えいご)を使(つか)うのは自信(じしん)がありません。」
example.english: Job interview, the interviewer: "Can you speak English, Mr. Tanaka?"Mr. Tanaka: "I am more or less able to do day-to-day conversations, but I don't feel confident in using English in business."

example.japanese: 警察官(けいさつかん)：「こんにちは、警察(けいさつ)から来(き)ました。オーナーと話(はなし)をしたいです。」エリアスさん：「一応(いちおう)私(わたし)がオーナーのエリアスです。」
example.english: Policeman: "Hello, I have come from the police station. I would like to speak with the owner."Elias: "I am Elias, more or less the owner."

example.japanese: 医者(いしゃ)、患者(かんじゃ)について:「ふう…一応(いちおう)、容態(ようたい)は安定化(あんていか)できました。」
example.english: Doctor, about a patient: "*sighing* We were able to stabilize her condition, for the time being."

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)１：「田中(たなか)といえば、、、ちょっと驚(おどろ)いた。勉強(べんきょう)嫌(きら)いなのに、漢字(かんじ)が思(おも)ったより書(か)けるのね。」友達(ともだち)２：「まぁ、日本人(にほんじん)ならどんなに勉強(べんきょう)嫌(きら)いでも漢字(かんじ)は書(か)けるよね。一応(いちおう)は。」
example.english: Friend1: "Speaking of Tanaka, I was a bit surprised. Even though he hates studying, he can write kanji better than I thought!"Friend2: "Well, no matter how much they hate studying, if they are Japanese they can write kanji. More or less."

synonym.explanation: just in case, just to be sure

english_grammar.title: に相違(そうい)ない
english_grammar.explanation: without a doubt, certainly・surely, not mistaken
english_grammar.structure: Verb + （から）+ に相違ない ［い］Adjective + （から）+ に相違ない ［な］Adjective + （である(1)）+ に相違ない Noun + （である(1)）+ に相違ない (1) であるから
english_grammar.about: In a similar fashion to に違(ちが)いない, に相違(そうい)ない is a structure that firmly states that something is 'without a doubt (A)', or that there is 'no mistaking (A)'. It may be used to strengthen one's own opinions, or to strongly agree with the opinion of another. Although 相違(そうい) may be used by itself meaning 'to differ', or 'to have a discrepancy', 相違(そうい)ない is considered as a set い-Adjective. When combined with ない, the literal meaning is just 'there is no discrepancy in (A)'.に相違(そうい)ない may be used with verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives and nouns. 彼(かれ)は小学生(しょうがくせい)の頃(ころ)から一生懸命(いっしょうけんめい)勉強(べんきょう)をし続(つづ)けたので、いい大学(だいがく)に行(い)けるに相違(そうい)ない。Since he's been studying hard since he was in elementary school, there's no doubt that he can go to a good university. このコースはあの世界的(せかいてき)に有名(ゆうめい)なシェフによって作(つ)られたものなので美味(おい)しいに相違(そうい)ない。This course has been prepared by a world famous chef, so there is no doubt that it will be delicious. この街(まち)には電車(でんしゃ)が3分(ぷん)に１本(ぽん)来(く)るので便利(べんり)に相違(そうい)ない。In this city, a train comes every 3 minutes, so there is no doubt that it is convenient. あの事件(じけん)の犯人(はんにん)はあの人(ひと)に相違(そうい)ない。There is no doubt that that person is the culprit. に相違ない will often follow から, highlighting that there is no mistaking the 'cause' of (A). 彼(かれ)がキョロキョロしているのは、嘘(うそ)をついているからに相違(そうい)ない。There is no doubt that he's being restless because he's lying. この技(わざ)が全国(ぜんこく)の大会(たいかい)で禁止(きんし)されているのは危(あぶ)ないからに相違(そうい)ない。There's no doubt that the reason why this move is forbidden in all competitions across the nation is because it's dangerous. Caution - This grammar structure is very formal, with に違(ちが)いない almost always being used in its place.

example.japanese: 田中(たなか)先生(せんせい)は一流(いちりゅう)の外科(げか)医(い)だから、手術(しゅじゅつ)は成功(せいこう)するに相違(そうい)ない。
example.english: Doctor Tanaka is a first-class surgeon, so the surgery will be successful without a doubt.

example.japanese: 報告(ほうこく)によると、この新(あたら)しいウイルスは空気(くうき)を介(かい)して広(ひろ)がるに相違(そうい)ない。
example.english: According to the report, this new virus is, without a doubt, spreading through the air.

example.japanese: 記者(きしゃ)： 首相(しゅしょう)は来年(らいねん)、減税(げんぜい)するので、グレーゾーンを減(へ)らすに相違(そうい)ないと言(い)った。
example.english: Reporter: The prime minister said that that he is certain that next year's tax reduction will reduce the gray zone.

example.japanese: 検察官(けんさつかん)： 被害(ひがい)者(しゃ)の死因(しいん)は鉄(てつ)パイプのようなもので殴(なぐ)りつけられたからに相違(そうい)ない。
example.english: Public prosecutor: It is certain that the cause of the victim's death was a blow from something like an iron pipe.

example.japanese: 課長(かちょう)：競合(きょうごう)他社(たしゃ)は何(なに)か魂胆(こんたん)があるに相違(そうい)ない。
example.english: Section manager: Competitors are surely plotting something.

synonym.explanation: There is no doubt that, I'm sure

english_grammar.title: 万(まん)が一(いち)
english_grammar.explanation: just in case, in the worst-case scenario, in the unlikely event, by any chance
english_grammar.structure: 万（が）一 + Phrase
english_grammar.attention: Can have a negative connotation
english_grammar.about: 万(まん)が一(いち), or sometimes simply 万一(まんいち) is a grammar pattern that literally means '1 in 10000'. It is used in a similar way to phrases such as 'in the unlikely event of (A)', or 'just in case (A)' in English, and will usually highlight some measure against (A), or what will happen as a result of (A) in the latter half of the sentence.万(まん)が一(いち) is primarily used adverbially, so will often come at the beginning of sentences. 万(まん)が一(いち)の時(とき)のために防災(ぼうさい)セットを買(か)っておきましょう。Let's buy a disaster kit (in advance) just in case. 万(まん)が一(いち)来(こ)れなくなった場合(ばあい)は、連絡(れんらく)をください。In the unlikely event that you are unable to come, please contact us. Fun-fact - 万(まん)が一(いち) is considered slightly stronger than 万一(まんいち), but 万(まん)が一(いち) is far more common due to it being easier to pronounce. 万(まん)が一(いち)の時(とき)のためにメールアドレスも教(おし)えていただいてもよろしいでしょうか。Can I possibly have your email address too just in case. 万一(まんいち)分(わ)からないことがあれば、何(なん)でも私(わたし)に聞(き)いてください。If by chance, there is something you don't understand, you can ask me anything.

example.japanese: 万(まん)が一(いち)のことがあったら、お祖母(ばあ)さんの家(いえ)に子(こ)どもを預(あず)けることになっている。
example.english: If an unlikely event happens, it has been decided that the children will be entrusted to grandmother.

example.japanese: 万(まん)が一(いち)、宝(たから)くじが当(あ)たったら、世界(せかい)一周(いっしゅう)旅行(りょこう)をすると思(おも)う。
example.english: By any chance, if I win a lottery, I think I will go on a round-the-world trip.

example.japanese: 万(まん)が一(いち)のために、消火器(しょうかき)を買(か)うことにした。
example.english: I decided to buy a fire extinguisher, just in case.

example.japanese: 万(まん)が一(いち)思(おも)いついたら、アイデアを教(おし)えてください。
example.english: Just in case you think of something, please tell me your idea.

example.japanese: 万(まん)が一(いち)熊(くま)の足跡(あしあと)を見(み)つけた場合(ばあい)は、連絡(れんらく)してください。
example.english: Just in case you should find bear tracks, please let me know.

synonym.explanation: In the event of, In the case of
just in case, just to be sure

english_grammar.title: 様(よう)がない
english_grammar.explanation: there's no way to, it's impossible to
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ よう + が(1) + ない. ［する］Verb + （の）+ しよう + が(1) + ない (1) も
english_grammar.attention: This is not Verb[volitional]
english_grammar.about: 様(よう)がない or 様(よう)もない is an expression used to highlight that there is no 'method' or 'manner' in which to do (A). It can be interpreted as 'there is no way to (A)', or 'it's impossible to (A)'.This phrase will appear attached to the conjunctive form of verbs. 車(くるま)も自転車(じてんしゃ)も壊(こわ)れているので買(か)い物(もの)に行(い)きようがない。Because my car and bicycle are broken, there is no way for me to go shopping. パソコンが車(くるま)にひかれて粉々(こなごな)になったため直(なお)しようがない。It's impossible to fix my computer because it was run over by a car and smashed to pieces. 電話(でんわ)番号(ばんごう)もメールアドレスも分(わ)からないので、連絡(れんらく)のしようがありません。I have no way to contact them because I don't know their phone number nor their email address. 様(よう)がない often focuses on that the action of (A) is not possible, despite that the speaker may actually want to do it.Caution - Because 様(よう) will often appear in hiragana, it is important not to get it mixed up with よう, the auxiliary verb used to create the volitional form of verbs such as する.

example.japanese: 何(なん)とも言(い)いようがない味(あじ)だ。
example.english: There is no way to put this taste/flavor into words.

example.japanese: 弁解(べんかい)のしようがない。
example.english: It is impossible to explain.

example.japanese: これはどうにもしようがない。
example.english: There is no way to do this.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は速(はや)すぎて追(お)い越(こ)しようがない。
example.english: He is too fast, there is no way to overtake him.

example.japanese: そんな無理(むり)な要求(ようきゅう)をされても、応(おう)じようがない。
example.english: Even if such an impossible demand is made, it is impossible to comply.

synonym.explanation: hard to, difficult to
there is no chance of/no way of・impossible
hardly possible, cannot be, highly unlikely, improbable
there is no way, there is no reason, it is impossible, cannot be
very unlikely to, does not seem that, does not appear that

english_grammar.title: に他(ほか)ならない
english_grammar.explanation: nothing but, none other than, simply
english_grammar.structure: Noun + にほかならない(1) (1) にほかならぬ
english_grammar.about: に他(ほか)ならない is a grammar pattern used with verbs to indicate that something is 'definitely (A)', or 'nothing but (A)'. Other common translations are 'none other than (A)', or 'simply (A)'.This expression is often used to emphasize statements, reasons, or causes. かすみさんがみんなに好(す)かれるのはお人(ひと)よしだからに他(ほか)ならない。The reason why Kasumi-san is liked by everyone is simply because she is a good person. こんな夜(よる)遅(おそ)くに訪問(ほうもん)してくるなんて迷惑(めいわく)に他(ほか)ならない。Visiting me at such a late time is nothing but a nuisance. Being a combination of the noun 他(ほか) 'other' and the negated form of the う-Verb なる 'to become'. This phrase literally just states that (A) will not become anything other than what it is, as the given definition is already the most accurate.Caution - In formal situations, particularly formal writing, に他(ほか)ならぬ may also sometimes be seen. Aチームがこの大会(たいかい)で優勝(ゆうしょう)できたのは岡村(おかむら)コーチのおかげにほかならぬ。The reason why team A was able to win this tournament is simply because of coach Okamura. 我(わ)が社(しゃ)の商品(しょうひん)が人気(にんき)なのは広告(こうこく)が印象的(いんしょうてき)だからにほかならぬ。The reason our company's products are popular is simply because our advertisements leave a lasting impression.

example.japanese: わが社(しゃ)の今年度(こんねんど)の多大(ただい)な利益(りえき)は顧客(こきゃく)のおかげにほかなりません。
example.english: Our company's tremendous profit for this fiscal year is thanks to none other than our customers.

example.japanese: タイタニック号(ごう)の沈没(ちんぼつ)は低(てい)品質(ひんしつ)なリベットに因(よ)ったものにほかならない。
example.english: The sinking of the Titanic was caused by nothing but low quality rivets.

example.japanese: 通常(つうじょう)の事故(じこ)の原因(げんいん)はスピード違反(いはん)にほかならない。
example.english: The common cause of the accidents is simply people going too fast.

example.japanese: 学校(がっこう)校長(こうちょう)の生徒(せいと)に対(たい)した演説(えんぜつ)：みなさんの未来(みらい)に責任(せきにん)を持(も)つのは誰(だれ)でしょうか。それはみなさん自身(じしん)にほかならないのです。
example.english: School director's speech to students: Who is responsible for your future? That is none other than yourself.

example.japanese: 三(さん)位(い)という結果(けっか)は彼(かれ)の実力(じつりょく)にほかならない。
example.english: Getting (the result of) 3rd was simply due to his skill.

synonym.explanation: no more than, just, merely
there's only, nothing but
completely covered in, full of
to have no choice but, no other way than, have to

english_grammar.title: っこない
english_grammar.explanation: there is no chance of/no way of・impossible
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ っこない
english_grammar.about: っこない is a combination of the suffix っこ, and the い-Adjective ない. When attached to the conjunctive form of verbs, it creates new い-Adjectives that express the impossibility of (A). (A) being whichever verb is used.Common translations of っこない include 'there is no chance of (A)', or 'doing (A) is impossible'. 今年(ことし)中(じゅう)に30万円(まんえん)貯(た)めたいの？お前(まえ)の給料(きゅうりょう)じゃできっこないよ。You want to save up three hundred thousand yen this year? There's no chance you can with your salary. どんなに鍛(きた)えてもあの人(ひと)だけには勝(か)てっこないよ。No matter how much I train, there's no chance that I can beat him. あんなデカい家(いえ)、どんなに貯金(ちょきん)しても買(か)えっこないよ。I will not be able to buy a house that big, no matter how much I save. Caution - Although extremely rare, as っこ stems from the kanji 子(こ), this grammar point may occasionally be seen in its kanji form. 明日(あした)までに５ページのレポートとか、絶対(ぜったい)書(か)けっ子(こ)ないよ。There is no way that I can write a 5 page essay by tomorrow. こんな漢字(かんじ)だらけの新聞(しんぶん)なんて読(よ)めっ子(こ)ない。There is no way I can read this newspaper that is filled with kanji.

example.japanese: 練習(れんしゅう)をたくさんしなくては、楽器(がっき)の演奏(えんそう)なんかできっこない。
example.english: If you do not practice a lot, there is no way you will be able to do a musical performance.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)で書(か)かないと日本語(にほんご)の書(か)き方(かた)が分(わ)かりっこない。
example.english: If you do not write in Japanese, there is no way you will understand how to write in it.

example.japanese: 怒(おこ)ったお母(かあ)さん：ひきこもりのように、一日(いちにち)中(じゅう)家(いえ)でゲームしてばかりでは、何(なに)も成(な)し遂(と)げっこない。
example.english: Angry mother: There is no way you are going to accomplish anything if you are just sitting at home, playing games like a hikikomori.

example.japanese: A：「試験(しけん)は明日(あした)だよ！」B：「明日(あした)？明日(あした)までに資料(しりょう)全部(ぜんぶ)なんて読(よ)めっこない。」
example.english: A: "The exam is tomorrow!"B: "Tomorrow? There is no chance of me reading all of the material by tomorrow."

example.japanese: どんなに勉強(べんきょう)したって「は」と「が」の違(ちが)いなんて分(わ)かりっこない。
example.english: No matter how much I study, there is no way for me to understand the difference between "は" and "が".

synonym.explanation: very unlikely to, does not seem that, does not appear that

synonym.text: ようがない・ようもない
synonym.explanation: there's no way to, it's impossible to
unlikely to, showing no signs of

english_grammar.title: それなら
english_grammar.explanation: then, if that's the case
english_grammar.structure: それなら + Phrase
english_grammar.about: Acting as a conjunction, それなら is a structure used for highlighting that if the previous statement is the case, then (B) will probably also be true, or will need to be considered. それなら may be interpreted as 'if that's the case, then (B)'. 駅(えき)の近(ちか)くにあるスーパーに行(い)くの？それならついでに私(わたし)を駅(えき)まで送(おく)ってくれない？You're going to the supermarket near the station? If that's the case, can you drop me off at the station? カメラの画質(がしつ)がいいスマホをお探(さが)しなんですか？それならこのスマホをお勧(すす)めします。You are looking for a smartphone with a good camera? If that's the case, I recommend this one. それなら is most often used when replying to some statement that the speaker has just heard from another person. In these cases, it will come before some sort of guess, suggestion, or consideration about what the speaker has just heard. それなら彼(かれ)でもできるようだ。If that's the case, it seems like even he will be able to do it. それなら早(はや)く警察(けいさつ)に電話(でんわ)したほうがいいよ！If that's the case, you should call the cops as soon as possible. それなら先生(せんせい)に聞(き)いたほうがいいと思(あも)います。If that's the case, you should ask the teacher. だったら and それだったら may also be seen, and carry the same meaning. 一人(ひとり)で食(た)べに行(い)くの？だったら僕(ぼく)も一緒(いっしょ)に行(い)ってもいい？You're going to go eat alone? If that's the case, can I come with you? 田中(たなか)君(くん)もコストコに行(い)くの？それだったら一緒(いっしょ)に行(い)こうよ。そのほうがガソリン代(だい)も節約(せつやく)できるし。Tanaka-kun, are you also going to Costco? If that's the case, let's go together. That way, we can save money on gas.

example.japanese: 田中(たなか):「彼女(かのじょ)はとても優秀(ゆうしゅう)な秘書(ひしょ)です。」山田(やまだ):「それなら、この仕事(しごと)は彼女(かのじょ)に任(まか)せましょう。」
example.english: Tanaka: "She is an excellent secretary." Yamada: "If that is the case, let's entrust this job to her."

example.japanese: 井上(いのうえ)さん:「あなたはゲームすると愚痴(ぐち)っぽくなって困(こま)る。」上条(かみじょ)さん:「それなら、そうと言(い)ってくれればいいのに。」
example.english: Inoue-san: "When you game you become irritable and I don't know what to do." Kamijo-san: "If that is the case, you should do me the favor of telling me that."

example.japanese: 土屋(つちや):「今日(きょう)、ちょっと体調(たいちょう)が悪(わる)いんだよね。」水口(みずぐち):「それなら、早(はや)く寝(ね)た方(ほう)がいいよ。」
example.english: Tsuchiya: "Today I am feeling a little under the weather." Mizuguchi: "If that is the case, you should go to bed early!

example.japanese: 小林(こばやし)さん:「シフトがあまりにも不規則(ふきそく)だ。」河村(かわむら)さん:「それなら以前(いぜん)の仕事(しごと)の方(ほう)がまだいいかもしれない。」
example.english: Kobayashi-san: "The shifts are excessively irregular."Kawamura-san: "If that's the case, then your previous job would probably be better."

example.japanese: 遠藤(えんどう)さん:「アプリをもっと使(つか)いやすくしました。」土井(どい)さん:「それなら普及(ふきゅう)すると思(おも)います。」
example.english: Endo-san: "They made the application easier to use."Doi-san: "If that is the case, I think it will spread."

english_grammar.title: ものなら ①
english_grammar.explanation: if, if one could, if something would be possible
english_grammar.structure: Verb［できる］+ ものなら + Phrase
english_grammar.about: Often seen after the potential form of verbs is the conjunction particle ものなら. This grammar pattern expresses that while (A) is not thought to be possible, if it were possible, (B). Common translations include 'if (A), (B)', if one could (A), (B)', and 'if (A) were possible, (B)'.As ものなら is just a combination of もの and the hypothetical form of だ (なら), ものなら simply states that if (A) were a 'thing', then (B). 俺(おれ)のことを捕(つか)まえることができると思(おも)うものなら、捕(つか)まえてみろ！If you think that you can catch me, try and catch me! すぐに直(なお)せるものなら直(なお)したいけど、今(いま)はちょっとお金(かね)がないから厳(きび)しいかな。If it can be fixed soon, I'd like to fix it, but it might be tough right now because I don't have money. Due to ものなら regularly expressing a desired outcome in the (B) part of sentences, this grammar structure will usually be accompanied by てみる or てみたい. Additionally, もし may also appear at the beginning of the sentence to further increase the nuance of 'if'. もしあなたが私(わたし)より上手(じょうず)に書(か)けるものなら自分(じぶん)で書(か)いてみたらどうですか？If you can write it better than I can, why don't you write it yourself? もし行(い)けるものならケニヤに行(い)ってみたいです。If it's possible, I would like to go to Kenya. てみる is often used for criticism, suggesting that if someone thinks that (A) were possible, then perhaps they should try it. てみたい on the other hand is more commonly seen when (A) is wished for, and the speaker would like to do it if possible.While not a strict rule, the verb in both the (A) and (B) parts of ものなら sentences is frequently the same. Especially when expressing a desire to do (A).

example.japanese: 私(わたし)よりもっと上手(うま)くやれるものならやってみろ！
example.english: If you can do this better than me, I'd like to see you try.

example.japanese: 時(とき)の流(なが)れに逆(さか)らえるものなら過去(かこ)に行(い)ってみたいが、時間(じかん)旅行(りょこう)は実現(じつげん)不(ふ)可能(かのう)だから。
example.english: If I could reverse the flow of time, I would like to travel to the past, but time travel is simply impossible.

example.japanese: 帰国(きこく)できるものなら 帰国(きこく)したいが、お金(かね)が十分(じゅうぶん)にない。
example.english: If I could return to my country, I would like to, but I do not have enough money.

example.japanese: この壁(かべ)の塗(ぬ)り方(かた)はまずいって言(い)うか？だったらペンキを買(か)いに行(い)ってもっと上手(うま)く塗(ぬ)れるものなら 塗(ぬ)ってみろ！
example.english: Are you saying that the way I painted this wall is bad? If you can paint (it) better, go and buy some paint. I'd like to see you try!

example.japanese: もしできるものなら、二(に)年(ねん)前(まえ)にビットコインを買(か)ったんだが。
example.english: If I could, I would have bought bitcoins two years ago.

synonym.explanation: If possible

english_grammar.title: に任(まか)せる
english_grammar.explanation: leave 〜 up to, entrust 〜 to
english_grammar.structure: (Task) Nounを + (Target) Nounに + 任せる (Target) Nounに + (Task) Nounを + 任せる
english_grammar.about: (A) を (B) に任(まか)せる is a structure used to highlight that something is being 'entrusted' or 'left up to (B). This can be thought of as a standard function of the る-Verb 任(まか)せる 'to entrust'.In (A) を (B) に任(まか)せる sentences, (A) を will identify the task, while (B) に will identify the person or thing that (A) is being left up to. 私(わたし)は忙(いそが)しいから、あなたにペットの世話(せわ)を任(まか)せてもいい？Is it alright if I trust you to take care of my pet since I'm busy? 先月(せんげつ)入社(にゅうしゃ)して来(き)たばかりの新人(しんじん)くんにあの重要(じゅうよう)なプレゼンを任(まか)せたの？You entrusted that important presentation to a newcomer who just joined the company last month? Fun-fact - Although this expression often highlights people that some task is being left up to, it is also frequently used when some eventuation or result is being left up to chance or fate. 彼女(かのじょ)と付(つ)き合(あ)えるかどうかを神様(かみさま)に任(まか)せる。I'm going to leave it to God to decide if I can go out with her or not. あの会社(かいしゃ)に入(はい)れるかどうかは運(うん)に任(まか)せる。I'll leave it to luck if I can join that company or not.

example.japanese: 大切(たいせつ)な発表(はっぴょう)をいつも彼(かれ)に任(まか)せる。
example.english: I always leave the important presentations up to him.

example.japanese: 研修生(けんしゅうせい)に掃除(そうじ)を任(まか)せます。
example.english: I will leave the cleaning up to the trainee.

example.japanese: 奇跡(きせき)が起(お)こるかどうかを神様(かみさま)に任(まか)せます。
example.english: Whether or not a miracle happens I will leave up to the gods.

example.japanese: 案内(あんない)状(じょう)の宛名(あてな)書(が)きを新入(しんにゅう)社員(しゃいん)に任(まか)せてみた。
example.english: I tried entrusting writing the address on the invitation to the new employee.

example.japanese: アンテナの修理(しゅうり)を息子(むすこ)に任(まか)せた。
example.english: I entrusted repairing the antenna to my son.

english_grammar.title: 活(い)かす
english_grammar.explanation: to make use of (something), to take full advantage of, to capitalize on, to leverage (skills), bring out (the quality of)
english_grammar.structure: Noun + を + 活かす(1) Noun + を + 活かした(2) + Noun (1) 生かす (2) 生かした
english_grammar.attention: Can also mean “to let live”
english_grammar.about: When を活(い)かす is partnered with a noun, it shows that (A) is something that is being made good use of, or leveraged. This can be in relation to skills, experiences, attributes, and many other things.This grammar point may appear either in the form of the う-Verb 活(い)かす 'to enliven' or 生(い)かす 'to keep alive', with very little change in nuance. However, 活(い)かす tends to appear far more frequently, as the focus of this kanji is less in relation to the preservation of life, and more on just 'making good use' of something. このパソコンの機能(きのう)を十分(じゅうぶん)に活(い)かすのにはたくさんの知識(ちしき)が必要(ひつよう)だ。You need to be very knowledgeable in order to make use of all the features of this computer. この失敗(しっぱい)を次(つぎ)に活(い)かしてみてください。Please try to make use of this failure next time. When linked to a (B) noun, in order to show that something 'has' been made good use of, 活(い)かす will appear in the past tense. 私(わたし)のくせ毛(げ)を活(い)かした髪型(かみがた)にカットしてください。Please give me a haircut that makes good use of my curly hair. この料理(りょうり)は鯖(さば)の旨味(うまみ)を活(い)かした料理(りょうり)なので調味料(ちょうみりょう)はあまり使(つか)っていません。This dish makes the most of the flavor of mackerel, so not much seasoning is used. Fun-fact - 活(い)かす will often be used with adverbs of amount or quality, in order to highlight just how well (A) is being made good use of, or capitalized on. Examples include 十分(じゅうぶん)に 'adaquately', 有効(ゆうこう)に 'effectively', 最大限(さいだいげん)に 'to the fullest', and similar words. 私(わたし)は仕事(しごと)で日本語(にほんご)を十分(じゅうぶん)に活(い)かせるかが心配(しんぱい)です。I am concerned about my ability to fully make use of my Japanese at work. 勉強(べんきょう)が出来(でき)る時間(じかん)は限(かぎ)られている為(ため)、時間(じかん)を有効(ゆうこう)に活(い)かせるようにプランを立(た)ててから勉強(べんきょう)をするようにしています。The time that I can study is limited, so in order to make good use of my time, I make sure to make a plan before I start studying.

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)との話(はなし)：「ぼくはこのチャンスを活(い)かしたい。」
example.english: Chat between friends: "I want to take full advantage of this chance."

example.japanese: 新聞記事(しんぶんきじ)：「ルイスさんは技師(ぎし)としての経験(けいけん)を活(い)かして修理業(しゅうりぎょう)を始(はじ)めました。」
example.english: Newspaper article: "Louis made good use of his experience as a technician and started a repair business."

example.japanese: ニスの生産者(せいさんしゃ)のサイトに：「木材(もくざい)の良(よ)さを活(い)かすとともに保護(ほご)するにはニスが必要(ひつよう)だ。」
example.english: On the website of a varnish producer: "Varnish is necessary to bring out the quality of the wood, as well as protect it."

example.japanese: ノートパソコンの生産者(せいさんしゃ)のサイト：「アルミニウムの美(うつく)しさを最大限(さいだいげん)に活(い)かしたノートパソコン」
example.english: Laptop producer’s website: "A laptop that takes full advantage of the beauty of aluminum"

example.japanese: 論文(ろんぶん)：「子供(こども)が才能(さいのう)を活(い)かすか殺(ころ)すか子供(こども)自身(じしん)はもとより親(おや)や教師(きょうし)次第(しだい)でもある。」
example.english: Essay/article: "Whether children leverage their talent or waste it, depends not only on the children themselves, but on the parents and teachers as well."

english_grammar.title: まい
english_grammar.explanation: won't, intend not to, probably not
english_grammar.structure: Verb + まい Verb［ます］+ まい
english_grammar.attention: する→しまい/するまい/すまい・くる→きまい/くるまい/こまい
english_grammar.about: The auxiliary verb まい is used in Japanese to express negative volition. This means that in many ways, it is the opposite of う and よう, which are the auxiliary verbs that express positive volition. まい connects to the base form of verbs, and is considered slightly formal.まい may be translated as 'won't (A)', 'to intend not to (A)', or 'probably not (A)'. It can be considered as a condensed way of expressing ～ないだろう. あんな接客(せっきゃく)が雑(ざつ)なレストランにはもう行(い)くまい。I probably won't go back to that restaurant with such poor customer service. あのアパートの家賃(やちん)は高(たか)いので、あそこには住(す)むまい。The rent for that apartment is expensive, so I probably won't live there. Caution - When appearing with する or 来(く)る, it is also common to see まい connected to the conjunctive form as しまい, すまい, きまい and こまい. However, the standard するまい and 来(く)るまい are also quite common structures. 田中(たなか)くんはとてもいい人なので、そんなひどい事(こと)はしまい。Since Tanaka-kun is a nice person, he probably wouldn't do such a terrible thing. 台風(たいふう)の警報(けいほう)が出(で)ているので、今日(きょう)中(じゅう)に届(とど)くはずだった荷物(にもつ)はこまい。Since there was a warning announced for the typhoon, I probably won't get the package that I was expecting today.

example.japanese: 昨日(きのう)飲(の)みすぎてしまったので、二度(にど)と酒(さけ)は飲(の)むまい。
example.english: Because I drank too much last night, I don't intend to drink ever again.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)は火曜日(かようび)だから、あのダンスクラブにはお客(きゃく)さんがおるまい。
example.english: Because it is Tuesday, there probably won't be many people at that dance club.

example.japanese: この車(くるま)の見(み)た目(め)からすると安(やす)くはあるまい。
example.english: Judging from the appearance of this car, it is probably not cheap.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)のせいでものすごい苦情(くじょう)だ。もう失敗(しっぱい)するまい。
example.english: I caused the terrible grievances. I intend not to fail again.

example.japanese: あの店(みせ)は行列(ぎょうれつ)がすごすぎる。もう行(い)くまい。
example.english: The line at that shop is too crazy. I probably won't go again.

english_grammar.title: 上(じょう)
english_grammar.explanation: from the standpoint of
english_grammar.structure: Noun + 上
english_grammar.about: Attaching to nouns, 上(じょう) is a suffix that highlights when something is being presented 'from the standpoint of (A)'. The 'standpoint' that 上(じょう) will indicate is usually a specific field or area of concern. The (B) part of the sentence will then go on to describe what exactly is being considered from that standpoint. 法律(ほうりつ)上(じょう)、伊勢海老(いせえび)を許可(きょか)なく釣(つ)り上(あ)げて持(も)って帰(かえ)ることが禁止(きんし)されている。From a legal standpoint, it is prohibited to fish for lobsters and bring them home without a permit. 規則(きそく)上(じょう)、生徒(せいと)は髪(かみ)を染(そ)めてはいけないのに、髪(かみ)を染(そ)めている生徒(せいと)が複数(ふくすう)います。From the standpoint of the rules, it is prohibited for the students to dye their hair, but there are a few students that have dyed hair. 上(じょう) is fairly formal, and can interpreted similarly to に関(かん)して 'in connection to', in that it is just expressing that (B) is being discussed in relation to (A).As 上(じょう) will be used with matters of concern, it is very frequently seen with words that express broad fields, such as work '仕事(しごと)', 'education' 教育(きょういく), 'history' 歴史(れきし), 'health' 健康(けんこう), 'experience' 経験(けいけん), 'the law' 法律(ほうりつ), and other similar things.Caution - Despite expressing standpoints, 上(じょう) cannot be used to indicate an individual person's point of view. Because of this, it cannot be used as a suffix for names of people or organizations that something is being considered from. 鈴木(すずき)上(じょう)、会社(かいしゃ)Aが会社(かいしゃ)Bに買収(ばいしゅう)される事(こと)はいい事(こと)だと思(おも)っている。From the standpoint of Suzuki, he thinks that company A being bought by company B is a good thing. (Unnatural Japanese)

example.japanese: 法律(ほうりつ)上(じょう)、学校(がっこう)は個人(こじん)情報(じょうほう)を漏(も)らしてはいけない。
example.english: From a legal standpoint, schools must not leak personal information.

example.japanese: 予算(よさん)上(じょう)、その依頼(いらい)は断(ことわ)るしかない。
example.english: From a budget standpoint, I have no choice but to deny that request.

example.japanese: 規則(きそく)上(じょう)、このアパートでペットを飼(か)うのは禁止(きんし)です。
example.english: From the standpoint of the rules, this apartment prohibits pets.

example.japanese: それは飽(あ)くまで計算(けいさん)上(じょう)の話(はなし)で、実際(じっさい)にはそう簡単(かんたん)にはいきません。
example.english: That is a discussion that will only ever be viewed from the standpoint of forecasting. In practice, it wouldn't go that easily.

example.japanese: 立場(たちば)上(じょう)ああいう発言(はつげん)をしたが、個人的(こじんてき)には争(あらそ)う気持(きも)ちは全(まった)くない。
example.english: From that (situation's) standpoint, I made that sort of remark, but personally I’m not in the mood to quarrel at all.

synonym.explanation: as well, besides, in addition to

synonym.text: からすると・からすれば
synonym.explanation: judging from, considering
speaking in terms of, from the point of view of

english_grammar.title: 上(うえ)に
english_grammar.explanation: as well, besides, in addition to
english_grammar.structure: Verb + 上(に) ［い］Adjective + 上(に) ［な］Adjective + な(1) + 上(に) Noun + の(1) + 上(に) (1) である
english_grammar.about: 上(うえ)に is a grammar pattern that functions as a slightly formal way of saying 'and' in Japanese. It shows that something is 'in addition to (A)', 'as well as (A)', or 'besides (A)'. Literally, it simply shows that 'on top of (A), (B)'.上(うえ)に may be used after that standard form of verbs and い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives followed by な上(うえ)に, and nouns followed by の上(うえ)に. Occasionally, the に may be dropped from this structure, without changing the meaning at all. 私(わたし)の犬(いぬ)は子供(こども)を見(み)ると吠(ほ)える上(うえ)に噛(か)みつこうとするので子供(こども)には近(ちか)づけさせないようにさせています。In addition to barking, my dog tries to bite children when he sees them, so I try not to let him get close to them. 家(いえ)の近所(きんじょ)にあるレストランはまずい上(うえ)に、高(たか)いからいつも空(す)いている。The restaurant near my house is always empty because in addition to having bad food, they are expensive. 高橋(たかはし)くんは無礼(ぶれい)な上(うえ)に清潔感(せいけつかん)がないため、周(まわ)りの人(ひと)たちには避(さけ)けられている。Takahashi-kun is rude as well as unhygienic, so he is avoided by the people around him. 彼女(かのじょ)は調理師免許(ちょうりしめんきょ)の上(うえ)に健康食(けんこうしょく)アドバイザーの資格(しかく)も持(も)っているので、彼女(かのじょ)が作(つく)る料理(りょうり)は健康的(けんこうてき)で美味(おい)しいです。In addition to having a chef's license, she also has qualification as a nutrition advisor, so the food she makes is healthy and delicious. When it comes to な-Adjectives and nouns, it is also common to see である上(うえ)に used as a conjugation pattern. あそこの駅(えき)は不便(ふべん)である上(うえ)に利用者(りようしゃ)が減(へ)っている為(ため)、来月(らいげつ)の中旬(ちゅうじゅん)に取(と)り壊(こわ)されるそうだ。I heard that the station over there is going to get torn down in the middle of next month because in addition to being inconvenient, it is losing users. ケントさんは新聞記者(しんぶんきしゃ)である上(うえ)にスーパーヒーローでもあった。Kent-san was a newspaper reporter as well as a superhero. Caution - 上(うえ)に must always be used to highlight qualities of things that are equivalent to each other. For example, a good thing and another good thing, or a bad thing and another bad thing. あの建築会社(けんちくがいしゃ)が建(た)てる家(いえ)は丈夫(じょうぶ)な上(うえ)にお洒落(しゃれ)なので、すごく人気(にんき)があるらしい。Apparently that building company is very popular right now because the houses they build are durable as well as stylish. (Natural Japanese) 彼(かれ)はハンサムな上(うえ)に失礼(しつれい)だから、あまりモテない。He is not very popular because in addition to being handsome, he is rude. (Unnatural Japanese)

example.japanese: そのジムは安(やす)い上(うえ)に、私(わたし)の家(いえ)から近(ちか)い。
example.english: As well as being cheap, that gym is close to my house.

example.japanese: あの店(みせ)はリフォームした上(うえ)に、メニューも変(か)わったらしい。
example.english: I heard that restaurant changed its menu, in addition to being remodeled.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)の宿題(しゅくだい)は簡単(かんたん)な上(うえ)に、少(すく)ない。
example.english: In addition to being easy, today's homework load was light.

example.japanese: あの人(ひと)の説明(せつめい)は、曖昧(あいまい)な上(うえ)に不(ふ)正確(せいかく)だ。
example.english: That person's explanation was vague, as well as inaccurate.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はお酒(さけ)を飲(の)むと、暴(あば)れる上(うえ)に悪態(あくたい)をつくから手(て)に負(お)えない。
example.english: If he drinks alcohol, in addition to getting violent, he uses abusive language, so he is uncontrollable.

synonym.explanation: once・since, now that, as long as
from the standpoint of
Also, As well, Moreover, Again, Additionally
after, upon
even more/further, again, more and more
and, giving reasons
besides, in addition, furthermore
in addition, on top of that, what is more, to make matters worse

english_grammar.title: 以上(いじょう) ②
english_grammar.explanation: since, now that, as long as, if
english_grammar.structure: Verb + 以上(は) ［い］Adjective + 以上(は) ［な］Adjective + である + 以上(は) Noun + である + 以上(は)
english_grammar.about: When combined with the adverbial particle は, 以上(いじょう) is frequently translated as 'since (A), (B)', 'now that (A), (B)', or 'as long as (A), (B)'. This is a formal structure that is rarely found in daily speech.This construction may be used with verbs and い-Adjectives in their standard forms, and な-Adjectives or nouns followed by である以上(いじょう)は. 猫(ねこ)を飼(か)うと決(き)めた以上(いじょう)は、最後(さいご)まで責任(せきにん)を持(も)って育(そだ)てないといけないと思(おも)います。Now that I have decided to keep a cat, I think that I have the responsibility to raise it until the end. 体調(たいちょう)が悪(わる)い以上(いじょう)は、会社(かいしゃ)に来(こ)ないでください。As long as you are sick, please don't come into work. 有名(ゆうめい)である以上(いじょう)は、テレビではもちろん、SNSでも発言(はつげん)に気(き)をつけなければいけません。As long as you are famous, you will have to watch what you say, not only on television, but also on social networks. この地域(ちいき)の住民(じゅうみん)である以上(いじょう)は、この地域(ちいき)のルールをしっかりと守(まも)ってもらわないと困(こま)ります。As long as you are a resident of this community, we need you to properly follow the rules of this community. As with many other grammar points, the particle is often dropped, leaving 以上(いじょう) by itself. キャプテンに選(えら)ばれた以上(いじょう)、結果(けっか)を残(のこ)すために精一杯(せいいっぱい)頑張(かんば)ります！Now that I have been chosen as captain, I will do my best to achieve results! どんなに気(き)を付(つ)けていても、人間(にんげん)である以上(いじょう)、ミスは防(ふせ)げないよ。No matter how careful you are, as long as you're human, you can't avoid making mistakes. Due to である以上(いじょう)は often presenting something which is being acted upon, the (B) part of sentences that include this grammar structure will frequently include the resolutions or intentions of the speaker, and can be thought of as either obvious or necessary once considering (A). This usually appears in the form of べきだ, つもりだ, はずだ, たい, ほうがいい, and similar patterns.Fun-fact - Despite the standard translations, the literal meaning of 'above and beyond (A), (B)' is also a good way to remember this grammar pattern, as it basically highlights that anything 'past', 'beyond', or 'above' (A) is what needs to be considered.

example.japanese: 日本(にほん)に来(き)た以上(いじょう)、真剣(しんけん)に日本語(にほんご)の勉強(べんきょう)をしたいと思(おも)います。
example.english: Now that I have come to Japan, I think I want to study Japanese seriously.

example.japanese: 試験(しけん)を受(う)ける以上(いじょう)、休(やす)むことはできない。
example.english: As long as I am taking the exam, I can't rest.

example.japanese: 親(おや)である以上(いじょう)は子(こ)育(そだ)てを頑張(がんば)るべきだ。
example.english: Since you are a parent, you should do your best to raise your child.

example.japanese: 一定(いってい)の結果(けっか)を出(だ)していない以上(いじょう)、あなたを解任(かいにん)するしかありません。
example.english: Now that you aren’t showing consistent results, we have no choice but to dismiss you.

example.japanese: 都心(としん)に住(す)んでいる以上(いじょう)、渋滞(じゅうたい)は避(さ)けられない。
example.english: Now that I am living in the city center, I can’t avoid the traffic.

synonym.explanation: since, henceforth
once・since, now that, as long as
as long as・since, given

english_grammar.title: 以上(いじょう)に
english_grammar.explanation: more than, no less than, even more
english_grammar.structure: Verb + 以上に ［い］Adjective + 以上に ［な］Adjective + 以上に Noun + 以上に 以上 + の + Noun
english_grammar.about: Like other structures that include 以上(いじょう) 'beyond', 以上(いじょう)に highlights that (A) is beyond some specific extent. In this grammar pattern, the case marking particleに will indicate the word that 以上(いじょう)に is attached to as an amount.With (A) being considered as 'beyond' something, 以上(いじょう)に can be translated as 'more than (A)', or 'even more than (A)'.以上(いじょう)に may be used after verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives, or nouns in their standard forms. 新(あたら)しく発売(はつばい)した商品(しょうひん)の評判(ひょうばん)が思(おも)っていた以上(いじょう)に良(よ)かったのでびっくりした。I was surprised to find that the newly launched product was more well-received than I had expected. 今日(きょう)の風(かぜ)は冷(つめ)たい以上(いじょう)に痛(いた)い。More than it is cold, today's wind is painful. 今(いま)節約(せつやく)中(ちゅう)だから必要(ひつよう)以上(いじょう)にお金(かね)を使(つか)わないようにしてる。Since I am saving money right now, I am trying not to use more money than necessary. 私(わたし)はスキー以上(いじょう)にスノーボードが好(す)きだ。I like snowboarding more than skiing. Occasionally, に may be replaced by の when a specific amount or quantity is being indicated with a second noun.
