The noun attached to の may not always obviously be an 'amount', but it is something that the speaker is 'measuring' in regard to (A). 僕(ぼく)の最初(さいしょ)のライブに想像(そうぞう)していた以上(いじょう)の人(ひと)が集(あつ)まったので、すごく嬉(うれ)しかった。I was very happy that more people than I expected showed up to my first concert. 私(わたし)の先輩(せんぱい)は思(おも)った以上(いじょう)の人生(じんせい)を送(おく)っている。My senpai is living a better life than I thought.

example.japanese: 天気(てんき)は予想(よそう)以上(いじょう)に悪(わる)かった。
example.english: The weather was worse than I thought (it would be).

example.japanese: 食(た)べられる量(りょう)以上(いじょう)に、料理(りょうり)を注文(ちゅうもん)してしまった。
example.english: I ordered more food than I am able to eat.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)には思(おも)った以上(いじょう)の人生(じんせい)がある。
example.english: He has more of a life than I thought.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は温泉(おんせん)以上(いじょう)に、この旅館(りょかん)の料理(りょうり)が気(き)に入(い)ったらしい。
example.english: He seems to like the food at this ryokan more than he likes the onsen.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は、カーブ以上(いじょう)にシュートをよく投(な)げる投手(とうしゅ)です。
example.english: He is a pitcher who throws screwballs more than curve balls.

synonym.explanation: More than, Over
more than (or equal to), over・(and) above, any more・greater, exceeding

english_grammar.title: 途中(とちゅう)に
english_grammar.explanation: on the way, partway, in the middle of
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ 途中 + で(1) Noun + の + 途中 + で(1) (1) に
english_grammar.about: With 途中(とちゅう) meaning 'on the way', the addition of either the case marking particleに or で will indicate that something is either being done 'on the way to (A)', 'partway through (A)' or 'in the middle of (A)'.途中(とちゅう) may be seen after verbs in their standard form, or nouns followed by の.As always, に will put more emphasis on the time or duration of (A), while で will put further emphasis on the process of (A) being the cause of (B), or being used as an opportunity to do (B). Let's take a look at both. 待(ま)ち合(あ)わせ場所(ばしょ)に向(む)かっている途中(とちゅう)に、「ごめん、やっぱり今日(きょう)行(い)けないかも」と友達(ともだち)からメールが来(き)た。On the way to the meeting place, I received a text from a friend saying, 'Sorry, I might not be able to make it today after all'. 授業(じゅぎょう)の途中(とちゅう)に校長(こうちょう)先生(せんせい)から呼(よ)び出(だ)された時(とき)はビクッとした。I was a bit startled when the principal called me out in the middle of class. 会社(かいしゃ)から帰(かえ)る途中(とちゅう)で変(へん)なおじさんに話(はな)しかけられた。On my way home from work, a strange man tried to talk to me. ミーティングの途中(とちゅう)で社長(しゃちょう)が倒(たお)れて、会社中(かいしゃじゅう)がパニックになった。The president collapsed in the middle of a meeting and everyone in the whole company panicked. The meanings of で and に in regard to this particular grammar point can overlap quite often, so it may be necessary to see many examples before the slight difference in nuance becomes apparent.

example.japanese: 旅(たび)の途中(とちゅう)で迷(まよ)っていたら、通行人(つうこうにん)が案内(あんない)してくれた。
example.english: In the middle of a trip, I lost my way, and a passerby gave me directions.

example.japanese: 面接(めんせつ)の途中(とちゅう)でリクルーターはいきなり笑(わら)い始(はじ)めた。
example.english: In the middle of an interview, the recruiter suddenly started laughing.

example.japanese: 朝(あさ)ご飯(はん)を作(つく)っている途中(とちゅう)で電話(でんわ)が鳴(な)った。
example.english: In the middle of making breakfast, the telephone rang.

example.japanese: シーズンの途中(とちゅう)で引退(いんたい)会見(かいけん)をするのは微妙(びみょう)だ。
example.english: Holding a retirement press conference in the middle of the season is questionable.

example.japanese: 司会(しかい)の途中(とちゅう)でトイレに行(い)きたくなって困(こま)った。
example.english: I found myself in a pickle when I had to go to the bathroom in the middle of leading a meeting.

synonym.explanation: in the middle of
on the way to, as you go
in the process of doing ~ right now/at this moment

english_grammar.title: 中(なか)を
english_grammar.explanation: in・on・into, inside of
english_grammar.structure: Noun + の + 中を
english_grammar.about: Coming from the base meaning of the noun 中(なか) meaning 'inside', the addition of the case marking particleを in its role of identifying the place where an action is taking place creates a grammar structure that can be translated as 'doing (B) in (A)', 'doing (B) on (A)', or 'doing (B) inside of (A)'.With this grammar point, (B) will be the action, while (A) will be a noun indicating the location. 家(いえ)に帰(かえ)ってきたら、まずは弁当(べんとう)箱(ばこ)の中(なか)を空(から)にしてっていつも言(い)ってるじゃん！I always tell you to empty out the lunch box first thing when you come home, don't I? スーパーの中(なか)を何(なに)も買(か)わずにウロウロしていたら、警備員(けいびいん)のおじさんに怪(あや)しまれて声(こえ)をかけられた。When I was wandering around the supermarket without buying anything, the security guard thought I was suspicious so he came to talk to me. Caution - The person or thing that is doing the action that 中(なか)を is indicating may not actually be within the noun being marked with (A). A good example of this is 'doing (B) into (A)', such as with the う-Verb 覗(のぞ)く 'to peer'. 子供(こども)が妙(みょう)に静(しず)かだな〜と思(おも)い、子供(こども)部屋(べや)の中(なか)を覗(のぞ)いてみたらただ寝(ね)ていただけだった。I thought, 'My kid is suspiciously quiet', so I peeked into their room, but they were just sleeping.

example.japanese: 家(いえ)の中(なか)を猫(ねこ)が駆(か)け回(まわ)っている。
example.english: The cat is running around the inside of the house.

example.japanese: トンネルの中(なか)を覗(のぞ)く。
example.english: I will peer into a tunnel.

example.japanese: 鍋(なべ)の中(なか)を洗(あら)う。
example.english: I will wash the inside of a pot.

example.japanese: 人混(ひとご)みの中(なか)を歩(ある)くのは大変(たいへん)です。
example.english: It is hard to walk within a crowd of people.

example.japanese: この水族館(すいぞくかん)は、まるで海(うみ)の中(なか)を歩(ある)いているようだ。
example.english: This aquarium is like walking inside of the ocean.

english_grammar.title: を中心(ちゅうしん)に
english_grammar.explanation: focused on, centered on/around, mainly, most notably
english_grammar.structure: Noun + を中心 + に(1) Noun + を中心 + にした(2) + Noun (1) にして、として (2) とした
english_grammar.about: When combined with nouns, the expression を中心(ちゅうしん)に indicates that something is being 'focused on' or 'centered around'. Occasionally, it may also be translated simply as 'mainly (A)', or 'most notably (A)'. 中心(ちゅうしん) itself is a noun that expresses the 'pivot', or 'central focus point' from which something else is occurring. The case marking particleに just marks '(A) を中心(ちゅうしん)に' as the target that is being focused on. あのアイドルは若者(わかもの)を中心(ちゅうしん)に人気(にんき)を集(あつ)めている。That idol is gaining popularity, mainly among young people. 私(わたし)は今(いま)日本語(にほんご)の文法(ぶんぽう)を中心(ちゅうしん)に勉強(べんきょう)をしています。Currently, I am focusing my studies on Japanese grammar. Due to 中心(ちゅうしん) itself marking a 'central point', it may also be used just to express the middle of something, rather than something that is being concentrated or focused on. 明日(あす)からは札幌(さっぽろ)を中心(ちゅうしん)に大雪(おおゆき)が降(ふ)るところがあるでしょう。There will be heavy snow in some areas, mainly in Sapporo, starting tomorrow. By adding する in either its dictionary or past forms, を中心(ちゅうしん)にする or を中心(ちゅうしん)にした may appear before another noun. This will highlight the noun that comes after as being the overall thing through which the 'focus on (A)' is taking place. この業界(ぎょうかい)ではお客様(きゃくさま)を中心(ちゅうしん)にすることが一番(いちばん)重要(じゅうよう)なことだと言(い)われている。It is said that the most important thing in this industry is to focus on the customers. これからはクライアントの提案(ていあん)を中心(ちゅうしん)にした話(はな)しを進(すす)めたいと思(おも)います。From now on, I would like to proceed with a focus on the client's proposal. ここはスケートボードを中心(ちゅうしん)にしたポップアップストアです。This is a pop-up store focusing on skateboards. Additionally, the case-marking particle と may sometimes replace に. This change will put more nuance on the focus point being conclusive, rather than progressive or decisive. 健康診断(けんこうしんだん)に行(い)ったら先生(せんせい)に揚(あ)げ物(もの)を中心(ちゅうしん)とする食生活(しょくせいかつ)はやめるようにと言(い)われた。When I went to my physical check-up, my doctor told me to stop centering my diet around fried food.

example.japanese: マコさんはコンピューターを中心(ちゅうしん)として生活(せいかつ)をしている。
example.english: Mako leads a life centered around computers.

example.japanese: てるはしさんを中心(ちゅうしん)に世界(せかい)が回(まわ)っている。
example.english: The world revolves mainly around Teruhashi-san.

example.japanese: 天気(てんき)予報(よほう)：「明日(あす)は、九(きゅう)州(しゅう)を中心(ちゅうしん)に雨(あめ)の降(ふ)る所(ところ)があるでしょう。」
example.english: Weather forecast: "Rain will fall mainly in Kyuushuu tomorrow."

example.japanese: 息子(むすこ)はあいかわらずお金(かね)を中心(ちゅうしん)に物(もの)を考(かんが)えているようだ。
example.english: As always, my son always thinks in terms that are focused on money.

example.japanese: アクセントを中心(ちゅうしん)に練習(れんしゅう)していけば、日本語(にほんご)がさらに上手(じょうず)になりますよ。
example.english: You will get even better at Japanese if your practice is centered around (improving) your accent.

english_grammar.title: その上(うえ)
english_grammar.explanation: besides, in addition, furthermore
english_grammar.structure: その上 + Phrase
english_grammar.about: その上(うえ) is a formal expression used in Japanese to indicate that something is 'besides', 'in addition to', or 'furthermore' in relation to the previous statement. It primarily comes at the beginning of sentences before reflecting back on and adding new information in regard to what has already been said.The literal meaning can be thought of as 'on top of that (B)', where 'that' is the information that has already been mentioned. 高橋(たかはし)さんはとても頭(あたま)がいい。その上(うえ)、人柄(ひとがら)もいいので会社(かいしゃ)での評判(ひょうばん)がいいです。Takahashi-san is very smart. Furthermore, he has a very good personality so he has a very good reputation in the company. 今(いま)住(す)んでいる家(いえ)はものすごく小(ちい)さい。その上(うえ)隣(となり)に住(す)んでいる住人(じゅうにん)が一日(いちにち)中(じゅう)うるさいので、来月(らいげつ)引(ひ)っ越(こ)そうと思(おも)う。The house I live in now is extremely small. In addition, the people who live next door are noisy all day long, so I'm thinking of moving out next month. 今日(きょう)は学校(がっこう)で先生(せんせい)に怒(おこ)られた。その上(うえ)家(いえ)に帰(かえ)ったら親(おや)に怒(おこ)られたのであまりいい一日(いちにち)ではなかった。I was scolded by my teacher at school today. In addition, I was scolded by my parents when I came home, so it was not a very good day today. Despite often being used in formal settings, it is not uncommon to hear this phrase used in daily speech, due to its simplicity in highlighting something being 'in addition'.

example.japanese: 昨日(きのう)は夜(よる)遅(おそ)くまで編(あ)み物(もの)をしてしまった。その上(うえ)、朝(あさ)早(はや)くから電話(でんわ)で起(お)こされたのでとても眠(ねむ)いです。
example.english: I stayed up late last night knitting. Furthermore, I was woken up early by a phone call so I am really tired.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)はとても寒(さむ)かった。その上(うえ)、雨(あめ)まで降(ふ)ってきたので屋外(おくがい)のアルバイトは大変(たいへん)だった。
example.english: It was very cold today. In addition, it decided to rain so my outdoor part time job was really rough.

example.japanese: 美味(おい)しいお料理(りょうり)をごちそうになってしまって。その上(うえ)、お土産(みやげ)までいただいて。本当(ほんとう)に、ありがとうございます。
example.english: I was treated to some great food. Furthermore, I was also given a souvenir. Thank you so much!

example.japanese: 顔(かお)が青白(あおじろ)い。その上(うえ)、唇(くちびる)は紫(むらさき)だ。大丈夫(だいじょうぶ)だろうか？
example.english: His face is pale. Furthermore, his lips are purple. Is he okay, I wonder?

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は勇(いさ)ましい。その上(うえ)優(やさ)しいのだから、言(い)うことない。
example.english: He is brave. In addition, he is kind, so there isn't anything to say.

synonym.explanation: in addition, on top of that, what is more, to make matters worse
in addition, incidentally, furthermore, moreover
and・besides, moreover・in addition
moreover, furthermore
even more/further, again, more and more
as well, besides, in addition to

english_grammar.title: 上(うえ)は
english_grammar.explanation: once・since, now that, as long as
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］ + 上は Verb［た］ + 上は
english_grammar.attention: Formal! Rarely used in modern Japanese (old-fashioned)Useからにはand以上はinstead.
english_grammar.about: A fairly old-fashioned phrase, 上(うえ)は highlights that something is being done or considered as a result of (A). It may be interpreted as 'once (A), (B)', 'since (A), (B)', 'now that (A), (B)', or 'as long as (A), (B)'. In these meanings, (B) will always be something that is deemed as either obvious or necessary.上(うえ) in this phrase is a noun, and will be attached to the adverbial particle は. This creates a literal meaning that is similar to 'over and above (A), (B)'. This 'over and above' has a similar nuance to 'with that said', or 'all things considered' in English, and just presents (A) as something that is finalized.This structure follows verbs in the standard form. 一人(ひとり)暮(ぐ)らしを始(はじ)めた上(うえ)は、家事(かじ)など料理(りょうり)は自分(じぶん)で全部(ぜんぶ)やらなくてはいけない。Now that I have started living alone, I must do all the housework and cooking on my own. アイルランドに住(す)むと決(き)めた上(うえ)は、アイルランドの文化(ぶんか)などを勉強(べんきょう)しなければならない。Now that I have decided to live in Ireland, I must study things such as Irish culture. この会社(かいしゃ)の従業員(じゅうぎょういん)として働(はたら)く上(うえ)はきちんと我(わ)が社(しゃ)のルールを守(まも)ってもらわないと困(こま)ります。As long as you are working as an employee of this company, we need you to follow our rules. Due to 上には being quite old-fashioned, expressions like からには or 以上(いじょう)は will be heard more frequently in modern-day Japanese, and will carry a similar meaning. ワンちゃんを保護(ほご)すると決(き)めたからには、最後(さいご)まで責任(せきにん)をもって育(そだ)てなくてはいけない。Now that you have decided to adopt a puppy, you must take responsibility and raise it until the end. 十分(じゅうぶん)な証拠(しょうこ)がない以上(いじょう)は、彼(かれ)を逮捕(たいほ)することができません。Since we don't have sufficient evidence, we can't arrest him.

example.japanese: 日本(にほん)に来(き)た上(うえ)は勉強(べんきょう)するつもりです。
example.english: Now that I have come to Japan, I intend to study.

example.japanese: 子供(こども)が犬(いぬ)を飼(か)う上(うえ)は、責任(せきにん)感(かん)を持(も)たせて成長(せいちょう)させなければならない。
example.english: Now that the child is raising a dog, they must take responsibility and mature.

example.japanese: 血圧(けつあつ)が上(あ)がり、肝機能(かんきのう)も低下(ていか)した上(うえ)は、なんらかの病気(びょうき)があるはずだ。
example.english: Since my blood pressure and liver functionality has gotten worse, I must have some sort of illness.

example.japanese: 政治家(せいじか)の山本(やまもと)さんは選挙(せんきょ)に勝(か)つための約束(やくそく)を結(むす)ぶ上(うえ)は守(まも)るべきだ。しかし、実際(じっさい)には必(かなら)ずしもそうとは限(かぎ)らない。
example.english: Now that the politician, Yamamoto-san, made a promise in order to win elections, he should keep it. But in reality, it is not always the case.

example.japanese: 何(なに)かをし始(はじ)める上(うえ)は正(ただ)しくやらなければならない。
example.english: Once you start doing something, you have to do it properly.

synonym.explanation: as well, besides, in addition to
since, henceforth
since, now that, as long as, if
as long as・since, given

english_grammar.title: の下(もと)で
english_grammar.explanation: under, under the supervision of, on the basis of
english_grammar.structure: Noun + のもとで(1) (1) もとに、もと
english_grammar.about: When the noun 下(もと) 'underneath' is combined with either of the case marking particles で or に, it will indicate that something is happening either under the influence, guidance, or basis of (A). (A) will be a noun that is connected to 下(もと)で or に through the case-marking particle の.In this grammar structure, (A) may mark either a specific person or some situation equally as naturally. こんな厳(きび)しい環境(かんきょう)の下(もと)で試料(しりょう)を採取(さいしゅ)できたのは皆(みな)様(さま)のおかげです。Thanks to all of you, we were able to gather samples under such harsh conditions. 先輩(せんぱい)の下(もと)で働(はたら)けて光栄(こうえい)です！It is my pleasure that I can work under you! その行為(こうい)はこの法律(ほうりつ)の下(もと)で禁止(きんし)されています。That action is prohibited on the basis of this law. Occasionally, に or で will be able to be omitted in preference of a comma directly after 下(もと). This expression is considered quite formal, and the omission of the particle in favor of a comma will make it sound even more formal. 皆(みな)さんの協力(きょうりょく)の下(もと)、このプロジェクトを無事(ぶじ)に終(お)えることができました。皆(みな)さんありがとうございました。Under everyone's hard work, we were able to successfully complete this project. Thank you all. 佐々木(ささき)先輩(せんぱい)のご指導(しどう)の下(もと)、企画書(きかくしょ)を作成(さくせい)しています。I am creating a proposal, on the basis of Sasaki-senpai's guidance. Fun-fact - の下(もと)で may be replaced with 下(か) attached directly to many different nouns, and still carry the same meaning. Examples of these are 統治下(とうちか) 'under the reign', 指揮下(しきか) 'under the direction', 影響下(えいきょうか) 'under the influence', 占領下(せんりょうか) 'under the occupation', 支配下(しはいか) 'under the control', and others. 沖縄(おきなわ)は1945年(ねん)から1972年(ねん)までアメリカの統治(とうち)下(か)であった。Okinawa was under the reign of America from 1945 to 1972. その国(くに)は現在(げんざい)敵国(てきこく)の支配(しはい)下(か)にある。Currently, that country is under the control of our enemy.

example.japanese: ある金属(きんぞく)は一定(いってい)の状態(じょうたい)のもとに電気(でんき)抵抗(ていこう)が急(きゅう)にゼロになる。そういう物質(ぶっしつ)を超(ちょう)伝導(でんどう)物質(ぶっしつ)英語(えいご)では「superconductors」と呼(よ)ばれている。
example.english: The electrical resistance in certain metals suddenly falls to zero under set conditions. Such materials are called "superconductors".

example.japanese: ベジカと戦(たたか)うためにそんゴツウはカエ王様(おうさま)のもとで修行(しゅぎょう)した。
example.english: In order to battle with Vegika, Songotsu trained under King Kae.

example.japanese: このエンジンは80度(ど)以下(いか)という温度(おんど)の条件(じょうけん)のもとで少(すく)なくとも50000時間(じかん)稼働(かどう)継続(けいぞく)できる。
example.english: This engine can operate non-stop for at least 50000 hours under a temperature lower than 80 degrees Celsius.

example.japanese: 叔父(おじ)さんのもとで働(はたら)いた3年間(ねんかん)は、僕(ぼく)にとって宝物(たからもの)です。
example.english: The three years that I worked under my uncle were special to me.

example.japanese: 火山(かざん)学者(がくしゃ)のもとで教(おし)えていただいた経験(けいけん)を活(い)かした仕事(しごと)がしたい。
example.english: I want to work somewhere that makes use of the things that I learned under a volcanologist.

english_grammar.title: 後(あと)の + (Noun)
english_grammar.explanation: …left, rest, remaining, in, …to, …else
english_grammar.structure: あと + の + Noun あと + Phrase あと + Number +（Counter)
english_grammar.about: One of the common uses for the noun 後(あと) 'behind' is to express a remainder, or everything after a certain point. This can be translated as 'what's left of (A)', 'the rest of (A)', 'what's remaining of (A)', or even 'other than (A)'. Let's have a look at a few examples.後(あと) will be grouped with the case marking particleの before nouns, come directly before numbers, or be used at the beginning of whole phrases. 今(いま)あなたが持(も)っている段(だん)ボール箱(ばこ)はキッチンまで運(はこ)んでおいてください。後(あと)の段(だん)ボール箱(ばこ)は全部(ぜんぶ)寝室(しんしつ)までお願(ねが)いします。Please bring the cardboard box you are carrying into the kitchen. Please take all the rest to the master bedroom. 後(あと)ちょっとで着(つ)くからもうちょっと我慢(がまん)して。We will arrive in a little bit, so please be patient for a little longer. 映画(えいが)公開(こうかい)まで後(あと)3日(か)！Three days left until the movie gets released! Despite having many different translations, the base meaning of 後(あと) will always just be to identify a sequence of things, and what comes 'after' or 'behind' a specific point in that sequence.

example.japanese: 子供(こども)がお隣(となり)さんと話(はな)している：「うちでは７匹(ひき)動物(どうぶつ)を飼(か)ってるんです。猫(ねこ)が５匹(ひき)、あとの２匹(ひき)は犬(いぬ)です。」
example.english: A child is talking with a neighbor: "We have 7 animals at home. 5 are cats and the remaining ones are dogs."

example.japanese: 学生(がくせい)１：「明日(あした)は試験(しけん)なのに、どうして一日中(いちにちじゅう)ゲームなんてしてたの！？」学生(がくせい)２：「うそっ！？試験(しけん)まであと一日(いちにち)しかないなんて聞(き)いてないよ！」
example.english: Student1: "Why did you play games all day long even though there is an exam tomorrow?"Student2: "No way! I didn’t hear anything about having only one day left until the exam!"

example.japanese: SF映画(えいが)：「ヨーロッパを除(のぞ)いて、あとの世界(せかい)は全(すべ)てあなた方(がた)のものだ。」
example.english: Sci-fi Movie: "Except for Europa, the remaining worlds belong to you."

example.japanese: 砂漠(さばく)で独(ひと)り言(ごと)を言(い)う：「ガソリンがあと7リットルしかない。足(た)りるかな？」
example.english: Talking to oneself in the desert: "There are only 7 liters of gasoline left. I wonder if it is enough?"

example.japanese: 妻(つま)は夫(おっと)と話(はな)している：「あと少(すこ)ししか砂糖(さとう)がないから、コンビニに買(か)いに行(い)ってくれない？」
example.english: A wife talking with her husband: "Since there is only a little sugar left, won’t you go to the convenience store and buy some?"

english_grammar.title: 手前(てまえ)
english_grammar.explanation: before, in front of, from one's standpoint/side
english_grammar.structure: Verb + 手前 Noun + の + 手前
english_grammar.about: The noun 手前(てまえ) 'in front of' has several different meanings in Japanese depending on whether it is being used with a verb in its standard form, or with a noun.Regarding verbs, it expresses 'going forward from (A), (B)'. This is usually in relation to something that has happened either accidentally or completely, and may represent what will be done as a result of being in that situation. 崖(がけ)から落(お)ちる手前(てまえ)で父親(ちちおや)に腕(うで)を引(ひ)っ張(ぱ)られた。My father pulled me by my arm before I fell off the cliff. 勢(いきお)いで手(て)を上(あ)げてしまった手前(てまえ)、答(こた)えずに手(て)を下(さ)げるわけにはいかない。From the standpoint of me raising my hand in the heat of the moment, there is no way of me backing out without answering the question. 先輩(せんぱい)にはいつもお世話(せわ)になっている手前(てまえ)、彼女(かのじょ)の頼(たの)みを断(ことわ)るわけにはいかない。Since my senpai always takes good care of me, there is no way that I can turn down her request. This can also be interpreted as 'now that (A), (B)', and simply highlights that nothing can be done except to move on or 'forward' given the current circumstances.When 手前(てまえ) appears with nouns followed by the case marking particleの, it often expresses that what is 'in front' of (A) is the reason for (B), or simply is 'in front of (B)'. 娘(むすめ)の手前(てまえ)、運動(うんどう)音痴(おんち)な姿(すがた)を見(み)せるわけにはいかない。I can't show my unathletic self in front of my daughter. 彼女(かのじょ)の両親(りょうしん)の手前(てまえ)、発言(はつげん)には気(き)を付(つ)けなければいけない。I have to be careful of what I say when I am in front of my girlfriend's parents. Despite the many translations, 手前(てまえ) always shows something that is 'facing' the noun or verb that appears with it. Due to this, thinking of this structure as similar to 'faced with (A), (B)' may be helpful, as English also expresses lack of option and finality in this way.

example.japanese: 君(きみ)の手前(てまえ)にあるものを見(み)てください。
example.english: Please look at the thing that is in front of you.

example.japanese: 死(し)んでしまう一歩(いっぽ)手前(てまえ)で助(たす)かった。
example.english: I was helped just before I would have died.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の手前(てまえ)の人(ひと)が、私(わたし)の友達(ともだち)です。
example.english: The person in front of me is my friend.

example.japanese: オルガンをもっと手前(てまえ)に配置(はいち)してください。
example.english: Please position the organ even more in front.

example.japanese: これまでよりも手前(てまえ)で曲(ま)がるカーブを投(な)げられるようになった。
example.english: I became able to throw a curveball that curves even more in front.

synonym.explanation: Before, In front of

english_grammar.title: を巡(めぐ)って
english_grammar.explanation: concerning, in regard to, about, (split) over
english_grammar.structure: Noun + をめぐって(1) Noun + をめぐる + Noun (1) をめぐり
english_grammar.about: One of the more indirect ways that 'to be concerning (A)' is conveyed in Japanese is through the pairing of a noun with the case marking particleを and the う-Verb 巡(めぐ)る 'to go around' in either its て-form, or standard form when paired with a second noun.This grammar point can be translated as 'concerning (A)', 'in regard to (A)', or 'about (A)'. However, following the most natural translation, we can see that 'to go around the topic of (A)', or 'encompassing (A)' are also acceptable. 隣人(りんじん)と土地(とち)の境界線(きょうかいせん)を巡(めぐ)ってトラブルが起(お)きた時(とき)は誰(だれ)に連絡(れんらく)するべきですか？Who should I contact if I have a problem with my neighbor concerning my property line? この島(しま)を巡(めぐ)る争(あらそ)いは私(わたし)が生(う)まれる前(まえ)から続(つづ)いています。The conflict concerning this island has been going on since before I was born. ゴミ出(だ)しルールを巡(めぐ)ってのトラブルはどの地域(ちいき)でも珍(めずら)しいことではありません。No matter the community, conflicts concerning garbage disposal rules are not uncommon. Caution - In addition to being quite formal, を巡(めぐ)って keeps the 'around the topic of (A)' nuance that comes from the stem verb. This means that rather than expressing one opinion, it takes into consideration many different viewpoints, and is frequently used when there is a disagreement or dispute about (A). 数(かず)が限(かぎ)られている限定(げんてい)商品(しょうひん)を巡(めぐ)ってお客様(きゃくさま)同士(どうし)が言(い)い合(あ)いになってしまった。Customers argued with each other over a limited number of limited edition products. 税金(ぜいきん)の使(つか)い方(かた)を巡(めぐ)る議論(ぎろん)から、内戦(ないせん)が始(はじ)まってしまった。A debate over the use of taxes has led to a civil war. Because of this, it can sound quite unnatural to use を巡(めぐ)って if the topic of (A) is simply a personal opinion.

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)、国会(こっかい)では増税(ぞうぜい)するべきかそのまま据(す)え置(お)きするべきかをめぐって激論(げきろん)が生(しょう)じた。
example.english: There was a heated debate today over whether the parliament should raise taxes or leave them as they are.

example.japanese: スイスに於(お)いて貿易(ぼうえき)協定(きょうてい)をめぐり米国(べいこく)とヨーロッパ連合(れんごう)の交渉(こうしょう)が始(はじ)まりました。
example.english: The negotiations between the United States and the European Union in regard to a trade agreement began in Switzerland today.

example.japanese: 時代(じだい)とともに、海賊(かいぞく)王(おう)の宝(たから)が隠(かく)された場所(ばしょ)をめぐる様々(さまざま)な論争(ろんそう)が起(お)こった。
example.english: As time passed, various disputes arose concerning the location of the hidden treasure of the pirate king.

example.japanese: 塩分(えんぶん)の過剰(かじょう)摂取(せっしゅ)を巡(めぐ)って意見(いけん)が分(わ)かれている。
example.english: Opinions are divided over the excessive consumption of salt.

example.japanese: 誰(だれ)が担当(たんとう)するのか、人気(にんき)の楽器(がっき)を巡(めぐ)っての争(あらそ)いが毎年(まいとし)ある。
example.english: Every year there is a contest to see who will be in charge in regards to the popular instrument.

synonym.explanation: related to, about, regarding

english_grammar.title: に渡(わた)って
english_grammar.explanation: across, throughout, extends, over (a period of time or range)
english_grammar.structure: Noun + にわたって(1) Noun + にわたる(2) + Noun (1) にわたり (2) にわたった
english_grammar.about: Partnered with the case marking particleに, the う-Verb 渡(わた)る 'to cross' in its て-form highlights a span of something in regard to breadth, size, or time. This structure is often translated as either 'across (A)', 'throughout (A)', 'extending through (A)'. or 'over the period of (A)'.Like other verb structures that pair with nouns, the standard form may also be used when paired with a second noun, in order to modify that noun. 彼(かれ)は脱獄(だつごく)後(ご)長年(ながねん)に渡(わた)って警察(けいさつ)から身(み)を隠(かく)し続(つづ)けた。He continued to hide from the police for many years after his escape. 15年(ねん)に渡(わた)る戦争(せんそう)は、ついにその幕(まく)を閉(と)じた。A war that has been taking place for over fifteen years has finally come to its end. Coming from the meaning of 渡(わた)る 'to cross', this grammar pattern always expresses that something is either happening or exists 'all across (A)', or 'from the start to the finish'. Additionally, に渡(わた)って is considered quite formal, so will often be seen in articles or on the news.Caution - As 渡(わた)る indicates a span of something that is being crossed, the 'span' must always be indicated clearly. 今朝(けさ)に渡(わた)って行(おこな)われた会議(かいぎ)がようやく終(お)わった。The meeting that has been going on throughout the whole morning has finally ended. 今晩(こんばん)に渡(わた)って落(お)ち続(つづ)けていたA社(しゃ)の株(かぶ)がやっと上(あ)がった。The stock of Company A has finally risen after going down throughout tonight.

example.japanese: 明日(あした)は北海道(ほっかいどう)全域(ぜんいき)にわたって強(つよ)い雪(ゆき)が降(ふ)るでしょう。
example.english: Tomorrow, heavy snow will fall all across Hokkaido.

example.japanese: C1道路(どうろ)は雪(ゆき)により5キロにわたって通行(つうこう)できません。迂回(うかい)路(ろ)を使用(しよう)してください。
example.english: The C1 is impassable over a range of 5 kilometers due to snow. Please use the detour.

example.japanese: 市役所(しやくしょ)は午後(ごご)9時(じ)から翌(よく)午前(ごぜん)6時(じ)にわたり閉館(へいかん)します。
example.english: City Hall will be closed over a period that extends from 9 p.m until 6 a.m the next day.

example.japanese: 二(に)か月(げつ)にわたって開催(かいさい)された冬季(とうき)オリンピックの閉会(へいかい)式(しき)が本日(ほんじつ)行(おこな)われます。
example.english: The closing ceremony for the winter Olympics, held over the span of two months, will be carried out today.

example.japanese: 長期(ちょうき)にわたって利用(りよう)してきたサービスが終了(しゅうりょう)してしまう。
example.english: Unfortunately the service we have come to use over a long period of time will end.

synonym.explanation: over (a period), from ~ until・through

english_grammar.title: に沿(そ)って
english_grammar.explanation: along, in accordance with, in line with
english_grammar.structure: Noun + にそって Noun + にそった(1) + Noun (1) にそう
english_grammar.about: When used with the case marking particleに, the う-Verb 沿(そ)う 'to run alongside' in its て-form expresses that something is going 'along with (A)', 'in accordance with (A)', or 'in line with (A)'. This is primarily in relation to laws, conventions, traditions, needs, and other things which are not usually deviated away from. The nuance with this particular grammar structure is that (A) is the controlling factor, and (B) is being done with that in consideration.に沿(そ)って may also appear with the verb in its standard form when paired with a second noun, in order to modify that noun. 会社(かいしゃ)のルールに沿(そ)って、残業(ざんぎょう)をする方(かた)は必(かなら)ずタイムカードを押(お)してからにしてください。In accordance with company rules, please make sure to clock-in before you begin overtime. クライアント様(さま)の希望(きぼう)に沿(そ)う方向(ほうこう)で進(すす)めたいと思(おも)います。We would like to proceed in accordance with the client's wishes. ご予算(よさん)内(ない)でお客様(きゃくさま)のご希望(きぼう)に沿(そ)ったお家(うち)を建(た)てれるよう全力(ぜんりょく)を尽(つ)くします！We will do our best to build you a home in accordance with your needs and within your budget! As the base meaning of 沿(そ)う is 'to follow along', it will also regularly be seen in relation to going along some specific path or street. この点線(てんせん)に沿(そ)って切(き)ってください。Please cut along this dotted line. While this grammar structure is relatively formal, when literally meaning 'alongside', it will be used fairly frequently.

example.japanese: 「道(みち)に沿(そ)っていったら、そのうちスーパーが見(み)えてきますよ」
example.english: "If you go along the street, the supermarket will eventually come into view".

example.japanese: クライアントの希望(きぼう)にそった新(しん)製品(せいひん)を開発(かいはつ)する予定(よてい)です。
example.english: We plan on developing new products in line with our clients' expectations.

example.japanese: マニュアル：従業(じゅうぎょう)員(いん)は火災(かさい)の際(さい)、避難(ひなん)計画(けいかく)にそってスーパーの前(まえ)に集(あつ)まること。
example.english: Manual: In case of fire, the employees should gather in front of the supermarket in accordance with the evacuation plan.

example.japanese: このサンプルに沿(そ)って作(つく)れば大抵(たいてい)の人(ひと)はうまくできます。
example.english: If they make it in accordance with this sample, most people can do it well.

example.japanese: この台本(だいほん)に沿(そ)って司会(しかい)してください。
example.english: Please lead the meeting in accordance with the script.

english_grammar.title: ～た末(すえ)
english_grammar.explanation: after, as a conclusion of
english_grammar.structure: Verb［た］+ すえ （に） Noun + の + すえ （に）
english_grammar.about: Appearing with verbs in their past form, or grouped with nouns after の is 末(すえ), a word meaning 'end tip'. に will follow 末(すえ) , marking the 'tip' as the point from which something will result.While this grammar pattern is usually translated as 'after (A), (B)', or 'as a result of (A), (B)', the nuance is on various things having happened along the way, and then finally reaching the 'point' or 'conclusion' of (A). 色々(いろいろ)と考(かんが)えた末(すえ)に、お父(とう)さんの会社(かいしゃ)を継(つ)ぐことに決(き)めた。After much thought, I decided to take over my father's company. 迷(まよ)いに迷(まよ)った末(すえ)に、彼女(かのじょ)と別(わか)れることにした。After much hesitation, I decided to break up with her. 5年(ねん)間(かん)にわたる争(あらそ)いの末(すえ)、アメリカ軍(ぐん)が撤退(てったい)を開始(かいし)した。After five years of conflict, the U.S. military began to withdraw. 社長(しゃちょう)と長(なが)い議論(ぎろん)の末(すえ)に、人事(じんじ)の伊藤(いとう)さんをクビにすることに決(き)めた。After a long discussion with the president, we decided to fire Ito-san from human resources. 末(すえ)に may highlight either positive or negative results, but will suggest that some long-lasting effort or struggle eventually resulted in (B).

example.japanese: 苦難(くなん)の末(すえ)に銃(じゅう)を壁(かべ)にかけて普通(ふつう)の生活(せいかつ)を送(おく)りはじめた。
example.english: After (much) suffering, he was able to hang up his gun and start an ordinary life.

example.japanese: 大学(だいがく)卒業(そつぎょう)後(ご)どうしようかと悩(なや)んだ末(すえ)、ベンチャー企業(きぎょう)を立(た)ち上(あ)げることにした。
example.english: After (continuously) worrying about what to do after graduation, I decided to start a business.

example.japanese: いろいろ面接(めんせつ)した末(すえ)に、大(だい)企業(きぎょう)に雇(やと)われたんだ。
example.english: After many interviews (repeating many times), I was hired by a big company.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)と長(なが)い議論(ぎろん)の末(すえ)に、来年(らいねん)の６月(がつ)、結婚(けっこん)することに決(き)めた。
example.english: After a (long) discussion with my girlfriend, we have decided to get married next June.

example.japanese: 頭(あたま)が痛(いた)かったせいで眠(ねむ)れない夜(よる)を過(す)ごした末(すえ)、医者(いしゃ)に診(み)てもらおうと決(き)めた。
example.english: After suffering through a (long) sleepless night due to a headache, I decided to see a doctor.

synonym.explanation: after, in the end, after all, eventually
after, upon

english_grammar.title: に従(したが)って
english_grammar.explanation: as, following, as then, according to, in accordance with
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ にしたがって(1) Noun + にしたがって(1) (1) にしたがい
english_grammar.about: By grouping the う-Verb 従(したが)う 'to comply' with に, a common pattern meaning 'to comply with (A)', 'in accordance with (A)', or 'following (A)' will be created. This is a fairly strong and formal structure, indicating that (B) is being controlled or heavily influenced by (A). (B) will often express some kind of ongoing or sudden change caused by (A).に従(したが)って may appear after either verbs of nouns in their dictionary forms. 年(とし)を取(と)るに従(したが)って、目(め)がどんどん悪(わる)くなっていってる気(き)がする。I feel like my eyes are getting worse and worse as I get older. テレワークの普及(ふきゅう)が進(すす)むに従(したが)って、通勤(つうきん)するサラリーマンが減(へ)っていっている。As teleworking becomes more widespread, the number of office workers commuting to work is decreasing. 僕(ぼく)はただ上司(じょうし)の指示(しじ)に従(したが)って仕事(しごと)を進(すす)めていただけです。I was just following my boss' instructions to get the job done. この説明書(せつめいしょ)に従(したが)って、パソコンの初期(しょき)設定(せってい)を行(おこな)ってください。Please follow these instructions to perform the initial setup of your computer. As this expression is quite formal, it is common to see it used in relation to matters that are usually discussed in formal or official situations, such as laws, standards, conventions, or traditions.

example.japanese: 年(とし)が経(た)つにしたがって、非(ひ)再生(さいせい)可能(かのう)資源(しげん)が枯渇(こかつ)する一方(いっぽう)だ。
example.english: As years pass by, non-renewable resources continue to run out.

example.japanese: 憲法(けんぽう)にしたがって、新(あら)たな法律(ほうりつ)が成立(せいりつ)する。
example.english: In accordance with the constitution, the new law will be established.

example.japanese: 世界中(せかいじゅう)でのインターネットの広(ひろ)がりにしたがい、情報(じょうほう)へのアクセスは前(まえ)よりもっと容易(ようい)になる。
example.english: As the internet spreads all over the world, access to information becomes easier than before.

example.japanese: 年齢(ねんれい)にしたがって、だんだんいいアイデアが思(おも)い浮(う)かばなくなっているような気(き)がする。
example.english: I feel like as you age, good ideas gradually stop coming to mind.

example.japanese: この足跡(あしあと)にしたがって進(すす)めば、きっとみんなに会(あ)えるはずです。
example.english: If you progress in accordance with these tracks, you will surely be able to see everyone.

english_grammar.title: に伴(ともな)って
english_grammar.explanation: as・due, (along/hand-in-hand) with, resulted in, be consequent upon
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+（の）+ に伴って(1) Verb［る］+（の）+ に伴う + Noun Noun + に伴って(1) Noun + に伴う + Noun (1) に伴い
english_grammar.about: When the う-Verb 伴(ともな)う 'to accompany' in its て-form is used with に and attached to the end of nouns or verbs in their dictionary forms, it is regularly translated as 'due to (A), (B)', 'hand in hand with (A), (B)', or 'along with (A), (B)'. In all of these meanings, the base interpretation of 'to accompany' is being highlighted.As 'accompanying' does not specifically indicate that (A) is controlling (B), this grammar structure may be used simply to indicate things that happen at the same time, rather than when something is being directly caused by the first. However, (A) having a strong influence on the change of (B) is usually implied.に伴(ともな)う may also appear directly before another noun when it is being modified by the verb. この町(まち)の人口(じんこう)が減少(げんしょう)するに伴(ともな)って空(あ)き家(や)が増加(ぞうか)して来(き)ました。As the population of this town has declined, the number of vacant houses has increased. パソコンの初期化(しょきか)をするのに伴(ともな)う手順(てじゅん)は取扱(とりあつかい)説明書(せつめいしょ)の５１ページに記載(きさい)されています。The procedure associated with formatting the computer is described on page 51 of the instruction manual. インターネットの普及(ふきゅう)に伴(ともな)って、オンラインで買(か)い物(もの)を済(す)ませる人(ひと)が増(ふ)えた。With the spread of the Internet, more and more people are completing their purchases online. 高速(こうそく)道路(どうろ)の情報(じょうほう)サイト：リフレッシュ工事(こうじ)に伴(ともな)う車線(しゃせん)規制(きせい)のお知(し)らせ。Highway information website: Notice of lane restriction due to road reconstruction. に伴(ともな)って is used both for events that are progressively changing at the same time, and momentary events that cause a sudden change. 津波(つなみ)は地震(じしん)に伴(ともな)い発生(はっせい)することが多(おお)いが、火山(かざん)現象(げんしょう)に伴(ともな)い津波(つなみ)が発生(はっせい)することも有(あ)るそうだ。Oftentimes, tsunami occur due to earthquakes, but apparently they can also occur due to volcanic phenomenon. 歳(とし)を取(と)るに伴(ともな)って物忘(ものわす)れが酷(ひど)くなってきてる感(かん)じがする。I feel like I'm getting more forgetful as I get older.

example.japanese: 城(しろ)の改修(かいしゅう)中(ちゅう)、床(ゆか)の修理(しゅうり)に伴(ともな)って、壁(かべ)も塗(ぬ)りなおされた。
example.english: During the castle renovation, along with the floor repairs, the walls were also repainted.

example.japanese: ライト兄弟(きょうだい)による初(はじ)めての飛行(ひこう)は１９０３年(ねん)に成(な)された。それに伴(ともな)い、近代(きんだい)の航空(こうくう)産業(さんぎょう)が生(う)まれた。
example.english: The Wright brothers succeeded in becoming the first in flight in 1903. This resulted in the birth of the modern aviation industry.

example.japanese: このゲームでは高(こう)レベルに達(たっ)するに伴(ともな)って、上級(じょうきゅう)の魔法(まほう)が使(つか)えるようになる。
example.english: In this game, as higher levels are reached, advanced magic will become available.

example.japanese: 火傷(やけど)に伴(ともな)う痛(いた)みは神経(しんけい)への刺激(しげき)が原因(げんいん)だとされている。
example.english: Pain associated with burns is considered to be caused by nerve stimulation.

example.japanese: トマトはヨーロッパに初(はじ)めて紹介(しょうかい)されたときは、毒(どく)と考(かんが)えられていた。年(とし)が経(た)つに伴(ともな)いこの野菜(やさい)に対(たい)する考(かんが)え方(かた)が変(か)わってきた。
example.english: Tomatoes were considered poisonous when introduced to Europe for the first time. As the years passed, the way of thinking about this vegetable has been changing.

english_grammar.title: に就(つ)き
english_grammar.explanation: due to, on account of, each/every
english_grammar.structure: Noun + につき
english_grammar.about: Although rarely seen in its kanji form, につき is a grammar pattern that comes from a combination of に and the conjunctive form of the う- Verb 就(つ)く 'to take up (A)', or 'to assume (A)'. This meaning is usually in regard to assuming a new position, such as a new job.However, the particular meaning conveyed here will be closer to 'due to (A), (B)', 'on account of (A), (B)', or 'for each (A), (B)'. につき will follow nouns directly, before the (B) part of the sentence describes what is happening 'due to' or 'on account of (A)'. 閉店(へいてん)につき、特別(とくべつ)セール開催中(かいさいちゅう)！Due to our store closing, there is a special sale going on! 工事(こうじ)中(ちゅう)につき、この先(さき)立(た)ち入(い)り禁止(きんし)。Due to construction, entry beyond this point is prohibited. この商品(しょうひん)は大人気(だいにんき)のため、一人(ひとり)につき二(ふた)つまでとさせていただいております。Since this product is very popular, we are limiting it to two per person. This grammar point is quite formal, so it is often seen in formal documents, announcements, and notifications.Regardless of the several common English translations, the base meaning of 'to affix to (A)' is kept in all of the uses of につき, as it simply implies that (B) is in answer to, exists in a way that is directly linked to, suitable for, or caused by (A).

example.japanese: 開店(かいてん)につき、事務(じむ)員(いん)を募集(ぼしゅう)する。
example.english: On account of opening a new shop, we are hiring clerks.

example.japanese: 暑(あつ)い気象(きしょう)につき、ケイティ・シェリーのコンサートがキャンセルされました。ご迷惑(めいわく)をおかけして申(もう)し訳(わけ)ありません。
example.english: Due to hot weather, Katy Sherry's concert has been canceled. We are sorry for the inconvenience.

example.japanese: 改築(かいちく)につき、２ 階(かい)のお手洗(てあらい)をご使用(しよう)ください。ご迷惑(めいわく)をおかけして申(もう)し訳(わけ)ありません。
example.english: Due to renovation, please use the restroom on the second floor. We are sorry for the inconvenience.

example.japanese: 明日(あした)は祭日(さいじつ)につき、会社(かいしゃ)は休(やす)みです。
example.english: On account of tomorrow's festival, the company will be closed.

example.japanese: 工事(こうじ)中(ちゅう)につき、迂回(うかい)してください。
example.english: Due to construction, please take a detour.

english_grammar.title: に付(つ)け
english_grammar.explanation: whenever, every time something happens
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ につけ（て） Noun + につけ（て）
english_grammar.attention: Rarely used in modern times, mostly in literature, 文学的・古い
english_grammar.about: In a similar way to につき, につけ implies that there is a something that is 'affixed' to the event or occasion of (A). However, unlike に就(つ)き this structure is a combination of に and the conjunctive form of the る-Verb 付(つ)ける 'to affix', or 'to adhere'.When using につけ, the most common translation will be that something is happening 'every (A)', or 'whenever (A)'. In the (B) part of the sentence, the thoughts or feelings of the speaker will often be expressed in relation to (A). Additionally, (B) will always be something that is thought to happen naturally due to (A).This structure may appear with either verbs or nouns in their dictionary forms. 元(もと)カノが写(うつ)っている写真(しゃしん)を見(み)るにつけ、胸(むね)が痛(いた)くなる。Every time I see a picture with my ex-girlfriend, my heart aches. この防波堤(ぼうはてい)で釣(つ)りをするにつけ、父親(ちちおや)のことを思(おも)い出(だ)す。Every time I fish on this pier, it reminds me of my father. 彼(かれ)は何(なに)かにつけ文句(もんく)を言(い)うので、一緒(いっしょ)にいるだけで疲(つか)れる。Since he complains whenever anything happens, it's exhausting being around him. 妻(つま)は妊娠中(にんしんちゅう)なので悲(かな)しいにつけ嬉(うれ)しいにつけ、すぐに泣(な)き出(だ)します。Since my wife is pregnant she cries easily whenever she is sad or happy. It is also possible to see につけて, but the abbreviated form is far more common. あの時(とき)先輩(せんぱい)に言(い)われた事(こと)を思(おも)い出(だ)すにつけて、怒(いか)りが込(こ)み上(あ)がってきます。Every time I remember what my senpai said to me, I get filled with anger. 彼(かれ)と一緒(いっしょ)に時間(じかん)を過(す)ごすにつけて、なんでこんな人(ひと)と付(つ)き合(あ)っているんだろうと思(おも)う。Everytime I spend time with him, I think to myself, 'why am I still dating such a person'. Caution - This is considered a fairly old-fashioned grammar structure, so will mostly only be seen in literature or shows that are emphasizing a specific time period.

example.japanese: この絵(え)を見(み)るにつけ、子供(こども)の頃(ころ)のことを思(おも)い出(だ)す。
example.english: Every time I see this picture, I recall my childhood.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は昔(むかし)から古(ふる)い写真(しゃしん)にとても興味(きょうみ)があった。写真(しゃしん)を見(み)るにつけ、撮(と)られた人(ひと)は誰(だれ)なのか、後(のち)にどんな生活(せいかつ)を送(おく)っていたのかなど疑問(ぎもん)に思(おも)う。
example.english: Since long ago, I have been interested in old pictures. Whenever I see a photo, I wonder who the people are, what kind of life they led, etc.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の高校生(こうこうせい)の生活(せいかつ)を思(おも)うにつけて、あの時(とき)の楽(たの)しさを思(おも)い出(だ)す。
example.english: Every time I think on my high school life, I recall how much fun I had.

example.japanese: 隣(となり)の叔父(おじ)さんは何(なに)かにつけて文句(もんく)を言(い)う人(ひと)だ。
example.english: The old man next door is a person who complains whenever something (anything) happens.

example.japanese: 悪(わる)い噂(うわさ)を聞(き)くにつけて、だんだん不安(ふあん)になってきた。
example.english: Every time I hear a bad rumor, I gradually become anxious.

english_grammar.title: に関(かか)わる
english_grammar.explanation: to relate to, to have to do with, concerning, depends on
english_grammar.structure: Noun + にかかわる Noun + にかかわる + Noun
english_grammar.about: When grouped with に, the う-Verb 関(かか)わる 'to be concerned with' is frequently used to show a relation between (A) and (B). This grammar pattern may be translated as 'relating to (A), (B)', concerning (A), (B)', or '(B) that has to do with (A)'.This structure appears after nouns, and is occasionally followed directly to a second noun in order to modify its meaning. Also, it is most common to see this pattern in its non-kanji form. あの試験(しけん)は私(わたし)の人生(じんせい)にかかわるので、一生懸命(いっしょうけんめい)勉強(べんきょう)しなくてはならない。​​I have to study hard for that exam because my life depends on it. 別(べつ)に命(いのち)にかかわる病気(びょうき)では無(な)いので、すぐに治療(ちりょう)する必要(ひつよう)はないです。This is not a disease that will affect your life, so there's no need to treat it immediately. This grammar pattern may also highlight that (A) is something that the speaker should be cautious about, due to a potential negative outcome. この面接(めんせつ)は私(わたし)の人生(じんせい)にかかわるので、頑張(がんば)らなければいけない。This interview concerns my life, so I must do my best. そのファイルにはお客様(きゃくさま)にかかわる大切(たいせつ)な情報(じょうほう)が記載(きさい)されているので何(なに)があっても絶対(ぜったい)無(な)くさないようにしてください。That file contains important information concerning our customers, so please do not lose it at all costs. Caution - Despite being similar to に関(かん)する, にかかわる implies a deeper, more important relationship between (A) and (B), so they are not completely interchangeable. このツールの使(つか)い方(かた)にかかわる質問(しつもん)はありますか？Do you have any questions that have to do with how to use this tool? (Unnatural Japanese) このツールの使(つか)い方(かた)に関(かん)する質問(しつもん)はありますか？Do you have any questions concerning how to use this tool? (Natural Japanese)

example.japanese: 医師(いし)は命(いのち)にかかわる仕事(しごと)です。
example.english: A doctor's job has to do with life.

example.japanese: この商品(しょうひん)の成功(せいこう)はわが社(しゃ)の将来(しょうらい)にかかわることだ。
example.english: The future of our company depends on this product's success.

example.japanese: 規制(きせい)を実施(じっし)するのはビットコインの市場(しじょう)の浮沈(ふちん)にかかわる問題(もんだい)だ。
example.english: The rise and fall of the Bitcoin market depends on the enforcement of its regulation.

example.japanese: 判事(はんじ)の行動(こうどう)は司法(しほう)の信用(しんよう)にかかわる。
example.english: Trust in the justice administration depends on the judge's behavior.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の約束(やくそく)を守(まも)らないと私(わたし)の沽券(こけん)にかかわるよ。
example.english: My reputation depends on keeping my promise. | If I do not keep my promise, my reputation will be affected

synonym.explanation: in・on・at, regarding, in terms of
concerning, about, regarding
related to, about, regarding
as soon as
despite, in spite of, regardless, nevertheless

english_grammar.title: に向(む)かって
english_grammar.explanation: towards, to face, to head to
english_grammar.structure: Noun + に向かって Noun + に向けて Noun + に向けて + の + Noun
english_grammar.about: Coming from a link between に and the う-Verb 向(むか)かう 'to face', or 'to go towards' in its て-form, に向(むか)かって indicates that some specific action is being done 'towards (A)' or 'facing (A)'. (A) usually marks a stationary object or destination in the form of a noun. However, it can also mark less obvious destinations, such as the future '未来(みらい)'. マイクに向(む)かって何(なに)か一言(ひとこと)お願(ねが)いします。Please face the mic and say something. 空(そら)に向(む)かって大声(おおごえ)を出(だ)した。I shouted loudly towards the sky. 明(あか)るい未来(みらい)に向(む)かって一緒(いっしょ)に人生(じんせい)を歩(あゆ)もうじゃ無(な)いか！Why don't we walk toward a bright future together! Additionally, when 向(む)ける (the transitive form of the verb) is used, it will imply that the speaker is intentionally 'aiming' or 'facing' something towards (A). This is especially true when the objective of the speaker is to make something 'suitable' for (A). 新入社員(しんにゅうしゃいん)に向(む)けて何(なに)かアドバイスを一言(ひとこと)お願(ねが)いします。Please share a few words of advice suitable for the new employees. 彼(かれ)らは全国(ぜんこく)大会(たいかい)に向(む)けて毎日(まいにち)朝(あさ)から夜(よる)までトレーニングをしている。They are training towards the national championship from morning to night everyday.

example.japanese: カメラに向(む)かって、笑顔(えがお)をお願(ねが)いします。
example.english: Please face the camera and smile.

example.japanese: 将来(しょうらい)に向(む)かって、治療(ちりょう)の発展(はってん)は進(すす)む一方(いっぽう)だ。
example.english: Heading toward the future, medical development is continuously progressing.

example.japanese: 日本(にほん)をはじめ、外国(がいこく)に向(む)けてブランドを広(ひろ)げたい。
example.english: Starting with Japan, I want to expand my brand towards foreign countries.

example.japanese: 受験生(じゅけんせい)に向(む)けてアドバイスをお願(ねが)いします。
example.english: Please give an advice aimed at a student preparing for exams.

example.japanese: 小学生(しょうがくせい)に向(む)かってなんでそんなに難(むずか)しい言(い)い方(かた)をするのだろう...
example.english: I wonder why he uses such a difficult way of speaking toward elementary school students.

synonym.explanation: To, Toward
intended for, aimed at
suitable for, facing

english_grammar.title: が気(き)になる
english_grammar.explanation: To be interested in, to be concerned about
english_grammar.structure: Noun + が気になる Verb + こと(1) + が気になる (1) の
english_grammar.about: One of the many collocations in Japanese based on 気(き) 'attention', or 'focus', is 気(き)になる. This is just a combination of the noun 気(き), に, and the う-Verb なる 'to become'. Also, 気になる will come after (A) が, where (A) marks the thing that is drawing the 'attention' or 'focus' of the speaker.The most common translations for this structure are 'to be interested in (A)', or 'to be concerned about (A)'. This grammar pattern will appear before nouns, and noun-like phrases. 家(いえ)自体(じたい)は良(い)いと思(おも)うんですけど、やっぱり値段(ねだん)が気(き)になります。なんでこんなに安(やす)いんですか？I think the house itself is nice, however I am concerned about the price. Why is it so cheap? 私(わたし)は高橋(たかはし)さんが気(き)になる。I am interested in Takahashi-san. やっぱりお前(まえ)がさっき言(い)ったことが気(き)になる。I am still concerned about what you said earlier. 私(わたし)は好(す)きな人(ひと)の考(かんが)えていることが気(き)になる。I am interested in what the person I like is thinking about. Caution - Unlike 気(き)にする, which implies more that the speaker in intentionally putting their 'focus' on (A) due to it being difficult to ignore, the use of なる just highlights that (A) is 'becoming' something that is being focused on naturally, due to either the speakers concern or interest in the result. 私(わたし)が気(き)にすることは彼(かれ)が良(い)い人(ひと)かどうかだけです。All I care about is whether he is a good person or not. 私(わたし)が気(き)になることは彼(かれ)が良(い)い人(ひと)かどうかだけです。The only thing that I am concerned about is whether he is a good person or not.

example.japanese: 最近(さいきん)、芸能界(げいのうかい)が気(き)になる。
example.english: Recently, I have become interested in the entertainment world.

example.japanese: あの工場(こうじょう)見学(けんがく)が気(き)になる。
example.english: I am interested in taking a tour of that factory.

example.japanese: この香水(こうすい)を付(つ)けている人(ひと)が気(き)になる。
example.english: I am interested in people who wear this perfume.

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)の日本語(にほんご)のアクセントが気(き)になる。出身(しゅっしん)はどこなんだろう…
example.english: I am interested in my friend's Japanese accent. I wonder where he is from.

example.japanese: この足跡(あしあと)が気(き)になる。もしかしたら熊(くま)の足跡(あしあと)かもしれません。
example.english: I am concerned about these tracks. It is possible that they are bear tracks.

english_grammar.title: に気(き)を付(つ)ける
english_grammar.explanation: take care, be careful, pay attention, make sure, watch out
english_grammar.structure: Noun + に気をつける Verb［ない］+ ように気をつける
english_grammar.attention: Often used with ないように
english_grammar.about: Another of the large number of collocations in Japanese based on 気(き) 'attention', or 'focus', is 気(き)を付(つ)ける. This is just a combination of the noun 気(き), を, and the る-Verb 付(つ)ける 'to adhere', or 'to attach'. 気(き)を付(つ)ける primarily follows (A) に. This marks (A) as something that the speaker is 'adhering' their attention to, and translates as 'to pay attention to (A)', 'to be careful of (A)', or 'to watch out for (A)'.This grammar pattern is used after nouns or noun-like phrases, indicating the thing that is being warned about, or that the speaker themselves is being cautious of. 最近(さいきん)、電車(でんしゃ)に痴漢(ちかん)が沢山(たくさん)いるらしいから怪(あや)しい人(ひと)に気(き)をつけて帰(かえ)ってくるんだよ。I hear there are a lot of perverts on the trains these days, so watch out for suspicious people on your way back home. 車(くるま)で歩道(ほどう)を横切(よこぎ)る時(とき)には歩行者(ほこうしゃ)に気(き)を付(つ)けましょう。Be careful of pedestrians when you drive through a sidewalk. Most often, 気(き)を付(つ)ける will be used to warn about possible errors that could be made, mistakes, or simply the loss of focus. Due to this, it frequently follows negative verbs as ないよう, highlighting that something should be done in a 'manner' that doesn't result in (A). このギターは俺(おれ)の姉(ねえ)ちゃんのやつだから壊(こわ)さないように気(き)を付(つ)けてね。This guitar belongs to my sister, so please be careful not to break it. 今月(こんげつ)はお金(かね)を無駄(むだ)遣(づか)いしないように気(き)を付(つ)けよう。This month, I will be careful not to waste money.

example.japanese: 氷(こおり)は滑(すべ)りやすいから、足(あし)もとに気(き)をつけて。
example.english: The ice is slippery, so please watch your step.

example.japanese: 妊娠(にんしん)中(ちゅう)の女性(じょせい)は、健康(けんこう)に気(き)をつけるべきだ。
example.english: Pregnant women should be careful of their health.

example.japanese: 階段(かいだん)は急(きゅう)なので、落(お)ちないように気(き)をつけなさい。
example.english: Since the stairs are steep, take care not to fall.

example.japanese: 母(はは)：パソコンの隣(となり)で食事(しょくじ)をする時(とき)は、水(みず)を零(こぼ)さないように気(き)をつけて。
example.english: Mother: When you are eating next to the computer, take care not to spill water on it.

example.japanese: 通(とお)りを横切(よこぎ)る時(とき)には、車(くるま)に気(き)をつけて。
example.english: When you are crossing the street, watch out for cars.

english_grammar.title: も構(かま)わず
english_grammar.explanation: without worrying about
english_grammar.structure: Verb + の + も(1) + かまわず ［い］Adjective + の + も + かまわず Noun + も(1) + かまわず (1) にも
english_grammar.about: も構(かま)わず is an expression that combines も, the う-Verb 構(かま)う 'to mind', or 'to care', and the literary auxiliary verb ず, which connects to verbs in the same way, and has the same meaning as ない. Common translations for this pattern include 'without worrying about (A), (B)', and 'without minding (A), (B)'.This structure is seen with verbs, い-Adjectives, and な-Adjectives followed by の, but may also follow nouns without the addition of の. Occasionally, にも may be used instead of も for further emphasis. 娘(むすめ)はレポートの提出(ていしゅつ)日(び)が迫(せま)っているのも構(かま)わず、友達(ともだち)と遊(あを)んでばかりいる。Without worrying about the due date of her paper, all she is doing is hanging out with friends. 彼(かれ)は遠(とお)いにも構(かま)わず、広島(ひろしま)まで休憩(きゅうけい)なしで運転(うんてん)し続(つづ)けた。Without worrying about the long distance, he kept driving to Hiroshima without taking a break. 彼女(かのじょ)は危険(きけん)なのも構(かま)わず、池(いけ)で溺(おぼ)れていた猫(ねこ)を救出(きゅうしゅつ)した。Without worrying about the danger, she rescued a cat that was drowning in the lake. 鈴木(すずき)先輩(せんぱい)は時間(じかん)も構(かま)わず、電話(でんわ)を掛(か)けてくるから困(こま)っている。I am annoyed because Suzuki-senpai calls me without worrying about the time. も構(かま)わず is used most frequently to express that (A) is something that is either being ignored or that the speaker is not worried about. The (B) part of the statement will regularly highlight something that is being without any consideration for (A). This comes from the standard 'to brace', or 'to give pause' meaning of 構(かま)う. 医者(いしゃ)にストップをかけられていたにも構(かま)わず試合(しあい)に出(で)て、大怪我(おおけが)をしてしまいました。I participated in the tournament without caring about the doctor's order to stop, and got seriously injured.

example.japanese: 他(ほか)の人(ひと)の視線(しせん)もかまわず、彼女(かのじょ)は裸(はだか)でダンスをした。
example.english: Without worrying about other people looking, she danced in the nude.

example.japanese: 恥(は)ずかしさにもかまわず、彼(かれ)はみんなの前(まえ)で告白(こくはく)した。
example.english: Without worrying about embarrassment, he confessed his feelings in front of everyone.

example.japanese: 失敗(しっぱい)にもかまわず、研究(けんきゅう)に打(う)ち込(こ)んでいる。
example.english: Without worrying about failure, I am diving into my research.

example.japanese: 御馳走(ごちそう)にもかまわず、仕事(しごと)に没頭(ぼっとう)している。
example.english: Without worrying about food, they immerse themselves in their work.

example.japanese: 再三(さいさん)の忠告(ちゅうこく)もかまわず結婚(けっこん)し、大(だい)失敗(しっぱい)しました。
example.english: I got married without worrying about the repeated advice I got. It was a huge failure.

english_grammar.title: 兼(か)ねる
english_grammar.explanation: cannot・be unable to, hard to, hesitant to
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ かねる
english_grammar.attention: Should be used only with transitive words with the exception of わかる and できる
english_grammar.about: 兼(か)ねる, a る-Verb meaning 'to spread across' (usually 2 different activities or thought processes), often follows the ます-stem of other verbs in order to highlight that '(A) is not possible'. However, 兼(か)ねる often indicates that the speaker would actually like to do (A), but cannot due to some external circumstances such as difficulty, already being busy, being hesitant, etc.This particular grammar pattern will most frequently be seen in its non-kanji form, although both are possible. こう言(い)う場合(ばあい)でも返金(へんきん)はできかねます。Even in situations like this we can't give you a refund. それはお客様(きゃくさま)のプライバシーに関(かか)わる情報(じょうほう)なのでお答(こた)えしかねます。That is information regarding our client's privacy so we cannot answer that. お電話(でんわ)での予約(よやく)受付(うけつけ)は受(う)けかねます。We cannot accept reservations by phone. 兼(か)ねる is somewhat formal, and may be used in cases where a phrase like できない would be considered too strong, so the speaker wants to lightly imply that (A) cannot be done.Fun-fact - As 兼(か)ねる means 'to spread across', this expression can be thought of as similar to 'to be a stretch' in English. It just indicates that doing the action of (A) would be a stretch of the speaker's ability or capacity. 弊社(へいしゃ)は内装(ないそう)専門(せんもん)なので外装(がいそう)に関(かか)わるお仕事(しごと)はお引(ひ)き受(う)けしかねます。It would be a bit of a stretch for us to accept exterior work, as we specialize in interiors.

example.japanese: 生徒(せいと):時間(じかん)旅行(りょこう)ができると思(おも)います。先生(せんせい):そのような意見(いけん)には、とうてい同意(どうい)しかねます。
example.english: Student: I think that time travel is possible.Teacher: I just cannot agree with such an opinion.

example.japanese: 悪(わる)いけど、試験(しけん)はこれ以上(いじょう)良(よ)い点数(てんすう)をつけかねる。
example.english: I am sorry, but I cannot give you a better score on the exam than that.

example.japanese: 匿名(とくめい)の大臣(だいじん)さん: 将来(しょうらい)の財政(ざいせい)赤字(あかじ)に関(かん)する首相(しゅしょう)の言葉(ことば)は信(しん)じかねる。反対(はんたい)するわけにもいかないので、うなずくしかない。
example.english: Anonymous cabinet minister: It is hard to believe the prime minister's words about the future budget deficit. However, because I can't oppose them, I just nod.

example.japanese: 個人(こじん)的(てき)な理由(りゆう)での払(はら)い戻(もど)しは応(おう)じかねます。
example.english: I cannot accept a refund based on personal reasons.

example.japanese: そんな無茶(むちゃ)な要望(ようぼう)はお引受(ひきう)けしかねます。
example.english: I cannot accept such an absurd demand.

synonym.explanation: unable to, cannot
cannot afford to, no way・impossible to do
being unable to finish or complete
and also, also (partly) to, also (partly) for (the purpose of), at the same time, to double as, when … also, while … as well, and as

english_grammar.title: 兼(か)ねない
english_grammar.explanation: might・could be, capable of, possible
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ かねない Noun + に + ​​かねない
english_grammar.about: The negative form of the る-Verb 兼(か)ねる 'to spread across' (usually 2 different activities or thought processes) is a grammar pattern that indicates a possibility of (A) happening, especially when it is something that the speaker themselves cannot control. 兼(か)ねない is often translated as 'might (A)', 'capable of (A)', or '(A) is a possibility'.This structure will be seen connected to the ます-stem of verbs, or after nouns followed by に. Both the kanji and non-kanji forms may be used. それは命(いのち)を落(お)としかねない感染症(かんせんしょう)らしい。Apparently that is an infectious disease that could lead to death. 地震(じしん)の後(あと)には津波(つなみ)が起(お)こりかねないので、出来(でき)るだけ早(はや)く避難(ひなん)しましょう。A tsunami might follow an earthquake so try to evacuate as soon as possible. ベッドでの喫煙(きつえん)は火災(かさい)になりかねないのでご遠慮(えんりょ)ください。Please refrain from smoking on the bed as it might cause a fire. 仕事(しこと)のやりすぎは、鬱(うつ)の原因(げんいん)になりかねない。Working too much could be a cause of depression. It is quite common to see 兼(か)ねない come after conditional phrases that include と, ば, たら, でも, and similar structures. This indicates that 'if (A) were to happen, (B) may also occur'. 操作(そうさ)を間違(まちが)えれば怪我人(けがにん)が出(で)かねない。If you operate it wrong, it could cause injuries. どんなに注意(ちゅうい)をしていても、事故(じこ)は起(お)こりかねない。No matter how careful you are, accidents might happen. Caution - While this grammar structure is most often used to highlight negative outcomes, it may also be used to indicate or desire or wish sarcastically. ちゃんと毎日(まいにち)勉強(べんきょう)すれば、来週(らいしゅう)のテストは合格(ごうかく)できかねない。 If I study everyday, I might do well on the test next week. Fun-fact - As 兼(か)ねる means 'to spread across', in the negative, this expression can be thought of as similar to 'to not be a stretch' in English. It just indicates the action of (A) would not be a stretch of the ability or capacity of whoever or whatever is being discussed. 彼女(かのじょ)はどんな病気(びょうき)でも治(なお)しかねない。It wouldn't be a stretch to say that she can cure any disease.

example.japanese: 賞味(しょうみ)期限切(きげんぎ)れの食品(しょくひん)は、下痢(げり)の原因(げんいん)になりかねない。
example.english: Expired food could be a cause of diarrhea.

example.japanese: この犬(いぬ)に噛(か)まれたら、大(おお)怪我(けが)をしかねない。
example.english: If his dog bites you, it is capable of causing serious injury.

example.japanese: この事(こと)をそのままにしていたら、摩擦(まさつ)を生(う)みかねない。
example.english: If you leave it at that, it might cause conflict.

example.japanese: あの財閥(ざいばつ)は、目的(もくてき)を達(たっ)するためなら他人(たにん)などかまわず何(なに)でもやりかねない。
example.english: That firm is quite capable of doing anything to reach their goals without any regard to other people.

example.japanese: この書類(しょるい)を開示(かいじ)されてはスキャンダルが 起(お)きかねないから、処分(しょぶん)する必要(ひつよう)があります。
example.english: If those documents are disclosed, it might cause a scandal, so it is necessary to get rid of them.

synonym.explanation: there is a risk/fear that, be in danger of, possibility of
it's not that…, kind of, might, slightly, somewhat, in some respects

antonym.explanation: cannot・be unable to, hard to, hesitant to

english_grammar.title: を除(のぞ)いて
english_grammar.explanation: except, with the exception of, unless
english_grammar.structure: Noun + を 除いて（は）(1) Noun + を 除く + Noun (1) を 除き
english_grammar.about: を除(のぞ)いて is a formal grammar structure that combines を and the て-form of the う-Verb 除(のぞ)く 'to exclude'. This pattern will be seen following nouns in their dictionary form, and carries the meaning of 'except for (A), (B)', 'with the exception of (A), (B)', 'unless (A), (B)', or 'excluding (A), (B)'. As with many verb-based expressions, the standard form may also be used when directly modifying a second noun. 高橋(たかはし)さんと浜崎(はまさき)さんを除(のぞ)いて、他(ほか)のみんなは残業(ざんぎょう)をしてください。 Everyone, with the exception of Takahashi-san and Hamasaki-san, please work overtime. 私(わたし)は第(だい)２土曜日(どようび)を除(のぞ)いて、毎日(まいにち)働(はたら)いています。 With the exception of the second Saturday of the month, I work every day. そこの壁(かべ)にかけてあるギターを除(のぞ)く全(すべ)てのギターは母親(ははおや)のものです。 With the exception of that guitar hanging on the wall, all of it is my mother's. 中田(なかた)先生(せんせい)を除(のぞ)く全(すべ)ての先生(せんせい)は同(おな)じ大学(だいがく)を卒業(そつぎょう)したらしい。 Apparently, all of the teachers, except Mr. Nakata, graduated from the same college. を除(のぞ)いて is more formal than 以外(いがい) 'except for', and is frequently found in formal writing, on street signs, and other similar places.

example.japanese: 病院(びょういん)スタッフを除(のぞ)いて、入(はい)ってはならない。
example.english: With the exception of hospital staff, do not enter.

example.japanese: 警察(けいさつ)は捜索(そうさく)状(じょう)を持(も)っている場合(ばあい)を除(のぞ)いては家(いえ)を捜索(そうさく)することができません。
example.english: Police cannot search a building unless they have a search warrant.

example.japanese: エウロパを除(のぞ)いて、これらすべての世界(せかい)が人間(にんげん)に属(ぞく)しています。
example.english: All these worlds belong to humans, except Europa.

example.japanese: 動物(どうぶつ)園(えん)にいるものを除(のぞ)くすべてのライオンはアフリカに生息(せいそく)している。
example.english: All lions, except those in Zoos, live in Africa.

example.japanese: 動物(どうぶつ)園(えん)を除(のぞ)くすべての都立(とりつ)公園(こうえん)は無料(むりょう)である。
example.english: All metropolitan parks, excluding zoos, are free.

synonym.explanation: setting aside, apart from
except・besides, other than, with the exception of

english_grammar.title: に関(かか)わらず
english_grammar.explanation: regardless of, whether or, no matter, with or without
english_grammar.structure: Noun (A) + 、(1) + Noun (B) + にかかわらず(2) A(3) + か + B(3) + か + にかかわらず(2) A(4) + (Antonym) A(4) + にかかわらず(2) A(3) + かどうか(5) + にかかわらず(2) A(3) + A［ない］(3) + にかかわらず(2) (1) ・、と、や (2) にかかわらなく (3) Noun、 ［な］Adjective、 ［い］Adjective、 Verb (4) ［い］Adjective、［な］Adjective (5) か否か
english_grammar.about: In order to convey 'regardless of (A)', 'no matter if (A)', or 'with or without (A)', the expression に関(かか)わらず will often be used. This is a combination of に, the う-Verb 関(かか)わる 'to be affected', 'to be influenced', and the literary auxiliary verb ず, which connects with verbs in the same way, and carries the same meaning as ない.This structure may be seen with verbs or adjectives in either their dictionary or negative forms, or with nouns in their dictionary form. Frequently the same word is repeated in both the positive and the negative, or grouped with かどうか in order to strengthen the 'whether (A) or not (A)' nuance. 雨(あめ)が降(ふ)るか降(ふ)らないかに関(かか)わらず、運動会(うんどうかい)は開催(かいさい)されます。The sports day will be held, regardless of whether it rains or not. このビーチは天気(てんき)がいいかどうかに関(かか)わらず、毎日(まいにち)サーファーたちで賑(にぎ)わっています。This beach is crowded with surfers regardless of the weather. 上手(うま)い下手(へた)に関(かか)わらず、何事(なにごと)も一生懸命(いっしょうけんめい)やるのが大切(たいせつ)だ。Regardless of if you are good or bad, it is important to do your best at everything you do. 彼(かれ)は性別(せいべつ)や国籍(こくせき)に関(かか)わらず、誰(だれ)とでも友達(ともだち)になれる。Regardless of gender or nationality, he is able to become friends with anyone. As the literal meaning of this structure is 'without being influenced by (A), (B)', or 'without being affected by (A), (B)', the primary nuance is on the fact that (B) is something that exists or will happen without consideration for (A). Due to this, に関(かか)わらず may also be used to show that 'any type of (A) will result in the same (B)'. このゲームは年齢(ねんれい)に関(かか)わらず、誰(だれ)でも楽(たの)しめます！Regardless of age, anyone can enjoy this game!

example.japanese: お天気(てんき)に関(かか)わらず雨天(うてん)でも、例年(れいねん)通(どお)り、マンション周辺(しゅうへん)の草取(くさと)りを行(おこな)います。
example.english: Regardless of the weather, even if it's rainy, the annual apartment building weeding event will take place.

example.japanese: 性(せい)別(べつ)や年齢(ねんれい)に関(かか)わらず、人(ひと)は毎日(まいにち)健康(けんこう)の為(ため)に散歩(さんぽ)をします。
example.english: Regardless of gender or age, people walk for their health every day.

example.japanese: 正義(せいぎ)感(かん)が強(つよ)いかどうかに関(かか)わらず、責任(せきにん)をもって活動(かつどう)できる限(かぎ)り、ボランティアになることができる！
example.english: Regardless of having a strong sense of justice or not, as long as one can perform the activities responsibly, then they can become a volunteer.

example.japanese: 《広告(こうこく)》会員(かいいん)の有無(うむ)に関(かか)わらずこのジムの開店(かいてん)記念(きねん)日(び)のため、今週(こんしゅう)のみ入場(にゅうじょう)無料(むりょう)の行事(ぎょうじ)を実施(じっし)します！
example.english: Advertisement: Regardless if you are a member or not, limited to this week only, in celebration of our one-year anniversary, we are holding a free admission event!

example.japanese: 商品(しょうひん)の使用(しよう)前(ぜん)使用(しよう)後(ご)に関(かか)わらず、会社(かいしゃ)方針(ほうしん)により返品(へんぴん)は受(う)け入(い)れられません。
example.english: Regardless of whether you have used the product or not, according to the company policy, we do not accept refunds.

synonym.explanation: regardless of, whether or not, no matter, with or without
Whether ~ or not
regardless of, no matter what
despite, in spite of, regardless, nevertheless

english_grammar.title: にも拘(かか)わらず
english_grammar.explanation: despite, in spite of, regardless, nevertheless
english_grammar.structure: Verb + にもかかわらず ［い］Adjective + にもかかわらず ［な］Adjective + である + にもかかわらず Noun + （である）+ にもかかわらず
english_grammar.attention: Do not confuse with にかかわらず
english_grammar.about: にもかかわらず is a formal grammar structure in Japanese used to convey that something is 'in spite of (A)', or 'despite (A)'. This pattern is a combination of に, も, the う-Verb 拘(かか)わる 'to fixate on', or 'to stick to', and the literary auxiliary verb ず, which connects with verbs in the same way, and carries the same meaning as ない.This structure is most frequently seen connected to verbs, い-Adjectives and nouns in their standard forms. In most cases, this pattern will appear without kanji. 浜崎(はまさき)さんは毎日(まいにち)一生懸命(いっしょうけんめい)働(はたら)いていたのにもかかわらず、会社(かいしゃ)をクビになった。Despite working hard every day, Hamasaki-san was fired by the company. 彼(かれ)が悪(わる)いのにもかかわらず、私(わたし)に謝(あやま)らそうとしてきた。Despite him being in the wrong, he tried to make me apologize. 田中(たなか)さんは優(やさ)しくて親切(しんせつ)であるにもかかわらず、見(み)た目(め)が怖(こわ)いから田中(たなか)さんのことをよく知(し)らない人(ひと)からは怖(こわ)がらて避(さ)けられている。Despite Tanaka-san being kind and helpful, he's feared and avoided by those who don't know him well because of his scary appearance. 深夜(しんや)にもかかわらず、上司(じょうし)が鬼電(おにでん)をしてきたので労基(ろうき)に報告(ほうこく)しようと思(おも)う。Despite being late at night, my boss blew up my phone, so I'm thinking of reporting it to the labor standards inspection office. Literally, this phrase can be thought of as expressing 'without being affected by (A), (B)', or 'without fixating on (A), (B)'. However, it is almost always used in exactly the same way as のに 'despite'.Caution - It is important not to get にも拘(かか)わらず mixed up with に関(かか)わらず. The former expresses 'despite', while the latter tends to be used more often for 'no matter if'. お客(きゃく)さんが来(く)ることを知(し)っていたにもかかわらず、部屋(へや)の掃除(そうじ)をしていなかったので息子(むすこ)を叱(しか)った。Despite knowing that we were going to have guests over, my son did not clean his room so I scolded him. お客(きゃく)さんが来(く)るかどうかに関(かか)わらず、部屋(へや)は綺麗(きれい)にしておいてください。Please keep your room clean no matter if guests are coming or not.

example.japanese: 古代(こだい)ローマ時代(じだい)、ガリアはローマによって征服(せいふく)されたにもかかわらず、ある小(ちい)さな村(むら)はなおも戦(たたか)い続(つづ)けた。
example.english: In Ancient Roman times, despite Gaul being conquered by Rome, a certain small village was still fighting.

example.japanese: 全(すべ)ての物体(ぶったい)は、その大小(だいしょう)にもかかわらず、真空(しんくう)においては同(おな)じ速度(そくど)で落下(らっか)する。
example.english: All objects, regardless of their size, fall at the same speed in a vacuum.

example.japanese: オデュッセウスは多数(たすう)の危険(きけん)にもかかわらず、大変(たいへん)な努力(どりょく)の結果(けっか)、ついに彼(かれ)の国(くに)に帰(かえ)ることができた。
example.english: Despite numerous dangers, Odysseus was able to finally return to his country as a result of his great efforts.

example.japanese: 熊(くま)は重(おも)いにもかかわらず、速(はや)く走(はし)れたり、木(き)に登(のぼ)れたりするので、危険(きけん)な動物(どうぶつ)だ。本物(ほんもの)を見(み)かけたら、じっとして驚(おどろ)かさないでください。
example.english: Despite being heavy, since bears run fast, climb trees, and more, they are dangerous animals. If you happen to see one, stand still and do not surprise them.

example.japanese: 単独(たんどく)の無名(むめい)の英雄(えいゆう)は満身(まんしん)創痍(そうい)(傷(きず)だらけ)だった。それにもかかわらず、気力(きりょく)のみで、像(ぞう)のように立(た)った。素晴(すば)らしい景色(けしき)だったと思(おも)う。
example.english: A sole, nameless hero was wounded all over. Nevertheless, by sheer force of will, he remained standing like a statue. It was quite a beautiful sight.

regardless of, whether or not, no matter, with or without

english_grammar.title: に限(かぎ)って
english_grammar.explanation: particularly when, those who, only when
english_grammar.structure: Noun + に限って
english_grammar.about: The expression に限(かぎ)って in Japanese is a phrase that has three primary uses, the first is to show that (B) is an unbelievable thing about (A), the second is to express that something is limited to (A), and the third highlights that in most cases for (A), (B). Depending on the particular nuance that is being used, common translations include 'particularly when (A), (B)', 'those who (A), (B)', and 'only when (A), (B)'.This structure is comprised of に, and the て-form of the う-Verb 限(かぎ)る 'to limit'. Let's look at a few examples of each potential meaning.First, when something about (A) is unbelievable due to what is either expected or previously known. うちの子(こ)に限(かぎ)って、他(ほか)の子(こ)に手(て)を出(だ)すなんて考(かんが)えられない。I can't imagine that my child, in particular, would hit another kid. 彼(かれ)に限(かぎ)って、こんな簡単(かんたん)なことでミスをする訳(わけ)が無(な)い。There is no way that he, in particular, would make a mistake on something this simple. Second, when something is limited to (A). 武(たけし)くんと釣(つ)りに行(い)く日(ひ)に限(かぎ)って、いつも雨(あめ)が降(ふ)るんだよな。Only on days when I go fishing with Takeshi-kun does it always rain. 先輩(せんぱい)は忙(いそが)しい日(ひ)に限(かぎ)って、飲(の)みに誘(さそ)ってくる。My senpai invites me to go drinking with him only on days that I am busy. Third, when (B) is true in most cases concerning (A). 「クレームを入(い)れるぞ」って言(い)う人(ひと)に限(かぎ)ってクレームを入(い)れないからあまり気(き)にしていない。I'm not too worried because particularly those who say, 'I'm going to file a claim', never do (file a claim). 「絶対(ぜったい)後(あと)でやる」って言(い)う人(ひと)に限(かぎ)って、いつまでもやらない人(ひと)が多(おお)い。Many of those who say, 'I'll definitely do it later', never do. While each of these uses can roughly be translated as 'only when', it will be important to keep all three meanings in mind when interpreting sentences that use に限(かぎ)って.

example.japanese: よく節約(せつやく)を口(くち)にしている人(ひと)に限(かぎ)って、給料(きゅうりょう)を受(う)け取(と)っては、後(あと)で身(み)につけもしない服(ふく)など無駄遣(むだづか)いしがちだ。
example.english: Those who often speak about "economizing" tend to waste their money on things like clothes they don't even wear whenever they receive salary.

example.japanese: 外(そと)に調査(ちょうさ)へ出(で)かける時(とき)に限(かぎ)って、雨(あめ)が降(ふ)る。
example.english: It is only when I go out to investigate that it rains.

example.japanese: 飛行機(ひこうき)に乗(の)る時(とき)に限(かぎ)って、天候(てんこう)が悪(わる)かったりする。
example.english: The weather becomes bad and such particularly when I board an airplane.

example.japanese: 定休(ていきゅう)日(び)ではないのに、僕(ぼく)があの店(みせ)に行(い)く日(ひ)に限(かぎ)って臨時(りんじ)休業(きゅうぎょう)している。
example.english: Despite it not being a set holiday, only on days when I go to that store is it temporarily closed.

example.japanese: 僕(ぼく)がカメラを忘(わす)れた日(ひ)に限(かぎ)って虹(にじ)が出(で)る。
example.english: Only on days when I forget my camera, do rainbows appear.

english_grammar.title: に限(かぎ)らず
english_grammar.explanation: not just, not only… but also
english_grammar.structure: Noun + に限らず
english_grammar.attention: More formal than だけでなく
english_grammar.about: に限(かぎ)らず is a sentence pattern in Japanese used that highlights when something is 'not just (A), but (B) too', or 'not only (A), but also (B)'. It is a combination of に, the う-Verb 限(かぎ)る 'to limit', and the literary auxiliary verb ず, which connects with verbs in the same way, and carries the same meaning as ない.This structure will appear after nouns, before the (B) part of the sentence will go on to explain things that can be included in the same scope or category as (A). USJは週末(しゅうまつ)に限(かぎ)らず、平日(へいじつ)でも多(おお)くの人(ひと)で賑(にぎ)わっています。USJ is crowded not only on weekends but also on weekdays. この遊園地(ゆうえんち)は子供(こども)に限(かぎ)らず、大人(おとな)でも楽(たの)しめます。This amusement park is enjoyable not only for children, but also for adults. このカフェは女性(じょせい)に限(かぎ)らず、男性(だんせい)の方(か)にも人気(にんき)があります。This café is popular not only with women but also with men. Occasionally, も may be added for extra emphasis in the (B) part of に限らず sentences. This is especially true when several extra things are being indicated, not just (B). For example, '(B) も (C) も'. このブランドは日本(にほん)だけに限(かぎ)らず、韓国(かんこく)でも中国(ちゅうごく)でも愛(あい)されています。This brand is loved not only in Japan, but also in Korea and China. 新(あたら)しい言語(げんご)を習(なら)う場合(ばあい)、文法(ぶんぽう)に限(かぎ)らず、その国(くに)の文化(ぶんか)もニュアンスも同(おな)じぐらい勉強(べんきょう)したほうがいい。When learning a new language, you should study not only the grammar, but also the culture and nuances of the country, if possible.

example.japanese: 均整(きんせい)で良(よ)い姿(すがた)になるために、夏(なつ)に限(かぎ)らず、年中(ねんじゅう)運動(うんどう)すべきです。
example.english: In order to have a well-balanced appearance, we should exercise not only in summer, but throughout the year.

example.japanese: イエローストーン火山(かざん)の爆発(ばくはつ)の可能性(かのうせい)は、アメリカに限(かぎ)らず世界(せかい)レベルの問題(もんだい)だ。
example.english: The possibility of the Yellowstone super volcano erupting is a problem not only in the U.S., but also on an international level.

example.japanese: ペラペラになるためには勉強(べんきょう)に限(かぎ)らず練習(れんしゅう)を積(つ)むことが大切(たいせつ)だ。
example.english: In order to become fluent, it is important to not only study, but also to practice.

example.japanese: マンションに限(かぎ)らず、綺麗(きれい)な部屋(へや)なら住(す)んでみたい。
example.english: Not just apartments, but if there are beautiful rooms I want to try living there.

example.japanese: 酔(よ)っ払(ぱら)いに限(かぎ)らず、お酒(さけ)を飲(の)んでいる人(ひと)と話(はな)すのが苦手(にがて)です。
example.english: Not only drunks, but I dislike talking to people who are drinking alcohol.

not only… but also
not only but also, let alone, not to mention, of course
not only…but also, as well as
not only...but also..., starting with
not only... but also, let alone, of course,

english_grammar.title: 尚(なお) ①
english_grammar.explanation: still, even, yet
english_grammar.structure: なお + Verb［ている］ なお + Nounもいる なお + Nounもある なお + Noun + だ(1) (1) である
english_grammar.about: When used at the beginning of a statement, the adverb 尚(なお) 'furthermore' will often carry the meaning of 'still', 'even', or 'yet'. This use is regularly seen after the previous statement ends in も, and will emphasize that 'even after (A)', or 'even though (A) is a fact, (B) is still true'. Especially when the information expressed in the (B) part of the sentence is surprising or shocking in some way.This structure will almost always appear without the kanji being used. Additionally, the (B) part of statements that include 尚(なお) will also frequently include も, in order to specify that the new information is 'in addition to (A)'. 上司(じょうし)のパワハラを人事(じんじ)に報告(ほうこく)してもなお、上司(じょうし)のパワハラが続(つづ)いている。Even after reporting my boss to human resources for power harassment, his harassment is still continuing. 彼(かれ)は先生(せんせい)に注意(ちゅうい)されてもなお、指摘(してき)された事(こと)を直(なお)そうとしない。He still refuses to fix what was pointed out to him, even after being warned by his teacher. 豊橋市(とよはしし)では今(いま)もなおチンチン電車(でんしゃ)が走(はし)っている。Trams are still running in Toyohashi-city. 浜崎(はまさき)先生(せんせい)は卒業後(そつぎょう)もなお、私(わたし)たちの事(こと)をしっかりと覚(おぼ)えている。Mr. Hamasaki still remembers us even after graduation. 今(いま)もなお has come to be used as a set phase, and may be heard in may different situations. Despite this, 尚(なお) itself is quite a formal grammar structure.

example.japanese: 蒸気機関車(じょうききかんしゃ)は今(いま)もなお、電気(でんき)がない地域(ちいき)において使用(しよう)されている。
example.english: Steam locomotives are still used in areas where there is no electricity.

example.japanese: アメリア・イアハートの消失(しょうしつ)は今(いま)もなお謎(なぞ)である。
example.english: The disappearance of Amelia Earhart is still a mystery.

example.japanese: ある旅館(りょかん)は718年(ねん)以来(いらい)今(いま)もなお一(ひと)家族(かぞく)によって経営(けいえい)されている。これからもそのまま続(つづ)いていくだろう。
example.english: A certain ryokan is still managed by one family since 718. It seems it will continue like that in the future.

example.japanese: 討議(とうぎ)を続(つづ)けてもなお問題(もんだい)の解決(かいけつ)を見(み)なかった。
example.english: Even after continuously discussing the problem, a solution has yet to present itself.

example.japanese: 退院(たいいん)してもなお病院(びょういん)に遊(あそ)びに来(く)る人(ひと)が絶(た)えないほど人気(にんき)の病院(びょういん)があるらしい。
example.english: Apparently there are hospitals that are so popular that even after being released, people still come to visit.

synonym.explanation: in addition, incidentally, furthermore, moreover

english_grammar.title: 尚(なお) ②
english_grammar.explanation: in addition, incidentally, furthermore, moreover
english_grammar.structure: Phrase. なお、+ Phrase
english_grammar.about: When used at the beginning of a sentence, the adverb 尚(なお) 'furthermore' will often carry the meaning of 'in addition', 'furthermore', 'even more', or 'moreover'. This use is regularly seen after the previous sentence or clause has expressed some base fact or situation that the second sentence will then add to. Especially when the information expressed in the (B) part of the sentence is surprising or shocking in some way.This structure will almost always appear without the kanji being used. それでは只今(ただいま)から説明会(せつめいかい)を開始(かいし)したいと思(おも)います。なお、ご不明(ふめい)な点(てん)がある場合(ばあい)はお気軽(きがる)にお申(もう)し付(つ)けください。Well then, I'd like to begin the information session. In addition, if you have any questions, please feel free to ask. ５日(か)の土曜日(どようび)には11時(じ)までに待(ま)ち合(あ)わせ場所(ばしょ)に集合(しゅうごう)してください。なお、遅(おく)れる場合(ばあい)は私(わたし)のLINEまで連絡(れんらく)をください。Please be at the meeting place by 11:00 am on Saturday the 5th. Moreover, if you are going to be late, please message me on LINE. 内容(ないよう)の確認(かくにん)が出来(でき)ましたら、「次(つぎ)へ」をクリックしてください。なお、「次(つぎ)へ」をクリックした後(あと)には内容(ないよう)の変更(へんこう)ができないのでご注意(ちゅうい)ください。After confirming the details, please click 'Next'. Please note that you cannot make changes after clicking 'Next'. As 尚(なお) is a formal grammar structure, it will most frequently appear in letters, posters, commercials and other similar material.Fun-fact - In all of its uses, なお simply indicates that taking the previous information of (A) into account, although (B) may not be expected, it is in fact true. This can be used either positively or negatively, and just highlights (B) as exceeding expectations.

example.japanese: ２０２X年(ねん)７月(しちがつ)２４日(にち)にマンション周辺(しゅうへん)の草取(くさと)りを行(おこな)います。なお、同時(どうじ)に、住人(じゅうにん)の子供(こども)向(む)きのイベントも行(おこな)います。
example.english: On 07/24/202X, weeding will take place around the apartment buildings. In addition, an event for residents' children will also be held at the same time.

example.japanese: 就職(しゅうしょく)面接(めんせつ)は八月(はちがつ)二日(ふつか)に開催(かいさい)される。なお、希望(きぼう)者(しゃ)は何(なに)か質問(しつもん)があれば、ご連絡(れんらく)ください。
example.english: The job interview will be held on August 2nd. Furthermore, if you have any questions, feel free to contact us.

example.japanese: マングースはすばやい反射(はんしゃ)神経(しんけい)や分厚(ぶあつ)い毛皮(けがわ)がある。なお、コブラの毒(どく)に対(たい)して強(つよ)い。したがって、蛇(へび)を食(た)べることは多(おお)い。
example.english: The mongoose has fast reflexes and thick fur. Moreover, the mongoose is also resistant to snake venom. Therefore, it often eats snakes.

example.japanese: 明日(あした)は臨時(りんじ)休業(きゅうぎょう)です。なお、定休(ていきゅう)日(び)は水曜日(すいようび)です。
