english_grammar.title: からといって
english_grammar.explanation: just because
english_grammar.structure: Verb + からといって ［い］Adjective + からといって ［な］Adjective + だからといって Noun + だからといって
english_grammar.about: からといって is a grammar pattern in Japanese comprised of the conjunction particle から 'from', と, and the て-form of the う-Verb 言(い)う 'to say'. It is usually translated to 'just because (A)', and will indicate that the underlying reason of (A) does not necessarily mean that (B) is also true, or that (B) is not good.As this grammar structure often includes a negative statement in the (B) part of the sentence, the more literal translation is closer to 'from saying that (A), doesn't mean (B)'. This simply focuses the nuance on that (A) does not equal (B), despite what one may think.からといって may appear after verbs and い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives and nouns that are followed by だ. たくさん勉強(べんきょう)をしたからといって、テストに合格(ごうかく)するとは限(かぎ)らない。Just because you studied a lot doesn't mean that you will pass the test. 公園(こうえん)が広(ひろ)いからと言(い)って、犬(いぬ)の放(はな)し飼(が)いをしてもいいと言(い)うわけではない。Just because the park is spacious doesn't mean that dogs are allowed off leash. 丈夫(じょうぶ)だからといって、雑(ざつ)に扱(あつか)えば必(かなら)ず壊(こわ)れます。Just because it is sturdy, it will definitely break if you handle it roughly. 日本人(にほんじん)だからといって、漢字(かんじ)を書(か)けるとは限(かぎ)らない。Just because someone is Japanese doesn't mean that they can write kanji. In most cases, からといって will be used for giving strong opinions, or for criticism of someone's actions or behavior.Caution - It is not rare to see からといって abbreviated as either からとて, or からって. There is no change in meaning in either of these cases, but they are more colloquial. 日本(にほん)に2年(ねん)間(かん)住(す)んでいたからとて、日本語(にほんご)が話(はな)せるとは限(かぎ)らない。Just because someone has lived in Japan for 2 years doesn't mean that they can speak Japanese. 暑(あつ)いからって、そんなに休憩(きゅうけい)ばかりしていたら仕事(しごと)が進(すす)まないだろ。Just because it's hot, if you keep taking so many breaks, you will never get your job done.

example.japanese: 貧(まず)しいからといって人(ひと)を差別(さべつ)することはこの学校(がっこう)で禁止(きんし)されている。
example.english: Discriminating against someone just because they are poor is against our school policy.

example.japanese: お父(とお)さんはよく買(か)い物(もの)に行(い)き、安(やす)いからといって買(か)いすぎてしまい、買(か)った食(た)べ物(もの)を腐(くさ)らせている。
example.english: Dad often goes shopping, buys too much, just because it is cheap, and the food ends up going spoiled.

example.japanese: 近頃(ちかごろ)の人(ひと)は便利(べんり)だからといって不健康(ふけんこう)なファストフードを食(た)べてばかり、いいことはないと思(おも)います。
example.english: Recently people are only eating unhealthy fast-food just because it is convenient. I think that is not a good thing.

example.japanese: トレーニングをしたからといって、必(かなら)ず試合(しあい)に勝(か)てるわけではない。
example.english: Just because you trained, it doesn't mean that you are certain to win the match.

example.japanese: 丼物(どんぶりもの)だからといって、安(やす)いとは限(かぎ)りません。
example.english: Just because it is “donburi”, doesn't confine it to being cheap.

synonym.explanation: simply because, only because, just because, simply on account of

english_grammar.title: そういえば
english_grammar.explanation: speaking of which, by the way, come to think of it
english_grammar.structure: そういえば + Phrase
english_grammar.about: そういえば is a hypothetical structure in Japanese consisting of the adverb そう 'like that', and the ば conjunctive form of the う-Verb 言(い)う 'to say'. Common translations include 'speaking of which', 'by the way', and 'come to think of it'. These translations are actually very close to the literal translation of 'if saying that' in that they all refer back to the previous statement as being a trigger for bringing up a topic that the speaker wants to discuss.そういえば will primarily appear at the beginning of sentences, before the speaker will then bring up the topic that they were reminded of. そういえば、この前(まえ)借(か)りた本(ほん)読(よ)み終(お)わったよ！めちゃくちゃ面白(おもしろ)かった！By the way, I finished reading the book I borrowed from you the other day! It was super interesting! そういえば、大家(おおや)さんに家賃(やちん)振(ふ)り込(こ)んでくれた？Speaking of which, did you transfer the rent to the landlord for me? そういえば、さっき駅(えき)でお母(かあ)さんの友達(ともだち)に会(あ)ったよ。よろしくだって。Speaking of which, I met your friend at the station. She told me to tell you she said hi. Caution - Due to そういえば refering to something that has already been brought up over the course of a conversation, it will not be used to move on to completely unrelated topics in the same way that phrases like 'by the way' are used in English. 中田(なかた)さん：今度(こんど)バッティングセンターに行(い)こ！高橋(たかはし)さん：そういえば、藤田(ふじた)さんと伊藤(いとう)くんが付(つ)き合(あ)い始(はじ)めたって聞(き)いた？Tanaka-san: Let's go to the batting cage next time!Takahashi-san: Speaking of which, did you hear that Fujita-san and Ito-kun has started dating? (Unnatural Japanese) Fun-fact - そういえば is very similar in the way it is used to といえば, with そう simply replacing the direct quotation of と. Many textbooks will list both as a single grammar point, despite そういえば itself basically being a set phrase.

example.japanese: そういえば、昨夜(さくや)は何時(なんじ)に家(いえ)に帰(かえ)ったの？
example.english: Speaking of which, what time did you get home last night?

example.japanese: そういえば、今日(きょう)は母(はは)の日(ひ)だ。
example.english: Come to think of it, it is Mother's Day today.

example.japanese: そういえば、昨日(きのう)の卒業式(そつぎょうしき)はどうだった？
example.english: Speaking of which, how was the graduation ceremony yesterday?

example.japanese: そういえば、着替(きが)え持(も)ってきてくれた？
example.english: Speaking of which, did you bring the change of clothes for me?

example.japanese: そういえば、今度(こんど)のイベントで機関車(きかんしゃ)に乗(の)れるみたいですよ。
example.english: Speaking of which, it looks like you can ride a locomotive at the upcoming event!

synonym.explanation: by the way, incidentally
speaking of, if it were the case that

english_grammar.title: お～願(ねが)う
english_grammar.explanation: please, could you please
english_grammar.structure: お + Verb［ます］+ 願う ご + (Chinese Origin) Noun + 願う (Western Origin) Noun + 願う
english_grammar.about: お～願(ねが)う is a humble speech expression in Japanese used for making requests in the same way as お～ください 'please do (A)'. As with many other polite structures, the use of お will primarily appear with words of Japanese origin, while ご will be used for the majority Chinese-origin kanji compounds.願(ねが)う itself is a う-Verb meaning 'to petition', and the literal translation is something like 'I petition that you do (A) for me', which sounds incredibly stiff in English, but gets the point across that someone is doing a favor for you. こちらからのメールが届(とど)いているか、お確(たし)かめ願(ねが)います。Could you please make sure that you have received our email. 鈴木(すずき)社長(しゃちょう)はもうすぐ到着(とうちゃく)するので、もう少々(しょうしょう)お待(ま)ち願(ねが)います。President Suzuki will be arriving shortly, so please wait a moment. この契約書(けいやくしょ)にご記入(きにゅう)された情報(じょうほう)に間違(まちが)いがないか、ご確認(かくにん)願(ねが)います。Please make sure that the information you have entered in this contract is correct. 歩道(ほどう)での禁煙(きんえん)にご協力(きょうりょく)願(ねが)います。We ask for your cooperation in not smoking on the sidewalks. Naturally, due to being a polite sentence pattern, お～願(ねが)う will almost always appear in it's ます-form, お～願(ねが)います.Interestingly, words of western origin, such as katakana loanwords, will often omit both お and ご, appearing simply with 願(ねが)う attached to the end. この契約書(けいやくしょ)の下(した)の方(ほう)と、この書類(しょるい)の下(した)の方(ほう)にサイン願(ねが)います。Please sign at the bottom of this contract and at the bottom of this document. Caution - As お～願(ねが)う is an even more polite way of saying お～ください, or simply even just てください, it will rarely be used outside of formal circumstances, such as voice-overs giving instructions etc. If used in daily speech, it may come across as sarcasm.

example.japanese: 面会(めんかい)をご希望(きぼう)の方(かた)は担当(たんとう)者(しゃ)が会議(かいぎ)中(ちゅう)ですので、待合室(まちあいしつ)でお待(ま)ち願(ねが)えますか？
example.english: Those who are here for a meeting, could you please wait in the waiting room? The person in charge is having a conference.

example.japanese: 書類(しょるい)のこの下(した)にサイン 願(ねが)います。
example.english: Please sign at the bottom of the document.

example.japanese: 問題(もんだい)が起(お)こった場合(ばあい)はご連絡(れんらく)願(ねが)います。
example.english: If you have any problems, please feel free to contact us.

example.japanese: 公共(こうきょう)の場(ば)での禁酒(きんしゅ)にご協力(きょうりょく)願(ねが)います。
example.english: We ask for your cooperation in not drinking in public places.

example.japanese: ここは図書館(としょかん)です。お静(しず)かに願(ねが)います。
example.english: This is a library. Please be quiet.

synonym.explanation: Please do (polite request)
Command to do
please do (honorific)

english_grammar.title: とか
english_grammar.explanation: I heard that… something like, he/she/it said ... or something
english_grammar.structure: Verb + とか ［い］Adjective + とか ［な］Adjective + とか Noun + とか
english_grammar.about: Being a combination of the particles と and か, とか 'quotes' the previous statement as being something that has been heard, but is unconfirmed or uncertain. In English, this translates as 'I heard something like (A)', or '(A) or something was said'.とか may appear after verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives, or nouns. 遠藤(えんどう)さんと近藤(こんどう)さんが結婚(けっこん)するとか。意外(いがい)じゃない？I heard that Endo-san and Kondo-san are getting married or something. Isn't that surprising? あの大手(おおて)家電(かでん)メーカーが開発(かいはつ)した最新(さいしん)のスマホはたくさんのブロートウェアがインストールされているせいで動作(どうさ)がものすごく重(おも)いとか。I heard that the latest smartphone developed by that major appliance manufacturer performs extremely slow because of all the bloatware that comes installed, or something like that. 高橋(たかはし)くんの彼女(かのじょ)が美人(びじん)だとか。あんなやつに美人(びじん)な彼女(かのじょ)ができたとは信(しん)じられないけどな。I heard that Takahashi's girlfriend is beautiful or something. I can't believe that a guy like that could have a beautiful girlfriend, though. あの人(ひと)は実(じつ)はお金持(かねも)ちだとか。I heard that person is actually rich or something. This meaning of 'or something' when using とか is fairly casual and will often be heard in everyday conversation.Caution - This combination of と and か may appear the same as the とか used to indicate lists, but the former is simply a combination of the case-marking particle と, and the adverbial particle か, while the latter is a single listing particle. Despite this, both structures are originally combinations of と and か, and may be thought to have some overlap in meaning.

example.japanese: めがねちゃん:「彼(かれ)が昨日(きのう)、何(なん)て言(い)ったか覚(おぼ)えてる？」 ヤンキー君:「明日(あした)、１１時(じ)ごろに学校(がっこう)の前(まえ)で会(あ)おうとか言(い)っていたようだけど、定(さだ)かではない。」
example.english: Megane-chan: "Do you remember what he said yesterday?" Yankee-kun: "He said, 'lets meet in front of school around 11' or something like that, but I am not really sure."

example.japanese: 社長(しゃちょう)は年末(ねんまつ)年始(ねんし)に温泉(おんせん)旅行(りょこう)に行(い)ってらっしゃるとか。
example.english: I heard that the company president is going on a hot springs trip over New Years or something like that.

example.japanese: AKB48という音楽(おんがく)グループは解散(かいさん)するとか。
example.english: I heard that the music group called AKB48 is going to break up or something like that.

synonym.explanation: I heard that, it is said that
I heard that, rumor has it that, it is said that, it means that
I heard that, He/She said that

english_grammar.title: う・よう + ではないか
english_grammar.explanation: let's do something, why don't we
english_grammar.structure: Verb［おう］ + ではないか Verb［おう］ + じゃないか
english_grammar.about: ようではないか is a construction that will primarily be used for making suggestions for mutual activities. This is a combination of either of the auxiliary verbs う or よう, ではない, and the sentence-ending particle, か. う and よう primarily express will or intent like 'shall' in English. Due to the negation following them, the literal translation will be similar to 'shall we not do (A)?'. For ease of translation, this structure can be remembered as simply 'let's do (A)', or 'why don't we do (A)'.As with all structures that use う or よう, ようではないか will be attached to the end of a verb indicating the action which is being suggested. 正々(せいせい)堂々(どうどう)と戦(たたか)おうではないか。Why don't we fight fair and square? この問題(もんだい)をどう解決(かいけつ)するかみんなで考(かんが)えようではないか。Why don't we all think about how we can solve this problem? Alternatively, the abbreviated for of じゃない may be used in place of ではない. こういう時(とき)こそお互(たが)い助(たす)け合(あ)おうじゃないか。Why don't we help each other, especially in times like this. せっかく日本(にほん)に来(き)たのだから、食(た)べれるだけの日本食(にほんしょく)を食(た)べようじゃないか。Since we have come all the way to Japan, why don't we eat as much Japanese food as we can. Despite this, ようではないか is primarily a formal grammar structure, so will most often use the unabbreviated version, or even more polite ようではありませんか construction.Fun-fact - Occasionally, this grammar structure may be seen preceded by もらう. In these cases, it is usually challenging the listener to do something. This can be interpreted as 'why don't I have you do (A) then'. もっと綺麗(きれい)に壁紙(かべがみ)の張(は)り替(か)えができるのなら、張(は)り替(か)えてもらおうではないか。If you think that you're able to reapply the wallpaper better, then why don't I just get you to do it? 乗(の)せていってくれるって言(い)っていいるんだから乗(の)せて行(い)ってもらおうではないか。They said that they will give us a ride, so why don't we have them give us a ride.

example.japanese: 共(とも)に素晴(すば)らしい世界(せかい)を創(つく)っていこうではないか。
example.english: Why don't we (go and) build a wonderful world together.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)を身(み)につけるために頑張(がんば)ろうではないか。
example.english: Why don't we try our best in order to learn Japanese.

example.japanese: 遊(あそ)んでばかりいないで勉強(べんきょう)でもしようではないか。
example.english: Instead of doing nothing but play, why don't we do something like study.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)の成功(せいこう)を信(しん)じようではないか。
example.english: Why don't we trust that he will be successful?

example.japanese: 勝手(かって)に判断(はんだん)せず、診断(しんだん)が出(で)るのを待(ま)とうではないか。
example.english: Why don't we wait for the diagnosis, without passing arbitrary judgement?

synonym.explanation: Let's, I shall (casual volitional)

english_grammar.title: かの様(よう)だ
english_grammar.explanation: as if, just like
english_grammar.structure: Verb + かのようだ(1) ［い］Adjective + かのようだ(1) ［な］Adjective + である + かのようだ(1) Noun + である + かのようだ(1) (1) かのように + Phrase、かのような + Noun
english_grammar.about: かのようだ is a set phrase in Japanese indicating that something 'appears to be (A)', but the speaker is not certain. It will be translated as 'as if (A)', or 'just like (A)'. This is a combination of the adverbial particle か, の and the auxiliary verb 様(よう)だ 'appearing to be'. The more literal meaning can be thought of as 'is it not like (A)?', due to the uncertainty expressed by か.かのようだ may follow verbs and い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives and nouns followed by である. このVRフライトゲームはものすごくリアルだ。まるで本物(ほんもの)の飛行機(ひこうき)を操縦(そうじゅう)しているかのようだ。This VR flight game is so realistic. It is just as if I am flying an actual airplane. なんだこの静(しず)けさは。この町(まち)には誰(だれ)もいないかのようだ。What is this quietness? What is this quietness? It is as if there is no one in this town. 彼(かれ)はまるで私(わたし)と話(はな)すのが面倒(めんどう)であるかのようだ。He talks to me as if it was a chore. 彼(かれ)と僕(ぼく)は兄弟(きょうだい)であるかのようだが、実(じつ)は彼(かれ)は僕(ぼく)のパートナーです。It is as if he and I are brothers, but actually he is my partner. When ようだ is altering the meaning of a verb or a noun later in the sentence, ように or ような may also be used. 長谷川(はせがわ)くんのお母(かあ)さんは私(わたし)を自分(じぶん)の子供(こども)であるかのように小(ちい)さい頃(ころ)から可愛(かわい)がってくれていた。Hasegawa-kun's mother has taken care of me just as if I was her own child. このスーパーに入(はい)ると、まるで母国(ぼこく)に帰(かえ)ってきたかのような感(かん)じがする。When I enter this supermarket, I feel as if I am back in my home country. This grammar construction will often be seen with expressions that emphasize the speaker's assumption about (A), such as まるで. If compared to English, this merely strengthens the sentence in a similar way to the difference between 'it's as if (A)', and 'it's just as if (A)'.

example.japanese: その日(ひ)、隣(となり)の家(いえ)の子供(こども)とすこし話(はな)した。10才(さい)の子供(こども)でも喋(しゃべ)り方(かた)はまるでもう大人(おとな)であるかのようだった。
example.english: On that day I spoke to the neighbor's child a bit. Despite being a ten year old, they spoke as if they were an adult.

example.japanese: その歌手(かしゅ)の振(ふ)る舞(ま)いは名高(なだか)い歌手(かしゅ)であるかのようだが、実(じつ)はキャリアを始(はじ)めたばかりだ。
example.english: That singer's behavior is as if she is famous, but in reality, she has just begun her career.

example.japanese: うちの犬(いぬ)は生(い)きていたとき私(わたし)をときどきじろじろ見(み)たもので、あたかも何(なに)か言(い)いたいかのようだった。
example.english: My dog used to stare at me from time to time when it was still around just like it was trying to tell me something.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はまるでお腹(なか)に風船(ふうせん)を入(い)れているかのようだ。
example.english: It is just as if he has a balloon in his belly.

example.japanese: 初(はじ)めてなのに、分量(ぶんりょう)が分(わ)かっているかのように料理(りょうり)を作(つく)っている。
example.english: Even though it's their first time, they are making food as if they understand how much of each item they need.

synonym.explanation: it is entirely as if, it is just as though
as・like, just like
it seems that, it appears that, it looks like
~ way, in a way that suggests, like ~
as if to say, as if to suggest that, in such a way that, things like

english_grammar.title: のではないでしょうか
english_grammar.explanation: I think ... isn't it?, It might be that..., don't you agree?
english_grammar.structure: Verb + の(1) + ではない(2)（だろう）か ［い］Adjective + の(1) + ではない(2)（だろう）か Noun + （なの(3)）+ ではない(2)（だろう）か ［な］Adjective + （なの(3)）+ ではない(2)（だろう）か (1) ん (2) じゃない (3) なん
english_grammar.about: のではないだろうか is a fairly long grammar pattern in Japanese that is used when one wants to express their opinion indirectly, in the form of a rhetorical question. Common translations include 'I think it's (A), isn't it?', and 'it might be that (A)'. However, being that this is just a combination of の, ではない 'isn't', だろう 'probably', and か, the literal meaning is simply 'is it probably not that it's (A)'. Just like in English, the elongation of the phrase and not saying anything with certainty makes it sound more modest.のではないだろうか may be seen following verbs and い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives and nouns when preceded with な. Additionally, でしょう may replace だろう. 先輩(せんぱい)は疲(つか)れているのじゃないだろうか。I think that our senpai is tired, don't you think? 息子(むすこ)がおもちゃをじーっとみている。あのおもちゃが欲(ほ)しいのじゃないだろうか。Our son is staring at a toy. I think he wants that toy, don't you agree? 長谷川(はせがわ)さんは田中(たなか)さんのことが好(す)きなのではないでしょうか。I think that Hasegawa-san likes Tanaka-san, don't you agree? あの人(ひと)の右腕(みぎうで)に入(はい)ってるタトゥー、防犯(ぼうはん)カメラに映(うつ)っていたのと全(まった)く同(おな)じです。あの人(ひと)は犯人(はんにん)なのではないでしょうか。The tattoo on that person's right arm is exactly the same as the one seen on the security camera. I think that he is the perpetrator, don't you agree? This phrase can also be used when seeking agreement from the listener, or when mildly trying to persuade them that your way of thinking may be correct.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はもしかして、あきれているのではないだろうか。
example.english: I think that he is probably amazed, right?

example.japanese: 仕事(しごと)に対(たい)する真剣(しんけん)な姿(すがた)に、憧(あこが)れるのではないだろうか。
example.english: I think a serious stance towards one's work is admired, isn't it?

example.japanese: こんなお願(ねが)いをしてしまって、厚(あつ)かましかったのではないだろうか。
example.english: I think it was pretty bold/shameless to make a request like this, wasn't it?

example.japanese: あの店(みせ)、水曜日(すいようび)は確(たし)か定休日(ていきゅうび)ではないだろうか。
example.english: If I am not mistaken, I think that store has its regular holiday on Wednesday, right?

example.japanese: 定価(ていか)は10,000円(えん)ではないでしょうか。随分(ずいぶん)安(やす)くなっていますね。
example.english: I think the regular price is 10,000 yen, isn't it? It has become considerably cheaper, don't you think?

synonym.explanation: Right?, Probably, Isn't it?
Right?, Probably, Isn't it?
isn't it?, is it not?

english_grammar.title: ～て当然(とうぜん)だ
english_grammar.explanation: natural, as a matter of course
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］+ 当然 + だ ［い］Adjective［て］+ 当然 + だ ［な］Adjective + で + 当然 + だ
english_grammar.about: て当然(とうぜん)だ is a commonly used expression which indicates that '(A) is natural', or '(A) is a matter of course'. This is a combination of the て-form of either verbs of い-Adjectives (or で when used with nouns), the noun 当然(とうぜん) 'naturally', and だ. あんな生意気(なまいき)なやつは嫌(きら)われて当然(とうぜん)だ。It is only natural that a cocky person like that is hated. このスープは俺(おれ)が作(つく)ったものだから、美味(おい)しくて当然(とうぜん)だ。I am the one that made this soup so, of course it is delicious. このビルは先月(せんげつ)建(た)てられたばかりだから、綺麗(きれい)で当然(とうぜん)だ。This building was only built last month, so of course it is beautiful. て当然(とうぜん)だ is a fairly strong phrase, and will often be used when pointing out things that the speaker considers to be obvious facts.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)はみんなに迷惑(めいわく)ばかりかけているから、嫌(きら)われて当然(とうぜん)だ。
example.english: Because she is always causing everyone trouble, of course she is hated.

example.japanese: そんなに食(た)べたら、太(ふと)って当然(とうぜん)だ。
example.english: If you eat like that, of course you will get fat.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)は優(やさ)しいから、好(す)かれて当然(とうぜん)だ。
example.english: Because she is nice, of course she is liked.

example.japanese: アイデアがいいから、人気(にんき)があって当然(とうぜん)だ。
example.english: Because the idea is good, it is natural that it would be popular.

example.japanese: アクセントが完璧(かんぺき)だから、ネイティブと間違(まちが)えられて当然(とうぜん)です。
example.english: Because your accent is perfect, it is natural that you would be mistaken for a native.

synonym.explanation: it is only natural that, it is no wonder
may well, have/has good reason for,no wonder, … is only natural

english_grammar.title: のも当然(とうぜん)だ
english_grammar.explanation: it is only natural that, it is no wonder
english_grammar.structure: Verb + のは(1) + 当然だ ［い］Adjective + のは(1) + 当然だ ［な］Adjective + な(1) + のは + 当然だ Noun + は(2) + 当然だ (1) のも (2) も
english_grammar.about: Like て当然(とうぜん)だ, the grammar point indicating that (A) is 'natural' or 'obvious', のは当然(とうぜん)だ works in a similar way, and highlights that it is 'no wonder that (A)', or 'it is only natural that (A)'.This construction will be seen following verbs and い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives and nouns that are followed by な. 会社(かいしゃ)のお金(かね)を勝手(かって)に使(つか)ったなら、クビになるのは当然(とうぜん)だ。If you did use company money without permission, it's only natural that you get fired. このタワーマンションは六本木(ろっぽんぎ)にあるので、家賃(やちん)が高(たか)いのは当然(とうぜん)です。This high-rise condo is located in Roppongi, it is only natural that the rent is expensive. おばあちゃんは毎朝(まいあさ)１０キロも散歩(さんぽ)しているから元気(げんき)なのも当然(とうぜん)だ。My grandma walks 10 kilometers every morning, so it is no wonder she is so healthy. この1年間(ねんかん)全然(ぜんぜん)勉強(べんきょう)をしてこなかったから落第(らくだい)も当然(とうぜん)だ。I have not studied at all for the past year, so it's no wonder I flunked out. As can be seen in several of the above examples, も may replace は, with only a slight change in nuance (も will place extra emphasis on the obviousness of the remark, according to the speaker).Compared to て当然(とうぜん)だ, のは当然(とうぜん)だ is slightly stronger, and separates the previous statement from what the speaker considers 'natural'. This is equivalent to the difference between 'being happy is natural' (slightly weaker), and 'it's natural that one would be happy' (slightly stronger) in English.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はあんな風(ふう)に振舞(ふるま)っていたらほかの人(ひと)からの受(う)けが悪(わる)いのも当然(とうぜん)だ。
example.english: If he is behaving like that, it is only natural that he is unpopular with other people.

example.japanese: その古(ふる)い、枯(か)れた木(き)はとうとう倒(たお)れたのも当然(とうぜん)だよ。そんな長(なが)い間(あいだ)立(た)っていたのはおどろくほどだよ。誰(だれ)も怪我(けが)をしなくて嬉(うれ)しい。
example.english: It is no wonder that old, withered tree has finally fallen. It is surprising that it had been standing for such a long time. I am glad that no one was hurt.

example.japanese: 久(ひさ)しぶりに彼(かれ)に会(あ)ったのだから、彼女(かのじょ)が嬉(うれ)しそうなのは当然(とうぜん)だ。
example.english: Since she got to see him after being apart for a while, it is only natural that she seems happy.

example.japanese: あれだけ頑張(がんば)って絵(え)を描(えが)いていたら、すぐに絵(え)の具(ぐ)がなくなるのも当然(とうぜん)です。
example.english: If you put that much effort into painting, it is only natural that you will soon run out of paint.

example.japanese: そんなマッチョな体型(たいけい)では、エプロンが似合(にあ)わないのも当然(とうぜん)だ。
example.english: It is only natural that an apron would not look good on such a muscular body.

synonym.explanation: may well, have/has good reason for,no wonder, … is only natural
natural, as a matter of course

english_grammar.title: たったの
english_grammar.explanation: only, just, no more than
english_grammar.structure: たった + （の）+ Number
english_grammar.about: たった is a common adverb in Japanese that originates from an emphasized alteration of 唯(ただ) 'only', 'merely'. たった keeps the same meaning of ただ in that it just expresses that something is 'only (A)', 'just (A)', or 'no more than (A)'.This nuance is usually used when the actual number of (A) is exceptionally low compared to the speaker's expectation of anticipation. たった will often appear at the beginning of sentences, and will either modify the whole sentence, or a specific number when followed by の and then that number. 先輩(せんぱい)、たった今(いま)東京(とうきょう)駅(えき)に着(つ)きました。Senpai, I arrived at Tokyo station just now. 僕(ぼく)、たった一人(ひとり)でここまで歩(ある)いてきたのかい？偉(えら)いね！Kid, you walked here all alone? I'm proud of you! クラスメイト全員(ぜんいん)を招待(しょうたい)したのに、たったの３人(にん)しか僕(ぼく)の誕生日(たんじょうび)パーティーにこなかった。I invited everyone in my class, but only 3 people showed up to my birthday party. このホテルからビーチまでの距離(きょり)はたったの１０メートルです！It's merely 10 meters in distance from this hotel to the beach! As たった is an adverb that is usually used for emphasis, it often accompanies other similar grammar patterns like だけ, しか, etc.Fun-fact - The common expression ただいま 'now', or 'I'm home' may occasionally be seen in the emphasized form たったいま. This is primarily when the meaning is 'now', or 'just now' (right at this present moment), rather than 'I'm home'. その電車(でんしゃ)はたった今(いま)出発(しゅっぱつ)したので次(つぎ)の電車(でんしゃ)が来(く)るまで少々(しょうしょう)お待(ま)ちください。That train has just departed, so please wait until the next train arrives.

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)１：「千円(せんえん)を貸(か)してくれる？」友達(ともだち)２：「たった５００円(えん)しかないよ。」
example.english: Friend1: "Can you lend me 1000 yen?"Friend2: "I only have 500 on me."

example.japanese: そうまさん：「ケーキ、出来(でき)ました。」えりなさん：「え、たった５分(ふん)で出来(でき)たの？！」
example.english: Souma: "The cake is done."Erina: "Wha?! You finished it just in 5 minutes?!"

example.japanese: 自分(じぶん)の子供(こども)について、母親(ははおや)：「ケビンはずっと、たったひとりで家(いえ)にいた！！」
example.english: Mother, about her son: "Kevin was at home all alone the whole time!"

example.japanese: ライフスタイルに関(かん)するウェブニュースのタイトル名(めい)：「お母(かあ)さんはたった６６５円(えん)で食(た)べ放題(ほうだい)！母(はは)の日(ひ)プレゼント」
example.english: News title from the website about a lifestyle: "Mothers, all-you-can-eat for just 665 yen! A Mother’s Day present"

example.japanese: 「彼(かれ)はたった1人(ひとり)の兄弟(きょうだい)です。」
example.english: "He is my only sibling."

synonym.explanation: only, slightly・a little, barely・merely

english_grammar.title: 恐(おそ)れがある
english_grammar.explanation: there is a risk/fear that, be in danger of, possibility of
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］(1) + 恐れがある ［い］Adjective + 恐れがある ［な］Adjective + な(2) + 恐れがある Noun + の(2) + 恐れがある (1) Verb［ない］ (2) である
english_grammar.about: 恐(おそ)れがある is a set phrase in Japanese that is used in a fairly literal sense to convey that 'there is a chance of (A)', or 'there is a fear of (A)'. This is a combination of the noun, 恐(おそ)れ 'fear', が, and the う-Verb ある 'to be'. 恐(おそ)れがある will be used when (A) is a negative outcome that may potentially occur in some particular situation, and is usually used to warn about being careful of something.恐(おそ)れ is primarily used directly after verbs, or nouns followed by の. 高温(こうおん)にすると爆発(ばくはつ)する恐(おそ)れがあるので、直射(ちょくしゃ)日光(にっこう)が当(あ)たるところに置(お)かないでください。Since there is a possibility of explosion when this reaches high temperatures, please don't place this in direct sunlight. 津波(つなみ)の恐(おそ)れがある場合(ばあい)には、速(すみ)やかに避難所(ひなんじょ)まで避難(ひなん)してください。When there is a risk of a tsunami, please evacuate to the evacuation area. In most cases, 恐(おそ)れ carries the meaning of something that innately carries some kind of concern in relation to it, so depending on the context, alternative suitable translations could be 'concern', 'anxiety', 'worry', etc.Fun-fact - In addition to がある following 恐(おそ)れ, other common combinations are 恐(おそ)れを抱(だ)く 'to carry the fear of (A)', or 'to bear the fear of (A)', and 恐(おそ)れが強(つよ)まる 'for the fear of (A) to strengthen', or 'for the fear of (A) to intensify'. 若者(わかもの)が将来(しょうらい)について恐(おそ)れを抱(だ)くことは普通(ふつう)のことです。It is normal for young people to have fears about the future. 夏場(なつば)の現場(げんば)では熱中症(ねっちゅうしょう)の恐(おそ)れが強(つよ)まるので、作業員(さぎょういん)の方(かた)はこまめに水分補給(すいぶんほきゅう)と休憩(きゅうけい)を取(と)るようにしてください。Workers are encouraged to hydrate and take frequent breaks, as the risk of heat stroke increases at construction sites during summer.

example.japanese: 天気(てんき)予報(よほう)：「明日(あす)は、本州(ほんしゅう)を中心(ちゅうしん)に大雨(おおあめ)の降(ふ)る所(ところ)がありそうです。関東(かんとう)から東北(とうほく)にかけては強風(きょうふう)の恐(おそ)れもあります。」
example.english: Weather forecast: "It seems that the areas where rain will fall tomorrow are centered in Honshuu.There is also the possibility of strong winds from the Kanto to Tohoku areas."

example.japanese: もし人口(じんこう)が注射(ちゅうしゃ)されなければ、伝染(でんせん)病(びょう)が拡(ひろ)がる恐(おそ)れがある。
example.english: There is fear of an epidemic spreading if the population is not vaccinated.

example.japanese: 医者(いしゃ)：「倒(たお)れたせいで肩(かた)に怪我(けが)をした恐(おそ)れがあるので、レントゲンを撮(と)ったほうがいいです。」
example.english: Doctor: "You should have an X-ray since there is a risk that you injured your shoulder due to falling."

example.japanese: この絵(え)の具(ぐ)は中身(なかみ)が漏(も)れる恐(おそ)れがあるから袋(ふくろ)に入(い)れてください。
example.english: There is a risk that the contents of these paints will leak, so please place them in a bag.

example.japanese: 遠足(えんそく)に行(い)ったのはいいが、急(きゅう)な天候(てんこう)の変化(へんか)で帰(かえ)れない恐(おそ)れがある。
example.english: It is alright if you go on the trip, but there is the possibility of a sudden change in weather that would not let you return (home).

synonym.explanation: might・could be, capable of, possible

english_grammar.title: 恐(おそ)らく
english_grammar.explanation: probably, perhaps, (most) likely, (I) fear that
english_grammar.structure: おそらく + Phrase
english_grammar.about: 恐(おそ)らく is an adverb which originally stems from the conjugation of the yodan verb, 恐(おそ)る 'to fear'. In most cases, 恐(おそ)らく is simply used as a formal way to say 'probably', or 'perhaps', and is usually partnered with other structures of conjecture such as だろう, かもしれない, etc.As 恐(おそ)らく behaves adverbially, it will most often appear at the beginning of sentences before a statement of conjecture is made. 妻(つま)は今夜(こんや)会社(かいしゃ)の人(ひと)たちと飲(の)み会(かい)に行(い)くと言(い)っていたので、おそらく11時(じ)ごろぐらいまでは帰(かえ)ってこないと思(おも)います。My wife said she was going to a drinking party tonight with some people from work, so she probably won't be home until around 11:00 or so. あいつの不自然(ふしぜん)な行動(こうどう)からして、おそらくあいつが犯人(はんにん)だろう！Judging by that guy's unnatural behavior, he's probably the culprit! おそらく明日(あした)は雨(あめ)かもしれないので、明日(あひた)予定(よてい)していたピクニックは中止(ちゅうし)しましょう。Perhaps it may rain tomorrow, so let's cancel the picnic we had planned for tomorrow. Although 恐(おそ)らく can, and often does, carry the meaning of 'I fear that (A)', it isn't necessarily always used in relation to negative things. In the case of this particular grammar pattern, the main nuance that 'I fear that (A)' conveys is modesty on behalf of the speaker in that they fear their assumption may be right, given the available information.Fun-fact - yodan, or 四段活用(よだんかつよう) verbs are a type of classical-Japanese verb that have primarily been replaced by godan (う-Verbs) in modern day Japanese.

example.japanese: おそらく彼(かれ)はここにいないだろう。
example.english: He most likely isn't here.

example.japanese: おそらく明日(あした)雨(あめ)が降(ふ)る。
example.english: Perhaps it will rain tomorrow.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)だったら、おそらくこんなことできっこないでしょう。
example.english: If it’s him, he most likely won’t be able to do it.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の兄(あに)はおそらく１１月(がつ)頃(ごろ)アメリカから帰(かえ)るかもしれない。
example.english: My older brother will probably return (home) from the US around November.

example.japanese: 代表(だいひょう)者(しゃ)によりますと大統領(だいとうりょう)はおそらく再選(さいせん)にねらうまい。
example.english: According to a representative, the president will most likely not aim for re-election.

synonym.explanation: Might, Maybe, Probably
perhaps, maybe, possibly

english_grammar.title: ものか
english_grammar.explanation: Definitely not, absolutely not, impossible, do you really think~?
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ もの(1) + か ［い］Adjective + もの(1) + か ［な］Adjective + な + もの(1) + か Noun + な + もの(1) + か (1) もん
english_grammar.about: ものか is a set expression in Japanese that is used to strongly suggest that the previous statement absolutely will not happen, or is definitely not true. It is a combination of the noun もの 'thing', and the adverbial particle use of か for conveying 'doubt' or 'uncertainty'. Common translations include 'definitely not (A)', 'absolutely not (A)', and 'do you really think that (A)'. Literally, the meaning is quite close to 'as if' in English, as ものか just poses a strong question to which the speaker already completely disagrees with.ものか may appear after any word that could attach to もの, such as a verbs and い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives and nouns followed by な. バカ言(い)うな。俺(おれ)がそんな派手(はで)な服(ふく)を着(き)るものか！Don't be stupid! Do you really think that I would wear something so flashy?! 仕事(しごと)？毎日(まいにち)怒(おこ)られてばかりだから楽(たの)しいもんか。Work? I get yelled at everyday, so I am definitely not having a good time. 私(わたし)は毎日(まいにち)残業(ざんぎょう)しているし、家(いえ)に帰(かえ)ったら家事(かじ)を全部(ぜんぶ)やっている。元気(げんき)なものか。I work overtime every day and when I get home I do all the chores. Do you really think I have any energy left? お前(まえ)みたいな奴(やつ)は友達(ともだち)なものか！A person like you is absolutely not my friend! Other forms which may be seen are もんか, もんですか, and ものですか, with women being more traditionally likely to use the もんですか and ものですか variants.Additionally, when following the た form of verbs, ものか will imply that the speaker cannot bear for (A) to eventuate, due to evaluating it as something highly negative. 一人(ひとり)でこの量(りょう)の仕事(しごと)を明日(あした)までにできたもんか。As if it's possible to do this amount of work by tomorrow myself. こんなまずい飯(めし)、食(た)べられたもんか。As if I could have eaten something so awful. Caution - There are several other situations in where ものか will be used, but in each of them it may be easiest to think of the primary translation as being 'as if (A)', as it merely implies the speakers shock or disbelief in relation to whatever conditions are presented in the previous statement. These 'conditions' may involve an amount, possibility, or result of (A).

example.japanese: 永井(ながい)：長谷川(はせがわ)さんって伊藤(いとう)と付(つ)き合(あ)っているらしい。長谷川(はせがわ)：違(ちが)うよ！伊藤(いとう)さんと付(つ)き合(あ)うものか！
example.english: Nagai: "Hasegawa-san, I heard that you are going out with Itou-san." Hasegawa: "No! I am absolutely not going out with him!"

example.japanese: 失恋(しつれん)なんて、経験(けいけん)のない君(きみ)にわかるもんか！
example.english: You, who has never experienced something like a broken heart, absolutely won't understand it!

example.japanese: 井上(いのうえ)：あなたの男友達(おとこともだち)が家(いえ)の前(まえ)で待(ま)っている。本田(ほんだ)：彼(かれ)が何(なに)をしようが、かまうものか！
example.english: Inoue: "Your male friend is waiting in front of your house." Honda: "I absolutely do not care what he is doing!"

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)が皮肉(ひにく)なんて言(い)うもんか。そういう奴(やつ)じゃない。
example.english: He absolutely will not use sarcasm. He is not that kind of a person.

example.japanese: 今(いま)から行(おこな)ったって日(ひ)の出(で)になんか間(ま)に合(あ)うものか。
example.english: If we start now we absolutely will not make it in time for sunrise.

synonym.explanation: this is not the time for…, far from, out of the question
far from, anything but
hardly possible, cannot be, highly unlikely, improbable
how…what..., god knows...

english_grammar.title: お負(ま)けに
english_grammar.explanation: in addition, on top of that, what is more, to make matters worse
english_grammar.structure: おまけに + Phrase
english_grammar.attention: 話し言葉
english_grammar.about: お負(ま)けに is a phrase which often functions as a conjunction between the (A) and (B) parts of a sentence in order to show that (B) is 'in addition to (A)'.This structure stems from the common use of the noun お負(ま)け which indicates a 'discount' or 'freebie' that is added in addition to the base of (A). Despite お負(ま)け itself primarily being used for positive things お負(ま)けに may convey 'in addition', 'on top of that', or 'what's more' regardless of whether the original topic is a good thing or not. However, (A) and (B) will always either be both good things, or both bad things, never a mixture of both.Being a combination of お負(ま)け and に, this phrase will appear either at the beginning of a new sentence, or at the beginning of a second clause of a 2-part sentence. 今日(きょう)は仕事(しごと)に遅刻(ちこく)して部長(ぶちょう)に怒(おこ)られたし、おまけに取引先(とりひきさき)の人(ひと)も怒(おこ)らせちゃったから、今日(きょう)は最悪(さいあく)の日(ひ)だったよ。Today was one of the worst days because I got yelled at by my boss for being late to work, and to make it worse, I upset one of our clients. 昨日(きのう)は彼氏(かれし)に美味(おい)しいご飯(はん)をご馳走(ちそう)してもらって、おまけにプレゼントまでもらった。Yesterday, my boyfriend treated me to a delicious dinner and on top of that he even gave me a gift. パソコンが全然(ぜんぜん)立(た)ち上(あ)がらない。おまけにスマホの充電(じゅうでん)がないから仕事(しごと)が全然(ぜんぜん)できない。My computer won't turn on. To make matters worse, my smartphone is out of battery, so I can't work at all. Fun-fact - An important distinction between phrases like それに and お負(ま)けに is that お負(ま)けに keeps its original meaning of (B) being some kind of 'bonus'. What this means is that whatever the speaker is trying to convey, (A) by itself is enough to meet some specific qualifications, and (B) is just adding 'insult to injury', or 'icing on the cake', depending on whether it is a good or a bad thing.

example.japanese: 家(いえ)を掃除(そうじ)した。おまけにランチを作(つく)っといた。
example.english: I have cleaned the house. On top of that, I have also made lunch.

example.japanese: 自転車(じてんしゃ)が盗(ぬす)まれただけではなく、おまけに雨(あめ)が降(お)りそうだ。
example.english: Not only has my bike been stolen, but to make matters worse, it looks like it is going to rain.

example.japanese: この中古(ちゅうこ)のコンピューターは、ハードディスクの速度(そくど)は速(はや)いし、おまけに安(やす)いし、すごくいいよ。
example.english: This second-hand computer has a hard disc that is fast, and what is more, it is cheap. It is really great.

example.japanese: 競馬(けいば)で負(ま)け、おまけに帰(かえ)りに財布(さいふ)を落(お)とし、最悪(さいあく)だ。
example.english: I lost at the horse races and, to make matters worse, I lost my wallet on the way home. Worst day ever.

example.japanese: 体重(たいじゅう)が激増(げきぞう)し、おまけに髪(かみ)まで薄(うす)くなった。ストレスですね。
example.english: On top of my hair thinning, my weight suddenly increased. This is definitely stress.

synonym.explanation: moreover, furthermore
besides, in addition, furthermore
and・besides, moreover・in addition
as well, besides, in addition to

english_grammar.title: に決(き)まっている
english_grammar.explanation: surely, bound to, certainly, be decided
english_grammar.structure: Verb + に決まっている ［い］Adjective + に決まっている ［な］Adjective + に決まっている Noun + に決まっている
english_grammar.about: に決(き)まっている is a strong expression which indicates that (A) is something that the speaker either strongly believes to be true (but cannot confirm), or that they believe that (A) is only natural. These meanings primarily end up being translated as 'surely (A)', 'bound to be (A)', or 'certainly (A)'. As this structure is a combination of に and the ている-form of the う-Verb 決(き)まる 'to decide', the closest literal translation is 'for (A) to be decisively the case'.に決(き)まっている may appear directly following verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives or nouns. あの選手(せんしゅ)は足(あし)が速(はや)いから勝(か)つに決(き)まっている。That athlete is fast at running, so they are bound to win. いくらクリフダイビングのプロでも、あの高(たか)さからダイブするのは怖(こわ)いに決(き)まってる。Diving off a cliff that high is surely scary, even for a professional cliff diver. この家(いえ)はあの有名(ゆうめい)な建設会社(けんせつがいしゃ)が建(た)てた家(いえ)だから、丈夫(じょうぶ)に決(き)まってる。This house was built by that famous construction company, so it is bound to be sturdy. あの人(ひと)はみんなに好(す)かれているからいい人(ひと)に決(き)まっている。That person is liked by everyone, so he is bound to be a good person. に決(き)まっている primarily focuses on the speaker's subjective opinion about (A). This means that it takes into consideration their own preformed opinions or thoughts about (A), regardless of what the actual facts may be.

example.japanese: Linuxオタク：2018は「デスクトップLinuxの年(とし)」になるに決(き)まっている！
example.english: Linux Nerd: 2018 is bound to be the year of Linux on the desktop.

example.japanese: 妻(つま)： 晩(ばん)御飯(ごはん)、気(き)に入(い)ってくれたの？夫(おっと)：あなたが作(つく)った料理(りょうり)だから、おいしいに決(き)まってるよ。
example.english: Wife: Did you enjoy the dinner? Husband: Any meal made by you is bound to be delicious.

example.japanese: 毎日(まいにち)お菓子(かし)を食(た)べることはダメに決(き)まってる！
example.english: Eating sweets every day is certainly no good!

example.japanese: 優秀(ゆうしゅう)な職人(しょくにん)はいつもいい仕事(しごと)を見(み)つけるに決(き)まっている。
example.english: Excellent craftsmen are bound to always find good jobs.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)のことだから、あいかわらずいい人(ひと)に決(き)まっている。
example.english: Since it is him, he is bound to be a good person.

synonym.explanation: To decide on, To choose, To make something into, To view something as
It will end up being, It is the result of, It has been decided that
There is no doubt that, I'm sure

english_grammar.title: 事(こと)になっている
english_grammar.explanation: to be expected to, to be scheduled to
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ ことになっている Verb［ない］+ ことになっている
english_grammar.about: ことになっている is an alternation of ことになる, a grammar point showing that something has been decided by someone other than the speaker. It is a combination of the nominalizing use of こと (for creating noun-phrases), and the ている-form of the う-Verb なる 'to become'. The primary difference between ことになる and ことになっている is that the latter focuses more on that something is 'expected to (A)', or 'scheduled to (A)'. In other words, it is 'becoming that (A)', but has not actually happened yet.This structure is often used after either the る or ない versions of verbs, in order to highlight the action which either is not not 'expected', or 'scheduled' to occur. Let's take a look at the 'scheduled to' meaning first. 授業(じゅぎょう)は12時(じ)から始(はじ)まることになっています。The class is scheduled to start at 12. 社長(しゃちょう)は来週(らいしゅう)の飲(の)み会(かい)に参加(さんか)しないことになっています。The president is scheduled to not come to the party next week. When indicating that something is 'expected to (A)', this is an example of ている's use for expressing habitual or ongoing actions/states that reoccur under some specific set conditions. タクシーは左(ひだり)から乗(の)ることになっている。It is expected for customers to get into the cab from the left side. 生徒(せいと)たちは授業中(じゅぎょうちゅう)に教室(きょうしつ)を出(で)れないことになっている。Students are expected to not leave the classroom during class.

example.japanese: 会議(かいぎ)は東京(とうきょう)にある官庁(かんちょう)で行(おこな)うことになっている。
example.english: The meeting is scheduled to take place in a government office in Tokyo.

example.japanese: 寺(てら)の中(なか)に入(はい)る時(とき)は、礼儀(れいぎ)として靴(くつ)を脱(ぬ)ぐことになっている。
example.english: When you enter a temple, in terms of etiquette, you are expected to take off your shoes.

example.japanese: 電車(でんしゃ)は規則(きそく)正(ただ)しい時間(じかん)に駅(えき)を通過(つうか)することになっている。
example.english: The train is scheduled to pass through the station at regular times.

example.japanese: この寮(りょう)では、起床(きしょう)時間(じかん)は6:00ということになっている。
example.english: In this dorm, it is expected that you are up by six o’clock.

example.japanese: うちの会社(かいしゃ)では、仕事(しごと)中(ちゅう)は敬語(けいご)で話(はな)すことになっています。
example.english: At my company, it is expected that you speak using keigo while working.

synonym.explanation: bound to (be), expected to (be), should be (able)
It will end up being, It is the result of, It has been decided that

english_grammar.title: 気(き)
english_grammar.explanation: feel like ~, spirit
english_grammar.structure: Verb + 気
english_grammar.about: When used after verbs, 気(き) often indicates either the will or desire to do that particular action. This use of 気(き) is often interpreted as 'to feel like doing (A)' in English. More literally, 気(き) may be translated as 'mind', as is similar to the way phrases like 'to have half a mind to (A)' in English, indicating that something is either positively or negatively drawing the speaker's attention toward doing (or avoiding) the action of (A). お風呂(ふろ)でゆっくりしていたら、勉強(べんきょう)をする気(き)がなくなった。I lost my motivation (spirit) to study, when I was relaxing in the bath. よーし、やる気(き)が出(で)てきたぞ！Alright! I am starting to get motivated! やばい、明日(あした)までに終(お)わる気(き)がしない。Shoot, I don't feel like I can finish this by tomorrow. As 気(き) itself is a noun expressing the 'mind' or 'intention' to do (A), it may be followed by a variety of different verbs indicating an array of slightly unique nuances. Common patterns are 気(き)がある 'to have the feeling of (A)', 気(き)がない 'to not have the feeling of (A)', 気(き)がする 'to feel like (A)', 気(き)がしない 'to not feel like (A)', 気(き)が出(で)る 'for the feeling of (A) to come about', and 気(き)が出(で)ない 'for the feeling of (A) to not come about'.

example.japanese: 誰(だれ)かに見(み)られている気(き)がする。
example.english: I feel like I am being watched by someone.

example.japanese: 何(なに)もやる気(き)が起(お)きない。
example.english: I can't muster any motivation (spirit). [feel like doing]

example.japanese: 応援(おうえん)されて、やる気(き)が出(で)た。
example.english: I was cheered on and found motivation (spirit). [feel like doing]

example.japanese: 僕(ぼく)の実力(じつりょく)では勝負(しょうぶ)にならない気(き)がする。
example.english: I feel like it wouldn't be a contest with my real strength.

example.japanese: 結局(けっきょく)賞金(しょうきん)はもらえないような気(き)がします。
example.english: I feel like I won't receive the prize money after all.

synonym.explanation: have a feeling that

english_grammar.title: 気(げ)
english_grammar.explanation: seemingly, giving appearance of, [expresses emotions or feelings]
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ げ + に(1) ［い］Adjective［い］+ げ + に(1) ［な］Adjective + げ + に(1) (1) な + Noun
english_grammar.about: げ, sometimes seen in the kanji form 気(げ) is a suffix in Japanese that expresses that something is 'giving off the feeling of (A)', or 'seems like (A)'. げ is frequently used in relation to emotions, feelings, and things that the speaker generally can't be 100% sure of due to them not being directly visible.げ is primarily seen used after the stem form of い-Adjectives, but may also appear following the stem forms of nouns of な-Adjectives. In all of these cases, the addition of げ creates a new な-Adjective meaning '(A) seeming'. Due to this, げ may then be followed by either な or に, depending on whether it is altering a verb or a noun later in the sentence. 自信(じしん)ありげに見(み)えたかもしれないけど、実(じつ)はめちゃくちゃ緊張(きんちょう)してて吐(は)きそうだった。I may have given off the appearance of being confident, but actually, I was super nervous and felt like I was going to throw up. 高校生(こうこうせい)たちがファストフード店(てん)で楽(たの)しげに話(はな)しているのを見(み)て、自分(じぶん)が高校生(こうこうせい)の頃(ころ)を思(おも)い出(だ)した。When I saw highschool students seemingly having a good time talking to each other at a fast food restaurant, it reminded me of the time when I was a highschooler. 高橋(たかはし)くんは不安(ふあん)げに手(て)を上(あ)げました。Seemingly nervous, Takahashi-kun raised his hand. げ is more subjective (based on the speaker's opinion) than そう, and is considered to be very low confidence. This may be considered a byproduct of the original 気(き), meaning of 'attention', referring to the way that the speaker 'senses (A)', regardless of what is actually true for (A) on the inside.

example.japanese: 誰(だれ)かに「私(わたし)の言(い)うとおりにすれば、いつの間(ま)にかお金持(かねも)ちになれるんだ」と言(い)われると、頭(あたま)の中(なか)に赤(あか)ランプが点灯(てんとう)して、これはなにか怪(あや)しげな儲(もう)け話(ばなし)だと思(おも)うようになる。このような人(ひと)には、いつも気(き)を付(つ)けなければならない。
example.english: When someone says: "Do as I say, and you will get rich in no time", a warning light in my head turns on and I begin to think that "this gives off the appearance of a suspicious get-rich-quick scheme". One must always be wary of people like this.

example.japanese: A：どうしてそんなに満足(まんぞく)げなの？B：日本語(にほんご)能力(のうりょく)試験(しけん)、合格(ごうかく)したんだよ！
example.english: A: Why are you giving off the appearance of being so satisfied?B: I passed the Japanese Language Proficiency Test!

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)は私(わたし)の言葉(ことば)を聞(き)いて悲(かな)しげな顔(かお)で出(で)かけた。どうしてそんな態度(たいど)を取(と)ったのか分(わ)からない。
example.english: She left with a seemingly sad look upon her face after hearing my words. I don't understand the change in her demeanor.

example.japanese: 楽(たの)しげに遊(あそ)ぶ子供(こども)を見(み)るたびに、私(わたし)は子供(こども)のころを思(おも)い出(だ)す。そして思(おも)わず笑顔(えがお)になる。
example.english: Every time I see children seemingly enjoying themselves, I recall my childhood. And, without thinking, I smile.

example.japanese: 子供(こども)たちが羨(うらや)ましげに見(み)ているから、お菓子(かし)を分(わ)けてあげた。
example.english: Looking at the children they were giving the appearance of being envious, so I divided up the candy and gave it to them.

synonym.explanation: Seem, Look like, Sound
have a feeling that
~ness, used to indicate conditions or nature
looking, feeling a little, touch of, tending to, slightly
-ish・-like, characteristic of, typical of, tendency to

english_grammar.title: 事(こと)だから
english_grammar.explanation: it is exactly because
english_grammar.structure: Verb + ことだから Noun + の + ことだから ［な］Adjective + な + ことだから
english_grammar.attention: ことだから ≠ ものだから*
english_grammar.about: ことだから is a set expression used for indicating that the speaker is fairly certain about (B), based specifically on their experience with (A). This is often translated as 'it is exactly because (A) that (B)', or 'precisely because it is (A), (B)'. ことだから is a combination of the noun こと 'thing', だ, and から. The literal meaning can be interpreted as 'from that it's (A), also (B)'. This just implies that due to (A) being a predetermined fact, (B) too can be assumed to be true.When making assumptions, ことだから will often be seen following verbs in their dictionary forms, or nouns followed by の. あの人(ひと)がすることだから、どうせ人(ひと)を騙(だま)して儲(もう)けているに違(ちが)いない。 Precisely because it is something that person does, there is no doubt that he is making money scamming people. いつも遅(おく)れてくる田中(たなか)くんのことだから、今日(きょう)も遅(おく)れてくるだろう。 It is exactly because Tanaka-kun always arrives late, that he will probably arrive late today. Alternatively, ことだから may appear following verbs in any of their standard forms when the situation of (A) is considered as a good opportunity to also do (B), according to the speaker. お父(とう)さんとお母(かあ)さんが珍(めずら)しくうちに来(き)ていることだから、久(ひさ)しぶりにみんなで映画(えいが)でも見(み)よう。 Dad, mom, considering that you guys are here, which is a rare occasion, why don't we watch a movie together for the first time in a while. 撮影(さつえい)が無事(ぶじ)終(お)わったことだから、打(う)ち上(あ)げでもしましょう！Considering that we have finished filming, it is a good opportunity for us to have a party! Lastly, ことだから may simply imply (strongly) that (A) is the reason for (B). In these cases, either verbs in their standard forms or nouns followed by の may precede ことだから. お客様(きゃくさま)のプライバシーに関(かか)わることなので、これ以上(いじょう)詳(くわ)しいことは言(い)えません。This is something that has to do with the privacy of our customer, we can't give you further details. 部長(ぶちょう)のことだから、またミスをしたらクビにさせられると思(おも)う。It is exactly because it is my boss, he will probably fire me if I mess up again. Despite having these three slightly different nuances, the speaker's intended meaning will usually be clear in the (B) part of the sentence. Due to this, ことだから may always be thought to simply mean that 'by the logic of (A), definitely (B)'.

example.japanese: あなたのことだから間違(まちが)いなくうまくいくと思(おも)うよ。
example.english: It is exactly because it's you that I definitely think it will go well.

example.japanese: そういうことだから、一人(ひとり)でそういうところには行(い)かない方(ほう)がいい。
example.english: It is exactly because that is the case that it is better not to go alone to such a place.

example.japanese: いつもウソをついている彼(かれ)のことだから、今回(こんかい)も信(しん)じがたい。
example.english: It is exactly because he is always lying that it is hard to believe him this time too.

example.japanese: それは学術(がくじゅつ)的(てき)なことだから、僕(ぼく)はうまく説明(せつめい)できない。
example.english: It is exactly because it is scholarly that I can't explain it well.

example.japanese: 学級(がっきゅう)委員(いいん)長(ちょう)のことだから、ちゃんと先生(せんせい)に伝(つた)えてくれるよ。
example.english: It is exactly because they are the class president, that they will properly tell the teacher for us.

because, the reason is, that is because
because, cause

english_grammar.title: ものだから
english_grammar.explanation: because, the reason is
english_grammar.structure: Verb + ものだから(1) + Phrase ［い］Adjective + ものだから(1) + Phrase ［な］Adjective + な + ものだから(1) + Phrase Noun + な + ものだから(1) + Phrase (1) もので、もんで、もんだから
english_grammar.attention: More informal → もんだから/もんで, *ことだから ≠ ものだから
english_grammar.about: ものだから is a strong phrase that is used when explaining something or giving an excuse for one's reasoning. This grammar structure can simply be thought of as an extension of から 'because', with the noun もの 'thing' having its usual role of emphasizing what is said before it. Common translations include 'because (A)', and 'the reason is (A)'.ものだから may appear directly after verbs and い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives and nouns that are followed with な. すみません、今(いま)仕事(しごと)をしているものだから、また後(あと)でかけ直(なお)します。Sorry, because I am working right now, I will call you back later. 週末(しゅうまつ)は人(ひと)が多(おお)いものだから、週末(しゅうまつ)に行(い)くのはあまりお勧(すす)めしません。I would not recommend going on the weekends, because it is usually crowded on weekends. 生(なま)の魚(さかな)は苦手(にがて)なものだから、寿司(すし)は食(た)べられない。I can't eat sushi because I don't like raw fish. 彼(かれ)は新人(しんじん)なものだから、まだこの会社(かいしゃ)のルールをよくわかっていない。Because he is new, he doesn't really understand the rules of this company. Occasionally, ものだから will be abbreviated to もので, or もんで, without any change in the overall meaning. The change of だ to its conjunctive form で indicates that there is something coming after, despite the fact that what comes after may sometimes be omitted if it is obvious. 今日(きょう)は夕方(ゆうがた)から娘(むすめ)の発表会(はっぴょうかい)があるもので、私(わたし)はそろそろ帰(かえ)りますね。Because my daughter has a recital this evening, I am going to go home soon. 最近(さいきん)は日本語(にほんご)を話(はな)す機会(きかい)が減(へ)ってきているもんで、日本語(にほんご)を忘(わす)れてきた感(かん)じがする。I feel as if I have forgotten some Japanese, because I have fewer opportunities to speak Japanese these days. まあ、安(やす)いもんで...Well, because it's cheap… Fun-fact - Although it is not a rule, ものだから will primarily be used when explaining one's actions, as a way of emphasizing that the situation of (A) specifically led to the speaker doing (B).

example.japanese: 道(みち)が渋滞(じゅうたい)していたものだから、時間(じかん)通(どお)りに来(こ)られませんでした。遅(おく)れて来(き)てすみません。
example.english: Because there was a lot of traffic, I could not come in time. Sorry for being late.

example.japanese: 英語(えいご)が苦手(にがて)なものだから、海外(かいがい)旅行(りょこう)に行(い)くのは楽(たの)しくない。
example.english: Because I am bad at English, taking trips abroad isn't fun.

example.japanese: 郊外(こうがい)に家(いえ)を買(か)ったものだから、通勤(つうきん)に２時間(じかん)もかかる。
example.english: Because I bought a house in the suburbs, the commute to work takes two hours.

example.japanese: 墨(すみ)で黒(くろ)く塗(ぬ)ってしまったものだから、何(なん)て書(か)いてあったか分(わ)からない。
example.english: Because it is painted black with ink, I don't know what was written.

example.japanese: 雨(あめ)で登板(とうばん)予定(よてい)がスライドしたものだから、立(た)ち上(あ)がりなかなか調子(ちょうし)が出(で)なかった。
example.english: Because rain changed the batting arrangement, the pitcher isn't doing very well.

english_grammar.title: ものですから
english_grammar.explanation: because, my excuse is, my explanation is
english_grammar.structure: Verb + ものですから(1) + Phrase ［い］Adjective + ものですから(1) + Phrase ［な］Adjective + な + ものですから(1) + Phrase Noun + な + ものですから(1) + Phrase (1) もので、もんで、もんですから
english_grammar.attention: Informal → もんだから/もんで, *ことだから ≠ ものだから
english_grammar.about: ものですから is a strong, slightly emphasized version of ものだから, a phrase that is used when explaining something or giving an excuse for one's reasoning. This grammar structure can simply be thought of as an extension of から 'because', with the noun もの 'thing' having its usual role of emphasizing what is said before it. Common translations include 'because (A)', and 'the reason is (A)'.ものですから may appear directly after verbs and い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives and nouns that are followed with な. 昔(むかし)大工(だいく)として働(はたら)いていたものですから、リフォームなら私(わたし)に任(まか)せてください！Because I used to work as a carpenter, if you are renovating, leave it to me! この道路(どうろ)は狭(せま)いものですから、スピードを落(お)として運転(うんてん)をしてください。Because this road is narrow, please drive slowly. 苦(にが)いものが苦手(にがて)なものですから、コーヒーやお茶(ちゃ)は飲(の)めません。Because I don't like bitter things, I can't drink things such as coffee and tea. この車(くるま)は中古(ちゅうこ)なものですから、不具合(ふぐあい)だらけです。Because this car is second hand, it is full of defects. Occasionally, ものですから will be abbreviated to もので, or もんで, without any change in the overall meaning. The change of だ to its conjunctive form で indicates that there is something coming after, despite the fact that what comes after may sometimes be omitted if it is obvious. 彼(かれ)は日本(にほん)に住(す)んでいたもので、日本語(にほんご)はまあまあ話(はな)せます。Because he lived in Japan, he speaks Japanese fairly well. 私(わたし)は運転(うんてん)をするのが嫌(きら)いだもんで、出(で)かけるときにはいつもタクシーと電車(でんしゃ)を使(つか)っている。Because I don't like driving, I always use taxis and trains when I go out. いや、危(あぶ)なかったもんで...Well, because it was dangerous… Despite the slight difference in emphasis, ものだから and ものですから can be thought of as a single interchangable grammar structure in most situations.Fun-fact - Although it is not a rule, ものですから will primarily be used when explaining one's actions, as a way of emphasizing that the situation of (A) specifically led to the speaker doing (B).

example.japanese: この広場(ひろば)では花火(はなび)が禁止(きんし)なものですから、他(ほか)の場所(ばしょ)を探(さが)さなければなりません。
example.english: Because fireworks are prohibited in this plaza, we have to find another place (to set them off).

example.japanese: 天体(てんたい)観測(かんそく)が趣味(しゅみ)なものですから、新(あたら)しい望遠鏡(ぼうえんきょう)が欲(ほ)しいのです。
example.english: Because my hobby is astronomical observation, I want a new telescope.

example.japanese: 銀行(ぎんこう)の窓口(まどぐち)がとても混(こ)んでいたものですから、遅(おそ)くなってしまいました。
example.english: Because the ticket window at the bank was crowded, I was (unfortunately) late.

example.japanese: 熊(くま)の足跡(あしあと)があったものですから、山(やま)に入(はい)るのはやめました。
example.english: Because there were bear tracks, I gave up on going into the mountains.

example.japanese: アクセントが違(ちが)ったものですから、地元(じもと)の方(かた)ではないのかと思(おも)いました。
example.english: Because his accent was different, I thought, he isn’t from my hometown.

english_grammar.title: ものがある
english_grammar.explanation: strong judgement, there is something, feel strongly that
english_grammar.structure: Verb + ものがある ［い］Adjective + ものがある ［な］Adjective + な +ものがある
english_grammar.about: ものがある is an interesting grammar structure in Japanese that is used to declare that something has a particular trait of (A), according to the speaker's subjective opinion. Often, ものがある is translated as 'I feel strongly that (A)', or 'there is something (A) about (B)'. The latter meaning is very close to the literal translation here, as もの 'thing', がある 'there is' implies that the speaker strongly senses the presence of (A) within (B), even if they themselves cannot figure out why they feel that way.ものがある is primarily seen following verbs in either their dictionary or negated forms, い-Adjectives, or な-Adjectives followed by な. この映画(えいが)は人(ひと)の心(こころ)を動(うご)かすものがある。This film has something that moves people's hearts. 彼(かれ)の話(はなし)には納得(なっとく)いかないものがある。There is something about his story that I don't agree with. 自分(じぶん)が好(す)きなことを仕事(しごと)にできるのは、嬉(うれ)しいものがある。There is something delightful about being able to do what you love for a living. 子供(こども)だけで川(かわ)で遊(あそ)ばせるのは、危険(きけん)なものがある。There is something dangerous about letting children play in the river alone. As ものがある emphasizes the existence of (A) within (B), it is very common for the emphasized には to also be used in place of に when highlighting the topic.Caution - Although 'I feel strongly that (A)' is a common interpretation of ものがある, it is important to remember that the actual thing that is generating that feeling within the speaker may either be very strong, or very weak. In other words, ものがある may be used even when something isn't obvious about (A), so long as the speaker themselves feel strongly about it.Fun-fact - 目(め)を見張(みは)るものがある is a set phrase that is a combination of 目(め)を見張(みは)る 'to be astonished', and ものがある. In most cases, this expression just means that (B) is extremely surprising or impressive. 彼(かれ)の運動(うんどう)神経(しんけい)の良(よ)さは目(め)を見張(みは)るものがある。His athleticism is remarkable.

example.japanese: 日本(にほん)の伝統(でんとう)芸能(げいのう)には、心(こころ)を動(うご)かすものがある。
example.english: In Japanese traditional art, there is something that really moves your heart.

example.japanese: 美味(おい)しいものを食(た)べるため、寒(さむ)い中(なか)行列(ぎょうれつ)に並(なら)ぶのはつらいものがある。
example.english: It is very hard to stand in line in the bitter cold, just to eat something delicious.

example.japanese: こちらのお店(みせ)のメニューには、人(ひと)を引(ひ)き付(つ)けるものがある。
example.english: I feel strongly that this restaurant's menu will bring in people.

example.japanese: 君(きみ)の俳句(はいく)にはなんとも言(い)えないものがある。
example.english: (I feel strongly that) there is something about your haiku that words cannot describe.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)の遺(のこ)した言葉(ことば)には考(かんが)えさせられるものがあった。
example.english: I felt strongly that his last words were inspiring.

english_grammar.title: 傾向(けいこう)がある
english_grammar.explanation: tendency, trend, inclination
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］(1) + 傾向 ［い］Adjective + 傾向 ［な］Adjective + な + 傾向 Noun + の + 傾向 (1) Verb［た］
english_grammar.about: 傾向(けいこう)がある is a slightly formal grammar pattern used when indicating that there is some sort of 'trend' or 'tendency' existing within (A). Being a combination of the noun 傾向(けいこう) 'inclination', and がある 'to have', the literal meaning is almost identical to the standard English interpretation.As 傾向(けいこう) itself is a noun, this structure may appear after verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives followed by な, and nouns followed by の. この国(くに)では首都(しゅと)に近(ちか)づけば近(ちか)づくほど物価(ぶっか)が上(あ)がっていく傾向(けいこう)がある。In this country, there is a tendency of prices rising as you get closer to the capital. 鬱(うつ)で悩(なや)まされている人(ひと)は気分(きぶん)の浮(う)き沈(しず)みが激(はげ)しい傾向(けいこう)がある。People suffering from depression are inclined to have severe mood swings. あの会社(かいしゃ)が発売(はつばい)する教科書(きょうかしょ)は使(つか)いやすくてユニークな傾向(けいこう)があると言(い)われている。It is said that textbooks released by that company have a tendency to be user-friendly and unique. 最近(さいきん)は世界中(せかいじゅう)で小家族化(しょうかぞくか)の傾向(けいこう)がある。Recently, there has been a trend toward smaller families around the world. Although がある is the most frequent structure seen with 傾向(けいこう), alternatives such as が見(み)られる 'the trend of (A) can be observed' are also widely used. 最近(さいきん)ではコンピューターやスマホが文字(もじ)を自動(じどう)変換(へんかん)してくれるので、漢字(かんじ)の書(か)き方(かた)を忘(わす)れてしまう傾向(けいこう)が見(み)られる。Recently, computers and smartphones automatically convert characters, so people tend to forget how to write kanji characters. It should also be noted that 傾向(けいこう)がある may be used both in instances where the trend is either positve or negative.Caution - 傾向(けいこう)がある tends to express behaviors or characteristics (static things that aren't actively changing), while 傾向(けいこう)にある focuses more on being in a state of something that is ongoing or proceeding in a certain direction, such as a declining trend. 日本(にほん)は少子化(しょうしか)の傾向(けいこう)にある。 Japan is experiencing a declining birthrate. (Ongoing trend) この研究(けんきゅう)によると、勤務(きんむ)時間(じかん)が短(みじか)いほうが仕事(しごと)の効率(こうりつ)がよくなる傾向(けいこう)にあるようだ。According to this study, shorter work hours tend to improve work efficiency. (Statistics)

example.japanese: ハイエンドスマホの需要(じゅよう)は最近(さいきん)ますます低下(ていか)の傾向(けいこう)にある。
example.english: The demand for high-end smartphones has been in a declining trend recently.

example.japanese: 大人(おとな)においてはどうしても他(ほか)の人(ひと)より自分(じぶん)の意見(いけん)は正(ただ)しいと思(おも)ってしまう傾向(けいこう)が見(み)られるのだ。
example.english: Adults have a tendency to think that no matter what, their opinion is correct.

example.japanese: 人間(にんげん)は無意識(むいしき)に外観(がいかん)で人(ひと)を判断(はんだん)してしまう傾向(けいこう)が強(つよ)い。
example.english: People have a strong inclination to unconsciously judge others by appearance.

example.japanese: 健康(けんこう)問題(もんだい)の数量(すうりょう)は老化(ろうか)とともに増加(ぞうか)する傾向(けいこう)がある。
example.english: The amount of health problems (that arise) has the tendency to increase with aging.

example.japanese: 年月(としつき)が経(た)つとともにこの傾向(けいこう)が見(み)られるようになった。
example.english: As the years passed, this trend became visible.

synonym.explanation: Have a tendency to, tend to, be slightly~

english_grammar.title: ～てしかたがない
english_grammar.explanation: extremely, very・really, it can't be helped
english_grammar.structure: Verb ［て］ + しょうがない ［い］Adjective［て］+ しょうがない ［な］Adjective + で + しょうがない
english_grammar.about: てしょうがない, is a common colloquial expression used when '(A) cannot be helped', or something is 'extremely (A)'. This structure is simply an abbreviated version of 仕様(しよう), a noun meaning 'way' or 'method', as しょう is easier to say than しよう. Literally, the meaning is close to 'it's (A), and nothing can be done about it'. Generally, this just implies that the extent of (A) is so high that it cannot be overlooked, or cannot be avoided.This structure may be seen following the て-form of verbs, い-Adjectives, of the で-from of な-Adjectives. 日本語(にほんご)が上手(じょうず)になりたくてしょうがない。I can't help but want to become good at Japanese. 部屋(へや)が暑(あつ)くてしょうがない。My room is extremely hot. スイーツが好(す)きでしょうがない。I love sweets so much that it can't be helped. Alternatively, 仕方(しかた)がない may be used, but there is an extremely small difference between these two structures, with the noun 仕方(しかた) also meaning 'way' or 'method'. Traditionally, 仕方(しかた)がない is perceived to be slightly more polite, so may be more likely to be found in literature. 私(わたし)は今(いま)妊娠(にんしん)をしているが、寿司(すし)を食(た)べたくて仕方(しかた)がない。Although I am pregnant right now, I really want to eat sushi. 眠(ねむ)くて仕方(しかた)がなかったので、少(すこ)しだけ昼寝(ひるね)をしました。Since I was extremely sleepy, I took a small nap. この古(ふる)いパソコンは不便(ふべん)で仕方(しかた)がないから捨(す)てることにします。Since this old computer is extremely useless, I will throw it away.

example.japanese: いつも同(おな)じものを忘(わす)れてしょうがない。
example.english: I can't help but always forget the same thing (again and again).

example.japanese: ゲームがしたくてしょうがない。
example.english: I want to play video games so bad it can't be helped.

example.japanese: 楽(たの)しくてしょうがない。
example.english: Extremely fun.

example.japanese: あの望遠鏡(ぼうえんきょう)が欲(ほ)しくてしょうがない。
example.english: I really want that telescope.

example.japanese: 包帯(ほうたい)をしているから、痒(かゆ)くてしょうがない。
example.english: Because it is bandaged, it is extremely itchy.

synonym.explanation: cannot help doing something, cannot resist doing something
