example.japanese: 田中(たなか)さんは普通(ふつう)のサラリーマンだが、危(あぶ)なくて後(あと)が無(な)い状況(じょうきょう)ともなると獅子(しし)のように他(た)の人(ひと)を守(まも)る。
example.english: Tanaka-san is just an ordinary office worker, but when the situation is dangerous and there is no way out, he will protect others like a lion.

example.japanese: 大人(おとな)にもなると、幼馴染(おさななじみ)との友情(ゆうじょう)は弱(よわ)くなりつつあるだろう。
example.english: Once you become an adult, the bond with childhood friends gets weaker and weaker.

example.japanese: チームリーダーに就任(しゅうにん)するともなると、自分(じぶん)の仕事(しごと)に限(かぎ)らずチームメンバーの仕事(しごと)に責任(せきにん)があるだろう。
example.english: Once you become a team leader, you will be responsible not only for your own but also for the work of team members.

example.japanese: 普段(ふだん)は貪欲(どんよく)ではない人(ひと)でも、莫大(ばくだい)な金額(きんがく)ともなると貪欲(どんよく)になるかもしれない。
example.english: Even people who are generally not greedy might become greedy when it comes to huge amounts of money.

synonym.explanation: as…then, in proportion to, (along) with

english_grammar.title: を良(い)い事(こと)に
english_grammar.explanation: to take advantage of
english_grammar.structure: Verb + の + をいいことに（して） Noun + （なの）+ をいいことに（して） ［い］Adjective + の + をいいことに（して） ［な］Adjective + なの + をいいことに（して）
english_grammar.attention: Similar to ～を言い訳に、～いい機会に
english_grammar.about: を良(い)いことに is an expression in Japanese that may be translated as 'to take advantage of (A)', and generally refers to someone that is using (A) as a good opportunity to do something that is either immoral, or irresponsible. This construction is a combination of を, the い-Adjective 良(い)い 'good', the noun こと 'thing', and the particle に. A more literal translation can be thought of as 'making good of (A), (B)', although the nuance is exactly the same as 'to take advantage of (A)' in English. を良(い)いことに will be seen following verbs, nouns, い-Adjectives and な-Adjectives, but will be preceded by either の or なの in all cases, based on standard conjugation rules for の. 顔(かお)が見(み)えないのを良(い)いことにひどいことを書(か)き込(こ)む人(ひと)は最低(さいてい)だと思(おも)う。 I think that people who write terrible things on the internet, taking advantage of anonymity, are the worst. 彼(かれ)が優(やさ)しいのを良(い)いことに、クラスメイトたちは彼(かれ)をいじめた。 Taking advantage of his niceness, his classmates bullied him. 彼女(かのじょ)は美人(びじん)であるのを良(い)いことに、色々(いろいろ)な男(おとか)からお金(かね)を騙(だま)し取(と)った。 Taking advantage of her great looks, she swindled many men out of their money. 休(やす)みなのを良(い)いことに、友達(ともだち)と一日中(いちにちじゅう)ゲームをした。 Taking advantage of my day off, I played video games all day with my friend. It is also quite common to see して attached to the end of を良(い)いことに without any significant change in either meaning or strength. 先生(せんせい)の耳(みみ)が遠(とお)いのをいいことにして、授業(じゅぎょう)中(ちゅう)に友達(ともだち)と話(はな)していた。 Taking advantage of my teacher being hard of hearing, I was talking with my friends during class.

example.japanese: 夏休(なつやす)みのうちに住人(じゅうにん)の留守(るす)をいいことに泥棒(どろぼう)が増(ふ)えるばかりだ。
example.english: During summer vacation, taking advantage of absent residents, thefts only increase.

example.japanese: 先生(せんせい)の目(め)が悪(わる)いのをいいことに試験(しけん)中(ちゅう)にカンニングしていた。
example.english: Taking advantage of the teacher's bad sight, I cheated during the exam.

example.japanese: コンマンはうちの子供(こども)が幼(おさな)いのをいいことに家(いえ)の鍵(かぎ)や携帯(けいたい)を詐欺(さぎ)で巻(ま)き上(あ)げた。
example.english: A con man took advantage of my child's young age and swindled (him) of (his) house keys and cellphone.

example.japanese: 田中(たなか)さんってば自分(じぶん)が大臣(だいじん)なのをいいことに姪(めい)を省(しょう)で縁故(えんこ)採用(さいよう)した。
example.english: That Tanaka-san... He took advantage of his position as a minister, and got his niece a job in ministry.

example.japanese: 記事(きじ)：「この期間(きかん)に多(おお)くの家族(かぞく)が親類(しんるい)を訪(おとず)れる。それをいいことに空(から)っぽの家(いえ)に泥棒(どろぼう)にはいる人(ひと)もいる。」
example.english: Article: "During this period, many families visit relatives. Some people take advantage of it and steal from empty households."

synonym.explanation: lead to, as a good opportunity to, as a result of, as a trigger

english_grammar.title: 如何(いかん)
english_grammar.explanation: depending on
english_grammar.structure: Noun + （の）+ 如何 + で（は） (1) Noun + （の）+ 如何 + だ(2)。 (1) によって（は） (2) である
english_grammar.about: いかん is a grammar structure that has evolved as an abbreviation of いかん, an adverb meaning 'in what way'. In almost all circumstances, it can be translated directly as 'depending on', and will be followed by either the auxiliary verb だ at the end of sentences, or the conjunctive form of だ, で, when used in the middle of a sentence. いかん will follow nouns, and may or may not be preceded by の. 嵐(あらし)の状況(じょうきょう)のいかんで、来週(らいしゅう)のイベントが中止(ちゅうし)されるかされないかが決(き)まる。 Whether or not next week's event will be canceled will depend on the status of the storm. 前回(ぜんかい)の試験(しけん)の結果(けっか)いかんでどの大学(だいがく)に入(はい)れるかが決(き)まる。 Which college I can get into will depend on the result of my last exam. 東大(とうだい)に入学(にゅうがく)できるかは、君(きみ)たちの努力(どりょく)のいかんだ。 Whether or not you guys can get into Tokyo University would depend on your efforts. 来月(らいげつ)昇進(しょうしん)できるかは自分(じぶん)の業績(ぎょうせき)いかんだ。 Whether I get a promotion next month depends on my performance. Occasionally, いかん will be followed by によって. This may seem like repetition for no particular reason, but in most cases it will just strengthen the original meaning of 'depending on', and can be literally translated as 'depending on what way (A) is oriented, (B)'. 実験(じっけん)の結果(けっか)いかんによっては、最初(さいしょ)からやり直(なお)さないといけなくなる可能性(かのうせい)もあります。 Depending on the results of the experiment, we may have to start over from the beginning. いかん itself is used in a very similar way to 次第(しだい) 'upon (A)', or 'depending on (A)', and more often than not implies that the degree of (A) will be the factor that determines the overall result. Due to this, it will often be followed by subclauses that use verbs of decision making such as 決(き)まる. Fun Factいかん, like いかに, is simply another word that has the same meaning as どう 'how', and even shares the same kanji structure of 如何(いかん), 如何(どう). It is also quite common to see the structure かどうであるによって 'depending on in what way' used as an explanation for the meaning of いかん in various dictionaries and other teaching resources. Due to this, it may be beneficial to simply consider いかん as a less common version of どう, or かどうである.

example.japanese: 入学(にゅうがく)試験(しけん)の成績(せいせき)いかんで、私(わたし)の将来(しょうらい)が決(き)まる。
example.english: Depending on the exam results, my future will be decided.

example.japanese: 衝突(しょうとつ)ならば傷(きず)の状態(じょうたい)いかんによっては入院(にゅういん)する場合(ばあい)もありうる。
example.english: In the case of an accident, depending on the severity of the wound, hospitalization is also possible.

example.japanese: 実験(じっけん)の結果(けっか)のいかんで研究(けんきゅう)資金(しきん)が決(き)まる。中止(ちゅうし)の場合(ばあい)もあります。
example.english: Depending on the experiment's results, funding will be decided. Cancellation is also a possibility.

example.japanese: ホテルのサイト：「今後(こんご)の状況(じょうきょう)如何(いかん)では予約(よやく)の取(と)り消(け)しが不可避(ふかひ)の場合(ばあい)もございます。その際(さい)はメールをもって告知(こくち)させていただきます。」
example.english: Hotel website: "Depending on future circumstances, we may have to cancel your reservation. In that case, we will notify you with an email."

example.japanese: 必要(ひつよう)な最小(さいしょう)参加者(さんかしゃ)数(すう)の到達(とうたつ)如何(いかん)によってコース開催(かいさい)かどうか決定(けってい)される。
example.english: Whether or not the course will be held all depends on the minimum number of required participants being reached.

synonym.explanation: depending on, so
so that, in order to, in such a way that
~ way, in a way that suggests, like ~
to depend on

english_grammar.title: ～るまでだ
english_grammar.explanation: just, merely・simply, only
english_grammar.structure: (Negative Situation) Verb［ば］(1) + Verb［る］+ まで(2) + だ (1) Phrase［たら］、Phrase［ても］ (2) までのこと
english_grammar.attention: Remember that までだ might simply mean "until" especially if there is no conditional/following period 「期限今月末までだ」
english_grammar.about: までだ, and までのことだ are structures that are usually translated as 'merely (B)', or 'simply (B)'. However, they are almost always used in somewhat hypothetical sentences, and translate much closer to 'one can only but (B)'. This nuance indicates a sense of resignation, or understanding on the part of the speaker that they personally have no options beyond (B). This grammar pattern will be used following verbs in their dictionary form, and will often come at the end of a sentence that uses なら in the first clause. In this way, it will mean 'if (A), then (B) is all that can be done'. (A) will almost always be a negative situation. 誰(だれ)にも教(おし)えてもらえないなら、ネットで調(しら)べてみるまでだ。 If know one is going to teach me, I will just search it online. もし失敗(しっぱい)したのなら、もう一回(いっかい)挑戦(ちょうせん)するまでだ。失敗(しっぱい)しても諦(あきら)めないことが大切(たいせつ)だ。 If you made a mistake, you just have to try again. It is important to not give up even if you fail. 誰(だれ)も迎(むか)えにきてくれないのなら、電車(でんしゃ)で帰(かえ)るまでのことだ。 If no one is going to come pick me up, I will simply go home by train. この会社(かいしゃ)に入社(にゅうしゃ)できなかったら、別(べつ)の会社(かいしゃ)を探(さが)すまでのことです。 If I can't join this company, I will simply look for a different one. Examining the standard meaning of the particle まで as signifying an extent, it can be seen that this meaning is kept in までだ, with the speaker expressing that (B) is the extent of what is possible given the negative circumstances brought about by (A).

example.japanese: もしJLPTに落(お)ちたら、もう一度(いちど)試(ため)してみるまで(のこと)だ。
example.english: If I fail the JLPT, I will simply try it once again.

example.japanese: 電車(でんしゃ)に乗(の)り遅(おく)れたら、次(つぎ)のを待(ま)つまで(のこと)だ。
example.english: If I miss the train, I will simply wait for the next one.

example.japanese: 祖国(そこく)で就職(しゅうしょく)できなかったら、外国(がいこく)への移住(いじゅう)になるまで(のこと)だ。
example.english: If I can't find work in the motherland, I will simply move abroad.

example.japanese: 夫婦(ふうふ)の話(はなし)：「やめなくちゃならないというなら、やめるまでだ。」
example.english: A conversation between a couple: "If you say I have to quit, then I will simply quit."

example.japanese: 「問題(もんだい)が起(お)きても、解決(かいけつ)するまでのことよ。」
example.english: "If a problem arises, I will just solve it."

synonym.explanation: just, merely・simply, only

english_grammar.title: にあって
english_grammar.explanation: at・in the (place/situation), under ~ conditions / circumstances・during・suited to
english_grammar.structure: Noun + にあって に + ある ￫ にあって
english_grammar.attention: Don't confuse this with the て-form of 遭う (to meet; to have an accident) which is often used with words like 事故 (事故にあって)
english_grammar.about: にあって is a fairly formal grammar construction used in Japanese in the same way as its component parts. The particle に indicates a location, while あって is the て-form of the う-Verb ある 'to be'. As such, にあって can be and is often translated simply as 'in the situation of (A)', or 'under the conditions of (A)'. にあって will be used after a noun marking the condition, before the second clause will then go on to explain something remarkable or noteworthy about that situation or circumstance. 彼女(かのじょ)は校長(こうちょう)先生(せんせい)という立場(たちば)にあって、いつも生徒(せいと)たちのために一生懸命(いっしょうけんめい)働(はた)いている。 In the position of a principal, she is always working hard for the students. インフルエンザが流行(はや)っているという状況(じょうきょう)にあって、外(そと)にいる人(ひと)はみんなマスクをしている。 In a situation where the flu is spreading, everyone outside is wearing masks. 緊急(きんきゅう)事態(じたい)宣言(せんげん)にあって、県(けん)を跨(また)ぐ移動(いどう)が制限(せいげん)された。 Under the state of emergency, movements across prefectures were restricted. Occasionally, にあって will be followed by も. This slightly alters the meaning and indicates that despite being in the noteworthy situation of (A), (B) is not being affected in the way that one would expect. 緊急時(きんきゅうじ)にあっても、常(つね)に冷静(れいせい)を保(たも)つようにしてください。 Even under emergencies, please stay calm at all times. こんな厳(きび)しい状況(じょうきょう)にあっても、諦(あきら)めずに営業(えいぎょう)を続(つづ)けていたから彼(かれ)は儲(もう)けることができた。 Even under difficult circumstances like this, they were able to make a profit because they kept running their business without giving up. Caution Be careful not to get にあって mixed up with the にあって used in sentences like 事故(じこ)にあって 'to meet with an accident'. This あって is a conjugation of 遭(あ)う, 'to meet or happen upon (often something negative)', while the あって is this grammar point is simply the て-form of ある.

example.japanese: 危険(きけん)な非常時(ひじょうじ)にあっては、安全(あんぜん)確保(かくほ)がまず大事(だいじ)だ。
example.english: Under emergency conditions, ensuring safety is the most important.

example.japanese: このような状況(じょうきょう)下(か)にあって、医療機関(いりょうきかん)へのアクセスは限定(げんてい)されているかもしれない。
example.english: Under conditions like this, access to the medical institutions might be limited.

example.japanese: 好況(こうきょう)にあっても破産(はさん)を申請(しんせい)している企業(きぎょう)がある。
example.english: Even during a boom, there are companies applying for bankruptcy.

example.japanese: CEOのスピーチ：「混乱期(こんらんき)にあっても心配(しんぱい)せずに将来(しょうらい)を見据(みす)えます。」
example.english: CEO’s speech: "Even in this chaotic time, without fear, we look into the future."

example.japanese: 歴史(れきし)の教科書(きょうかしょ)：「総理大臣(そうりだいじん)という立場(たちば)にあって、言論(げんろん)の自由(じゆう)のみならず動物(どうぶつ)の権利(けんり)も提唱(ていしょう)した。」
example.english: History textbook: "In the position of Prime Minister, she advocated not only for the freedom of speech but also for animal rights."

synonym.explanation: due to, because of, as a result of

english_grammar.title: を余儀(よぎ)なくされる
english_grammar.explanation: to be forced to do something
english_grammar.structure: Noun + を余儀なくされる
english_grammar.attention: Similar to 「～する他仕方がない」and「～するしかない」
english_grammar.about: を余儀(よぎ)なくされる is a formal grammar pattern in Japanese that is usually translated as 'to be forced to (A)'. Its component parts are the adverbial particle を, the noun 余儀(よぎ) 'another method', the conjunctive form of the い-Adjective ない, なく, and the passive form of する, される. In this way, it literally means 'to not be given another way than to (A)'. を余儀(よぎ)なくされる will be seen following nouns, where that noun will be the thing that is unavoidable. パーク内(ない)での迷惑(めいわく)行為(こうい)が悪化(あっか)し始(はじ)めたため、人気(にんき)撮影(さつえい)スポットの封鎖(ふうさ)を余儀(よぎ)なくされた。 Due to the worsening nuisance caused by guests in the park, they were forced to close off the popular photo spot. 飲食店(いんしょくてん)はコロナの影響(えいきょう)で、営業(えいぎょう)の自粛(じしゅく)を余儀(よぎ)なくされた。 Restaurants were forced to refrain from continuing business due to Covid. 最近(さいきん)大(おお)きな地震(じしん)があったため、この地域(ちいき)の人(ひと)たちは避難所(ひなんじょ)での生活(せいかつ)を余儀(よぎ)なくされた。 Due to a recent major earthquake, people in the area were forced to live in shelters. In most cases, the subject of sentences that use を余儀(よぎ)なくされる will be a person, or something that is representative of people, such as a company. However, there are exceptions to this. Caution Both を余儀(よぎ)なくされる 'to be forced to do' and を余儀(よぎ)なくさせる 'to force to do' are variations of this grammar structure. を余儀(よぎ)なくさせる will be taught in a different lesson. Fun FactDespite 余儀(よぎ) and ない being separate words, 余儀(よぎ)なく is often thought of simply as a single word that means 'unavoidably', or 'inevitably'.

example.japanese: 景気(けいき)悪化(あっか)のため、会社(かいしゃ)は閉鎖(へいさ)を余儀(よぎ)なくされた。
example.english: Due to the economic downturn, the company has been forced to close down.

example.japanese: 津波(つなみ)が接近(せっきん)したため、野外(やがい)コンサートは中止(ちゅうし)を余儀(よぎ)なくされた。
example.english: Because of the approaching tsunami, outdoor concerts were forced to be canceled.

example.japanese: 少子(しょうし)化(か)により学生(がくせい)が減(へ)れば、多(おお)くの学校(がっこう)は閉校(へいこう)を余儀(よぎ)なくされるだろう。
example.english: If the number of students decreases due to declining birth rates, many schools will be forced to close down.

example.japanese: 20〇〇(まるまる)年(ねん)５月(がつ)には降着装置(こうちゃくそうち)の故障(こしょう)により緊急着陸(きんきゅうちゃくりく)を余儀(よぎ)なくされた飛行機(ひこうき)が飛行(ひこう)活動(かつどう)に復帰(ふっき)した。
example.english: In May 20XX, the plane that was forced to make an emergency landing due to a failure of the landing gear returned to flying operations.

example.japanese: 根岸(ねぎし)総理大臣(そうりだいじん)は初(はじ)め拒否(きょひ)していた。しかし結局(けっきょく)、数日後(すうじつご)に、大衆(たいしゅう)の抗議(こうぎ)により辞任(じにん)を余儀(よぎ)なくされた。
example.english: Prime Minister Negishi resisted in the beginning. But in the end, he was forced to resign by mass protests anyway a few days later.

synonym.explanation: there's only, nothing but

english_grammar.title: とは
english_grammar.explanation: that..., (surprised) that..., (never expected) that..., (shocked) that...
english_grammar.structure: Verb + （など）+ とは Noun + （だ(1)）+ （など）+ とは ［い］Adjective + （など）+ とは ［な］Adjective + （だ(1)）+ （など）+ とは (1) だった
english_grammar.about: とは is an emphatic structure that is regularly seen at the end of sentences, and will imply that the statement before it is shocking, appalling, or unexpected. In English, it translates very similarly as 'to think that (A)' in that it expresses a strong emotional response without expressly saying what that exact response is. とは is a combination of the case-marking particle と in its quotation use, and the adverbial particle は. In this way, it is just marking the whole statement of (A) as what is being highlighted as the topic, without actually stating anything else about it. まさかこんな場所(ばしょ)でなつみちゃんに会(あ)うとは！元気(げんき)にしてた？ I would have never expected to see you at a place like this! How have you been? こんな安(やす)く家(いえ)が買(か)えるとは思(おも)わなかったよ。 I did not think that I would have been able to buy a house this cheap. 君(きみ)があんなに速(はや)く走(はし)れるとは...なんで今(いま)まで黙(だま)っていたんだい？ I had no idea that you could run that fast… Why did you keep this from us? とは may sometimes be seen following など or similar structures, and in these cases will just imply that 'something like (A)' is what is shocking. こんな簡単(かんたん)なことで失敗(しっぱい)するなどとは思(おも)っていなかったが、あいつに任(まか)せた俺(おれ)が悪(わる)い。 I was not expecting him to fail at something so simple, but it was my fault for leaving it to him. まさか彼(かれ)が私(わたし)の知(し)らないところでそんなひどいことを言(い)っていたなどとは... I had no idea that he was saying such horrible things behind my back… Caution Although it is common for とは to come at the end of a sentence with the actual feeling word omitted, the speaker may expressly state their reaction afterwards. 高橋(たかはし)さんがもう結婚(けっこん)していたとは驚(おどろ)いた。 I was surprised to hear that Mr. Takahashi was already married.

example.japanese: 病(びょう)弱(じゃく)で内気(うちき)だった田中(たなか)さんがボクシングチャンピオンになるとは夢(ゆめ)にも思(おも)わなかったよ！
example.english: I would never have even dreamed that sickly and reserved Tanaka-san would become a boxing champion.

example.japanese: まさか二(に)ヶ月(かげつ)で10キロも痩(や)せるとは！このダイエットは効果(こうか)的(てき)だ！
example.english: I (never expected) that I would lose 10kg in two months! This diet is super effective!

example.japanese: メアリーさんとたけしさんが去年(きょねん)もう一度(いちど)新婚旅行(しんこんりょこう)に行(い)ったとは驚(おどろ)いた。
example.english: I was surprised that Mary-san and Takeshi-san went on a honeymoon again last year.

example.japanese: こんなところでキアヌ・リーブスに出会(であ)ったとはねぇ！
example.english: I (never expected) that I would come across Keanu Reeves in a place like this!

example.japanese: 「ついこの間(あいだ)彼(かれ)と話(はな)したばかりなのに、今日(きょう)が彼(かれ)の葬式(そうしき)だとは信(しん)じられないよ。
example.english: "It’s unbelievable that I spoke with him just recently, and yet today is his funeral."

english_grammar.title: じゃあるまいし
english_grammar.explanation: You are not ~ so..., it isn't ~ so...
english_grammar.structure: Noun + じゃある(1) + まいし Verb + ん + じゃある(1) + まいし Verb + わけ + じゃある(1) + まいし (1) ではある、でもある
english_grammar.about: じゃ or ではあるまいし is an expression which can be translated in a similar way to 'it is not (A), so it is not (B)', or 'you are not (A), so you can't (B)', and is often used for criticism of something acting in a way that is not befitting of it. まい is an auxiliary verb which highlights negative-volitional statements. This means that it has a similar meaning to ないだろう. Due to this, the combination of では, the う-Verb ある 'to be', まい 'not as if', and し, the particle that highlights reasons, all combine to have a literal meaning of 'it is not as if it's (A), so therefore (B)'. じゃあるまいし will be used after nouns, or phrases that have been nominalized with something like の. 親(おや)に止(と)められているのではあるまいし、好(す)きに自分(じぶん)が行(い)きたいところに行(い)けばいいんじゃないの？ You are not being stopped by your parents, so why don't you just go wherever you want to? 減(へ)るわけではあるまいし、少(すこ)しぐらい貸(か)してくれてもいいじゃん。 It's not like it's going to decrease, so why don't you just let me borrow it? もう子供(こども)じゃあるまいし、行動(こうどう)する前(まえ)に少(すこ)しでも考(かんが)えたらどうなの？ You aren't a child anymore, so why don't you think a little before taking action. The statement that follows じゃあるまいし will state the speaker's opinion in relation to (A), and will almost always be negative.

example.japanese: 子供(こども)じゃあるまいしお菓子(かし)を見(み)つけた途端(とたん)に全部(ぜんぶ)食(た)べるな！
example.english: You are not a child, so don't instantly eat every sweet you stumble upon!

example.japanese: A: 野菜(やさい)好(す)きじゃない！B: 赤(あか)ちゃんでもあるまいしもう駄々(だだ)をこねるのはよして！
example.english: A: I don't like veggies!B: You are not a baby, so stop whining already!

example.japanese: A：いってきます！B:まって、砂漠(さばく)じゃあるまいし、外(そと)に出(で)たら厚着(あつぎ)をしろよ！
example.english: A: I am heading out!B: Wait, it's not a desert (outside), so if you go out then dress warmly!

example.japanese: アニメじゃあるまいし、かわいい女(おんな)の子(こ)は急(きゅう)に空(そら)から落(お)ちてこない。
example.english: This is not an anime, so a cute girl won't suddenly fall out of the sky!

example.japanese: 田中(たなか)さん！新入(しんにゅう)社員(しゃいん)でもあるまいし！そんな簡単(かんたん)なミスはすべきじゃないよ。
example.english: Tanaka-san! You are not a new employee, so you should not make such simple mistakes.

english_grammar.title: ～てからと言(い)うもの
english_grammar.explanation: after, since, ever since then
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］ + から + というもの Phrase (A)。 それから + というもの + Phrase (B)
english_grammar.about: てからというもの is an extension of the grammar point てから meaning 'after (A)', and partners と言(い)う 'that which is' with もの 'thing'. It is often translated as 'ever since (A)', and will always express a new state of (B) that has been ongoing since (A). Although the literal translation is 'with that which was from (A)', the fact that (B) is ongoing is simply implied. As with てから, this structure will be seen following verbs in their て-form. この会社(かいしゃ)に入社(にゅうしゃ)してからというもの、日付(ひづけ)が変(か)わる前(まえ)に家(いえ)に帰(かえ)ったことがない。 Ever since I joined this company, I have not been home before the clock ticks over midnight. 仕事(しごと)に行(い)く前(まえ)に散歩(さんぽ)に行(い)くようにしてからというもの、どんどん体重(たいじゅう)が減(へ)ってきたのでこれからも散歩(さんぽ)を続(つづ)けようと思(おも)っている。 Ever since I started to go on walks before work, I have been steadily losing weight, so I am thinking of continuing to go on walks. ファイナルデスティネーションという映画(えいが)を見(み)てからというもの、木材(もくざい)を運(はこ)んだトラックの後(うし)ろを走(はし)るのを避(さ)けるようになった。 Ever since watching the movie 'Final Destination', I have been avoiding driving behind trucks carrying lumber. Although not quite as common, からというもの may be seen following それ, when それ is at the beginning of a new sentence. In these cases, それ will linked to what was stated in the previous sentence. 彼(かれ)は社長(しゃちょう)にみんなの前(まえ)でものすごく怒(おこ)られた。それからというもの彼(かれ)は別人(べつじん)になったかのように性格(せいかく)が変(か)わった。 He was yelled at in front of everyone by the boss. Ever since that event, he became a different person. 先月(せんげつ)彼女(かのじょ)が痴漢(ちかん)にあった。それからというもの、満員(まんいん)電車(でんしゃ)を避(さ)けるようになった。 She was groped last month. Ever since then, she has been avoiding packed trains. Caution As this phrase implicitly highlights something that has remained ongoing ever since (A), it will not be used when (A) is something that only happened in the very recent past. However, because length of time is subjective, it usually depends on what is considered 'long' based on any specific outcome.

example.japanese: 赤(あか)ちゃんが生(う)まれてからというもの、もっと本気(ほんき)で働(はたら)くようになった。
example.english: Ever since the baby was born, I have come to take my job more seriously.

example.japanese: あやうく溺(おぼ)れかけてからというもの、泳(およ)ぎ方(かた)を習(なら)い始(はじ)めました。
example.english: Ever since I almost drowned, I started learning how to swim.

example.japanese: スペースXのファルコンヘビーの離陸(りりく)を観(み)てからというもの、宇宙(うちゅう)が頭(あたま)から離(はな)れない。
example.english: Ever since watching the launch of SpaceX's falcon heavy, I cannot stop thinking about space.

example.japanese: 映画(えいが)ナレーター：「30年(ねん)前(まえ)、ロボットが反旗(はんき)を翻(ひるがえ)した。それからというもの人生(じんせい)のために戦(たたか)わない日(ひ)はなかった。」
example.english: Movie narrator: "30 years ago robots revolted. Ever since then, a day has not passed where we have not fought for our lives."

example.japanese: 伝記(でんき)：「彼(かれ)はとても元気(げんき)な人(ひと)だったが、パラシュートの落下(らっか)事故(じこ)にあってからというもの、身体(しんたい)が目(め)に見(み)えて弱(よわ)っていった。」
example.english: Biography: "He used to be a very lively man, but ever since he had the parachute accident, his health has clearly declined."

english_grammar.title: 傍(かたわ)ら
english_grammar.explanation: while, besides, in addition to
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ かたわら Noun + の + かたわら
english_grammar.about: 傍(かたわ)ら, seen primarily in hiragana, is a noun in Japanese that means 'bystander', in regard to something that is alongside or in the same place as the main focus. As a grammatical structure, it will be translated as 'while (A)', 'in addition to (A)', or 'besides (A)'. かたわら may come after nouns followed by の, or after the dictionary form of verbs. 彼(かれ)は飲食店(いんしょくてん)を経営(けいえい)しているかたわら、鳶職人(とびしょくにん)としても働(はたら)いている。 Besides running a restaurant, he also works as a steeplejack. グレッググラフィンは大学(だいがく)の教授(きょうじゅ)をしているかたわら、歌手(かしゅ)として活動(かつどう)している。 In addition to being a college professor, Greg Graffin is also active as a singer. 私(わたし)の妹(いもうと)は本業(ほんぎょう)のかたわら、英会話(えいかいわ)教室(きょうしつ)で英語(えいご)を教(おし)えている。 My sister teaches English at an English conversation class in addition to her day job. 妻(つま)は子育(こそだ)てのかたわら、近所(きんじょ)の子供達(こどもたち)にそろばんを教(おし)えている。 My wife teaches abacus to kids in the neighborhood in addition to raising our children. Something that can be remembered from the 'bystander' meaning of this word is that かたわら will always come after the primary action or state of (A), while (B) is considered to just be there incidentally to (A), or as being done secondarily to it. This usually takes the form of something like a side job or a hobby. Caution Unlike ながら, かたわら does not necessarily indicate two actions that are happening at the exact same time, just actions that are happening independently of each other with one being the focus, and the other happening to a lesser extent within the same subject's life, day to day activities, etc.

example.japanese: ブルースは、昼(ひる)は財閥(ざいばつ)を経営(けいえい)するかたわら、夜(よる)はバーマンとして危険(きけん)地域(ちいき)を見回(みまわ)っている。
example.english: During the daytime, Bruce manages his family corporation, while at night he patrols dangerous areas as BARMAN.

example.japanese: いくつかの国(くに)では、女性(じょせい)は仕事(しごと)のかたわら、苦労(くろう)をいとわず子供(こども)を育(そだ)てている。立派(りっぱ)なことだと思(おも)う。
example.english: In some countries, women work in addition to raising their children, not minding the hardships. I think that is quite praiseworthy.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)は大学(だいがく)で教(おし)えるかたわら、家(いえ)でも個人(こじん)指導(しどう)をしている。
example.english: Besides teaching at university, she gives private lessons at home.

example.japanese: 本業(ほんぎょう)のかたわらバイトなどの副業(ふくぎょう)をしている多数(たすう)の人々(ひとびと)がいる。
example.english: Besides working their main jobs, there are many people that also work part-time jobs on the side.

example.japanese: 指導医(しどうい)として病院(びょういん)に務(つと)めるかたわら、コンサルタントと専門医(せんもんい)として企業(きぎょう)でも業務(ぎょうむ)を行(おこな)っています。
example.english: In addition to working as the preceptor at the hospital, she also engages in business as a consultant and a medical specialist.

synonym.explanation: while ~ing, during, as
on the other hand, at the same time, while

english_grammar.title: を皮切(かわき)りに
english_grammar.explanation: beginning of, starting with
english_grammar.structure: Noun + を皮切りに(して)(1) Verb［る］(2) + の + を皮切りに(して)(1) (1) を皮切りとして (2) Verb［た］
english_grammar.about: を皮切(かわき)りに is a grammar structure that will be utilized with nouns in order to show the starting point for something, from which it then expanded, or something kept happening after. In most cases, を皮切(かわき)りに will just be translated as 'starting with (A)', or 'beginning with (A)'. This structure is a combination of the adverbial particle を, the noun 皮切(かわき)り 'beginning' or 'outset', and the case-marking particle に. It will appear after nouns or phrases that have been nominalized, before going on to explain how something continued to expand afterwards. 藤田(ふじた)先輩(せんぱい)がやめたのを皮切(かわき)りに、他(ほか)の人(ひと)たちもどんどんやめていった。 Starting with Fujita senpai quitting, others quit in quick succession. あの俳優(はいゆう)はテレビ東京(とうきょう)に出演(しゅつえん)したのを皮切(かわき)りに、色々(いろいろ)な局(きょく)に出演(しゅつえん)することになった。 That actor started by appearing on TV Tokyo and then went on to appear on various stations. 佐々木(ささき)さんの発言(はつげん)を皮切(かわき)りに、賛成(さんせい)する人(ひと)が出(で)てきた。 Starting with Sasaki-san's comment, some people began to agree with him. クラスメイトの高橋(たかはし)さんを皮切(かわき)りに、クラスみんな風邪(かぜ)になってしまった。 Starting with Takahashi-san, my classmate, everyone in my class caught a cold. In place of に by itself, にして and として are also standard variations of the same grammar pattern. 彼女(かのじょ)が社長(しゃちょう)に文句(もんく)を言(い)ったのを皮切(かわき)りにして、みんな社長(しゃちょう)に文句(もんく)を言(い)い始(はじ)めた。 Starting with her making a complaint to the boss, everyone started to make complaints to the boss. あのグループは名古屋(なごや)を皮切(かわき)りとして、全国(ぜんこく)でライブを行(おこな)った。 Starting with Nagoya, that group performed throughout the country. Caution It is rare for を皮切(かわき)りに to be used in relation to natural phenomena, or negative results. What happens as a result of (A) will usually be something positive, and have a specific 'doer'. Fun FactAlthough 皮切(かわき)り is really only used to mean 'beginning', the kanji combination of 'to cut a hide' can be used as a helpful memory tool for the nuance of creating a starting point from which something expanded outwards over a large area, like skinning an animal.

example.japanese: 皆川(みながわ)さんが監督(かんとく)として選(えら)ばれたのを皮切(かわき)りにして、うちのチームは次々(つぎつぎ)とスポーツの成功(せいこう)を掴(つか)んだ。
example.english: Starting with Minagawa-san being chosen as our trainer, our team continued to be successful.

example.japanese: 店(みせ)の移転(いてん)を皮切(かわき)りとして、売上(うりあ)げはどんどんと上(あ)げていく。
example.english: Starting with shop relocation, sales are rapidly increasing.

example.japanese: 「レオナルド・ディカプリオはタイタニックの主人公(しゅじんこう)になったのを皮切(かわき)りにスターへの道(みち)を歩(あゆ)み始(はじ)め、大(だい)ヒット映画(えいが)に出演(しゅつえん)している。」
example.english: "Starting with his leading role in Titanic, Leonardo DiCaprio embarked on the road to stardom and has appeared in many hit movies."

example.japanese: 東京(とうきょう)を皮切(かわき)りに、明治(めいじ)時代(じだい)を舞台(ぶたい)にした演劇(えんげき)「〇〇」が全国(ぜんこく)３０劇場(げきじょう)で公演(こうえん)されます。
example.english: Starting with Tokyo, the play XX, which is set in the Meiji era, will be performed at 30 theaters nationwide.

example.japanese: それを皮切(かわき)りとして、コンビニは相次(あいつ)いで出店(しゅってん)し始(はじ)めた。
example.english: Starting with that, convenience stores started opening one after the other.

synonym.explanation: not only...but also..., starting with

english_grammar.title: に至(いた)っては
english_grammar.explanation: when it comes to, as for, in particular, what is worse/more
english_grammar.structure: Noun + に至っては
english_grammar.about: に至(いた)っては is an expression which presents the most extreme example for something from within a specific category. Due to this, it will usually be translated as 'when it comes to (A), (B)', 'in particular to (A) is (B)', or 'with (A) as the most extreme example, (B)'. This is a combination of the case-marking particle に, the て-form of the る-Verb 至(いた)る 'to climax', or 'to culminate in', and the adverbial particle は in its standard role of presenting a topic. In this way, the literal meaning of 'culminating within (A) is (B)' is quite close to the nuance of the English translations. に至(いた)っては will appear following nouns, or nominalized phrases. 私(わたし)の家族(かぞく)は全員(ぜんいん)機械音痴(きかいおんち)です。母(はは)に至(いた)ってはインターネットさえ使(つか)えないです。 My whole family is mechanically illiterate. What's more, my mother can't even use the internet. 最近(さいきん)ここにいる社員(しゃいん)みんなのやる気(き)がない。藤田(ふじた)さんに至(いた)ってはパソコンもつけていない。 Recently, employees here are unmotivated. As for Fujita-san, their computer isn't even turned on. 漢字(かんじ)テストは49点(てん)だった。リスニングに至(いた)っては20点(てん)だった。 My kanji test's score was 49. What's worse is that my listening score was 20. Caution As the verb 至(いた)る itself is used to present extreme examples or locations that are considered to be right 'on the precipice' of something, に至(いた)っては will primarily present things that are surprising or astonishing in some way. This is primarily only used when the example itself is quite negative or unfavorable. あそこのお宅(たく)の次男(じなん)は留年(りゅうねん)するらしいですよ。長男(ちょうなん)に至(いた)っては学年(がくねん)トップだったらしいですよ。 I heard that the second son of the family over there flunked. As for their eldest son, I heard that he was at the top of his grade.

example.japanese: 最近(さいきん)の子供(こども)は、かろうじてCDは知(し)っているが、フロッピーに至(いた)っては全(まった)く知(し)らない場合(ばあい)が珍(めずら)しくない。
example.english: Children these days barely know CDs, but when it comes to floppy disks, it is not unusual if they know nothing at all about them.

example.japanese: ネット調査(ちょうさ)によると、将来(しょうらい)結婚(けっこん)をしたいと思(おも)う人(ひと)の割合(わりあい)は約(やく)40%、子供(こども)がほしいと思(おも)う人(ひと)に至(いた)っては9％以下(いか)だった。
example.english: According to an internet survey, the percentage of people who want to get married in the future is about 40%, and as for those who want children, it was less than 9%.

example.japanese: 二年(にねん)前(まえ)の出生(しゅっしょう)率(りつ)は女性(じょせい)1人(ひとり)あたり1.8、去年(きょねん)に至(いた)っては女性(じょせい)1人(ひとり)あたり1.33と歴史(れきし)上(じょう)最低(さいてい)の結果(けっか)となった。
example.english: The birthrate two years ago was 1.8 per woman, as for last year it was 1.33 per woman, which was the lowest (result) in history.

example.japanese: 父親(ちちおや)はパソコンならともかくスマートフォンに至(いた)ってはまるでお手上(てあ)げらしい。
example.english: My father isn't too bad if it is a PC, but when it comes to smartphones he seems to have given up.

example.japanese: ２０〇〇(まるまる)年(ねん)は非常(ひじょう)に乾燥(かんそう)していた。４月(がつ)に至(いた)っては二回(にかい)しか降(ふ)らなかった。
example.english: The year 20XX was a very dry one. April in particular, as it rained only twice.

english_grammar.title: なり
english_grammar.explanation: as soon as, the moment, when
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ なり
english_grammar.about: なり is an old-fashioned particle in Japanese that has several different uses. One of those uses is to convey the meaning of 'as soon as (A), (B)', or 'the moment of (A), (B)'. This structure will follow the dictionary form of verbs and is classified as a conjunction particle. (B) is usually something that is surprising, and brought about by a strong sense of will or emotion. Additionally, なり is almost always used in relation to other people, rather than oneself. 息子(むすこ)が家(いえ)に上(あ)がるなりトイレへと駆(か)け込(こ)んだ。 My son ran to the toilet as soon as he entered the house. ママ友(とも)が私(わたし)の家(いえ)に入(はい)るなり、冷蔵庫(れいぞうこ)の中(なか)を物色(ぶっしょく)し始(はじ)めた。 As soon as my mom-friend came into my house, she started to go through my refrigerator. 彼(かれ)は机(つくえ)に座(すわ)るなりすぐスマホをいじり始(はじ)めたから注意(ちゅうい)した。 I warned him because he started playing on his phone as soon as he sat down. Fun FactDespite appearing to be a conjugation of the う-Verb なる 'to become' at first glance, なり is actually one of the readings of 形(なり), meaning 'shape', and refers to the overall situation of (A) in a similar way to ところ.

example.japanese: 踊(おど)りを止(や)めるなり、彼女(かのじょ)が急(きゅう)にキスしてくれたんだ。気持(きも)ちいい。
example.english: As soon as I stopped dancing, she suddenly kissed me. I feel great.

example.japanese: 父(ちち)が出張(しゅっちょう)から帰(かえ)るなり母(はは)は泣(な)きだした。
example.english: The moment father returned home from a business trip, mother started crying.

example.japanese: 故郷(ふるさと)に帰(かえ)るなり灰燼(かいじん)に帰(き)した家(いえ)を見(み)て、驚(おどろ)き、悲(かな)しんだ。
example.english: The moment I returned to my home town, I saw my house reduced to ashes. I was shocked and saddened.

example.japanese: 実家(じっか)のお母(かあ)さんからの電報(でんぽう)が来(く)るなり、山田(やまだ)さんは青(あお)ざめた。
example.english: As soon as he received a telegram from his mother, Yamada became pale.

example.japanese: うちの奥(おく)さんは毎日(まいにち)起(お)きるなりスマホで電子(でんし)メールを見(み)ている。
example.english: As soon as my wife wakes up, she checks mail on her smartphone.

synonym.explanation: at the same time as, the instant, the moment, as well as
the instant・moment, as soon as, just as
as soon as

synonym.text: かと思ったら・かと思うと
synonym.explanation: then again, just when I thought, no sooner than

english_grammar.title: とも無(な)く
english_grammar.explanation: absentmindedly, mindlessly, unconsciously, without paying attention
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］(A) + ともなく(1) + Verb［たら］(2)(A) (1) ともなしに (2) Verb + と
english_grammar.attention: ・It can be also used with うちに、ところに and similar expressions
english_grammar.about: ともなく and ともなしに are structures used to indicate that (A) was being done absentmindedly when (B) happened. It will be translated as 'unconsciously (A) when (B)', or 'without paying attention to (A), (B)'. This pattern is a combination of the case-marking particle と, the adverbial particle も, and the conjunctive form of the い-Adjective ない. It will be seen after the dictionary form of verbs, and can be thought of as literally meaning something similar to 'even while not intending to (B), while (A), (B)'. 昨日(きのう)テレビを見(み)るともなく見(み)ていたら、急(きゅう)にお母(かあ)さんが出(で)てきたから驚(おどろ)いた。 When I was absentmindedly watching TV yesterday, I was surprised when my mother suddenly appeared. 話(はなし)を聞(き)くともなく、先生(せんせい)と黒板(こくばん)の方向(ほうこう)をぼーっと見(み)ていた。 I listened absentmindedly while staring towards the direction of my teacher and the blackboard. ともなしに is similar, but pairs the noun なし 'without' with に, instead of using the conjugative form of ない. 飲(の)み会(かい)で上司(じょうし)の話(はなし)を聞(き)くともなしに聞(き)いていたら、「お前(まえ)はどう思(おも)う」と聞(き)かれたから適当(てきとう)に返事(へんじ)した。 When I was at a drinking party and was absentmindedly listening to my boss, he asked what I thought, so I gave him a random response. 暇(ひま)だったから近所(きんじょ)を歩(ある)くともなしに歩(ある)いていたら、高校(こうこう)の同級生(どうきゅうせい)にばったりあった。 When I was mindlessly walking in my neighborhood because I had nothing to do, I met my classmate from high school. ともなく and ともなしに will often be seen in sentences that use たら. This puts emphasis on the specific time that something happened while performing another action absentmindedly. Despite translating this way, the action that precedes ともなく itself will be intentional, but the thing that comes about as a result of performing that action will not be what the doer was aiming to achieve.

example.japanese: 山田(やまだ)さんと晩(ばん)御飯(ごはん)を食(た)べるともなく食(た)べていたら、急(きゅう)に彼(かれ)が告白(こくはく)してきて驚(おどろ)いた。
example.english: When I was absentmindedly eating dinner with Yamada-san, he suddenly confessed (his feelings for me) and it really surprised me.

example.japanese: 勝者(しょうしゃ)の発表(はっぴょう)を聞(き)くともなく聞(き)いていたら、なんと私(わたし)の名前(なまえ)が挙(あ)がっていた。
example.english: I listened absentmindedly to the announcements of the winners, when, to my disbelief, my name came up.

example.japanese: 隣人(りんじん)の窓(まど)を見(み)るともなく見(み)ると、驚(おどろ)いたことに裸(はだか)の人(ひと)がいた。
example.english: I looked at my neighbor's window without paying attention, and, to my surprise, there was a naked person.

example.japanese: 昨日(きのう)、考(かんが)えるともなく考(かんが)えているところに、スズメバチにひどく刺(さ)されて「痛(いた)っ！」思(おも)わず叫(さけ)んでしまった。
example.english: Yesterday, when I was thinking about nothing in particular, I was badly stung by a wasp, and without thinking shouted: "Ouch!"

example.japanese: ノベル：「彼(かれ)は夜遅(よるおそ)くテレビを見(み)るともなく見(み)ているうちにいつのまにか寝入(ねいれ)ってしまったようだ。」
example.english: Novel: "It seems that he fell asleep while he was mindlessly watching TV late at night."

english_grammar.title: 塗(まみ)れ
english_grammar.explanation: stained, covered in, smeared, dirty with, soaked in
english_grammar.structure: Noun + まみれ Noun + まみれ + の + Noun Noun + まみれ + になって + Phrase
english_grammar.attention: Usually not used for non-physical objects such as mistakes, etc. However, there are exceptions like 借金まみれ.
english_grammar.about: まみれ, seen primarily in hiragana only, is a grammar pattern that indicates being 'completely covered in (A)', 'smeared all over with (A)', or 'stained with (A)'. It will follow nouns, and may appear as まみれの when linked directly to a second noun that まみれ is modifying. お母(かあ)さん：「服(ふく)泥(どろ)まみれじゃん！どうしたの？！」 Mother: 'You are covered in mud! What happened?!' 家(いえ)に帰(かえ)ったら犬(いぬ)が血(ち)まみれになっていたと思(おも)ったら、どうやらいちごジャムを食(た)べて寝(ね)たみたい。 When I got home, I thought my dog was covered in blood, but it seems like he ate some jam and fell asleep. あんな借金(しゃっきん)塗(まみ)れの男(おとこ)とは付(つ)き合(あ)わない方(ほう)がいいよ！ I don't think you should date a guy like that, who is drowning in debt! ストップ！そんな泥(どろ)まみれの服(ふく)を洗濯機(せんたくき)に入(い)れないで！ Stop! Don't put clothes covered in mud in the washing machine! In the vast majority of cases, まみれ will be used in regard to something that is negative, or can be perceived negatively even if it is not physical, like debt or desires. Examples of physically negative things include but are not limited to blood, mud, oil, etc. Fun Factまみれ is the noun form of the る-Verb 塗(まみ)れる, coming from the same kanji and with a similar meaning as 塗(ぬ)る, 'to paint'. Just like 'to paint', まみれる and まみれ primarily describe something covering the outer surface of another object, rather than its contents.

example.japanese: 先生(せんせい)の田中(たなか)さんは氷(こおり)で滑(すべ)って雪(ゆき)の塊(かたまり)で転(ころ)び、雪(ゆき)まみれになってしまった。
example.english: Mr. Tanaka slipped on ice and fell on a lump of snow. He was completely covered in snow.

example.japanese: 仕事(しごと)で油(あぶら)まみれになったら、家(いえ)に帰(かえ)ってからシャワーを浴(あ)びると気持(きも)ちがいいよね。
example.english: After getting soaked in oil at work, there's nothing better than having a shower after coming back home, right?

example.japanese: 床(ゆか)は泥(どろ)まみれになった。
example.english: The floor became covered in mud.

example.japanese: 頭(あたま)から汗(あせ)まみれになって、走(はし)っている選手(せんしゅ)はすごいと思(おも)います。
example.english: I think that players running with their heads covered in sweat are amazing.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)：「キモイ！机(つくえ)がよだれまみれだわ！」彼氏(かれし)：「勉強中(べんきょうちゅう)に寝(ね)ちゃったもので...」
example.english: Girlfriend: "Gross! You got drool all over the desk!"Boyfriend: "I fell asleep while studying, so…"

english_grammar.title: う・よう + が～まいが
english_grammar.explanation: even if, no matter what, whether or not, [emphatic], volitional + が・と
english_grammar.structure: Even if / No matter what Verb ［おう］ + が(1) Verb［まい］ + が(1) Noun + だろう.(2) + が(1) ［な］Adjective + だろう(2) + が(1) ［い］Adjective［い］+ かろう Whether or not Verb ［おう］ + が(1) + Verb［まい］ + が(1) Noun (A) + だろう(2) + が(1) + Noun (B) だろう(2) + が(1) ［な］Adjective１ + だろう(2) + が(1) + ［な］Adjective２ + だろう(2) + が(1) ［い］Adjective［い］+ かろう + ［い］Adjective［い］+ かろう (1) と (2) であろう
english_grammar.about: When both the positive and negative volitional auxiliary verbs are combined with a verb in Japanese, it has the nuance of 'whether or not (A)', the result will be (B)'. This is quite emphatic, and has a literal meaning similar to 'say it does (A) or say it doesn't (A), it will still be (B)'. As a reminder, the positive auxiliary verbs of volition are either う or よう, depending on what they are being connected to, while the negative auxiliary verb of volition is まい. Either the case marking particle が or と will appear after both the positive and the negative, with が being slightly more common. 忘年会(ぼうねんかい)に出席(しゅっせき)しようが出席(しゅっせき)するまいが、会費(かいひ)はみんなからもらっています。 Whether you attend the year-end party or not, we will collect the admissions fee from everyone. 雨(あめ)が降(ふ)ろうが振(ふ)るまいが、明日(あした)は絶対(ぜったい)に釣(つ)りに行(い)くと決(き)めた。 Whether it rains or not, I have decided to go fishing tomorrow. While this structure is primarily seen after verbs, it is important to remember that other auxiliary verbs such as だ can be conjugated in the same way, as can い-Adjectives with the less common かろう structure. This means that both nouns, な-Adjectives and い-Adjectives can also appear using a similar grammar pattern. However, because the negative volitional まい cannot pair with these structures, an antonym will usually appear with them instead, with both words using the う or よう positive volitional. 楽(たの)しかろうが楽(たの)しくなかろうが、学校(がっこう)は子供(こども)の仕事(しごと)だから学校(がっこう)には行(い)かなくてはだめだ。 Whether it is fun or not, school is a child's job, so you must go to school. 安全(あんぜん)だろうが安全(あんぜん)でなかろうが、２メートル以上(いじょう)の場所(ばしょ)に上(あ)がる場合(ばあい)は安全帯(あんぜんたい)を必(かなら)ず装着(そうちゃく)してください。 Whether it is safe or not, always wear a safety belt when you climb to a place higher than 2 meters. 犬(いぬ)であろうが猫(ねこ)であろうが、どちらにしても動物(どうぶつ)なので軽(かる)い気持(きも)ちで買(か)っては行(い)けない。 Whether it is a dog or a cat, they are both animals, so they must not be bought on a whim. Based primarily on the use of volitionals, this grammar pattern will often indicate the speaker's strong will or opinion that will not change regardless of (A).

example.japanese: 人(ひと)が何(なん)と言(い)おうが、ずっとあなたを愛(あい)しています！
example.english: No matter what people say, I will always love you!

example.japanese: 生徒(せいと)が授業(じゅぎょう)に出席(しゅっせき)しようが出席(しゅっせき)するまいが、私(わたし)はきちんと授業(じゅぎょう)を進(すす)めていく。
example.english: Whether or not students attend, I will proceed with my lecture as planned.

example.japanese: 何(なん)年(ねん)がかかろうと、ドラゴンボールを見(み)つけるようにする！
example.english: Even if it takes many years, I will do my best to find the dragon balls!

example.japanese: 商品(しょうひん)は上質(じょうしつ)であろうが悪質(あくしつ)であろうが、よく売(う)れるものはよく売(う)れる。
example.english: Whether the product is of good quality or low quality, if it sells well, it sells well.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)の勉強(べんきょう)は難(むずか)しかろうが易(やさ)しかろうが、流暢(りゅうちょう)に話(はな)せるようになるまで勉強(べんきょう)する。
example.english: Whether learning Japanese is difficult or easy, I will learn until I become fluent.

synonym.explanation: Whether ~ or not
even if I have to, by all/any means, no matter what
even if, no matter
even if, even though
even if, even though, no matter how

english_grammar.title: からする
english_grammar.explanation: about, or more, over, starts at
english_grammar.structure: Number + Counter + からする Number + Counter + からする + Noun Number + Counter + からの + Noun
english_grammar.about: からする is a slightly formal grammar pattern in Japanese that appears after some kind of number or counter in order to indicate a minimum from which an estimation is being made. It will generally be translated as 'about (A)', '(A) or more', or 'starting at (A)'. This structure is a combination of the case-marking particle から, and the special verb する. It has quite a literal meaning in that a number is 'going from (A)', where (A) is the start point and the speaker doesn't know the exact amount. その靴(くつ)買(か)ったの？それって15万(まん)からするやつでしょ？やばいね。 You bought those shoes? Those are the ones that cost 150,000 yen or more, aren't they? That's nuts. この辺(へん)だと家賃(やちん)は15万(まん)からする。 Around here, rent costs 150,000 yen or more. 父(ちち)から300万円(まんえん)からする時計(とけい)をもらった。 I received a watch that costs 3,000,000 yen or more from my father. In addition to からする, からの may be used with the same meaning. However, unlike する, because の must attach directly to a second noun, からの is a bit more limited in the way it will be used. この商品(しょうひん)を製造(せいぞう)するには、１億(おく)からのお金(かね)がかかる。 In order to manufacture this product, it will cost 100 million yen or more. 昨日(きのう)の大地震(だいじしん)で10人(にん)からの人(ひと)が行方不明(ゆくえふめい)になった。 10 or more people have gone missing due to the big earthquake that happened yesterday. Caution Due to からする being used for giving an estimation, it has a tendency to only appear when the number or amount of something is quite large, and the speaker is emphasizing that the actual number cannot be guessed. Because of this, it may sound quite unnatural when used with small numbers. 105円(えん)からするライトを買(か)ったらすぐ壊(こわ)れた。 When I bought a light that went from 105 yen, it broke immediately. (Unnatural Japanese) Caution からする tends to be used most frequently in regard to money, while からの will be used when referring to people and other general amounts. In the case of things like weight, size, or distance, からある, another similar structure will be used. からある will be covered in its own grammar point.

example.japanese: この辺(あた)りはとても高(たか)いよ。家賃(やちん)は１０万(まん)円(えん)からする。
example.english: This neighborhood is awfully expensive. The rent is around 100,000 yen or more.

example.japanese: ５００ｋｍからの距離(きょり)を車(くるま)で走(はし)るのは疲(つか)れる。
example.english: Traveling 500 kilometers or more by car is tiring.

example.japanese: スタジアムに１０万(まん)人(にん)からの人(ひと)が集(あつ)まったそうだ。
example.english: I heard that over 100,000 people gathered at the stadium.

example.japanese: ビルさんは彼女(かのじょ)に２００万(まん)ドルからする車(くるま)を買(か)ってあげたらしいわ。
example.english: I heard that Bill gave his girlfriend a car that is worth over 2 million dollars.

example.japanese: アーノルドさんはもう７２歳(さい)なのに１００キロからのダンベルを持(も)ち上(あ)げられるよ。
example.english: Mr. Arnold can lift over 100 kg of dumbbells even though he is 72!

english_grammar.title: にして ①
english_grammar.explanation: at, over, in, only (after/when/because)
english_grammar.structure: Number + Counter + にして Noun + にして
english_grammar.about: When the case-marking particle に is combined with the て-form of する, it often carries the meaning of 'at (A)', 'over (A)', or 'only when (A)'. This nuance is used when (A) is something that is a fairly high level, or some point that would be considered a prime example for any given topic. にして may appear following counters, or standard nouns. 30歳(さい)にして初(はじ)めて海外(かいがい)旅行(りょこう)に行(い)った。 At the age of 30, I traveled abroad for the first time. ５回目(かいめ)にしてやっと資格(しかく)を取(と)ることができた。 I was finally able to get my qualification only after my fifth try. 犯人(はんにん)たちは道(みち)を曲(ま)がって、一瞬(いっしゅん)にして暗闇(くらやみ)の中(なか)へと消(き)えた。 The perpetrators turned off the road and disappeared into the darkness in an instant. While にして marks (A) as some particular exemplar, what follows may either be something that is or is not considered befitting of that example. In this way, (B) generally describes something that either does or does not fulfill the expectations of (A), and perhaps why. It is common to see にして followed by grammar patterns such as ようやく 'finally', or 初(はじ)めて 'only when'. These function to emphasize にして even further as being a point from which something is achieved or attained. 50歳(さい)にしてようやく、イタリアに住(す)んでいる従兄弟(いとこ)の家(いえ)に行(い)くことができた。 At age 50, I was finally able to visit my cousin who lives in Italy. 母(はは)は60歳(さい)にして初(はじ)めて、コンサートに行(い)ったらしい。 My mother went to a concert for the first time at the age of 60. Fun FactJust like other structures that make use of the various conjugations of にする, にして indicates something that has been decided upon, or is being accepted as a fact from which a new condition will arise, or has arisen.

example.japanese: 今(いま)にして思(おも)えばあの頃(ころ)５ドルでビットコインを売(う)るのは間違(まちが)った決定(けってい)だったかも。
example.english: When I think about it now, selling bitcoin for 5 dollars at that time might have been a bad decision.

example.japanese: 釈迦(しゃか)は２９歳(さい)にして初(はじ)めて、宮殿(きゅうでん)を出(で)た。
example.english: Buddha left the palace for the first time at the age of 29.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はバブルがはじけたことにより一夜(いちや)にして破産者(はさんしゃ)となった。
example.english: Due to the bubble burst, he went bankrupt overnight.

example.japanese: 小説(しょうせつ)、語(かた)り手(て)：「ミステリアスなその見知(みし)らぬ人(ひと)は、一瞬(いっしゅん)にして二人(ふたり)の暗殺者(あんさつしゃ)を同時(どうじ)に殺(ころ)してしまった。」
example.english: A novel, narrator: "The mysterious stranger, in a moment, killed two assassins at once."

example.japanese: ふうかはあきつき氏(し)夫妻(ふさい)の結婚(けっこん)２０年(ねん)目(め)にして初(はじ)めて授(さず)かった長女(ちょうじょ)だった。
example.english: Fuuka was the first daughter that the Akitsuki couple was blessed with in the 20th year of their marriage.

english_grammar.title: ものを
english_grammar.explanation: but, although, if only, I wish I had
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ば］(1) + Verb + ものを(2) Verb［ば］(1) + ［い］Adjective + ものを(2) Verb［ば］(1) + ［な］Adjective + な + ものを(2) Verb［ば］(1) + Noun + の + ものを(2) (1) Verb［たら］、Verb + と (2) ものを
english_grammar.about: ものを is a grammar point that functions in a similar way to のに in that it will express that (A) is something that was desired, despite (B) being the actual result. However, it is primarily used when the speaker is trying to convey their displeasure at the result of (B), due to (A) being something that by all means should have happened. ものを will be translated as 'if only (A)', or '(A), but (B)'. Despite being a construction of もの and the adverbial particle を, ものを is often considered as a standalone conjunction particle. It can be seen following verbs or い-Adjectives in their standard form, or な-Adjectives followed by な. もっと早(はや)くに歯医者(はいしゃ)に行(い)けば歯(は)を抜(ぬ)かずに住(す)んだものを... If you went to the dentist earlier, they wouldn't have had to remove your tooth, but… 目(め)を合(あ)わせなかったら止(と)められなかったものを、なんで警察(けいさつ)なんかと目(め)を合(あ)わせちゃうんだ。 If you didn't make eye contact with the police, we wouldn't have been stopped, so why did you have to go and make eye contact with them? アレルギーなどがあったなら、さきに言(い)ってくれればいいものを... If you had an allergy, you should have let me know beforehand, but… 「手伝(てつだ)って」って言(い)えばいいものを、一人(ひとり)でやるからこう言(い)う目(め)に会(あ)うんだよ。 If you have just asked for help, but because you did it alone, it ended up like this. みんなでやれば簡単(かんたん)なものを... It would have been easy if we all worked on it together, but… 道具(どうぐ)を使(つか)えば楽(らく)なものを、わざわざ自分(じぶん)の力(ちから)でやろうとするから怪我(けが)をするんだよ。 It would have been easier if you used tools, but because you went out of your wat to try it without any tools, you ended up getting hurt. As can be seen in the above examples, ものを is almost always preceded by hypothetical structures such as ば at some point leading up to its use. Caution ものを will often be seen at the end of sentences, with what would have come after it being left unspoken. In these cases, the important information is still there, as the (A) part of the sentence will always highlight what the ideal result was. Because of this, it can be safely assumed that the speaker is just frustrated that (A) didn't happen. 素直(すなお)に認(みと)めていればいいものを... I should have just been honest, but… (I should have just been honest, but instead I continued to lie) Fun FactThe adverbial particle を is often used this way in Japanese, where no specific action is linked to it. In these situations it usually just indicates an ideal or goal to which the method of achieving it (the verb that would usually be attached to を) is omitted. ものを can be thought of as an extension of this in literally meaning 'to that which was (A)', with 'I wish it had happened' being unsaid. 政治(せいじ)ポスター：日本(にほん)を前(まえ)へ。 Political poster: Japan forward. (Verb omitted but obvious from context, the positive improvement of Japan)

example.japanese: かみやま：「その不良学生(ふりょうがくせい)が僕(ぼく)の鉛筆(えんぴつ)を食(く)わなかったら入学試験(にゅうがくしけん)を受(う)けるはずのもんを...(食(く)ったから、受(う)けられなかった。）」
example.english: Kamiyama: "If that delinquent hadn’t eaten my pencil, I would have taken the school entrance exam for sure, but… (He has eaten it, so I couldn’t.)"

example.japanese: 犯罪(はんざい)コメディ映画(えいが)、トニー：「まったく、ボリス、おとなしく死(し)んでおればいいものを...」
example.english: Crime comedy movie, Tony: "Dear God, Boris, it would have been good if you had just shut up and died, but…"

example.japanese: 「もっと早(はや)くタバコをやめれば健康問題(けんこうもんだい)なしに済(す)んだものを、手遅(ておく)れになってしまった。」
example.english: "If I had quit smoking much earlier I would have ended up without any health problems, but now it is too late."

example.japanese: 父(ちち)は息子(むすこ)に言(い)う：「RINEでメッセージをしてくれたら迎(むか)えに行(い)ってあげたもんを...(メッセージしなかった。）」
example.english: Father speaking to his son: "If you had messaged me on Rine, I would have picked you up, but… (you didn’t)."

example.japanese: 「彼(かれ)が君(きみ)に謝(あやま)ったのなら許(ゆる)すべきものを、子供(こども)じゃあるまいし、無視(むし)するなんてひどすぎるよ。」
example.english: "You are not a child! If he is apologizing, you should forgive him, but ignoring him is too cruel!"

english_grammar.title: であれ
english_grammar.explanation: even if, even, no matter
english_grammar.structure: Noun + であれ ［な］Adjective + であれ WH-Word + であれ
english_grammar.about: Functioning as an extension of であれ, the formal copula that is a combination of the conjunctive form of the auxiliary verb だ, and the う-Verb ある, であれ or であろうと will be used in order to express strong will or conviction. あれ is simply the imperative form of ある, while あろうと is the positive volitional form combined with the case-marking particle と. Both structures are usually translated as 'even if (A), (B)', or 'no matter if (A), (B)'. Despite this, the more literal meaning of each is closer to 'so it's (A), (B) still won't be affected'. This just emphasizes the fact that (A) is of no relation to the result, like saying 'so what if it is' in English. Both であれ and であろうと will primarily attach to nouns in sentences that express some kind of question or assumption through words like どんな or たとえ. 子供(こども)であれ、法律(ほうりつ)は守(まも)らなくてはいけない。 Even if you are a child, you still need to obey the law. 理由(りゆう)が何(なん)であれ、家族(かぞく)や友達(ともだち)を裏切(うらぎ)るのはよくないと思(おも)う。 No matter the reason, I don't think it is right to betray your family and friends. いくらあなたが年上(としうえ)であろうと、ここでは一応(いちおう)私(わたし)が先輩(せんぱい)なので私(わたし)の言(い)うことに従(したが)ってください。 No matter how much older you are, I am your superior here so please do as I say. 上司(じょうし)からのメール：インフルエンザであろうと、会社(かいしゃ)にはきてください。 Email from my boss: 'Even if you have the flu, please come to work.' As both であれ and であろうと use structures that indicate strong will, these grammar patterns will frequently be used in sentences where the speaker is expressing their opinions or resolutions.

example.japanese: 友人(ゆうじん)の家(いえ)であれ、訪問時(ほうもんじ)は靴(くつ)を脱(ぬ)ぐことが、基本的(きほんてき)な礼儀(れいぎ)です。
example.english: Even if it is a friend's house, taking shoes off when visiting are basic manners.

example.japanese: 小説(しょうせつ)：「どのような状況(じょうきょう)であれ、逃(に)げることは許(ゆる)されない。」
example.english: Novel: "No matter the circumstances, running away is unforgivable."

example.japanese: たとえ氷(こおり)のように純粋(じゅんすい)であれ、世界(せかい)の悪(あく)からは免(まぬが)れられないだろう。
example.english: Even if one is as pure as ice, it seems that one cannot avoid the evil of the world.

example.japanese: 誰(だれ)であれ全(すべ)ての人々(ひとびと)は同様(どうよう)に死(し)ぬ。
example.english: No matter who you are, all people die similarly.

example.japanese: たとえ小(ちい)さなものであれ検察官(けんさつかん)は賄賂(わいろ)を受(う)け取(と)るわけにはいかない。
example.english: Even if it is just a small thing, the public prosecutor must not accept a bribe.

synonym.explanation: whether or, or, no matter which, in either case
whether… or
even if, even though, no matter, whether… or
though, although (I admit that), be that as it may, nonetheless
no wonder, after all, in fact, because, at any rate

english_grammar.title: を措(お)いて他(ほか)に〜ない
english_grammar.explanation: no...but, nothing else but, none other than
english_grammar.structure: Noun + をおいてほか + には(1) + … + ない (1)に
english_grammar.about: を措(お)いて is a grammar pattern that expresses something similar to 'none other than (A)', or 'nothing else but (A)'. を措(お)いて is a combination of the adverbial particle を, and the て-form of the う-Verb 措(お)く 'to set aside'. In this way, the literal meaning is similar to English phrases like 'setting aside (A), (B)', where (B) will be a broad statement about something that cannot be fulfilled by anything but (A). を措(お)いて will follow nouns or noun phrases, and frequently have 他(ほか)にない directly after it, emphasizing the point that 'there is no other'. こんなに人類学(じんるいがく)に詳(くわ)しい人(ひと)は高橋(たかはし)教授(きょうじゅ)をおいてほかにない。 No one knows anthropology better than Professor Takahashi. 最初(さいしょ)のライブは、大阪(おおさか)をおいてほかにない。 The first concert will be held in none other than Osaka. 日本語(いんほんご)の文法(ぶんぽう)を習(なら)いたいなら、文(ぶん)プロをおいてほかにない。 If you want to learn Japanese grammar, there is none other than Bunpro. を措(お)いて tends to only be used when the speaker positively evaluates (A), and is giving it praise in saying that nothing else can compare to it. Fun FactAs this grammar point regularly appears in hiragana, it may be helpful to remember that this uses 措(お)く 'to set aside', rather than 置く 'to place'. It may be easy to confuse these meanings, as they are very similar, and are classified as 同訓異字(どうくんいじ). These are words that have the same kun-yomi reading, and also have a similar meaning. There are hundreds of examples of these in the language, so memorizing words with the same readings will help in identifying the meaning of new kanji at a later stage.

example.japanese: 社長(しゃちょう)は副社長(ふくしゃちょう)に言(い)う：「私(わたし)は引退(いんたい)しようと思(おも)う。次期社長(じきしゃちょう)は君(きみ)をおいてほかにふさわしい人(ひと)は思(おも)い浮(う)かばない。」
example.english: The company president speaks to the vice president: "I am planning to retire. No one but you comes to my mind as a suitable successor."

example.japanese: 記事(きじ)：「日本人(にほんじん)監督(かんとく)といえば、現代(げんだい)の映画(えいが)撮影(さつえい)技術(ぎじゅつ)に最(もっと)も大(おお)きな影響(えいきょう)を与(あた)えたのは、もちろん黒沢明(くろさわあきら)をおいてほかにいない。
example.english: Article: "When I mention Japanese directors, the one that has the greatest influence on modern cinematography is of course none other than Akira Kurosawa."

example.japanese: 探偵(たんてい)は容疑者(ようぎしゃ)に言(い)う：「とぼけないでください。これほど事件(じけん)について知(し)っているのは犯人(はんにん)自身(じしん)をおいて他(ほか)にいないでしょう。」
example.english: Detective speaking to the suspect: "Don’t play dumb. No one but the murderer himself knows this much about the murder."

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)の勉強(べんきょう)を始(はじ)めたばかりの初心者(しょしんしゃ)の方(かた)におすすめするアプリを一つ(ひとつ)あげるとするなら、「文(ぶん)プロ」をおいてほかにはありません。
example.english: If I were to mention an app that I would recommend for beginners that have just started learning Japanese then it would be none other than "Bunpro."

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)との話(はなし)、こまり：「東京(とうきょう)で観光(かんこう)するつもりよ。」ほたる：「東京(とうきょう)で観光(かんこう)するなら東京(とうきょう)タワーをおいてほかにはないと思(おも)うの。」
example.english: Chat between friends, Komari: "I plan to go to sightseeing in Tokyo."Hotaru: "If you are going sightseeing in Tokyo, then I can think of nothing but Tokyo Tower."

synonym.explanation: there's only, nothing but
except・besides, other than, with the exception of
other・another, any other・anything else, as well as・besides・in addition

english_grammar.title: をもって
english_grammar.explanation: as of, with, effective from
english_grammar.structure: Time-Related Expression + をもって 以上(1) + をもって (1) これ
english_grammar.about: When used with time related expressions, the structure をもって is often translated as 'as of (A)', or 'effective from (A)'. This grammar pattern is a construction of the adverbial particle を, and もって 'by means of'. をもって will be used after nouns that indicate a time, or an event that happens at a specific time. このゲームのオンラインサービスは2023年(ねん)8月(がつ)10日(か)をもって終了(しゅうりょう)することに決定(けってい)しました。 It has been decided that the online service for this game will end as of August 10, 2023. 本日(ほんじつ)をもって、受付(うけつけ)を終了(しゅうりょう)いたします。 As of today, we will no longer be accepting applications. 今回(こんかい)のツアーをもって、解散(かいさん)することになりました。 We have decided to disband as of this tour. Although not common, をもって may sometimes be seen as をもちまして in very polite speech. いつもご来店(らいてん)ありがとうございます。この店舗(てんぽ)は本日(ほんじつ)をもちまして閉店(へいてん)いたします。 Thank you for visiting our store. This store will be closed as of today. Alternatively, the small っ (called a 促音(そくおん)) may occasionally be dropped. This results in をもて. 父(ちち)は4月(がつ)2日(か)をもて、40年間(ねんかん)勤(つと)めていた会社(かいしゃ)をやめることにした。 As of April 2nd, my father decided to quit the company he had worked for for 40 years. Caution Although 'effective from' can have the nuance of 'starting' in English, をもって primarily focuses on something ending, or what has happened up until the end date specified. Due to this, it will not be used to indicate that something is starting from a date that had nothing significant happen before it. 2023年(ねん)7月(がつ)27日(か)をもって、人気(にんき)映画(えいが)の続編(ぞくへん)が公開(こうかい)されます。 The sequel to the popular film will be released on July 27, 2023. (Unnatural Japanese) Fun FactComing from the kanji 以(もっ)て, and specifically meaning 'by means of', もって originally derives its nuance from 持(も)って, 'to hold', or 'to have'. In this way, it may help to remember もって as working in a similar way to 'having (A)', or 'having reached (A)' in English.

example.japanese: ファイナルファンタジー7のXbox Series X版(ばん)及(およ)びPlayStation 5版(ばん)のサービスは２０２１年(ねん)7月(がつ)16日(にち)（金(きん)）をもちまして終了(しゅうりょう)させて頂(いただ)くことになりました。
example.english: It has been decided that Final Fantasy 7's services for the Xbox Series X and PlayStation 5 will be shut down as of July 16th, 2021 (Friday).

example.japanese: 会議(かいぎ)、問(と)いかけに答(こた)えた後(あと)：「これをもちまして質疑応答(しつぎおうとう)を終(お)わります。ありがとうございます。」
example.english: The conference, after answering a question: "With this, I will end the question-answer session. Thank you very much."

example.japanese: 社長(しゃちょう)の退社(たいしゃ)の辞(ことば)：「本年(ほんねん)７月(がつ)をもちまして社長(しゃちょう)の立場(たちば)に退任(たいにん)することに致(いた)しました。今(いま)まで大変(たいへん)お世話(せわ)になりましたことを心(こころ)より御礼(おれい)申(もう)し上(あ)げます。」
example.english: Company president’s retirement speech: "I decided to retire from the position of President effective from the month of July this year. I sincerely appreciate your continued patronage."

example.japanese: 辞令(じれい)：「一条(いちじょう)蛍(ほたる)殿(どの)。令和(れいわ)２年(ねん)５月(がつ)１日(にち)をもって経理部(けいりぶ)第(だい)5課(か)勤務(きんむ)を命(めい)ずる。」
example.english: Appointment notice: "Ichijou Hotaru, we appoint you to a position in the fifth section of the accounting department, effective May 1st, 2020."

example.japanese: 以上(いじょう)をもちまして、私(わたし)のスピーチは終(お)わりとさせて頂(いただ)きます。
example.english: "With this, I would like to conclude my speech."

english_grammar.title: とは言(い)え
english_grammar.explanation: though, although (I admit that), be that as it may, nonetheless
english_grammar.structure: Verb + とはいえ + Phrase ［い］Adjective + とはいえ + Phrase Noun + （だ）+ とはいえ + Phrase ［な］Adjective + （だ）+ とはいえ + Phrase Phrase (A)。とはいえ + Phrase (B)
english_grammar.about: とは言(い)え is one of the standard grammar patterns in Japanese that makes use of the imperative form in order to strongly state a point. It will often be translated as 'although (A), (B) will not change', or 'be that as it may, (B)'. Literally, it is just making use of the case-marking particle と in addition to the adverbial particle は to present (A) as a quote that the speaker acknowledges, but may not actually accept. As this structure begins with と, it may be used at the end of any standard statement. この事件(じけん)の犯人(はんにん)が分(わ)かったとはいえ、犯人(はんにん)はまだ捕(つか)まっていないからまだ油断(ゆだん)はできない。 Although the culprit in this case has been found, we can't let our guard down yet because the culprit has not been caught yet. このパソコンは新(あたら)しいといえ、今(いま)持(も)っているパソコンより性能(せいのう)がいいと言(い)うわけではない。 Although this computer is new, it does not mean that it has better features than the computer that I already own. この国(くに)は安全(あんぜん)だといえ、日本(にほん)ではないので子供(こども)から目(め)を離(はな)さないようにしてください。 Although this country is safe, it is not Japan, so please keep an eye on your child. 日本人(にほんじん)とはいえ、スペインで育(そだ)ったから日本語(にほんご)があまり話(はな)せない。 Although I am Japanese, I grew up in Spain so I can't speak much Japanese. In most situations, the way that とはいえ will be used is like the English 'say that it is (A), that still doesn't change (B)'. (A) will generally be something that is true, or true as far as the speaker knows.

example.japanese: 犯人(はんにん)は逮捕(たいほ)されたとはいえ有罪(ゆうざい)と宣告(せんこく)されるまで時間(じかん)がかかるだろう。
example.english: Although (I admit that) the criminal has been caught, it will be some time before they are declared guilty.

example.japanese: 馬(うま)は肉(にく)を食(た)べることができる。とはいえ、普通(ふつう)は食(た)べない。
example.english: Horses are perfectly capable of eating meat. Having said that, they generally do not eat it.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は社長(しゃちょう)とはいえ名前(なまえ)ばかりだ。取締役会(とりしまりやくかい)には権限(けんげん)がある。
example.english: Although (I admit that) he is the company president, it is in name only. It is the board of directors that holds the power.

example.japanese: 論文(ろんぶん)：「この場合(ばあい)、「ようだ」と「ごとし」のどちらを使(つか)ってもよいということである。しかしながら、どちらも使(つか)えるとはいえ、実際(じっさい)には意味合(いみあ)いが異(こと)なる。」
example.english: Thesis: "In this case, one can use both 'ようだ' and 'ごとし.' However, although I say you can use both, their meanings actually have different nuances."

example.japanese: 今(いま)では、パンデミックの進行状況(しんこうじょうきょう)は遅(おそ)いとはいえ、まだ安心(あんしん)するわけにはいかない。
example.english: Although (I admit that) the progress of the pandemic is slow, we cannot afford to feel at ease just yet.

synonym.explanation: even if, even though, no matter, whether… or
whether… or
even if, even, no matter
whether or, or, no matter which, in either case

english_grammar.title: ならでは
english_grammar.explanation: unique to, only, impossible if not, expected only of
english_grammar.structure: More common patterns: Noun + ならでは + の + Noun Noun + ならでは + だ。 Less common patterns: Noun + ならでは + Verb［できる］［ない］+ Noun
english_grammar.about: ならでは is a construction which indicates that something is 'unique to (A)', or 'impossible if not (A)'. While ならでは is usually considered as its own standalone word, it is actually just a combination of the negative-conjunctive form of the the classical copula なり, ならで, with the addition of the adverbial particle は. ならでは will follow nouns, and the sentence will then usually go on to say what the thing is that is unique to (A). 味噌(みそ)カツは名古屋(なごや)ならではの食(た)べ物(もの)です。 Misokatsu is a food unique to Nagoya. アメリカならではの観光地(かんこうち)といったらどこを連想(れんそう)しますか。 Where do you think is a tourist attraction that is unique to the States? この祭(まつ)りはこの地域(ちいき)ならではの祭(まつ)りです。 This festival is unique to this area. As seen in the above examples, ならでは will only be used when something is being evaluated positively. As a result of this, it is very common to see in advertising and slogans. Caution ならでは may be seen directly before the auxiliary verb だ. In these cases, the thing that is unique to (A) will have been expressed earlier in the sentence, or will be obvious from context. こんな綺麗(きれい)な作品(さくひん)を作(つく)れるのは、藤田(ふじた)さんならではだ。 Only you, Fujita-san, can create such an amazing piece. 車(くるま)なしで生活(せいかつ)できるのは都会(とかい)ならではだ。 Only in the city can one live without a car. Based on the history of ならでは, the structure being the negative-conjunctive form of the copula なり means that it is basically identical in meaning of the more modern でなくては 'if it isn't (A)'.

example.japanese: 求人(きゅうじん)のサイト、求人(きゅうじん)情報(じょうほう)：「小(ちい)さいカフェならではの良(よ)さが溢(あふ)れています。」
example.english: Job search website, job information: "The charm unique to a small cafe is overflowing."

example.japanese: 広告(こうこく)ポスター：「沖縄(おきなわ)ならでは見(み)られない透明度(とうめいど)の高(たか)い青(あお)い海(うみ)は必見(ひっけん)だ。」
example.english: A poster ad: "The extremely clear blue waters that can only be seen in Okinawa are a must-see."

example.japanese: 本(ほん)のおすすめ記事(きじ)：「そのようなマンガやアニメなどの小(こ)ネタっぽいライトノベルを書(か)き上(あ)げるのはさすが西尾(にしお)維新(いしん)先生(せんせい)ならではです。」
example.english: A book recommendation article: "The one who can write a light novel filled with small joke references to manga and anime is unique to Nishio Ishin."

example.japanese: お茶(ちゃ)の広告(こうこく)：「ハイクオリティな紅茶(こうちゃ)ならではの味(あじ)わい！〇〇紅茶(こうちゃ)ティーバッグ３０バッグ入(いり)」「すっきりと香(かお)り高(たか)く澄(す)み切(き)った味(あじ)です！」
example.english: Tea advertisement: "A flavor only possible with high-quality tea! XX tea bags, 30 bags included.""A serene, refreshing, and aromatic taste!"

example.japanese: 求人(きゅうじん)のサイト、店員(てんいん)コメント：「こうした社風(しゃふう)の良(よ)さは当社(とうしゃ)ならではだと思(おも)います。」
example.english: Job search website, employee comment: "I think that the good quality of our corporate culture is unique to this company."

english_grammar.title: すら
english_grammar.explanation: even
english_grammar.structure: Noun + （Particle）+ すら（も）
english_grammar.attention: Sometimes you can encounter 「すらさえ」in song lyrics, which is used to emphasize すら more. However, this should be avoided as it is not a common expression.
english_grammar.about: すら is an adverbial particle in Japanese that basically translates as 'even'. The primary difference between it and も is that すら tends to present far more extreme examples to which a specific rule applies, and therefore also applies to all other less extreme examples. In most cases すら will be used with a negative nuance. As すら is an adverbial particle, it will be seen directly after nouns, or nouns followed by case-marking particles. 鉛筆(えんぴつ)すら持(も)ってきてないの？本当(ほんとう)にやる気(き)あるの？ You didn't even bring a pencil? Do you actually want to do this? 子供(こども)ですらできることをできないのか。お前(まえ)よくここまで生(い)きてこれたな。 You can't do what even a child can do. How have you managed to live this long? 彼(かれ)にすら話(はな)してないのに、親(おや)と話(はな)すわけがない。 I haven't talked to my boyfriend about it, there is no way I'm telling my parents. すら may also be followed by も in order to emphasize the point even further. ガラケーすらも使(つか)えないのに、パソコンが使(つか)えるわけないじゃん。 I can't even use a flip phone, there is no way I can use a computer. Caution すら and さえ are relatively similar in terms of strength. However, すら is more formal and cannot be used in the さえ～ば construction. すら also tends to be the most extreme example from within a large group, while さえ places more emphasis on a specific individual. そこさえ乗(の)り越(こ)えれば、あとは楽(らく)になるよ。 If you can overcome that, everything will be a breeze. そんなことさえ乗(の)り越(こ)えることができないのなら、この先(さき)何(なに)もできませんよ。 If you can't even overcome something so simple, you won't be able to do anything beyond this point. Fun Factは, も, さえ, and すら are all adverbial particles that share a linear relationship in regards to the way that they are used. This relationship refers to the intensity of how (A) fits into a group. This can be imagined as follows. (A) は - (A) is as expected, and there is nothing surprising about it. (A) も - (A) also fits the category of the main topic (は), but may or may not be surprising. (A) さえ - (A) also fits the category of the main topic (は), but is quite surprising when examined individually. (A) すら - (A) also fits the category of the main topic (は), but is the most extreme example possible, thus implying that anything below that level also applies.

example.japanese: 記事(きじ)：「カラスは道具(どうぐ)を使用(しよう)する能力(のうりょく)を示(しめ)したことすらあります。」
example.english: Article: "Crows have even demonstrated the ability to use tools."

example.japanese: 南極大陸(なんきょくたいりく)では夏(なつ)ですら気温(きおん)が0度(ど)以下(いか)である。
example.english: In Antarctica, temperatures are below zero even in summer.

example.japanese: マンガの迷(まよ)った主人公(しゅじんこう)：「何日(なんにち)たったのかすら...」
example.english: A lost manga protagonist: "I don’t even (know) how many days have passed…"

example.japanese: ノベル、語(かた)り手(て)：「負傷(ふしょう)により、走(はし)るどころかベッドから立(た)ち上(あ)がることすらもできない。」
example.english: A novel, narrator: "She couldn’t even stand, let alone run due to the injury."

example.japanese: ノベル、語(かた)り手(て)：「友達(ともだち)どころか家族(かぞく)にすら説明(せつめい)せずに旅(たび)に出(で)た。」
example.english: A novel, narrator: "Without even explaining to his family, let alone friends he embarked on a journey."

english_grammar.title: あっての
english_grammar.explanation: exist only because of/due to, owe everything to
english_grammar.structure: Noun (A) + （が）+ あっての + Noun (B)
english_grammar.attention: が is usually omitted
english_grammar.about: あっての is a pattern which emphasizes that (B) is something that only exists because of (A). It will often be translated as '(B) owes everything to (A)', or '(B) existing is only due to (A)'. This structure is a combination of the う-Verb ある 'to be' in its て-form, and the case-marking particle の. あっての will be preceded and followed directly by nouns, where the first noun is (A), and the second noun is (B). お客様(きゃくさま)あっての仕事(しごと)だと思(おも)うのですが、理不尽(りふじん)なクレームを言(い)われるとちょっとイラっときます。 My job only exists because of the customers, but I get a little annoyed when people make unreasonable complaints. 今回(こんかい)は皆様(みなさま)の努力(どりょく)あっての結果(けっか)です。皆様(みなさま)本当(ほんとう)にありがとうございました。 This time, the results are because of your efforts. Thank you very much. あっての will primarily be used when (B) is something that benefits positively from (A), and therefore is showing or should show some kind of gratitude toward it. Occasionally, the case-marking particle が will come between the (A) noun and あっての. However, it is often omitted. 私(わたし)はお金(かね)がなかったら愛(あい)もない、お金(かね)があっての幸(しあわ)せだと思(おも)います。 I think that love exists only because of money, and without money there is no love. Fun Factあっての can be thought of as an evolution of the basic grammar structure がある 'to have'. The main difference being that の allows (B) to be marked as the thing that has (A), while the て-form indicates that there is more information that will be given later about why this is important. Due to this information that comes later being important, (B) will almost always be followed by structures like から, or ので.

example.japanese: 「あなたあってのわたしです。あなたがいなければ私(わたし)の人生(じんせい)は無意味(むいみ)ですよ。」
example.english: "I can only exist because of you. My life would be meaningless without you."

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)が大学(だいがく)をやめるのは、何(なに)か理由(りゆう)があってのことだろう。
example.english: I guess he is dropping out of university only because some sort of reason exists.

example.japanese: 支配人(しはいにん)、社員(しゃいん)に：「ゲストあっての遊園地(ゆうえんち)だということを忘(わす)れてはいけません。」
example.english: Manager to employees: "You must not forget that the amusement park exists only because of the customers."

example.japanese: ベストセラー作者(さくしゃ)の演説(えんぜつ)：「 私(わたし)の本(ほん)は、家族(かぞく)の支(ささ)えあってのものです。息子(むすこ)と夫(おっと)がいなければここまでやってこれなかったと思(おも)います。」
example.english: Best Selling author’s speech: "My books exist only because of the support of my family. I believe, if it was not for my son and husband, I would not have gotten this far."

example.japanese: 切手(きって)のコレクションが火事(かじ)で全焼(ぜんしょう)して悲(かな)しいのは分(わ)かっているけどさ、生(い)きて逃(に)げられたのは何(なに)よりだよ。「命(いのち)あっての物種(ものだね)」だね。
example.english: I understand that you are sad because your stamp collection was destroyed in the fire, but getting out of there with your life is more important than anything. "While there is life, there is hope," right? ("things only exist because of life")

english_grammar.title: ～たまで + だ
english_grammar.explanation: just, merely・simply, only
english_grammar.structure: Verb［た］+ まで(1) + だ (1)までのこと
english_grammar.about: In comparison to ～るまでだ, the grammar pattern expressing that 'one can only but (A)', ～たまでだ works in a similar way, with the past tense of the verb indicating that 'doing (A) was all it was'. This emphasis is usually translated as 'I simply (A)', or 'I only (A)', with nuance on the action not being something especially big. Like ～るまでだ, ～たまでだ may be replaced with ～たまでのことだ, depending on what the speaker is trying to emphasize. なんで俺(おれ)が悪者(わるもの)扱(あつか)いされないといけないんだ？俺(おれ)はただ自分(じぶん)の意見(いけん)を言(い)ったまでだ。 Why do I have to get blamed for this? I only expressed my opinions. お婆(ばあ)さんが困(こま)った顔(かお)をしていたから、助(たす)けたまでだ。 I just helped because the old lady looked like she needed help. 最近(さいきん)学校(がっこう)にも行(い)かないし部屋(へや)からも出(で)ないから、聞(き)いたまでのことだ。 I merely asked because recently, you haven't left your room and haven't gone to school. そんなお礼(れい)とかはやめてください、人(ひと)として当(あ)たり前(まえ)のことをしたまでです。 Please, don't thank me. I just did something expected as a human. As this structure emphasizes that (A) is not a big deal, it will often be used in order to modestly highlight that one only did the bare minimum, and therefore praising them is unnecessary. Caution Both ～るまでだ and ～たまでだ are only used in reference to one's own personal actions, or the actions of a group they are affiliated with. 彼(かれ)は私(わたし)が困(こま)っていたから、助(たす)けてくれたまでだ。 Because I looked like I was in need, he merely helped me. (Unnatural Japanese)

example.japanese: A：助(たす)けてくれてありがとうございます！B：いや、自然(しぜん)のことをしたまで(のこと)です。
example.english: A: Thank you very much for helping me!B: Not at all. It was just the natural thing to do.

example.japanese: なんで怒(おこ)っているの？私(わたし)の意見(いけん)を言(い)ったまで(のこと)だ。
example.english: Why are you angry? I merely stated my opinion.

example.japanese: A：わぁ、日本語(にほんご)上手(じょうず)だね！B：ただ趣味(しゅみ)で勉強(べんきょう)してたまで(のこと)で、まだまだだけどね。
example.english: A: Wow, your Japanese is good!B: I merely learned it as a hobby. I still have a ways to go.

example.japanese: 僕(ぼく)はただ伝言(でんごん)を頼(たの)まれたから伝(つた)えたまでで、それは僕(ぼく)の考(かんが)えではないからね！
example.english: Since I was just requested to have a word with you, that's merely all I did, it's not like they were my thoughts.

example.japanese: 真実(しんじつ)を話(はな)したまでのことなのに、なぜかクラスメイトから嘘(うそ)つきと言(い)われてしまいました。
example.english: When I just told the truth, I was accused by my classmate of being a liar for some reason.

synonym.explanation: just, merely・simply, only

english_grammar.title: を経(へ)て
english_grammar.explanation: via, through, after (experience at job/university/etc.), pass through
english_grammar.structure: Noun + を経て
english_grammar.about: を経(へ)て is a fairly formal grammar point used when highlighting a passage of time, or an event that took a certain amount of time. 経(へ)る itself is a る-Verb that means 'to elapse' or 'to pass' in terms of time. The difference between it and 過(す)ぎる 'to pass time' is that 過(す)ぎる focuses on having reached the end point, while 経(へ)る focuses on what was happening for the whole period leading up to that end point. Because of this, を経(へ)て can also be translated as 'having undergone (A)', due to the emphasis being on the preceding action. を経(へ)て will directly follow nouns, and the rest of the sentence usually then goes on to describe the significance of that passage of time or experience, or what happened as a result. 私(わたし)たちは2019年(ねん)に出会(であ)って、約(やく)2年間(ねんかん)の交際(こうさい)を経(へ)て結婚(けっこん)しました。 We met in 2019, and married after going through two years of dating. 日本(にほん)への留学(りゅうがく)を経(へ)て、日本(にほん)の文化(ぶんか)などを学(なな)ぶことができました。 Through my study in Japan, I was able to learn about Japanese culture and other aspects of the country. 人(ひと)は色々(いろいろ)な経験(けいけん)を経(へ)て、成長(せいちょう)していく。 People grow through various experiences. As it is a formal structure, を経(へ)て is often seen in biographies, introductions, and similar media.

example.japanese: ちとげとらくは、約(やく)１０年(ねん)の交際(こうさい)を経(へ)てやがて結婚(けっこん)した。
