example.english: Chitoge and Raku finally married after going through about ten years of dating.

example.japanese: 略歴(りゃくれき)：「早稲田大学(わせだだいがく)理学部(りがくぶ)卒業後(そつぎょうご)Google勤務(きんむ)を経(へ)て202◯年(ねん)独立(どくりつ)。」
example.english: Short bio: “Graduated from the department of science, Waseda University. After working at Google, he started his own business in 202X.”

example.japanese: 新聞(しんぶん)：「今後(こんご)必要(ひつよう)な手続(てつづ)きを経(へ)て、鉱山(こうざん)買収(ばいしゅう)は完了(かんりょう)します。」
example.english: Newspaper: “After going through all of the necessary procedures, the mine acquisition will be complete.”

example.japanese: 数(すう)世代(せだい)を経(へ)てもなお争議(そうぎ)が続(つづ)いている。
example.english: Even after several generations, the dispute still continues.

example.japanese: ベルリンからローマを経(へ)てブエノスアイレスに向(む)かいます。
example.english: From Berlin, via Rome, to Buenos Aires.

english_grammar.title: ながら + に
english_grammar.explanation: while being, born (with), traditional (old-fashioned, as it was long ago), as always, while crying/in tears, (burned) alive
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ ながら（に） Noun + ながら（に） Verb［ます］+ ながら + の + Noun Noun (A) + ながら + の + Noun (B) ,,生きる ￫ 生きながら（にして） 生まれる ￫ 生まれながら（にして） 昔 ￫ 昔ながら いつも ￫ いつもながら 毎回 ￫ 毎回ながら 涙 ￫ 涙ながらに 溜め息 ￫ 溜め息ながら いる ￫ いながら（にして）
english_grammar.about: When combined with the case-marking particle に, ながら 'while' as a suffix will indicate that something remains in the state of (A), while also having or doing (B). This can be translated as 'while being (A), (B)', or '(A) as always (B)'. ながらに will be seen following nouns, or verbs in their stem form. Additionally, して may be added to the end of に, without any change to the nuance. 自由権(じゆうけん)は人(ひと)が生(う)まれながらに持(も)っている権利(けんり)の一(ひと)つだ。 Freedom is one of the rights that people are born with. 家(いえ)に居(い)ながらにして仕事(しごと)ができるから、職場(しょくば)までわざわざ行(い)かなくても良(よ)くなった。 I can work while being home, so I don't have to go all the way to my workplace anymore. 彼女(かのじょ)は涙(なみだ)ながらに彼(かれ)を見送(みおく)った。 She sent him off while crying. 子供(こども)ながらにして、なんで親(おや)がいつも喧嘩(けんか)をしていたかは理解(りかい)していた。 Even as a child, I understood why my parents were always fighting. ながらに is a structure that has many potential translations in English, but the key point to remember is that (B) is something that is being highlighted as happening or existing in same state as (A) in an unchanged state. This doesn't necessarily mean at the same time. For example, in the case of 生(う)まれながらに, it can be translated as '(B) has existed since birth', but what it really means is that 'while being in the state of (A), (B) is still there'. Caution ながらに tends to only be used with a limited set of words, so it is best not to use it with structures that you have not already seen at some point in the past.

example.japanese: コウタはカエデからの手紙(てがみ)を手(て)に取(と)りつつ、涙(なみだ)ながらに喜(よろこ)んだ。
example.english: While crying with joy, Kouta held the letter from Kaede in his hands.

example.japanese: いつもながらあなたたちと話(はな)すのは楽(たの)しいですよ。
example.english: It is a pleasure to talk with you, as always.

example.japanese: 生(い)きながら焼(や)かれるところだった。
example.english: She was almost burned alive.

example.japanese: 料理(りょうり)レシピサイト：「昔(むかし)ながらのオムライスの作(つく)り方(かた)を簡単(かんたん)で分(わ)かりやすい動画(どうが)で紹介(しょうかい)しています。」
example.english: A site with cooking recipes: "With this simple and easy-to-understand video, we will introduce a traditional omuraisu recipe."

example.japanese: テレワークというのは家(いえ)にいながら働(はたら)くということだ。
example.english: Telework means to work while being at home.

english_grammar.title: ～たなり
english_grammar.explanation: while... ~ing, remaining, not/ever since, keep/leave
english_grammar.structure: Verb［た］+ なり + （で）+ Phrase
english_grammar.about: When following the た, past-tense form of a verb, the conjunction particle なり 'shape' indicates something existing in an ongoing state, similar to まま. This may be translated as 'while (A)', or 'remaining (A)'. Due to ～たなり sentences usually describing something happening while in the state of (A), it will often be followed directly by a comma, or by the conjunctive form of the auxiliary verb だ, で. After this, the (B) phrase will then describe what is happening during (A). ～たなり will primarily be used to express an undesirable state continuing despite (A) having happened, although this is not a strict rule. 弟(おとうと)は彼女(かのじょ)に振(ふ)られて部屋(へや)に入(はい)ったなり、全然(ぜんぜん)部屋(へや)から出(で)てこなくなってしまった。 Ever since my brother locked himself in his room after his girlfriend broke up with him, he hasn't come out of his room at all. 父(ちち)が釣(つ)りにいったなりまだ帰(かえ)ってこない、大丈夫(だいじょうぶ)かな... My father hasn't come back home since he went out fishing. I wonder if he is okay… 兄(あに)は上京(じょうきょう)したなり、帰(かえ)ってこない。 My older brother hasn't come back, ever since he moved to Tokyo. As ～たなり indicates that (A) is something that is continuing to stay in the same state, it will often have the nuance of 'ever since (A)' in situations where a significant amount of time has passed. Caution This なり derives from the noun 形(なり) 'shape' in its hiragana form, and is different to the なり that is used as the classic copula.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は腰(こし)かけたなりでじっと考(かんが)えていた。
example.english: While remaining seated, he has been pondering intently.

example.japanese: ３年(ねん)前(まえ)に涙(なみだ)ながらに家出(いえで)したなり、帰(かえ)ってこない。
example.english: She ran away three years ago in tears, and hasn’t come back since.

example.japanese: レース後(ご)、草(くさ)の上(うえ)に横(よこ)になったなり、泣(な)き続(つづ)けた。
example.english: After the race, he cried while lying down on the grass.

example.japanese: 町(まち)を離(はな)れたなりで消息(しょうそく)は途絶(とだ)えた。
example.english: We haven’t heard from her ever since she left the city.

example.japanese: 宿泊客(しゅくはくきゃく)の一人(ひとり)がドアを開(あ)けたなりにしてあります。
example.english: One of the hotel guests left the doors open.

synonym.explanation: as is, while remaining, left in a state
only, just, since

english_grammar.title: の極(きわ)み
english_grammar.explanation: ultimate, extreme, utter, epitome, peak
english_grammar.structure: Noun + の + 極み
english_grammar.about: When paired with a noun followed by the case-marking particle の, 極(きわ)み 'extremity' will indicate something that is 'the ultimate (A)', 'the extreme (A)', or 'the epitome of (A)'. This may be used in either positive or negative sentences. あと5分(ふん)待(ま)って居(い)れば私(わたし)が大好(だいす)きなアイドルに会(あ)えていたとは...痛恨(つうこん)の極(きわ)みだ。 If only I had waited five more minutes, I would have met my favorite idol... It's the peak of despair. 今(いま)までこんなに良(よ)くしてくれて、感激(かんげき)の極(きわ)みです。 I am beyond thrilled that you have been so good to me so far. 有給(ゆうきゅう)は取(と)るなとか鬼畜(きちく)の極(きわ)みだ。 Telling us to not take paid time off? That's the epitome of being evil. As 極(きわ)み itself is a noun, it will often be followed by the auxiliary verb だ, or the conjunctive form で when going on to describe something that is as a result of (A). こんな景色(けしき)がいいところで、こんな美味(おい)しい料理(りょうり)を食(た)べられるなんて、なんて贅沢(ぜいたく)の極(きわ)みだ。 It's the ultimate luxury to be able to eat such delicious food in such a scenic place. この曲(きょく)の歌詞(かし)は感動(かんどう)の極(きわ)みで、聞(き)くたびに涙(なみだ)が溢(あふ)れ出(で)てくる。 The lyrics of this song are the peak of emotion and bring tears to my eyes every time I listen to it. Caution の極(きわ)み is a structure that is paired with nouns, while 極(きわ)まる and 極(きわ)まりない are grammar patterns that will be paired with adjectives, despite the meanings being quite similar.

example.japanese: 小説(しょうせつ)：「ダイモス王(おう)はこの報道(ほうどう)を聞(き)いて、驚(おどろ)きの極(きわ)みに達(たっ)しました。」
example.english: Novel: "Hearing the news, the King Daimos reached the very peak of surprise."

example.japanese: 目上(めうえ)の人(ひと)にはじめて出会(であ)う時(とき)：「お目(め)に掛(か)かることができ、光栄(こうえい)の極(きわ)みです。」
example.english: When meeting a superior for the first time: "It is an extreme honour to be able to meet you."

example.japanese: レストランサイト：「寿司(すし) - 日本(にほん)の極(きわ)み、主(おも)に米飯(べいはん)に魚介類(ぎょかいるい)など組(く)み合(あ)わせた和食(わしょく)です。」
example.english: Restaurant website: "Sushi - the epitome of Japan. This Japanese-style meal is made by combining fish and shellfish with cooked rice."

example.japanese: 地震(じしん)によってビルに閉(と)じ込(こ)められた人々(ひとびと)は混乱(こんらん)の極(きわ)みにあった。
example.english: The people trapped in the building due to the earthquake were in extreme (utter) turmoil.

example.japanese: 釈迦(しゃか)様(さま)は当初(とうしょ)贅沢(ぜいたく)の極(きわ)みを尽(つ)くした生活(せいかつ)をしていた。
example.english: At first, Buddha lived an utterly luxurious life.

synonym.explanation: extreme, extremely

english_grammar.title: にして + 見(み)れば
english_grammar.explanation: For (A), In the case of (A), From (A)'s point of view, In the eyes of (A)
english_grammar.structure: Noun + にしてみれば(1) (1) にしてみたら
english_grammar.about: にしてみれば, usually written completely in hiragana, is an expression used when the speaker is making a hypothetical statement about how something may appear from the point of view of another. It will often be translated as 'from the point of view of (A), (B)', 'in the case of (A), (B)', or simply 'for (A), (B)'. Literally, the meaning is 'assuming that I was (A) and then looking from there, (B)'. にしてみれば will appear after nouns that represent a person, or organizations representative of people. It is a combination of the case-marking particle に, the て-form of する, and the hypothetical form of 見(み)る, 見(み)れば. 上級者(じょうきゅうしゃ)には簡単(かんたん)かもしれないが、初心者(しょしんしゃ)にしてみればかなり難(むずか)しいと思(おも)う。 For someone who is experienced it may be easy, but for someone new, I think it would be difficult. 日本人(にほんじん)の私(わたし)にしてみれば、日本語(にほんご)は簡単(かんたん)だけど英語(えいご)は難(むずか)しい。 As a Japanese person, Japanese is easy, but English is hard. アニメをあまり知(し)らない人(ひと)にしてみれば、ポケモンもデジモンも同(おな)じアニメだ。 From the point of view of someone who doesn't watch anime, Pokemon and Digimon are the same anime. As にしてみれば will exclusively follow words that indicate a person or a group of people, the (B) part of the phrase will usually discuss how the speaker assumes that they would feel given the situation. Because of this assumption, these sentences often finish with だろう, でしょう, かもしれない, and other similar structures.

example.japanese: ハリーにしてみれば、優(やさ)しくしてもらうなど、初(はじ)めての経験(けいけん)だった。
example.english: For Harry, it was the first time he had ever been treated kindly.

example.japanese: 傍(そば)から見(み)ればただの安(やす)っぽいペンダントだろうが、ラクにしてみれば貴重(きちょう)な思(おも)い出(で)の品(しな)になっている。
example.english: It might appear to be a mere cheap pendant from the side, but for Raku, it has become a precious memento.

example.japanese: 大人(おとな)には非常(ひじょう)に簡単(かんたん)だが、小(ちい)さな子供(こども)にしてみればかなり困難(こんなん)なことかもしれない。
example.english: For an adult, it is very simple, but for a small child, it might be quite hard.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)は冗談(じょうだん)のつもりだったが、彼(かれ)にしてみれば笑(わら)い事(ごと)ではなくて３週間(しゅうかん)彼女(かのじょ)と話(はな)さなかった。
example.english: She intended it as a joke, but for him, it wasn’t a laughing matter, and he didn’t talk to her for three weeks.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)たちにとっては危険(きけん)すぎるようにみえる彼(かれ)の生活(せいかつ)は、彼自身(かれじしん)にしてみればごく普通(ふつう)のことなのでしょう。
example.english: His life that seems too dangerous to us, is likely quite ordinary for him.

english_grammar.title: だの
english_grammar.explanation: things like, and so on, or something, and whatnot
english_grammar.structure: A(1) + だの + B(1) + だの A(1) + だの + 何だの (1) Noun、Quotation
english_grammar.about: Although originally a combination of the auxiliary verb だ, and the case-marking particle の, だの is considered to be a standalone adverbial particle in modern Japanese that is used in the same way as structures like など and とか in presenting examples. Due to this, it will often be translated as 'and things like (A)', or '(A) and whatnot'. だの will only be used when at least two examples are given, with each of those examples being followed by だの. Usually, these two things are either opposites of each other, or two things that share the same negative trait. だの may appear after verbs, い-Adjectives, nouns, or quotations. 彼(かれ)は仕事(しごと)はやめるだの家事(かじ)を手伝(てつだ)わないだの、本当(ほんとう)に自分(じぶん)以外(いがい)のことは何(なに)も考(かんが)えていない。 He does things such as quit work, and not help with chores and so on. He really does not think about anyone other than himself. この建物(たてもの)は汚(きたな)いだの危(あぶ)ないだのと近所(きんじょ)の人(ひと)に言(い)われていたので解体(かいたい)されるらしい。 The neighbor has been saying that this building is dirty, dangerous and what not so apparently it is going to get demolished. 揚(あ)げ物(もの)だのコンビニ弁当(べんとう)だのばかり食(た)べてると、また健康(けんこう)診断(しんだん)の時(とき)に先生(せんせい)に怒(おこ)られるよ。 If you only eat things like fried food, convenience store food and what not, you are going to get told off by your doctor again at the next check-up. 妻(つま)は大嫌(だいきら)いだの嫌(きら)いだのと毎日(まいにち)言(い)ってくるから悲(かな)しくなってきた。 My wife tells me that she hates me and dislikes me and what not everyday so I am starting to feel sad. 彼(かれ)は「嫌(いや)」だの「大変(たいへん)」だの、何(なに)かをやる前(まえ)から弱音(よわね)を吐(は)くから、一緒(いっしょ)にいるとこっちまで仕事(しごと)をしたくなる。 He only says things like 'No' and 'impossible' even before trying anything, so it even makes me not want to work. Caution In situations where the words that だの is attached to are opposites, it will be exhibiting a large range to which the same rule applies. However when the words are similar, it is usually expressing things within that specific category as being undesirable. Because of this, regardless of what the words are, the overall statement itself aims to emphasize the speaker's feelings of frustration or boredom in relation to things that fall under that category, or that scope. そんなに好(す)きだの嫌(きら)いだのと言(い)うんだったら明日(あした)から自分(じぶん)でご飯(はん)作(つく)りな。 If you are going to say things like 'I like this', 'I don't like this', and things like that, why don't you start making your own food starting tomorrow? (Opposite ends of a spectrum) あの新入社員(しんにゅうしゃいん)はつらいだの面倒(めんどう)だのの理由(りゆう)で会社(かいしゃ)を入社(にゅうしゃ)して二週間(にしゅうかん)でやめた。 That newbie said things like 'this is too much', and 'this is a pain' and gave a reason similar to that and ended up quitting after 2 weeks of working with us. (Both negative)

example.japanese: ヒナは「臭(くさ)い」だの「まずい」だのと文句(もんく)ばかりを言(い)っている。
example.english: Hina only complains that "it smells" or "it's awful" and so on.

example.japanese: ラーメンやカレーが嫌(きら)いな人：「ラーメンだのカレーだのが好(す)きなやつは味(あじ)のわからんやつだよ。」
example.english: A person that hates ramen and curry: "People who like things like ramen, curry, and so on are people who don't understand what taste is."

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)１は友達(ともだち)２に文句(もんく)を言(い)う：「私(わたし)たちは最近(さいきん)会話(かいわ)だの何(なん)だのばかりしているけど、実際(じっさい)に新製品(しんせいひん)を開発(かいはつ)する人(ひと)はいないよ。」
example.english: Friend1 complains to friend2: "Recently we are doing nothing but shooting the breeze (chatting) and whatnot, but there is no one that will actually develop a new product."

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はゲームに負(ま)けるといつも｢回線(かいせん)が悪(わる)い｣だの｢敵(てき)がチート｣だのと言(い)い訳(わけ)ばかり言(い)う。
example.english: Every time he loses a game, he just gives excuses things like "there’s a bad connection" or "the other players are cheating" and whatnot.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はいつも責任(せきにん)を持(も)つだの何(なん)だの戯言(たわごと)ばかり言(い)ってるけど、責任(せきにん)を取(と)る時(とき)に、真(ま)っ先(さき)に逃(に)げるのは彼(かれ)だ。
example.english: He always talks nonsense about "being responsible" and so on, but when it comes time to take responsibility he is the first to run.

english_grammar.title: 飽(あ)くまでも
english_grammar.explanation: to the (bitter) end, stubbornly, persistently
english_grammar.structure: あくまで（も） + Phrase
english_grammar.about: 飽(あ)く is the old-fashioned and somewhat poetic version of 飽(あ)きる the る-Verb meaning 'to tire of (A)', or 'to get sick of (A)'. When used in conjunction with the adverbial particles まで 'until', and も 'even', 飽(あ)くまでも will imply that (A) is being done 'persistently', 'stubbornly', or 'to the bitter end'. The more literal translation of 'to continue (A) even to the point of getting tired of it' fits these interpretations quite well. 飽(あ)くまでも will often come at the beginning of sentences before going on to describe that thing that is being done persistently. 容疑者(ようぎしゃ)はあくまでも自分(じぶん)がしたことを認(みと)めようとしませんでした。 The suspect stubbornly refused to admit what he had done. 私(わたし)たちはあくまでもあなたのお子(こ)さんを見(み)つけるつもりです！ We intend to look for your child until we can find them! 彼女(かのじょ)はあくまでも子供(こども)たちには秘密(ひみつ)にしておこうと思(おも)っていたが、これ以上(いじょう)子供(こども)たちには嘘(うそ)をついていられないと思(おも)い、子供(こども)たちに全(すべ)てを話(はな)した。 She thought that she would have kept it a secret from her kids till the bitter end, but she couldn't lie to her children any longer, so she told them everything. も is not required, and 飽(あ)くまで may sometimes be seen without it. However, as the phrase is quite strong, it is far more common for も to be included to highlight the emphasis. 犯人(はんにん)のことなら私(わたし)にお任(まか)せください！あくまで彼(かれ)を捕(つか)まえるまで探(さが)し続(つづ)けるつもりです！ Leave it up to me to find the culprit! I intend to look for them until I catch them! Due to the persistence that the verb 飽(あ)く itself can highlight, it will often be seen together in sentences that include words like つもり 'intention', to show that someone intends to do something regardless of the consequences. Despite 飽(あ)くまで being a combination of 飽(あ)く and まで, it will appear in most dictionaries as a standalone adverb in modern Japanese.

example.japanese: あくまでも、不正(ふせい)に立(た)ち向(む)かおうとします。
example.english: I will fight against injustice to the end.

example.japanese: あくまでもやると言(い)うなら、私(わたし)は止(と)めません。
example.english: If you (stubbornly) insist on doing this, I won’t stop you.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)は政治的圧力(せいじてきあつりょく)にも関(かか)わらずその新税(しんぜい)にあくまで反対(はんたい)した。
example.english: Despite political pressure, she opposed the new tax to the bitter end.

example.japanese: 被告(ひこく)はあくまでも無罪(むざい)を主張(しゅちょう)するつもりらしい。
example.english: I have heard that the defendant insists on claiming his innocence until the bitter end.

example.japanese: イラ次長(じちょう)はあくまでも意見(いけん)を変(か)えませんでした。結果(けっか)、このプロジェクトを葬(ほうむ)らざるを得(え)ませんでした。
example.english: Vice Director Ira stubbornly didn’t change her decision. As a result, we had no choice but to shelve the project.

english_grammar.title: べく
english_grammar.explanation: for the purpose of, in order to, to ensure
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ べく Exceptions: す(1) + べく (1) する
english_grammar.about: As the conjunctive form of the classical auxiliary verb べし, べく will be attached to the dictionary form of verbs in order to convey the purpose of an action. This will be translated as 'for the purpose of (A), (B)', 'in order to (A), (B)', or 'to ensure that (A), (B)'. べく itself will only attach to verbs that can be done intentionally, with some purpose in mind. The (B) part of べく sentences will also indicate an intentional action that will be performed in order to reach the goal of (A). 地域(ちいき)の高齢者(こうれいしゃ)の安全(あんぜん)を守(まも)るべく、交番(こうばん)が設置(せっち)されました。 In order to ensure the safety of the elderly in the community, a police box has been set. 息子(むすこ)は医者(いしゃ)になるべく、ここ3年間(ねんかん)ほぼ寝(ね)ずに毎日(まいにち)勉強(べんきょう)をしている。 In order to become a doctor, he has been studying these past 3 years without much sleep. When combining with する with べく, due to べく being a classical auxiliary verb, it will attach to the classical stem of する, す. However, in modern Japanese it is fairly common to see both すべく and するべく, with both forms being considered correct. ここでの交通(こうつう)事故(じこ)を防止(ぼうし)すべく、ガードレールなどの設備(せつび)を設置(せっち)することになった。 In order to prevent car accidents here, things such as guardrails are to be installed. 次(つぎ)の大会(たいかい)で優勝(ゆうしょう)するべく、彼(かれ)らは毎日(まいにち)朝(あさ)から夜(よる)まで練習(れんしゅう)をするようにしている。 They try to practice every day from morning to night in order to win the next competition. べく itself is a very formal structure in modern Japanese, so will rarely be used in standard speech. Fun FactAlthough べし and all of its conjugations have slightly different translations based on the grammar points that they appear in, the underlying meaning can be stemmed from the originating kanji 可(べ)し, meaning 'to be permissible'. The focus with this kanji and all forms of べし are just that the word it is attached to is being marked as a strong goal. This means that rather than 'in order to (A)', べく is closer to 'to attain (A)', in that it adds further emphasis.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は研修医(けんしゅうい)となるべく、5年(ねん)以上(いじょう)医科大学(いかだいがく)で修練(しゅうれん)しました。
example.english: In order to become a medical intern, he studied at a medical college for five years.

example.japanese: コーポレートサイト：「クライアントのニーズに応(こた)えるべく、我(わ)が社(しゃ)は世界(せかい)で初(はじ)めて、AIカスタマーサポートを生(う)み出(だ)しました。」
example.english: Corporate site: In order to meet our customers' needs, our company has developed the world's first AI customer support.

example.japanese: 大学(だいがく)ウェブサイト：「IZU科学技術大学(かがくぎじゅつだいがく)では、予定通(よていどお)り秋期(しゅうき)講座(こうざ)を開講(かいこう)すべく、鋭意(えいい)準備(じゅんび)を進(すす)めてまいりました。」
example.english: University website: "We, at the IZU university of science and technology, have been making preparations in order to launch lectures for the Fall Term as planned."

example.japanese: 社長(しゃちょう)の演説(えんぜつ)：「当社(とうしゃ)はCO2排出量(はいしゅつりょう)の低減(ていげん)義務(ぎむ)を果(は)たすべく、工場(こうじょう)にCO2専用(せんよう)フィルタの取(と)り付(つ)けを決定(けってい)いたしました。」
example.english: Company president speech: "Our company has decided to install specialized CO2 filters in our factories to ensure that we meet CO2 emission reduction obligations."

example.japanese: 伝記(でんき)：「ホテル業界(ぎょうかい)での有力者(ゆうりょくしゃ)としての地位(ちい)を固(かた)めるべく、海外(かいがい)でもホテルを購入(こうにゅう)しようとしたが、拒否(きょひ)されてしまった。」
example.english: Biography: "In order to cement his influential position in the hotel world, he also attempted to buy hotels abroad, but he was refused."

english_grammar.title: ところを
english_grammar.explanation: when, while, in spite of (the circumstances), regardless of (the circumstances)
english_grammar.structure: Verb + ところ（を） ［い］Adjective + ところ（を） ［な］Adjective + ところ（を） Noun + の + ところ（を）
english_grammar.about: Being a combination of the noun ところ 'place' or 'situation', and the adverbial particle を, ところを is a grammar construction that will be used in order to express 2 primary meanings. The first is 'in spite of (A)', or 'regardless of (A)'. This nuance of ところ will be that the speaker is politely acknowledging the situation that someone else is in, and apologizing for interrupting them in that moment. ところを may come after any structure that could pair with a noun. This means verbs in their standard forms, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives followed by な, or nouns followed by の. 先輩(せんぱい)、休(やす)んでいるところを申(もお)し訳(わけ)ないんですけど、エクセルの使(つか)い方(かた)を教(おし)えてください。 Senpai, I'm sorry to bother you while you are on vacation, but could you please teach me how to use Excel? お忙(いそが)しいところをすみませんが、相談(そうだん)したいことがあるので少(すこ)しだけ時間(じかん)いいですか。 I am sorry to bother you while you are busy, but I want some advice. May I have some of your time? ご多忙(たぼう)なところをご対応(たいおう)いただきありがとうございました。 Thank you for taking time out in spite of you being busy. お急(いそ)ぎのところを恐縮(きょうしゅく)ですが、何時(なんじ)ぐらいに向(む)こうに着(つ)くか教(おし)えてもらってもよろしいでしょうか。 I'm sorry to bother you when you are in a hurry, but may I ask what time you expect to arrive over there? The second meaning that ところを is often used for will simply be 'when (A)', or 'at the time of (A)', with a focus on being a situation in which the action of (A) is interrupted by (B). This may have either a positive or negative nuance. This use of ところを will appear exclusively after verbs in any of their standard forms. 警察(けいさつ)に逃(に)げるところを目撃(もくげき)された。 I was seen by the police while I was fleeing. 母(はは)に悪戯(いたずら)をしているところを見(み)られてしまった。 My mother caught me while I was playing a prank. 彼(かれ)は強盗(ごうとう)をしていたところを周(まわ)りの人(ひと)に目撃(もくげき)されていたので、どこにも逃(に)げれなかった。 Since he was seen when he was robbing the store, he had nowhere to run. The を itself may be omitted when used to express either of these meanings. Fun Factところを is occasionally split into two different grammar points depending on the source. However, it is important to remember that the underlying meaning of both of these is the same. ところ marks the place or situation, while を marks how that situation is being utilized either positively or negatively. When it comes to apologizing, the speaker themselves is the one 'using' that moment with を, and is therefore acknowledging that.

example.japanese: 先生(せんせい)からの返信(へんしん)のお礼(れい)を言(い)う：「お忙(いそが)しいところを、ご返信(へんしん)ありがとうございます。」
example.english: Expressing gratitude to a teacher for their reply: "In spite of being busy, thank you for your reply."

example.japanese: 目上(めうえ)の人(ひと)に尋(たず)ねる：「お急(いそ)ぎのところを恐縮(きょうしゅく)ですが、このプロジェクトについてのご意見(いけん)をお聞(き)かせ願(ねが)えませんか」
example.english: Asking a superior: "I hate to trouble you when you are in such a hurry, but could you let me hear your opinion about this project?"

example.japanese: メール：「ご病気(びょうき)中(ちゅう)のところを恐(おそ)れ入(い)りますが、田中(たなか)先生(せんせい)の携帯(けいたい)の番号(ばんごう)を教(おし)えていただけますでしょうか。」
example.english: Email: "I am awfully sorry to trouble you when you are ill, but could you tell me Mr. Tanaka’s cell number?"

example.japanese: 駅(えき)の放送(ほうそう)：「この電車(でんしゃ)は、3分(ぷん)遅(おく)れて到着(とうちゃく)いたします。お急(いそ)ぎのところを、ご迷惑(めいわく)をおかけいたします。」
example.english: Station announcement: "This train will arrive three minutes late. We apologize for the inconvenience while you are in a rush."

example.japanese: 会議(かいぎ)での冒頭(ぼうとう)の挨拶(あいさつ)：「皆様(みなさま)、本日(ほんじつ)はご多忙(たぼう)のところをお越(こ)しいただき、ありがとうございます。」
example.english: Greetings on the outset of a conference: "Ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for coming today despite being so busy."

english_grammar.title: からある
english_grammar.explanation: as much as, as many as, at least
english_grammar.structure: Number + Counter + からある Number + Counter + からある + Noun Number + Counter + からいる Number + Counter + からいる + Noun
english_grammar.about: Like からする, a structure showing that something 'goes from (A)', からある works in a similar way, but simply shows that something 'exists from (A)'. This grammar pattern will be used when making an estimation where the minimum is being guessed. からある is a combination of the case-marking particle から 'from', and the う-Verb ある 'to be'. からある will appear after numbers and counters. おじいちゃんは80歳(さい)なのに60キロからあるダンベルを持(も)ち上(あ)げることができる。 Even though my grandpa is 80 years old, he is able to lift dumbbells that weigh as much as 60 kilos. 中学生(ちゅうがくせい)の頃(ころ)から好(す)きなバンドのコンサートチケットを買(か)おうとしたら、5000枚(まい)からあるチケットがすぐに売(う)り切(き)れていて、買(か)うことができなかった。 When I tried to buy concert tickets for a band that I have liked since middle school, I couldn't because as many as 5000 tickets were sold out instantly. 彼(かれ)は小柄(こがら)であるにも関(かか)わらず、７０キロからある冷蔵庫(れいぞうこ)を一人(ひとり)で持(も)ち上(あ)げることができる。 Although he is smaller in stature, he can lift refrigerators that weigh as much as 70 kilos, all by himself. からある has a tendency to appear most frequently when describing things that are thought to be static, such as distances, sizes, or weights. Caution Following the standard rules of いる and ある, いる will need to be used if something living is being counted. この会社(かいしゃ)には正社員(せいしゃいん)が3000人(にん)からいる。 There are as many as 3000 full time workers in this company. However, this is not a common use of this grammar structure, with からの almost always being used in place of からいる for counting living things. あのコンサートには1万(まん)人(にん)からの人数(にんずう)がいる。 There are as many as 10,000 people at that concert.

example.japanese: 百匹(ひゃっぴき)からいるネズミをどうやって退治(たいじ)するのか！
example.english: How do you get rid of as many as 100 mice!

example.japanese: 「富士山(ふじさん)はここから２００キロからあるのに、よく見(み)えます。」
example.english: "Mt. Fuji is as many as 200 kilometers from here, and yet it is quite visible."

example.japanese: オーストラリアの大火事(おおかじ)で10億(おく)匹(ひき)からいる動物(どうぶつ)が焼死(しょうし)した。
example.english: As many as one billion animals perished in the Australian fires.

example.japanese: 狼(おおかみ)は、人間(にんげん)には聞(き)こえない音(おと)が聞(き)こえる。また、体重(たいじゅう)が80キロからある個体(こたい)もある。
example.english: Wolves can hear sounds that are inaudible to humans. Also, some specimens weigh as much as 80 kilograms.

example.japanese: 名探偵(めいたんてい)ゴナン：「犯人(はんにん)は少(すく)なくとも３人(にん)からいます。」
example.english: The great detective Gonan: "There are, at the very least, as many as three culprits."

synonym.explanation: more than (or equal to), over・(and) above, any more・greater, exceeding

english_grammar.title: にして ②
english_grammar.explanation: to be ~ and ~, to be ~ as well as ~, both ~ and ~
english_grammar.structure: Noun + にして ［な］Adjective + にして
english_grammar.about: Occasionally, the combination of the case-marking particle に 'in', and the て-form of the special verb する, して will be considered as a compound particle. While this does not change the way it will be used, it puts more emphasis on the 'going from that (A), (B)' nuance of にして. This will be translated as '(A) as well as (B)', 'both (A) and (B)', or 'to be (A) and (B)'. This use of にして will appear following either nouns or な-Adjectives. この足場(あしば)は安全(あんぜん)にしてかつ組(く)み立(た)てるのが簡単(かんたん)だから、注文(ちゅうもん)が殺到(さっとう)している。 Orders for this scaffolding have been pouring in because it is both safe and easy to assemble. 彼女(かのじょ)は大学(だいがく)の教授(きょうじゅ)にして会社(かいしゃ)の経営者(けいえいしゃ)でもある。 She is both an university professor and a CEO. Some set expressions like 幸(さいわ)いにして and 不幸(ふこう)にして also exist. These can be interpreted as 'fortunately' and 'unfortunately' respectively. 携帯(けいたい)を駅(えき)で落(お)としてしまったが、幸(さいわ)いにして交番(こうばん)に届(とど)いていた。 I accidentally lost my phone at the station, but fortunately it was delivered to the police station. 彼(かれ)は不幸(ふこう)にして、幼(おさな)い頃(ころ)に両親(りょうしん)を亡(な)くした。 Unfortunately, he lost his parents when he was younger. Caution Like with 幸(さいわ)いにして and 不幸(ふこう)にして, にして tends to be used with a fairly limited set of words when having the meaning of 'both (A) and (B)'. Due to this, it is best to only use patterns that you have come across before. Fun FactThe tense at the end of にして sentences often changes that way that it will be understood, but it is important to remember that all にして structures simply put emphasis on (A) as being what allowed (B), led to (B), or exists in precedence to (B).

example.japanese: 紺碧(こんぺき)にして美(うつく)しい海(うみ)である。
example.english: The sea is both beautiful and a deep blue.

example.japanese: 山田(やまだ)先生(せんせい)は有名(ゆうめい)な教授(きょうじゅ)にして尊重(そんちょう)されている弁護士(べんごし)でもある。
example.english: Dr. Yamada is both a famous professor and a respected lawyer.

example.japanese: 牛(うし)は優美(ゆうび)、温和(おんわ)にして頭(あたま)が冴(さ)えている。
example.english: Cows are graceful, gentle, and smart.

example.japanese: シンプルにしてかつパワフルなアプリである。
example.english: This is a simple and moreover a powerful app.

example.japanese: 田中(たなか)総理大臣(そうりだいじん)は稀代(きたい)の政治家(せいじか)にして同時(どうじ)に偉大(いだい)な父(ちち)でもある。
example.english: Prime minister Tanaka is both an extraordinary politician and, at the same time, a great father.

english_grammar.title: つ (Conjunctive)
english_grammar.explanation: two contrasting actions
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ つ + (Antonym) Verb［ます］+ つ Verb［ます］+ つ + (Antonym) Verb［ます］+ つ + の + Noun Verb［ます］+ つ + Verb［られる］ーる + つ Verb［ます］+ つ + Verb［られる］ーる + つ + の + Noun 行きつ戻りつ - going back and forth 浮きつ沈みつ - rising and falling (bobbing) 見えつ隠れつ - coming in and out of sight とつおいつ (from 取りつ置きつ) - wavering between 矯めつ眇めつ - taking a good look 組んず解れつ - struggling with 抜きつ抜かれつ - neck-and-neck 持ちつ持たれつ - give-and-take 押しつ押されつ - pull and be pulled 追いつ追われつ - lead changing many times 差しつ差されつ - taking turns filling cups
english_grammar.about: つ is a conjunction particle in Japanese that is used in constructions where it will appear twice, highlighting contrasting verbs. This つ～つ structure is often translated as 'to be doing (A) and (B) over and over', where the actions are happening repeatedly one after the other. つ will connect to the conjunctive form of verbs, with (A) and (B) generally appearing in direct sequence. 新(あたら)しく発売(はつばい)されたゲーム機(き)を買(か)おうか悩(なや)みながら、お店(みせ)の前(まえ)を行(い)きつ戻(もど)りつした。 I walked back and forth in front of the store, wondering if I should buy the newly released game console. 川(かわ)で脱(ぬ)げた靴(くつ)が浮(う)きつ沈(しず)みつ流(なが)れていった。 My shoe that came off in the river was bobbing up and down as it floated away. Additionally, it is also quite common to see the same verb being repeated in both places. When this happens, the (A) verb will be in the standard form, while the (B) verb will be in the passive form. This just translates as 'to do (A) and to have (A) done to oneself'. 僕(ぼく)たちは持(も)ちつ持(も)たれつの関係(かんけい)で、保育園(ほいくえん)の頃(ころ)から今(いま)に至(いた)るまでお互(おたが)い助(たす)け合(あ)ってきた。 We have always been in a give and take relationship, helping each other from the time we were in nursery school until now. コンサート会場(かいじょう)には大勢(おおぜい)の人(ひと)が集(あつ)まっていて、ゲートが開(ひら)かれても押(お)しつ押(お)されつで全然(ぜんぜん)会場(かいじょう)に入(はい)れなかった。 There were so many people gathered at the concert venue that even when the gate was opened, I could not enter the venue at all because of the pushing and shoving. Caution This grammar pattern is only used with a limited set of words in modern Japanese. Here is a list of some standard combinations. 行(ゆ)きつ戻(もど)りつ - To go back and forth. 浮(う)きつ沈(しず)みつ - To surface and submerge (to bob). 見(み)えつ隠(かく)れつ - To go in and our of sight. とつおいつ (from 取(と)りつ置(お)きつ) - To waver between. 矯(た)めつ眇(すが)めつ - To take a good look. 組(く)んず解(ほど)れつ - To intertwine and release (to grapple). 抜(ぬ)きつ抜(ぬ)かれつ - To pull away and be pulled away from (to be neck and neck). 持(も)ちつ持(も)たれつ - To have and to be held (to give and take). 押(お)しつ押(お)されつ - To press and be pressed. 追(お)いつ追(お)われつ - To overtake and be overtaken. 差(さ)しつ差(さ)されつ - To pour and be poured (to take turns exchanging drinks).

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はドアの前(まえ)をしばらく不安(ふあん)げに行(い)きつ戻(もど)りつしていたすえに入(はい)ることにした。
example.english: After some time, he finally decided to go inside after nervously going back and forth in front of the door.

example.japanese: アリとアリマキは持(も)ちつ持(も)たれつの関係(かんけい)にある。
example.english: Ants and aphids have a give-and-take relationship.

example.japanese: 老人(ろうじん)は小枝(こえだ)の浮(う)きつ沈(しず)みつを眺(なが)めながら、海(うみ)の匂(にお)いを楽(たの)しんだ。
example.english: The old man enjoyed the smell of the sea while watching the sinking and rising (bobbing) twig.

example.japanese: 藤原(ふじわら)拓海(たくみ)、須藤(すどう)京一(きょういち)など、多(おお)くの有名(ゆうめい)なドライバが抜(ぬ)きつ抜(ぬ)かれつのレースを繰(く)り広(ひろ)げた。
example.english: Takumi Fujiwara, Kyoichi Sudo and many other famous drivers put on a neck and neck race.

example.japanese: 風(かぜ)が強(つよ)い曇(くも)り空(ぞら)だったから月(つき)が雲(くも)に見(み)えつ隠(かく)れつしていた。
example.english: It was a cloudy night with a strong wind, so the moon was moving in and out the clouds.

english_grammar.title: 飽(あ)くまで
english_grammar.explanation: just, only, merely, strictly
english_grammar.structure: あくまで(も）+ Phrase
english_grammar.about: 飽(あ)く is the old-fashioned and somewhat poetic version of 飽(あ)きる the る-Verb meaning 'to tire of (A)', or 'to get sick of (A)'. When used in conjunction with the adverbial particles まで 'until', 飽(あ)くまで can imply that (A) is 'just', 'only', or 'strictly' something. The more literal translation of 'to continue (A) to the point of getting tired of it' fits these interpretations quite well, implying that (A) will never deviate from what is being described about it. This use of 飽(あ)くまで often appears at the beginning of a phrase, and functions adverbially. The adverbial particle も 'even' may be added for extra emphasis, but it is not required. 彼(かれ)はあくまでも新人(しんじん)なので優(やさ)しく接(せっ)してあげてください。 He is merely a newbie, so please treat him kindly. それはあくまで可能性(かのうせい)に過(す)ぎないからなんの役(やく)にも立(た)たない。 That is merely a possibility, so it doesn't help. 私(わたし)はあくまでも素人(しろうと)に過(す)ぎませんが、設計(せっけい)にミスがあると思(おも)います。 I am just an amateur, but I think that there is a mistake in the design. In many cases, 飽(あ)くまで will be used in polite sentences when the speaker is expressing their own opinion. In these cases, the nuance of 'this is merely my opinion' is conveying to the listener that the speaker realizes that what they are saying is not the only viewpoint. これはあくまで私(わたし)の意見(いけん)なので参考(さんこう)にしないでくださいね。 This is just my opinion, so please don't refer to it. This way of highlighting opinions is often combined with structures like けど, or が when the speaker wants to soften their statement before offering what they think a solution might be.

example.japanese: 会社(かいしゃ)の代表(だいひょう)はビジネスパートナーに：「今(いま)からお話(はな)しすることは、飽(あ)くまで私(わたし)の個人的(こじんてき)な意見(いけん)で、会社(かいしゃ)としての公式(こうしき)な意見(いけん)ではないことをご了承(りょうしょう)いただきたいのですが、...」
example.english: Company representative to business partners: "What I am about to say is just my personal opinion, so please understand that this is not our official stance as a company…"

example.japanese: 配偶者(はいぐうしゃ)１は配偶者(はいぐうしゃ)２に：「もうガスがちゃんと閉(し)めてあるか確認(かくにん)したのを知(し)ってるけど、もう一度(いちど)確認(かくにん)してね。飽(あ)くまでも一応(いちおう)ですけどね。」
example.english: Spouse 1 to Spouse 2: "I know you have already checked if the gas is turned off, but please check again. Just to be sure."

example.japanese: 「その影響(えいきょう)で東京(とうきょう)オリンピックは20XX年(ねん)も開催(かいさい)できないと思(おも)います。でもまぁ、飽(あ)くまでも私(わたし)の想像(そうぞう)に過(す)ぎないので、真剣(しんけん)に考(かんが)えないでください。」
example.english: "I think that due to its influence, the Olympics might also not happen in 20XX. But this is just what I imagine will happen, so don’t look into it too much."

example.japanese: 学術論文(がくじゅつろんぶん)：「このアルゴリズムの実世界(じっせかい)での使用法(しようほう)は場合(ばあい)によって異(こと)なりますので、飽(あ)くまでも本稿(ほんこう)はガイドラインとして取(と)り扱(あつか)いください。」
example.english: Scientific article: "The real-world application of this algorithm differs from case to case, therefore use this paper just as a reference."

example.japanese: 探偵(たんてい)：「その火(ひ)が上(あ)がったのは偶然(ぐうぜん)ではなかったかもしれない。まぁ、これは飽(あ)くまで僕(ぼく)の仮説(かせつ)ですが。」
example.english: Detective: "That fire might not have been entirely an accident. This is just my hypothesis, though."

english_grammar.title: であれ〜であれ
english_grammar.explanation: whether or, or, no matter which, in either case
english_grammar.structure: Noun (A) + であれ + Noun (B) + であれ ［な］Adjective (A) + であれ + ［な］Adjective (B) + であれ
english_grammar.about: Functioning as an extension of である, the formal copula that is a combination of the conjunctive form of the auxiliary verb だ, and the う-Verb ある, であれ or であろうと will be used in order to express strong will or conviction. あれ is simply the imperative form of ある, while あろうと is the positive volitional form combined with the case marking particle と. Both structures are usually translated as 'even if (A), (B)', or 'no matter if (A), (B)'. Despite this, the more literal meaning of each is closer to 'so it's (A), (B) still won't be affected'. This just emphasizes the fact that (A) is of no relation to the result, like saying 'so what if it is' in English. When used consecutively, てあれ shows that regardless of whether something is (A) or (B), the result of (C), will not change. Both であれ and であろうと will primarily attach to nouns in sentences that express some kind of question or assumption through words like どんな or たとえ. 子供(こども)であれ大人(おとな)であれ、入場料(にゅうじょうりょう)は4000円(えん)です。 Whether you are a child or an adult, the entrance fee is 4000 yen. 日本製(にほんせい)であれベトナム製(せい)であれ同(おな)じ機械(きかい)でできてるから質(しつ)に変(か)わりはない。 Whether it is made in Japan or Vietnam, it is made with the same machine, so there is no difference in the quality. 正社員(せいしゃいん)であろうとアルバイトであろうと、客(きゃく)には関係(かんけい)がない話(はなし)だ。 Whether someone is a full time worker or a part time worker doesn't matter to a customer. 未経験者(みけいけんしゃ)であろうとベテランであろうと、この現場(げんば)に入(はい)るにはこの講習(こうしゅう)を受(う)けなくてはいけないです。 Whether you are inexperienced or experienced, you must take this course to enter this work site. Caution Although ～であれ～であれ implies 'no matter whether it is (A) or (B)', both (A) and (B) in these types of sentences usually fall under the same category, as (C) needs to be something that links them logically. For example (A) may be 'a plane', and (B) may be 'a submarine', while (C) will be describing something about them both being vehicles.

example.japanese: 近代美術(きんだいびじゅつ)であれ伝統芸能(でんとうげいのう)であれ、芸術(げいじゅつ)は芸術(げいじゅつ)だ。
example.english: Whether it is modern art or traditional art, art is art.

example.japanese: 遺伝情報(いでんじょうほう)とは、人間(にんげん)であれバナナであれ、すべて同(おな)じようにDNAに組(く)み込(こ)まれているものだ。
example.english: Whether it is in a human or in a banana, genetic information is something that is similarly encoded in DNA.

example.japanese: 人(ひと)は無病息災(むびょうそくさい)であれ、病気(びょうき)であれ、常(つね)に健康(けんこう)に注意(ちゅうい)が必要(ひつよう)です。
example.english: Whether someone is healthy or ill, they should take care of their health.

example.japanese: 本(ほん)ウェブサイト、故意(こい)に、オンラインであれオフラインであれ、ユーザからの個人情報(こじんじょうほう)を収集(しゅうしゅう)しません。
example.english: Whether online or offline, this website does not knowingly collect personal information from users.

example.japanese: 勉強(べんきょう)であれスポーツであれ何(なん)であれ、結果(けっか)は注(そそ)いできた努力(どりょく)次第(しだい)である。
example.english: Whether it is studying, sports, or whatever, results depend on the effort one has put in.

synonym.explanation: even if, even, no matter
whether… or
even if, even though, no matter, whether… or
though, although (I admit that), be that as it may, nonetheless
no wonder, after all, in fact, because, at any rate

english_grammar.title: たら最後(さいご)
english_grammar.explanation: once, now that, as soon as
english_grammar.structure: Verb［た］+ が + 最後 Verb［たら］+ 最後
english_grammar.about: たら最後(さいご) and たが最後(さいご) are grammar structures that both share the meaning of 'once (A), definitely (B)'. (B) will always be something negative that is thought to inevitably occur once the action of (A) happens. These expressions may be translated as 'once (A), (B)', 'now that (A), (B)', or 'as soon as (A), (B)'. Both たら and が are being used as conjunction particles. たら carries its usual meaning of 'if' or 'when', while が has the meaning of 'however', or 'but'. This means that たが最後(さいご) means '(A), but it will end up as (B)', while たら最後(さいご) means 'when (A), in will end up as (B)'. Although this nuance is slightly different, they are used completely interchangeably. 恋愛(れんあい)だけではなく、友達(ともだち)の間(あいだ)でも信頼(しんらい)を失(うしな)ったが最後(さいご)、取(と)り戻(もど)すにはかなりの時間(じかん)がかかる。 Once you lose trust, not only in love, but also among friends, it takes a long time to regain it. その会社(かいしゃ)と契約(けいやく)をしたが最後(さいご)、解約(けいやく)するのがものすごくめんどくさい。 Once you have signed a contract with that company, it is a huge hassle to cancel. あの蛇(へび)に噛(か)まれたら最後(さいご)、体(からだ)が麻痺(まひ)するらしい。 I heard that once you get bitten by that snake, your body becomes paralyzed. 田中(たなか)さんが話(はな)し始(はじ)めたら最後(さいご)、口(くち)が疲(つか)れるまでずっと話(はな)し続(つづ)ける。 Once Tanaka-san starts talking, he won't stop until his mouth gets tired. Because 最後(さいご) is primarily seen before the comma in these types of sentences, it can be easy to think that it is connected to the が or たら. However, it is actually more correctly connected logically to the (B) half of the sentence, and states that the 'final state' will end up being that way. Caution Occasionally, the (B) phrase will be omitted from these sentences when the negative result is obvious. あの人(ひと)に政治(せいじ)についての意見(いけん)を求(もと)めたら最後(さいご)だ。 It's the end once you ask him for his political opinions. (He won't stop talking after that) 先生(せんせい)が注意(ちゅうい)しなくなったら最後(さいご)だ。 It's the end once your teacher stops giving you advice. (Because it means that they have given up on you)

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の彼氏(かれし)はゲームをいったんやり始(はじ)めたら最後(さいご)、どうしても深夜(しんや)までやめられない。
example.english: Once my boyfriend starts playing a game, he can’t stop until late at night no matter what.

example.japanese: 会社(かいしゃ)、先輩(せんぱい)は後輩(こうはい)に：「イラ次長(じちょう)に目(め)を付(つ)けられたら最後(さいご)、この会社(かいしゃ)では生きていけなくなるんだよ。もちろん比喩(ひゆ)ではない。」
example.english: At a company, senpai to kouhai: “Once vice-director Ira has an eye on you, you won’t be able to continue at this company. I’m not joking, of course. ”

example.japanese: 社長(しゃちょう)、社員(しゃいん)に：「会社(かいしゃ)は信頼性(しんらいせい)を一度(いちど)失(うしな)ったが最後(さいご)、絶対(ぜったい)に取(と)り戻(もど)すことができないので、クライアントとの対話(たいわ)には気(き)をつけてね。」
example.english: Company president to employees: “Once the company loses its reputation, it cannot be regained, so be careful when communicating with clients.”

example.japanese: 小説(しょうせつ)のカスタマーレビュー：「綺麗(きれい)な話(はなし)です。 読(よ)みはじめたら最後(さいご)、涙(なみだ)がとまりません。」
example.english: Customer review of a book: “What a beautiful story. Once I started reading, I couldn’t stop crying.”

example.japanese: 口(くち)を開(ひら)いたら最後(さいご)、自分(じぶん)の意志(いし)では止(と)められなくて何時間(なんじかん)も喋(しゃべ)り続(つづ)けてしまう。
example.english: Once she opens her mouth, she will keep on talking for hours with no intention of stopping.

english_grammar.title: 如何(いか)なる
english_grammar.explanation: what kind of, no matter what kind of, no … (with a negative verb); any... (with a negative verb)
english_grammar.structure: いかなる + Noun
english_grammar.about: 如何(いか)なる is a combination of 如何(いか), and なる. なる being derived from the classical auxiliary verb なり 'to be'. 如何(いか) is never used as a word by itself, and will always be attached to something else when it has the reading of いか. However, its meaning is the same as the modern どう 'how'. Because of this, いかなる is interchangeable with どんな 'what kind of', with the exception that it is primarily used only in books and formal writing. いかなる is classified as being attributive, meaning that it will appear directly before a noun, or modify a noun somewhere within the same clause. いかなることがあっても、決(け)して手(て)を離(はな)してはいけません。わかりましたか？ No matter what happens, you must not let go. Do you understand? 私(わたし)たちはいかなる時(とき)にも出動(しゅつどう)できるように、常(つね)に訓練(くんれん)しています。 We are constantly training to be ready to dispatch at any moment. 彼(かれ)らはいかなる要求(ようきゅう)にも応(おう)じなければならない。 They must comply with any request, no matter what it is. Just like どんな, when に is added to いかなる, a negative statement will usually follow. This translates as 'no matter how much (A)', or 'no matter what kind of (A)'. However, に will not directly follow いかなる like it does with どんな. Instead, it will appear later in the sentence before the verb. いかなる状況(じょうきょう)に置(お)かれても、諦(あきら)めずに突(つ)き進(すす)むことを忘れないでください。 Remember, no matter what situation you find yourself in, do not give up and keep pushing forward. 彼(かれ)らは結婚(けっこん)してから長(なが)いから、いかなる困難(こんなん)にあっても、二人(ふたり)で乗(の)り越(こ)えられる。 They've been married long enough that no matter what challenges they face, they can overcome them together. Occasionally, いかな may also be used, but this is far less common. いかな状況(じょうきょう)にも耐(た)え得(え)る人(ひと)になりたい。 I want to be a person who can withstand any situation. Fun FactBoth な and なる are derived from the classical auxiliary verb なり. Structures that stem from なり can be seen in many modern parts of the Japanese language. This also includes なら, the hypothetical form of だ, which shares the same meaning of 'to be' as なり. While な is the form that appears with most adjectival nouns, なる is still sometimes used in place of な when the speaker wants to be poetic, or give a sense of archaism.

example.japanese: 論文(ろんぶん)：「亀(かめ)とはいかなる魚(さかな)なのか？」
example.english: Essay: “What kind of fish is a turtle?”

example.japanese: Kappazonグループはいかなる理由(りゆう)であろうとも、Kappazonネットショップからいかなる製品(せいひん)も削除(さくじょ)する権利(けんり)を保有(ほゆう)しています。
example.english: Kappazon Group reserves the right to remove any product from the Kappazon online store, no matter the reason.

example.japanese: シヌラ電気動力株式会社(でんきどうりょくかぶしきがいしゃ)はいかなる第三者(だいさんしゃ)にも顧客(こきゃく)情報(じょうほう)を販売(はんばい)、配布(はいふ)いたしません。
example.english: The Shinura Electric Power Company does not sell or disclose any data to third parties (no matter what).

example.japanese: いかなる方(かた)ともログイン情報(じょうほう)またはパスワードの共有(きょうゆう)はお控(ひか)え願(ねが)います。
example.english: We request that you refrain from sharing login or password information with anyone (no matter who).

example.japanese: パイロットはいかなる事態(じたい)になろうとも、適切(てきせつ)に対処(たいしょ)せねばならない。
example.english: A pilot has to react accordingly no matter what the situation might become.

synonym.text: そんな・こんな・あんな・どんな
synonym.explanation: such a・kind of, something like ~

english_grammar.title: なりに
english_grammar.explanation: in one's/its own way, of someone's own, do ones best in one's own way, as much as one can
english_grammar.structure: Noun + なりに それ + なりに ［い］Adjective + なりに ［な］Adjective + なりに Noun (A) + なり + の + Noun (B) それ + なりの + Noun
english_grammar.about: When used as a noun, なり often presents an example group from which something exhibits traits of, regardless of whether that group is actually a good example of the trait being described. This use can be translated as 'for (A) do to (C) in the way of (B)'. Or more simply, 'to do its best in its own way', or 'to do as much as one can'. This use stems from 形(なり), meaning 'shape' or 'pattern', and can be thought of as meaning 'in the pattern of'. In these sentences, (A) will be a specific example from within a group, (B) will be representative of the whole group, and (C), will be the trait or behavior in question related to (B). Either of the case marking particles に or の will come after なり, depending on whether なり is linked directly to a noun, or is being used adverbially. なりに and なりの may follow almost any word in its plain form, with the word it follows being the group or quality that is being represented. 自由(じゆう)時間(じかん)が増(ふ)えたら、増(ふ)えたなりに有効(ゆうこう)に使(つか)いたい。 If I get more free time, I would like to use all that freetime. 広(ひろ)い部屋(へや)は広(ひろ)いなりのデメリットがあります。 Large rooms have their own disadvantages. 彼(かれ)は仕事(しごと)が下手(へた)なりに、他(ほか)の社員(しゃいん)のモチベーションをあげてくれたりしている。 For all of his lack of skill, he does his best to motivate other workers. 自分(じぶん)なりに頑張(がんば)ってみたが、やっぱりダメだった。 I tried my best in my own way, but it was still not enough. This use of なり is considered a neologism, which is a pre-existing word that has been adapted to have a new meaning or nuance. When used this way, なり will almost always express that (A) is not doing something adequately or as desired, but is doing the best it can based on the 'pattern' or 'mold' that it comes from.

example.japanese: なつみちゃん：「田舎(いなか)って本当(ほんとう)に不便(ふべん)だよね」こまりちゃん：「田舎(いなか)は不便(ふべん)な時(とき)もあるけど、それなりに魅力(みりょく)もあるよ。」
example.english: Natsumi: "The countryside is really inconvenient, right?"Komari: "It might be inconvenient sometimes, but it also has its own charm."

example.japanese: 「子供(こども)はいいね。何(なん)にも心配(しんぱい)ごとも無(な)いし...」「でも、子供(こども)には子供(こども)なりの苦(くる)しみがあるんだけど。」
example.english: "Children have it nice. No worries at all…""But children have their own worries though."

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は下手(へた)なりに頑張(がんば)ってラブレターを書(か)いた。
example.english: For all of his lack of skill, he did the best that he could to write a love letter.

example.japanese: 会計士(かいけいし)は会計士(かいけいし)なりに頑張(がんば)って全(すべ)ての手段(しゅだん)を尽(つ)くしましたが、解決策(かいけつさく)を見(み)つけられませんでした。
example.english: The accountants have done their best to leave no stone unturned, but they could not find a solution.

example.japanese: 「その問(と)い合(あ)わせに対(たい)する私(わたし)なりの回答(かいとう)をご紹介(しょうかい)いたします。」
example.english: “I would like to present my own answer to that query.”

english_grammar.title: れる・られる + ままに
english_grammar.explanation: do as (one is told/ordered…), in accordance with, in compliance with, just like
english_grammar.structure: Verb［られる］+ （が）+ まま + （に）
english_grammar.about: When paired with まま, a noun meaning 'in the state of', and the case marking particle に, the auxiliary verbs れる and られる indicate something being done 'as one is told', or 'as ordered'. Because of this, れる and られる will almost always be paired with verbs that indicate some kind of communication. As these structures are in the passive, the literal translation is close to 'to do (B) in the state that (A) was done to me'. The (B) part will come directly after ままに and simply states how someone is going to react in compliance with (A). 私(わたし)は先輩(せんぱい)に言(い)われるままにしただけですよ。 I only did things as I was told by senpai. 日本(にほん)では上司(じょうし)に命(めい)じられるままに仕事(しごと)をしている人(ひと)が多(おお)い。 In Japan, many people work as ordered by their bosses. 警察(けいさつ)に聞(き)かれるままに、仲間(なかま)の名前(なまえ)を教(おし)えた。 I gave the names of my accomplices to the police as they asked me. The conjunction particle が may appear between られる and ままに, but this is not common in modern Japanese. Although it does carry the meaning of 'but', the focus is more on expressing that the (A) is not being resisted or argued with when doing (B). 婚活(こんかつ)アプリで出会(であ)った人(ひと)に言(い)われるがままに、ギフトカードを買(か)ってしまった。 I did as I was told by someone I met on a dating app and bought a gift card. Caution In this grammar pattern, られる will never appear in the past-tense form. 先生(せんせい)に教(おし)えられたままに漢字(かんじ)を書(か)いた。 I wrote kanji characters as my teacher taught me. (Unnatural Japanese)

example.japanese: 先生(せんせい)に教(おし)えられるままに、生徒(せいと)はその発音(はつおん)を繰(く)り返(かえ)した。
example.english: The students repeated the pronunciation as they were taught by the teacher.

example.japanese: 聞(き)かれるままに、彼女(かのじょ)の住(す)んでいる場所(ばしょ)を教(おし)えた。
example.english: As I was asked, I told him where she lives.

example.japanese: 店員(てんいん)さんにすすめられるまま、この洋服(ようふく)を買(か)ってしまった。でも、あまり自分(じぶん)には似合(にあ)わないと思(おも)う。
example.english: I bought these clothes as advised by the shop clerk. But I don’t think that they suit me very well.

example.japanese: 強盗(ごうとう)に要求(ようきゅう)されるまま、金(かね)をわたした。
example.english: I handed over the money as demanded by the robber.

example.japanese: ガイドに案内(あんない)されるまま、私(わたし)たちはパリ市内(しない)を観光(かんこう)した。
example.english: We explored the city of Paris as guided by the guide.

synonym.explanation: Was done to ~ by ~, Done without consent, Done to one's dismay
as is, while remaining, left in a state
as, following, as then, according to, in accordance with
along, in accordance with, in line with
in that way, exactly・precisely, just as
so that, in order to, in such a way that

english_grammar.title: に纏(まつ)わる
english_grammar.explanation: surrounding, related/relating to, associated with, connected to
english_grammar.structure: Noun (A) + にまつわる + Noun (B)
english_grammar.about: Making use of the う-Verb まつわる 'to coil around', にまつわる is a formal grammar pattern that follows nouns and expresses that something broadly discusses the topic of (A). It is usually translated as 'surrounding (A)', 'associated with (A)', or 'connected to (A)'. In most cases, まつわる will be both preceded and followed by a noun, with the preceding noun being the topic, and the following noun being the thing that is dealing with that topic. 僕(ぼく)が小(ちい)さい頃(ころ)は、おじいちゃんにこの地域(ちいき)にまつわる怖(こわ)い話(はなし)をよくしてもらってた。 When I was little, my grandfather used to tell me scary stories connected to this area. この監督(かんとく)の映画(えいが)は戦争(せんそう)にまつわる映画(えいが)が多(おお)い。 Many of this director's films are related to war. 彼(かれ)はこの神社(じんじゃ)にまつわる神話(しんわ)には詳(くわ)しい。 He is familiar with the myths connected to this shrine. まつわる itself is primarily seen when (B) is some sort of information or explanation related to (A). Because of this, 話(はなし) 'tale', 物語(ものがたり) 'story', 伝説(でんせつ) 'legend', 神話(しんわ) 'myth', and similar words will often appear as (B). Fun Fact纏(まつ)わる shares the same kanji as 纏(まと)まる, another common verb that means 'to come together', or 'to consolidate'. Although the kanji itself is rarely used outside of books, it may help to remember the nuance being conveyed in まつわる of 'coming together'. This 'coming together around (A)', or simply 'surrounding (A)' translates the feeling of the structure quite accurately.

example.japanese: この物語(ものがたり)はとある魔術(まじゅつ)の禁書(きんしょ)目録(もくろく)にまつわるものである。
example.english: This is a story surrounding a certain magical index.

example.japanese: この神社(じんじゃ)にまつわる伝説(でんせつ)や神話(しんわ)は数(かぞ)えきれない。
example.english: There are more legends connected to this shrine than one can count.

example.japanese: ブログ記事(きじ)：「猫(ねこ)にまつわる英語(えいご)の慣用表現(かんようひょうげん)６選(せん)」
example.english: Blog post title: "A selection of 6 English idioms related to cats."

example.japanese: 楊(よう)貴妃(きひ)には美貌(びぼう)にまつわる漢詩(かんし)が数多(かずおお)く残(のこ)されている。
example.english: There is quite a bit of remaining poetry relating to Yang Guifei’s beauty.

example.japanese: アクア女神(めがみ)にまつわる神話(しんわ)はこの町(まち)に代々(だいだい)伝(つた)えられている。
example.english: A myth surrounding the goddess Aqua has been passed down in this town for generations.

english_grammar.title: たるに
english_grammar.explanation: to be (in a position of), as a, for
english_grammar.structure: Noun + たるに Noun + たる + Noun
english_grammar.about: たるに is a structure that indicates something that 'is (A)' in the same way as である, and will often be translated as '(B) in the position of (A)', or '(B) as an (A)'. たるに itself as a combination of たる, which is the attributive form of classical auxiliary verb たり, and the case marking particle に. たるに will appear after a noun marking some sort of position, with a statement about that position following after. It may be used either positively or negatively. あの選手(せんしゅ)に負(ま)けるぐらいなら、うちのチームの一員(いちいん)たるにふさわしくない。 If you aren't good enough to defeat that opponent, you are not suitable to be (in the position) a member of our team. あなたは従業員(じゅうぎょういん)たるに相応(ふさわ)しい対応(たいおう)ができたと思(おも)っているのかい？ Do you think that you were able to deal with that as an employee? たるに is not as common as たるもの, which is a combination of たる and the noun 者(もの), used to identify people. In these cases, (A) たる者(もの) will specifically mean 'a person in the position of (A)', and generally describes what is appropriate of that position. This use may be translated as 'for' or 'as'. 先生(せんせい)たる者(もの)、生徒(せいと)の将来(しょうらい)を優先(ゆうせん)するべきだ。 As teachers, we should put the future of our students first. 警察(けいさつ)たる者(もの)、国民(こくみん)の平和(へいわ)を守(まも)るべきだ。 As police, you should protect the peace of the people. Although this structure means 'to be' in the same way as である, the emphasis is far more on qualifications or expectations related to that position. Due to this, たる will not be used when simply stating that '(B) is (A)'. Caution Although たる does relate to the suitability of something being in a specific position, be careful not to confuse it with the う-Verb 足(た)る 'to be sufficient', or 'to be worthy'. Fun Factたり itself is a contraction of the case marking particle と and あり 'to be'. This can be compared to なり, which is a contraction of に and あり.

example.japanese: なんと言(い)っても教師(きょうし)たる者(もの)は、情熱(じょうねつ)が必要(ひつよう)なのである。
example.english: Above all, to be (in the position of) a teacher, a person must be passionate.

example.japanese: 社員(しゃいん)が叱責(しっせき)を受(う)ける：「そんな簡単(かんたん)な問題(もんだい)さえ解決(かいけつ)出来(でき)ないようならうちの社員(しゃいん)たるに相応(ふさわ)しくない人(ひと)ですよ。 」
example.english: An employee receiving a reprimand: "If you cannot even solve that simple problem, then you are not suitable to be (in the position of) an employee at our company."

example.japanese: 学生(がくせい)たる者(もの)は、アルバイトに感(かま)けすぎて学業(がくぎょう)を疎(おろそ)かにしてはならない。
example.english: A (person that is in the position of a) student must not get too preoccupied with a part-time job and neglect their studies.

example.japanese: 「需要(じゅよう)と供給(きょうきゅう)の関係(かんけい)を理解(りかい)できない彼(かれ)には総理大臣(そうりだいじん)たる資格(しかく)がない。」
example.english: He who cannot comprehend the relationship between supply and demand is not qualified to be (in the position of) a prime minister.

example.japanese: 職人(しょくにん)たるもの、 最新(さいしん)の専門分野(せんもんぶんや)の発達(はったつ)についていかなければならない。
example.english: A (person that is in the position of a) professional must follow the latest developments in their field.

synonym.explanation: to be worthy of, to be enough, to be sufficient
as (i.e. in the role of), for
as a, for a, as for
Formal/literary だ, authoritative, copula

english_grammar.title: なら〜で
english_grammar.explanation: if ~ should, before ~ should
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ なら(1) + Verb［る］+ で ［い］Adjective + なら(1) + ［い］Adjective + で ［な］Adjective + なら + ［な］Adjective + で Noun + なら + Noun + で (1) のなら
english_grammar.about: なら〜で is a structure which appears in situations where the same word will repeat twice, followed by some sort of opinion in regard to it. It can be translated as 'if (A), you should (B)', or 'before (A), you should (B)'. In many cases it will be used to exhibit the speaker's dissatisfaction about something. なら〜で may follow verbs in their standard forms, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives or nouns. Both なら and で are functioning as conjunction particles in this grammar pattern. 仕事(しごと)するならするでちゃんとしろ！ If you are going to work, you should do it properly. 欲(ほ)しいなら欲(ほ)しいで始(はじ)めっから言(い)ってくれればよかったのに！ If you wanted it, you should have told me so! 嫌(いや)なら嫌(いや)でやめればいい。嫌々(いやいや)やっていても誰(だれ)のためにもならないでしょ。 If you don't like it, you should quit. Continuing something you don't want to do does not benefit anyone. 休(やす)むなら休(やす)むでちゃんと休(やす)んでください。仕事(しごと)のことはわたしたちに任(まか)せてもらって全然(ぜんぜん)いいんで。 If you are going to take a break, please take a break. You can leave work to us, so no need to worry about that. Caution This nuance is different to ば～で, なら〜で, and たら～たで, which are used when conveying that something either is or is not an issue in relation to (A). With this pattern, なら〜で will only appear following な-Adjectives.

example.japanese: 上司(じょうし)：「塗(ぬ)るなら塗(ぬ)るでもっと丁寧(ていねい)に仕上(しあ)げなさい。」
example.english: Boss: "If you are going to paint then (you should) be more careful."

example.japanese: 夜(よる)１１時(じ)、子供(こども)：「あした、学校(がっこう)で水彩絵(すいさいえ)の具(ぐ)が要(い)る。｣母(はは)：「必要(ひつよう)なら必要(ひつよう)で早(はや)く言(い)っとくべきだったでしょ。もうお店(みせ)が閉(し)まっちゃったよ。」
example.english: 11 p.m., child: "I need watercolors for school tomorrow."Mother: "If you needed it, you should have told me sooner. The shops are already closed."

example.japanese: 娘(むすめ)：「もう空港(くうこう)で1時間(じかん)も待(ま)ってるよ。」母(はは)：「もう待(ま)っているなら待(ま)っているでもっと早(はや)くケータイを鳴(な)らしてくれたらよかったのに...」
example.english: Daughter: "I have already waited at the airport for an hour!"Mother: "If you were already there (waiting), then you should have called me sooner…"

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)：「実(じつ)はお腹(なか)が痛(いた)いの...」彼氏(かれし)：「お腹(なか)が痛(いた)いなら痛(いた)いで、ベッドで寝(ね)た方(ほう)がいいよ。あとは俺(おれ)に任(まか)せてね。」
example.english: Girlfriend: "To be honest, my stomach hurts..."Boyfriend: "If your stomach hurts then you had better lie in bed. Leave the rest to me, ok?"

example.japanese: イライラした妻(つま)、ダラダラ食(た)べる夫(おっと)に：「食(た)べるなら食(た)べるで、きちんと食(た)べなさい。」
example.english: Irritated wife to her husband who is sluggishly eating: "If you are going to eat, (you should) do it properly!"

english_grammar.title: をものともせず
english_grammar.explanation: making nothing of, ignoring, in defiance of, regardless of, disregarding
english_grammar.structure: Verb + の + を ものともせず（に） ［い］Adjective + の + を ものともせず（に） ［な］Adjective + な + の + を ものともせず（に） Noun + を ものともせず（に）
english_grammar.about: をものともせず is a combination of the adverbial particle を, the noun 物(もの) 'thing', the particle とも 'even as', and the negative form of する paired with classical auxiliary verb ず, せず. The common translations of 'to make nothing of (A)', or 'in defiance of (A)' are quite close to the more literal translation of 'without making (A) a thing'. As を must follow a noun, this expression may only be used after nouns, or nominated phrases. 谷口(たにぐち)選手(せんしゅ)は足(あし)が震(ふる)えているのをものともせず、レースを完走(かんそう)した。 Taniguchi completed the race, regardless of his shaky legs. 彼(かれ)らは外(そと)が暑(あつ)いのをものともせず、一日中(いちにちじゅう)街頭(がいとう)募金活動(ぼきんかつどう)をした。 Regardless of it being hot outside, they spent all day on the streets fundraising. 彼女(かのじょ)は危険(きけん)なのをものともせずに、子供(こども)たちを助(たす)けに行(い)った。 She went to help the children, ignoring the danger. 彼(かれ)は手首(てくび)の怪我(けが)をものともせずに試合(しあい)で優勝(ゆうしょう)した。 He won the match despite his wrist injury. をものともせず will often follow negative words which are being praised as something that a person was not affected by 'did not make a think of' in their response to it. Caution をものともせず will not be used when talking about one's own actions. 私(わたし)は嵐(あらし)をものともせず海(うみ)にドライブに行(い)った。 Ignoring the storm, I went for a drive to the beach. (Unnatural Japanese)

example.japanese: 勇敢(ゆうかん)なボランティアたちは零下(れいか)30度(ど)の気温(きおん)をものともせず、行方不明(ゆくえふめい)の子犬(こいぬ)を探(さが)し続(つづ)けた。
example.english: In defiance of the -30°C temperatures, the brave volunteers continued searching for the lost puppy.

example.japanese: 厳(きび)しい経済状況(けいざいじょうきょう)をものともせず、アンブレラ社(しゃ)の株(かぶ)は急騰(きゅうとう)した。
example.english: Regardless of the tough economic situation, Umbrella Corporation stocks shot up.

example.japanese: 清瀬(きよせ)灰二(はいじ)選手(せんしゅ)は肺(はい)がはげしくあえぐのをものともせずに、最後(さいご)まで頑張(がんば)って勝利(しょうり)した。
example.english: Haiji Kiyose, ignoring his lungs desperately gasping for air, pressed on and managed to be victorious.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)は政敵(せいてき)からの揶揄(やゆ)をものともせず選挙(せんきょ)を戦(たたか)い抜(ぬ)き、大統領(だいとうりょう)の座(ざ)を勝(か)ち取(と)った。
example.english: Disregarding the mockery from her political opponents, she fought to the bitter end and won the presidential seat.

example.japanese: 上司(じょうし)の反対(はんたい)をものともせず提案(ていあん)を押(お)し通(とお)した。
example.english: Making nothing of the objection of their superiors, they insisted on the proposal.

english_grammar.title: には当(あ)たらない
english_grammar.explanation: no need to, cannot, not worth it to, not suitable
english_grammar.structure: Verb + には(1) + あたらない (1)に
english_grammar.attention: With する-Verbs, する can be omitted
english_grammar.about: には当(あ)たらない is a somewhat formal pattern used in Japanese for indicating that something is 'not worth (A)', or that there is 'no need to (A)'. This is a combination of the case marking particle に, the adverbial particle は, and the negative form of the う-Verb 当(あ)たる 'to strike', or 'to be on the mark', 当(あ)たらない. Due to this, the literal meaning can be thought of as 'it's not on the mark to (A)'. には当(あ)たらない will appear directly after verbs in their dictionary form, or する verbs either with or without the する. 彼(かれ)がまた彼女(かのじょ)に振(ふ)られたの。まあ、あいつは自分(じぶん)のことしか考(かんが)えていないから驚(おどろ)くには当(あ)たらない。 He was dumped by his girlfriend again? Well, that's not surprising because that guy only ever thinks of himself. 人(ひと)として当(わた)たり前(まえ)のことをやったまでです、感謝(かんしゃ)するには当(あ)たらないですよ。 I just did what any normal person would do, so no need to thank me. あの人(ひと)がやったことは人間(ひんげん)としては最低(さいてい)だけど犯罪(はんざい)には当(あ)たらないから何(なに)もできない。 What that person did was despicable, but not suitable to be a crime, so we cannot do anything about it. Additionally, the は may occasionally be omitted, without any change in meaning. あのバンドが新(あたら)しくリリースした曲(きょく)は歌詞(かし)もメロディーも微妙(びみょう)だから聴(き)くに当(あ)たらないらしい。 They say that the newly released song by that band is not worth listening to because the lyrics and melodies are too subtle. Rather than implying that something is 'way off', には当(あ)たらない most often simply highlights that a particular situation is not to the extent where (A) would be appropriate. (A) itself is regularly a verb that relates to reactions or feelings. Some examples include 驚(おどろ)く 'to be surprised', 非難(ひなん) 'to reproach', 称賛(しょうさん) 'to admire', 感心(かんしん) 'to be impressed', 喜(よろこ)ぶ 'to rejoice', and other similar words.

example.japanese: カグラ：「ギンちゃんは昨日(きのう)、犬(いぬ)に噛(か)まれたって。かわいそうね。」シンパ千：「同情(どうじょう)にはあたらない。彼(かれ)はいつも犬(いぬ)を挑発(ちょうはつ)しているから。」
example.english: Kagura: “Gin-chan was bitten by a dog yesterday. Poor guy…”Shinpachi: “No need to take pity on him. He always provokes dogs.”

example.japanese: 「珍(めずら)しいことではありません。称賛(しょうさん)には当(あ)たりません。」
example.english: “It is not uncommon. No need for praise.”

example.japanese: 母(はは)は息子(むすこ)に、母(はは)の友達(ともだち)の息子(むすこ)について話(はな)します：「坂本(さかもと)ちゃん、試験(しけん)にトップで合格(ごうかく)したそうよ。」息子(むすこ)：「長年(ながねん)英語(えいご)を勉強(べんきょう)した彼(かれ)が合格(ごうかく)することは当然(とうぜん)だよ。びっくりするにはあたらないよ。」
example.english: Mother speaking to son about her friend’s son: “I heard that Sakamoto passed the exam at the top of his class.”Son: “It’s only natural for someone who has studied English for many years. No need to be so surprised.”

example.japanese: 社員(しゃいん)１：「田中(たなか)さんは勤務(きんむ)態度(たいど)悪(わる)いね。」社員(しゃいん)２：「でも彼(かれ)はいつも彼(かれ)なりに努力(どりょく)をしているのだから、ちょっとだらしないとしても、非難(ひなん)するには当(あ)たらない。」
example.english: Company employee1: “Mr. Tanaka has a poor working attitude, doesn’t he?”Company employee2: “But he is always doing his best, so even if he is a bit undisciplined, you don’t have to criticize him.”

example.japanese: 「結核(けっかく)は予防接種(よぼうせっしゅ)を受(う)けた健康(けんこう)な人(ひと)なら、心配(しんぱい)するにはあたらない。」
example.english: “Tuberculosis is not something you need to worry about if the person in question is vaccinated and healthy.”

english_grammar.title: ものと思(おも)う
english_grammar.explanation: think that, believe that, expect that, have confidence that, absolutely
english_grammar.structure: Verb + ものと思う ［い］Adjective + ものと思う ［な］Adjective + な + ものと思う Noun + な + ものと思う
english_grammar.about: 物(もの)と思(おも)う is made up of the noun 物(もの) 'thing', the case marking particle と, and the う-Verb 思(おも)う 'to think'. Regular translations include 'to believe that (A)', or 'to have confidence that (A)'. In a broader sense, this grammar pattern is just making use of one of the meanings of 物(もの) as being something abstract that the speaker can reliably determine has all of the qualities of something concrete. As もの is a noun, this pattern may follow any word in its attributive form. あの人(ひと)はなんでもできると自信(じしん)ありげに言(い)っていたんで、仕事(しごと)ができるものと思(おも)っていたが全然(ぜんぜん)だった。 He said confidently that he could do anything, so I expected him to be capable of doing the job, but he was not at all. 夫(おっと)の部屋(へや)からものすごいキーボードの音(おと)が聞(き)こえたから、忙(いそが)しいものと思(おも)っていたがただゲームをしていただけだ。 I heard my husband typing on his keyboard, so I was confident that he was busy, but he was just gaming. 結婚(けっこん)は幸(しあわ)せなものと思(おも)う人(ひと)は多(おお)いだろう。 Many people believe that marriage is a happy thing. 日本(にほん)で最(もっと)も寒(さむ)い月(つき)は12月(がつ)であるものと思(おも)っている人(ひと)が多(おお)いが、実(じつ)は2月(がつ)だ。 Many people think that the coldest month in Japan is December, but actually it is February. When 思(おも)う appears in the past tense, the most common translation is 'as I had believed was true of (A)', or 'I was under the impression that (A)'. 外国人(がいこくじん)観光客(かんこうきゃく)は日本語(にほんご)が話(はな)せないものと思(おも)っていたが、実際(じっさい)そうでもなかった。 I was under the impression that foreign tourists could not speak Japanese, but this was not the case. Although this grammar construction is slightly formal, it may occasionally be heard in daily speech.

example.japanese: よしの：「ウサギは卵(たまご)を産(う)まないわ...」しどう：「でも、実際(じっさい)には多(おお)くの人(ひと)がそんな風(ふう)に思(おも)うもんと思(おも)うよ。」
example.english: Yoshino: “Bunnies do not lay eggs…”Shidou: “But I think that a lot of people think that they do.”

example.japanese: 社員(しゃいん)は上司(じょうし)に話(はな)す：「宅配便(たくはいびん)が今日(きょう)、約束通(やくそくどお)りに来(く)るものと思(おも)っていますが、万(まん)が一(いち)電話(でんわ)をかけます。」
example.english: Employee talks to the boss: “I think that the courier will come today as promised, but I will call him just in case.”

example.japanese: セールスマンはクライアントに：「この商品(しょうひん)の品質(ひんしつ)でご満足(まんぞく)いただけるものと思(おも)います。」
example.english: Salesman to a client: “I am confident that you will be satisfied with the quality of the product.”

example.japanese: 会社(かいしゃ)の社長(しゃちょう)の新年(しんねん)の演説(えんぜつ)：「新(あたら)しい年(とし)、２０XX年(ねん)は、自動(じどう)で運転(うんてん)できる車(くるま)が大(おお)きく発展(はってん)する年(とし)になるものと思(おも)います。」
example.english: A company president's new year speech: “I believe that the new year, 20XX, will become a year in which self-driving cars will be vastly developed.”

example.japanese: 財務大臣(ざいむだいじん)：「この問題(もんだい)について、政府(せいふ)と産業界(さんぎょうかい)との連携(れんけい)はやがて成果(せいか)に結(むす)びつくものと思(おも)います。」
example.english: Minister of Finance: “About this matter, I expect that the cooperation of the government and the industry will eventually bear fruit.”

synonym.explanation: was under the impression that, (always) the thought used to think

english_grammar.title: を踏(ふ)まえて
english_grammar.explanation: based on, considering, keeping in mind, taking into account, therefore
english_grammar.structure: Noun + を踏まえ（て）(1) Noun (A) + を踏まえた(2) + Noun (B) (1) を踏まえた上で (2) を踏まえての
english_grammar.attention: When modifying a noun, を踏まえた is more common
english_grammar.about: 踏(ふ)まえる is a る-Verb that means 'to tread firmly', but is often used figuratively in regard to taking things into account. Because of this, the combination of the adverbial particle を, and 踏(ふ)まえる in its て-form can frequently be translated as 'considering (A)', or 'keeping (A) in mind'. を踏(ふ)まえて is primarily used in formal situations where (B) is an action being undertaken with (A) as the premise. As this structure begins with を, it will need to follow a noun. お客様(きゃくさま)の意見(いけん)を踏(ふ)まえて、色々(いろいろ)と機能(きのう)を追加(ついか)するつもりです。 We intend to add various features based on customer feedback. 先週(せんしゅう)の反省(はんせい)を踏(ふ)まえて、今週(こんしゅう)は別(べつ)のやり方(かた)でやってみようと思(おも)っています。 Based on my reflections from last week, I am going to try a different approach this week. 前回(ぜんかい)の失敗(しっぱい)を踏(ふ)まえて、今回(こんかい)はもう少(すこ)し気(き)をつけて挑戦(ちょうせん)してみる。 Based on my last failure, I will try to be a little more careful this time. In this grammar pattern, the literal meaning of を踏(ふ)まえて as 'being firmly planted' can be used equally as naturally, so long as its figurative nature is kept in mind. アンケートの結果(けっか)を踏(ふ)まえて、お客様(きゃくさま)に喜(よろこ)んでいただけるアイディアをどんどん提案(ていあん)してください。 Being firmly planted on the results of the survey, please keep throwing in ideas that you would think would please our customers.

example.japanese: 経営陣(けいえいじん)は従業員(じゅうぎょういん)に：「この数(すう)ヶ月(かげつ)でクライアント数(すう)の着実(ちゃくじつ)な増加(ぞうか)が見(み)られます。以上(いじょう)のことを踏(ふ)まえて営業時間(えいぎょうじかん)の延長(えんちょう)を決定(けってい)いたしました。」
example.english: Management to employees: “In the last few months, a steady increase of the client base can be observed. Taking this into account, we have decided to extend our hours of operation.”

example.japanese: 経営陣(けいえいじん)との話(はなし)：「去年(きょねん)の反省(はんせい)を踏(ふ)まえて、今年(ことし)は新(あら)たなマーケティング戦略(せんりゃく)を提唱(ていしょう)いただきたいと思(おも)います。」
example.english: A discussion with management: “Based on (my) reflection of last year(‘s strategy), I would like to propose a new marketing strategy this year.”

example.japanese: 会社(かいしゃ)のサイト：「国際的(こくさいてき)な基準(きじゅん)を踏(ふ)まえた新製品開発(しんせいひんかいはつ)に懸命(けんめい)に取(と)り組(く)んでいます。
example.english: Website of a company: “We work earnestly to develop our products with international standards in mind.

example.japanese: 経営陣(けいえいじん)との話(はなし)：「市場(しじょう)は成長(せいちょう)が鈍化(どんか)し始(はじ)めているという現状(げんじょう)を踏(ふ)まえて、新(あら)たな資金源(しきんげん)を探(さが)す必要(ひつよう)があります。」
example.english: A discussion with management: “Based on the present circumstances, i.e. the market starting to slow down, there is a need to look for new sources of revenue.”

example.japanese: 代弁者(だいべんしゃ)は記者(きしゃ)の質問(しつもん)に答(こた)える：「このイベント、確(たし)かにいろいろ問題点(もんだいてん)もあるとは思(おも)いますが、それを踏(ふ)まえてうちの会社(かいしゃ)は計画(けいかく)どおり進展(しんてん)しようと考(かんが)えています。」
example.english: A spokesman answers a reporter’s question: “Speaking of the event, surely there are all sorts of problems, however keeping these in mind we plan to proceed as planned.”

synonym.explanation: based on, in accordance with

english_grammar.title: 故(ゆえ)に
english_grammar.explanation: because, the reason is, due to, therefore, so
english_grammar.structure: Noun + （の(1)) + ゆえ + （に） Noun + （の(1)) + ゆえ + の + Noun ［な］Adjective + （な(1)）+ ゆえ + （に） ［な］Adjective + （な(1)）+ ゆえ + の + Noun ［い］Adjective + （が）+ ゆえ + （に） ［い］Adjective + （が）+ ゆえ + の + Noun Verb + （が）+ ゆえ + （に） Verb + （が）+ ゆえ + の + Noun Phrase (A)。（その(2)）+ ゆえ + に+Phrase (B) (1) である、が、であるが (2) それ、それが
english_grammar.about: When the noun 故(ゆえ) 'consequence' is paired with the case marking particle に, it will be used in formal situations to highlight reasons. This may be interpreted as 'because of (A)', 'due to (A)', or 'the reason is (A)'. However, 'consequently to (A)', or 'as a consequence of (A)' are also completely acceptable translations that may help to differentiate ゆえに from less formal structures. As ゆえ itself is a noun, regular grammar rules such as being preceded by の will need to be followed if directly following another noun. In other cases, ゆえに will simply attach to the standard form of words. お巡(まわ)りさんたちが夜(よる)も眠(ねむ)らずにパトロールしているが故(ゆえ)に、夜(よる)でも安心(あんしん)して散歩(さんぽ)できる。 Due to the police officers patrolling the area at night without sleep, it makes it safe for us to go on walks at night. 私(わたし)のおじいちゃんは目(め)が悪(わるい)いが故(ゆえ)に、運転免許証(うんてんめんきょしょう)を返納(へんのう)した。 My grandpa had to give up his driver's license because of his bad eyesight. 彼(かれ)の接客(せっきゃく)は丁寧(ていねい)な故(ゆえ)に、お客(きゃく)さんからの評判(ひょうばん)がいい。 His customer service is courteous and therefore well received by his customers. 日本(にほん)ではまだ女性(じょせい)のゆえに差別(さべつ)されることがある。 In Japan, women are still discriminated against because of their gender. ゆえに may also appear at the beginning of new sentences. When this happens, it expresses 'as a result of (A)', where (A) is the entire previous sentence. あの国(くに)では高齢化(こうれいか)が深刻(しんこく)な問題(もんだい)になってきている。ゆえに、海外(かいがい)から若者(わかもの)を呼(よ)び込(こ)み始(はじ)めた。 Aging is becoming a serious problem in that country. Due to that, they have started to attract young people from abroad. The に will need to be replaced with の when ゆえ is being connected to another noun and therefore modifying it. 若(わか)さゆえの過(あやま)ちであったとしても必(かなら)ず許(ゆる)さなければならないということでもない。 Just because something was done due to a young age, doesn't mean that it should be forgiven. Caution Just like 'as a consequence of' in English, ゆえに tends to be used far more frequently in regard to negative reasons than positive ones.

example.japanese: 小説(しょうせつ)：「ベンジャミンの若(わか)さゆえの自信過剰(じしんかじょう)も無知(むち)もミセス・ロビンソンの目(め)からすれば、可愛(かわい)らしい。」
example.english: Novel: “From the perspective of Mrs. Robinson, Benjamin’s overconfidence and naivety, due to his youthfulness, is charming.”

example.japanese: A⇒B、B⇒C ゆえにA⇒C (Aが真(しん)ならばBも真(しん)、Bが真(しん)ならばCも真(しん)。ゆえにAが真(しん)ならばCも真(しん)である）
example.english: A⇒B、B⇒C therefore A⇒C (If A, then B, if B then C. Therefore if A, then C)

example.japanese: ラテン語(ご)のフレーズ：「不合理(ふごうり)ゆえにわれ信(しん)ず 」
example.english: Latin phrase: “I believe just because it is absurd.”

example.japanese: ファンタジー小説(しょうせつ)：「 ドワーフ族(ぞく)が滅(ほろ)んだのは富(とみ)に対(たい)する飽(あ)くなき欲望(よくぼう)がゆえであった。」
example.english: Fantasy novel: “The reason for the dwarves’ undoing was their untiring desire for wealth.”

example.japanese: 手紙(てがみ)：「季節(きせつ)の変(か)わり目(め)ゆえ、くれぐれもご自愛(じあい)くださいませ。」
example.english: Letter: “Since the seasons are changing, please take good care of yourself.”

english_grammar.title: と言(い)う
english_grammar.explanation: every single, each and every, emphasis, everything that could be called
english_grammar.structure: Noun (A) + という + Noun (A)
english_grammar.about: One of the uses of the extremely common という structure in Japanese is the pairing of identical nouns in order to convey the meaning of 'every single (A)'. In many cases, this expression will simply be used for emphasis, but the literal meaning is 'every (B) that could be called an (A)'. という will be used between the same noun repeating itself. 空(あ)き家(や)に入(はい)ったら床(ゆか)という床(ゆか)が全(すべ)てゴミに覆(おお)われていたのでびっくりした。 When I entered the vacant house, I was surprised because every single floor was covered in garbage. この街(まち)の電柱(でんちゅう)という電柱(でんちゅう)に広告(こうこく)の張(は)り紙(がみ)が沢山(たくさん)貼(は)られてあったので、街(まち)の人(ひと)たちが張(は)り紙(がみ)を全(すべ)て撤去(てっきょ)した。 There were so many advertising posters on every single telephone pole in this city that the people of the city removed all the posters. 世界(せかい)各国(かっこく)の偉(えら)い人(ひと)たちが来(く)るということで、サミットの近(ちか)くの道(みち)という道(みち)は閉鎖(へいさ)されている。 Every single road near the summit was closed due to the fact that important people from all over the world are coming. Caution When this structure is seen with abstract expressions like 今日(きょう) 'today', it will generally mean '(A) of all (A)'s'. This just implies that 'of anything that can be called (A), this particular one has something special about it'. What that special thing is will usually follow immediately after in the sentence. 今日(きょう)という今日(きょう)は絶対(ぜったい)あいつを許(ゆる)さない！ I will not forgive him today of all days! 今度(こんど)という今度(こんど)は優勝(ゆうしょう)してみせる！ I will win THIS TIME!

example.japanese: 僕(ぼく)がセナの部屋(へや)に入(はい)ると、壁(かべ)という壁(かべ)にヨゾラの写真(しゃしん)があるのを見(み)てショックを受(う)けた。
example.english: When I went into Sena's room, I was shocked to see that every single wall was decorated with photos of Yozora.

example.japanese: 政治家(せいじか)という政治家(せいじか)はみんな口(くち)ばっかりだ。
example.english: Every single politician is nothing but talk.

example.japanese: 山々(やまやま)に生(は)えた木(き)という木(き)は地(じ)すべりのため根(ね)こそぎ倒(たお)れていた。
example.english: Every single tree that was growing on the mountain collapsed due to the landslide.

example.japanese: 「今日(きょう)という今日(きょう)は許(ゆる)さん。」
example.english: “I absolutely will not allow it TODAY.”

example.japanese: 名古屋(なごや)に生(う)まれて名古屋(なごや)で育(そだ)った。だから、町中(まちなか)の道(みち)という道(みち)、家(いえ)という家(いえ)を、すっかり知(し)っている。
example.english: (They were) born and raised in Nagoya. Therefore, (they) know every single street and each and every house in the city.

english_grammar.title: に止(とど)まらず
english_grammar.explanation: not limited to, not only...but also, not stopping at
english_grammar.structure: Verb + にとどまらず Noun + （である）+ にとどまらず ［な］Adjective + である + にとどまらず
english_grammar.about: にとどまらず is a formal structure that pairs the case marking particle に, the う-Verb 止(とど)まる 'to remain', or 'to be limited to', and the classical auxiliary verb ず 'not'. にとどまらず is generally translated as 'not limited to (A)', or 'not stopping at (A)', and follows words indicating an extent, before going on to explain how something spreads beyond (A). にとどまらず will be seen following either nouns, or verbs in their dictionary form. 彼(かれ)は会社(かいしゃ)の経費(けいひ)を管理(かんり)するにとどまらず、社員(しゃいん)の給料(きゅうりょう)も管理(かんり)している。 He not only manages the company's expenses, but also the salaries of its employees. 先生(せんせい)は授業(じゅぎょう)を行(おこな)うにとどまらず、部活(ぶかつ)の指導(しどう)などもしなくてはならない。 Teachers must not only teach classes, but also supervise club activities. 寿司(すし)は日本(にほん)にとどまらず、世界中(せかいじゅう)で人気(にんき)がある。 Sushi is popular not only in Japan but all over the world. この漫画(まんが)は子供(こども)にとどまらず、大人(おとな)の間(あいだ)でも話題(わだい)になっている。 This manga is not limited to children, but has become a topic of conversation among adults as well.
