This expression may be used to highlight either positive or negative effects. Caution にとどまらず will only be used when (B) is something that is expanding outward from the pre-existing boundaries of (A). This means that (B) will not be something that isn't directly tied to (A) somehow. このコンサートのチケットにとどまらず、限定(げんてい)グッズなども高(たか)かった。 Not only were tickets to this concert expensive, but also limited edition merchandise. (Unnatural Japanese)

example.japanese: 間(はざま)博士(はかせ)の研究分野(けんきゅうぶんや)は遺伝学(いでんがく)にとどまらず、微生物学(びせいぶつがく)にまで及(およ)ぶ。
example.english: Doctor Hazama's field of research is not limited to genetics, but it also extends to microbiology.

example.japanese: 会社(かいしゃ)ウェブサイト：「当社(とうしゃ)は製品(せいひん)を販売(はんばい)するにとどまらず、その商品(しょうひん)の設計(せっけい)もいたします。」
example.english: Company website: "Our company is not only selling products but also designing them."

example.japanese: 共感(きょうかん)は人間(にんげん)だけにとどまらず、動物(どうぶつ)にも見(み)られるものである。
example.english: Compassion is not only limited to humans but is something that can also be observed in animals.

example.japanese: ボックスステーション７日本国内(にほんこくない)にとどまらず、海外(かいがい)でも普及(ふきゅう)しています。
example.english: Boxstation7 is not only popular in Japan, but also abroad.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)が運営(うんえい)しているフィットネスの利用者(りようしゃ)は若(わか)い男女(だんじょ)にとどまらず、高齢者(こうれいしゃ)や障害者(しょうがいしゃ)にまで及(およ)びます。
example.english: Among my fitness operation’s consumers, not limited to young men and women, they also extend to the elderly and handicapped.

english_grammar.title: と思(おも)いきや
english_grammar.explanation: thought...but, when...thought that...but, despite having thought...
english_grammar.structure: Verb + （か）+ と思いきや + Phrase［た］ ［い］Adjective + （か）+ と思いきや + Phrase［た］ ［な］Adjective + (か(1)）+ と思いきや + Phrase［た］ Noun + (か(1)）+ と思いきや + Phrase［た］ (1)（だ）
english_grammar.about: と思(おも)いきや is an expression used in Japanese for indicating that something is not as one had thought, and will often be translated as 'despite having thought (A), (B)', or 'when I thought that (A), it was actually (B)'. と思(おも)いきや is a combination of the case marking particle と, the conjunctive form of the う-Verb 思(おも)う, 思(おも)い, the classical auxiliary verb き, which indicates past tense, and the classical binding (adverbial) particle や, which marks actual or rhetorical questions in the same way as か. Due to this, a more literal translation is 'I thought it had (A), but I guess (B)'. Despite the origin of the phrase, in modern Japanese と思(おも)いきや is just thought of as an emphatic structure that highlights the speaker's surprise in relation to something not being as they had expected. と思(おも)いきや may follow any word in its standard form. 今日(きょう)も残業(ざんぎょう)するかと思(おも)いきや、4時(じ)になったと同時(どうじ)に上司(じょうし)が「みんな、毎日(まいにち)お疲(つか)れさん、今日(きょう)は早(はや)めに帰(かえ)って、ゆっくりしてくれ」と言(い)ってくれたから定時(ていじ)前(まえ)に帰(かえ)ることができた。 I thought I would have to work overtime again today, but as soon as it hit 4:00, my boss said, 'Hey guys, thanks for working hard every day, go home early today and relax,' so I was able to leave before the regular time. 木村(きむら)くんのピアノの先生(せんせい)は優(やさ)しいと思(おも)いきや、見学(けんがく)してみたらめちゃくちゃ怖(こわ)くて厳(きび)しいということが分(わ)かった。 I thought that Kimura-kun's piano teacher was nice, but when I went to observe the class, I found out that she is very strict and scary. 家(いえ)を建(た)てるのは簡単(かんたん)かと思(おも)いきや、建(た)てる前(まえ)に色々(いろいろ)土地(とち)の調査(ちょうさ)など測量(そくりょう)などをしないといけなかったから思(おも)っていたより面倒(めんどう)だった。 I thought building a house would be easy, but it was more trouble than I expected because I had to do things such as survey and inspect the land before building. 彼女(かのじょ)たちは姉妹(しまい)だと思(おも)いきや、親子(おやこ)だった。 I thought that they were sisters, but they were mother and daughter. The particle か may appear before と思(おも)いきや, but this just further emphasizes the same rhetorical question, as や itself has the same role. Caution A past tense phrase will always appear in (B), as it is considered to be the actual situation which has come about, or has been realized by the speaker. 彼(かれ)は日本(にほん)に10年(ねん)も住(す)んでいるもんだから日本語(にほんご)をペラペラに話(はな)せると思(おも)いきや、少(すこ)しも話(はな)せない。 He had lived in Japan for 10 years, so I thought that he could speak Japanese fluently, but he can't speak a word of it. (Unnatural Japanese)

example.japanese: 娘(むすめ)は部屋(へや)がとても静(しず)かだからきっと寝(ね)ていると思(おも)いきや、意外(いがい)にも勉強(べんきょう)していた。
example.english: I thought that my daughter was sleeping because it was very quiet, but to my surprise she was studying.

example.japanese: いよいよ晴(は)れるだろうと思(おも)いきや、たちまち雨(あめ)が降(ふ)り出(だ)してしまった。
example.english: I thought that the weather would finally clear up, but it suddenly started raining.

example.japanese: うたげさんが小(ちい)さいから同級生(どうきゅうせい)かと思(おも)いきや、驚(おどろ)くことに先生(せんせい)だった。
example.english: Because she was small (like me), I thought Utage-san was (my) classmate, but, to my surprise, she was (my) teacher.

example.japanese: 納豆(なっとう)はまずそうに見(み)えるから、間違(まちが)いなくまずいと思(おも)いきや、実際(じっさい)は、そうではなかった。
example.english: I thought for sure that natto would be gross since it looks unappetizing, but that was not the case.

example.japanese: 「やっぱり、今度(こんど)も失敗(しっぱい)したか...」と思(おも)いきや、見事(みごと)合格(ごうかく)だった。
example.english: Despite having thought, “As expected, I failed again,” I passed with flying colors.

synonym.text: かと思ったら・かと思うと
synonym.explanation: then again, just when I thought, no sooner than

english_grammar.title: どうにも
english_grammar.explanation: cannot, there is no way one can, nothing one can do, cannot possibly not by any means, cannot do no matter how hard one tries, nothing will come out, it is meaningless to
english_grammar.structure: どうにも（こうにも） + (Negative)Verb［できる］ どうにも（こうにも） + Verb［ます］+ ようがない どうにもできない どうにも（こうにも）ならない
english_grammar.about: どうにも is an expression that is often paired with negative structures such as できない 'cannot', ならない 'won't happen', or ようがない 'no way'. It is a combination of the adverb どう 'how', the case marking particle に, and the adverbial particle も, and may be translated as 'even however (A), still not (B)'. The whole structure itself is usually interpreted simply as 'it is meaningless to (A)', 'there's nothing one can do about (A)', or nothing will come of (A)'. どうにも will primarily be seen either at the start or end of sentences, after or before going on to explain a situation which seems impossible due to some specific reason. 今更(いまさら)頑張(がんば)ってもどうにもならないよ。 Even if you try your best now, nothing will come out of it. そんなこと急(きゅう)に言(い)われても、どうにもできないよ。 Nothing could be done, even if you suddenly tell me that. 自分(じぶん)で読(よ)むだけじゃどうにも理解(りかい)できないので、先生(せんせい)に聞(き)くことにした。 I couldn't manage to understand it just by reading it myself, so I decided to ask my teacher. This grammar pattern emphasizes the speaker's feelings of resignation, frustration, or regret in relation to something that is out of their control. Due to this, it often highlights the actions of someone other than the speaker. Occasionally, どうにも is further emphasized by the addition of こうにも. そんなことを言(い)われてもどうにもこうにもなりません。 No matter what you say, nothing will come out of it. 説明(せつめい)してあげたいけど、どうにもこうにも説明(せつめい)できない。 I would love to explain it for you, but there is no way I can explain it.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)は人の言(い)うことを聞(き)かないからアドバイスしたところでどうにもならないよ。
example.english: She doesn't listen to what people say, so even if you give her advice, nothing will come out of it.

example.japanese: どうにもできない事態(じたい)に陥(おちい)ったので手(て)を借(か)りるしかない。
example.english: I got trapped in a situation about which nothing could be done so I have no choice but to ask for help.

example.japanese: 《友達(ともだち)との話(はなし)》「後悔(こうかい)したってもうどうにもなんない。」
example.english: Chat with a friend: "Even if you regret it, nothing can be done now."

example.japanese: 都心(としん)に 向(む)かう電車(でんしゃ)の中(なか)は、人(ひと)でいっぱい。どうにも身動(みうご)きしようがない。」
example.english: "Trains heading downtown are packed with people. There is no way for one to move."

example.japanese: 《友達(ともだち)へのアドバイス》「過去(かこ)のどうにもできないことは気(き)にしないで。過去(かこ)は過去(かこ)、未来(みらい)は未来(みらい)。」
example.english: Advice to a friend: "Don't worry about things of the past about which nothing can be done. The past is the past, the future is the future."

english_grammar.title: ことだし
english_grammar.explanation: (and) so, because, since
english_grammar.structure: Verb + ことだし ［い］Adjective + ことだし ［な］Adjective + な(1) + ことだし Noun + の(1) + ことだし (1) である
english_grammar.about: ことだし is a combination of the noun こと 'thing', the auxiliary verb だ, and the conjunction particle し, used for listing reasons. The whole structure itself often translates simply as 'because (A)', or 'since (A)', but places extra emphasis on there being other reasons besides what the speaker has specified. This structure may appear after any word in its attributive form, or after a noun that has been followed with の. せっかく君(きみ)のお父(とう)さんとお母(かあ)さんが来(く)ることだし、どっかいい焼肉屋(やきにくや)さんにでも行(い)こう。 Since your father and mother are coming all the way (to see us), let's go to a nice yakiniku restaurant. 天気(てんき)もいいことだし、みんなで公園(こうえん)にでも行(い)きましょう。 Since the weather is nice, let's all go to the park together. 彼(かれ)が勤(つと)めている会社(かいしゃ)は有名(ゆうめい)なことだし、給料(きゅうりょう)もいいんだろう。 Since the company he works for is famous, his salary must be good. 彼(かれ)のことだし、また遅(おく)れてくるんじゃないの。 Knowing him, I bet that he will come late as usual. Just like with its standard use in creating lists, し is being used in this grammar point to show that (A) is not exclusive. The way this comes across is that 'while there are other reasons, (A) is good enough to (B)'. (B) is usually some suggestion, invitation, or expression of determination.

example.japanese: 飛行機代(ひこうきだい)も安(やす)いことだし天気(てんき)もいいから沖縄(おきなわ)に行(い)こうよ。
example.english: Since plane tickets are cheap and the weather is nice, let's go to Okinawa.

example.japanese: 割引(わりびき)クーポンもあることだし、明日(あした)映画(えいが)を一緒(いっしょ)に観(み)に行かない？
example.english: I also have discount coupons, so why don't we go watch a movie together tomorrow?

example.japanese: もう夜(よる)も更(ふ)けてくることだし、今日(きょう)のパーティーはこれでお開(ひら)きにしよう！
example.english: It's getting late, so let's call it a night with this!

example.japanese: 彼も十分(じゅうぶん)反省(はんせい)していることだし、今回(こんかい)はもうこの辺(へん)で許(ゆる)してあげたら？
example.english: I'm sure he's also sufficiently remorseful, so why won't you already let him off the hook this time?

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)のことだし、きっと次(つぎ)の試合(しあい)には勝(か)つとわたしは信(しん)じているよ！
example.english: Knowing her, I am convinced that she will surely win the next match.

english_grammar.title: か否(いな)か
english_grammar.explanation: whether or not
english_grammar.structure: Verb + か否か ［い］Adjective + か否か ［な］Adjective + （である）+ か否か Noun + （である）+ か否か
english_grammar.attention: や否や is used to express "as soon as"
english_grammar.about: 否(いな) 'no' is an interjection in Japanese that is primarily paired with the adverbial particle か 'or' when stating 'whether or not (A)'. The literal meaning is just '(A) or no'. This is a very formal expression that will mainly be seen in writing. か否(いな)か may appear after almost any word in their standard forms. この授業(じゅぎょう)を楽(たの)しむか否(いな)かは自分(じぶん)次第(しだい)だ。 Whether you enjoy this class or not is up to you. 怖(こわ)いか否(いな)かは別(べつ)として、この映画(えいが)はとても面白(おもしろ)かった。 Putting aside whether this movie was scary or not, it was really enjoyable. あの人(ひと)が貧乏(びんぼう)であるか否(いな)かは私(わたし)たちには関係(かんけい)のないことです。 Whether that person is poor or not is none of our business. あの人(ひと)がこの子(こ)の父親(ちちおや)か否(いな)か、DNA検査(けんさ)をしなくてはわからない。 We will never know if that man is the father of this child or not without a DNA test. This structure is often paired with words like べき 'ought to', を問(と)わず 'without questioning', にかかわらず 'regerdless of', and will be used to make determinations about the suitability of something based on a specific situation.

example.japanese: 小説(しょうせつ)、語(かた)り手(て)：「スウォン王(おう)は武力(ぶりょく)で反乱(はんらん)を鎮圧(ちんあつ)すべきか否(いな)か、について迷(まよ)っていた。」
example.english: A novel, narrator: "King Su-won was hesitant about whether or not he should put the rebellion down by force."

example.japanese: 記事(きじ)のタイトル：「プロゲーマーは真(しん)のスポーツ選手(せんしゅ)か否(いな)か。eスポーツ業界(ぎょうかい)が直面(ちょくめん)するビザの問題(もんだい)」
example.english: Article title: "Are pro gamers real athletes or not? The visa problem that eSports faces."

example.japanese: サイバーセキュリティ会社(かいしゃ)のサイト：「怪(あや)しいか否(いな)かの判断(はんだん)に迷(まよ)うメールを受(う)け取(と)った場合(ばあい)は、どうぞそれを開(ひら)かずにLain＠cyberland.xyzまでご連絡(れんらく)をお願(ねが)いします。」
example.english: Cybersecurity company website: "In the event that you receive an email in which you are unable to determine whether or not it is suspicious, do not open it and please contact us at Lain@cyberland.xyz."

example.japanese: サイト、クッキーファイルについて：「利用者(りようしゃ)はそのクッキーを受(う)け入(い)れるか否(いな)かを決(き)めることができますし、また、全部(ぜんぶ)のクッキーを削除(さくじょ)することもできます。
example.english: Website, about cookie files: "Users can decide whether or not they accept cookies. Users are also able to delete all accepted cookies anytime."

example.japanese: イベントのサイト「参加資格(さんかしかく)：登録(とうろく)ユーザーであるか否(いな)かを問(と)わず、どなたでもご参加可能(さんかかのう)」
example.english: Event website: "Entry qualifications: Regardless of whether you are a registered user or not, anyone can participate."

synonym.explanation: whether or not, if...or not

english_grammar.title: たら〜で
english_grammar.explanation: even if, if
english_grammar.structure: Verb［たら］(1) + Verb［た］+ で ［い］Adjective［たら］(2) + ［い］Adjective(3) + で ［な］Adjective + なら + ［な］Adjective + で (1) Verb［ば］ (2) ［い］Adjective［ば］ (3) ［い］Adjective［た］
english_grammar.about: たら〜で is an expression that appears with repeating words, and may be used either positively or negatively in order to show that 'if (A), then with (A), (B)'. It is often simply translated as 'even if (A), (B)'. たら〜で may use either the conjunction particle たら or ば when paired with verbs or い-Adjectives, but will use なら when paired with な-Adjectives. ニートになったらなったで大変(たいへん)だと思(おも)うよ。 Even if you become a NEET, I think it would still be tough. 明日(あした)雨(あめ)が降(ふ)れば降(ふ)ったでなんとかすればいい。 If it rains tomorrow, we can do something about it. 大(おお)きい方(ほう)が荷物(にもつ)とかいっぱい積(つ)めるけど、大(おお)きかったら大(おお)きいでデメリットがある。 The bigger the car, the more luggage it can carry, but if the car is big, there are many disadvantages. 力(ちから)がなくてもできる仕事(しごと)は沢山(たくさん)あるから、弱(よわ)ければ弱(よわ)いでいい。 There are plenty of jobs that can be done even if you are weak. 嫌(いや)なら嫌(いや)で、最初(さいしょ)っから言(い)ってくれればよかったのに。 If you didn't want to, you should've let me know beforehand. In たら〜で constructions, it is important to remember that the nuance will change depending on the first half of the sentence. Basically, the most common interpretations are as follows. In the good situation of (A), the problem of (B) will arise. In the problematic situation of (A), (B) can still be done. So in either case, it can be seen that (B) will be something that is contradictory to (A). Caution In this meaning, なら～で will only ever follow な-Adjectives. If you see なら〜で following another type of word, then it will be the meaning used for showing dissatisfaction, or telling people what to do. 好(す)きなら好(す)きで、はっきりと伝(つた)えなくちゃ。 If you like them, you have to tell them clearly that you like them. (This grammar point's meaning) 辞(や)めるなら辞(や)めるでいいけど、後(あと)からやっぱりやめなければよかったとかって言(い)わないでね。 If you want to quit, then go ahead and quit, but don't say later that you wish you hadn't quit after all. (The other なら～で meaning)

example.japanese: 「結婚(けっこん)したい。」「結婚(けっこん)したらしたで大変(たいへん)だよ。」
example.english: "I want to marry…”"Even if you get married, it’s (still) tough."

example.japanese: 「また子供(こども)になりたいな。」「けど、子供(こども)になったらなったで子供(こども)なりの苦労(くろう)があるよ」
example.english: "I want to be a child again…""But, children have problems of their own even if you become (are) one."

example.japanese: 「金(かね)は沢山(たくさん)あったらあったで悩(なや)みも増(ふ)えるものだよ。」「それはそうだけど、でも、なかったらないで困(こま)るでしょ。」
example.english: "Even if you have a lot of money, problems will also multiply.""That might be right, but even if you don’t have any, then it’s (still) troublesome."

example.japanese: 「もし失敗(しっぱい)したら失敗(しっぱい)したで、また最初(さいしょ)からやり直(なお)そうと思(おも)う。」
example.english: "Even if I fail, I will do it again from the beginning."

example.japanese: 「ったく、いつも、彼(かれ)は、雨(あめ)が降(ふ)ったら降(ふ)ったで『外(そと)に出(で)かけられない』と文句(もんく)を言(い)うし、晴(は)れたら晴(は)れたで「暑(あつ)い暑(あつ)い」と文句(もんく)を言(い)う。」
example.english: "Good grief, if it rains, he always complains that he cannot go outside, and if it’s sunny he always complains that it’s really hot."

english_grammar.title: べくして
english_grammar.explanation: as expected, meant to, supposed to, destined to, sure to
english_grammar.structure: (Intransitive) Verb［る］+ べくして + (Intransitive) Verb1［る］(1) Verb［られる］［る］+ べくして + Verb［られる］［る］(1) (1)Verb［られる］［た］
english_grammar.about: べくして is a combination of the conjunctive form of the classical auxiliary verb べし, べく, and the conjunctive particle して, which shows a situation from which a logical determination can be made, or will be a natural course of action. べく itself indicates the word that it is attached to as a 'purpose' or 'end goal'. べくして is often translated simply as 'as expected of (A), (B)', or 'as was supposed to (A), (B)'. (A) and (B) will be the same verb repeated. 彼女(かのじょ)らはここ2年間(ねんかん)毎日(まいにち)文句(もんく)を言(い)わずにトレーニングしてきたから、大会(たいかい)で勝(か)つべくして勝(か)ったんだ。 These girls have trained every day for the last two years without complaint, so as expected they won the competition. 役所(やくしょ)には何回(なんかい)もここに止(と)まれの標識(ひょうしき)を設置(せっち)するように訴(うった)えたが対応(たいよう)してくれなかったので、この事故(じこ)は起(お)こるべくして起(お)こった。 We have asked the city office multiple times to install a stop sign here, but they never listened to us, so this accident was expected. 最近(さいきん)、彼女(かのじょ)とは出会(であ)うべくして出会(であ)ったと感(かん)じることが多(おお)い。 Recently, I have been feeling that we were destined to meet. The literal meaning of 'as determined with the purpose of (A)' may also be used if it helps to remember the nuance. This expression is quite formal, so will rarely be heard in daily speech. Fun FactAs mentioned in other grammar patterns that contain variations of べく such as べき and べし, this structure derives from the kanji 可(か), which is usually translated as 'permissible' or 'allowed'. All 可 really indicates is a situation that does not currently exist, but it certain to come about as a part of the most logical course of events.

example.japanese: タイトル：「俺(おれ)の青春(せいしゅん)ラブコメはまちがいになるべくしてなった。」
example.english: Title: "As expected, my romantic youth comedy was a blunder."

example.japanese: 壊(こわ)れた一時停止(いちじていし)標識(ひょうしき)を放置(ほうち)した結果(けっか)、起(お)こるべくして起(お)こった交通事故(こうつうじこ)だ。
example.english: As expected, the result of neglecting a broken stop sign was a traffic accident.

example.japanese: 「これらの二人(ふたり)は、専門分野(せんもんぶんや)も年齢(ねんれい)も共(とも)に近(ちか)いゆえに出会(であ)うべくして出会(であ)ったと言(い)えるだろう。」
example.english: As expected, one can say that these two met because they both shared fields of expertise and were close in age.

example.japanese: 不景気(ふけいき)か否(いな)かにかかわらず、高品質(こうひんしつ)で適正価格(てきせいかかく)の商品(しょうひん)は売(う)れるべくして売(う)れている。
example.english: Regardless of whether there is a recession or not, products of good quality and reasonable price are sure to sell.

example.japanese: 好景気(こうけいき)が遅(おそ)かれ早(はや)かれ終(お)わるのは経済学者(けいざいがくしゃ)にとって当然(とうぜん)のことであったし、そうなるべくしてなった。
example.english: To the economists, it was only natural that prosperity will end sooner or later, and, as expected, that’s what happened.

english_grammar.title: ままに (As Desired)
english_grammar.explanation: as (one likes/feels/pleases), spur of the moment, wherever one fancies, spontaneously, on a whim
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ （が）+ まま（に）
english_grammar.about: Unlike the ままに that is partnered with passive structures like れる and られる 'to do as one is told', when paired with verbs in their standard forms, ままに means 'to do (A) as one wishes', or 'to do (A) on a whim'. ままに is a combination of the noun まま 'as is', and the case marking particle に. ままに will follow verbs in their dictionary form. これはもうあなたのものだから、自分(じぶん)が思(おも)うままに使(つか)えばいいよ。 This is yours now, so you can use it as you see fit. 僕(ぼく)はしばらくの間(あいだ)一人(ひとり)で、足(あし)の向(む)くままに旅(たび)をする。 I will be alone for a while, traveling where my feet take me. 文法(ぶんぽう)とかは気(き)にしなくていい！ただ思(おも)いつくままに書(か)いてくれればいい。 There is no need to worry about grammar! Just write whatever comes to mind. In many cases, this use of ままに indicates that the speaker or doer is letting the action of (A) happen in whatever way is most natural, and is not making any particular effort to control the outcome. Due to this, there are only a limited number of verbs that are commonly used with ままに, and it is best not to attempt to use combinations that you have not come across before. Some standard sequences are 気(き)の向(む)くままに 'in whatever way my attention is inclined', 思(おも)うままに 'in whatever way I think up', 思(おも)いつくままに 'in whatever way I come up with', 足(あし)の向(む)くままに 'in whatever direction my feet are pointed', 赴(おもむ)くままに 'in whatever way it proceeds', 欲(ほっ)するままに 'in whatever way is desired', and 風(かぜ)の吹(ふ)くままに 'in whatever way the wind blows'.

example.japanese: 筆者(ひっしゃ)とのインタビュー：「これまで、思(おも)いつくままにいろいろと書(か)いてきましたが、出来(でき)が良(よ)くないような気(き)がしましたので出版(しゅっぱん)しないことに決(き)めました。」
example.english: Interview with an author: "Previously, I wrote many things as they spontaneously came to my mind, but because I felt the end product was not very good, I decided not to publish them."

example.japanese: A：「ジラヤさんはどこ？」B：「わからん。どこかに行(い)ったんだ。」A：「相変(あいか)わらず、風(かぜ)の吹(ふ)くまま、赴(おもむ)くなぁ。」
example.english: A: "Where is Jiraya?"B: "Dunno. He went somewhere."A: "As always, he goes wherever the wind takes him."

example.japanese: モーガンさん、クリスチャンさんに：「あなたのものですから気兼(きが)ねなく自分(じぶん)の思(おも)うままに扱(あつか)ってもいいです。」
example.english: Mr. Morgan to Mr. Christian: "It belongs to you, so feel free to handle it as you please."

example.japanese: 抽象画家(ちゅうしょうがか)は深(ふか)く考(かんが)えずに形(かたち)や色(いろ)を気(き)の向(む)くままに選(えら)ぶ。
example.english: Abstract painters choose shapes and colors as they please, without thinking deeply about them.

example.japanese: 小説(しょうせつ)：「彼女(かのじょ)は特(とく)に行(い)き先(さき)も目的(もくてき)も考(かんが)えず足(あし)の向(む)くままに歩(ある)き続(つづ)けた。」
example.english: Novel: "She kept on going as her feet led her, without any particular goal or destination in mind."

synonym.explanation: therefore・thus, as a result
in that way, exactly・precisely, just as

english_grammar.title: かれ〜かれ
english_grammar.explanation: or, either or
english_grammar.structure: ［い］Adjective［い］+ かれ + ［い］Adjective［い］(Antonym) + かれ 遅かれ早かれ - sooner or later 多かれ少なかれ - more or less to a greater or lesser extent 良かれ悪しかれ - good or bad for better or worse
english_grammar.about: かれ～かれ is a grammar pattern that pairs with opposite い-Adjectives in Japanese to convey that 'whether (A) or (B), the result will be the same'. It is usually translated as 'or', or 'either (A) or (B)'. Originally, this structure was a contraction of the conjunctive stem of い-Adjectives, く, and the imperative form of the う-Verb ある 'to be', あれ. い-Adjectives do not have their own imperative form, so くあれ and then the abbreviation かれ evolved to fill this role. As it is imperative, the literal meaning is simply 'be it (A) or (B)', and is a declaration. かれ～かれ will attach to the stem of 2 adjectives that are antonyms, before going on to explain how the result remains the same regardless. どんな人(ひと)でも多(おお)かれ少(すく)なかれ悩(なや)みを抱(かか)えて生(い)きている。 Every person lives worries, toa greater or lesser extent. 暑(あつ)かれ寒(さむ)かれ、脱水(だっすい)症状(しょうじょう)は起(お)こりうるので水分(すいぶん)補給(ほきゅう)はこまめにしてください。 Dehydration can occur in hot or cold weather, so please hydrate frequently. 遅(おそ)かれ早(はや)かれ提出(ていしゅつ)させないといけないのであるならば、早(はや)めに提出(ていしゅつ)した方(ほう)がいいと思(おも)う。 If it has to be submitted sooner or later, I think it is better to submit it as soon as possible. かれ～かれ is used with a very limited set of adjectives, so it is best not to use it with words that you have not come across previously. Caution In the case of 良(よ)い 'good' and 悪(わる)い 'bad', 悪(わる)い will be read as 悪(あ)しかれ, which comes from the archaic 悪(あ)し 'bad'. This is considered as set phrase in modern Japanese. この発明(はつめい)は、良(よ)かれ悪(あ)しかれたくさんの人(ひと)に影響(えいきょう)を与(あた)えるだろう。 This invention will affect a lot of people, for better or worse.

example.japanese: 「こんなにタバコを吸(す)い続(つづ)けては遅(おそ)かれ早(はや)かれ病気(びょうき)になるだろう。」
example.english: "If you keep on smoking like this, sooner or later you will get sick."

example.japanese: この発見(はっけん)は良(よ)かれ悪(あ)しかれ、大(おお)きな変化(へんか)をもたらすだろう。
example.english: For better or worse, this discovery will bring great change.

example.japanese: 好奇心(こうきしん)は多(おお)かれ少(すく)なかれ誰(だれ)もが持(も)っているものだろう。
example.english: Curiosity is something that everybody has, to a greater or lesser extent.

example.japanese: 遅(おそ)かれ早(はや)かれ有人(ゆうじん)火星(かせい)探査(たんさ)の時代(じだい)はやってくるはずだ。
example.english: I am sure that sooner or later, the era of manned missions to Mars will come.

example.japanese: 研究(けんきゅう)によるとあらゆる頭部外傷(とうぶがいしょう)は多(おお)かれ少(すく)なかれ脳(のう)に影響(えいきょう)を及(およ)ぼすということだ。
example.english: According to research, all kinds of head trauma affect the brain to a greater or lesser extent.

english_grammar.title: ～に〜ない
english_grammar.explanation: cannot even...if wants, would like to...but cannot, wants to...but cannot
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］(A) + に + Verb［できる］［ない］(A)
english_grammar.about: に～ない is a construction which appears with repeating verbs in Japanese to indicate that one 'cannot (A) even if they want to', or 'due to some circumstances, can't (A)'. the case marking particle に will appear after a verb in its dictionary form, before the potential form of the same verb will be negated with ない. In this way, the more literal meaning is 'for (A), (A) is not possible'. 生徒(せいと)が言(い)った冗談(じょうだん)は面白(おもしろ)かったが内容(ないよう)が下品(げひん)だったので笑(わら)うに笑(わら)えなかった。 The joke the student told was funny, but it was inappropriate so I could not laugh even if I wanted to. 本当(ほんとう)は時間(じかん)はあんまりなかったが、先輩(せんぱい)に頼(たの)まれたから断(ことわ)るに断(ことわ)れなかった。 I actually didn't really have too much time, but since my senpai asked me I couldn't refuse even if I wanted to. 息子(むすこ)には明日(あした)までに滑(すべ)り台(だい)を作(つく)ってあげると約束(やくそく)してしまったので、どんな忙(いそが)しくても引(ひ)くに引(ひ)けない。 I promised my son that I would build him a slide by tomorrow, so I can't back out no matter how busy I am. It will be important to keep in mind that する does not have a potential form, so できない will be used in the latter half of this expression when paired with する verbs. 最近(さいきん)は色々(いろいろ)と悩(なや)み事(ごと)が多(おお)くて、集中(しゅうちゅう)するにできない。 A lot has been on my mind recently that I haven't been able to concentrate even if I wanted to. Additionally, ない may sometimes be replaced with other structures that convey negation, such as ず. 息子(むすこ)が一晩中(ひとばんじゅう)泣(な)いていて寝(ね)るに寝(ね)れず徹夜(てつや)をしてしまった。 My son cried all night and because of that I couldn't sleep even if I wanted to and stayed up all night. Caution Occasionally, the dictionary form of a verb will be replaced with the auxiliary verb う or よう volitional forms, and will then be followed by にも. The potential form of the same verb coming before ない will remain the same. 昨日(きのう)の練習(れんしゅう)で足(あし)の怪我(けが)をしてしまったので歩(ある)こうにも歩(ある)けない。 I can't walk even if I wanted to because I injured my foot in yesterday's practice. 今(いま)の仕事(しごと)を辞(や)めようと思(おも)っているが、次(つぎ)のところが見(み)つからないから今(いま)の仕事(しごと)を辞(や)めようにも辞(や)められない。 I'm thinking of quitting my current job, but I can't find another one, so I can't quit my current job even if I wanted to. Although the meanings are the same between both of these, the dictionary form tends to highlight psychological circumstances for why one 'cannot (A)', while the volitional form highlights more concrete or physical circumstances.

example.japanese: 中学生(ちゅうがくせい)の頃(ころ)、好(す)きな子(こ)に告白(こくはく)して断(ことわ)られた。周(まわ)りに人(ひと)がいたから泣(な)くに泣(な)けない状況(じょうきょう)だった。
example.english: During my junior high school days, I confessed to a girl I liked and was rejected. There were some people nearby, so I was in a position where I could not cry even if I wanted to.

example.japanese: 嫌(きら)われている上司(じょうし)が見事(みごと)に転(ころ)んでしまった。従業員(じゅうぎょういん)が笑(わら)うに笑(わら)えない、という顔(かお)をしてた。
example.english: The boss that everyone hates had a spectacular fall. The employees' faces looked as though they wanted to laugh but were unable to.

example.japanese: 「彼(かれ)はどうして学校(がっこう)に戻(もど)ろうとしないのかな？」「何(なに)があったか知(し)らないけど、言(い)うに言(い)えない事情(じじょう)があるのかな。」
example.english: "Why is he not willing to go back to school?""I’m not sure if something happened or not, but maybe he is in a situation where he cannot talk about it (even though he may want to)."

example.japanese: 「彼女(かのじょ)が断(ことわ)れば殺(ころ)すと言(い)って突然(とつぜん)断(ことわ)るに断(ことわ)れない状態(じょうたい)になった。」
example.english: "She said, 'If you refuse, I will kill you,' so the situation suddenly turned into one where I couldn't refuse even if I wanted."

example.japanese: 今日(きょう)、会議(かいぎ)があるけど、雪(ゆき)が積(つ)もって道(みち)が通行止(つうこうど)めになったから行(い)くに行(い)けない。
example.english: I have a meeting today, but snow has piled up and the road is closed, so I can’t go, even if I want to.

english_grammar.title: なくしては
english_grammar.explanation: without, if not for
english_grammar.structure: Noun + なくして(は) Verb + ことなくして(は)
english_grammar.about: なくしては is a hypothetical expression that indicates that 'if not for (A), then not (B)'. It may appear as either なしには, なしでは, or なくしては, with little variation in meaning. It is a combination of the conjunctive form of the い-Adjective ない, なく, the conjunction particle して, which highlights the word before it as a condition from which a determination can be made, and the adverbial particle は. As the second part of なくしては sentences will also be negative, we can see the more literal meaning of 'from the lack of (A), a lack of (B) can be determined'. This 'determination' comes across quite strongly, and may be interpreted as '(B) is impossible without (A)'. なくしては will appear after either nouns, or phrases that have been nominalized with こと. 私(わたし)は彼女(かのじょ)なくしては生(い)きていけないと思(おも)います。 I don't think that I can live without her. 努力(どりょく)なくしては、日本語(にほんご)は上達(じょうたつ)しません。 Without hard work, your Japanese won't improve. 失敗(しっぱい)することなくしては、成功(せいこう)できないと言(い)われているが本当(ほんとう)なのだろうか。 It is said that, without failure you cannot succeed, but I wonder if that is true. 相手(あいて)の気持(きも)ちを考(かんが)えることなくしては、友情(ゆうじょう)は続(つづ)かない。 Friendship cannot last without considering the feelings of the other person. As mentioned previously, なしには and なしでは may also be seen. These are just the noun 無(な)し 'without', paired with either of the particle combinations には or では. なくしては is the most formal of the three. この国(くに)ではエアコンなしには夏(なつ)を乗(の)り越(こ)えられません。 In this country you cannot survive summer without air conditioning. あなたなしでは生(い)きていけません！ I can't live without you! The (B) part of なくしては sentences will almost always be some state of completion or desirable outcome that cannot be achieved without (A).

example.japanese: スピーチ：「何(なに)よりまず我(わ)が友人(ゆうじん)トトロに感謝(かんしゃ)します。彼(かれ)なくしては今日(きょう)の私(わたし)はなかったと言(い)えるでしょう。」
example.english: Speech: "First and foremost, I would like to thank my friend Totoro. It can be said that without him, I wouldn’t be the person I am today."

example.japanese: 愛(あい)なくしては生(い)きられないというが、それが苦痛(くつう)になることもある。
example.english: They say that one cannot live without love, but sometimes it becomes a significant burden.

example.japanese: 名言(めいげん)：「努力(どりょく)なくして成功(せいこう)なし。」
example.english: Wise saying: "There is no success without hard work."

example.japanese: トランジスタの開発(かいはつ)なくして、現在(げんざい)の世界(せかい)は成立(せいりつ)しえない。
example.english: The world we know today is not possible without the development of transistors.

example.japanese: 「ノーベル賞(しょう)受賞(じゅしょう)はノーベル委員会(いいんかい)に是認(ぜにん)されることなくしては、ありえないことであろう。」
example.english: Receiving the Nobel prize is impossible without the approval of the Nobel Committee.

english_grammar.title: のなんのって
english_grammar.explanation: so much that, extremely, very
english_grammar.structure: Verb + のなんのって ［い］Adjective + のなんのって ［な］Adjective + な + のなんのって
english_grammar.about: のなんのって is a casual phrase that is used in spoken Japanese to indicate that the word before it is 'excessively (A)', or 'extremely (A)'. This structure consists of the case marking particle の, the pre-noun adjectival 何(なん)の 'what kind of', and って, an abbreviation of という 'to say'. The literal meaning of 'and to say it's (A) or something' just indicates that something is so (A) that if it is not that then the speaker doesn't know what to call it. This structure will be seen after い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives followed by な, and verbs. あんな痩(や)せているのにあの量(りょう)一人(ひとり)で食(た)べちゃうなんて、びっくりしたのなんのって。 I was extremely surprised that such a skinny guy could eat that amount of food all by himself. 名古屋(なごや)の夏(なつ)は暑(あつ)いのなんのって、外(そと)に出(で)た瞬間(しゅんかん)シャツが汗(あせ)でびっしょりになるんだよ。 It is so hot in Nagoya in the summer that the moment you step outside, your shirt will be drenched in sweat. あの建物(たてもの)は丈夫(じょうぶ)なのなんのって、去年(きょねん)あった深度(しんど)７の地震(じしん)までも耐(た)えたんだよ。 That building is so sturdy that it even withstood last year's earthquake that measured 7 on the Japanese seismic scale. のなんのって itself is a more condensed variation of ～の～ないのって, which has the same meaning, but has (A) appear in both the positive and negative for 'to say it's (A) or not (A), (B)', where (B) will usually be a phrase explaining the extent of (A). Occasionally (B) will be left unsaid, as ～の～ないのって itself is always used to mean 'extremely (A)'. 彼(かれ)は食(た)べるの食(た)べないのって、30分(ぷん)で3キロも肉(にく)を一人(ひとり)で食(た)べた。 He eats so much that he ate 3 kg of meat in 30 minutes all by himself. あのジェットコースターは大人(おとな)でも失神(しっしん)するほど怖(こわ)いの怖(こわ)くないのって。 That rollercoaster is so scary that even an adult would pass out.

example.japanese: A：「疲(つか)れた顔(かお)だね。」B：「昨日(きのう)は騒音(そうおん)で眠(ねむ)れなかったから、もう眠(ねむ)いのなんのって・・・」
example.english: A: "You look tired!"B: "I couldn’t sleep yesterday because it was noisy, so I am already extremely sleepy…"

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)は日帰(ひがえ)りについて話(はな)す、A：「で、お腹(なか)がすいてなかった？」B：「そりゃお腹(なか)がすいたのなんのって、一人(ひとり)でご飯(はん)３杯(ばい)も食(たべ)べたよ。」
example.english: Friends talking about a day trip, A: "And then? Weren’t you hungry?"B: "I was extremely hungry. I ate three bowls of rice by myself!"

example.japanese: A：「今(いま)買(か)ったケーキはどう？食(た)べてみたい。」B：「ケーキおいしいのなんのって、もう完食(かんしょく)しちゃったほど。」
example.english: A: "How is the cake we bought today? I want to try."B: "It was so delicious (to the point) that I ate it all already."

example.japanese: A：「田舎(いなか)はどうだった？」B：「よかったよ。静(しず)かなのなんのって虫(むし)の音(ね)が聞(き)こえる。とてもリラックスできた。」
example.english: A: "How was the countryside?"B: "Great! It was so quiet that one could hear the insects chirping. I was really able to relax."

example.japanese: 「あそこのエンジニアが下手(へた)クソでさ。修理(しゅうり)が上手(うま)くないのなんのって。修理(しゅうり)から一日(いちにち)経(た)っただけでまた壊(こわ)れたんだよ。」
example.english: "That engineer is absolutely terrible (at his job). He is extremely unskillful! Only one day after "repairs" it broke again."

english_grammar.title: にかかっている
english_grammar.explanation: to depend on
english_grammar.structure: Noun + （如何）+ にかかっている Phrase + かどうか(1) + （如何）+ にかかっている WH-Word + Phrase + か + （如何）+ にかかっている (1) か否か
english_grammar.about: にかかっている is a structure that may be translated as 'to depend on (A)', or 'to rest on (A)'. It is a combination of the case marking particle に, and the the ている continuous form of 懸(か)かる 'to depend'. Although にかかっている may attach to nouns, it is also frequently seen following set structures such as かどうか 'whether or not', and か否(いな)か 'yes or no'. 来月(らいげつ)旅行(りょこう)に行(い)けるかは、部長(ぶちょう)が僕(ぼく)に休(やす)みをくれるかにかかっている。 Whether I can go on the trip next month depends on whether my boss will give me time off. 地球(ちきゅう)の未来(みらい)は若者(わかもの)にかかっているから、若者(わかもの)を教育(きょういく)しなくてはいけない。 We must educate the youth because the future of this earth depends on them. 自分(じぶん)で立(た)ち上(あ)げた会社(かいしゃ)が成功(せいこう)するかどうかは自分(じぶん)の努力(どりょく)にかかっている。 Whether your company will succeed or not depends on your own efforts. The に in にかかっている may sometimes be replaced with the adverb 如何(いか)に 'how', 'in what way', or 'to what extent. In these situations, the meaning stays relatively the same, but will extend to 'depending on the way in which (A)', or 'depending on to what extent (A)'. この商品(しょうひん)の売(う)れ行(ゆ)きはマーケティングが成功(せいこう)するかどうか如何(いか)にかかっている。 The sales of this product will depend on the success of the marketing. みなさんが合格(ごうかく)できるかできないかは、皆(みな)さんが努力(どりょく)するかどうか如何(いか)にかかっている。 Whether or not you will be able to pass the exam depends on how hard you are going to work. Fun Fact懸(か)かる is from the same family of verbs as 掛(か)かる, 架(か)かる, and 罹(かか)る. These all have a similar meaning, but with a slightly different nuance. Japanese has many verbs like this that have the same reading, but with a nuance that changes based on the kanji. Due to kanji not always being used for many of these, it will be important to be able to recognize which nuance is being used in any given situation.

example.japanese: ほむら：「すべてが一人(ひとり)の少女(しょうじょ)の選択(せんたく)にかかっている。」
example.english: Homura: "Everything depends on one girl’s choice."

example.japanese: 成功(せいこう)するかどうかは才能(さいのう)よりむしろどれだけ頑張(がんば)るかにかかっていると言(い)えるだろう。
example.english: "It is fair to say that whether or not one succeeds depends on how hard one can work rather than one’s ability."

example.japanese: コーチ：「勝(か)つも負(ま)けるも我々(われわれ)の協力(きょうりょく)にかかっているから頑張(かんば)ろう。」
example.english: Coach: "Whether we win or lose depends on our cooperation, so let’s do our best!"

example.japanese: 記事(きじ)：「田中(たなか)社長(しゃちょう)は当社(とうしゃ)の将来(しょうらい)が、政府(せいふ)からの貸付(かしつ)けを受(う)けられるかどうか如何(いか)にかかっている、ということを確信(かくしん)しました。」
example.english: Article: "Company President Tanaka believes that the company's future depends on whether or not it is able to acquire a government loan."

example.japanese: 小説(しょうせつ)：「帝国(ていこく)の運命(うんめい)はターニャの作戦(さくせん)が成功(せいこう)するか否(いな)かにかかっている。」
example.english: Novel: "The fate of the empire depends on whether Tanya’s strategy succeeds or not."

synonym.explanation: depending on, so
depending on

english_grammar.title: ～て止(や)まない
english_grammar.explanation: never cease to, always, sincerely・greatly, from the bottom of one's heart
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］+ やまない
english_grammar.attention: ほしくてやまない is also sometimes used
english_grammar.about: ～てやまない is a formal construction that combines the て-form of a verb with the negative form of the う-Verb 止(や)む 'to cease', or 'to desist'. The literal meaning of 'to not stop (A)', or 'to not desist (A)' is often translated as 'to always (A)', or 'to (A) from the bottom of one's heart'. It is an expression that is used exclusively in relation to feelings and emotions. 私(わたし)が愛(あい)してやまない犬(いぬ)が急(きゅう)に体(からだ)を壊(こわ)したから心配(しんぱい)でしょうがない。 The dog that I love from the bottom of my heart got sick suddenly, so I am worried. あんなことを親(おや)にさせてしまって後悔(こうかい)してやまない。 I never cease to regret letting my parents do that for me. 1日(にち)も早(はや)く普通(ふつう)の生活(せいかつ)に戻(もど)れる様(よう)に祈(いの)ってやみません。 I will never cease to pray for them to be able to return to their normal lives as soon as possible. Common words that may be partnered with やまない include 愛(あい) 'love', 敬愛(けいあい) 'love and respect', 願(ねが)う 'to wish for', 祈(いの)る 'to hope for', 望(のぞ)む 'to have ambitions for', 希望(きぼう) 'wish', 期待(きたい) 'anticipation', 尊敬(そんけい) 'respect', 信(しん)じる 'to trust', and several more. Either positive or negative emotions may be used. Caution As やまない emphasizes the continuation of something, てやまない will not be used with feelings that are temporary, such as (temporary) anger, or (temporary) disappointment. 上司(じょうし)に子供(こども)や妻(つま)のことを悪(わる)く言(い)われて、腹(はら)が立(た)ってやまない。 I was sincerely mad at my boss for saying such things about my wife and kids. (Unnatural Japanese)

example.japanese: 献辞(けんじ)：「愛(あい)してやまない妻(つま)と息子(むすこ)へ」
example.english: Dedication: "To my wife and son, whom I will always love."

example.japanese: 賛辞(さんじ)：「友達(ともだち)としても人(ひと)としても心(こころ)の中(なか)に生涯(しょうがい)存在(そんざい)する尊敬(そんけい)してやまない人(ひと)でした。」
example.english: Eulogy: "She was a person I greatly respected throughout my life both as a friend and as a human being."

example.japanese: スピーチ：「今日(きょう)こちらにお集(あつ)まりになった皆様(みなさま)には、当社(とうしゃ)の製品(せいひん)紹介(しょうかい)をお楽(たの)しみいただけるよう願(ねが)ってやみません。」
example.english: Speech: "To all who have gathered here today, I sincerely hope that you will be able to enjoy the presentation of our new product."

example.japanese: 記事(きじ)：「巨大(きょだい)なピラミッドの信(しん)じられないほどの大(おお)きさと美(うつく)しさは、建設(けんせつ)以来(いらい)何千(なんぜん)年(ねん)経(た)っても人(ひと)の心(こころ)を魅了(みりょう)してやみません。」
example.english: Article: "Despite thousands of years passing since their construction, the incredible size and beauty of the great pyramids will never cease to capture the hearts of people."

example.japanese: 小説(しょうせつ)：「彼(かれ)は人(ひと)を惹(ひ)きつけてやまない何(なに)かを持(も)っていると言(い)えるだろう。」
example.english: Novel: "One could say that he has something that greatly fascinates people."

english_grammar.title: くらいなら
english_grammar.explanation: would rather...than, rather than, better off
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ ぐらいなら(1) + Phrase (1) くらいなら
english_grammar.about: くらいなら will often be translated as 'would rather (B) than (A)', or 'better off (B) than (A)'. It is a grammar pattern that combines the adverbial particle usages of くらい 'about' and なら 'if' to imply that 'if it gets to the extent of (A), then (B)', where (B) will be something that is preferable. くらいなら will be used directly following verbs in their dictionary forms. あの地域(ちいき)に引(ひ)っ越(こ)すくらいなら、死(し)んだ方(ほう)がマシだ。 I would rather die, than move to that neighborhood. あの先輩(せんぱい)の下(もと)で働(はたら)くぐらいなら、一人(ひとり)で働(はたら)いた方(ほう)がいいと思(おも)うよ。 I think you would be better off working alone, than working under that senpai. 何十万(なんじゅうまん)もかけて直(なお)すくらいなら、もう少(すこ)し出(だ)して新(あたら)しい車(くるま)を買(か)った方(ほう)がいい。 I would rather buy a new car that is a little expensive than pay thousands of dollars to fix this car. As this structure emphasizes (A) as being something that is undesirable, (B) will often contain statements that offer a solution, suggestion, or opinion, such as ほうがいい 'would be better to', ほうがましだ 'would be less bad', なさい 'do!'. Caution Although くらいなら will always follow a verb in dictionary form, the second half of the sentence may imply that (A) has actually already happened, and the speaker is wishing that it hadn't. In these cases, くらいなら almost always translates to 'if I had known that (A), then I would have (B)'. え、前(まえ)使(つか)ってたパソコン捨(す)てちゃったの？捨(す)てるくらいなら俺(おれ)が買(か)ったのに。 What… You threw away the computer you were using? If I had known that you were getting rid of it, I would have bought it from you. あんな奴(やつ)に頼(たの)むぐらいなら、自分(じぶん)でやればよかった。 I should have done it myself, rather than asking a person like that to do it.

example.japanese: A：「彼(かれ)に助(たす)けを求(もと)めたらどう？」B：「彼(かれ)に助(たす)けを求(もと)めるくらいなら、むしろピラニアだらけの池(いけ)を泳(およ)いだほうがましだぞ。」
example.english: A: "What about asking him for help?"B: "I would rather swim through a pond full of piranha than ask him for help."

example.japanese: 「その仕事(しごと)は絶対(ぜったい)に嫌(いや)だ。それに戻(もど)るくらいなら死(し)んだほうがましだ。」
example.english: "I really hate that job. I would rather die than go back."

example.japanese: 「小(ちい)さなことに目(め)くじらを立(た)てる人(ひと)と一緒(いっしょ)に生活(せいかつ)するくらいならホームレスになったほうがましだ。」
example.english: "I would rather become homeless than live together with a person who nitpicks every little thing I do."

example.japanese: A：「愛(あい)Phoneの画面(がめん)の修理(しゅうり)は3万円(まんえん)からするよ。どうしようかな？」B：「とっても高(たか)いよね！修理(しゅうり)するくらいなら新(あたら)しいのを買(か)っちゃった方(ほう)がいいかなあ。」
example.english: A: "My aiPhone screen repair cost starts at about 30000 yen! What should I do?"B: "Wha, that’s super expensive! You would be better off buying a new one rather than repairing it."

example.japanese: 「やらずに後悔(こうかい)するくらいなら、いっそやってみなさいよ。」
example.english: "Rather than regret not doing it, try it!"

english_grammar.title: ってば
english_grammar.explanation: I said...!, I told you...!, !
english_grammar.structure: Verb + ってば(1)。 ［い］Adjective + ってば(1)。 ［な］Adjective + （だ）+ ってば(1)。 Noun + （だ）+ ってば(1)。 (1) ったら
english_grammar.attention: Originates in contraction of と言えば・と言ったら。
english_grammar.about: ってば and ったら are often used in casual Japanese to insist the speaker's own viewpoint or opinion about something. The structures are frequently translated as 'I said (A)!', or 'I told you (A)!'. ってば and ったら are contractions of といえば 'if it were said', and といったら 'if it were said' respectively. In these cases, the literal meaning is very similar to the English 'didn't I say (A)!?' when used sarcastically or aggressively. Either ってば or ったら may follow just about any word, but will require a だ to precede them when coming after nouns or な-Adjectives. 分(わ)かったってば！何回(なんかい)も言(い)われると本当(ほんとう)むかつくからちょっと黙(だま)ってて。 I said I got it! You telling me the same thing (repeatedly) is getting on my nerves so can you please be quiet for a little bit? 痛(いた)いったら！なんでずっと痛(いた)いって言(い)ってるのに何回(なんかい)も何回(なんかい)もフォークでつついてくるの？ I said that hurts! Why do you keep poking me with a fork even when I say that it hurts? 嫌(きら)いだってば！あんな奴(やつ)なんて大嫌(だいきら)いだ！ I said I don't like them! I don't like such people! だから、俺(おれ)は大人(おとな)だったら！背(せ)が低(ひく)いからってひどいぞ本当(ほんとう)に。 For the last time, I said that I am an adult. It is kind of mean to say such things just because I am short. Caution ってば and ったら may also directly follow nouns without だ. In these cases, the noun is generally a person (perhaps the speaker themselves), and the translation will be 'oh that (A)', 'that darn (A)'. (A) will primarily be people that the speaker is quite familiar with, and they are expressing some kind of real or playful frustration. 金太郎(きんたろう)ってば、またエアコンつけっぱなしで家(いえ)出(で)てったよ。 That darn Kintaro, he went out with his AC still running. あなたったら本当(ほんとう)におっちょこちょいね。 Oh you, you are such a clutz aren't you.

example.japanese: 犬(いぬ)が飼(か)い主(ぬし)を舐(な)めている、飼(か)い主(ぬし)：「アカマル、やめろ！」舐(な)めまわされること1分(ぷん)後(ご)、飼(か)い主(ぬし)：「やめろってば！」
example.english: A dog licking their owner, pet owner: "Akamaru, stop!"One minute of licking later, pet owner: "I said stop!"

example.japanese: 親(おや)：「宿題(しゅくだい)やりなさいよ！」イライラした子供(こども)：「今(いま)からやるったら！」
example.english: Parent: "Do your homework!"Irritated child: "I said I’m gonna do it!"

example.japanese: 親(おや)：「夕飯(ゆうはん)前(まえ)には家中(うちじゅう)に掃除機(そうじき)掛(か)けといてね。」子供(こども)：「わかった。」３分(ぷん)後(ご)、親(おや)：「忘(わす)れないでね。」子供(こども)：「わかったってば！」
example.english: Parent: "Vacuum the house before dinner, OK?"Child: "Got it."3 minutes later, parent: "Don’t forget, OK??"Child: "I said I got it!"

example.japanese: 配偶者(はいぐうしゃ)１はケーキを食(た)べようとしている配偶者(はいぐうしゃ)２に「ケーキを夕食(ゆうしょく)の前(まえ)に食(た)べちゃダメったら！」
example.english: Spouse to spouse that is about to eat cake: "I told you not to eat cake before dinner!"

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)１：「俺(おれ)と一緒(いっしょ)バンジージャンプ、やってみない？」友達(ともだち)２：「興味(きょうみ)ないんだ。」友達(ともだち)１：「本当(ほんとう)に？」友達(ともだち)２：「やだってば、もう！」
example.english: Friend1: "Won't you go bungee jumping together with me?"Friend2: "Not interested."Friend1: "Are you sure?"Friend2: "I said no, Jeez!"

english_grammar.title: ずとも
english_grammar.explanation: even if not, without, don't have to
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］+ ず + とも Noun + ならずとも(1) 1. なる［ない］ + ず + とも Exceptions: する ￫ せずとも
english_grammar.about: When combined with the classical auxiliary verb ず (used for negation), the conjunction particle とも 'even if' implies that regardless of the hypothetical situation of (A), (B) still applies. This often translates as 'even if not (A), (B)', or 'don't have to (A) to (B)'. ずとも will appear attached to the ない-stem of verbs. 昔(むかし)は練習(れんしゅう)せずとも新(あたら)しい曲(きょく)を完璧(かんぺき)に弾(ひ)けたのに、今(いま)となってはどんだけ練習(れんしゅう)しても上手(うま)く弾(ひ)けないいんだよな。 I used to be able to play new music without any practice, but now I can't play well no matter how much I practice. あなたが今(いま)ものすごく落(お)ち込(こ)んでいるということは聞(き)かずともわかりますよ。 I can tell that you are very upset without even asking. 日本(にほん)に留学(りゅうがく)せずとも、日本語(にほんご)を習得(しゅうとく)する方法(ほうほう)はあるが、日本(にほん)に行(い)って勉強(べんきょう)する方(ほう)が楽(たの)しそうだから私(わたし)は日本(にほん)に留学(りゅうがく)したいです。 I know that there are ways to study Japanese without studying abroad in Japan, but I am going to Japan because it seems fun to study there. When the speaker wants to express 'not being (A)' rather than 'not doing (A)', ならずとも will follow a noun. This is simply the negated form of the う-Verb なる 'to become'. 専門家(せんもんか)ならずとも、彼(かれ)は政治(せいじ)について色々(いろいろ)と知(し)っている。 Even though he is not an expert, he knows alot about politics. 親(おや)ならずとも子育(こそだて)てが大変(たいへん)だということは見(み)てわかるはずだ。 You don't have to be a parent to see that parenting is hard work. Although ずとも is a formal expression, it may occasionally be used sarcastically. Additionally, it is common for ずとも to be followed by 良(よ)い. This can be interpreted as 'okay even if not (A)'. 来週(らいしゅう)の試合(しあい)の相手(あいて)はあの弱(よわ)いチームだから、そんなに練習(れんしゅう)せずとも良(よ)いだろう。 Next week's game is against that weak team, so we won't have to practice so much.

example.japanese: 久(ひさ)しぶりに会(あ)った友達(ともだち)の話(はなし)、まさお：「こんな可愛(かわい)い女(おんな)の子(こ)とどういう関係(かんけい)だ？ まさかガールフレンドか？」あおしま：「まあ、当(あ)たらずとも遠(とお)からずなんだよ。我(わ)が妻(つま)だ。」
example.english: Chat with friends who met after a long time, Masao: "What is your relationship with such a cute girl? Don’t tell me she is your girlfriend?"Aoshima: "Well... Even if you’re not spot on, you are close. She’s my wife."

example.japanese: 妹(いもうと)：「でも、どうやってわかった？」兄(あに)：「家族(かぞく)だから言(い)わずともわかる。」
example.english: Younger sister: "But, how did you know?"Older brother: "We are a family, so I understand you even if you don’t say anything."

example.japanese: ゲーム評論(ひょうろん)：「RPGゲームファンならずとも、ウィッチャー３に興味(きょうみ)をひかれずにはいられません。」
example.english: Game review: "Even if I am not an RPG fan, I cannot help but be captivated by Witcher 3."

example.japanese: 記事(きじ)：「アメリカ人とイギリス人は他(ほか)の言語(げんご)を学(まな)ばずとも生(い)きられる言語(げんご)環境(かんきょう)に居(い)ます。」
example.english: Article: "Americans and Brits are in a language environment where they can live without learning other languages. "

example.japanese: 時代小説(じだいしょうせつ)、瀕死(ひんし)の親(おや)：「わたしの身(み)の心配(しんぱい)などせずとも良(よ)い。我(わ)が娘(むすめ)よ。」
example.english: A historical novel, dying parent: "You don’t have to worry about me. My dear daughter."

english_grammar.title: とあって
english_grammar.explanation: since...(it is no wonder that), because...(it is no wonder that), due to...(it is no wonder that)
english_grammar.structure: Verb + とあって ［い］Adjective + とあって ［な］Adjective + （だ）+ とあって Noun + （だ）+ とあって
english_grammar.about: とあって is a formal grammar expression that combines the case marking particle と with the て-form of ある 'to be'. It is used to present an unusual situation from which an obvious result will or has occurred. It is often translated as 'since (A), it is no wonder that (B)', or 'because of (A), it's natural that (B)'. とあって is usually seen following almost any word in their standard forms, but な-Adjectives will require a だ to come between them and とあって. あのグループの卒業(そつぎょう)ライブが行(おこな)われるとあって、この会場(かいじょう)は大勢(おおぜい)のファンで溢(あふ)れている。 Since a farewell concert of that group is about to take place, this venue is filled with a large number of fans. 北海道(ほっかいどう)は夏(なつ)の間(あいだ)でも涼(すず)しいとあって、冬(ふゆ)の間(あいだ)だけでなく夏(なつ)にも多(おお)くの観光客(かんこうきゃく)が訪(おとず)れるらしい。 I heard that Hokkaido attracts many tourists not only during winter, but also summer since it is cool there even during the summer months. あの街(まち)は便利(べんり)だとあって、土地(とち)の値段(ねだん)が高(たか)い。 Since that city is convenient, the price of land is expensive. お盆(ぼん)の最終日(さいしゅうび)とあって、高速道路(こうそくどうろ)だけでなく、下道(したみち)もものすごく混(こ)んでいる。 Both the toll free road and the expressway are extremely crowded since it is the last day of Obon. This construction can be thought of as similar to として 'as', but with focus more on 'what (A) is or is viewed as', emphasized through ある, rather than 'how (A) conducts itself or is conducted', emphasized through する. Caution とあって is only used objectively, and will not refer to the speaker or writer themselves. 私(わたし)はハンサムとあって、友達(ともだち)が作(つく)りやすい。 Since I am handsome, it is easy to make friends. (Unnatural Japanese)

example.japanese: 記事(きじ)：「この都市(とし)で唯一(ゆいいつ)のイタリアンが食(た)べれるレストランとあって、自然(しぜん)と大人気(だいにんき)になった。」
example.english: Article: "Since it is the only restaurant in this city where one can eat Italian cuisine, (it is no wonder that) it naturally became very popular."

example.japanese: 記事(きじ)：「沖縄(おきなわ)は日本(にほん)の他(ほか)のところと比(くら)べて冬(ふゆ)でも暖(あたた)かいとあって、夏休(なつやす)みにとどまらず一年中(いちねんじゅう)日本(にほん)全国(ぜんこく)から多(おお)くの人(ひと)が訪(おとず)れる。」
example.english: Article: "Since even winters in Okinawa are mild compared to other parts of Japan, (it is no wonder that) it is visited by many people from all over the country not only in summer but all year round."

example.japanese: ニュースサイト：「 気軽(きがる)に鹿(しか)などの野生動物(やせいどうぶつ)が撮影(さつえい)できるとあって、大変(たいへん)人気(にんき)の撮影(さつえい)スポットの一(ひと)つになっています。」
example.english: News site: "Since one can easily photograph wild animals such as deer, (it is no wonder that) it has become one of the most popular photography spots."

example.japanese: ニュース：「今日(きょう)は元日(がんじつ)とあって、神社(じんじゃ)には初詣(はつもうで)に来(き)て、お賽銭(さいせん)をお供(そな)えする人(ひと)がいっぱいです。」
example.english: News: "Since it is the first day of the new year, (it is no wonder that) there are many people who have come to the shrine(s) for hatsumode to pay their respects and offer money."

example.japanese: ニュースサイト：「日本(にほん)で初(はつ)上映(じょうえい)とあって、大人(おとな)から子(こ)どもまで多(おお)くの人(ひと)が集(あつ)まりました。」
example.english: News: "Since it premiered in Japan, (it is no wonder that) many people of all ages gathered."

english_grammar.title: でもなんでもない
english_grammar.explanation: not at all, by no means, definitely not, nothing like that, not really
english_grammar.structure: Noun + でもなんでもない ［な］Adjective + でもなんでもない
english_grammar.about: でもなんでもない is a structure seen after nouns or な-Adjectives in Japanese to indicate that something is 'definitely not (A)', or 'not (A) at all'. This is a combination of the adverbial particle でも 'even', the adverb 何(なん)でも 'whatever' or 'anything at all', and the い-Adjective ない 'not'. Due to this, the literal translation of 'not even (A) or anything of the sort' reflects the desired nuance. 俺(おれ)はファンでもなんでもないよ、ただあの人(ひと)が作曲(さっきょく)した曲(きょく)を聞(き)くのが好(す)きなだけ。 I am not a fan by all means. I just like listening to the music he produces. あっ、あの人(ひと)ですか？友達(ともだち)でもなんでもないですよ、なんかさっき急(きゅう)に話(はな)しかけてきたので話(はな)していただけです。 Oh, that person? They are not my friend at all. They just came up to me and started talking to me so I was just talking to them. 迷惑(めいわく)でもなんでもないですよ、ゆっくりしていってください。 It's not bothersome at all. Please take your time. 好(す)きでもなんでもない人(ひと)からそんなこと言(い)われても全然(ぜんぜん)嬉(うれ)しくない。 I'm not at all happy to hear such a thing from someone I don't like or anything. でもなんでもない may be used either positively or negatively. When being used positively, it often has the translation of '(A) is no big deal'. Caution Although not as common, some sources list the conjunctive form of い-Adjectives partnered with もなんでもない as another possibility. あいつとは別(わか)れたけど、ひどい奴(やつ)だったから、悲(かな)しくもなんでもない。 I broke up with him, but since he was such an awful person, I am not sad or anything. これ重(おも)くもなんでもないじゃん。 This isn't heavy at all.

example.japanese: 《AがBをいじめている》A：「ただの遊(あそ)びだ・・・」B：「遊(あそ)びでもなんでもないよ、ただの嫌(いや)がらせじゃないか。」
example.english: A is teasing B, A: "I’m just playing with you..."B: "This is definitely not a game! Aren’t you just harassing me?"

example.japanese: 《友達(ともだち)との話(はなし)》A：「ごめんね、迷惑(めいわく)かけちゃったよね。」B：「ううん。別(べつ)に迷惑(めいわく)でもなんでもないよ。」
example.english: Chat between friends, A: "Sorry. I have caused you troubles."B: "Nah. There was no trouble at all."

example.japanese: 《研究室(けんきゅうしつ)、後輩(こうはい)入(はい)る時(とき)》後輩(こうはい)：「お忙(いそが)しいところを、すみません。」先輩(せんぱい)：「いえ、仕事(しごと)でも何(なん)でもないです。ただの調(しら)べごとですよ。」
example.english: Laboratory, junior enters, junior: "I am sorry to bother you when you are busy."Senior: "No, I’m not really working at all. I’m just reading up on (articles, data)."

example.japanese: 「これは偶然(ぐうぜん)でもなんでもないんです、起(お)こるべくして起(お)こったんです。」
example.english: "It is not a coincidence at all. It was sure to happen."

example.japanese: 《AとBから離(はな)れた位置(いち)の人(ひと)について話(はな)す》 A：「あの人(ひと)、誰(だれ)？恋人(こいびと)？」B：「恋人(こいびと)でもなんでもない。ただの知(し)り合(あ)い。」
example.english: A and B talk about a person some distance away, A: "Who is that person? Girlfriend?"B: "She is not my girlfriend at all. Just an acquaintance."

synonym.text: い-Adj[く] + もなんともない
synonym.explanation: not... or anything, not at all, not, by no means, definitely not, nothing like that

english_grammar.title: 包(ぐる)みで
english_grammar.explanation: whole, -wide, across the, entire, all of, with … altogether
english_grammar.structure: Noun + ぐるみで Noun + ぐるみ + の + Noun
english_grammar.about: When following nouns, the suffix ぐるみ 'including (A)', 'all over (A)', or '(A) wide' is used to express that something encompasses absolutely all of (A). ぐるみ stem from the う-Verb 包(くる)む, meaning 'to wrap', or 'to encompass'. In many cases, the case marking particle で will follow ぐるみ to mark 'with', but の may also be seen when preceding a second noun. 毎年(まいとし)家族(かぞく)ぐるみで初詣(はつもうで)に行(い)きます。 I go to Hatsumode with my entire family every year. 会社(かいしゃ)ぐるみで違法(いほう)な取引(とりひき)をしていたので、社員(しゃいん)全員(ぜんいん)逮捕(たいほ)された。 All the employees were arrested because the entire company was doing illegal business. 彼(かれ)とは家族(かぞく)ぐるみの付(つ)き合(あ)いです。 Our family is friends with him and his whole family. (He is a family friend) 街(まち)ぐるみの治安(ちあん)をよくするために、町内会(ちょうないかい)の人(ひと)たちが毎晩(まいばん)パトロールをしています。 In order to improve the security of the entire town, people from the neighborhood association patrol the area every night. ぐるみ is most frequently seen following words that specify a whole 'group' or 'span' to which the topic of the sentence is only one part of. This could be one member of a family, one home within a neighborhood, one student within a school, or any other number of things that share a clearly identifiable link. Despite this, the primary nuance will always be that the group itself shares a common trait, rather than focusing on any individual part.

example.japanese: 「ともさんとは家族(かぞく)ぐるみの付(つ)き合(あ)いです。」
example.english: 'Our family is acquaintances with Tomo and her entire family.'

example.japanese: その会社の食品(しょくひん)偽装(ぎそう)は会社(かいしゃ)ぐるみで行(おこな)われたものだ。社員(しゃいん)1人(ひとり)だけに責任(せきにん)をおしつけるべきではない。
example.english: The false labeling of food products was a company-wide practice. A single employee should not be blamed.

example.japanese: 《 地方自治体(ちほうじちたい)のサイト》「◯◯県(けん)では、地域(ちいき)ぐるみで気候変動対策(きこうへんどうたいさく)に取(と)り組(く)むことにより、ゴミの量(りょう)を50％減(へ)らすことができました」
example.english: Local government website: "In XX Prefecture we were able to reduce the amount of garbage by 50% through region-wide efforts to combat climate change."

example.japanese: 《 地方自治体(ちほうじちたい)のサイト》「街(まち)ぐるみの年中行事(ねんちゅうぎょうじ)「ゴミ拾(ひろ)い」が10/10（土(ど)）に行(おこな)われます。」
example.english: Local government website: "A city-wide annual event, "Garbage Collecting" will be held on Saturday, October 10."

example.japanese: 《詐欺(さぎ)》詐欺師(さぎし)「もしもし、お祖母(ばあ)さん？俺(おれ)、俺(おれ)！」 武(たけし)の祖母(そぼ)「武(たけし)？どうしたの？」 詐欺師(さぎし)「うん、悪(わる)い人(ひと)に身(み)ぐるみ剥(は)がされたんだ。お金(かね)持(も)ってきてくれない？。」
example.english: Scam, Scammer: "Hello, Grandma? It's me!"Takeshi's grandmother: "Takeshi? What's wrong?"Scammer: "Yes, it's me. I was ripped off for everything I had by bad people. Could you bring me some money?"

english_grammar.title: そばから
english_grammar.explanation: as soon as, right after, even if … still
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ そばから + Phrase Verb［た］+ そばから + Phrase
english_grammar.about: そばから is a combination of the noun 側(そば) 'side', and the case marking particle から 'from'. It illustrates something that happens immediately upon (A), and can be translated as 'as soon as (A), (B)', or 'right after (A), (B)'. (B) is usually something that is considered annoying, unfavorable, or somehow nullifies (A) by the speaker, but there are exceptions. If the more literal translation of 'from right beside (A), (B)' helps to remember the nuance of (B) happening straight away, then that may be a helpful way to memorize this construction. そばから will follow verbs in either their dictionary or past-tense forms. 彼女(かのじょ)は約束(やくそく)をするそばからすぐ約束(やくそく)を破(やぶ)る。 She breaks her promises as soon as she makes them. 彼(かれ)は注意(ちゅうい)するそばから失敗(しっぱい)をするから、私(わたし)のいうことは聞(き)いていないんだろう。 I guess he doesn't listen to me because he makes mistakes as soon as I warn him. パソコンを直(なお)したそばからまた壊(こわ)れてしまうから困(こま)っている。 I'm having trouble with my computer because it breaks down just as soon as I fix it. 早(はや)く読(よ)みすぎると読(よ)んだそばから忘(わす)れるから、もっとゆっくり読(よ)む様(よう)にしている。 I try to read more slowly, because if I read too quickly, I forget as soon as I read it. Regardless of whether the dictionary or the past-tense form of a verb is used, as そばから means 'right after (A)', the meaning will not change at all. Caution そばから will almost always imply that (B) is something that always happens upon (A), rather than being a once-off situation. 車(くるま)の洗車(せんしゃ)を終(お)えるそばから、雨(あめ)が降(ふ)ってきた。 It started to rain as soon as I was about to finish washing my car.

example.japanese: メリーさん「夢(ゆめ)を覚(おぼ)えている？」 ゆめじさん「夢(ゆめ)なんて起(お)きたそばから忘(わす)れてしまうものだけど、夜(や)中(ちゅう)に起きてまた眠(ねむ)ると思(おも)い出(だ)す。」
example.english: Merry: "Do you remember your dreams?"Yumeji: "Dreams are something I forget as soon as I wake up, but if I wake up in the middle of the night and go back to sleep then I remember."

example.japanese: 自転車(じてんしゃ)を直(なお)したそばからまた壊(こわ)れてしまう。
example.english: My bike breaks as soon as I repair it.

example.japanese: あなたって人(ひと)は、「やるな」と言(い)ったそばからやるんだから。
example.english: People like you are just… As soon as I told you not to do it, you still do it…

example.japanese: 教(おそ)わったそばから同(おな)じ間違(まちが)いをおかした。
example.english: I made the same mistake as soon as I learned of it.

example.japanese: ケーキが熱(あつ)いから触(さわ)らないように言ったそばからこいつは～（そうした）。
example.english: As soon as I told him not to touch the cake because it was hot, he… (did so).

english_grammar.title: に至(いた)って
english_grammar.explanation: when it came to, only when, only after, go as far as
english_grammar.structure: Verb + に至って(1) Noun + に至って(1) (1)に至り
english_grammar.attention: When following time expressions or location it often simply means “at”
english_grammar.about: Just like in other grammar points that include the う-Verb 至(いた)る 'to result in', or 'to reach a climax', に至(いた)って will indicate (A) as an extreme extent from which (B) results. The case marking particle に will mark either a verb or noun as the extent that 至(いた)る is signifying as being extreme. Common translations include 'only when (A), did (B)', and 'going as far as to (A), (B)'. 先輩(せんぱい)に注意(ちゅうい)されるに至(いた)って、どれだけ俺(おれ)が自分(じぶん)勝手(かって)だったかが分(わ)かった。 It wasn't until I was warned by a senior colleague that I realized how selfish I had been. 工場(こうじょう)で大(おお)きな事故(じこ)が発生(はっせい)するに至(いた)って安全(あんぜん)大会(たいかい)を実施(じっし)する様(よう)では、この工場(こうじょう)では事故(じこ)が起(お)こり続(つづ)けます。 If a safety meeting is held only after a major accident occurs at the plant, accidents will continue to occur at this plant. 糖尿病(とうにょうびょう)に至(いた)って、食生活(しょくせいかつ)に気(き)をつける様(よう)になった。 Only when I got diabetes, I started to watch what I ate. この年(とし)に至(いた)って会社(かいしゃ)を立(た)ち上(あ)げるなんて、自分(じぶん)でもびっくりだよ。 Deciding to start a company only after reaching such an age, even I am surprised. The extreme extent that に至(いた)って implies will often be the result of something that has been left far too long in a certain state. Due to this, に至(いた)って is often used in relation to criticism of a lack of action. As with many other grammar structures that use verbs, occasionally the formal conjunctive 至(いた)り will replace the standard て-form 至(いた)って. Caution に至(いた)って and に至(いた)っても have quite different meanings, the primary thing to be aware of is as follows. (A) に至(いた)って (B) - Only when reaching the extreme of (A) did (B) occur. (A) に至(いた)っても (B) - Even if reaching the extreme of (A), (B) won't occur. に至(いた)っても will be covered in its own grammar point.

example.japanese: 《記事(きじ)》何(なん)千(ぜん)ものバナナの木(き)が枯(か)れるに至(いた)って、バナナ産業(さんぎょう)は初(はじ)めてパナマ病(びょう)の深刻(しんこく)さに気(き)が付(つ)いた。
example.english: Article: Only when thousands of banana trees died, did the banana industry realize the seriousness of the Panama disease for the first time.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の祖父(そふ)は肺(はい)不全(ふぜん)に至(いた)って、いよいよタバコを止(や)めざるをえないことを認(みと)めた。
example.english: Only when his lungs failed, did my grandfather finally accept that he has no choice but to stop smoking.

example.japanese: 過労(かろう)で意識(いしき)を失(うしな)うに至(いた)って、ようやく働(はたら)きすぎたことがわかった。
example.english: Only when I collapsed due to overwork, did I finally realize that I worked too hard.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)は家宅(かたく)捜索(そうさく)を受(う)ける段(だん)に至(いた)って、やっと自分(じぶん)の置(お)かれている状況(じょうきょう)を理解(りかい)したようである。
example.english: It seems that only at the point when her house had been searched that she finally understood the situation she was in.

example.japanese: 《記事(きじ)》その建物(たてもの)は崩壊(ほうかい)するに至(いた)って、ようやく開発(かいはつ)業者(ぎょうしゃ)がどのくらい建築物(けんちくぶつ)の強度(きょうど)設計(せっけい)の問題(もんだい)を軽視(けいし)したかが明(あき)らかになった。
example.english: Article: Only when the building collapsed, did it finally become clear how much the developer neglected the issue of strength in the design of the building.

english_grammar.title: だに + しない
english_grammar.explanation: not even, not at all, never could have
english_grammar.structure: Noun + だに + しない Exceptions: 夢 + （に）+ だに + 思わない
english_grammar.about: だに is an adverbial particle that shares a similar meaning to さえ and すら 'even', but is more commonly found in classical literature. It will be paired with negative structures and presents 'minimum' or 'light' examples to which (A) does not apply, and therefore obviously also does not apply to anything greater than (A). It will be translated as 'not even (A), so not (B)', or 'not (B) at all'. だに will be seen following nouns or noun-phrases. アメリカでこんな大(おお)きい地震(じしん)が来(く)るとは誰(だれ)も予想(よそう)だにしなかった。 No one could have expected such a big earthquake to happen in the United States. 彼(かれ)が彼女(かのじょ)と別(わか)れるなんて想像(そうぞう)だにしなかったよ。 I would have never imagined he would leave her. まさかこの年(とし)になって子供(ことど)を授(さず)かるなんて思(おも)いだにしていなかった。 I would have never thought I would have a child at this age. Although だに often appears when the (B) part of a sentence is negative, だに itself is not limited to being used this way. When following verbs, and the (B) phrase is not negative, だに simply means 'just'. It is best to keep this in mind, as the core meaning of this adverbial particle will always be to mark the word or phrase before it as an extremely small amount or lower limit. Caution だに is only used in a very limited set of expressions in modern Japanese. Some example of these are 夢(ゆめ)にだに 'even in a dream', 想像(そうぞう)するだに 'even in my imagination', 考(かんが)えるだに 'even to consider', 聞(き)くだに 'even hearing', 微動(びどう)だに 'even a quiver'.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》たかぎさん「にしかたさんのことが大好(だいす)きよ。」たかぎの口(くち)からは想像(そうぞう)だにしていなかった言葉(ことば)がいきなり飛(と)び出(だ)してきた。
example.english: Novel, Takagi-san: “I love you, Nishikata-san.”The words I never could have imagined suddenly came out of Takagi's mouth.

example.japanese: 《アニメのプロローグ》語(かた)り手(て)「あのとき、俺(おれ)はあんな悲劇(ひげき)が待(ま)ち受(う)けていたなんて、夢(ゆめ)にだに思(おも)わなかった。
example.english: Anime prologue, narrator: “Back then, I couldn't have even dreamt that such a tragedy lay ahead.”

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》「彼女(かのじょ)はソファーに座(すわ)ったままで、まるで本物(ほんもの)の人形(にんぎょう)のように微動(びどう)だにしない。」
example.english: Novel: “She remained seated on the sofa, just like a doll, not even moving an inch.”

example.japanese: 《記事(きじ)》ビットコインがこれほどになるとは２００９年(ねん)始(はじ)めには誰(だれ)も予想(よそう)だにしなかった。
example.english: Article: “No one could have even predicted in early 2009 that bitcoin would come this far.”

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》彼(かれ)が心(こころ)の中(なか)にこんな暗闇(くらやみ)を抱(かか)えていたなど、勇者(ゆうしゃ)は夢想(むそう)だにしなかった。
example.english: Novel: “The hero couldn’t have even dreamt that he was carrying such darkness in his heart.”

english_grammar.title: がてら
english_grammar.explanation: on the occasion of, while … as well, while … (one is) at it, during, along the way
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ がてら Noun + がてら,
english_grammar.attention: Some Japanese use it in a way similar to ながら, like in ドライブがてら話し合った
english_grammar.about: がてら is a neologism that is used in the same way as an adverbial particle in modern Japanese, and will connect to the conjunctive form of verbs, and to nouns. It is similar to ながら in that it will be translated as 'while (A), (B)', 'during (A), (B)', or 'on the occasion of (A)'. When (A) is a noun, it will almost always be a noun that signifies some sort of physical movement. 弟(おとうと)を駅(えき)から迎(むか)えがてらに、今夜(こんや)の夕飯(ゆうはん)の買(か)い物(もの)をしに行(い)く。 I will go grocery shopping for tonight's dinner on my way to pick up my brother as well. 友達(ともだち)の家(いえ)に行(い)きがてら、近(ちか)くの神社(じんじゃ)にお参(まい)りに行(い)った。 While going to my friend's house, I went to pray at the shrine nearby as well. ワンちゃんの散歩(さんぽ)がてらに、ペットショップにいってくる。 While taking my dog on a walk, I am going to go to the pet store as well. 運動(うんどう)がてらに会社(かいしゃ)まで自転車(じてんしゃ)で行(い)くことにした。 On the occasion of exercising, I decided to ride the bicycle to work. Unlike ながら, がてら focuses more on (A) being a good opportunity which can be utilized or taken advantage of in order to do (B). Fun Factがてら is a vocal change of がてり, which originally comes from an abbreviation of the conjunctive form of 糅(か)つ, かて 'to mix together', and あり. So かてあり was abbreviated to かてり, which then went through sound changes to がてり and がてら. However, the 'being mixed together' meaning is still kept in the modern day nuance of this grammar point.

example.japanese: 「イノシシの散歩(さんぽ)がてら、ちょっとコンビニまで行(い)ってきます。」
example.english: “While taking a walk with my pet wild boar, I will go to the convenience store as well.”

example.japanese: 「お花見(はなみ)がてら、公園(こうえん)を散歩(さんぽ)しよう。」
example.english: “Let's take a walk in the park while viewing the cherry blossoms as well.”

example.japanese: 《回顧録(かいころく)》ヒースロー空港(くうこう)への移動(いどう)がてら、観光(かんこう)スポットを訪(おとず)れた。
example.english: Memoirs: “I visited some tourist attractions on my way to Heathrow Airport as well.”

example.japanese: 「帰(かえ)りがてら手紙(てがみ)出(だ)してくるね。」
example.english: I’ll post the letter on my way home as well.

example.japanese: 《友達(ともだち)との話(はなし)》「じゃあ買(か)い物(もの)がてら、紅葉(こうよう)を見(み)に行(い)かないか？」
example.english: Chat between friends: “So, why don't we view the autumn leaves while shopping as well?”

synonym.explanation: while you are at it, on the occasion
while ~ing, during, as

english_grammar.title: んが為(ため)に
english_grammar.explanation: in order to, to, for the purpose of
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］+ ん + が + ため（に） Verb［ない］+ ん + が + ため + の + Noun Exceptions: する ￫ せんがため
english_grammar.attention: Exception: する → せん
english_grammar.about: んがため is a grammar pattern used when indicating that something is being done 'for the purpose of (A)', or 'with (A) as the goal'. ん comes from an abbreviation of む, which is a classical auxiliary verb used to show intent or strong will in the same way as う and よう in modern Japanese. ん is then followed by が, and the noun ため 'sake', or 'purpose'. ん connects to the indeterminate form of verbs (ない stem). Either の or に will usually come after んがため, depending on whether it is followed directly by a noun, or a statement linking to a verb. 彼(かれ)は若(わか)い頃(ころ)からお金(かね)を貯(た)めんがために、色々(いろいろ)と我慢(がまん)してきた。 In order to save up money, he has sacrificed a lot since he was young. 私(わたし)の両親(ちょうしん)たちは私(わたし)たちの夢(ゆめ)を叶(かな)えんがために、毎日(まいにち)休(やす)まずに仕事(しごと)をしてきました。 In order to fulfill our dreams, my parents have worked everyday without any rest. こんなことはしたくないが大会(たいかい)で勝(か)たんがためのことだ。 I don't want to do such a thing, but in order to win this competition. 売(う)れ残(のこ)りの商品(しょうひん)を売(う)らんがための作戦(さくせん)を考(かんが)えたが何(なに)も思(おも)いつかなかった。 I tried to come up with a strategy in order to sell the unsold goods, but came up with nothing. The meaning of む is kept in ん, as this grammar structure will imply the speaker's will to achieve the goal of (A). As む expresses intent, the verb that ん is attached to must be something that can be controlled by the speaker. Caution Like most classical structures that interact with する, the more old-fashioned せ will be used as the base, rather than し. 彼女(かのじょ)は自分(じぶん)の作戦(さくせん)を成功(せいこう)させんがために、友達(ともだち)を裏切(うらぎ)った。 She betrayed her friends in order to make her plans work.

example.japanese: 《記事(きじ)》その会社(かいしゃ)は不(ふ)良品(りょうひん)を売(う)らんがために、高齢者(こうれいしゃ)の弱(よわ)みにつけ込(こ)んだ。
example.english: Article: That company took advantage of the elderly in order to sell defective products.

example.japanese: ソクラテス「生(い)きんがために食(く)え、食(く)わんがために生(い)きるな」
example.english: Socrates: “Thou shouldst eat to live; not live to eat.”

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》力(りょく)の指輪(ゆびわ)を得(え)んがための戦争(せんそう)が始(はじ)まった。
example.english: Novel: The war for the purpose of acquiring the ring of power has begun.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》魔王(まおう)の軍(ぐん)よりこの世界(せかい)を救(すく)わんがためにドワーフと人間(にんげん)とエルフとの協力(きょうりょく)が必要(ひつよう)である。
example.english: Novel: The cooperation of dwarves, humans, and elves is needed in order to save the world from the army of the Demon King.

example.japanese: 《時代(じだい)小説(しょうせつ)》A：「我々(われわれ)が失敗(しっぱい)したら？」B：「そうなれば、みずからの身(み)を守(まも)らんがため退却(たいきゃく)を余儀(よぎ)なくされるときがくるかもしれぬ。」
example.english: A historical novel, A: “And what if we fail?” B: “If that happens, the time may come when we will be forced to retreat in order to protect ourselves. ”

synonym.explanation: for, for the sake of, in order to
for, for the sake of, in order to

english_grammar.title: いかん〜ず
english_grammar.explanation: regardless of (whatever … is), irrespective of (whatever … is)
english_grammar.structure: Noun + (の) + いかん + に関わらず(1) (1) によらず、を問わず
english_grammar.attention: いかん is a formal written expression meaning “how"/ “in what way”
english_grammar.about: When the noun いかん 'how', or 'what' is paired with a verb negated with the classical auxiliary verb ず, it will commonly be translated as 'regardless of (A), (B)', or 'irrespective of (A), (B)'. The verbs used for this construction are restricted to 関(かか)わらず 'without relation', によらず 'without approaching', and を問(と)わず 'without questioning. いかん〜ず come after a noun followed by the case marking particle の. 天候(てんこう)のいかんに関(かか)わらず、明日(あした)のコンサートは予定(よてい)通(どお)りに開催(かいさい)されます。 Regardless of the weather, the concert tomorrow will be held as scheduled. 予約日(よやくび)の24時間(じかん)前(まえ)であれば、理由(りゆう)のいかんによらず、キャンセル料(りょう)を取(と)られずにキャンセルをすることができます。 Cancellations may be made 24 hours prior to the appointment date, regardless of the reason without incurring a cancellation fee. 未経験者(みけいけんしゃ)や経験者(けいけんしゃ)のいかんを問(と)わず、ここで働(はたら)く前(まえ)には新規(しんき)研修(けんしゅう)を受(う)けてもらいます。 Regardless of whether you are experienced or not, we require everyone to undergo training before working here. いかん〜ず is a formal grammar pattern that is used primarily to express that (B) will not be affected by (A), even if it is something that would usually be expected. Because of this, 'without taking (A) into account' is another fairly accurate translation of the nuance.

example.japanese: 《ライセンス契約(けいやく)》当社(とうしゃ)は事情(じじょう)のいかんに関(かか)わらず、本品(ほんぴん)の不適切(ふてきせつ)な使用(しよう)によって生(しょう)じたいかなる損害(そんがい)については責任(せきにん)を負(お)いません。
example.english: License agreement: The company will not be held responsible for any damage caused due to the improper usage of the product regardless of (what) the circumstances (are).

example.japanese: 《販売店(はんばいてん)の返品(へんぴん)ポリシー》商品(しょうひん)到着後(とうちゃくご)２週間(しゅうかん)以内(いない)であれば、理由(りゆう)のいかんによらず、自由(じゆう)に返品(へんぴん)することが可能(かのう)です。
example.english: Return policy of a store: It is possible to return any product, free of charge, regardless of (what) the reason (is) if the return falls within two weeks of the delivery of the product.

example.japanese: 《学校(がっこう)の方針(ほうしん)》本校(ほんこう)はプログラム及(およ)び活動(かつどう)などでは、宗教(しゅうきょう)・国籍等(こくせきとう)のいかんを問(と)わず、いかなる差別(さべつ)も許(ゆる)しません。
example.english: School policy: The school will not discriminate regardless of religion or ethnic origin, and so on, in its programs or activities.

example.japanese: 試験(しけん)は一部(いちぶ)の試験(しけん)科目(かもく)でも合格点(ごうかくてん)に達(たっ)しなければ、他(た)の試験(しけん)科目(かもく)の成績(せいせき)のいかんに関(かか)わらず、不(ふ)合格(ごうかく)となります。
example.english: If the student does not achieve a passing mark in any part of the exam, then regardless of (what) the results of the other parts (are) the test will be considered failed.

example.japanese: 《登録(とうろく)確認(かくにん)のメール》このメッセージに返信(へんしん)しないようお願(ねが)いいたします。返信(へんしん)いただいてもこちらのメールアドレスは送信(そうしん)専用(せんよう)なので内容(ないよう)のいかんに関(かか)わらずお答(こた)えできません。ご了承(りょうしょう)ください。
example.english: A registration confirmation email: We kindly ask you to not reply to this message. Even if you do so, this mail address is dedicated only to sending, therefore we will not be able to answer, regardless of (what) the contents of the message (are). Thank you for your understanding.

english_grammar.title: う・よう + にも～ない
english_grammar.explanation: cannot... even if one wants/tries, would like but cannot, wants/tries but cannot
english_grammar.structure: Verb1［おう］ + にも + Verb1［できる］［ない］ Verb［おう］ + にも + (Reason) Phrase
english_grammar.attention: Generally used with にも
english_grammar.about: When combined with either of the auxiliary verbs of volition, う or よう, にも～ない conveys that 'despite wanting to (A), it can't be done'. There are usually some circumstances as to why (A) cannot be done that are beyond the control of the speaker. The same verb will be repeated in both the volitional form and the negated potential form. This means that the literal meaning of this grammar pattern is 'Even if I went to (A), I can't (A)'. This 'went to' implies the 'attempt' or 'will' on behalf of the speaker. もう夜(よる)遅(おそ)いから電車(でんしゃ)もバスも走(はし)ってないし、全然(ぜんぜん)タクシーも通(とお)らないし、帰(かえ)ろうにも帰(かえ)れない。 Since it is late at night, there aren't any trains or buses, and I haven't seen a taxi, so I can't go home even if I wanted to. 色々(いろいろ)と仕事(しごと)のことで悩(なや)んでいるから、毎晩(まいばん)寝(ね)ようにも寝(ね)れない。 I can't sleep even if I wanted to because I am worried about a lot of things regarding work. 昨日(きのう)出(で)てきた釣竿(つりざお)を買(か)いたいけど、高(たか)いから買(か)おうにも買えない。 I want to buy the new fishing rod that came out yesterday, but since it is expensive, I can't buy it even if I wanted to. Caution As opposed to the similar に～ない grammar point that pairs with verbs in dictionary form, ようにも～ない tends to refer more to physical reasons for why something cannot be done. に～ない on the other hand is often used to illustrate mental limitations. 行(い)きたくないけど、先輩(せんぱい)に誘(さそ)われたら断(こと)るに断(こと)れない。 I don't want to go, but since my senpai invited me, I can't say no even if I wanted to. (Mental reason) 携帯(けいたい)を無(な)くしてしまったから、上司(じょうし)に連絡(れんらく)しようにもできない。 Since I lost my phone, I can't call my boss even if I wanted to. (Physical reason)

example.japanese: 亡(な)き妻(つま)の笑顔(えがお)は忘(わす)れようにも忘(わす)れられない。
example.english: I cannot forget the smile of my late wife, even if I try to.

example.japanese: 藤沼(ふじぬま)探偵(たんてい)：「彼(かれ)が犯人(はんにん)だと思(おも)うけど、逮捕(たいほ)しようにも、証拠(しょうこ)がないんだ。」
example.english: Detective Fujinuma: “I think that he is the criminal, but even if I try to arrest him, I have no proof.”

example.japanese: アクション映画(えいが)、バスの運転手(うんてんしゅ)は警察官(けいさつかん)に：「時速(じそく)が８０キロを下回(したまわ)るとバスに隠(かく)された爆弾(ばくだん)が爆発(ばくはつ)するから減速(げんそく)しようにもできないわ。」」
example.english: Action movie, the bus driver to the policeman: “If the speed falls below 80 km/h, the bomb hidden in the bus will explode, so I cannot slow down even though I want to!”

example.japanese: コメディ、語(かた)り手(て)：「ペイン軍曹(ぐんそう)は戦(たたか)おうにも相手(あいて)がいなくて困(こま)っている。とっくにすべての敵(てき)を殺(ころ)したからだ。」
example.english: Comedy, narrator: “Sergeant Pain was greatly troubled because even though he wanted to fight, he had no opponents. He already killed them all a long time ago.”

example.japanese: プロジェクトについて心配(しんぱい)するあまり、寝(ね)ようにも寝(ね)られない。
example.english: I am so worried about the project that I cannot sleep even if I try.

synonym.explanation: no matter how

english_grammar.title: く + もなんともない
english_grammar.explanation: not... or anything, not at all, not, by no means, definitely not, nothing like that
english_grammar.structure: ［い］Adjective［く］+ もなんともない
english_grammar.about: When paired with the conjunctive form of い-Adjectives, く, もなんともない is often translated as 'not (A) or anything', or 'definitely not (A)'. This is a combination of the adverbial particle も and the adverb 何(なん)ともない 'doesn't amount to anything'. なんともない is often grouped with other negative structures in order to show that the thing it is linked to is not a large amount or considerable extent. まだまだだな、お前(まえ)のパンチを喰(く)らっても痒(かゆ)くもなんともないぞ。 You still have a long way to go. Even after getting punched by you, it doesn't even itch. ここで売(う)ってるもんは全(すべ)て珍(めずら)しいとかって言(い)ってるけど、実(じつ)は珍(めずら)しくもなんともないんだよ。他(ほか)の店(みせ)に行(い)くと5千円(せんえん)イカで売(う)ってるよ。 They are saying that everything they are selling is rare, but actually they are not rare at all. If you go to other stores, you can see that they sell them for under 5 thousand yen. ホラー映画(えいが)にしたら怖(こわ)くもなんともない、むしろちょっとコメディーっぽいかも。 As a horror movie, this is not scary at all. Matter of fact, it's more like a comedy movie. In many cases, 何(なん)ともない illustrates that the extent of the thing that it follows is not sufficient to cause a problem. Because of this ～くもなんともない will often be used in sentences where (A) is something that could potentially be an issue, but the speaker is expressing that it has not reached that point, or does not go that far. Because of this, ～くもなんともない is frequently used with adjectives that describe sensations or emotions.
