Caution This structure is also commonly used with the auxiliary adjective たい, for showing that someone 'doesn't want to do (A)'. 私(わたし)はジェットコースターとかが苦手(にがて)だから遊園地(ゆうえんち)に行(い)きたくもなんともない。 Since I dislike roller coasters, I don't want to go to amusement parks at all. 彼(かれ)のことは聞(き)きたくもなんともない。 I don't want to hear about him at all.

example.japanese: 《ミツバが転(ころ)んだ》エマ：「大丈夫(だいじょうぶ)？」ミツバ：「へいきだよ。」 エマ：「血(ち)、出(で)てるよ。」 ミツバ：「でも、痛(いた)くもなんともないよ。」
example.english: Mitsuba has fallen over, Emma: “Are you ok?”Mitsuba: “I’m ok!”Emma: “You're bleeding!”Mitsuba: “But, it doesn’t hurt at all.”

example.japanese: 「もうやめない？その話(はなし)。面白(おもしろ)くもなんともないから！」
example.english: “Won't you stop (talking about) that topic? Because it is not interesting at all!”

example.japanese: 《東京(とうきょう)観光(かんこう)》コマリ：「東京(とうきょう)スカイツリーは本当(ほんとう)に大(おお)きいねえ。」ヒカゲ：「私(わした)には珍(めずら)しくもなんともないけど。初(はじ)めての人(ひと)は驚(おどろ)くよね。」
example.english: Tokyo sightseeing, Komari: “Tokyo Skytree is really big!” Hikage: “It’s not unusual for me at all. But, it’s amazing for first-timers. ”

example.japanese: 「噂(うわさ)なんて全然(ぜんぜん)知(し)りたくもなんともないけど。」
example.english: “I don’t want to know any rumors at all.”

example.japanese: 《ホラー映画(えいが)のレビュー》「ゾンビ映画(えいが)にしては怖(こわ)くもなんともない。それでも面白(おもしろ)いからハマる。」
example.english: Review of a horror movie: “For a zombie movie, it is not scary at all. But still, one can get into it since it’s interesting”

synonym.explanation: not at all, by no means, definitely not, nothing like that, not really

english_grammar.title: (Verb) + だに
english_grammar.explanation: just, even just, even merely
english_grammar.structure: Verb + だに
english_grammar.about: As mentioned in our だに + しない grammar point, だに is an adverbial particle that shares a similar meaning to さえ and すら 'even', but is more commonly found in classical literature. It presents (A) as 'minimum' or 'light' examples, and therefore implies that anything greater than (A) would be more than can be handled, imagined, etc. In this use, it is often translated as 'just (A)', or 'merely (A)'. だに will appear directly following verbs in their dictionary form. あんな地獄(じごく)みたいな職場(しょくば)にまた明日(あした)も行(い)かないとって考(かんが)えるだに気(き)が重(おも)くなる。 Even just the thought of having to go back to that hellish workplace again tomorrow makes me feel depressed. 彼(かれ)のことを思(おも)い出(だ)すだに、悲(かな)しくなります。 Just remembering about him makes me sad. 部長(ぶちょう)からもらった仕事(しごと)の量(りょう)を見(み)るだに、やる気(き)が失(う)せる。 I lose all motivation by just looking at the amount of work my boss gave me. This is a formal structure, and will be seen far more often in literature than it will be spoken. Despite this, it is actually quite common in anime and manga when characters are being dramatic. As (A) presents a 'minimum', it will often be a word which expresses something that depicts the difference between reality and fantasy. For example, if (A) was 想像(そうぞう)するだに 'even in my imagination'. The 'minimum' is the imagination, for which the opposite end of the spectrum would be 'in reality'.

example.japanese: 《記事(きじ)》「人間(にんげん)にとってはダニを食(た)べるのは考(かんが)えるだにおぞましい。」
example.english: Article: “For a human being, just thinking about eating ticks is repulsive.”

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》「クトゥルフは見(み)るだに正気(しょうき)を失(うしな)ってしまうほどたいへん恐(おそ)ろしい化物(ばけもの)であるらしい。」
example.english: Novel: “It is said that Cthulhu is a monster so awfully scary that one goes mad just by seeing it.”

example.japanese: 《記事(きじ)》「その映画(えいが)のワンシーンを思(おも)い出(だ)すだに、胸(むね)が痛(いた)くなります。」
example.english: Article: “Just recalling that movie scene breaks my heart.”

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》「ただ、その事故(じこ)の話(はなし)を聞(き)くだに古傷(ふるきず)が疼(うず)く。」
example.english: Novel: “Just hearing a conversation about that accident makes my old wound throb with pain.”

example.japanese: 《記事(きじ)》「太陽(たいよう)の中心(ちゅうしん)の温度(おんど)は想像(そうぞう)するだに恐(おそ)ろしい。」
example.english: Article: “Just imagining the temperature at the center of the sun is terrifying.”

english_grammar.title: ～なり～なり
english_grammar.explanation: or, either or
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］(A) + なり + Verb［る］(B) + なり + する Noun (A) + （Particle(1)）+ なり + Noun (B) + （Particle(1)）+ なり Noun (A) + なり + Noun (B) + なり + （Particle(1)） Verb［る］+ なり + WH-Word + （Particle）+ なり + する Noun + （Particle(1)）+ なり + WH-Word + （Particle(1)）+ なり (1) Particles を and が cannot be used in this case
english_grammar.about: When the classical adverbial particle なり is used in lists, it expresses that each item within that list is a possibility, but that one particular thing will be or needs to be chosen. This use of なり will indicate that either (A) or (B) is fine, but anything else that falls within that same category is probably fine too. Due to this, it is non-exhaustive. なり is a fairly polite construction and will appear after either verbs in their dictionary forms, or nouns that may or may not be followed by another particle. This is in cases where that particle is giving important information involved in the 'choice'. An example of this would be に for marking a location. もうちょっと待機(たいき)しないといけなさそうだから、タバコを吸(す)うなり弁当(べんとう)食(た)べるなりして待(ま)ってな。準備(じゅんび)ができたら呼(よ)ぶからゆっくりしてな。 It seems like we have to wait a little longer, so why don't you go smoke some cigarettes or eat your lunch and wait. Once everything is ready, I'll let you know so take your time. どうぞ受(う)け取(と)ってください。いらないなら売(う)るなり捨(す)てるなりしてもらっても結構(けっこう)ですので。 Please take this. If you don't want it you can sell it or throw it away. 遅(おく)れるなら電話(でんわ)なりメールなりするのが社会人(しゃかいじん)としての常識(じょうしき)じゃないのか？！ Isn't it common sense as a member of society to call or text if you are going to be late?! なんでお前(まえ)はいつもそう一人(ひとり)でなんでも解決(かいけつ)しようとするんだ？俺(おれ)になり高橋(たかはし)になり相談(そうだん)してくれればいいのに！ Why do you always try to solve everything on your own? You should come talk to me or Takahashi! As with all adverbial particles, なり cannot follow either が or を. Caution This emphasis on (A) なり (B) なり presenting lists from which something will be chosen is what differentiates it from similar structures such as など and や. Due to this, なり will not be used to mean 'such as', but only for 'either, or' statements.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》勇者(ゆうしゃ)が魔王(まおう)に：「仲間(なかま)にだけは手(て)を出(だ)さないでください。俺(おれ)を煮(に)るなり焼(や)くなり好(す)きにしていい！」
example.english: A novel, Hero to Demon King: “Please don’t lay a hand on my friends! Instead, you can do whatever you like to me!” [lit. boil me or grill me]

example.japanese: 《怒(おこ)った親(おや)が子供(こども)に》「部屋(へや)を漫画(まんが)本(ぼん)だらけにしないで！読(よ)まないものは売(う)るなり捨(す)てるなりして片(かた)づけなさい！」
example.english: Angry parent to a child: “Don’t scatter the manga all over the room! Either sell or throw away the things you don’t read!

example.japanese: 《父親(ちちおや)は娘(むすめ)に》「孤独(こどく)を感(かん)じていたのなら、俺(おれ)になり母(かあ)さんになり電話(でんわ)くれればよかったのに。」
example.english: Father to daughter: “If you were feeling lonely, you should have called me or mom…”

example.japanese: 《友達(ともだち)にアドバイスする》「黙(だま)ってばかりいないでよ。喧嘩(けんか)するなり文句(もんく)を言(い)うなりしてみたら？」
example.english: Giving advice to a friend: “Don’t be quiet all the time! Why don't you try to argue or complain?”

example.japanese: 《怪我(けが)をしている友達(ともだち)にアドバイスする》「ケガをしてるよ！絆創膏(ばんそうこう)を貼(は)るなり包帯(ほうたい)を巻(ま)くなりした方(ほう)がいいんじゃないかな！」
example.english: Giving advice to and injured friend: “You are injured! I think you’d better put a band-aid on or bandage it.”

synonym.explanation: Things like ~ and ~
Among other things, For example, Such as
Or

english_grammar.title: ないでもない
english_grammar.explanation: kind of, might, slightly, it’s not (impossible) that, somewhat, in some respects
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］+ （もの）+ でも(1) + ない (1)では
english_grammar.about: ないでもない, and なくもない are structures that have the literal meaning of 'to not not be (A)', and are used to express that something is 'a little (A)', or 'kinda (A)'. These structures are used primarily when the speaker can neither confirm or deny (A), but may also be used simply when not wanting to directly disagree with something that another person has said. Both ないでもない and なくもない may be used after either the negated form of verbs, or nouns followed by the case marking particle が. あいつが悪(わる)いとは思(おも)わないでもないけど、お前(まえ)にも少(すこ)しは非(ひ)があると思(おも)うよ。 I kind of think he is in the wrong, but I think you are a little at fault too. まあ、そう言(い)われてみれば鳥(とり)に見(み)えなくもないけど... Well, when you put it like that, it kind of looks like a bird… 彼女(かのじょ)が謝(あやま)ってきたら、彼女(かのじょ)がしたことを許(ゆる)す気(き)がないでもない。 If she comes apologizing, I might forgive her for what she's done. ピアノを弾(ひ)くのは好(す)きだが、ピアノのレッスンをやめようと思(おも)うことがなくもない。 I like to play the piano, but there are times when I kind of think about quitting piano lessons. ないでもない and なくもない are completely interchangeable, with the primary difference simply being that なくもない is less frequently used. Additionally, ないものでもない may also be seen, but just like なくもない, it is far less common. あなたの考(かんが)えが分(わ)からないものでもないけど、そういうことはあまり口(くち)に出(だ)さないほうがいいと思(おも)うよ。 I kind of understand your opinion, but I don't think you should say things like that out loud.

example.japanese: 先輩(せんぱい)「あの雲(くも)を見(み)ろよ。シマウマみたいに見(み)えるぞ。」後輩(こうはい)「まあシマウマに見(み)えないでもないですね。」
example.english: Senpai: “Look at that cloud! It looks like a zebra.”Kouhai: “Well, it kind of looks like a zebra.”

example.japanese: 《友達(ともだち)との話(はなし)》ちよ「猫(ねこ)が好(す)きじゃないの？かわいくない？」さかき「猫(ねこ)はかわいいと思(おも)わないでもないけど、噛(か)むしひっかくしできるだけ避(さ)けるよ。」
example.english: Chat between friends, Chiyo: “Don’t you like cats? Aren’t they cute?”Sakaki: “I think that they are kind of cute, but they bite and scratch so I try to avoid them as much as possible.”

example.japanese: 《友人(ゆうじん)に文句(もんく)を言(い)う》「最近(さいきん)、両親(りょうしん)はうちの子犬(こいぬ)に夢中(むちゅう)だよ。まあその気持(きも)ちはわからないでもないけど。とても可愛(かわい)らしいから。」
example.english: Complaining to a friend: “Recently, my parents are all about our puppy! I kind of understand them though. It’s pretty adorable.”

example.japanese: ケイマさん「クラス会(かい)は来(く)るか？」ユリさん「これには興味(きょうみ)ない。あら、ケイマ君(くん)がおごってくれるなら考(かんが)えないでもないけど？」
example.english: Keima: “Are you coming to the class reunion?”Yuri: “Not interested. Oh, I might consider it if you treat me to dinner, though.”

example.japanese: 「なんとなく彼(かれ)が言(い)った話(はなし)には欠陥(けっかん)や問題(もんだい)がたくさんあるような気(き)がしないでもないが、いってくれないよりマシだ。」
example.english: “I kind of feel that there are many gaps and problems in his story, but it is better than nothing.”

synonym.explanation: you could say, you might say

english_grammar.title: もさることながら
english_grammar.explanation: it is a fact that、 but, even more than, it goes without saying, not only but also,
english_grammar.structure: Noun + もさることながら
english_grammar.about: もさることながら is a construction in Japanese that is often translated as 'it goes without saying that (A), but (B)', or 'not only (A), but (B) too'. This expression is a combination of the adverbial particle も, the pre-noun adjectival さる 'particular', or 'certain', the noun 事(こと) 'thing', and the conjunction particle ながら 'while'. Due to this, the more literal translation is simply 'while (A) is also of particular merit, (B)'. This literal translation will be helpful to remember, as もさることながら will always present (A) as important, but (B) as even more important than that. もさることながら will be attached to the end of nouns and noun phrases. あのブランドが出(だ)す商品(しょうひん)もさることながら、マーケティングも素晴(すば)らしい。 It is a fact that the products that the brand produces are amazing, but also how they market them. このパソコンは機能(きのう)もさることながら、デザインもいい。 It is a fact that the features of this computer are good, but also the design. 日本語(にほんご)を勉強(べんきょう)するにおいて漢字(かんじ)もさることながら、文法(ぶんぽう)も勉強(べんきょう)しなくてはいけない。 When it comes to studying Japanese, it is a fact that you need to study kanji, but also grammar too. As (B) is being emphasized in sentences that use this grammar structure, it is common to see other expressions of emphasis combined with もさることながら. Some examples include さらに 'additionally', なにより 'more than anything', and 以上(いじょう) 'above that'.

example.japanese: 《経営(けいえい)会議(かいぎ)》社長(しゃちょう)「競争(きょうそう)が激(はげ)しいからマーケティング予算(よさん)を上(あ)げよう。」部長(ぶちょう)「マーケティングもさることながら製品(せいひん)品質(ひんしつ)も重要(じゅうよう)なのではないでしょうか？」
example.english: Management meeting, company president: “The competition is intense, so we will increase the marketing budget.”Head director: “It is a fact that marketing is important, but isn’t the product quality too?”

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》だが、この国(くに)の強(つよ)さは、自国(じこく)の単独(たんどく)力量(りきりょう)もさることながら、同盟国(どうめいこく)の多(おお)さにある。
example.english: Novel: However, it is a fact that the strength of this country lies in its power, but it also has numerous allies.

example.japanese: 入学(にゅうがく)試験(しけん)を受(う)けることは、当人(とうにん)の苦痛(くつう)もさることながら、家族(かぞく)にも、大(おお)きな心理的(しんりてき)負担(ふたん)を与(あた)えます。
example.english: It is a fact that taking an entrance exam is stressful for the person concerned, but it also places a psychological burden on the family.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)を勉強(べんきょう)するとき、熱心(ねっしん)さもさることながら、長(なが)い目(め)で見(み)て一貫性(いっかんせい)も重要(じゅうよう)な要素(ようそ)である。
example.english: When learning Japanese, it is a fact that enthusiasm is an important factor, but in the long term - consistency too.

example.japanese: 《伝記(でんき)》選手(せんしゅ)としての彼(かれ)の素晴(すば)らしい才能(さいのう)もさることながら、何(なに)より信望(しんぼう)や指導力(しどうりょく)が成功(せいこう)の要因(よういん)となった。
example.english: Biography: It is a fact that he has great ability as a player, but more than anything, his popularity and leadership skills were the cause of his success.

synonym.explanation: It is a fact that ~, There is no doubt that

english_grammar.title: ものと思(おも)っていた
english_grammar.explanation: was under the impression that, (always) the thought used to think
english_grammar.structure: Verb + ものと思っていた ［い］Adjective + ものと思っていた ［な］Adjective + な + ものと思っていた Noun + の + ものと思っていた
english_grammar.attention: sometimes ものだと思っていた is used. もんと思っていた is more casual variant
english_grammar.about: 物(もの)と思(おも)う is made up of the noun 物(もの) 'thing', the case marking particle と, and the う-Verb 思(おも)う 'to think'. Regular translations include 'to believe that (A)', or 'to have confidence that (A)'. In a broader sense, this grammar pattern is just making use of one of the meanings of 物(もの) as being something abstract that the speaker can reliably determine has all of the qualities of something concrete. When 思(おも)う appears in the past tense as ものと思(おも)っていた, the most common translation is 'as I had believed was true of (A)', or 'I was under the impression that (A)'. As もの is a noun, this pattern may follow any word in its attributive form. え...まだ晩御飯(ばんごはん)食(た)べてないの？てっきり帰(かえ)りに食(た)べてくるものと思(おも)っていたから、あなたの分(ぶん)は作(つく)ってないですよ。 What… You haven't eaten dinner yet? I was totally under the impression that you were going to grab something on the way back home, so I did not make anything for you. 私(わたし)の母(はは)は猫(ねこ)が好(す)きではないものと思(おも)っていたが、聞(き)いてみたらただ猫(ねこ)アレルギーがあるそうだ。 I was under the impression that my mother did not like cats, but after asking her, I found out that it's just that she is allergic to them. ゲートボールは老人(ろうじん)しかやらないものと思(おも)っていたが、最近(さいきん)は若者(わかもの)の間(あいだ)で流行(はや)っているらしい。 I was under the impression that gateball was something only old people played, but it seems to be popular among young people these days. As ものと思(おも)っていた highlights an impression of something that was true, contradictory statements will often appear in part (B) of the sentence following structures like が or けど.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は彼(かれ)が拒否(きょひ)するものと思(おも)っていたが、予想(よそう)とは逆(ぎゃく)に彼(かれ)は賛成(さんせい)した。
example.english: I was under the impression that he would disagree, but contrary to expectations he agreed.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》勇者(ゆうしゃ)：「ドラゴンは伝説(でんせつ)のものと思(おも)っていたが…｡」小(ちい)さいドラゴン：「ガオー！」
example.english: Novel: “I was under the impression that the dragons were things of legends.”Small dragon: “Rarrrr!”

example.japanese: 子供(こども)の頃(ころ)、森(もり)の中(なか)で迷(まよ)った。てっきりこのまま死(し)ぬものと思(おも)っていた（が救(すく)われた。）
example.english: When I was a child, I lost my way in the forest. I was under the impression that I would die like this. (but I was saved)

example.japanese: てっきり漢字(かんじ)を学(まな)ぶのは退屈(たいくつ)なものと思(おも)っていた。（がそうではない。）
example.english: I was under the impression that learning kanji would be boring. (But it is not.)

example.japanese: A：「彼女(かのじょ)が負(ま)けたなんて驚(おどろ)いたな。きっと勝(か)つものと思(おも)ってたけど。」B：「わたしもそう思(おも)ってた。」
example.english: A: “Surprisingly, she lost. I was under the impression that she would win.”B: “I thought so too.”

synonym.explanation: think that, believe that, expect that, have confidence that, absolutely

english_grammar.title: でなくてなんだろう
english_grammar.explanation: if … is not … then what is?
english_grammar.structure: Noun + でなくてなん + だろう(1)（か） (1)であろう
english_grammar.about: でなくてなんだろう is a formal pattern that appears following nouns that the speaker is certain is something which is true. It can be translated as 'if it's not (A), then what is it?'. でなくてなんだろう is a combination of the conjunctive form of the auxiliary verb だ, で, the conjunctive form of the い-Adjective ない, なくて, the prefix なん 'what', and the volitional form of だ, だろう. As can be seen, the literal and common translations are quite similar. あの子(こ)が新(あたら)しいってだけでいじめるられている。あれはパワハラでなくてなんだろう。 She is getting bullied just because she is new. If that is not power harassment, then what is? 俺(おれ)はこんなに夜(よる)遅(おそ)くまでタダ働(はたら)きをしている。俺(おれ)は社畜(しゃちく)でなくてなんだろう。 I am working late for free. If I am not a corporate slave, then what is? Occasionally でなくてなんだろう will be followed by the sentence-ending particle か. This just emphasizes the point further, without changing the nuance. 私(わたし)の家(いえ)だけ浸水(しんすい)しなかった。これが奇跡(きせき)でなくてなんだろうか。 My house was the only one that did not get submerged. If this is not a miracle, then what is? 説明欄(せつめいらん)には新品(しんぴん)だと書(か)いてあったのに届(とど)いた商品(しょうひん)は傷(きず)だらけだった。これは詐欺(さぎ)でなくてなんだろうか。 In the description, it was written that it was brand new, but the product that arrived was covered in scratches. If this is not a scam, then what is? In most cases, でなくてなんだろう will be used to ask a rhetorical question, or to strongly assert the speaker's own opinion about something.

example.japanese: 《随筆(ずいひつ)》もう聞(き)こえないと言(い)われた私(わたし)の耳(みみ)は人工(じんこう)内耳(ないじ)のおかげでまた聞(き)こえるようになった。これが奇跡(きせき)でなくてなんだろう。
example.english: Essay: “I was told that I would never hear again, but thanks to the cochlear implants I can hear once again. If this is not a miracle then what is?”

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》外国(がいこく)での休暇(きゅうか)の途中(とちゅう)で、長年(ながねん)連絡(れんらく)が取(と)れなかった幼馴染(おさななじみ)に偶然(ぐうぜん)出会(であ)うなんて運命(うんめい)でなくてなんだろうか。
example.english: Novel: If meeting a childhood friend you lost contact with years ago, in the middle of holidays abroad is not fate, then what is?

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》飯(めし)がうまくて、楽(たの)しい仲間(なかま)がいて、その上(うえ)、近(ちか)くには温泉(おんせん)がある。これが楽園(らくえん)でなくてなんだろうか？
example.english: Novel: There is good food, good company, and what is more, a hot spring is nearby. If this is not a paradise then what is?

example.japanese: 《記事(きじ)》たけださんはひとり親(おや)であるばかりに昇進(しょうしん)が見送(みおく)られた。これが差別(さべつ)でなくてなんであろうか。
example.english: Article：Mr. Takeda has been refused promotion just because he is a single parent. If this is not discrimination, then what is?

example.japanese: 《レビュー》「「遥(はる)かな町(まち)へ」という漫画(まんが)を初(はじ)めて読(よ)んで涙(なみだ)が出(で)るほど感動(かんどう)した。このような漫画(まんが)が傑作(けっさく)でなくなんだろう？」
example.english: Review: “When I read the manga titled “A distant Neighborhood” for the first time, it moved me to tears. If manga like this is not a masterpiece then what is?”

english_grammar.title: はさておき
english_grammar.explanation: (leaving/putting) aside, apart
english_grammar.structure: Noun + はさておき(1) Phrase + かどうか(2) + はさておき(1) (1) はさておいて (2) か
english_grammar.about: はさておき is an expression which is often translated as 'leaving aside (A)', or 'apart from (A)'. It is a combination of the adverbial particle は, the conjunction さて 'now' (moving on to a new thing), and the conjunctive form of 置(お)く 'to place', or 'to leave', 置(お)き. The more literal 'now putting aside (A)' may also be used. This structure will be used when (A) is a topic that the speaker would like to move away from, in order to discuss something more important. はさておき will primarily directly follow nouns. みんなの感想(かんそう)はさておき、私(わたし)は美味(おい)しいと思(おも)ったよ。 Aside from everyone else's opinions, I thought that it was delicious. そんなことはさておき、仕事(しごと)をちゃちゃっと終(お)わらせて早(はや)く帰(かえ)りましょうよ。 That aside, let's quickly finish work and go home. However, it is also common to see はさておき following a phrase that ends with かどうか. This can be translated as 'disregarding whether it is (A) or not, (B)', and will imply that (B) is a more appropriate topic, so (A) should be moved on from. 日本語(にほんご)に自信(じしん)があるかどうかはさておき、一人(ひとり)で行(い)ったことのない国(くに)へ行(い)くのには勇気(ゆうき)がいる。 Regardless of whether I am confident in Japanese or not, going to a country you haven't been to alone takes some courage. 彼女(かのじょ)がいるかいないかはさておき、普段(ふだん)から清潔(せいけつ)にしていたほうがいいと思(おも)うよ。 Regardless of whether you have a girlfriend or not, you should be hygienic. Caution さて may occasionally appear in either of the kanji forms 扨(さて), or 扠(さて). However, this is quite rare. 置(お)く itself may also be replaced with 措(お)く 'to set aside'. Fun Fact冗談(じょうだん)はさておき is a set expression that has the meaning of 'jokes aside', or 'moving on to the serious business'. 冗談(じょうだん)はさておき、そろそろ会議(かいぎ)を始(はじ)めよう。 Jokes aside, let's start the meeting soon.

example.japanese: 「それはさておき、本題(ほんだい)に入(はい)りましょう。」
example.english: Aside from that, let’s get straight to the point.”

example.japanese: たけしさん「たなかさんは腕(うで)を折(お)ったと聞(き)いたんだけど・・・」たなかさん「そうだけど、大丈夫(だいじょうぶ)だよ。嫌(いや)なことはさておき、息子(むすこ)さん元気(げんき)？」
example.english: Takeshi-san: “I have heard that you have broken your arm...”Tanaka-san: “Yeah, but don’t worry. Putting unpleasant stuff aside, how is your son?”

example.japanese: 《飲(の)み会(かい)、仕事(しごと)のことだけ話(はな)す同僚(どうりょう)に》「仕事(しごと)の話(はなし)はさておき、改(あらた)めて乾杯(かんぱい)！」
example.english: Drinking party, to a co-worker, that only talks about work: “Work talk aside, cheers!”

example.japanese: 武(たけし)さん「じゃ、エマさんは試験(しけん)に合格(ごうかく)すると思(おも)う？」エマさん「合格(ごうかく)するかどうかはさておき、たくさんのことを学(まな)んでよかった。」
example.english: Takeshi: “So, what do you think, will you pass the exam?”Ema: “Leaving aside whether I pass or not, I am glad that I have learned a lot.”

example.japanese: 学生(がくせい)１「そういえば知(し)ってる？トイレのはなこさんが旧(きゅう)校舎(こうしゃ)に出(で)るってうわさ」学生(がくせい)２「はっはっは、誰(だれ)がそんなことを。冗談(じょうだん)はさておき、本気(ほんき)でこのビルには気(き)をつけたほうがいいよ。状態(じょうたい)が悪(わる)いから危(あぶ)ない。」
example.english: Student1: “Speaking of which, did you know? There are rumors that Hanako-san (the spirit) of the toilet appears in the old school building.Student2: “Hahahaha, who says that? Jokes aside, you should be careful around that building. It’s dangerous because of its poor condition.”

synonym.explanation: setting aside, apart from

english_grammar.title: 折(おり)には
english_grammar.explanation: when, occasion, opportunity, time
english_grammar.structure: Verb + 折（に(1)） ［い］Adjective + 折（に(1)） ［な］Adjective + な + 折（に(1)） Noun + の + 折（に(1)） (1) には、は
english_grammar.attention: Rarely written as 折りに
english_grammar.about: When the noun 折(おり) 'fold' or 'pleat' is used adverbially with the case marking particle に, it indicates a time which may be used as an opportunity to do something. It is often translated as 'on the occasion of (A)', or 'when the chance of (A) comes up'. It is an expression that is primarily used as a formal, positive alternative for 時(とき)に, but there are times that it may indicate something negative. 折(おり)に may be seen after any structure that could connect to a noun, but will primarily appear after verbs in their standard forms, or nouns followed by の. こちらの旅館(りょかん)にいらっしゃる折(おり)には、事前(じぜん)の予約(よやく)をお願(ねが)いいたします。 On the occasion that you will visit our ryokan, please make a booking before the fact. 今度(こんど)お会(あ)いした折(おり)に、旅行(りょこう)へ行(い)った時(とき)のお土産(みやげ)をお渡(わた)しします。 When the chance comes up that we meet again soon, I'll give you the present that I got when I went on a trip. 卒業(そつぎょう)の折(おり)に担任(たんにん)の先生(せんせい)に手紙(てがみ)を渡(わた)そうと思(おも)っている。 On the opportunity of my graduation, I am thinking that I'd like to give a letter to the teacher that was looking after me. Additionally, 折(おり)に may occasionally appear as 折(おり)には, but the additional は if often omitted. In most cases, 折(おり)に will be used to indicate things that happen 'from time to time', rather than one off events. Caution 折(おり)に appears in several common expressions that each have a slightly different meaning. 折(おり)に触(ふれ)れて - On the occasion of (A), always (B). 折(おり)があれば - If there is the chance of (A), (B). 折(おり)を見(み)て - When the conditions are good for (A). 折(おり)も折(おり) - At the exact moment of (A).

example.japanese: 《自伝(じでん)》初(はじ)めてのパリへの出張(しゅっちょう)の折(おり)にはルーヴル美術館(びじゅつかん)に立(た)ち寄(よ)った。
example.english: Autobiography: “On the occasion of my first trip to Paris, I stopped by the Louvre museum for a short visit.”

example.japanese: 《手紙(てがみ)、名誉(めいよ)あるゲストの再(さい)招待(しょうたい)》「北海道(ほっかいどう)にいらした折(おり)に、是非(ぜひ)にお寄(よ)りください！」
example.english: A letter, re-invitation of an honored guest: “Please, make sure to drop by when you come to Hokkaido.”

example.japanese: 《自伝(じでん)》京都(きょうと)への観光(かんこう)旅行(りょこう)の折(おり)に、駅(えき)で偶然(ぐうぜん)小学校(しょうがっこう)の先生(せんせい)に会(あ)った。
example.english: Autobiography: “On the occasion of a sightseeing trip to Kyoto, I came across my elementary school teacher at the train station.”

example.japanese: 《メール、本社(ほんしゃ)からの上司(じょうし)に》お暇(ひま)な折(おり)にぜひ我(わ)が支店(してん)にお越(こ)しください。
example.english: E-mail to a superior from the head office: “Please, make sure to come to our branch when you are free.”

example.japanese: 《献辞(けんじ)》折(おり)に触(ふ)れて相談(そうだん)に乗(の)って下(くだ)さった、敬愛(けいあい)してやまない友人(ゆうじん)、黒木(くろき)智子(ともこ)さんに心(こころ)から感謝(かんしゃ)いたします。
example.english: Dedication: “I am grateful from the bottom of my heart to my friend I greatly respect, Tomoko Kuroki, who has helped me wherever the occasion arose. ”

synonym.explanation: when, at the time of, in case of, on the occasion of
When, At the time of

english_grammar.title: とばかりに
english_grammar.explanation: as if (to say), seeming that
english_grammar.structure: Quote + とばかり（に） Noun +（だ）+ とばかり（に）
english_grammar.attention: ばっかり, ばっか, ばかし, and ばっかし are all fairly common casual variations of ばかり
english_grammar.about: とばかり is a construction that is often used to show that something is being done 'as if to say (A)', or 'seeming that (A)'. It is a combination of the case-marking particle と in its 'quotation' use, and the adverbial particle ばかり, exhibiting that something is 'basically exactly as described'. Due to this, とばかり simply indicates that while (A) is as described, it is not literally the case. とばかり can appear after almost any word, as the と is creating a quote. に will often follow ばかり when the sentence is going on to describe what is actually happening. 中田(なかた)選手(せんしゅ)のバランスが崩(くず)れたので、斉藤(さいとう)選手(せんしゅ)はチャンスとばかりに中田(なかた)選手(せんしゅ)の太(ふと)ももを蹴(け)った。 As Nakata lost his balance, Saito took the opportunity and kicked Nakata in the thigh. うちのわんちゃんが「待(ま)ってました」とばかりに尻尾(しっぽ)を振(ふ)って友達(ともだち)に飛(と)びついた。 Our dog wagged his tail and jumped onto my friend as if to say 'I have been waiting'. 先生(せんせい)が「俺(おれ)の話(はなし)聞(き)いてるか」とばかりに生徒(せいと)たちを睨(にら)みつけた。 The teacher stared at the students as if to say 'Are you listening to me'. とばかりに is an abbreviation of と言(い)わんばかり 'to only just not be at the point where (A) is said', which itself will still be seen quite often. 早(はや)くしろと言(い)わんばかりに上司(じょうし)が何回(なんかい)も「まだ？」って聞(き)いてきた。 My boss repeatedly asked me, 'Are you done?' as if to say 'hurry up'. つまらないと言(い)わんばかりの顔(かお)でみられたから、話(はな)すのをやめた。 They were looking at me as if they were bored, so I stopped talking. In this case, 言(い)わん is an abbreviation of 言(い)わぬ, making use of the classical auxiliary verb ぬ used for negation. Caution As とばかりに will be used to describe the way that something 'looks like it is about to say', it won't be used for describing the speaker themselves. However, it may occasionally be seen being used about the speaker if the sentence is in third person.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》 なかなかお目(め)にかかれない美(うつく)しい景色(けしき)なので武(たけし)はここぞとばかりにカメラを手(て)にし、撮影(さつえい)した。
example.english: Novel: It's a beautiful scene that you don't see very often, so Takeshi took the opportunity to grab his camera and take some pictures.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》洋服店(ようふくてん)に入(はい)るなり、長(なが)いことこのときを待(ま)っていたとばかりに、店員(てんいん)が声(こえ)をかけてきた。
example.english: Novel: As soon as he entered the clothing store, the clerk approached him, as if she had been just waiting for this very moment for a long time.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》「もうあなたとははなしたくない」とばかりに彼(かれ)はドアをばたんと閉(し)めた。
example.english: Novel: He slammed the door as if to say "I don't want to talk with you anymore".

example.japanese: スーパーで閉店(へいてん)が近(ちか)づき食品(しょくひん)などが割引(わりびき)される時間帯(じかんたい)になると、主婦(しゅふ)たちはここぞとばかりに多(おお)くの買(か)い物(もの)をした。
example.english: As the closing time of the supermarket approached, when food and other items were discounted, housewives took the opportunity and did a lot of shopping.

example.japanese: 「おまえも黙(だま)れ」とばかりに手(て)でテーブルを叩(たた)いた。
example.english: She slammed the table with her hand as if to say "Silence!".

english_grammar.title: わ〜わ
english_grammar.explanation: ~and ~and, keep ~ing, one after another, so much, so many, one after another
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ わ + Verb［る］+ わ(*) (*) The same verb has to be repeated
english_grammar.about: わ is an adverbial particle that is commonly used in cases of stress of emphasis in Japanese. When appearing after the dictionary form of a verb that is being repeated, it highlights a large amount, something happening successively, or more and more. It will often be translated as 'more and more (A)', '(A) keeps on happening', or 'so much (A)'. わ～わ may be used either positively or negatively. To use this structure, simply place わ after the verb, and then repeat the same verb with a second わ. もう、昨日(きのう)子供達(こどもたち)が喧嘩(けんか)して泣(な)くわ泣(な)くわで大変(たいへん)だったんだから。 Oh my god, it was so hectic yesterday because the kids got into a fight and cried so much. 空(あ)き家(や)を買(か)ったのはいいけど、家中(いえじゅう)にはゴキブリがいるわいるわ。多分(たぶん)自分(じぶん)じゃ何(なん)もできないから業者(ぎょうしゃ)に頼(たの)むしかなさそう。 I bought a vacant house, and that's exciting, but there are so many cockroaches all over the house. I probably won't be able to do anything myself, so I will have to call someone. 私(わたし)の息子(むすこ)なんて、部活(ぶかつ)を始(はじ)めてからというもの食(た)べるわ食(た)べるわ、食費(しょくし)が心配(しんぱい)だよ。 Ever since my son has started after school activities, he eats so much that I am worried about the cost of food. わ～わ primarily emphasizes the speaker's surprise in regard to the amount or extent of (A). This structure is predominantly used by men, but it may also sometimes be used by women. However, there are several different variations of わ depending on where they appear in sentences, each of which have gender usage tendencies that will need to be learned. In many cases where a する verb is being used with わ～わ, the second instance of the action will be omitted, with する appearing by itself. For example, instead of 勉強(べんきょう)するわ勉強(べんきょう)するわ, 勉強(べんきょう)するわするわ would be used. あの子(こ)は医者(いしゃ)になりたいって決(き)めてから、毎日(まいにち)勉強(べんきょう)するわするわ。 Ever since he has decided that he wants to be a doctor, he studies a lot. Fun Factわ is simply an emphatic version of the usual は adverbial particle, and originates from は being changed to わ. Due to this, the literal meaning can be thought of as a stronger version of the standard 'as for (A)' meaning of は. This would come across something like 'as for (A), it did (A)', with the repetition itself adding to the emphasis.

example.japanese: 「病院(びょういん)に入院(にゅういん)してた時(とき)、いろいろ検査(けんさ)したらまあ、出(で)るわ出(で)るわ…（思(おも)った以上(いじょう)のことが指摘(してき)された）。」
example.english: "When I was in the hospital, they did various tests and, well, they just kept coming up..." （the results that were worse than expected）

example.japanese: 「新婚(しんこん)旅行(りょこう)から戻(もど)ったらメールボックスには郵便物(ゆうびんぶつ)があるわあるわ、つかえてしまって引(ひ)っ張(ぱ)ることができなかった。」
example.english: "When we got back from our honeymoon, there was so much mail in the mailbox that it was stuck and I couldn’t pull it out."

example.japanese: 「子供(こども)が転(ころ)んで泣(な)くわ泣(な)くわ。なだめるの大変(たいへん)だった。」
example.english: "Our child fell and cried so much that it was hard to calm her down."

example.japanese: 「先輩(せんぱい)は面白(おもしろ)いのなんのって喋(しゃべ)ると笑(わら)うわ笑(わら)うわ。」
example.english: "Senpai is so funny, that I laugh so much whenever he talks."

example.japanese: 「ちょっとからかっただけで、あいつ怒(おこ)るわ怒(おこ)るわ。」
example.english: "He gets so angry just by teasing him a bit."

english_grammar.title: に至(いた)っても
english_grammar.explanation: even when
english_grammar.structure: Verb + に至っても Noun + に至っても
english_grammar.about: In contrast to に至(いた)っては, which presents the most extreme examples for something from within a specific category. に至(いた)っても will present the same extreme example from which some result will not occur. This is due to the adverbial particle も 'even' replacing は. に至(いた)っても may be translated as 'even if it came to (A), (B)', 'even when (A), (B)'. (B) will often be negative, thus highlighting that even the extreme (A) couldn't affect (B). This is a combination of the case-marking particle に, the て-form of the る-Verb 至(いた)る 'to climax', or 'to culminate in', and the adverbial particle も. に至(いた)っては will appear following nouns, or verbs in their dictionary form. あの事故(じこ)に巻(ま)き込(こ)まれてから2年(ねん)経(た)つに至(いた)っても、相手(あいて)は謝罪(しゃざい)すらもしてこない。 Even now, 2 years since I have been involved in an accident, and the other party has not even apologized. 社会人(しゃかいじん)になるに至(いた)っても、まだ自分(じぶん)が子供(こども)だと思(おも)っている人(ひと)は少(すく)なくないだろう。 Even as people become a functioning member of society, there are probably a lot of people that think they are still kids. 彼(かれ)と別(わか)れて3年(ねん)経(た)った現在(げんざい)に至(いた)っても、男(おとこ)の人(ひと)を信用(しんよう)することができない。 Even now, 3 years after I broke up with him, I still have a hard time trusting men. この会議(かいぎ)は朝方(あさがた)に至(いた)っても、続(つづ)きそうだ。 This meeting seems like it is going to continue, even if it becomes morning. に至(いた)っても will often be used when the speaker laments or regrets that despite reaching the point of (A), (B) is something that will still not, or did not change. However, it may occasionally be used positively, especially when the speaker is expressing their determination. これは俺(おれ)が決(き)めたことだから、どんな結果(けっか)に至(いた)っても、絶対(ぜったい)に後悔(こうかい)しない！ This is something I have decided on, so I will not regret the result even if it's bad.

example.japanese: ハルヒさんの消失(しょうしつ)から半月(はんつき)以上(いじょう)が過(す)ぎた今日(きょう)に至(いた)っても、彼女(かのじょ)の行方(ゆくえ)は未(いま)だに知(し)れない。
example.english: Even to this day, when more than half a month has passed since the disappearance of Haruhi, her whereabouts are still impossible to tell.

example.japanese: 会社(かいしゃ)が破産(はさん)直前(ちょくぜん)の状況(じょうきょう)に至(いた)ってもなお経営陣(けいえいじん)は減給(げんきゅう)されることに首(くび)を縦(たて)に振(ふ)ろうとはしない。
example.english: Even in a situation when the company is on the verge of bankruptcy, the management have still not agreed to have their salaries cut.

example.japanese: 結婚(けっこん)するに至(いた)っても、完全(かんぜん)にお互(たが)いを理解(りかい)し合(あ)えないカップルが多(おお)い。
example.english: Many couples can’t understand each other completely even when they are about to get married.

example.japanese: スミスさんは、事故(じこ)から6年(ねん)経(た)った現在(げんざい)に至(いた)っても、未(いま)だに腕(うで)の痛(いた)みを感(かん)じます。
example.english: Even now, 6 years since the accident, Mr. Smith still feels pain in his arm.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》：だが、事(こと)ここに至(いた)っても、まだ謝(あやま)ることを拒否(きょひ)するほど頑固(がんこ)である。
example.english: Novel: However, even when things have come to this, he is still obstinate to the point that he refuses to apologize.

english_grammar.title: を兼(か)ねて
english_grammar.explanation: and also, also (partly) to, also (partly) for (the purpose of), at the same time, to double as, when … also, while … as well, and as
english_grammar.structure: Noun + を(1) + 兼ねて (1) も
english_grammar.about: を兼(か)ねて is a grammar pattern that makes use of the standard meaning of the る-Verb 兼(か)ねる 'to stretch across to', or 'to do concurrently'. The adverbial particle を will mark a noun which will be considered the secondary event or state, while 兼(か)ねて will be followed by the primary event or state that will be done concurrently with (A). This is often translated as 'to (A) at the same time as (B)', 'to double as (A)', or 'to (A) also partly for the purpose of (B)'. おばあちゃんはボケ防止(ぼうし)を兼(か)ねて、毎日(まいにち)クロスワードパズルをしています。 My grandma does crossword puzzles also partly to prevent dementia. 日本語(にほんご)の勉強(べんきょう)を兼(か)ねて、英語(えいご)の字幕(じまく)なしで日本(にほん)の映画(えいが)をみています。 I watch Japanese movies without subtitles also partly to learn Japanese. ダイエットを兼(か)ねて、毎朝(まいあさ)ランニングしています。 I run everyday also partly to lose weight. を兼(か)ねて often highlights (B) as the primary goal, where (A) is something that acts to support it, makes sense to be done together, or just gives the speaker a good excuse to do (B). In order to remember that (A) is actually the secondary goal in this structure, using the literal translation of 'while extending across to (A), (B)' may help. In the case of multiple goals existing, the case-marking particle と will be used for listing of nouns. 運動(うんどう)不足(ぶそく)とストレス発散(はっさん)を兼(か)ねて、キックボクシングジムにこよっている。 I go to a kickboxing gym also partly to relieve stress and to get exercise. 体調(たいちょう)管理(かんり)と節約(せつやく)を兼(か)ねて、寝(ね)る時(とき)はエアコンを使(つか)わないようにしている。 I try not to use the air conditioner also partly for my health and to save money.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)の勉強(べんきょう)を兼(か)ねて、日本(にほん)のゲームをしています。
example.english: I play Japanese games also (partly) to learn the language.

example.japanese: ダイエットを兼(か)ねて、スポーツジムに通(かよ)っています。
example.english: I go to the gym also (partly) to lose weight.

example.japanese: 散歩(さんぽ)を兼(か)ねて隣町(となりまち)まで歩(ある)いて買(か)い物(もの)に行(い)きました。
example.english: I went to the shop and (partly) for a stroll as well.

example.japanese: ちよちゃんの誕生日(たんじょうび)が近(ちか)いので、お誕生日会(たんじょうびかい)祝(しゅく)を兼(か)ねてパーティーを行(おこな)いたい。
example.english: Chiyo-chan's birthday is approaching, so I want to organize a party that will double as a birthday meet-up as well.

example.japanese: 小遣(こづか)い稼(かせ)ぎを兼(か)ねて趣味(しゅみ)で同人誌(どうじんし)を描(えが)いている。
example.english: I draw doujinshi as a hobby and also (partly) for extra money.

synonym.explanation: cannot・be unable to, hard to, hesitant to

english_grammar.title: ないものだろうか
english_grammar.explanation: (why) can’t, isn’t there, wish that, if only
english_grammar.structure: Verb［できる］［ない］+ もの + （だろう）+ か
english_grammar.about: When paired with negative expressions, the noun 物(もの) and either the sentence-ending particle か or a combination of だろう and か will indicate that the speaker wishes (A) were possible, but for some reason it is beyond their immediate capacity. This structure may be translated as 'if only (A)', or 'isn't there a way to (A)', but the literal translation is closer to 'I wonder if it really a thing that can't (A)'. This grammar pattern will primarily be seen attached to the negated form of verbs, but may also be used in reference to nouns when the ない is being used to indicate a lack of existence of (A), rather than a lack of ability to do (A). これはもっとシンプルにできないものか。 Can't this be made to be more simple? こっちから言(い)わないとやって貰(もら)えないものだろうか。 Can't you do it for me without me telling you to? 難(むずか)しいのはわかっているんですが、佐々木(ささき)さんの腕(う)でなんとかできないものでしょうか。 I am aware that it is difficult, but can't something not be done with your skills? 仕事(しごと)をもう少(すこし)し楽(たの)にする方法(ほうほう)はないものか。 Is there no way to make work a little easier? もっと楽(らく)にお金(かね)を稼(かせ)げる仕事(しごと)はないものだろうか。 I wonder if there are any jobs where I can earn money easier. これよりもっと燃費(ねんぴ)がいい車(くるま)はないものでしょうか。 Are there no cars that have better mileage than this one? As can be seen in these examples, the polite でしょう may replace だろう. Additionally, similar structures such as かな or かしら may replace だろうか or でしょうか in more casual conversations.

example.japanese: 電気(でんき)自動車(じどうしゃ)の値段(ねだん)はもう少(すこ)し安(やす)くできないものだろうか。
example.english: Can’t electric cars’s price be a bit lower?

example.japanese: 《上司(じょうし)、部下(ぶか)の提案(ていあん)への反応(はんのう)》「まあ機能(きのう)はするだろうね。ただちょっと気(き)になる部分(ぶぶん)があったから、他(ほか)にもっといい方法(ほうほう)はないものかなあ...」
example.english: Superior, reacting to the subordinate proposal: “Well, it will probably work. But there is a part that bothers me a bit. Is there no other, better way?”

example.japanese: 《伝記(でんき)》なんとかしてもっと操作(そうさ)しやすい携帯(けいたい)電話(でんわ)を作(つく)れないものかと、スティーブはいつも考(かんが)えていた。
example.english: Biography: “Steven has been always thinking if there isn't some way he could make the smartphones easier to use.”

example.japanese: 《インタビュー》その時(とき)、工業(こうぎょう)製品(せいひん)の品質(ひんしつ)を何(なん)とか上(あ)げるようにできないものかと考(かんが)えました。
example.english: Interview: “At that time, we were thinking if there isn't some way to increase the quality of our products.”

example.japanese: 《テレビ番組(ばんぐみ)》刑事(けいじ)ゴンロポ「そのことは問題(もんだい)になります。ついては今(いま)、ここでそれに対(たい)する説明(せつめい)をうかがえないものでしょうか？」容疑者(ようぎしゃ)「そのことでしたら隠(かく)す理由(りゆう)もございません。私(わたし)は昨晩(さくばん)ずっと家(いえ)におりました。」
example.english: TV show, detective Gonropo: “This might be a problem. So, why can’t I ask for an explanation about that right away?”Suspect: “If it’s this then there is nothing to hide. I have been at my house all night long. ”

english_grammar.title: ～て見(み)せる
english_grammar.explanation: I will definitely, I will certainly, just watch, whatever it takes, I swear, for sure
english_grammar.structure: Verb［て］+ みせる
english_grammar.about: て見(み)せる, primarily written in hiragana, is an emphatic structure that indicates that the speaker is going to do (A) in a way that it is clear to the listener. This can be translated as 'I will definitely (A)', or 'I swear I will (A)', but the literal translation of 'I will show you that I'll do (A)' also makes the point clear. To use てみせる, simply alter the verb preceding it into its て-form. お前(まえ)のために、次(つぎ)の試合(しあい)では勝(か)ってみせる！ I will definitely win the next competition for you! 来週(らいしゅう)のテストで合格(ごうかく)してみせる！ I will definitely pass the test next week! 足(あし)が痛(いた)いけど、完走(かんそう)させてみせる！ My legs hurt, but I am definitely going to finish the race! Due to みせる requiring a target for who the speaker is showing, this grammar pattern will only be used when there is either directly someone that will be shown (A), or when the speaker is talking about showing someone (A) that does not happen to be there at the moment either physically or temporally. It will not be used when simply strongly stating that you will do (A), unless who sees that (A) is important. In a sentence like this, where the person being shown is not obvious, it will come across as 'I'll show everyone'. As て見(み)せる literally just means to 'show (A)', it will often be used without any special emphasis. Whether it is being used emphatically or not will usually be obvious from the overall context of the sentence.

example.japanese: 「今年(ことし)こそ、必(かなら)ず運転(うんてん)免許(めんきょ)を取(と)ってみせるよ。」
example.english: 'I will definitely get a drivers license this year!'

example.japanese: 《アニメ》友達(ともだち)１「先輩(せんぱい)に私(わたし)の気持(きも)ちを絶対(ぜったい)気付(きづ)かせてみせるわ！」頼(たよ)れる友達(ともだち)２「がんばれ！」
example.english: Anime: Friend1: “I will definitely make senpai realize my feelings!”Supportive friend2: “Go for it!”

example.japanese: 「何(なに)があっても、必(かなら)ずファンの期待(きたい)に応(こた)えてみせます！」
example.english: “No matter what happens, I will definitely live up to my fans’ expectations!”

example.japanese: 《負(ま)けた後(のち)、相手(あいて)を挑戦(ちょうせん)する》「次(つぎ)こそ、必(かなら)ず勝(か)ってみせるぞ！あなたには負(ま)けない！」相手(あいて)「よし、かかってこい！」
example.english: After losing, challenging the opponent: “I will definitely win next time! I won’t lose!”Opponent: “OK! Bring it on!”

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》必(かなら)ずこの手(て)で魔王(まおう)を倒(たお)してみせるという勇者(ゆうしゃ)えみりあの言葉(ことば)に、わたしたちは賭(か)けることにした。
example.english: Novel: “We decided to bet on Emilia the hero's words, that she would definitely defeat the demon king with her very own hands.”

english_grammar.title: 相(あい)まって
english_grammar.explanation: combined with, coupled with, together with
english_grammar.structure: Noun + が(1) + 相まって (1) と
english_grammar.attention: sometimes written as 相俟って!
english_grammar.about: 相(あい)まって is a structure used for showing that (A) and (B) are things that will perform some sort of synergistic task in order to achieve the result of (C). In many cases, either (A) or (B) alone could achieve (C), but their combined action will bring about a better result. This structure is a combination of 相(あい), 'mutual', or 'reciprocal', and the て-form of the う-Verb 俟(ま)つ 'to wait on'. In this pattern, both (A) and (B) will often come before 相(あい)まって, with either of the case-marking particles と or が being used after the nouns. Common translations include '(A) combined with (B) will (C)', or 'coupled together with (A), (B) will (C)'. As for a literal translation, 'mutually depending on each other, (C)' is fairly close to the exact nuance. See the fun-fact for more about this. あの古(ふる)い屋敷(やしき)は霧(きり)と相(あい)まって不気味(ぶきみ)な雰囲気(ふんいき)を出(だ)しています。 That old mansion, combined with the fog, creates an eerie atmosphere. ツイッターでの流行(りゅうこう)と相(あい)まって、この漫画(まんが)は若者(わかもの)の間(あいだ)ではすごく人気(にんき)だ。 Combined with its popularity on Twitter, this manga is very popular among young people. このステーキはシェフ特製(とくせい)のソースが相(あい)まって、とても美味(おい)しい。 This steak is very tasty, coupled with the chef's special sauce. クライアントのアイデアと私(わたし)たちの努力(どりょく)が相(あい)まって、とてもいいイベントを開催(かいさい)することができた。 The client's ideas, combined with our efforts, resulted in us being able to host a very good event. Fun-fact - Although 俟(ま)つ 'to wait on' and 待(ま)つ 'to wait for' are very similar, they have a primary difference in their focus. 待(ま)つ indicates waiting in the sense of 'waiting for (A) to come', while 俟(ま)つ indicates 'waiting for (A) to go'. What this means is that with 相(あい)まって and other uses of 俟(ま)つ, the important thing happens after (A) and (B) come together. This gives the nuance of (A) and (B) having some kind of reliance on each other in order to do (C). Due to 俟(ま)つ being far less common in modern Japanese, it will often be written in hiragana.

example.japanese: 記事(きじ)：ピーナッツバターはキュウリの酢(す)の物(もの)と相(あい)まって思(おも)いがけない独特(どくとく)な味(あじ)をもたらす。
example.english: Article : Peanut butter combined with pickled cucumber gives an unexpected, unique flavor.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》夕暮(ゆうぐ)れが虹(にじ)と相(あい)まって空(そら)をある種(しゅ)のキャンディーのように見(み)せた。
example.english: Novel: Twilight combined with a rainbow made the sky look like some sort of candy.

example.japanese: 《都市(とし)汚染(おせん)についての記事(きじ)》盆地(ぼんち)に不利(ふり)な地理的(ちりてき)位置(いち)と工業(こうぎょう)排(はい)ガスが相(あい)まって家庭用(かていよう)空気(くうき)清浄機(せいじょうき)はさらに必要(ひつよう)となる。
example.english: Article about city pollution: Industry emission combined with the unfavorable geographical location in the basin makes house air purifiers even more necessary.

example.japanese: 《ゲームレビュー》ペースの速(はや)いストーリー展開(てんかい)と個性的(こせいてき)なキャラクターが相(あい)まって、自然(しぜん)とこのゲームはRPGファンの間(あいだ)で大(おお)きな話題(わだい)となっている。
example.english: Game review: Fast paced story development combined with unique characters naturally gained this game much attention among RPG fans.

example.japanese: 《記事(きじ)》水位(すいい)上昇(じょうしょう)と異常(いじょう)気象(きしょう)が相(あい)まって、それらはモルディブなどの島国(しまぐに)では重大(じゅうだい)な脅威(きょうい)となっています。
example.english: Article: Weather anomalies combined with rising water levels are a great threat to island countries such as the Maldives.

english_grammar.title: に足(た)りない
english_grammar.explanation: to not be worthy, to not be enough, to not be sufficient, to lack
english_grammar.structure: Verb + に足りない
english_grammar.attention: に足らない is an older variant.
english_grammar.about: に足(た)りない is a grammar expression appearing after the dictionary form of verbs used to indicate that something is 'not worth (A)', or 'not sufficient for (A)'. It comes from a combination of the case-marking particle に, and the る-Verb 足(た)りる 'to be sufficient', or 'to be enough'. This structure is formal, so will mostly be used in literature or formal speech settings. 彼(かれ)は陰謀論者(いんぼうろんしゃ)だから、あの人(ひと)のいうことは信(しん)じるに足(た)りない。 He is a conspiracy theorist so nothing he says is worth believing. あの人(ひと)は自分(じぶん)を良(よ)くみせるためだったら、すぐに自分(じぶん)の失敗(しっぱい)を人(ひと)のせいにするから、彼(かれ)は信頼(しんらい)するに足(た)りない。 He will blame others for his own mistakes, just to make himself look good, so he is not worth trusting. ブランド物(ものう)のバッグをリサイクルショップに売(う)りに行(い)ったけど、買取(かいとり)の金額(きんがく)が売(う)るに足(た)りない金額(きんがく)だった。 I went to sell a designer brand bag to a secondhand store, but the purchase price was not enough for me to sell it. While に足(た)りない may be similar to another grammar point, に足(た)る, in that they are conversely pointing out the worth, or lack of worth of something, they are actually different verbs. 足(た)る is an う-Verb, and is often used more in literature, or in western Japan. This means that the negative form of 足(た)る is 足(た)らない, not 足(た)りない. Caution - Both 足(た)りない and 足(た)らない may be used as part of the set phrase 取(と)るに足(た)りない, 'to be worthless', or 'to not be worth taking up for discussion'. 周(まわ)りから見(み)ると取(と)るに足(た)りない、ただのゴミだが、私(わたし)にとっては大切(たいせつ)なコレクションの一部(いちぶ)だ。 From the perspective of the people around me, it's nothing but a worthless piece of garbage, but to me they are an important part of my collection. この部品(ぶひん)は取(と)るにたらない物(もの)のように見(み)えるかもしれないが、これが壊(こわ)れたら、この機械(きかい)は動(うご)かなくなる。 This component may seem insignificant, but if it breaks, this machine will stop working.

example.japanese: 他人(たにん)から見(み)たら取(と)るに足(た)りない、小(ちい)さな貝(かい)にすぎないが、私(わたし)にとってはあの日(ひ)のお土産(みやげ)だ。
example.english: From another person's perspective, it is nothing but a worthless, small shell, yet for me, it is a souvenir of that day.

example.japanese: 《記事(きじ)》失敗(しっぱい)など全(まった)く恐(おそ)れるに足(た)りない。なぜなら、間違(まちが)えたり、失敗(しっぱい)することは、人(ひと)として成長(せいちょう)するからである。
example.english: Article: The likes of failure are not worth fearing at all. It is because of mistakes, that we grow as people.

example.japanese: ロジャー・キントの言葉(ことば)は一(ひと)つとして信(しん)じるに足(た)りないことだ。
example.english: Not even one word of Roger Kint is worth believing.

example.japanese: 現代(げんだい)の人類(じんるい)は、多忙(たぼう)である為(ため)、自然(しぜん)の美(うつく)しさなどは注目(ちゅうもく)するに足(た)りないものと思(おも)って、常(つね)に無視(むし)しているきらいがある。
example.english: Due to the fast-paced life, modern humans have a tendency to ignore the beauty of nature regarding it as something that is not worth our attention.

example.japanese: 狼(おおかみ)少年(しょうねん)は嘘(うそ)を重(かさ)ねた結果(けっか)、信(しん)ずるに足(た)りないやつだと村人(むらびと)に思(おも)われるようになった。
example.english: As a result of his repeated lies, the boy who cried wolf has come to be regarded as untrustworthy by the villagers.

english_grammar.title: べからず
english_grammar.explanation: do not, must not, should not, cannot (べからざる)
english_grammar.structure: Verb + べからず Exceptions: する ￫ す(1) + べからず Verb + べからざる + Noun which is generally limited to: 許すべからざる + Noun ありうべからざる + Noun 欠くべからざる + Noun (1) する
english_grammar.about: べからず, and べからざる are two formal expressions used to convey the meaning of 'must not (A)', or 'ought not to (A)'. It is a combination of the helper-conjugation form of the auxiliary verb べし, べから, and the classical auxiliary verb ず 'not'. ざる itself is just the helper-conjugation form of ず, meaning that the nuance remains exactly the same. In this way, we can see that the literal meaning of 'ought not (A)' exhibits some sort of moral or logical obligation, as is true for all uses of べき derived patterns. べからず and べからざる will be seen following verbs in their dictionary forms. べからざる will be followed by a noun, indicating that that noun is being modified by the phrase. ことわざ：「初心(しょしん)忘(わす)れるべからず。」 Proverb: 'Do not forget beginner's humility.' この施設内(しきちな)ではスケートボードなどのことをするべからず。 You must not skateboard or anything similar in this facility. 配達員(はいたついん)を装(よそお)って玄関(げんかん)のドアを開(あ)けさせるのは、許(ゆる)すべからず行為(こうい)だ。 Making someone open the door, by pretending to be a delivery person is an act that is not to be forgiven. 吸(す)うべからず場所(ばしょ)でタバコを吸(す)っているのを見(み)られたら、1000円(えん)払(はら)うことになります。 If you are seen smoking in an area where you must not smoke, you will end up having to pay 1000 yen. In modern Japanese, the meanings of both of these grammar patterns have shifted slightly from 'obligation', to simply having a strong nuance of 'don't (A)'. In addition to this, they will almost only ever be used on signs or notices. Caution The べからざる form that combines with nouns is usually only seen in a few set variations. These are 許(ゆる)すべからざる 'cannot be forgiven', ありうべからざる 'must not exist' (impossible), and 欠(か)くべからざる 'must not be without'.

example.japanese: 《公園(こうえん)の看板(かんばん)》芝生(しばふ)にゴミ捨(す)てるべからず
example.english: A signboard at the park: “Do not dump rubbish on the lawn”

example.japanese: 空気(くうき)は生(い)きるに欠(か)くべからざるものだ。
example.english: Air is essential to life. [Must not lack air]

example.japanese: 《ブログ記事(きじ)》英語(えいご)で上手(じょうず)にフォーマルな手紙(てがみ)を書(か)くための「べし・べからず」集(しゅう)
example.english: Blog post: Dos and Don'ts for writing a formal letter in English skillfully.

example.japanese: 《もろい歴史的(れきしてき)建造物(けんぞうぶつ)の手前(てまえ)の看板(かんばん)》中(なか)に入(はい)るべからず
example.english: A signboard in front of the fragile historic building: “Do not enter inside”

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》さだおさんがなにゆえそのような許(ゆる)すべからざる大罪(だいざい)を犯(おか)したのか、ゆうささんは解(かい)できなかった。
example.english: Novel: Yusa-san couldn’t understand why did Sadao-san commit such an unpardonable crime. [a crime that cannot be forgiven]

synonym.explanation: Must not, May not
must not, cannot, should not

english_grammar.title: んばかりに
english_grammar.explanation: as if, as if it were about to, about to
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］+ ん + ばかり + に Verb［ない］+ ん + ばかり + の + Noun
english_grammar.attention: ばっかり, ばっか, ばかし, and ばっかし are all fairly common casual variations of ばかり
english_grammar.about: Like とばかりに, んばかりに is a construction that is often used to show that something is being done 'as if it were (A)', or 'seeming that it will (A)'. It is thought to be a combination of ん, an abbreviation of む, the classical auxiliary verb used to show intent or strong will in the same way as う and よう, and the adverbial particle ばかり, exhibiting that something is 'basically exactly as described'. As a result, んばかり simply indicates the volitional form of (A) as appearing to be about to happen. んばかりに will appear linked to the indeterminate form of verbs (ない stem), and then followed by a statement that is being modified by the に. If んばかり will modify a noun instead, の will replace に. 台風(たいふう)の風(かぜ)で、隣(となり)の空(あ)き家(や)が崩(くず)れんばかりにギシギシ音(おと)を立(た)てていた。 The vacant house next door was making creaking sounds as if it were to collapse because of the winds caused by the typhoon. 先生(せんせい)は「こっちを見(み)ろ」って言(い)わんばかりに、机(つくえ)を叩(たた)いた。 The teacher slammed his desk as if to say, 'look this way'. このコンサート会場(かいじょう)は溢(あふ)れんばかりのファンで埋(う)め尽(つ)くされている。 The concert venue was filled, as if it was about to overflow with fans. 彼(かれ)が交通(こうつう)事故(じこ)で亡(な)くなったってことを聞(き)いて、私(わたし)は胸(うで)が張(は)り裂(さ)けんばかりの気持(きも)ちになって、その場(ば)から動(うご)くことができなくなった。 When I heard that he had died in a car accident, I felt as if my heart was about to tear apart (heartbroken), and I could not move. Caution When attached to the indeterminate form of verbs, there is some contention among linguists whether ん is an abbreviation of む, the classical way of expressing う or よう, or whether it is an abbreviation of ぬ, the classical way of expressing ない. Due to being unable to accurately determine what the actual origin is, it would be advisable to choose whichever variation helps to remember the nuance of the grammar point on a case-by-case basis.

example.japanese: 小説(しょうせつ)：「割(わ)れんばかりの拍手(はくしゅ)に部屋(へや)は満(み)たされた。」
example.english: Novel : 'As if it were about to shatter, the room filled with thunderous applause.'

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》この巨大(きょだい)な宝石(ほうせき)はまるで｢拾(ひろ)ってください｣と言(い)わんばかりに、燦然(さんぜん)と光(ひか)り輝(かがや)いていた｡
example.english: Novel: The enormous jewel was shining brilliantly as if it were saying “please pick me up”.

example.japanese: コロ先生(せんせい)の最後(さいご)の講演(こうえん)とあって、講堂(こうどう)が生徒(せいと)で溢(あふ)れんばかりだった。
example.english: Since it was the last lecture of Koro-sensei, the auditorium was about to overflow with people.

example.japanese: 《回顧録(かいころく)》16年後(ねんご)、スミレに偶然(ぐうぜん)出会(であ)った時(とき)、彼女(かのじょ)は僕(ぼく)を知(し)らないふりして通(とお)り過(す)ぎた。しかし彼女(かのじょ)は胸(むね)がいっぱいになり、喜(よろこ)びの涙(なみだ)で泣(な)き出(だ)さんばかりの顔(かお)をした。
example.english: Memoirs: When I happened to meet Sumire sixteen years later, she passed by, pretending not to know me. However, she was filled with emotion, as if she were about to burst into tears of happiness.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》木橋(もくきょう)は車(くるま)の重(おも)さで折(お)れんばかりに軋(きし)み音(おん)をたてる。
example.english: Novel: The wooden bridge is making a squeaking noise as if it were about to collapse.

english_grammar.title: に則(のっと)って
english_grammar.explanation: according to, in accordance with, based on, in line with
english_grammar.structure: Noun + に則って(1) Noun (A) + に則った(2) + Noun (B) (1)に則り (2)に則っての
english_grammar.about: に則(のっと)って is a formal expression used when something is being done 'according to (A)', or 'in line with (A)'. This is usually some basis, foundation, or standard which has a long running history. The case-marking particle に is being combined with the て-form of the う-Verb 則(のっと)る 'to follow along with' in this grammar pattern. Based on this, the literal meaning is just that (B) is something that follows along with (A). While several forms may be seen, the most common are a noun followed by にのっとて, or a noun followed by にのっとった which will then modify a second noun. どの国(くに)に行(い)こうと、その国(くに)の法律(ほうりつ)に則(のっと)って、生活(せいかつ)しなくてはいけない。 No matter what country you go to, you must live according to the laws of that country. 芸能(けいのう)事務所(じむしょ)の規則(きそく)に則(のっと)って、事務所(じむしょ)に内緒(ないしょ)で交際(こうさい)を始(はじ)めたアイドルがクビになった。 In accordance with the rules of the production company, the idol that began to date without notifying the company got fired. 私(わたし)は無宗教(むしゅうきょう)なので、宗教(しゅうきょう)にのっとった式(しき)はあげたくないです。 I am not religious, so I do not want to have a ceremony based on religion. たとえ国(くに)のガイドラインにのっとった方法(ほうほう)で物事(ものごと)を進(すす)めても、批判(ひはん)の声(こえ)を上(あ)げる人(ひと)は出(で)てくる。 Even if things are done in accordance with national guidelines, there will still be those who will voice criticism. Both the kanji form and the plain hiragana form are quite common, so it will be helpful to remember both. As (A) is generally considered to be something that has some kind of foundation. It will mostly represent a thing that has some kind of inception point from which point little, if anything, changed. Some examples are laws, traditions, standards, codes of conduct, etc.

example.japanese: 《記事(きじ)》たけしさんはボクシングリングで何(なに)があろうと騎士道(きしどう)精神(せいしん)に則(のっと)って行動(こうどう)してきた。そのため、ボクシング界(かい)では尊敬(そんけい)される立場(たちば)となった。
example.english: Article: No matter what happens, Mr. Takeshi has always acted in accordance with the spirit of chivalry in the boxing ring. For that reason, he has come to be greatly respected in the boxing world.

example.japanese: 《伝統的(でんとうてき)なレストランの広告(こうこく)》着物(きもの)姿(すがた)のスタッフが伝統(でんとう)に則(のっと)ったおもてなしをさせていただきます。
example.english: Traditional restaurant advertisement: Our kimono-dressed staff will make sure to give you a warm welcome and attentive service that is in accordance with the honored tradition.

example.japanese: 《求人(きゅうじん)》交通費(こうつうひ)は企業(きぎょう)方針(ほうしん)に則(のっと)り支給致(しきゅういた)します
example.english: Job offer: We cover travel expenses in accordance with the company policy.

example.japanese: 《企業(きぎょう)ウエブサイト》弊社(へいしゃ)は個人(こじん)情報(じょうほう)保護法(ほごほう)に則(のっと)って、個人(こじん)データの取扱(とりあつか)いに細心(さいしん)の注意(ちゅうい)を払(はら)います。
example.english: Company website: Our company pays close attention to handling personal data, in accordance with Personal Information Protection Law.

example.japanese: 注文(ちゅうもん)のキャンセルの場合(ばあい)は当社(とうしゃ)既定(きてい)に則(のっと)り、10%キャンセル手数料(てすうりょう)を請求(せいきゅう)させていただきます。
example.english: In the case of cancellation of the order, we will charge a 10% cancellation fee in accordance with the predetermined (procedures) of our company.

synonym.explanation: along, in accordance with, in line with
as, following, as then, according to, in accordance with

english_grammar.title: (Adjective) + 限(かぎ)りだ
english_grammar.explanation: extremely, really, very, as ... as one can be
english_grammar.structure: ［い］Adjective + 限り + だ ［な］Adjective + な + 限り + だ
english_grammar.about: 限(かぎ)りだ is a structure that follows adjectives in order to indicate that something is 'extremely (A)', or 'as (A) as can be'. This grammar pattern is simply a mix of the noun 限(かぎ)り, 'limit', and the auxiliary verb だ, or です in the case of a polite sentence. Therefore, the literal meaning is just that something is 'the limit of (A)', where (A) is some describable feature. 限(かぎ)りだ will follow adjectives in their standard forms. こんな私(わたし)のためにこんな素晴(すば)らしい送別会(そうべつかい)を開(ひら)いてくれるなんて、嬉(うれ)しい限(かぎ)りです。 I am very happy that you threw such an amazing farewell party for me. 宝(たから)くじで一等(とう)が当(あ)たったなんて、羨(うらや)ましい限(かぎ)りだ。 Something like winning first place in a lottery is very enviable. 一分(いっぷん)遅(おく)れただけで不合格(ふごうがく)にされるなんて、残念(ざんねん)な限(かぎ)りだ。 It is very disappointing that I failed just by being a minute late. 同僚(どうりょう)にあんなことを言(い)われて、不快(ふきつ)な限(かぎ)りです。 I am very offended that my colleague said something like that to me. 限(かぎ)りだ is a fairly formal grammar point that simply aims to highlight the intensity of traits as perceived by the speaker. As this perception is something coming from the speaker, the adjective itself will often be an emotion that the speaker themselves is experiencing, rather than a direct quality of the object, such as its color or shape. Some examples of this are as follows. 嬉(うれ)しい - The feeling of happiness, as experienced by the speaker. 頼(たの)もしい - The feeling of reliability, as experienced by the speaker. 羨(うらや)ましい - The feeling of jealousy, as experienced by the speaker. 寂(さみ)しい - The feeling of lonliness, as experienced by the speaker. 恥(はず)ずかしい - The feeling of embarrassment, as experienced by the speaker. 心強(こころづよ)い - The feeling of reassurance, as experienced by the speaker. As can be seen in all of the examples. The intensity of the adjective is something that will change depending on one speaker to the next, rather than something that the target is doing.

example.japanese: 自分(じぶん)を高(たか)めたいという強(つよ)い意志(いし)を持(も)って学(まな)んでいる生徒(せいと)たちの姿(すがた)は、教師(きょうし)にとって心強(こころづよ)い限(かぎ)りだ。
example.english: Seeing pupils studying with a strong wish for improvement is very reassuring for a teacher.

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)１：「この二人(ふたり)が私(わたし)の娘(むすめ)たちです。」娘(むすめ)たち：「どうぞよろしく。」友達(ともだち)２：「まあ立派(りっぱ)な娘(むすめ)さんたちですよね。頼(たの)もしい限(かぎ)りです。」
example.english: Friend1: “These 2 are my daughters.”Daughters: “Pleased to make your acquaintance.”Friend2: “Oh my, what fine daughters you have. They look very promising.”

example.japanese: 《足(あし)を折(お)られた同僚(どうりょう)に》「足(あし)のことを聞(き)きました、お気(き)の毒(どく)な限(かぎ)りです。」
example.english: To a coworker that broke his/her leg: “I heard about the leg. Very sorry to hear that.”

example.japanese: コスタリカ旅行(りょこう)の抽選(ちゅうせん)に当(あ)たったなんて、うらやましい限(かぎ)りだよ。
example.english: Something like winning a Costa Rica trip on the lottery is very enviable.

example.japanese: 《漫画家(まんがか)は読者(どくしゃ)に感謝(かんしゃ)する》「私(わたし)の漫画(まんが)をここまで読(よ)んでくださり、嬉(うれ)しい限(かぎ)りです。ありがとうございました。」
example.english: A mangaka expressing gratitude to readers: “I am very glad that you have been reading my manga to this moment. Thank you very much.”

synonym.explanation: so much...that
very, extremely, can't help but do
can't help but want to, very, extremely

english_grammar.title: は疎(おろ)か
english_grammar.explanation: let alone, much less, needless to say, not to mention, not only but also
english_grammar.structure: Noun (A) + はおろか + Noun (B) + さえ(1) (1)も、まで、すら
english_grammar.about: は疎(おろ)か is an expression that works similarly to はもちろん 'of course (A), but (B)' in Japanese. 疎(おろ)か itself is a な-Adjective that means 'negligent', or 'alienation'. However, this use of 疎(おろ)か is not seen much in modern Japanese, and the word will mainly be used in set expressions where it doesn't behave exactly as a な-Adjective usually would. Despite this, the meaning of 'alienation', or 'completely removed from' is kept in はおろか, as it simply means 'completely putting aside (A), (B)'. Common translations include 'let alone (A), (B)', and 'it's needless to say that (A), when (B)'. (B) and (A) will usually be things that fall into the same category, where (B) is considered the far more obvious of the two. Due to this obviousness, (B) will often be immediately followed by the adverbial particle さえ. This shows that (B) is the noteworthy minimum extent. 彼(かれ)は掃除(そうじ)はおろか、料理(りょうり)さえできない。 He can't even cook, let alone clean. 私(わたし)はスーパーはおろか、コンビニさえもないど田舎(いなか)に住(す)んでいる。 I live in a very rural area where there isn't a convenience store, let alone a supermarket. 父(ちち)はパソコンはおろか、スマホさえも使(つか)うことができない。 My father cannot use a computer, let alone a smartphone. Alternatively, さえ may be exchanged with other adverbial particles that fill a similar purpose such a も, すら, or まで. In most cases, は疎(おろ)か sentences tend to have a fairly negative nuance.

example.japanese: 「ルームメイトはオムライスはおろか、おにぎりさえ作(つく)れない。」
example.english: “My roommate cannot even make onigiri, let alone omurice.”

example.japanese: 「最近(さいきん)、痔(じ)が痛(いた)み出(だ)したなぁ。座(すわ)ってるのはおろか、歩(ある)くのも痛(いた)いぞ。」
example.english: “Recently my hemorrhoids have been so painful. It even hurts to walk, much less sit.”

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》敵(てき)はおろか味方(みかた)からも恐(おそ)れられ、「バーサーカー」と言(い)われるようになった。
example.english: Novel: Feared by friends, let alone enemies, she has come to be called “berserker”.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はアクションアドベンチャーの有名(ゆうめい)な本(ほん)をシリーズで執筆(しっぴつ)したが、実(じつ)は祖国(そこく)はおろか、故郷(こきょう)すら出(で)たことがないという。
example.english: It is said that although he wrote a famous action-adventure series, he has never left his hometown, let alone motherland.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)の文字(もじ)と中国語(ちゅうごくご)の文字(もじ)の区別(くべつ)はおろか、ロシア語(ご)の文字(もじ)との区別(くべつ)さえつかない人(ひと)も少(すく)なくない。
example.english: There are quite a few people who cannot tell the difference between Japanese characters and Russian characters, let alone Japanese Characters and Chinese characters.

english_grammar.title: めく
english_grammar.explanation: like, to show signs of, to have the appearance of, to come to a (state) similar to, somewhat, an air of, feels almost like,
english_grammar.structure: Noun + めいて Noun + めいている Noun［Season］ + めいてきた​​ Noun + めいた + Noun
english_grammar.about: めく is a fairly unique う-Verb in Japanese in that it will only be used as a suffix. This is due to its meaning of 'to show signs of (A)', or 'to have the appearance of (A)'. It will be attached to nouns that the speaker experiences to be the case. As めく itself is a verb, it may appear in several different conjugation forms depending on how it is describing the rest of the sentence. When connected directly to a second noun, the past-tense form めいた is most common. 昨日(きのう)までは嘘(うそ)みたいに暑(あつ)かったのに、やっと春(はる)めいてきた！ It has been hot until yesterday, but it's finally starting to become spring-like! 冗談(じょうだん)めいて言(い)ったが、多分(たぶん)冗談(じょうだん)だったということは気(き)づいていないと思(おも)う。 I said it like a joke, but I don't think they understood it as a joke. 皮肉(ひにく)めいたことを言(い)ってしまって、相手(あいて)が黙(だま)り込(こ)んでしまった。 I said something which sounded like sarcasm and the other person fell silent. 彼女(かのじょ)はなんか謎(なぞ)めいた雰囲気(ふんいき)があるよね。 She has a somewhat mysterious vibe, doesn't she? This 'that the speaker experiences to be the case' part is important, as めく will almost always highlight the speaker's own personal feelings in regard to (A), and how they perceive it. The thing being described as (A) will usually not actually be (A), and the speaker is often aware of this fact. Caution - めく is mostly used with set nouns, so it is best to only use it with expressions that you have already heard. Some examples are 謎(なぞ)めく 'to appear to be a riddle', 皮肉(ひにく)めく 'to appear to be sarcastic', 良(い)い訳(わけ)めく 'to appear to be an excuse', 作(つく)り物(もの)めく 'to appear to be fictitious', and seasons of the year.

example.japanese: 《手紙(てがみ)の挨拶(あいさつ)》九月(くがつ)になると空(そら)も風(かぜ)もだいぶ秋(あき)めいてまいりました。お変(か)わりありませんか。
example.english: Greetings in letter：In September, the sky and wind start to get quite autumn-like. How have you been?

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》その知(し)らせを聞(き)いて彼女(かのじょ)の顔(かお)には謎(なぞ)めいた微笑(びしょう)が浮(う)かんでいた。
example.english: Novel: Hearing the news, a somewhat mysterious smile appeared on her face.

example.japanese: 作(つく)り物(もの)めいて見(み)えるほど、平穏(へいおん)で美(うつく)しい景色(けしき)だった。
example.english: It was calm and beautiful scenery, to the point of looking man-made.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》いつのまにか冬(ふゆ)は去(さ)り、かなり春(はる)めいていた。
example.english: Novel: Before I knew it, it had already gotten quite spring-like.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)の気分(きぶん)を上(あ)げるため、何(なに)か冗談(じょうだん)めいた、とるに足(た)りない話(はなし)をしようとした。
example.english: In order to improve her mood, I tried to tell a joke-like, non-serious story.

english_grammar.title: と言(い)わず
english_grammar.explanation: not only A or B but every-; A, B and every-; not only A or B but all over; A, B both, whether a or B
english_grammar.structure: Noun (A) + といわず + Noun (B) + といわず
english_grammar.about: When used in succession, と言(い)わず indicates that something is not limited to either (A) or (B), but applies to everything in a specific category or group. It may be translated as 'not just (A) or (B), but all', or '(A), (B) and everything else'. It is a combination of the case-marking particle と in its quotation use, the negative stem of 言(い)う, 言(い)わ, and the literary form of the classical auxiliary verb ぬ, ず. The literal translation is simply 'without saying (A), and without saying (B), (C)'. This 'without saying (A)' just means 'without limiting it to (A)'. This structure will follow both an (A) and a (B) noun before going on to explain what applies to everything. 旅行(りょこう)から帰(かえ)ってきたら、タンスと言(い)わず、棚(たな)と言(い)わず、家中(いえじゅう)泥棒(どろぼう)に物色(ぶっしょく)されていた。 When I returned from my trip, the whole house had been ransacked by thieves, not only the wardrobe or the shelves. 彼(かれ)は仕事中(しごとちゅう)と言(い)わず、休憩中(きゅうけいちゅう)と言(い)わず、ずっとユーチューブを見(み)ている。 He is always watching Youtube not only when he is working, but also on his break. この映画(えいが)は子供(こども)と言(い)わず、大人(おとな)と言(い)わず、みんなに愛(あい)されている。 Not only is this movie loved by children, but also by adults. It will be important to remember that both (A) and (B) must be some part of a logical group when using this grammar structure, in order for it to sound natural. For example, the hands and the feet are part of the body, the morning and the afternoon are parts of a day, the chorus and the melody are parts of a song, etc. と言(い)わず～と言(い)わず is a fairly formal expression, and will rarely be used in everyday speech.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》街灯(がいとう)は、はるか北(きた)の村(むら)で、夜(よる)といわず昼(ひる)といわずともりつづけた。
example.english: Novel: The lights in the village far north are lit continuously, not only during day or night (but all the time).

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》ぜなの室内(しつない)は、壁(かべ)といわず天井(てんじょう)といわず、全(すべ)てよそらのポスターや写真(しゃしん)で埋(う)め尽(つ)くされている。
example.english: The interior of Zena’s room has been plastered with posters and photographs of Yosora not only on walls and the ceiling but everywhere.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》勇者(ゆうしゃ)は戦闘後(せんとうご)、手(て)といわず、足(あし)といわず、満身創痍(まんしんそうい)だった。
example.english: Novel: After the battle, the hero was wounded not only on his hands or feet but all over his body.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》新(しん)国王(こくおう)の名前(なまえ)を聞(き)くと、一般(いっぱん)市民(しみん)といわず、貴族(きぞく)といわず、恐怖(きょうふ)に震(ふる)え上(あ)がった。
example.english: Novel: Hearing the name of the new king, not only ordinary citizens or aristocrats (but everyone) trembled with fear.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》アンディは他(た)の囚人(しゅうじん)に組(く)み敷(し)かれていて頭(あたま)といわず顔(かお)といわず、身体中(しんたいちゅう)をめった打(う)ちにされた。
example.english: Novel: Andy was pressed down by another prisoner, and has been beaten not only on his head or face but all over the body.

english_grammar.title: にも程(ほど)がある
english_grammar.explanation: there is a limit to, you are too ..., How …!, How … one can be!
english_grammar.structure: Verb + にもほどがある ［い］Adjective + にも + ほどがある ［な］Adjective + にも + ほどがある Noun + にも + ほどがある
english_grammar.about: にも程(ほど)がある is an expression that will often be used fairly critically in order to state that something is too much, based on the speaker's personal opinion. Common translations include 'how (A) can one be', 'there is a limit to (A)', or 'you are too (A)'. Being that it is composed of the case-marking particle に, adverbial particle も, the noun 程(ほど) 'bounds', and がある 'to have', the more literal meaning of 'there are bounds even within (A)' also carries the critical nuance of the more standard translations. This structure may follow almost any word type in their standard forms. お前(まえ)またぶっ倒(たお)れるまで飲(の)み続(つづ)けたの？飲(の)み過(す)ぎにも程(ほど)があるよ。 You drank until you blacked again? There is a limit to how much you should drink. あいつからまたメールがきた。また「今夜(こんや)も泊(と)めて！」だってさ。図々(すうすう)しいにも程(ほど)があるって。 I got a text from him again. He said, 'Let me crash at your place again!' There is a limit to how shameless one can be. 敬語(けいご)使(つか)わないのは別(べつ)として、先輩(せんぱい)に向(む)かって「お前(まえ)」っていうのはどうかと思(おも)うよ。失礼(しつれい)にも程(ほど)がある。 Setting aside you not using keigo, I don't think you should say 'you' towards your senpai. There is a limit to how impolite you can be. そういうことは相手(あいて)を傷(きず)つけるかもしれないから冗談(じょうだん)にしないほうがいいよ。冗談(じょうだん)にも程(ほど)がある。 Things like that could hurt the other person's feelings, so you should not joke about that. There are limits to jokes too. Caution Despite being used negatively in the vast majority of situations, there are instances where にも程(ほど)がある will be used positively with adjectives such as かわいい 'cute' or うまい 'delicious'. In sentences like this, the grammar structure is being used jokingly to express admiration or approval. なんだこれは！店(みせ)出(だ)せるほどの美味(おい)しさじゃん！うまいにも程(ほど)があるだろ。 What the heck is this!? This is so good you can open a restaurant! There is a limit to how good it can be!

example.japanese: 自信(じしん)を持(も)ち過(す)ぎている友達(ともだち)１:「遅(おそ)かれ早(はや)かれノーベル賞(しょう)を受賞(じゅしょう)してみせるよ。」言(い)い過(す)ぎへの反応(はんのう)をする友達(ともだち)２:「ノーベル賞(しょう)を受賞(じゅしょう)なんて冗談(じょうだん)にもほどがあるぞ。」
example.english: Overconfident friend1: “Sooner or later, I will definitely win a Nobel Prize.”Friend2 who is reacting to the overstatement: “Getting a Nobel Prize? There are limits to jokes, too.”

example.japanese: 《Aが勝手(かって)にBの部屋(へや)に入(はい)ってきた状況(じょうきょう)》「こんな時間(じかん)に部屋(へや)に押(お)しかけてくるなんて、いったいどういう神経(しんけい)しているんだ。失礼(しつれい)にもほどがある。」
example.english: A situation in which A entered B’s room without permission: “What a nerve, to barge into a person's room at this hour. There is a limit to how impolite you can be!”

example.japanese: 《常(つね)に迷子(まいご)になってしまう方向(ほうこう)音痴(おんち)の友人(ゆうじん)へ》「高校生(こうこうせい)のくせに学校(がっこう)から帰(かえ)る途中(とちゅう)で道(みち)に迷(まよ)うなんて方向(ほうこう)音痴(おんち)にもほどがあるよ。」
example.english: To a friend with a poor sense of direction that gets lost on daily basis: “To get lost on the way home from school despite being a high schooler, there is a limit to how bad with directions you can be!”

example.japanese: 「まったく最近(さいきん)の若(わか)い子(こ)って、目上(めうえ)の人(ひと)がしゃべっているのにおしゃべりするなんて礼儀知(れいぎし)らずにもほどがある。」
example.english: “Seriously, youths these days, to talk when one’s superior is talking, there is a limit to how mannerless one can be.”

example.japanese: 《親(おや)が友達(ともだち)と話(はな)す》「うちの子供(こども)たちはずっと一日中(いちにちじゅう)二人(ふたり)でゲームしてるよ。起(お)きてから何(なに)も食(た)べずにゲーム三昧(ざんまい)よ。不(ふ)健康(けんこう)な生活(せいかつ)にもほどがあるよね。」
example.english: Parent speaks with a friend: “My children play games all day long. They wake up and without eating anything, and then they are absorbed in their games. There is a limit to how unhealthy life one can live.”

english_grammar.title: にもまして
english_grammar.explanation: even -er than, even more than, more than anything, more than anybody, more than ever
english_grammar.structure: Noun + にもまして 何にもまして 誰にもまして いつにもまして
english_grammar.about: にもまして is a structure used to imply that something has surpassed a certain point, and will be used particularly when that thing was at a consistent level in the past, but has now risen. Common translations include 'more than ever, (B)', or 'even more than (A), (B)'. にもまして is simply a combination of the case-marking particle に, the adverbial particle も 'even', and the て-from of the う-Verb 増(ま)す 'to increase'. The に will be attached to a noun which it is marking as the comparison point from which 増(ま)す indicates an increase or growth. This means that the literal translation is simply 'even increasing from (A), (B)'. 今年(ことし)は去年(きょねん)にもまして、湿気(しっけ)が高(たか)い。 This year is even more humid than last year. ちゃんと薬(くすり)を飲(の)んで体(からだ)を休(やす)ませたのに、昨日(きのう)にもまして腹痛(ふくつう)がひどい。 I took the proper medication and rested my body, but my stomach ache is even worse than yesterday. This pattern will regularly follow words like 誰(だれ) 'who', 何(なに) 'what', or いつ 'when'. In these cases, (A) is just being expressed as 'anyone', 'anything', or 'ever', rather than something more specific. 斎藤(さいとう)くんは誰(だれ)にもまして仕事(しごと)を一生懸命(いっしょうけんめい)やってくれるからものすごく助かっている。 Saito-kun works harder than anyone else, so he is very helpful. このプロジェクトを成功(せいこう)させることは、何(なに)にもまして大切(たいせつ)なんだ。 Succeeding in this project is more important than anything else. 彼女(かのじょ)はいつにもまして輝(かがや)いている。 She is shining brighter than ever.

example.japanese: 利用者(りようしゃ)は大(だい)企業(きぎょう)が常(つね)に大量(たいりょう)のデータ収集(しゅうしゅう)する時代(じだい)にこれまでにもまして自分(じぶん)プライバシーを気(き)にせざるを得(え)ない。
example.english: In this age when large companies constantly gathering data, users cannot help but pay even more attention to their privacy than before.

example.japanese: 日本(にっぽん)の夏(なつ)は常(つね)に蒸(む)し暑(あつ)いことで知(し)られている。だが今年(ことし)は例年(れいねん)にもまして湿度(しつど)が高(たか)くなっている。
example.english: Summers in Japan are known for being sultry. But the humidity is even higher than average this year.

example.japanese: 全(すべ)ての選手(せんしゅ)が本当(ほんとう)に奮闘(ふんとう)したが、はいろさんに至(いた)っては、誰(だれ)にもまして情熱(じょうねつ)を燃(も)やした。
example.english: All of the team members are making an all-out effort, but when it comes to Hairo-san, he burns with passion even more than anyone else.

example.japanese: 社会(しゃかい)の情報化(じょうほうか)が進(すす)むにつれ、会社(かいしゃ)は従来(じゅうらい)にもましてセキュリティ上(じょう)の危険(きけん)にさらされるようになった。
example.english: With the informatization of the society, companies have come to be exposed to security risks even more than before.

example.japanese: 親(おや)として、何(なに)にもましてうちの子供(こども)が健(すこ)やかに成長(せいちょう)できるように願(ねが)う。
example.english: As a parent, even more than anything else, I wish for my children to grow up healthy.

english_grammar.title: 捲(まく)る
english_grammar.explanation: like crazy, keep doing (without a second thought), nothing but, on and on, do … all around, to do a lot of, one after another, all over, keep, everything, constantly, all the time
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］(*) + まくる Verb［て］+ Verb［て］+ Verb［ます］(*) + まくる (*) Verb has to be volitional (can be controlled by the will of a doer)
english_grammar.attention: まくる is also sometimes used as a noun, using Verb［ます］+ まくり + だ pattern
english_grammar.about: まくる is a verb that will be attached to the conjunctive form of other verbs in order to show that (A) is being done over and over, a lot, or with a great amount of vigor. It comes from the verb う-Verb 捲(まく)る 'to roll', or 'to turn', so means 'to do (A) around and again'. Common translations include 'to (A) like crazy', 'to do nothing but (A)', and 'to constantly do (A)'. As mentioned, this structure will attach to the conjunctive form of other verbs. 昨日(きのう)は釣具屋(つりぐや)でルアーを買(か)いまくったから、来週(らいしゅう)までご飯(はん)とふりかけで我慢(がまん)しなきゃいけない。 I bought a bunch of lures at the tackle shop yesterday, so I have put up with eating rice and furikake until next week. 久(ひさ)しぶりに実家(じっか)に帰(かえ)って、母(はは)の料理(りょうり)を食(た)べまくってるから少(すこ)し太(ふと)ってきた。 I have started to gain some weight because I've been eating so much of my mom's food, ever since I came to visit my family after a long time. 昨日(きのう)はカラオケで歌(うた)いまくったから、声(こえ)が全然(ぜんぜん)でない。 I sang like crazy at the karaoke last night, so I lost my voice. This structure may be used both in positive or negative contexts, and it is quite common for the nuance of まくる to indicate that (A) is being done recklessly, or with abandon. This implies that the speaker isn't thinking about the consequences of doing (A) repeatedly, if any may exist. Caution - The (A) verb must be something that is volitional, meaning that the speaker must have control over it and its repetition. しゃっくりが出(で)まくりすぎて苦(くや)しい。 I am having a hard time breathing because I am hiccuping like crazy. (Unnatural Japanese)

example.japanese: はやせとなおとは狂(くる)ったように踊(おど)って踊(おど)って踊(おど)りまくった。
example.english: Hayase and Naoto danced like crazy.

example.japanese: 「最近(さいきん)、チョコを食(た)べまくっているからちょっと太(ふと)った。」
example.english: "I've been eating chocolate like crazy lately, so I've gained some weight."

example.japanese: うざき「ゴールデンウィーク何(なん)か用事(ようじ)あるの？」 さくらい 「せっかくだから毎日(まいにち)朝(あさ)から晩(ばん)までゲームをやりまくりたいんだ。」
example.english: Uzaki: "Do you have plans for the golden week? " Sakurai: "It's a rare opportunity, so I want to play games every day like crazy, from dusk till dawn."

example.japanese: 「まさはるさんは新車(しんしゃ)購入(こうにゅう)したから毎日(まいにち)乗(の)りまくってるらしいよ。」
example.english: "I heard that Masaharu-san bought a new car and has been driving it all the time, every single day."

example.japanese: 「よしこって喋(しゃべ)るのが大好(だいす)きだ。ベラベラしゃべりまくるから彼女(かのじょ)には我慢(がまん)できない。」
example.english: "Yoshiko loves to talk. She talks nonstop, like crazy so I can't stand her."
