english_grammar.title: わ〜わで
english_grammar.explanation: and...so, and...because, since
english_grammar.structure: (A) (1)+ わ + (B) (1) + わ（で） (1) Verb［る］、［い］Adjective、［な］Adjective + だ、Noun + だ
english_grammar.about: As mentioned in the わ grammar point, わ is an adverbial particle that is commonly used in cases of stress of emphasis in Japanese. When used after either verbs, い-Adjectives, な-Adjectives, or nouns in their standard forms, it generally implies that (A) and (B) are negative factors that have lead to (C), where (C) is either a negative outcome, or a negative opinion. It will often be translated simply as 'with (A) and (B), (C)'. To use this structure, simply place わ after a word, and then repeat the same after a second (different) word. In the case of な-Adjective or nouns, だわ will be used. The case-marking particle で will then follow the second わ, indicating 'with', or 'as a consequence of'. 昨日(きのう)はクライアントに怒(おこ)られるわ、自分(じぶん)の上司(じょうし)に暴言(ぼうげん)吐(は)かれるわで大変(たいへん)だった。 I had a bad day yesterday because my client was mad at mea and because my boss yelled at me. このアパートはボロいわ狭(せま)いわで最悪(さいあく)な物件(ぶっけん)だ。 This apartment sucks because it is run-down and small. 新(あたら)しく入(はい)ってきた新人(しんじん)はクライアントには無礼(ぶれい)だわ、クレーム対応(たいおう)が下手(へた)だわで、どこから教育(きょういく)していいかわからない。 The newbie that just joined is rude to our clients and bad at handling complaints, so I don't know how I should train him. 携帯(けいたい)を買(か)ってくれたこと自体(じたい)は嬉(うれ)しかったんだけと、5年(ねん)前(まえ)のモデルだわ画面(がめん)は割(わ)れているわで使(つか)い物(もの)にならなそうだったから、自分(じぶん)で新(あたら)しい携帯(けいたい)を買(か)った。 I am happy that they bought me a phone, but it was a 5 year old model and the screen was broken and didn't look like I would be able to use it, so I went ahead and bought myself a new phone. わ～わで, like わ, primarily emphasizes the speaker's surprise in regard to the words that appear before it. However, unlike わ, where the same verb will be repeated in order to highlight an excessive extent, わ～わで simply indicates surprise in terms of irritation or frustration. This structure is predominantly used by men, but it may also sometimes be used by women. However, there are several different variations of わ depending on where they appear in sentences, each of which have gender usage tendencies that will need to be learned. In essence, わ is used in the same way as し～し, where the words that they are being attached to are just being listed as reasons. Additionally, the で may occasionally be omitted. Fun-fact - わ is simply an emphatic version of the usual は adverbial particle, and originates from は being changed to わ. Due to this, the literal meaning can be thought of as a stronger version of the standard 'as for (A)' meaning of は. Caution - While this grammar pattern is used almost exclusively with a negative nuance, it may, in rare cases, have a positive nuance. 今年(ことし)は宝(たから)くじには当(あ)たるわ、長年(ながねん)付(つ)き合(あ)っていた彼氏(かれし)にプロポーズされるわで、幸(しあわ)せなことが沢山(たくさん)あってとても嬉(うれ)しい。 I am very happy this year because I won the lottery and my boyfriend of many years is going to propose to me. (Positive meaning)

example.japanese: A「顔色(かおいろ)が悪(わる)いね。」 B「そうなんだよね。昨日(きのう)の夜(よる)、ルームメイトがうるさいわ、蚊(か)にたくさんさされるわでちっとも眠(ねむ)れなかった。」
example.english: A: "Oh, you look pale!" B: "Yeah, I know. I couldn't sleep at all last night because of my noisy roommate and all the mosquito bites."

example.japanese: 「今朝(けさ)の通勤時(つうきんじ)は、急(きゅう)に雨(あめ)が降(ふ)ってくるわ傘(かさ)は壊(こわ)れるわで大変(たいへん)だった。」
example.english: "I had a hard time getting to work this morning because it suddenly started raining and my umbrella broke."

example.japanese: 「今日(きょう)はタンスに小指(こゆび)をぶつけるわ、道(みち)でつまずくわで、ついてなかった。」
example.english: "I was not lucky today because I hit my little finger on the dresser and tripped on the street."

example.japanese: 「朝(あさ)から犬(いぬ)に吠(ほ)えられるわ、鳥(とり)のウンチが頭(あたま)に落(お)ちてくるわで…（最低(さいてい)な1日(にち)だったわ）。」
example.english: "The dogs barked at me in the morning and the bird pooped on my head, so... （it was a horrible day.）"

example.japanese: 「あのレストラン、料理(りょうり)に虫(むし)が入(はい)ってるわ、クレームいったら切(き)れられるわで最低(さいてい)だったの。」
example.english: "Speaking of that restaurant, it was the worst since they had bugs in the food, and when I complained about it, I was ignored."

english_grammar.title: や否(いな)や
english_grammar.explanation: as soon as, no sooner than, the minute
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］+ や否や(1) + Phrase［た］ (1)や
english_grammar.about: や否(いな)や, like か否(いな)か, is a grammar pattern that makes use of 否(いな) 'no', an interjection. However, unlike the pairing with the adverbial particle か 'or' when stating 'whether or not (A)', the pairing of 否(いな) with や in its role as a conjunction particle has the meaning of 'as soon as (A)', or 'no sooner than (A)'. Remembering that や simply highlights the word before it is not being limited to that, the literal meaning of や否(いな)や is 'at a point when neither (A) or not (A) could be determined, (B)'. や否(いな)や will be used after verbs in their dictionary form. 私(わたし)が部屋(へや)から出(で)てくるのを見(み)るや否(いな)や、空(あ)き巣(す)が手(て)に持(も)っていたものを私(わたし)に投(な)げて、逃(に)げていった。 As soon as the burglar saw me coming out of the room, he threw everything that was in his hand at me and ran away. 俺(おれ)の顔(かお)を見(み)るや否(いな)や友達(ともだち)の犬(いぬ)が吠(ほ)え出(だ)した。 As soon as he saw my face, my friend's dog started barking. 彼(かれ)は席(せき)に座(すわ)るや否(いな)や「とりあえず生(なま)一(ひと)つ」といった。 He said 'I'll have a beer to start' as soon as he sat down. や否(いな)や is a formal expression that will generally be used when (B) is something that happens spontaneously, or is surprising. Caution - As や itself carries the 'not limited to' meaning, it is also possible to see this structure with the 否(いな)や part omitted. In these situations, the meaning will not change at all. や in this case behaves similarly to か when presenting a question in the middle of a sentence, and sounds like 'when not certain that (A), (B)'. 彼(かれ)は本(ほん)を開(ひら)くや、寝(ね)た。 He fell asleep as soon as he opened the book. 彼女(かのじょ)はあの曲(きょく)を聴(き)くや、泣(な)き始(はじ)めた。 She started to cry as soon as she listened to the song.

example.japanese: 《記事(きじ)》警察官(けいさつかん)に気(き)が付(つ)くや否(いな)や急(きゅう)に走(はし)り出(だ)した。
example.english: Article: As soon as he noticed the policeman, he suddenly started to run.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》彼(かれ)があくびをするや否(いな)や彼女(かのじょ)もあくびが出(で)てしまった。
example.english: Novel: As soon as he has yawned, the girl also yawned.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》焼(や)き立(た)てのパンが皿(さら)に出(で)てくるや否(いな)やすぐに彼(かれ)の口(くち)の中(なか)に消(き)えた。
example.english: Novel: As soon as the freshly baked bread appeared on the plate, it immediately disappeared in his mouth.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》とっくの昔(むかし)に亡(な)くなっている友達(ともだち)からもらった、古(ふる)い手紙(てがみ)を読(よ)み始(はじ)めるや否(いな)や感情(かんじょう)があふれ、たちまち涙(なみだ)が溢(あふ)れてしまった。
example.english: Novel: As soon as I started reading an old letter I received from a friend who was long gone, my feelings flooded and I suddenly dissolved into tears.

example.japanese: 《アイドルについての小説(しょうせつ)》照橋(てるはし)さんはサングラスを外(はず)すや否(いな)やあっという間(ま)にファンが周(まわ)りに集(たか)った。
example.english: Novel about idols: As soon as Teruhashi-san took off the sunglasses, in the blink of an eye, she was surrounded by fans.

english_grammar.title: 次第(しだい)です
english_grammar.explanation: because the reason is, therefore, the present situation is like this, this is how (it is), those are the circumstances, this is why
english_grammar.structure: Verb + 次第 + です
english_grammar.attention: avoid using 次第でございます since 次第 in this usage is already humble and でございます might make the phrase too polite, and some people may even take it as irony
english_grammar.about: When following a verb in one of its standard forms, 次第(しだい) 'directly following' will be used to express reasons or give explanations. In these cases, it will be followed by either of the auxiliary verbs だ, or です. However, です is far more common, due to this use of 次第(しだい) primarily appearing in polite speech. 高速(こうそく)で玉突(たまつき)き事故(じこ)があったので、遅(おく)れた次第(しだい)です。 I was late because there was an accident involving several cars on the highway. 来月(らいげつ)から、向(む)かいの家(いえ)に引(ひ)っ越(こ)すことになったので、挨拶(あいさつ)しにきた次第(しだい)です。 I came to introduce myself because we will be living in the house across from yours starting next month. 先輩(せんぱい)が提案(ていあん)してくださったプランでは予算(よさん)オーバーしそうだったので、今(いま)クライアントと相談(そうだん)しつつ色々(いろいろ)と調整(せいび)している次第(しだい)です。 We are now discussing with the client and making various adjustments because the plan proposed by you (senpai) seemed like it was going to go over their budget. In this particular use of 次第(しだい), it is similar to 'the eventuation is that (A)', meaning that something ultimately ended up as (A), Fun FactIn all of its nuances, 次第(しだい) just expresses a sequence of events or deciding factors, and what either will or has happened due to that. This link can be seen in other grammar patterns like 次第(しだい) 'as soon as' , and 次第(しだい)だ 'depending on', or 'so'.

example.japanese: 《取引先(とりひきさき)への説明(せつめい)メール》「プロジェックトの進捗(しんちょく)状況(じょうきょう)についてご理解(りかい)頂(いただ)きたく、ご連絡(れんらく)差(さ)し上(あ)げた次第(しだい)です。」
example.english: Explanation mail to a customer: I am contacting you because I would like you to know about the current state of the project.

example.japanese: 《謝罪(しゃざい)メール》倉庫(そうこ)火災(かさい)によりご注文(ちゅうもん)いただいた商品(しょうひん)の納期(のうき)が遅(おく)れてしまった次第(しだい)です。心(こころ)よりお詫(わ)び申(もう)し上(あ)げます。
example.english: An apology email: The delivery date of the ordered products has been delayed because of a warehouse fire. We sincerely apologize.

example.japanese: 《招待客(しょうたいきゃく)への説明(せつめい)メール》万国博覧会(ばんこくはくらんかい)は、台風(たいふう)接近(せっきん)のため中止(ちゅうし)にせざるを得(え)なかった次第(しだい)です。
example.english: Explanation mail to the invitee: “We were obliged to cancel the World Expo because of the approaching typhoon.”

example.japanese: 《部下(ぶか)が上司(じょうし)に》「吹雪(ふぶき)の影響(えいきょう)で列車(れっしゃ)の運行(うんこう)ダイヤが乱(みだ)れており、出社(しゅっしゃ)が遅(おく)れた次第(しだい)です。」
example.english: Subordinate to boss: “I arrived late to the office because of the blizzard and the train schedule was disrupted.”

example.japanese: 《内定状(ないていじょう)》博士(はかせ)にご執筆(しっぴつ)いただきました教科書(きょうかしょ)は、学生(がくせい)の間(あいだ)でとても好評(こうひょう)です。つきましては、博士(はかせ)にぜひ講師(こうし)としてご就任(しゅうにん)いただきたく、お願(ねが)い申(もう)し上(あ)げる次第(しだい)です。
example.english: Job offer letter: The textbook that you have written is very popular among the students. Therefore we would like to humbly request you to assume the position of lecturer.

english_grammar.title: と言(い)うところ
english_grammar.explanation: I would say (about), I guess (about), it could be said that, about, at best
english_grammar.structure: Phrase + というところ(1) + だ (1) といったところ、ってとこ
english_grammar.attention: Don't confuse ってとこ with ってこと！
english_grammar.about: というところ is a grammar expression that is used when highlighting an approximate number or degree for something. It is a combination of the case-marking particle と, the う-Verb 言(い)う 'to say', and the noun ところ 'place', which often marks situations. Common translations include 'I would say about (A)', 'I guess about (A)'. A more literal translation is 'To be at the point where saying (A) is accurate'. It is most common for this structure to appear following either verbs or nouns, but may also occasionally follow adjectives. Coming primarily at the end of sentences, というところ will often be followed immediately by the auxiliary verb だ or です. このペースだとこの工事(こうじ)はあと二週間(にしゅうかん)で終(お)わるというところだ。 At this pace, I would say this construction work will be finished in about two weeks. どれぐらい辛(つら)いって聞(き)かれても...汗(あせ)が出(で)るぐらい辛(つら)いというところかな。 You are asking me how spicy it is? I would say spicy enough to make you sweat. まあ順調(じゅんちょう)は順調(じゅんちょう)だけど、まあまあというところだ。 Well, you could say everything is going smoothly, but it's alright, I guess. 電車(でんしゃ)で行(い)けば三十(さんじゅ)分(っぷん)かかるけど、車(くるま)なら十五(じゅうご)分(ふん)というところです。 It would take 30 minutes by train, but I would say it would take 15 minutes by car. Occasionally, という will be replaced by the past-tense form, といった. However, the meaning does not change at all in these cases. これぐらいの物件(ぶっけん)だったら5000万(まん)といったところですね。 For a property of this size, I would say it would cost something like 50 million. 徒歩(とほ)だと1時間(じかん)といったところです。 I would say it would take a minute by walking. Caution というところ has a tendency to be used when the number being given is the theoretical maximum for something, rather than the theoretical minimum. Due to this, it may sound unnatural when wanting to present an approximate minimum. 買取(かいとり)となると、最低(さいてい)で5千円(せんえん)というところです。 If we were to buy this from you, I would say we would pay you at least 5 thousand yen.

example.japanese: はなこ「オリビアの日本語(にほんご)のレベルはどうですか？」かすみ「せいぜい平均(へいきん)といったところでしょう。」
example.english: Hanako: “How are Olivia’s Japanese skills?”Kasumi: “I would say average at best.”

example.japanese: 上司(じょうし)「頼(たの)んでいた仕事(しごと)はどこまでおわりましたか？」部下(ぶか)「70、80％というところです。」
example.english: Boss: “How far have you gotten on the job I asked you to do?”Subordinate: “I would say it is about 70-80% done.”

example.japanese: ともだち１「スーパーまで行(い)くのにどれくらいかかる？」ともだち２「たぶん２０分(ふん)といったところだろう。」
example.english: Friend1: “How long will it take to get to the supermarket?”Friend2: “I would say about 20 minutes.”

example.japanese: 友達(ともだち)１「小説(しょうせつ)はいつ書(か)き上(あ)げる？」友達(ともだち)２「あと４、５日(にち)といったところかしら？」
example.english: Friend1: “When will you finish writing the novel?”Friend2: “I would say there are about 4-5 days left.”

example.japanese: 《散歩中(さんぽちゅう)、見(み)た家(いえ)について話(はな)すカップル》配偶者(はいぐうしゃ)１「この３LDKの家(いえ)、だいたいいくらぐらい？どう思(おも)う？」配偶者(はいぐうしゃ)２「おおよそ3892万(まん)というところかな」
example.english: A Couple chatting about a house they see during a walk, Spouse 1: “About how much is this 3 bedroom house worth? What do you think?”Spouse 2: “I would say it’s worth about 38 920 000 yen.”

english_grammar.title: １～たりとも～ない
english_grammar.explanation: not even one, not a single, no (at all)
english_grammar.structure: 1 + Counter + たりとも + Phrase［ない］(1) (1) Verb［な］
english_grammar.attention: 何人たりとも + Phrase[ない]/Verb + な
english_grammar.about: たりとも is a grammar pattern that is most often used in negative sentences, in order to indicate that (A) is not an exception to something. It will follow either number words, or nouns. Possible translations include 'not even one (A)', and 'not a single (A)'. However, due to たりとも just being a combination of the auxiliary verb たり 'presenting examples', and the conjunction particle とも 'presenting approximate limitations', the literal translation of たりとも is just 'even limited to (A) as an example, not (B)', with the 'not (B)' coming from the negative structure in the second half of the sentence. みんなで押(お)し入(い)れようとしたが、一(いち)ミリたりとも動(うご)かなかったから、ユンボで押(お)し込(こ)みました。 We all tried to push it in together, but it did not even move a millimeter, so we pushed it in using a backhoe. 消防士(しょうぼうし)などは一秒(いちびょう)たりとも気(き)を抜(ぬ)くことができない。 People like firefighters can't lose focus, even for a second. 私(わたし)は一分(いっぷん)たりとも残業(ざんぎょう)をしたくないので毎日(まいにち)定時(ていじ)に帰(かえ)っています。 I don't want to work overtime even for a minute, so I go home on time every day. 少(すこ)したりとも油断(ゆだん)をすると、ミスをして命(いのち)を落(お)とす恐(おそ)れがあります。 If you let your guard down even a little, you could make a mistake that could cost you your life. This is a very formal expression, so will not be used in daily conversation. Fun-fact - 何人(なんびと)たりとも 'no matter who it is, no exceptions' is a set expression that may see more frequent use than any of the other たりとも structures. この洞窟(どうくつ)へは20年前(ねんまえ)に起(お)きた事故(じこ)以来(いらい)、何人(なんびと)たりとも立(た)ち入(い)ることが許(うる)されない。 Since the accident that occurred 20 years ago, no one has been allowed to enter this cave.

example.japanese: 小説(しょうせつ)、敵役(かたきやく)：「貴様(きさま)らは全員(ぜんいん)、今日(きょう)この場所(ばしょ)で死(し)ぬことになる。一(いっ)匹(ぴき)たりとも逃(に)がすつもりはない。」
example.english: A novel, the villain : 'It is decided, you all die here today. I do not intend to let even one of you escape.'

example.japanese: 安全(あんぜん)や生命(せいめい)を脅(おびや)かすものは何(なん)人(びと)たりとも許(ゆる)されない。
example.english: Not even one person is allowed to threaten life or security.

example.japanese: 茜雫(せんな)の死(し)以来(いらい)１５年(ねん)経(た)ったが、彼女(かのじょ)を忘(わす)れたことは一(いち)度(ど)たりともなかった。
example.english: Even though 15 years have passed since the death of Senna, I have not forgotten her even one time.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》一瞬(いっしゅん)たりとも無駄(むだ)にしないつもりで生(い)きている。
example.english: Novel: He follows his belief of wasting not even one moment in his life.

example.japanese: 人間(にんげん)は酸素(さんそ)なしには１日(にち)たりとも生(い)きられない。
example.english: Humans can not live even one day without oxygen.

english_grammar.title: といっ + たらない
english_grammar.explanation: cannot tell/describe/say/express how, words cannot express, too … for words, extremely
english_grammar.structure: More common patterns: Noun + といったらない(1) ［い］Adjective［さ］(2) + といったらない(1) Less common patterns: Verb + といったらない(1) ［な］Adjective + といったらない(1) (1)ったらない (2)［い］Adjective
english_grammar.about: といったらない is a casual expression used when something is at a level such that not even (A) is sufficient to describe it. It is usually translated as 'there are no words to express (A)', or 'too (A) for words'. This structure is a combination of the case-marking particle と, the conjunction particle たら 'when', or 'if', and the い-Adjective ない. It may be used in either positive or negative contexts. といったらない, or the shortened form ったらない may appear after adjectives or nouns in their standard forms. 隣(となり)の人(ひと)の犬(いぬ)は朝(あさ)からうるさいといったらない。 I can't describe to you how loud my neighbor's dog is in the morning. 息子(むすこ)を家(いえ)で留守番(るすばん)させるのは心配(しんぱい)といったらない。 I can't tell you how worried I am to let my son stay at home alone. プロジェクトを終(お)わらせた後(あと)の達成感(たっせいかん)ったらない。 I can't describe the feeling of accomplishment after finishing a project. The ない in this grammar pattern is commonly thought to be an abbreviation of ありはしない, or ありゃしない, the conjunctive form of the う-Verb ある combined with the case marking particle は, and the negated form of する, しない. In this way, a more literal meaning can be thought of as 'if one were to say (A), it's not possible'. あの子(こ)の運転(うんてん)は危(あぶ)ないといったらありゃしないから、あの子(こ)と出(で)かける時(とき)には運転(うんてん)させないようにしている。 I can't describe how bad her driving is. I always make sure not to let her drive when we go somewhere. 田舎(いなか)では車(くるま)がないとどこにもいけないから、不便(ふべん)といったらありゃしない。 I can't describe to you how inconvenient the countryside is. You can't go anywhere without a car. 彼女(かのじょ)は私(わたし)の話(はなし)を全然(ぜんぜん)聞(き)いてくれない。むかつくといったらありゃしない。 She does not listen to a word I say. I can't describe to you how annoyed I am. Caution - As this expression highlights an extreme amount, い-Adjectives will often be used with the さ suffix added, specifically to indicate amount. あの人(ひと)の優(やさ)しさと言(い)ったらありゃしない。 I can't describe how nice he is.

example.japanese: 「校長(こうちょう)と鹿(しか)との戦(たたか)いを見(み)たときの驚(おどろ)きといったらないよ。」
example.english: “I can’t describe my surprise at seeing a fight between the principal and a deer.”

example.japanese: 「車(くるま)のタイヤが盗(ぬす)まれた。本当(ほんとう)に腹(はら)が立(た)つったらない。」
example.english: “My car tires have been stolen. I can’t tell you how angry I am!”

example.japanese: A：「歯(は)を引(ひ)っこ抜(ぬ)くのはどうだった？」B：「あの痛(いた)みといったらないわよ、本気(ほんき)で死(し)ぬかと思(おも)ったもの。」
example.english: A: “How was the tooth extraction?”B: “I can’t tell you how painful it is! I really thought I was going to die.”

example.japanese: 数(すう)年(ねん)が経(た)ったのにまだあの日(ひ)の日没(にちぼつ)を覚(おぼ)えている。その景色(けしき)の美(うつく)しさと言(い)ったらなかった。
example.english: Even though years have passed, I can still remember the sunset that day. I couldn’t describe the beauty of the scene in words.

example.japanese: メークした時(とき)の星野(ほしの)の変(か)わり様(よう)と言(い)ったらなかった。まるで別人(べつじん)のようだった。
example.english: I couldn’t describe how much Hoshino has changed when she put on the makeup. She was like a different person.

english_grammar.title: に照(て)らして
english_grammar.explanation: in light of, based on, according to, referencing, comparing against, in view of
english_grammar.structure: Noun + に照らして(1) Noun (A) + に照らした + Noun (B) (1)に照らすと
english_grammar.about: に照(て)らして is an expression based on the standard meaning of the う-Verb 照(て)らす 'to illuminate', and is primarily used comparatively in a similar way to 'in light of' in English. This comparative meaning aims to illustrate (B) from the perspective of (A), and usually refers to situations, level of experience, or something similar. To use this structure, attach the case-marking particle に to the end of a noun, then follow it with 照(て)らして. If a second noun will be modified directly, then 照(て)らした will be used instead. 母(はは)は自分(じぶん)の経験(けいけん)に照(て)らして、こういう時(とき)はどうすればいいかをアドバイスしてくれた。 My mother advised me what to do in these situations in light of her own experience. 労働(ろうどう)基準法(きじゅんほう)を守(まも)らない会社(かいしゃ)は法律(ほうりつ)に照(て)らして罰(ばっ)せられるべきだ。 Companies that do not comply with the labor laws should be punished in accordance with the law. 経済(けいざい)統計(とうけい)に照(て)らした強盗(ごうとう)と窃盗(せっとう)事件(じけん)に関(かん)する犯罪(はんざい)統計(とうけい)。 Crime statistics on burglaries and thefts in light of economic statistics. 犯罪者(はんざいしゃ)は刑法(けいほう)に照(て)らして罰(ばっ)せられる。 Criminals are punished in accordance with the law. Keep in mind that the に in this structure is marking (A) as the 'doer' of 照(て)らす 'to illuminate', as it is a transitive verb. This means that the structure has a more literal translation of '(B) as reflected by (A)'. This can also be thought of as 'as made clear by (A), (B)', 'as made evident by (A), (B)'. (B) will almost always be a judgment that is logically based on (A).

example.japanese: ２０１７年(ねん)の経験(けいけん)に照(て)らして価格(かかく)下落(げらく)は限定的(げんていてき)であると私(わたし)は考(かんが)えています。
example.english: In light of the experience of 2017, I believe that price drop will be limited in scope.

example.japanese: 彼女(かのじょ)の生活(せいかつ)習慣(しゅうかん)に照(て)らして罪(つみ)がないことを宣言(せんげん)された。
example.english: In light of her everyday life (alibi), she has been declared innocent.

example.japanese: 我々(われわれ)の基準(きじゅん)に照(て)らすと、この製品(せいひん)を粗悪品(そあくひん)と言(い)う人(ひと)は少(すく)なくない。
example.english: There are quite a few people that would call this product inferior in light of our standards.

example.japanese: アルバイトをすることは学校(がっこう)の規則(きそく)に照(て)らして規則(きそく)違反(いはん)になる。
example.english: Part-time working is a violation in light of school rules.

example.japanese: 国内(こくない)の状況(じょうきょう)に照(て)らすと、国外(こくがい)からの石油(せきゆ)の購入(こうにゅう)は必要(ひつよう)である。
example.english: In light of the domestic situation, purchasing petrol abroad is necessary...

english_grammar.title: とあれば
english_grammar.explanation: (emphatic) if, if it is the case that, as (you wish)
english_grammar.structure: Noun + （だ）+ とあれば
english_grammar.about: とあれば is a grammar pattern in Japanese that is used as an emphatic version of なら 'if'. It will primarily be used in formal situations, or for literary effect, such as in a novel. It may be translated as 'if (A) is the case, then (B)', or 'should (A) be true, then (B)'. This is a combination of the case-marking particle と, and the hypothetical form of the う-Verb ある 'to be', あれば. とあれば will primarily follow nouns, but is occasionally also seen after other structures such as verbs and adjectives when the と is being used as a quotation. データを復元(ふくげん)できるとあれば、いくらでも出(だ)します！ If it is for recovering my data, I would pay whatever you offer! 状態(じょうたい)がいいとあれば4万(まん)円(えん)ぐらいで売(う)れると思(おも)いますよ。 If it is in good condition, I think you'd be able to sell it for 40,000 yen. 先輩(せんぱい)の指示(しじ)とあれば従(したが)わないわけにはいけないけど、絶対(ぜったい)私(わたし)のやり方(かた)の方(ほう)が効率(こうりつ)がいいと思(おも)うのに。 It is my Senpai's orders so I have to do it, but I swear my way is a lot more efficient. お前(まえ)の頼(たの)みとあればやるしかないだろ。俺(おれ)に任(まか)せろ。 If it is your wish, I have to do it. Leave it up to me. (A) is often some special circumstance or condition that leads to the conclusion or assumption of (B), were (A) to be accurate. As this expression is emphatic, (B) will usually indicate something that must be done, or can't be avoided with structures like しかない, なければならない, ざるを得ない, etc. Fun-fact - とあれば tends to appear with のため before it quite often. This can be translated as 'if for the purpose of (A)', and will describe the lengths that the speaker is willing to go for (A) in (B). 息子(むすこ)のためとあればどれだけでも残業(ざんぎょう)をする。 If it is for my son, I will do as much overtime as I have to.

example.japanese: 息子(むそこ)のためとあれば、火(ひ)の中(なか)でも飛(と)び込(こ)みます。
example.english: If it is for my son, I would even dive into a fire.

example.japanese: A「お願(ねが)いがあって。ねえ聞(き)いてくれる？」B「もちろん！Aさんの望(のぞ)みとあれば何(なに)でも聞(き)いちゃうよ。なに？」
example.english: A: “I have a request. Will you listen?”B: “Of course. If it is your wish, I will listen to everything. What (is it)?”

example.japanese: A「あすの朝(あさ)でも発(た)てるか？」B「必要(ひつよう)とあれば（行(い)くしかない）ね」
example.english: A: “Are you leaving tomorrow morning?”B: “If it is necessary (I will have no choice, but to go).”

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》「皇帝(こうてい)陛下(へいか)の命令(めいれい)とあればせざるを得(え)ない！」
example.english: Novel: “If it is his Highness's order, then I will have no choice but to do it.”

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》誘拐犯(ゆうかいはん)「おまえの父親(ちちおや)は、おまえのためとあれば、法外(ほうがい)に巨額(きょがく)の身代金(みのしろきん)でも喜(よろこ)んで払(はら)うだろう。」
example.english: Novel, kidnapper: “Your father, if it is for you, will gladly pay even an absurdly large ransom.”

english_grammar.title: さぞ
english_grammar.explanation: you must be very, how … you must be, I dare to say, I am sure/certain that you must be very
english_grammar.structure: さぞ + （かし）+ Phrase + （こと）+ だろう
english_grammar.attention: sometimes used with ことと思う、ことと存じる、に間違いない
english_grammar.about: さぞ is a fairly formal adverb in Japanese that is used emphatically to highlight that the following statement is something that the speaker understands to be true. This is often in relation to the feelings or situation of another. Common translations include 'you must be very (A)', 'how (A) you must be', or 'I dare say that (A)'. 'I dare to say that (A)' is probably the closest to the literal meaning of さぞ, as the speaker is empathizing with someone else by trying to imagine the situation from their point of view. As さぞ is an adverb, it will usually appear at the beginning of a sentence, modifying the whole phrase that follows. あの一流(いちりゅう)企業(きぎょう)で働(はたら)いているなら、さぞいいところに住(す)んでいるんでしょう。 If you work for that prestigious company, you must live in a very nice place. おばあさんが急(きゅう)に入院(にゅういん)されて、さぞご心配(しんぱい)でしょう。 Your grandmother's sudden hospitalization must be very worrisome. あんなニコニコしている斎藤(さいとう)さんは初(はじ)めて見(に)た。さぞ嬉(うれ)しい出来事(できごと)があったんでしょう。 I had never seen Saito-san smiling like that before. He must have had something good happen to him. The phrase following さぞ will often finish with だろう or でしょう. This highlights the speaker's opinion about the situation as being limited by their own knowledge. Caution さぞ comes from the kanji 嘸(さぞ), which has two alternative readings, 嘸(さぞ)や, and 嘸(さぞ)かし. Both 嘸(さぞ)や, and 嘸(さぞ)かし are occasionally used as even further emphasized versions of さぞ. あんなに大切(たいせつ)にしていた車(くるま)を盗(ぬす)まれたなんて、さぞや悔(くや)しかっただろう。 You must have been so frustrated to have such a cherished car stolen. あの人が彼(かれ)の父(ちち)だなんて、さぞかし驚(おどろ)いただろう。 He must have been very surprised that that man was his father. Despite being almost identical in meaning, さぞかし is used more often than さぞや.

example.japanese: 「夜勤(やきん)の仕事(しごと)もさぞ大変(たいへん)だろう。」
example.english: How tough the night shift work must be!

example.japanese: 「智子(さとこ)は昇進(しょうしん)が見送(みおく)られて、さぞがっかりしたに違(ちが)いない。」
example.english: Not getting the promotion, Satoko must be very disappointed. | How disappointed Satoko must be after not getting the promotion!

example.japanese: 「初(はじ)めての赤(あか)ちゃんのお誕生(たんじょう)にさぞ嬉(うれ)しいことでしょう。」
example.english: You must be very happy to have your first child. | How happy you must be to have your first child!

example.japanese: 《硬(かた)い手紙(てがみ)》ご子息(しそく)様(さま)のこと、さぞご心配(しんぱい)のことと思(おも)います。
example.english: Formal letter: You must be very worried about your son. | How worried you must be about your son!

example.japanese: 「家族(かぞく)が一生懸命(いっしょうけんめい)働(はたら)いているのに、あなただけ毎日(まいにち)遊(あそ)んでいるだけ、さぞ楽(たの)しいでしょうね！」
example.english: “Even though your family is working so hard, you are just having fun, how fun it must be!”

english_grammar.title: と来(き)たら ①
english_grammar.explanation: when it comes to, that/this … of mine, that/this darn …, that/this blasted …
english_grammar.structure: Noun + ときたら
english_grammar.attention: AときたらB can also express that for a topic A, the most suitable course of action/the most suited match is B. As in 夏ときたらやっぱり海！
english_grammar.about: ときたら is an expression used casually when expressing mild frustration toward (A) in a lighthearted manner. This structure is a combination of the case-marking particle と, and 来(く)る combined with the conjunction particle たら 'if', 来(き)たら. It will often simply be translated as 'that blasted (A)', or 'that damn (A)'. Despite this, the literal meaning is just 'when it comes to (A)'. ときたら will directly follow nouns. うちの息子(むすこ)ときたら、就職(しゅうしょく)もしないで家(いえ)でダラダラしている。 When it comes to my son, he is not even trying to get a job, and he is just sitting around at home. うちの弟(おとうと)ときたら、朝(あさ)から文句(もんく)ばかり言(い)ってくるから本当(ほんとう)にうざい。 This brother of mine, he always complains to me in the morning, and it is really annoying. 私(わたし)の上司(じょうし)ときたら、自分(じぶん)が仕事(しごと)できないくせに少(すこし)しでもミスをしたらものすごく怒(おこ)るからみんなから嫌(きら)われている。 When it comes to my boss, he gets super mad if you make the slightest mistake, even though he is not the best worker, so he is disliked by everyone at work. This grammar pattern will almost exclusively appear in kana, so memorizing the stem verb it comes from will help to remember the meaning. Fun-fact - In line with the literal meaning of 'when it comes to (A)', ときたら may also be used when the speaker wants to highlight something about (A) that is 'to be expected', or 'only natural'. Determining whether ときたら is being used in this way, or to express frustration, is usually quite clear in the second half of the statement. うちの犬(いぬ)ときたら、家(いえ)にお客(きゃく)さんが来(く)るとその人(ひと)に飛(と)びつくからもっと躾(しつけ)をちゃんとしないといけない。 When it comes to my dog, when a guest comes to our place, he jumps on them so I need to train him properly. (To be expected) カセットテープを使(つか)う機会(きかい)がなくなったため、最近(さいきん)の若者(わかもの)ときたら、カセットプレイヤーが使(つか)えない子達(こたち)が多(おお)い。 Since there is no opportunity to use cassette tapes, when it comes to the younger generation, there are many who do not know how to use cassette players. (Only natural) Despite having two almost opposite nuances, it may help to think of ときたら as just 'when it comes to (A)' in all situations, with the (B) part of the phrase indicating whether it is positive or negative.

example.japanese: 「このプリンターときたら、忙(いそが)しい時(とき)に限(かぎ)って故障(こしょう)するぞ！」
example.english: “This freaking printer of mine, it breaks only when I am busy.”

example.japanese: 「義理(ぎり)の母(はは)ときたら私(わたし)のことをぼやいてばかりよ。」
example.english: “That mother-in-law of mine, she always complains about me!”

example.japanese: 「娘(むすめ)は真面目(まじめ)に勉強(べんきょう)しているのに、息子(むすこ)ときたら・・・（何(なに)もやらない。）」
example.english: “Even though my daughter studies very seriously, that son of mine... (doesn’t do anything at all.)”

example.japanese: 「うちの旦那(だんな)ときたら、連休中(れんきゅうちゅう)うちでゴロゴロばかりで、子(こ)どもの面倒(めんどう)をみてくれないの。」
example.english: “That husband of mine, he is always loafing around during the holidays and doesn’t take care of children!”

example.japanese: 「武(たけ)さんのお父(とう)さんは格好(かっこう)いいよ。うちときたら水(みず)を節約(せつやく)してとか電気(でんき)を無駄(むだ)使(つか)いするなとかうるさくて腹(はら)が立(た)つ。」
example.english: “Take, your father is so cool. When it comes to mine, he is always fussy, telling things like “don’t waste water” or “don’t waste electricity” and it pisses me off.”

english_grammar.title: びる
english_grammar.explanation: -like, looking, feeling, with an air of, to become
english_grammar.structure: Noun + びる ［い］Adjective［い］ + びる Noun + びた + Noun ［い］Adjective［い］ + びた + Noun Used with a limited set of expressions: ・Common: おとなびる・おとなびた 古びた ひなびた ・Uncommon/sometimes used in literary language: 田舎びた 物寂びる ・Generally not used in modern language: ひねこびる 神さびる おさなびる,
english_grammar.attention: Notice that 古びた and ひなびた are generally only used to modify (describe) nouns.
english_grammar.about: びる, like めく, is a verb that is used exclusively as a suffix. It is a る-Verb, and may be translated as '(A) looking', '(A) seeming', or 'behaving like (A)'. びる is quite formal, and will follow a limited set of expressions. びる will appear after nouns, or occasionally the stem form of い-Adjectives. 実家(じっか)で屋根裏部屋(やねうらべや)を掃除(そうじ)していたら、古(ふる)びたアルバムが続々(つぎつぎ)と出(で)てきた。 While cleaning out the attic at my parents' house, I found a series of old-looking albums. 彼女(かのじょ)は幼(おさな)びて見(み)えるけど、実際(じっさい)は33歳(さい)らしい。 She is young-looking, but apparently she is 33 years old. 彼女(かのじょ)は大人(おとな)びて見(み)えるが、まだ社会(しゃかい)のことなんて分(わ)かってないただの学生(がくせい)だ。 She is adult-looking, but she is actually just a student that knows nothing about the real world. この町(まち)は田舎(いなか)びているから好(す)きだ。 I like this town because it is rural-like. びる indicates that, according to the speaker, something 'gives off the sense of (A)', and is based on visual information. As it is a descriptive verb, びる will change to びた when linked directly to a second noun. 私(わたし)はどんなに治安(ちあん)が良(よ)くても、田舎(いなか)びた町(まち)には住(す)みたくない。 No matter how safe it is, I don't want to live in a rural-looking town. なぜ子供(こども)は大人(おとな)びた格好(かっこう)をしたがるのだろうか。 I wonder why kids tend to want to dress adult-like. Fun-fact - Both びる and めく can be thought of as similar to さ, the structure that pairs with adjectives to create new nouns indicating an extent. This is due to the fact that when びる or めく attach to a word, they turn that word itself into a verb that expresses 'having the feeling of (A)', or 'having gained the feeling of (A)' when used in past tense.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)、序章(じょしょう)》旭丘(あさひがおか)は日(ひ)がのんびりとのどかに過(す)ぎていく、海岸沿(かいがんぞ)いのひなびた雰囲気(ふんいき)が漂(ただよ)う漁村(ぎょそん)だった。
example.english: A novel, prologue: Asahigaoka was a coastal fishing village with a rustic feel to it, where time passed peacefully.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》ヴァミリオは大人(おとな)びて見(み)えるが、純粋(じゅんすい)で、表情(ひょうじょう)がわかりやすい少女(しょうじょ)なのだ
example.english: A novel: Vamirio looked mature-like, but she was a pure girl with easy-to-read facial expressions.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》古(ふる)びた木橋(もくきょう)は足(あし)を踏(ふ)み出(だ)すたびに不穏(ふおん)な音(おと)がした。
example.english: A novel: The old-looking wooden bridge was making a disturbing noise with every step.

example.japanese: 一見(いっけん)するとひなびた小(ちい)さな街(まち)ではあるが夏(なつ)ともなると多(おお)くの観光(かんこう)客(きゃく)がこの街(まち)に来(く)る。
example.english: At first glance, it might be a small city with a rustic feel to it, but when the summer begins, numerous tourists come.

example.japanese: 「くみこは年(とし)の割(わり)に大人(おとな)びている。」
example.english: “Kumiko feels mature for her age.”

english_grammar.title: にしたところで
english_grammar.explanation: even, even for, even from the perspective of, even in the case of
english_grammar.structure: Noun + にしたところで(1) Less formal: Noun + にしたって(2) (1)としたところで (2)としたって
english_grammar.about: にしたところで or としたところで are two expressions that are used to indicate the hypothetical situation of (A), from within which the result of (B) will not change. These structures primarily express a lack of power over the ultimate result, or a lack of significant difference between (A) and any other potential choice. Translations include 'even in the case of (A), (B)', or 'even for (A), (B)'. These structures combine either of the case-marking particles と or に with the past tense of する, した, the noun ところ, used for marking the situation, and the case marking particle で. It will directly follow nouns or noun-modified phrases. 先輩(せんぱい)の青木(あおき)さんにしたところで、上達(じょうたつ)しなければいけない箇所(かしょ)はある。 Even our senpai Aoki-san has areas where he can improve. ノートパソコンにしたところで、Wi-Fiがないと仕事(しごと)ができない。 Even with a laptop, if there is no Wi-Fi I can't work. 1時間(じかん)寝坊(ねぼう)をしてしまったのでいくら急(いそ)いだとしたところで、間(あいだ)に合(あ)うわけがない。 Even if I hurry, I am not going to make it because I overslept an hour. ダイエットを始(はじ)めたとしたところで、私(わたし)は三日(みっか)坊主(ぼうず)だから続(つづ)かないだろう。 Even if I go on a diet, I have a short attention span so I don't think I will be able to continue. These patterns can be thought of more simply as a combination of にする 'going with (A)' or とする 'as (A)', and the たところで 'even if (A), not (B)' grammar structure that indicates negative outcomes. In casual situations, たところで will occasionally be replaced with たって. 私(わたし)にしたってそんなことはしたくないけど、上司(じょうし)に言(い)われたからにはするしかない。 Even if I don't want to do such a thing, my boss told me to, so I have no choice but to do it. 謝(あやま)ったとしたって、社長(しゃちょう)は彼(かれ)のことを許(ゆる)さないだろう。 Even if I apologized, he would probably not forgive him.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は非常(ひじょう)に深刻(しんこく)な状態(じょうたい)だ。天才(てんさい)医師(いし)のジャックにしたところで何(なに)もできない。
example.english: He is in very serious condition. Even the genius-doctor Jack cannot do anything.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》ホロは賢(かしこ)い神(かみ)だという。もっとも彼女(かのじょ)としたところで普通(ふつう)人間(にんげん)と同(おな)じように孤独(こどく)を感(かん)じる日(ひ)もあるが。
example.english: Novel: Holo is said to be a wise god. However, even for her, there are days when she feels lonely like an ordinary human.

example.japanese: 新(しん)首相(しゅしょう)は前(ぜん)首相(しゅしょう)を批判(ひはん)したが、彼(かれ)にしたって国(くに)の経済(けいざい)を好転(こうてん)させられるわけではない。
example.english: The new prime minister criticized the previous one, but it does not mean that even he can change the country's economy for the better.

example.japanese: 誰(だれ)にでも欠点(けってん)はある。完全(かんぜん)な田中(たなか)さんとしたって同(おな)じだ。
example.english: Everyone has faults. It is the case even for the perfect Tanaka.

example.japanese: 最高(さいこう)の監視員(かんしいん)にしたところでプールなどで全(すべ)ての者(もの)の安全(あんぜん)を見守(みまも)るのは不可能(ふかのう)だ。
example.english: Even for the best lifeguard, it is impossible to watch over everybody in the pool.

english_grammar.title: ばこそ
english_grammar.explanation: precisely because, only because, because, due to
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ば］+ こそ + Phrase ［い］Adjective［ば］+ こそ + Phrase ［な］Adjective + であれば + こそ + Phrase Noun + であれば + こそ + Phrase Phrase (A)。であればこそ + Phrase(B)
english_grammar.about: ばこそ will be used in a similar way to からこそ, indicating that (A) is the the precise reason for (B). It will be translated as 'precisely because of (A)', or 'it is only due to (A) that (B)'. This pattern is a combination of the conjunction particle ば, and the adverbial particle こそ, which is being used in a similar way to a sentence ending particle in this case. ばこそ may follow almost any word type that has been adjusted into its hypothetical form. However, it will appear as であればこそ when used after nouns or な-Adjectives. 娘(むすめ)の将来(しょうらい)を思(おも)えばこそ、塾(じゅく)に通(かよ)わせます。 Precisely because I am thinking about my daughter's future, I will make her attend cram school. 忙(いそが)しければこそ時間(じかん)を効率的(こうりつてき)に使(つか)うことができるようになる。 Precisely because you are busy, you will be able to use your time more efficiently. 健康(けんこう)であればこそ、年(とし)をとっても楽(たの)しい人生(じんせい)を過(す)ごせる。 You will be able to enjoy life even if you grow old, precisely because of good health. 小(ちい)さな会社(かいしゃ)であればこそ、優秀(ゆうしゅう)な人材(じんざい)が必要(ひつよう)だ。 Precisely because it is a small company, we need the best workers. In many cases, (A) will be a reason that is difficult to conceive of as what would lead to (B) under normal circumstances, and therefore requires the speaker to emphasize it with こそ. Caution - ばこそ is very formal, and a bit old-fashioned, so からこそ will almost always be the preferred choice in modern day Japanese.

example.japanese: 社長(しゃちょう)「皆(みな)さんがチームの一員(いちいん)として協力(きょうりょく)すればこそ成功(せいこう)できるのです。」
example.english: Company president: “Precisely because we work together as members of the team, we can succeed. ”

example.japanese: 両親(りょうしん)が子(こ)どもを叱(しか)るのは子(こ)どもの幸福(こうふく)を考(かんが)えればこそだ。
example.english: It is precisely because parents think of the well-being of their children that they scold them.

example.japanese: 悲(かな)しみがあればこそ、喜(よろこ)びもある。
example.english: Precisely because there is sadness, there is also happiness.

example.japanese: 日本語(にほんご)の勉強(べんきょう)は難(むずか)しければこそ、却(かえ)ってやりがいを感(かん)じるのです。
example.english: Precisely because studying Japanese is hard, it feels all the more rewarding.

example.japanese: 人間(にんげん)の寿命(じゅみょう)は限(かぎ)られている。であればこそ、人間(にんげん)はその命(いのち)をできるだけ楽(たの)しく快適(かいてき)で充実(じゅうじつ)して過(す)ごそうと思(おも)う。
example.english: Human lifespan is limited. Precisely because of that, I plan to make life as enjoyable, comfortable, and fulfilling as possible.

synonym.explanation: only if・because・by, unless, until
emphasized because, precisely because

english_grammar.title: ても差(さ)し支(つか)えない
english_grammar.explanation: may, is bit a bother if, do you mind if, is it a problem if
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ても］ + 差し支え + ありません(1)（か） Noun［でも］ + 差し支え + ありません(1)（か） ［な］Adjective［でも］ + 差し支え + ありません(1)（か） ［い］Adjective［ても］ + 差し支え + ありません(1)（か） (1) ないでしょう、ございません
english_grammar.attention: ても差し支えないです is also used but lacks politeness compared to other phrases, so it is less common and it is better to avoid it.
english_grammar.about: ても差(さ)し支(つか)えない is a polite expression used in a similar way to てもいい 'may I', or 'do you mind'. This is a combination of ても (or でも when following nouns or な-Adjectives), and the る-Verb 差(さ)し支(つか)える 'to interfere', or 'to hinder' in its negative form, 差(さ)し支(つか)えない. It may be used either for asking for or granting permission. Due to this pattern being polite, ありません will almost always be used in place of ない by itself. The more literal translation is 'it is not a hindrance if (A)'. In cases where permission is being asked for, か will be added to the end of ありません. ここに座(すわ)ってもらっても差(さ)し支(か)えありません。どうぞお座(すわ)りください。 I don't mind if you sat there. Please sit down. お風呂(ふろ)は熱(あつ)くても差(さ)し支(か)えません。むしろ熱(あつ)い方(ほう)がありがたいです。 I don't mind if the bath is hot. In fact, I like hotter baths. 私(わたし)はまだ初心者(しょしんしゃ)です。下手(へた)でも差(さ)し支(か)えありませんか。 I am still a beginner. Do you mind if I'm not very good at it? 今週(こんしゅう)はものすごく忙(いそが)しいので来週(らいしゅう)でも差(さ)し支(か)えありませんか。 I'm extremely busy this week, so would you mind if we do it next week? Caution Although ても差(さ)し支(つか)える is used in polite sentences, the verb 差(さ)し支(つか)える itself is not strictly reserved for use in polite language, and will appear in sentences when implying that (A) has or will have a negative impact on (B). 明日(あした)の大会(たいかい)に差(さ)し支(か)えるので、焼肉(やきにく)に行(い)くのは大会(たいかい)の後(あと)にしましょう。 Since it will interfere with tomorrow's tournament, let's go to the yakiniku after the tournament. タバコは健康(けんこう)に差(さ)し支(か)えるので、吸(す)わないようにしています。 I do not smoke cigarettes because it is hazardous to my health.

example.japanese: 《電車(でんしゃ)》「ここに座(すわ)っても差(さ)し支(つか)えありませんか？」
example.english: Train: “Would it bother you if I sit here?”

example.japanese: 《医者(いしゃ)に》「この薬(くすり)とその薬(くすり)を一緒(いっしょ)に飲(の)んでも差(さ)し支(つか)えないでしょうか？」
example.english: To a doctor: “May I take that medicine together with this one?”

example.japanese: 営業(えいぎょう)担当者(たんとうしゃ)「明日(あした)、お電話(でんわ)差(さ)し上(あ)げても差(さ)し支(つか)えございませんか？」クライエント「はい、問題(もんだい)ありません。」
example.english: Sales representative: “Would it bother you if I call you tomorrow?”Client: “No problem at all.”

example.japanese: 医者(いしゃ)「この飲(の)み薬(ぐすり)は風邪(かぜ)の症状(しょうじょう)が治(おさ)まりましたら、服用(ふくよう)を停止(ていし)しても差(さ)し支(つか)えありません。」
example.english: Doctor: “You may stop taking this medicine when your cold symptoms have subsided.”

example.japanese: 《目上(めうえ)の人(ひと)に》「書類(しょるい)は宅配(たくはい)サービスを利用(りよう)してお送(おく)りしても差(さ)し支(つか)えないでしょうか？」
example.english: To superior: “Would it bother you if I send the documents using the courier service?”

english_grammar.title: には及(およ)ばない ①
english_grammar.explanation: there is no need to, it is fine if you don’t, unnecessary
english_grammar.structure: Verb + には及ばない ［する］Verb + （する）+ には及ばない （お）+ 礼 + には及ばない （ご）+ 心配 + には及ばない それには及ばない
english_grammar.attention: Noun + には及ばない is used in the comparison, to express that the Noun is no match for something it is compared with
english_grammar.about: には及(およ)ばない is a polite expression in Japanese used in order to indicate that there is 'no need to (A)', or that '(A) is unnecessary. It is a combination of the case-marking marking particle に, the adverbial particle は, and the negated form of the う-Verb 及(およ)ぶ 'to reach', 及(およ)ばない. The literal translation is 'it does not extend to (A)'. This phrase will appear after nouns, or verbs in their dictionary form. こちらから前(まえ)いただいたアドレスに送(おく)るので、こんな遠(とお)くまで取(と)りに来(き)ていただくには及(およ)びません。 I am going to send it to the email address you gave us last time, so there is no need to come this far to pick it up. 私(わたし)たちの方(ほう)からそちらに書類(しょるい)を持(も)っていくので、こちらまでお越(こ)しいただくには及(およ)びません。 We will bring the documents to you, so there is no need to come here. 心配(しんぱい)には及(およ)びません。これぐらいの怪我(けが)なら全然(ぜんぜん)我慢(がまん)できます。 There is no need to worry. This level of injury is totally bearable. ここに書(か)いてあることは皆(みな)さんもう知(し)っていられると思(おも)うんで、説明(せつめい)には及(およ)びませんね。 I think everyone already knows the contents of this, so there is no need for me to explain. As this grammar pattern is used in polite speech, the word that it is attached to if often preceded by either お or ご, depending on what type of verb it is. Caution When not used as a polite expression, には及(およ)ばない may simply show the extent of something. This is usually when a comparison is being made between two things. This use will be translated as '(A) does not reach the extent of (B)', or '(A) cannot be compared to (B)'. あの有名(ゆうめい)ラーメン店(てん)には及(およ)ばないけど、ここのラーメンも結構(けっこう)美味(おい)しいと思(おも)う。 I think the ramen here is also quite good, though not as good as that famous ramen restaurant. お宅(たく)の息子(むすこ)さんには及(およ)ばないかもだけど、私(わたし)の息子(むすこ)も結構(けっこう)上達(じょうたつ)してきたと思(おも)う。 Maybe not as good as your son, but I think my son has also improved a lot.

example.japanese: 申請者(しんせいしゃ)「明日(あした)、書類(しょるい)を持(も)って行(い)っても差(さ)し支(つか)えありませんか？」公務員(こうむいん)「持(も)って来(き)ていただくには及(およ)びません。メールでも大丈夫(だいじょうぶ)です。」
example.english: Applicant: “Would it be a problem if I bring the documents tomorrow?”Public servant: “There is no need to bring them. It is ok if you send them via email.”

example.japanese: 普通(ふつう)の人(ひと)｢ありがとうございました。｣偉(えら)い人(ひと)｢いや、礼(れい)には及(およ)ばない。｣
example.english: Ordinary person: “Thank you very much.”Person in high position: “No need to thank me.”

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》バトラー「気(き)に入(い)ったなら、何(なに)か食(た)べるものでもお支度(したく)致(いた)しましょうか。」ゲスト「いいえ、それには及(およ)びません。」
example.english: A novel, butler: “If you would like I can make something to eat.”Guest: “No, there is no need for that.”

example.japanese: 社員(しゃいん)「部長(ぶちょう)、車(くるま)で本社(ほんしゃ)までお送(おく)りします。空港(くうこう)でお待(ま)ち下(くだ)さい。」部長(ぶちょう)「わざわざ車(くるま)で迎(むか)えに来(く)るには及(およ)びません。近(ちか)いので私(わたし)がそこへ歩(ある)いていきます。」
example.english: Company employee: “Director, I will drive you to the headquarters. Please, wait at the airport.”Head of the department: “No need to pick me up by car. It is close, so I will walk there myself.”

example.japanese: はいだ「れつこさんの顔色(かおいろ)が悪(わる)いね。」れつこ「ご心配(しんぱい)には及(およ)びません。ただちょっと活気(かっき)のないです。」
example.english: Haida: “Retsuko, you are pale.”Retsuko: “No need to worry. I am just a bit tired.”

english_grammar.title: に即(そく)して
english_grammar.explanation: inline with, based on, in accordance with
english_grammar.structure: Noun + に即し(1)（て） Noun + に即した(1) + Noun (1) に則した
english_grammar.about: に即(そく)して is a formal grammar structure which is used to express that something is being done for the purpose of handling a matter in the best possible way. It is a combination of に, and the する-verb 即(そく)する 'in corcordance with (A)', ' in line with (A)' in its て-form. Occasionally, に則(そく)して 'in following with' will be used instead. This structure will be used before nouns, or may be used when one noun is directly modifying another. In the case of the latter, に即(そく)した will be used instead of に即(そく)して. 会社(かいしゃ)のルールに即(そく)して、副業(ふくぎょう)をしてはいけない。 In line with the company's rules, you may not work a second job. あの監督(かんとく)はちゃんと事実(じじつ)に即(そく)して映画(えいが)を作(つく)るから、映画(えいが)を見(み)るだけでいろいろなことが学(まな)べる。 That director makes his films in accordance with the facts, so you can learn a lot just by watching his films. 法律(ほうりつ)に則(そく)した勤務(きんむ)時間(じかん)は週(しゅう)40時間(じかん)にも関(かか)わらず、あの会社(かいしゃ)は社員(しゃいん)に週(しゅう)70時間(じかん)働(はたら)かせている。 Work hours in line with the law is 40 hours a week, but that company makes its worker work 70 hours a week. 外国人(がいこくじん)であろうと、日本(にほん)にいる限(かぎ)り、日本(にほん)の法律(ほうりつ)に則(そく)した罰(ばつ)が与(あた)えられます。 No matter if you are a foreigner, as long as you are in Japan, you will be punished in line with Japanese law. Caution に即(そく)して is used when things are being done based on circumstances or situations, while に則(そく)して tends to be used when something is being done in accordance with laws, policies, or standards. There are situations where に則(そく)して will be incorrect, so に即(そく)して is often used in both cases in recent years. この計画(けいかく)は現実(げんじつ)に則(そく)していないません。 This plan does not follow with reality. (Unnatural Japanese)

example.japanese: 古(ふる)い慣習(かんしゅう)に縛(しば)られずに，時代(じだい)に即(そく)した法律(ほうりつ)を制定(せいてい)すべきである。
example.english: The law that is in line with the time should be established without being bound to old-fashioned customs.

example.japanese: 映画(えいが)は実情(じつじょう)に即(そく)して制作(せいさく)されたものだ。
example.english: The movie was made in line with actual circumstances.

example.japanese: McRonald社(しゃ)とSFC社(しゃ)との抗争(こうそう)は現地(げんち)の法律(ほうりつ)に則(そく)して処理(しょり)される。
example.english: The dispute between McRonald and SFC will be handled in line with local law.

example.japanese: 会社(かいしゃ)方針(ほうしん)に則(そく)した費用(ひよう)補償(ほしょう)は30日(にち)以内(いない)にお支払(しはら)いいたします。
example.english: We will pay cost compensation that is in line with company policy within 30 days.

example.japanese: 請願書(せいがんしょ)は方針(ほうしん)に則(そく)して担当(たんとう)大臣(だいじん)に提出(ていしゅつ)しなければならない。
example.english: The petition must be submitted to the minister in charge, in line with the policy.

english_grammar.title: ないまでも
english_grammar.explanation: may not … but (at least), even though not, even if not
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］+ までも + Phrase Noun + ではない(1) + までも + Phrase (1) じゃない
english_grammar.about: ないまでも is a combination of the negated form of a verb, the case-marking particle まで 'until', and the adverbial particle も 'even'. It will often be translated as 'even though not (A), (B)', or 'it may not be (A), but (B)'. This structure usually presents some form of extreme (A) which has not yet been reached, but the lower extent of (B) cannot be denied. The literal translation is 'even though not reaching (A), (B)'. この作品(さくひん)は名作(めいさく)だとは言(い)えないまでも、なかなかいい作品(さくひん)だと思(おも)う。 This may not be a masterpiece, but I think that it is a pretty good piece. 犯罪(はんざい)などは完全(かんぜん)になくせないまでも、減(へ)らすように頑張(がんば)るべきだ。 Even though it may not be possible to eliminate crime, we should try our best to reduce it. プロ野球(やきゅう)選手(せんしゅ)にはなれないまでも、プロ野球(やきゅう)に関(かか)わる仕事(しごと)をしているので満足(まんぞく)している。 Even though I can't become a professional baseball player, I am satisfied because my job is related to professional baseball. Depending on the source, this structure may occasionally be used with nouns. In this case, it will need to follow ではない, or the casual じゃない. 毎週(まいしゅう)ではないまでも、娘(むすめ)に会(あ)えるだけ幸(しあわ)せだ。 I'm just happy to see my daughter, even if it's not every week. 好(す)きな仕事(しごと)ができないから幸(しあわ)せじゃないまでも、生活費(せいかつひ)に困(こま)っていないから文句(もんく)は言(い)えない。 Even though I can't do what I love for work, I can't complain because I am not struggling with my bills. This grammar pattern will be used in both positive and negative situations. For example, (A) may be the best outcome, where (B) is something just below that which is desirable, or (A) may be the worst outcome, where (B) is just below that, but still quite bad. Often, the (B) phrase will express some kind of wish or demand that the speaker wants to meet with structures like たい, てほしい, てください, たらどう, つもり, といい, etc.

example.japanese: 《ファンタジー小説(しょうせつ)》「勇者(ゆうしゃ)えみりあを仲間(なかま)にしないまでも、一(いち)度(ど)は会(あ)ってみたらどうですか？」
example.english: Fantasy novel: “You may not make hero Emilia into an ally, but what about meeting her at least once?”

example.japanese: これは不可能(ふかのう)ではないまでも、実行(じっこう)するのは困難(こんなん)である。
example.english: This may not be impossible, but carrying it out is hard.

example.japanese: 急速(きゅうそく)充電(じゅうでん)はバッテリーを直(ただ)ちに駄目(だめ)にしないまでも、性能(せいのう)をより速(はや)く低下(ていか)させる。
example.english: Fast charging may not immediately damage the battery, but it will decrease its performance faster.

example.japanese: リザ「大谷(おおや)は一番(いちばん)ハンサムといわないまでも、かなりカッコいい男(おとこ)だと思(おも)うよ。」
example.english: Riza “I won’t say that Ooya is the most handsome, but I think he is quite a cool guy.”

example.japanese: 初(はじ)めてJLPTN1を受験(じゅけん)したが、合格(ごうかく)できないまでも、せめて８０点(てん)は得点(とくてん)できたい。
example.english: I took the JLPT N1 exam for the first time, I may not pass, but at least I want to get 80 points.

english_grammar.title: を余所(よそ)に
english_grammar.explanation: ignoring, disregarding, despite
english_grammar.structure: Noun + をよそに Phrase + の + をよそに
english_grammar.about: を余所(よそ)に is used to express that (A) is something that effectively has nothing to do with the speaker, or that the speaker is ignoring it in relation to something else. It may be translated as 'ignoring (A)', or 'disregarding (A)'. It is a combination of the adverbial particle を, the noun 余所(よそ) 'other place', and the case-marking particle に. Due to this, its literal meaning is close to 'putting (A) completely aside, (B)'. This structure will follow nouns, or phrases that have been nominalized with の. It is reasonably formal, so will be seen more often in writing. 彼(かれ)は親(おや)の心配(しんぱい)をよそに、毎晩(まいばん)夜(よる)遅(おそ)くまで友達(ともだち)たちと遊(あそ)んでいる。 Ignoring his parent's worries, he hangs out with his friends every night until late at night. 社長(しゃちょう)は社員(しゃいん)の反対(はんたい)をよそに、仕事(しごと)の効率(こうりつ)を上(あ)げるために休憩所(きゅうけいじょ)を撤去(てっきょ)した。 Ignoring objections from his workers, the president got rid of the break room inorder to increase efficiency. 彼(かれ)は周囲(しゅうい)の視線(しせん)をよそに、コンビニの店員(てんいん)に暴言(ぼうげん)を吐(は)き続(つづ)けていた。 Ignoring the eyes of those around him, he continued to lash out on the convenience store worker. The most common pattern for をよそに to follow is that (A) expresses some overall situation, while (B) indicates an action that is being done without any thought or care given toward those circumstances. Because of this, it is often used critically about actions that are seen as irresponsible. Caution - While this grammar point will primarily highlight the actions of people, it will not be used to refer to the speaker's own actions. 私(わたし)は両親(りょうしん)の反対(はんのう)をよそに、彼(かれ)と結婚(けっこん)することにした。 Ignoring my parents' objections, I decided to marry him. (Unnatural Japanese)

example.japanese: 母(はは)の心配(しんぱい)をよそに、彼(かれ)は商船(しょうせん)の船員(せんいん)になった。
example.english: Ignoring his mother's worries, he has become a merchant seaman.

example.japanese: メアリーと武(たけし)は親(おや)の反対(はんたい)をよそに一緒(いっしょ)になった。
example.english: Ignoring objections from their parents, Mary and Takeshi got together.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)たちがその衝撃的(しょうげきてき)な言葉(ことば)の意味(いみ)をまだ飲(の)み込(こ)めてないのをよそに彼女(かのじょ)は説明(せつめい)を続(つづ)けた。
example.english: Ignoring that we still haven’t digested the meaning of her shocking remark, she continued the explanation.

example.japanese: ピーターは周(まわ)りの忠告(ちゅうこく)をよそに、MMORPGゲームばかりすることを存分(ぞんぶん)に楽(たの)しんだ。
example.english: Ignoring the advice of those close to him, Peter does nothing but play MMORPG games to his heart's content

example.japanese: 地域(ちいき)住民(じゅうみん)の反対(はんたい)の声(こえ)をよそに、自治体(じちたい)が空港(くうこう)建設(けんせつ)の計画(けいかく)を進(すす)めている。
example.english: Ignoring the voices of opposition, the local government carries forward the plan of airport construction.

english_grammar.title: に限ったことではない
english_grammar.explanation: not limited to, not restricted to, not only
english_grammar.structure: Noun + に限ったことではない
english_grammar.about: に限(かぎ)ったことではない is a fairly emphatic expression that, like several other grammar patterns, makes use of the う-Verb 限(かぎ)る 'to limit'. It is a combination of the case-marking particle に, the past tense of 限(かぎ)る, 限(かぎ)った, the noun こと 'thing', the conjunctive form of the auxiliary verb だ, で, the adverbial particle は, and the い-Adjective, ない. The literal translation is 'it is not something that is limited to (A)', but other common interpretations include 'not only (A), but (B)', or 'not restricted to (A), (B) too'. This structure will be used following nouns, and tends to be reserved for fairly formal situations. 最近(さいきん)の若者(わかもの)は挨拶(あいさつ)ができないと言(い)われているが、若者(わかもの)に限(かぎ)ったことではない。 It is said that young people these days can't greet people, but it is not limited to young people. 今日(きょう)に限(かぎ)ったことではないが、なんか仕事(しごと)する気(き)にならない。 It is not limited to today, but for some reason I don't feel like working. 文法(ぶんぽう)が難(むずか)しいのは日本語(にほんご)に限(かぎ)ったことではない。 Grammar being difficult is not something that is limited to Japanese. This grammar pattern often indicates that (A) is something that is not especially rare, so should not be, or does not require to be treated in any special way.

example.japanese: うつ病(びょう)は人間(にんげん)に限(かぎ)ったことではない。動物(どうぶつ)でもうつ病(びょう)と診断(しんだん)されることがある。
example.english: Depression is not limited to humans. Even animals can be diagnosed with depression.

example.japanese: 敬語(けいご)は何(なに)も日本語(にほんご)に限(かぎ)ったことではない。他(た)言語(げんご)にもあるか、または過去(かこ)にあった。
example.english: Honorifics are not restricted to Japanese at all. Other languages also have it, or had it in the past.

example.japanese: 松岡(まつおか)さんが宿題(しゅくだい)を忘(わす)れるのは今日(きょう)に限(かぎ)ったことではない。
example.english: Mr. Matsuoka forgetting to do his homework was not limited only to today.

example.japanese: オレオレ詐欺(さぎ)で騙(だま)されるのはお年寄(としよ)りに限(かぎ)ったことではない。大人(おとな)も騙(だま)される。
example.english: It is not only the elderly who are deceived by the ‘ore ore’ scam. Adults are too.

example.japanese: 科学(かがく)者(しゃ)によると、少子(しょうし)化(か)はなにも日本(にっぽん)に限(かぎ)ったことではないとのこと。すべての先進(せんしん)国(こく)における問題(もんだい)だそうだ。
example.english: According to scientists, the declining birthrate is not limited to Japan at all. It seems that it is a problem in all developed countries.

english_grammar.title: とは比(くら)べものにはならない
english_grammar.explanation: nothing compared to, cannot be compared to, much more, way better, above comparison (beyond comparison), far greater than
english_grammar.structure: Noun + とは比べものにはならない
english_grammar.about: In order to emphasize that something is far beyond what could possibly be compared to (A), the emphatic phrase とは比(くら)べものにはならない will be used. This is a combination of the case-marking particle と, the adverbial particle は, the neologism 比(くら)べもの 'a comparable thing', case-marking particle に, adverbial particle は, and the negated form of the う-Verb なる 'to become', ならない. This may seem like a lot, but it is just expressing that '(A) will not be a comparable thing'. This structure will be used before nouns, where that noun is the thing that cannot be compared. This is usually due to quality, quantity, or some other feature that is easily measurable. A社(しゃ)の作(つく)る部品(ぶひん)はいいが、B社(しゃ)の作(つく)る部品(ぶひん)とは比(くら)べ物(もの)にならない。 Parts made by Company A are good, but they are not comparable to the parts made by Company B. お母(かあ)さんのスパゲティーとは比(くら)べものにはならないが、ここのシェフが作(つく)るやつはなかなか美味(おい)しい。 The spaghetti prepared by the chef here is quite good, but it is nothing compared to the spaghetti my mother makes. 岐阜(ぎふ)は寒(さむ)いが、北海道(ほっかいどう)とは比(くら)べものにはならない。 Gifu is cold, but it is nothing compared to Hokkaido. As this grammar pattern is emphatic, it will indicate that the difference between (A) Fun FactAs a reminder, a neologism is just a set word or phrase which has come to be used a certain way due to habits or customs. 比(くら)べもの itself is just a mix of the conjunctive form of the る-Verb 比(くら)べる 'to compare', and the noun もの 'thing'.

example.japanese: 光(ひかり)の速(はや)さでも、この宇宙(うちゅう)の大(おお)きさとは比(くら)べものにはならない。
example.english: Even the speed of light is nothing when compared to the size of the universe.

example.japanese: この寿司(すし)は悪(わる)くはないが良質(りょうしつ)の寿司(すし)とは比(くら)べものにはならない。
example.english: This sushi is not bad, but it is nothing compared to good quality sushi.

example.japanese: スーパー火山(かざん)の噴火(ふんか)の被害(ひがい)は他(た)の火山(かざん)とは比(くら)べものにはならないとされます。
example.english: It is considered that the damage from a supervolcano eruption is beyond comparison to other volcanoes.

example.japanese: スマホのパフォーマンスは当時(とうじ)とは比(くら)べものにはならないほど上(あ)がってます。
example.english: The performance of smartphones has improved to a degree that is beyond comparison to back then.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の絵画(かいが)など須(す)ノ宮(みや)さんのとは比(くら)べものにはならない。
example.english: My paintings are nothing compared to Sunomiya's.

english_grammar.title: まじき
english_grammar.explanation: unbecoming of, unworthy of, not proper for, should not, must not, cannot
english_grammar.structure: Noun (A) + にある(1) + まじき + Noun (B) 許すまじき + Noun (1)としてある
english_grammar.about: まじき is the attributive form of まじ, a classical auxiliary verb that has been replaced almost entirely by まい 'must not', 'should not' in modern Japanese. まじ itself has this same meaning of 'must not', and will only be seen in a very limited number of formal expressions. Although slightly different in nuance, まじき is often translated simply as 'not proper for (A)', or 'unbecoming of (A)' in each case. The most common pattern that まじき will be seen in is (A) にあるまじき (B), where the case-marking particle に follows a noun, then is linked to the う-Verb ある, before まじき will connect to a second noun. 生徒(せいと)に手(て)を挙(あ)げることは先生(せんせい)にあるまじき行為(こうい)だ。 Raising your hand to a student is unbecoming of a teacher. 彼(かれ)は飲酒(いんしゅ)運転(うんてん)という警察官(けいさつかん)にあるまじき行動(こうどう)をし、クビになった。 He was fired for drunk driving, an unbecoming behavior for a police officer. Occasionally, に will be replaced by として 'as', with the rest of the structure remaining the same. 先日(せんじつ)、斉藤(さいとう)首相(しゅしょう)は総理(そうり)としてあるまじき発言(はつげん)をし、SNSで炎上(えんじょう)している。 Recently, Prime Minister Saito has been under fire on social media for making comments that are unbecoming of a prime minister. 彼(かれ)は医師(いし)としてあるまじきミスをしてしまい、医師(いし)免許(めんきょ)を剥奪(はくだつ)された。 He made a mistake that was unbecoming of a physician and was stripped of his medical license. 許(ゆる)すまじき 'must not be forgiven', or simply 'unforgivable' is another pattern that may be seen. 煽(あお)り運転(うんてん)のような許(ゆる)すまじき行為(こうい)をした場合(ばあい)、免許(めんきょ)は取(と)り消(け)しになります。 If you commit unforgivable acts such as tailgating, your license will be revoked.

example.japanese: ララティーナは貴族(きぞく)にあるまじき態度(たいど)で、甘(あま)やかされた子供(こども)のようにふるまいをした。
example.english: Lalatina behaved in a manner unbecoming of a noble, like a spoiled child.

example.japanese: 戦場(せんじょう)から離脱(りだつ)することは武士(ぶし)にあるまじき行為(こうい)と咎(とが)められ、罰(ばっ)せられた。
example.english: Fleeing from the battlefield was condemned as unbecoming of a warrior and punished.

example.japanese: 言(い)うまでもないが、公金(こうきん)横領(おうりょう)など政治家(せいじか)としてあるまじき行為(こうい)だ。
example.english: It goes without saying, but something like misappropriation of public funds is an act unbecoming of a statesman.

example.japanese: リヒャルトは王(おう)としてあるまじき汚名(おめい)を着(き)せられ、やがて廃位(はいい)された。
example.english: Richard was tarred with the stigma unbecoming of the position of the king and was eventually dethroned.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》深(ふか)く考(かんが)えず勝手(かって)に好(す)きなことをいうのは普通(ふつう)の人(ひと)にとっては許(ゆる)せるかもしれないが、外交官(がいこうかん)にとっては許(ゆる)すまじき悪行(あくぎょう)だったのだ。
example.english: Novel: Saying whatever one wants, without thinking deeply might be allowed for an ordinary person, but for a diplomat, it is a misdeed that cannot be forgiven.

english_grammar.title: の至(いた)り
english_grammar.explanation: utmost, height of, extreme, heartiest, such a, very, really, completely, deeply
english_grammar.structure: Noun + の + 至り + だ
english_grammar.about: の至(いた)り is a set, formal expression used to highlight that (A) is the highest level of something, and will often be used positively, although not exclusively. It is a combination of the case-marking particle の, and the noun 至(いた)り 'pinnacle', or 'climax'. Common translations include 'the utmost (A)', or 'the extreme of (A). To use this structure, attach it to the end of a noun, where that noun is the 'limit' for whatever is being expressed. ここ4年間(ねんかん)色々(いろいろ)と教(おし)えていただき、恐縮(きょうしゅく)の至(いた)りです。 I am extremely grateful for the many things you have taught me over the last four years. このような大切(たいせつ)な式(しき)に、こんな私(わたし)を招待(しょうたい)してくださったことは光栄(こうえい)の至(いた)りです。 I am extremely honored that you invited me to such an important ceremony. 色々(いろいろ)とアドバイスをしていただいて、感謝(かんしゃ)の至(いた)りです。 I am extremely grateful for all the advice you have given me. (A) is usually some emotion that can be experienced to a high degree when confronted with certain situations such as 光栄(こうえい) 'honor', 赤面(せきめん) 'embarrassment', 感謝(かんしゃ) 'gratefulness', 恐縮(きょうしゅく) 'obligation', etc. Fun-fact - 若気(わかげ)の至(いた)り is a set expression that is used to indicate some blunder made on a count of being young and not thinking things through thoroughly. 若気(わかげ) is a noun that roughly translates as 'youthful impetuousness'. 大学生(だいがくせい)の頃(ころ)は若気(わかげ)の至(いた)りでたくさん悪(わる)いことをしてしまった。 I did a lot of bad things when I was in college, due to an extreme moment of youthful indiscretion.

example.japanese: 《演説(えんぜつ)》「特別賞(とくべつしょう)を受賞(じゅしょう)することになり、光栄(こうえい)の至(いた)りです。」
example.english: Speech: “Receiving the special reward is an extreme honor.”

example.japanese: 「このような小(ちい)さな誤(あやま)りに気(き)づくのに数(すう)日(にち)もかかるとは、赤面(せきめん)の至(いた)りです。」
example.english: “I am extremely ashamed that it took a few days to notice such a simple mistake.”

example.japanese: 《演説(えんぜつ)》「たいそうな品(しな)をいただき、恐縮(きょうしゅく)の至(いた)りです。」
example.english: Speech: “We are extremely grateful for your generous gift.”

example.japanese: 《インタビュー》「ファンや映画(えいが)評論家(ひょうろんか)の皆(みな)さまから肯定的(こうていてき)なレビューをいただき、感激(かんげき)の至(いた)りです」
example.english: Interview: “We are extremely moved by the positive reviews we have received from fans and film critics.”

example.japanese: 《伝記(でんき)》若気(わかげ)の至(いた)りで、給料(きゅうりょう)の良(よ)い仕事(しごと)を辞(や)めて独立(どくりつ)開業(かいぎょう)した。
example.english: Biography: Due to an extreme moment of youthful indiscretion, I had quit a well-paid job and started an independent business.

english_grammar.title: に恥(は)じない
english_grammar.explanation: lives up to, truly to …’s name, worthy of, not dishonor, not putting to shame, measure to
english_grammar.structure: Noun + に恥じない Noun + に恥じない + Noun
english_grammar.about: When showing that something lives up to an expected standard or level of quality, the phrase に恥(は)じない will be used. This is a combination of the case-marking particle に, and the negated form of the る-Verb 恥(は)じる 'to shame'. The literal translation is 'without shaming (A)'. This structure will follow nouns. あの大学(だいがく)のバスケチームは日本一(にほんいち)という名(な)に恥(は)じない強(つよ)さだ。 That university's basketball team's strength lives up to its name of being the best in Japan. 日本(にほん)代表(だいひょう)の名(な)に恥(は)じないよう、ベストを尽(つ)くします。 I will do my best to live up to the name of a representative of Japan. 会社(かいしゃ)の名(な)に恥(は)じないよう、精一杯(せいいっぱい)頑張(がんば)ります。 I will do my best to live up to the name of the company. In many cases, (A) will be a word indicating an aspect of something that has come to be well known. Examples of this are 名(な) name, 名誉(めいよ) 'reputation', etc. As に恥(は)じない has the nuance of 'not shaming (A)', or 'not damaging the reputation of (A)', it will usually only be used in positive contexts, where someone or something is being praised.

example.japanese: サハラ砂漠(さばく)の名(な)に恥(は)じない天候(てんこう)だ。
example.english: It is a weather that lives up to the name of the Sahara desert.

example.japanese: 《店(みせ)のウェブサイト》当店(とうてん)は80年(ねん)培(つちか)った信頼(しんらい)と伝統(でんとう)に恥(は)じないサービスをご提供致(ていきょういた)します。
example.english: Shop’s website: “Our shop provides services that live up to the trust we have built over 80 years and the tradition.”

example.japanese: 《昇格(しょうかく)する演説(えんぜつ)》ブランド名(めい)に恥(は)じないよう、精一杯(せいいっぱい)努(つと)めさせていただきます。
example.english: Being promoted speech: “I will work as hard as I can to live up to the brand’s name.”

example.japanese: 《ホテルのウェブサイト》「5つ星(ぼし)ホテルの名(な)に恥(は)じないサービスをお客様(きゃくさま)に提供(ていきょう)しております。」
example.english: Hotel’s website: “We provide a service for our guests that lives up to the name of a five star hotel.”

example.japanese: 《受賞(じゅしょう)の演説(えんぜつ)》「この賞(しょう)に恥(は)じないよう、これからも最善(さいぜん)を尽(つ)くすつもりです。」
example.english: Receiving award speech: “I intend to continue doing my best to live up to this award.”

english_grammar.title: ずじまい
english_grammar.explanation: ended up not, did not (in the end), never did
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ない］+ ず + じまい
english_grammar.attention: originates from the voiced verb[stem] form of しまう. Very often used in past form.
english_grammar.about: ずじまい is a grammar structure that combines the literary form of the classical auxiliary verb ぬ, ず 'not', and the voiced conjunctive form of the う-Verb しまう 'to finish', or 'to bring to a close', じまい. Like しまう, ずじまい will often indicate regret at something ending up a certain way. However, this regret is about '(A) not happening', due to the negation provided by ず. This structure will be used following the indeterminate form of verbs. Common translations include 'to end up not (A)', and 'to not have done (A) in the end'. マウンテンバイクを買(か)ったが、使(つか)わずじまいで売(う)ってしまった。 I bought a mountain bike, but I ended up selling it without using it. コンサートのチケットを買(か)ったが、色々(いろいろ)とやることがあって行(い)かずじまいだった。 I bought the ticket to the concert, but I had a lot on my plate so I ended up not going. 日本(にほん)で使(つか)うために電子(でんし)辞書(じしょ)を持(も)っていったが、持(も)ち運(はこ)ぶのが面倒(めんどう)だったから結局(けっきょく)使(つか)わずじまいだった。 I brought my electronic dictionary to Japan to use it there, but I ended up not using it because it was a pain to carry it. ずじまい will often be followed by だった or でした, indicating that (A) was not something that turned out happening, despite the wishes or intentions of the doer. Caution As is always the case with ず, する will be altered to せず. 好(す)きな子(こ)に告白(こくはく)せずじまいで、高校(こうこう)を卒業(そつぎょう)してしまった。 I ended up graduating highschool without confessing my feelings to the girl I liked.

example.japanese: A「結局(けっきょく)、やらずじまいで新(しん)学期(がっき)になっちゃったよ。」B「なにをやらなかったの？」A「夏休(なつやす)みの宿題(しゅくだい)…」
example.english: A: “I ended up not doing it, and the new school term started.”B: “What did you not do?”A: “The summer homework...”

example.japanese: 「宇崎(うざき)さんと映画館(えいがかん)に行(い)こうと思(おも)っていたけど、仕事(しごと)から手(て)が離(はな)せなくて結局(けっきょく)行(い)けずじまいだった。」
example.english: "I planned to go to the cinema with Uzaki, but I couldn’t get away from work, so I ended up not going."

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》事故(じこ)の原因(げんいん)について調(しら)べようとしたが、ついにわからずじまいだった。
example.english: Novel: I tried to investigate the cause of the accident, but I ended up not discovering anything.

example.japanese: 「最新(さいしん)の愛(あい)Phoneを買(か)おうとストアに１０時間(じかん)並(なら)んだのに、自分(じぶん)の番(ばん)が来(く)る頃(ころ)には欲(ほ)しい色(いろ)がもう売(う)り切(き)れていて結局(けっきょく)買(か)えずじまいだった。」
example.english: "I stood for 10 hours in line to buy the new 愛Phone, but when my turn came, it turned out that the color I wanted had already sold out, so I ended up not buying it."

example.japanese: 「日本語(にほんご)の教科書(きょうかしょ)をたくさん買(か)ったけど、結局(けっきょく)使(つか)わずじまいだった。」
example.english: "I bought lots of Japanese textbooks, but I ended up not using them."

english_grammar.title: に言(い)わせると
english_grammar.explanation: if you ask, in … opinion, according to
english_grammar.structure: Noun + に言わせれば(1) (1) に言わせると、に言わせたら
english_grammar.attention: に言わせたら is less common than に言わせれば and に言わせると.から is sometimes used instead of に (から言わせれば).
english_grammar.about: に言(い)わせれば is a structure that will be attached to nouns, in order to indicate a person or group that is giving a strong opinion. It is usually translated as 'if you ask (A), (B)', or 'according to (A), (B)'. The literal meaning is 'if (A) is allowed to speak, (B)', as this pattern is just a combination of the case-marking particle に, the う-Verb 言(い)う 'to say' followed by the hypothetical form of the auxiliary verb せる, せれ 'to allow to do', and the conjunction particle ば. To use this structure, simply attach it to the end of a noun marking the person or group whose opinion is being given. 私(わたし)に言(い)わせれば５キロを25分(ふん)で走(はし)るのは簡単(かんたん)だ。 If you ask me, running 5km in 25 minutes is easy. 私(わたし)はあのパーソナルトレーナーは厳(きび)しすぎると思(おも)ったが、彼(かれ)に言(い)わせれば優しすぎるらしい。 I thought that that personal trainer was too strict, but according to him, he is apparently too nice. 専門家(せんもんか)に言(い)わせれば、もっと早(はや)い対応(たいおう)をするべきだったそうです。 According to a specialist, we should have dealt with it earlier. Other hypothetical structures such as と and たら may also be used, but ば is the most common. Additionally, this pattern may sound self-important, so is best used sparingly, especially when giving your own opinions. Occasionally, から will be used instead of に. 私(わたし)から言(い)わせれば、なんでそんなことして許(ゆる)されると思(おも)ったのかがわからない。 In my opinion, I don't know why they thought they would be forgiven after doing such a thing. Caution With the auxiliary verbs せる and させる, it will be important to remember that に tends to be mark the doer when they are being allowed to do something, as in this case, while を will be used more frequently when the doer is being made to do something.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)に言(い)わせればあなたが買(か)ったスマホは不(ふ)良品(りょうひん)だよ。もう３回(かい)も壊(こわ)れたんだから！
example.english: If you ask me, the smartphone you bought is a defective product. It has fallen apart 3 times already!

example.japanese: ドイツ側(がわ)に言(い)わせればオーストラリア企業(きぎょう)は初(はじ)めは経済(けいざい)協力(きょうりょく)に反対(はんたい)していたという。
example.english: According to the German side, the Australian companies were opposed to cooperation from the beginning.

example.japanese: 会社(かいしゃ)の観点(かんてん)からすれば、結果(けっか)は失敗(しっぱい)とみなされるかもしれないが、少(すく)なくとも私(わたし)に言(い)わせれば、完全(かんぜん)な失敗(しっぱい)というわけではない。
example.english: From the company’s point of view, the results might be considered a failure, but it does not mean it was a complete failure, at least if you ask me.

example.japanese: 君(きみ)にとっては面白(おもしろ)いのだろうが、私(わたし)に言(い)わせれば、ただの無礼(ぶれい)にしかすぎない。
example.english: For you it might be funny, but if you ask me, it is just rude.

example.japanese: 武田(たけだ)さんに言(い)わせれば、最近(さいきん)の若者(わかもの)はまったくお年寄(としよ)りを敬(うやま)わないとのこと。
example.english: According to Mr. Takeda, youth these days do not respect their elders at all.

english_grammar.title: ったら
english_grammar.explanation: cannot tell/describe/say/express/find words for how, words cannot express, too … for words, extremely
english_grammar.structure: More common patterns: Noun + たら(1) + ありゃしない(2) ［い］Adjective［さ］(3) + たら(1) + ありゃしない(2) Less common patterns: Verb + たら(1) + ありゃしない(2) ［な］Adjective + たら(1) + ありゃしない(2) (1) といたら (2) ありはしない (3)［い］Adjective
english_grammar.attention: と言ったらありはない is a written, rarely used variant
english_grammar.about: といったらない is a set expression used to highlight a very high extent of something (like being disappointed, astonished and so on), to the point of not being able to describe it with mere words. Unlike ったらない it is only used in a negative context, and often follows words like 図々しい、ばかばかしい、恥ずかしい、みっともない、情けない and the like.

example.japanese: 「凹凸(おうとつ)の多(おお)い地形(ちけい)は走(はし)りにくいと言(い)ったらありはしない。」
example.english: “I cannot tell you how difficult it is to run on uneven terrain.”

example.japanese: 「犬(いぬ)を飼(か)ったのに世話(せわ)をしないなんて、無責任(むせきにん)ったらありゃしない。」
example.english: “I cannot tell you how irresponsible it is to keep a dog but not take care of it.”

example.japanese: 《上司(じょうし)》「君(きみ)は毎日(まいにち)毎日(まいにち)、会社(かいしゃ)に遅刻(ちこくき)して来(き)て。見苦(みぐる)しいったらありゃしないぞ。」
example.english: Boss: “You are late for work every single day. I can’t tell you how unseemly it is!”

example.japanese: 「さだおさんの企業(きぎょう)が倒産(とうさん)してからの元従業員(もとじゅうぎょういん)の連中(れんちゅう)の態度(たいど)と言(い)ったらありゃしない。」
example.english: “I cannot express the attitude of Sadao’s former employees after his company went bankrupt.”

example.japanese: 「昨晩(さくばん)遅(おそ)くに帰宅(きたく)したルームメイトに起(お)こされた。腹(はら)がたつったらありゃしない。」
example.english: “I was awoken by my roommate who returned home late last night. I can’t tell you how angry I am.”

english_grammar.title: こととて
english_grammar.explanation: due to, since, on account of, because
english_grammar.structure: Verb + こととて Verb［ない］+ ぬ(1) + こととて Noun + の + こととて (1) ない
english_grammar.attention: こととて in some contexts can also mean “even”
english_grammar.about: こととて is a combination of the noun こと 'thing', and the binding (adverbial) particle とて, which is used for presenting reasons. It will be translated as 'due to (A)', or 'because of (A)'. This is a fairly old-fashioned expression, and will almost exclusively be used in writing in modern Japanese. To use こととて, attach it to the end of a verb, or a noun followed by the case-marking particle の. あの事件(じけん)は20年(ねん)前(まえ)に起(お)こったこととて、世間(せけん)からは忘(わす)れられているだろう。 Due to that incident happening 20 years ago, it probably has been forgotten by the public. 商品(しょうひん)についてあまり知(し)らぬこととて、お客(きゃく)様(さま)の信頼(しんらい)を失(うしな)ってしまった。 Due to me lacking knowledge about the product, I unfortunately lost credibility. 新人(しんじん)のこととて、まだ分(わ)からないことがたくさんありますが、これからよろしくお願(ねが)いいたします。 Since I am still new, there are many things I don't know, but please take good care of me. 突然(とつぜん)のこととて、前(まえ)の車(くるま)を避(さ)けきれませんでした。 Due to it being a sudden event, I was not able to avoid the car in front of me. こととて will primarily be used when asking for forgiveness for something. Due to this, when appearing after verbs, the verb will usually be in past tense, or have been negated with either ない or ぬ. This highlights something that was done and shouldn't have been, or wasn't done and should have been. In many cases, (A) will be something for which the negative result of (B) is obvious, or to be expected. Fun Factとて is thought to either be a combination of the case-marking particle と and the conjunction particle て, or the conjunctive form of the classical auxiliary verb たり, と, and the conjunction particle て. As the origin is unclear, it will be best to think of it as its own structure, that carries its own original meaning.

example.japanese: 《時代(じだい)劇(げき)》A「あなたのお父(とう)さんによろしくお伝(つた)えください。」B「お父(とう)さんは遥(はる)か昔(むかし)に亡(な)くなりました。」A「そうでしたか。知(し)らぬこととて、失礼(しつれい)をお許(ゆる)しください。」
example.english: A period drama, A: “Please, send my greetings to your father.”B: “My father passed away long ago.”A: “Is that so? Please, forgive my rudeness due to my lack of knowledge.”

example.japanese: 《古(ふる)い手紙(てがみ)》取(と)り込(こ)み中(ちゅう)のこととてご迷惑(めいわく)をおかけしましたがなにとぞご寛容(かんよう)のほどお願(ねが)い申(もう)し上(あ)げます。
example.english: Old letter: “I have caused you a lot of trouble due to being busy, but I would kindly ask for your understanding.”

example.japanese: 「仕事(しごと)になれぬこととて間違(まちが)いをしてしまいました。申(もう)し訳(わけ)ございません。」
example.english: “I made a mistake due to not being accustomed to the work. For that I am awfully sorry.”

example.japanese: 「田舎(いなか)のこととて年齢(ねんれい)や学年(がくねん)に関係(かんけい)なく生徒(せいと)が勉強(べんきょう)する教室(きょうしつ)が1教室(きょうしつ)だけしかなかった。」
example.english: Since it was the countryside, there was only one classroom where school children studied, regardless of their age or grade.

example.japanese: 「子供(こども)がやったこととて、親(おや)としてお詫(わ)び申(もう)し上(あ)げます。」
example.english: “Since my child did it, I would like to apologize as their parent.”

english_grammar.title: ずくめ
english_grammar.explanation: Completely, Entirely, All in, Nothing but, A real streak of, Without exception, Jet
english_grammar.structure: Noun + ずくめ Noun (A) + ずくめ + の + Noun (B)
english_grammar.attention: づくめ is an older, pre-reform variant. ずくめ should be used instead., There is another suffix that uses づくし, meaning “all sorts/kinds of (A)”
english_grammar.about: Originally stemming from the suffix use of 尽(づ)く 'completely', or 'using solely', and the addition of め, ずくめ came to be preferentially written as hiragana, with ず replacing づ. This structure may be translated as 'completely (A)', 'all in (A)', or 'nothing but (A)'. Generally, it is attached directly to nouns, and expresses that (A) is to such an extent that nothing apart from (A) can be seen, felt, or noticed. In cases where ずくめ will directly modify the following noun, の will come between ずくめ and that noun. 今月(こんげつ)も仕事(しごと)ずくめになりそうだ。 It seems like I'm going to be doing nothing but work again this month. 最近(さいきん)は嫌(いや)なことずくめで全然(ぜんぜん)楽(たの)しくない。 I'm not having the best time right now, because nothing but bad things are happening. 彼(かれ)は黒(くろ)ずくめの男たちに誘拐された。 He was kidnapped by men covered in black. 警察(けいさつ)への電話(でんわ)：もしもし、家(いえ)の前(まえ)に黒(くろ)ずくめの車(くるま)が何台(なんだい)も止(と)まっているんで今(いま)から言(い)う住所(じゅうしょ)まできてもらってもいいですか。 Calling the cops: Hello, there are several jet black cars parked in front of my house, so could you please come to the address I'm about to tell you? Although づくめ may occasionally be seen in older literature, it is mostly considered incorrect kana usage these days. While ずくめ may be used in either positive or negative contexts, it is mainly seen in set expressions, so is best used with combinations that you have already heard or read. Fun-fact - 尽(づ)くし is another older structure that is used to express things that are separate, but are grouped together. This is usually translated as 'all sorts of (A)', or 'all kinds of (A)'. It is the conjunctive form of the う-Verb 尽(つ)くす 'to be exhaustive' with a voiced pronunciation of the つ. 国(くに)づくしの偉(えら)い人(ひと)が集(あつ)まった。 Great people from all sorts of countries gathered.

example.japanese: 《新聞(しんぶん)の見出(みだ)し》６月(がつ)猛暑(もうしょ)記録(きろく)ずくめ
example.english: Newspaper headline: June - A Heatwave full of Temperature Records

example.japanese: 規制(きせい)は必要(ひつよう)であるが規則(きそく)ずくめで窒息(ちっそく)しそうな社会(しゃかい)は強圧的(きょうあつてき)ではないだろうか。
