example.english: Regulations are needed, but isn’t a society that is about to suffocate with nothing but restrictions overbearing?

example.japanese: ２０２０年(ねん)は異例(いれい)ずくめの大変(たいへん)な年(とし)でしたが何(なん)とか乗(の)り切(き)りました。
example.english: 2020 was a very challenging year full of irregularities, but we somehow got through it.

example.japanese: 《ツイッターの投稿(とうこう)》朝(あさ)から晩(ばん)まで、ごちそうずくめで結婚(けっこん)を祝(いわ)う。
example.english: Twitter post: We are celebrating the marriage with nothing but delicacies from morning till night.

example.japanese: 黒(くろ)ずくめのスーツに身(み)を包(つつ)んだ男(おとこ)はベンチに座(すわ)り、逆(さか)さに持(も)った新聞(しんぶん)を読(よ)むふりをしていた。
example.english: A man dressed in a completely black suit was sitting on a bench and pretending to read a newspaper that was upside down.

english_grammar.title: には及(およ)ばない ②
english_grammar.explanation: To be no match (for), To not compare (with), To fall short (of), To not reach, Cannot win with, To be out of reach (for), To not be on par (with)
english_grammar.structure: Noun + には(1) + 及ばない Set expression: Noun + の足元にも及ばない (1) に
english_grammar.about: As mentioned in the には及(およ)ばない grammar point lesson as a polite expression, には及(およ)ばない may simply show the extent of something. This is usually when a comparison is being made between two things. This pattern is a combination of the case-marking marking particle に, the adverbial particle は, and the negated form of the う-Verb 及(およ)ぶ 'to reach', 及(およ)ばない. The literal translation is 'it does not extend to (A)'. This nuance of the phrase will appear after nouns. In this comparative use, the structure may also be translated as 'to be no match for (A)', 'to fall short of (A)', 'to not be on par with (A)'. この海(うみ)は沖縄(おきなわ)の海(うみ)には及(およ)ばないが、結構(けっこう)綺麗(きれい)だ。 This beach is no match for the beaches in Okinawa, but it is quite beautiful. あの一流(いちりゅう)レストランの味(あじ)には及(およ)ばないが、かなり似(に)ている。 The taste is no match for that top-notch restaurant, but it is very similar. 彼(かれ)はものすごくギターが上手(うま)いが、布袋(ほてい)寅泰(ともやす)には及(およ)ばない。 He is very good at playing the guitar, but he is no match for Hotei Tomoyasu. には及(およ)ばない will be used most frequently when (A) is something that is being given extremely high praise. As such, set combinations like (A) の足元(あしもと)には及(およ)ばない 'to not even reach the feet of (A)' will often be seen. どれだけ頑張(がんば)っても、青木(あおき)先輩(せんぱい)の足元(あしもと)には及(およ)ばない。 No matter how hard I try, I am no match for Aoki senpai.

example.japanese: 言(い)うまでもなく真作(しんさく)には及(およ)ばないでしょうが、いい贋作(がんさく)です。
example.english: Needless to say, it is no match for the original. Even still, it is a good forgery.

example.japanese: 「物理学(ぶつりがく)では、とてもアルバートには及(およ)ばない。」
example.english: “I am no match for Albert in physics.”

example.japanese: 続編(ぞくへん)は立派(りっぱ)なものの、明(あき)らかに最初(さいしょ)の映画(えいが)には及(およ)ばない。
example.english: Even though the sequel is splendid, it is clearly not on par with the first movie.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》はるこの嗅覚(きゅうかく)は、犬(いぬ)には及(およ)ばないが、普通(ふつう)の人間(にんげん)のよりははるかにすぐれている。
example.english: Novel: Haruko’s sense of smell was no match for a dog’s. However, it was far better than an ordinary human’s.

example.japanese: 「どんなに練習(れんしゅう)してもさいたま先生(せんせい)の足元(あしもと)にも及(およ)ばない。」
example.english: “No matter how much I train, I am no match for Saitama-sensei.”

english_grammar.title: とは言(い)うものの
english_grammar.explanation: Although, But, Although I say, Although it is said, Having said that
english_grammar.structure: Verb + とは言うものの + Phrase ［い］Adjective + とは言うものの + Phrase ［な］Adjective + （だ）+ とは言うものの + Phrase Noun + （だ）+ とは言うものの + Phrase Phrase (A)。とは言うものの + Phrase (B)
english_grammar.about: とは言(い)うものの is a set expression that may be used after most types of words, it is a combination of と as a case-marking particle, は as an adverbial particle, the う-Verb 言(い)う, and the conjunction particle ものの 'although'. Its literal translation of 'although it is said that (A), (B)' is the same as how it will usually be interpreted in English. When used after either nouns or な-Adjectives, だ will precede とは言(い)うものの. なんでも頑張(がんば)れば必(かなら)ずできるようになるとはいうものの、どれだけ頑張(がんば)ってもできないことはある。 Although it is said that you will be able to do something if you try your best, there are things that can't be done no matter how much you try. 今(いま)働(はたら)いている会社(かいしゃ)の給料(きゅうりょう)はいいとはいうものの、お金(かね)を使(つか)う時間(じかん)がない。 Although the pay at my current company is good, I don't have any time to use my money. スマホは便利(べんり)だというものの、使(つか)い方(かた)がわからないとスマホの便利(べんり)さをしれきれない。 Although it is said that smartphones are useful, if you don't know how to use them, you can't fully appreciate their usefulness. 彼(かれ)は学生(がくせい)だというものの、バイトばかりしていて勉強(べんきょう)についていけていない。 Although he is a student, he is falling behind with his studies because he works a lot. This phrase may also be used at the beginning of sentences when acknowledging a statement that was made, but then pointing out that there is other important information as well. In all cases, the (B) phrase that comes after ものの will be considered the important or defining detail.

example.japanese: 数学(すうがく)は時間(じかん)の無駄(むだ)だとは言(い)うものの、やはり基本(きほん)を知(し)る価値(かち)だってある。
example.english: Although it is said that math is a waste of time, actually, learning the basics still has its value.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)はホラー作家(さっか)として知(し)られているとは言(い)うものの、傑作(けっさく)と言(い)えるものは1982年(ねん)に出版(しゅっぱん)された犯罪(はんざい)小説(しょうせつ)だ。
example.english: Although he is known as a horror author, what can be called his masterpiece is actually a crime novel that was published in 1982.

example.japanese: チェコの「ストラホフ・スタジアム」は「世界(せかい)最大(さいだい)のスポーツスタジアム」とは言(い)うものの、実際(じっさい)にはスポーツ目的(もくてき)にはほとんど使(つか)われていない。
example.english: Although the Czech “Strahov Stadium” is said to be the "world’s largest sports stadium", in practice it is hardly used for sports purposes.

example.japanese: このカフェは人気(にんき)が高(たか)いとは言(い)うものの、実際(じっさい)には知(し)る人(ひと)ぞ知(し)る所(ところ)だ。
example.english: Although I say that this coffeehouse is popular, actually that’s limited to the people that know the place.

example.japanese: それは「人工(じんこう)知能(ちのう)」とは言(い)うものの、まだ「知能(ちのう)」というよりも「コンピューター」に近(ちか)いものだ。
example.english: Although that is called "artificial intelligence", it is still closer to a “computer” than actual “intelligence”.

english_grammar.title: が早(はや)いか
english_grammar.explanation: As soon as, No sooner than, The instant that, No sooner had
english_grammar.structure: Verb［る］(1) + が早いか + Phrase［た］ (1) Verb［た］
english_grammar.attention: While it can be used with the past form, non-past is more common.
english_grammar.about: が早(はや)いか is an expression in Japanese that groups with verbs, for the purpose of indicating an action which is immediately followed by a second, often unexpected action. It is a combination of the case-marking particle が, the い-Adjective 早(はや)い 'soon', and the adverbial particle か. It is often translated as 'no sooner than (A), (B)', or 'the instant that (A), (B)'. The more literal translation, taking into account the use of か, is '(A), or possibly sooner, (B)'. This just illustrates the instantaneousness of the (B) action in that (A) was unable to be determined as actually completed before (B) started. This grammar pattern is formal, and will follow verbs in their dictionary or past tense forms. The verb that comes in the (B) phrase will always be in the past tense. 彼女(かのじょ)は彼(かれ)が書(か)いた手紙(てがみ)を読(よ)むが早(はや)いか、悲(かな)しさのあまりで泣(な)き始(はじ)めた。 As soon as she read the letter from her boyfriend, she started to cry out of joy. 息子(むすこ)は食卓(しょくたく)に座(すわ)るが早(はや)いか、並(なら)べてあった夕食(ゆうしょく)を吸(す)い込(こ)むように食(く)い上(あ)げた。 As soon as my son sat at the dining table, he ate all the food that was out as if he sucked them up. 木村(きむら)くんはアラームが鳴(な)ったが早(はや)いか、スヌーズボタンを押(お)した。 As soon as the alarm went off, Kimura-kun pressed the snooze button. 警察官(けいさつかん)は犯人(はんにん)を見(み)つけたが早(はや)いか、犯人(はんにん)に飛(と)びつき手錠(てじょう)をかけた。 As soon as the police officer saw the suspect, he jumped onto him and handcuffed him. (A) will tend to be actions that happen momentarily, or having a clearly defined finish point. For actions that don't have a clearly defined finish point, 終(お)わる 'to finish' will often be linked to the stem form, in order to specify the end. Additionally, while the (B) action will often be unexpected, it will also usually be volitional, that is to say something done intentionally. Caution Due to が早(はや)いか always expressing something in the past, it cannot be used to express wishes or intentions for the future. Additionally, it will not highlight the speaker's own actions. 雨(あめ)が止(や)むが早(はや)いか、出(で)かけるつもりだ。 As soon as the rain stops, I am planning to go out. (Unnatural Japanese) 俺(おれ)は毎日(まいにち)家(いえ)に荷物(にもつ)を置(お)くが早(はや)いか、友達(ともだち)の家(いえ)に行(い)く。 I go to my friends house as soon as I drop my stuff off at home, everyday. (Unnatural Japanese)

example.japanese: お母(かあ)さんがケーキを焼(や)き上(あ)げるが早(はや)いか、お父(とう)さんが食(た)べ始(はじ)めた。
example.english: As soon as mom had baked the cake, dad started eating it.

example.japanese: 黒(くろ)ずくめの男(おとこ)は探偵(たんてい)を見(み)つけたが早(はや)いか、疾風(しっぷう)のごとく駆(か)け出(だ)した。
example.english: As soon as the man dressed completely in black noticed the detective, he dashed off like the wind.

example.japanese: 夜(よる)、幼(おさな)い魔法使(まほうつか)いが窓(まど)を開(あ)けるが早(はや)いか、白(しろ)フクロウが飛(と)び込(こ)んできた。
example.english: At night, as soon as the young wizard opened the window, a white owl flew in.

example.japanese: 自動(じどう)ドアが開(ひら)くが早(はや)いか、まもなく人々(ひとびと)は電車(でんしゃ)に乗(の)り込(こ)んだ。
example.english: As soon as the automatic doors opened, people promptly entered the train.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》田中(たなか)は目(め)が覚(さ)めたが早(はや)いかベッドから飛(と)び起(お)きた。
example.english: Novel: As soon as Tanaka opened his eyes, he jumped out of bed.

english_grammar.title: に難(かた)くない
english_grammar.explanation: Not hard to, Not difficult to, Easy to, Is obvious that
english_grammar.structure: Most common pattern: 想像 + （する）+ に難くない Less common patterns: 予想 + （する）+ に難くない 察する + に難くない 理解 + （する）+ に難くない 推測 + （する）+ に難くない
english_grammar.about: にかたくない is a formal grammar pattern that uses a different version of the い-Adjective 難(むずか)しい 'difficult', 難(かた)い, which has the same meaning. This adjective will be used in the negative, in order to indicate that something is 'not difficult'. The case-marking particle に at the beginning is limited to following verbs that indicate thinking or conjecture. そう言(い)う叱(しかり)り方(かた)は子供(こども)にいい影響(えいきょう)を与(あた)えないだろうことは想像(そうぞう)に難(かた)くない。 It is not hard to imagine that scolding children like that would not have a positive effect on the child. このプロジェクトを中止(ちゅうし)したら多(おお)くの人(ひと)に迷惑(めいわく)がかかることは予想(よそう)に難(かた)くない。 It is not hard to guess that canceling this project would end up inconveniencing a lot of people. 子供(こども)を亡(な)くした親(おや)たちの気持(きも)ちは理解(りかい)に難(かた)くない。 It is not difficult to understand the feelings of parents who have lost their children. This structure will only appear with quite a limited number of verbs, with 想像(そうぞう) 'to imagine', 予想(よそう) 'to predict', 察(さっ)する 'to infer' or 'to sense', 理解(りかい) 'to understand', and 推測(すいそく) 'to guess' making up the majority of them. Fun FactMany words have alternative forms that will be described as (A) の改(あらた)まった表現(ひょうげん) 'the reformed version of (A)' in Japanese dictionaries. Although the standard meaning of the る-Verb 改(あらた)まる is 'to redo', it can also often be 'to reform' in the sense of making something ceremonious or formal. (A) will usually be the far more common or everyday version of a word, such as with 難(むずか)しい in the case of this grammar point.

example.japanese: ピラミッドが、古代人(こだいじん)に畏敬(いけい)の念(ねん)を抱(いだ)かせたであろうことは、想像(そうぞう)に難(かた)くない。
example.english: It is not hard to imagine the awe that the pyramids likely inspired in the ancients.

example.japanese: 飛行機(ひこうき)が墜落(ついらく)すれば乗客(じょうきゃく)に何(なに)が起(お)こるかは察(さっ)するに難(かた)くない。
example.english: It is not hard to guess what happens to passengers when an airplane crashes.

example.japanese: その日(ひ)の悲惨(ひさん)な出来事(できごと)が、大(おお)いに影響(えいきょう)していただろうことは想像(そうぞう)に難(かた)くない。
example.english: It is not hard to imagine that the tragic events of that day likely affected her greatly.

example.japanese: 暴力(ぼうりょく)に満(み)ちているこのゲームが90年代(ねんだい)に論争(ろんそう)を巻(ま)き起(お)こした理由(りゆう)は理解(りかい)に難(かた)くない。
example.english: It is not hard to understand the reason why this game that is filled with violence caused controversy in the ‘90s.

example.japanese: バスの運転手(うんてんしゅ)がいかに大(おお)きな責任(せきにん)を背負(せお)っているか、想像(そうぞう)に難(かた)くない。
example.english: It is not hard to imagine how much responsibility a bus driver shoulders.

english_grammar.title: ならいざ知(し)らず
english_grammar.explanation: Don’t know about it, Maybe it would/might be possible for
english_grammar.structure: Most common pattern: Noun + なら(1) + いざ知らず Less common patterns: Verb + （の）+ なら(1) + いざ知らず ［い］Adjective + （の）+ なら(1) + いざ知らず Noun + であれば(2) + いざ知らず Noun + は + いざ知らず (1) ならば (2) だったら
english_grammar.about: (A) いざ知らず (B) is a slightly old-fashioned expression, which nowadays is mostly used in writing. It literally means that “If it’s (A) then I don’t know, but for (B) ... ” where いざ (originally いさ) is an interjection similar to the modern さあ and indicates confusion about how to answer a question.This expression is used to show the contrast between the extreme example (A) for which something might be the case, and then (B).Often followed by expressions of surprise, impossibility, or criticism.

example.japanese: １万(まん)円(えん)は社会人(しゃかいじん)ならいざ知(し)らず、小学生(しょうがくせい)にとっては想像(そうぞう)を絶(ぜっ)する金額(きんがく)だ。
example.english: I don’t know about working adults, but for children, 10 000 yen is an unimaginable amount of money.

example.japanese: 百(ひゃく)年(ねん)前(まえ)ならいざ知(し)らず、現代(げんだい)のこの国(くに)においては情報(じょうほう)へのアクセスは容易(ようい)になっているからそのようなことを誰(だれ)でも知(し)っているはずだ。
example.english: I don’t know about 100 years ago, but in modern times, since access to information is widespread in this country, everybody should know something like that.

example.japanese: 「運動(うんどう)は不健康(ふけんこう)だからしない」と最近(さいきん)よく聞(き)く。プロのスポーツ選手(せんしゅ)ならいざ知(し)らず、一般(いっぱん)の人(ひと)ならば、運動(うんどう)は有益(ゆうえき)である。
example.english: Recently, I often hear that “exercising is unhealthy, so I don’t do it”. I don’t know about professional athletes, but for ordinary people exercising is beneficial.

example.japanese: A：「子供(こども)の頃(ころ)、ここでザリガニを釣(つ)ったものだ。」 B：「昔(むかし)ならいざ知(し)らず、現代(げんだい)では川(かわ)が汚染(おせん)されているから​​無理(むり)です。」
example.english: “When I was a child, I used to catch crayfish here.”“I don’t know about how it was in the past, but nowadays the river is polluted, so it’s impossible.”

example.japanese: 「自分(じぶん)一人(ひとり)で衣装(いしょう)を着(き)て楽(たの)しむのならいざ知(し)らず、人前(ひとまえ)にコスプレ姿(すがた)で出(で)るのは私(わたし)にとっては不可能(ふかのう)に近(ちか)いです。」
example.english: “It might be possible to wear the costume by myself for fun, but when it comes to going out in public dressed in cosplay, then it’s nigh on impossible!

english_grammar.title: を禁(きん)じ得(え)ない
english_grammar.explanation: Cannot help feeling, Cannot but, Cannot hold back
english_grammar.structure: Noun + を禁じ得ない Verb + の + を禁じ得ない
english_grammar.about: (A) を禁じ得ない is a formal phrase used when the speaker/writer cannot suppress the rise of certain emotions (sadness, happiness, etc.) or the result of those emotions (like laughter or crying).It is generally used with a limited number of expressions like: 涙、笑い、同情（の念）、驚き（の念）、怒り、苦しみ、失望、喜び、感動. This expression is uncommon in daily conversation.

example.japanese: この生徒(せいと)たちは流暢(りゅうちょう)な日本語(にほんご)でニュースについて議論(ぎろん)していたが、彼(かれ)らは2年(ねん)前(まえ)から日本語(にほんご)を勉強(べんきょう)し始(はじ)めたと聞(き)いて、驚(おどろ)きを禁(きん)じ得(え)なかった。
example.english: I could not help being surprised, hearing that these students who were discussing the news in fluent Japanese, had started studying it two years ago.

example.japanese: この不況(ふきょう)の中(なか)、政治家(せいじか)が自分(じぶん)の給与(きゅうよ)を上(あ)げるとの報道(ほうどう)を耳(みみ)にし、怒(いか)りを禁(きん)じ得(え)ません。
example.english: I cannot help but feel anger upon hearing the news that the politicians raised their salaries during this time of recession.

example.japanese: 《伝記(でんき)》戦争(せんそう)がこの地方(ちほう)にもたらした破壊(はかい)を見(み)て、涙(なみだ)を禁(きん)じ得(え)なかった。
example.english: Biography: I could not hold back tears after seeing the destruction that the war brought upon this area.

example.japanese: 長(なが)い年月(としつき)の後(のち)、互(たが)いに抱(だ)き合(あ)った姿(すがた)に、喜(よろこ)びを禁(きん)じ得(え)ない。
example.english: I cannot help but feel joy at seeing those two embracing one another after all these years.

example.japanese: 全(すべ)てを失(うしな)った地震(じしん)の被害者(ひがいしゃ)に同情(どうじょう)の念(ねん)を禁(きん)じ得(え)ない。
example.english: I cannot help feeling compassion for the victims of the earthquake, who lost everything.

english_grammar.title: に託(かこつ)けて
english_grammar.explanation: In the name of, Using the excuse of, To use as a pretext of, Under the guise/pretense of
english_grammar.structure: Noun + にかこつけて Verb + の(1) + にかこつけて (1) こと
english_grammar.about: (A) にかこつけて (B) is a phrase meaning “under the pretence of” and is used to mark behavior (A) that is used to hide real reason or intention. The phrase is often used for criticism.

example.japanese: 「花子(はなこ)ったら部(ぶ)活動(かつどう)にかこつけて、部室(ぶしつ)に潜(もぐ)り込(こ)んでひとり遊(あそ)んでばかりいるよ。」
example.english: “Speaking of Hanako, she sneaks into the club room under the pretence of club activity and just lazes around.”

example.japanese: 人(ひと)（私(わたし)も含(ふく)めて）はお菓子(かし)が大好(だいす)きで何(なに)かにかこつけていつも買(か)ってしまうのではないだろうか。
example.english: I think that people (myself included) love sweets and will always buy them under some pretext.

example.japanese: 武田(たけだ)「田中(たなか)さんったら出張(しゅっちょう)にかこつけてパリを観光(かんこう)するつもりね。」田中(たなか)さん「いやいや、そんなこと。」
example.english: Takeda: “Tanaka-san, you're planning to go sightseeing in Paris using the pretence of a business trip, aren't you?”Tanaka: “No no, nothing like that.”

example.japanese: A：「あすかさんと会(あ)いたいけどどうしたらいい？」 B：「プリントを渡(わた)すというのにかこつけて家(いえ)に行(い)ったらどう？」
example.english: A: “I want to meet with Asuka, but what should I do?” B: “How about going to her house under the pretext of intending to give her printouts?”

example.japanese: 風邪(かぜ)にかこつけて、仕事(しごと)を休(やす)んで一(いち)日中(にちじゅう)コーラを飲(の)んだりゲームをしてしまった。
example.english: Using the pretext of a cold, he took some time off work, drank coke, and played games all day long.

english_grammar.title: 様(よう)によっては
english_grammar.explanation: Depending on the way, Depending on how
english_grammar.structure: Verb［ます］+ ようによっては + Phrase
english_grammar.about: (A) ようによっては (B) is a phrase meaning that “(B) depends on the way you (A)” and is used when (B) changes depending on (A). よう is a noun meaning “the way/manner” that something appears or is done. In this expression, it generally follows the stem of verbs like 考える、見る、聞く、読む、やる and 使う。

example.japanese: このドレスの色(いろ)は見(み)ようによっては「青(あお)と黒(くろ)」か「白(しろ)と金(きん)」に見(み)えるかもしれない。
example.english: Depending on how you look at it, the color of this dress may seem like it’s “blue and black” or “white and gold”.

example.japanese: 「結構(けっこう)です」は聞(き)きようによっては肯定(こうてい)にでも否定(ひてい)にでもどちらにでも受(う)け取(と)れる。
example.english: Depending on the way you hear it, “結構です” can be taken either as affirmation or denial.

example.japanese: 経済(けいざい)危機(きき)は、一見(いっけん)絶望(ぜつぼう)しかないように見(み)えるが、考(かんが)えようによっては素晴(すば)らしい機会(きかい)とも言(い)えるかもしれない。
example.english: The economic crisis may seem to be nothing but despair. However, depending on the way you think about it, it might also be called a great opportunity.

example.japanese: 確(たし)かに、この大(おお)きな目(め)のクモは、見(み)ようによっては可愛(かわい)いらしいと言(い)えなくもない。
example.english: Needless to say, depending on the way you look at this big-eyed spider, it can kind of be called adorable.

example.japanese: このツイートは読(よ)みようによっては皮肉(ひにく)にも取(と)れるだろう。
example.english: Depending on the way you read this tweet, you could take it as irony, right!?

english_grammar.title: べくもない
english_grammar.explanation: No (doubt/hope), There is no way, It is impossible, Not a hope in hell
english_grammar.structure: Verb + べくもない Exceptions: ［する］Verb + す(1) + べくもない (1) する
english_grammar.about: (A) べくもない is a formal written expression used when there is no possibility of (A) happening at all. It generally follows expressions like 望む、疑う、知る、比べる、及ぶ、考える、否定、かなう、勝つ、想像する, and does not appear in daily conversation.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》戦力差(せんりょくさ)は歴然(れきぜん)としているゆえ、まともな勝負(しょうぶ)は望(のぞ)むべくもない。
example.english: Novel: Since the difference in strength is clear, there is no hope of a decent match.

example.japanese: いくら頑張(がんば)ったところで、絵(え)は写真(しゃしん)にはおよぶべくもないのである。
example.english: No matter how much one tries, a drawing is no match for a photograph.

example.japanese: 地球(ちきゅう)温暖化(おんだんか)は人間(にんげん)活動(かつどう)と直接(ちょくせつ)関係(かんけい)があるということは疑(うたが)うべくもない。
example.english: There is no doubt that global warming is directly linked to human influence.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》今回(こんかい)、彼(かれ)は危害(きがい)を免(まぬか)れたにせよ、そのように運転(うんてん)を続(つづ)けていては将来(しょうらい)は彼(かれ)に何事(なにごと)が起(おこ)りかねぬかは、知(し)るべくもない。
example.english: Novel: Even though he escaped injury this time, there is no way to know what might happen to him in the future if he continues driving like that.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》この真(ま)正直(しょうじき)な少年(しょうねん)に、嘘(うそ)をつくなど望(のぞ)むべくもない。
example.english: Novel: There’s not a hope in hell that this honest boy would lie.

english_grammar.title: と来(き)たら ②
english_grammar.explanation: for …(is the best), when it comes to, concerning
english_grammar.structure: Phrase + ときたら
english_grammar.about: (A) ときたら (B) is used to emphasize that for (A), the most suitable course of action, the natural outcome, or the most natural match is (B). Often used together with やっぱり/やはり.

example.japanese: 「田中(たなか)さんがクビになったと聞(き)いたよ。」「毎日(まいにち)遅刻(ちこく)ときたらクビになるのは当然(とうぜん)でしょ。」
example.english: 'I heard Mr. Tanaka got fired.’'No wonder he would get fired when he was late every day.'

example.japanese: ドーナツときたらやっぱり牛乳(ぎゅうにゅう)でしょ！
example.english: For doughnuts, as expected, milk (is the best), right?

example.japanese: テストで毎回(まいかい)0点(てん)を取(と)っているときたら、お母(かあ)さんが怒(おこ)らないわけがない。
example.english: When you get a zero on every test, there's no way your mother won't get angry.

example.japanese: 暑(あつ)い日(ひ)ときたら、やっぱり麦茶(むぎちゃ)よね。
example.english: For a hot day, as expected, barley tea (is the best), right?

example.japanese: こんなに曇(くも)っているときたら、雨(あめ)が降(ふ)らないはずがない。
example.english: When it is so cloudy, it is impossible for it not to rain.

english_grammar.title: ものとして
english_grammar.explanation: assuming, supposing, (interpret) as, on the assumption, regarding, considering
english_grammar.structure: Verb + ものとして ［い］Adjective + ものとして ［な］Adjective + な(1) + ものとして Noun + である + ものとして (1) である
english_grammar.about: (A) ものとして means 'to suppose that (A) is the case'. It is often used in formal writing, like contracts and documents.

example.japanese: これ以上(いじょう)討議(とうぎ)しても進展(しんてん)は見込(みこ)めないものとして、これをもって会議(かいぎ)はお開(ひら)きとします。
example.english: Considering no further progress can be made in the discussion, with this the meeting is closed.

example.japanese: 講師(こうし)：「ご質問(しつもん)等(など)はありますか？ない場合(ばあい)は理解(りかい)したものとして今日(きょう)はここまでです。」
example.english: Lecturer : ‘Do you have any questions? If not, I will assume that you understood, and that will be all for today.’

example.japanese: 大学(だいがく)のサイト：先生(せんせい)からの連絡(れんらく)は一度(いちど)掲示(けいじ)された内容(ないよう)については1週間(しゅうかん)後(ご)、全(ぜん)学生(がくせい)に伝達(でんたつ)されたものとして扱(あつか)います。
example.english: University website : ‘Once posted, communications from the teacher will be assumed to have been delivered to all students after one week.’

example.japanese: 格闘技(かくとうぎ)においては選手(せんしゅ)は畳(たたみ)やマットを3回(かい)叩(たた)くと降参(こうさん)したものとして、試合(しあい)の決着(けっちゃく)がつく。
example.english: In martial arts, a match will be regarded as forfeited when a fighter strikes the tatami or mat three times.

example.japanese: しかしながら、市長(しちょう)は、住民(じゅうみん)の心配(しんぱい)事(ごと)を、ありえないものとして、却下(きゃっか)しました。
example.english: However, the mayor dismissed the residents' worries, supposing they were improbable.

english_grammar.title: を前提（ぜんてい）にして
english_grammar.explanation: on the premise of
english_grammar.structure: Noun + を前提に(して)(1) Verb + こと + を前提に(して)(1) (1) として
english_grammar.about: (A)を前提に(B) is used to express condition (A) assumed to be true, on which some kind of idea or product is developed.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)たちは、結婚(けっこん)を前提(ぜんてい)に付(つ)き合(あ)っている。
example.english: We are dating on the premise of marriage.

example.japanese: 元々(もともと)、 1人(ひとり)で住(す)むことを前提(ぜんてい)にこの家(いえ)を建(た)てたから、時(とき)が経(た)ったらちょっと狭(せま)くなった。
example.english: The house was originally built on the premise that I would live there by myself, so it turned out to be a little small over time.

example.japanese: 原価(げんか)見積(みつもり)は、建材(けんざい)の価格(かかく)が緩(ゆる)やかに上昇(じょうしょう)することを前提(ぜんてい)に計算(けいさん)されます。
example.english: Cost estimates are calculated on the premise of a slow increase in the price of building materials.

example.japanese: 多(おお)くの家庭(かてい)用(よう)ゲーム機(き)を所有(しょゆう)している人(ひと)はゲームが終(お)わったら売(う)ることを前提(ぜんてい)にそのゲームを買(か)っている。
example.english: Many console owners purchase games based on the premise that they will sell them after finishing.

example.japanese: 本(ほん)教科書(きょうかしょ)は、文法(ぶんぽう)に関(かん)する知識(ちしき)があることを前提(ぜんてい)に書(か)かれています。
example.english: This textbook was written on the premise that you have an understanding of basic grammar.

english_grammar.title: せずにはすまない
english_grammar.explanation: Won't get away without, Won't get off without, Have to, Have no choice but to, Can’t not
english_grammar.structure: Verb[ない] + ずには + すまない Verb[ない] + では + すまない Exception: する→せずにはすまない
english_grammar.attention: It is advisable to use ざるをえない or ないわけにはいかない or similar grammar points instead as this expression is not very common.
english_grammar.about: (A) ずにはすまない is a formal written phrase, literally meaning that someone is "not going to get away without (A)". It is used when someone has to do something due to social norms, laws or customs. Reason for doing (A) is usually negatiive in some way.

example.japanese: 重要(じゅうよう)な会議(かいぎ)だから、間(ま)に合(あ)わないではすまない。
example.english: It's an important meeting, so I won't get away without making it on time.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は相談(そうだん)もなく重要(じゅうよう)な道具(どうぐ)を廃棄(はいき)した。首(くび)にならずにはすまないだろう。
example.english: He has scrapped an important tool without consultation. He won't get off without being fired.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)は子犬(こいぬ)を助(たす)けるためとはいえ、無断(むだん)で車(くるま)の窓(まど)を破(やぶ)った。罰(ばつ)を受(う)けずにはすまないだろう。
example.english: I broke the window of the car without permission, even though I was trying to save a puppy. I won't get away unpunished.

example.japanese: この深刻(しんこく)な問題(もんだい)は難(むずか)しいので、上司(じょうし)に話(はな)さずにはすまないだろう。
example.english: I have no choice but to talk to my boss about it, since it is a serious problem.

example.japanese: 大人(おとな)なのだから、知(し)らないではすまないだろう。
example.english: Since you are an adult, you won't get by without knowing it.

english_grammar.title: に堪(た)えない
english_grammar.explanation: Cannot bear to, Cannot stand to, Too much to, Cannot go on doing, Cannot tolerate
english_grammar.structure: Verb + に堪えない Adverb + に堪えない
english_grammar.attention: Can be written as に堪えない、に耐えない
english_grammar.about: にたえない is a phrase literally meaning "cannot bear to". It is used when one cannot look at/ listen to/read something because it is dreadful or in some way unpleasant (often brutal).Affirmative form (にたえる) is used when something is worth doing. にたえない is also used (usually in the polite form, as に絶えません) with words expressing feelings to show their extreme degree 感謝にたえません (my deepest gratitude).

example.japanese: くりやまさんの歌声(うたごえ)は酷(ひど)すぎて聞(き)くに堪(た)えなかった。
example.english: Kuriyama-san's singing voice was so terrible that I couldn't bear to listen.

example.japanese: このホラー映画(えいが)には正視(せいし)にたえない、すごく残虐(ざんぎゃく)なシーンが多(おお)い。
example.english: In this horror movie, there are so many brutal scenes that I cannot bear to watch it.

example.japanese: 最近(さいきん)、新聞(しんぶん)で悪(わる)いニュースばかりが続(つづ)いているから読(よ)むに堪(た)えない。
example.english: With all the bad news in the newspaper lately, I cannot bear to read it.

example.japanese: この捨(す)てられた、​​負傷(ふしょう)した子犬(こいぬ)があまりに不憫(ふびん)で、直視(ちょくし)に耐(た)えなかった。
example.english: I felt so sorry for this abandoned, injured puppy that I couldn't bear to look directly at it.

example.japanese: 嘘(うそ)をついてばかりいる政治家(せいじか)のインタビューはもう聞(き)くに堪(た)えない。
example.english: I can't tolerate listening to interviews with politicians who tell nothing but lies.

english_grammar.title: 始末(しまつ)だ
english_grammar.explanation: Ends up, Finally, In the end, (Unfortunately) As a result, This is what happened, To come about, To wind up
english_grammar.structure: Verb[る] + 始末だ この始末だ
english_grammar.about: (A), (B) 始末だ is an expression that is used to show that the unfavorable (B) is the end result of the event or series of events caused by (A). It can be used to express a speaker's disappointment or irritation. It is often used with expressions like あげく、結局、とうとう and so on for emphasis.この始末だ is a set phrase indicating exasperation at the current state of affairs.

example.japanese: 武田(たけだ)さんは小(ちい)さな声(こえ)で職場(しょくば)でハラスメントを受(う)けたことを伝(つた)えてきて、しまいに大(おお)きな声(こえ)で泣(な)き出(だ)す始末(しまつ)だ。
example.english: Takeda-san told me that she was being harassed at work, and wound up crying out loud.

example.japanese: あいつは、自分(じぶん)が起(お)こしたミスなのに、謝(あやま)るどころか私(わたし)のせいにする始末(しまつ)だ。
example.english: Even though it was a mistake that he had made, far from apologizing, he ended up blaming me!

example.japanese: せっかく友達(ともだち)と海(うみ)へ行(い)く計画(けいかく)を立(た)てたのに、田中(たなか)は大事(だいじ)な用(よう)があって行(い)けないとか、武田(たけだ)もシフトが入(はい)ってたとかで、結局(けっきょく)私(わたし)一(ひと)人(り)だけで行(い)く始末(しまつ)だ。
example.english: Even though I went out of my way to plan this trip to the beach with friends, Tanaka said that he had something important to do and couldn't go, while Takeda said that he had a shift. So I ended up going all by myself.

example.japanese: 武田(たけだ)「山田(やまだ)さん、顔色(かおいろ)が悪(わる)いですけど・・・」山田(やまだ)「夜(よる)遅(おそ)くまでゲームをしていたので、おかげでこの始末(しまつ)だ。」
example.english: Takeda: "Yamada-san, you don't look so good..."Yamada "I was playing video games until late at night, and this is the result."

example.japanese: 田中(たなか)には2度(ど)と仕事(しごと)は頼(たの)まないぞ。納期(のうき)は守(まも)らないし仕上(しあ)がりも悪(わる)かったのに、言(い)い訳(わけ)ばかりならべて。最後(さいご)には追加(ついか)の料金(りょうきん)を払(はら)えと言(い)い出(だ)す始末(しまつ)だ。
example.english: I'll never ask Tanaka to work for me again. He can’t meet deadlines, his workmanship is poor, and he only gives excuse after excuse. In the end he told me to pay an additional fee.

english_grammar.title: ものなら ②
english_grammar.explanation: If you were to do, If you try to, If … happens, Should there be
english_grammar.structure: Verb[volitional] + ものなら/もんなら + Phrase
english_grammar.about: (A) [volitional] ものなら (B) is a phrase expressing the opinion of the speaker that possibly if situation (A) happens, the negative result (B) will follow.In (A), phrases showing extreme examples of something like でも、万が一 or expressions like ちょっと、うっかり、もし are common. (B) often ends with phrases of conjecture, like かもしれない、だろう、はず.

example.japanese: しのぶさんはとても血(ち)を恐(おそ)れている。万(まん)が一(いち)、一滴(いってき)でも血(ち)を見(み)ようものなら気絶(きぜつ)してしまうはずだ。
example.english: Shinobu is completely terrified of blood. If she were to see even one drop of it by chance, she would faint for sure.

example.japanese: ブラッド・ピットに出逢(であ)おうものなら、死(し)んでしまう。
example.english: If I were to run into Brad Pitt, I would die.

example.japanese: 秘密(ひみつ)を打(う)ち明(あ)けようものなら、彼女(かのじょ)はすぐに他(ほか)の奴(やつ)らにしゃべってしまうだろう。
example.english: If you happen to tell her a secret, she will quickly spill it to others.

example.japanese: 万(まん)が一(いち)このプロジェクトが失敗(しっぱい)しようものなら、我々(われわれ)は終(お)わりだ。
example.english: If this project were to fail, we'd be finished.

example.japanese: うっかり彼(かれ)のお菓子(かし)を食(た)べようものなら、きっと、ものすごく彼(かれ)にしかられるはずだ。
example.english: If you were to go and eat his sweets, you would be scolded for sure.

english_grammar.title: に引(ひ)き換(か)え
english_grammar.explanation: In stark contrast, In comparison, On the other hand, While, In sharp contrast
english_grammar.structure: Noun＋にひきかえ ［な］Adjective＋な・である＋の＋にひきかえ ［い］Adjective＋の＋にひきかえ Verb＋の＋にひきかえ Phrase (A)。それにひきかえ、Noun は＋Phrase (B)
english_grammar.about: (A) にひきかえ (B) is used to contrast two things/people/animals and so on subjectively. The speaker considers (A) and (B) to be complete opposites and evaluates one of them positively (usually A) and the other negatively (usually B). The それにひきかえ pattern is the most common. にひきかえ is used with factual clauses, so it is generally not used with expressions of conjecture like かもしれない and the like.

example.japanese: 母親(ははおや)の友達(ともだち)の息子(むすこ)さんは、弁護士(べんごし)として立派(りっぱ)に働(はたら)いているのにひきかえ、僕(ぼく)は・・・（まだフリーターだ）。
example.english: In stark contrast to my mother's friend's son, who is working prominently as a lawyer, I am… (still a permanent part-timer.)

example.japanese: 姉(あね)は積極的(せっきょくてき)で活発(かっぱつ)な性格(せいかく)にひきかえ、弟(おとうと)の健太郎(けんたろう)はとても無気力(むきりょく)だ。
example.english: In stark contrast to the elder sister's lively personality, the younger brother, Kentaro, is very apathetic.

example.japanese: 兄(あに)は優秀(ゆうしゅう)な成績(せいせき)をおさめている。それにひきかえ妹(いもうと)の方(ほう)は遊(あそ)んでばかりだ。
example.english: The elder brother has excellent grades. In stark contrast to that, the younger sister is just mucking around.

example.japanese: 前回(ぜんかい)のテストにひきかえ今回(こんかい)のテストは難(むずか)しい。
example.english: In stark contrast to the previous test, this one is hard.

example.japanese: 隣(となり)の家(いえ)の猫(ねこ)は痩(や)せていて頭(あたま)がいいのにひきかえうちの猫(ねこ)はぐうたらしてばかりだなあ。
example.english: In stark contrast to the neighbor's cat, which is skinny and smart, our cat is just loafing around.

english_grammar.title: それまでだ
english_grammar.explanation: if… then It is all in vain, it's done, it is useless, no point, it is a waste, that's it, it is all gone,
english_grammar.structure: Verb [たら] + それまでだ Verb [ば] + それまでだ
english_grammar.about: (A) [conditional]それまでだ is a phrase meaning that if A happens, then all ends - implying that efforts and resources are wasted. It is often used when advising someone to avoid A. The phrase is frequently following ても (even if).

example.japanese: A：「毎日(まいにち)毎日(まいにち)勉強(べんきょう)していてとても疲(つか)れてるんだ。。大学(だいがく)を中退(ちゅうたい)したい。。。」B：「でも、もう３年生(ねんせい)だよ！あきらめてしまったらそれまでだよ。」
example.english: A: "I'm studying every single day, I am so tired. I want to drop out of college."B: "But you're already in your third year! If you give up then it's all in vain."

example.japanese: どんなに大(おお)きな家(いえ)でも、誰(だれ)も住(す)まなければそれまでだ。
example.english: No matter how big the house is, if no one lives there then it's all in vain.

example.japanese: この内定(ないてい)を受諾(じゅだく)することに興味(きょうみ)がないだけと言(い)えばそれまでだが、もういちどよく考(かんが)えて決(き)めたほうがいいだろうな。こんなチャンスは二度(にど)とないよ。
example.english: If you say that you are not interested in accepting this offer then there is no point (in discussing further), but I think you'd better think it over once again and then decide. You won't get a second chance like this.

example.japanese: 《ダイエットしている友達(ともだち)へ》「頑張(がんば)って運動(うんどう)しても毎日(まいにち)食(た)べ過(す)ぎたらそれまでだよ。」
example.english: To a friend who is dieting: "Even if you do your best exercising, if you eat too much every day then it's all in vain."

example.japanese: 《スパイ映画(えいが)》「敵(てき)に発見(はっけん)されたらそれまでだ。」
example.english: Spy movie: "If we are discovered then it's all in vain."

english_grammar.title: と言(い)おうか
english_grammar.explanation: how to put it, how shall I put it, how should I put it, or perhaps, or maybe, call it … or
english_grammar.structure: AといおうかBといおうか + (Phrase) where A and B can be Noun, い [Adjective], な [Adjective] or Verb
english_grammar.attention: It is advisable to use というか・というか pattern instead since it is much more common and interchangeable
english_grammar.about: (A) といおうか(B) といおうか is a phrase used when the speaker is troubled over how to call something. It is often followed by a more detailed description or words indicating that matter cannot be easily expressed. It can be also used when the speaker wants to make something vaguer to avoid using strong words, especially when saying something negative. The following clause is often omitted.

example.japanese: この前(まえ)、電車(でんしゃ)を乗(の)り違(ちが)えてしまったんだ。僕(ぼく)はそのとき、自分(じぶん)でもこんなドジをして、面白(おもしろ)いといおうか、困(こま)っているといおうか…とにかく忘(わす)れられない思(おも)い出(で)になったよ。
example.english: I took the wrong train the other day. I made such a blunder at that time, how shall I put it, it was funny? or perhaps troubling?... Anyway, it turned into an unforgettable memory.

example.japanese: A「プチチーズってなんですか。」B「クラッカーといおうか、チーズとのスナックといおうか…（うーん、的確(てきかく)な言葉(ことば)が思(おも)い浮(う)かばないなぁ。）」
example.english: A What is 「プチチーズ」?B "How shall I put it, a cracker, or perhaps a snack with cheese..." (well, I can't think of the right word.)

example.japanese: 「彼女(かのじょ)は誰(だれ)ですか？」「彼(かれ)の元(もと)カノといおうか友達(ともだち)といおうか複雑(ふくざつ)ですよ。」
example.english: "Who is she?""How shall I put it, his ex-girlfriend, or perhaps his friend, it's complicated."

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は穏(おだ)やかといおうか、のんびりといおうか、何事(なにごと)につけてもゆっくりしている。
example.english: How shall I put it, he is calm or perhaps relaxed, he takes his time with everything.

example.japanese: とうとう一人暮(ひとりぐ)らしを始(はじ)めたのに、寂(さび)しいといおうか嬉(うれ)しいといおうか、よくわからない。
example.english: I finally started living alone, and how shall I put it, I don't really know if I am lonely or happy.

english_grammar.title: ずには措(お)かない
english_grammar.explanation: will definitely, will certainly, bound to, not fail to
english_grammar.structure: Verb [ない-stem] + ずには + おかない Verb [ない] + では + おかない Exception: する→せずにはおかない Verb [Negative] + では + おかない
english_grammar.attention: also used to express that subject (usually non-animate like a book) has an emotional effect on people
english_grammar.about: (A) ずにはおかない is a phrase used when a subject (person or organization, usually speaker herself/himself) has a strong resolution to exert influence over someone. Often used with the causative form, adverbs like きっと, 絶対に or 必ず can be added for emphasis.

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)、勇者(ゆうしゃ)》「どんな手段(しゅだん)を用(もち)いても、かならず魔王(まおう)を倒(たお)さずにはおかない。」
example.english: Novel: "No matter what it takes, I will not fail to defeat the Demon Lord!"

example.japanese: 「私(わたし)はきっと彼(かれ)に同(おな)じ手(て)で仕返(しかえ)しをしないではおかない。」
example.english: "I won't fail to pay him back in his own coin."

example.japanese: 「警察(けいさつ)はすべての悪者(わるもの)に必(かなら)ず罰(ばち)を与(あた)えずにはおかない。」
example.english: "The police will not fail to punish all the wicked people."

example.japanese: 「彼(かれ)はまた私(わたし)との約束(やくそく)をすっぽかした。絶対(ぜったい)に彼(かれ)に「ごめんなさい」と言(い)わせずにはおかない。」
example.english: "He skipped our appointment again. I won't fail to get him to say 'I'm sorry."

example.japanese: 《小説(しょうせつ)》探偵(たんてい)は「この残虐(ざんぎゃく)行為(こうい)の責任者(せきにんしゃ)を訴追(そつい)せずにはおかない」と意(い)を決(けっ)する。
example.english: Novel: "The detective resolved himself, 'I won't fail to bring the person responsible for this atrocity to justice.'"

english_grammar.title: を限(かぎ)りに
english_grammar.explanation: As of (the end of), (Starting) from, (No longer) after, By (the), Ending with
english_grammar.structure: Noun + を限りに Noun + 限りで
english_grammar.about: (A) を限りに is an expression used to indicate the time that something ends or significantly changes. (A) is usually a time expression. 限りで is less formal compared to を限りに. This phrase often follows words like 今日、今回、今月、今年 and so on.を限りに is also used in a set phrase「声を限りに」- "to the limit of one's voice" or "at the top of one's lungs" as in 「武は声を限りに叫んだ。」- "Takeshi screamed at the top of his lungs." It can be also written as 声の限りに

example.japanese: 妻(つま)の「今回(こんかい)限(かぎ)りでタバコをやめよう」という言葉(ことば)を今(いま)までに何(なん)回(かい)聞(き)いただろう？
example.english: How many times do you think I've heard my wife's words "I'm quitting smoking as of this time"?

example.japanese: 明日(あす)を限(かぎ)りに閉店(へいてん)致(いた)します。当店(とうてん)は1972年(ねん)に開業(かいぎょう)し、４９年(ねん)にわたり現在(げんざい)の場所(ばしょ)で営業(えいぎょう)してまいりました。
example.english: We will close as of tomorrow. This store opened in 1972 and has been operating at our current location for 49 years.

example.japanese: 《異動(いどう)》公務員(こうむいん)「今週(こんしゅう)限(かぎ)りで、現在(げんざい)の職務(しょくむ)から離(はな)れることになりました。」
example.english: Changes in personnel, civil servant: "I will be leaving my current position as of this week."

example.japanese: 「うまくいかないから、やっぱり、今日(きょう)限(かぎ)りで別(わか)れよう。」
example.english: "It's not working out, so let's break up as of today."

example.japanese: 《同僚(どうりょう)との話(はなし)》「今月(こんげつ)限(かぎ)りで田中(たなか)さんは退職(たいしょく)するつもりって聞(き)いたけど、本当(ほんとう)か？」
example.english: Conversation between coworkers: "I heard that Tanaka is planning to resign as of this month, but is that true?"

english_grammar.title: ては敵(かな)わない
english_grammar.explanation: It's unbearable when, It'd be unbearable if, I can't stand it when, I couldn’t stand it if
english_grammar.structure: Verb［られる］［て］＋ては(1)＋かなわない ［い］Adjective［い］＋くては(1)＋かなわない ［な］Adjective＋では(2)＋かなわない (1) ちゃ (2)じゃ
english_grammar.attention: (A) にはかなわない is used when one is no match for (A)
english_grammar.about: (A) てはかなわない is an old-fashioned expression used to indicate the displeasure of the speaker/writer with (A). こう and こんなに are often used when (A) is an adjective.

example.japanese: こう寒(さむ)くてはかなわない。
example.english: It's unbearable when it's cold like this.

example.japanese: 雨(あめ)に降(ふ)られてはかなわない。
example.english: I can't stand getting rained on.

example.japanese: 上(うえ)の部屋(へや)の人(ひと)がうるさくてはかなわない。
example.english: It's unbearable when the people upstairs are noisy.

example.japanese: 話(はなし)をしている時(とき)、非常識(ひじょうしき)なひとに邪魔(じゃま)されてはかなわない。
example.english: It's unbearable when I am interrupted by a thoughtless person when I am speaking.

example.japanese: 毎日(まいにち)こんなに蒸(む)し暑(あつ)くてはかなわない。
example.english: It's unbearable when it is so humid every day like this.

english_grammar.title: 旁(かたがた)
english_grammar.explanation: Partly for (the purpose of), In addition to, Along with, By the way, And also to, Incidentally, While
english_grammar.structure: Noun + かたがた ［する］Verb + かたがた
english_grammar.about: (A) かたがた (B) is a formal expression meaning that the speaker/writer, on the opportunity of doing (A), does (B) as well, or does (B) for the purpose of (A). It has a strong nuance of respect towards the addressee, therefore it is used in formal letters to superiors, clients, and such. It often follows nouns like お礼、挨拶、報告、お見舞い. In (B), verbs of movement like 訪問する、伺う are common.

example.japanese: 《恩師(おんし)の訪問(ほうもん)》本日(ほんじつ)は当時(とうじ)のお礼(れい)かたがた、卒業(そつぎょう)して以来(いらい)どうしているかをご報告(ほうこく)しに訪(たず)ねさせていただきました。
example.english: Visiting a former teacher: Today I visited her to express my gratitude for that time (in my life), and also to let her know how I have been doing since I graduated.

example.japanese: 《​​挨拶状(あいさつじょう)》まずは右(みぎ)ご挨拶(あいさつ)かたがたお知(し)らせまで
example.english: Greeting card: For now, this is only a notification and also greetings.

example.japanese: 結婚(けっこん)の報告(ほうこく)かたがた、妻(つま)の兄弟(きょうだい)の家(いえ)を訪(たず)ねました
example.english: I visited my wife's sibling's house partly for the purpose of announcing our marriage.

example.japanese: 《同(おな)じ会社(かいしゃ)で働(はたら)く上司(じょうし)へのメール》「ご挨拶(あいさつ)かたがた訪問(ほうもん)をさせて頂(いただ)きたいのですが、明日(あした)のご都合(つごう)はいかがでしょうか。
example.english: Email to a superior in the same company: "I would like to pay you a visit to say hello (and also other things). How would tomorrow be for you?"

example.japanese: 《同(おな)じ会社(かいしゃ)で働(はたら)く上司(じょうし)へのメール》まずはお礼(れい)かたがたご挨拶(あいさつ)申(もう)し上(あ)げます。
example.english: Email to a superior in the same company: "For now, I would like to express my gratitude, and also greetings."

english_grammar.title: を余儀(よぎ)なくさせる
english_grammar.explanation: Force to, To compel, Make unavoidable
english_grammar.structure: Noun + を余儀なくさせる Verb + こと + を余儀なくさせる
english_grammar.about: (A) が (B) に (C) を余儀なくさせる means that (A) forces (B) to (C), regardless of his/her will. Unlike the を余儀なくされる, the subject (A) is usually a non-human cause.

example.japanese: 地球(ちきゅう)温暖化(おんだんか)が、サンタクロースに北(ほっ)極点(きょくてん)から移転(いてん)することを余儀(よぎ)なくさせた。
example.english: Global warming forced Santa Claus to relocate away from the North Pole.

example.japanese: パンデミックは店(みせ)や学校(がっこう)の閉鎖(へいさ)を余儀(よぎ)なくさせた。
example.english: The pandemic forced stores and schools to close.

example.japanese: 大(だい)洪水(こうずい)は都市(とし)からの撤退(てったい)を余儀(よぎ)なくさせた。
example.english: The major flood forced people to withdraw from the city.

example.japanese: 70年代(ねんだい)のエネルギー危機(きき)は政府(せいふ)にガソリン以外(いがい)の代替(だいたい)エネルギーを探(さが)すことを余儀(よぎ)なくさせた。
example.english: The energy crisis of the 1970s forced the government to look for alternative energy sources, other than gasoline.

example.japanese: バブル崩壊(ほうかい)が彼(かれ)に会社(かいしゃ)の株式(かぶしき)の売却(ばいきゃく)を余儀(よぎ)なくさせた。
example.english: The economic bubble burst forced him to sell his shares in the company.

english_grammar.title: ～て + やる
english_grammar.explanation: Just wait and see, Just you wait, To do a favor, For you, Definitely, For sure
english_grammar.structure: Verb[て] + やる
english_grammar.about: てやる may be used ironically to show anger, or the strong resolve to perform undesirable actions to the listener (threatening), rather than performing favors for others sake. In addition it may also be used to express an intention to show off one's true ability/power. It’s often used together with expressions like どうせ、絶対、さっさと and the like.

example.japanese: アクション映画(えいが)のマッチョな主人公(しゅじんこう)：「ぶっ殺(ころ)してやる！」
example.english: The macho protagonist in an action movie: ‘I'm gonna kill you!’

example.japanese: お金(かね)がなくて行(い)きたい大学(だいがく)に行(い)けないという状況(じょうきょう)：「金持(かねも)ちになってやる！」
example.english: The situation of not being able to go to the school one wants to, due to money problems : ‘I will get rich, just you wait!’

example.japanese: 低得点(ていとくてん)で馬鹿(ばか)にされた後(あと)：「絶対(ぜったい)、次(つぎ)のテストでは100点(てん)取(と)って、あいつを見返(みかえ)してやる。 」
example.english: After being ridiculed for a low score : 'I will definitely score 100 on the next test and prove I’m better than that dude, just you wait!'

example.japanese: 「絶対(ぜったい)、合格(ごうかく)してやる！」
example.english: ‘I will surely pass, just wait and see!’

example.japanese: A子(こ)：「こっちからあっちまで競走(きょうそう)しよ！」 B子(こ)：「いいよ、勝(か)ってやる!」
example.english: Child A : ‘Let's race from here to there! Child B : ‘Okay! I'll win!’

english_grammar.title: ただ〜のみだ
english_grammar.explanation: Nothing but, Should, Have to, Only, All that remains,
english_grammar.structure: (ただ) + Verb［る］+ のみ + (だ(1)) (ただ) + ［する］Verb + ある(2) + のみ + (だ(1)) (1) である (2) する
english_grammar.about: (A) のみだ is a formal expression with a bookish nuance, indicating that there is nothing other than (A). With verbs that indicate movement, continuation, or hope (like 願う、祈る、練習、待つ、前進、行く、走る) it is often used to express the only possible course of action, in a way similar to しかない. In this use, するのみ can be replaced with あるのみ for an additional literary feel, without changing the meaning.

example.japanese: A「どうやれば作家(さっか)になる夢(ゆめ)を実現(じつげん)することができるのでしょう？」 B「やっぱりなにごとも練習(れんしゅう)あるのみだな。」
example.english: A : 'How can I achieve my dream of becoming a writer?' B : 'In the end, It all rests on practice.'

example.japanese: 「私(わたし)にできることは、あなたが成功(せいこう)できるよう、ただ祈(いの)るのみです。」
example.english: ‘What I can do is nothing but to simply pray for your success.’

example.japanese: ｢できるだけのことをした。あとは降伏(こうふく)するのみだ。｣
example.english: ‘We have done all we can. All that remains is to surrender.’

example.japanese: 人生(じんせい)には後悔(こうかい)する暇(ひま)なんてありません。ただ前進(ぜんしん)あるのみです。
example.english: There is no time for something like regrets in life. We have only to move forward.

example.japanese: テストを受(う)けた後(あと)、ただ結果(けっか)を待(ま)つのみだ。
example.english: ‘After taking the test, it just rests on the wait for results.’

english_grammar.title: ものとする
english_grammar.explanation: Shall, To assume, To suppose, To consider
english_grammar.structure: Verb + ものとする
english_grammar.about: ものとする is a legal jargon phrase, meaning 'it is agreed upon' (literally 'to decide on a thing that') and is often used in legal documents, licenses, business contracts, and agreements following various terms and conditions.

example.japanese: 契約(けいやく)者(しゃ)は、次(つぎ)に掲(かか)げる業務(ぎょうむ)を行(おこな)うものとする。
example.english: A contractor shall perform the duties listed below.

example.japanese: 別表(べっぴょう)第(だい)七(なな)に定(さだ)める帳簿(ちょうぼ)は、五(ご)年間(ねんかん)保存(ほぞん)するものとする。
example.english: The account books provided in attached table 7 shall be retained for five years.

example.japanese: 当該(とうがい)研究(けんきゅう)は、法令(ほうれい)の範囲(はんい)内(ない)で行(おこな)うものとする。
example.english: The said research shall be conducted within the limits permitted by laws and regulations.

example.japanese: 延滞(えんたい)金(きん)は、納付(のうふ)金(きん)に先立(さきだ)つものとする。 ​
example.english: Penal interest shall be collected prior to the payment.

example.japanese: 契約(けいやく)書(しょ)は、英語(えいご)と日本語(にほんご)をもって記載(きさい)するものとする。
example.english: The contract shall be recorded in both English and Japanese.

english_grammar.title: との
english_grammar.explanation: That, To
english_grammar.structure: Verb + との + Noun ［い］Adjective + との + Noun ［な］Adjective + (だ) + との + Noun Noun + (だ) + との + Noun
english_grammar.about: (A) との (B) is a compound particle constructed from と (indicating a quotation), and の (indicating an attribute of a noun). It shows that the information included in the following noun is that of communication, like 提案、知らせ、意向、意見、依頼、見方、指摘、連絡、報告、見解、理由、こと and the like.

example.japanese: 多(おお)くの経済(けいざい)学者(がくしゃ)は、景気(けいき)が回復(かいふく)しつつあるとの見方(みかた)を維持(いじ)した。
example.english: Many economists maintain the opinion that business conditions are in the process of recovering.

example.japanese: 政府(せいふ)関係(かんけい)者(しゃ)は電気(でんき)自動車(じどうしゃ)の普及(ふきゅう)を推進(すいしん)するとの意向(いこう)を強調(きょうちょう)した。
example.english: The government officials stressed that their intention was to promote the popularization of electric vehicles.

example.japanese: 田中(たなか)さんは新(あたら)しい反(はん)トラスト法(ほう)が抜(ぬ)け穴(あな)だらけとの意見(いけん)を表明(ひょうめい)した。
example.english: Mr. Tanaka made clear his view that the new antitrust law is full of loopholes.

example.japanese: 《探偵(たんてい)の伝記(でんき)》 ２００２年(ねん)、彼(かれ)は、南(みなみ)アフリカに連(つ)れて行(い)った男性(だんせい)の家出(いえで)人(じん)を探(さが)してほしいとの依頼(いらい)を受(う)けた。
example.english: The biography of a detective : In 2002, he received a request to find a runaway man that went to South Africa.

example.japanese: あの日(ひ)、 雪崩(なだれ)が発生(はっせい)したとの報告(ほうこく)もあったが、けが人(にん)が出(で)ているかどうかは確認(かくにん)されていなかった。
example.english: That day there was also a report that an avalanche had occurred, but it was not clear whether any injured people had appeared.

english_grammar.title: 以前
english_grammar.explanation: Before, Not even, Before even, Precede, Far from
english_grammar.structure: Noun(1) + 以前（に） Noun(1) (A) + 以前 + の + Noun (B) (1) A(2) + (Antonym) A(2), Verb (A) + Verb (A)［ない］(2) (2) ［な］Adjective、［い］Adjective
english_grammar.about: (A) 以前 is used when a certain level/stage has not been reached yet, and the more fundamental issues of (B) remain. Often used to criticize thoughtless remarks, irresponsible attitudes, and the like. The noun 問題 is commonly modified by 以前.

example.japanese: ポイ捨(す)ては法律(ほうりつ)以前(いぜん)の道義(どうぎ)的(てき)な問題(もんだい)だ。
example.english: When it comes to littering, before even the law, it is a moral issue.

example.japanese: 彼(かれ)は、自分(じぶん)が女(おんな)の子(こ)にモテないのはファッションがださいからだと思(おも)ってる。それは事実(じじつ)だけど、それ以前(いぜん)の問題(もんだい)として、彼(かれ)は性格(せいかく)に問題(もんだい)がある。
example.english: He believes that he is not popular with girls due to his bad fashion sense. While that is true, preceding even that, he has issues with his personality.

example.japanese: 信(しん)じる信(しん)じない以前(いぜん)にもっと根本(こんぽん)的(てき)な問題(もんだい)なんだよ。先(ま)ずどうにか彼女(かのじょ)にこの事(こと)を伝(つた)えなきゃ。
example.english: Before whether she believes it or not, there is a more fundamental issue. To start, I must somehow convey this to her.

example.japanese: 食(た)べずに「ブロッコリーが嫌(きら)い」という人(ひと)もいます。 好(す)き嫌(きら)い以前(いぜん)に、食(た)べてみることが大事(だいじ)なのです。食(た)べた上(うえ)で、好(す)き嫌(きら)いはご自由(じゆう)に。
example.english: There are even people who say that they don’t like broccoli without having eaten it. Before being nitpicky, what’s important is to try it. Upon eating it, then feel free to be fussy.

example.japanese: パフォーマンス以前(いぜん)の問題(もんだい)で、基本(きほん)的(てき)な機能(きのう)を実装(じっそう)する必要(ひつよう)があります。
example.english: Preceding the performance issue, it is necessary to equip it with basic functionality.

english_grammar.title: ともあろうものが
english_grammar.explanation: of all people, such,
english_grammar.structure: Noun + ともあろう + もの(1) + が (1) 方、人
english_grammar.about: ともあろう〜が follows a noun that denotes a person or group of people of high social standing, specialists, or simply someone that the speaker evaluates highly. It is followed by the speaker's opinion about that person's actual behavior, which differs from their expectations. It often expresses shock, reproach, or disappointment. However, it is sometimes also used for motivation (implying that the person in question is highly valued by the speaker) or to state in general what should be done by a person in such a position. Often seen alongside なんて, とは, のは and directly followed by expressions like 者, 人, 方.

example.japanese: この田中(たなか)さんともあろうものがくだらないミスをしてしまった。
example.english: For Mr. Tanaka of all people to make such a silly mistake.

example.japanese: 大(だい)自然(しぜん)を保護(ほご)することを呼(よ)びかけている国会(こっかい)議員(ぎいん)ともあろうものが、砂浜(すなはま)にごみを散(ち)らかすとは信(しん)じられない。
example.english: Of all people, It is unbelievable that a member of the Diet who calls for the protection of nature would litter at the beach.

example.japanese: 乱世(らんせい)の時(とき)にこんなふざけた言動(げんどう)があるだろうか。議員(ぎいん)ともあろうものが…
example.english: A joke like this in such turbulent times? And from a member of parliament of all people…

example.japanese: 上司(じょうし)が部下(ぶか)坂(ざか)本(ほん)に：「君(きみ)ともあろう優秀(ゆうしゅう)な部下(ぶか)がこんなミスをするなんて。なぜあんなことを？
example.english: Superior to his subordinate, Sakamoto : 'I cannot believe that of all people, brilliant subordinate such as you would make this kind of mistake. Why did you do such a thing?'

example.japanese: ファンタジー映画(えいが)：「 賢(かしこ)いウィザードともあろう者(もの)がいつ正気(しょうき)を失(うしな)った？」
example.english: Fantasy movie : 'When did the wise wizard of all people lose all sanity?'

english_grammar.title: こそすれ〜ない
english_grammar.explanation: and certainly not, but certainly not, but, although, even though
english_grammar.structure: ［する］Verb + こそすれ Verb［ます］+ こそすれ
english_grammar.about: (A) こそすれ (B), when followed by the clause ending with a negative form is used in written language to strongly emphasize that (A) is the case, certainly not (B). This grammar construction has roots in Classical Japanese where こそ forces the predicate into the realis form (已然形). Normally こそ would emphasize (A), but when the realis form is in the middle of the sentence it expresses concession. This pattern can be seen in other combinations like こそなれ and こそあれ.

example.japanese: セキュリティ事故(じこ)は増(ふ)えこそすれ、減(へ)りはしないだろう。
example.english: The security incidents will only increase, certainly not decrease.

example.japanese: 小説(しょうせつ)：だが実際(じっさい)は、剣士(けんし)の復讐(ふくしゅう)心(しん)は火(ひ)の手(て)をつよめこそすれ、決(けっ)して冷(さ)めるどころではなかったのである。
example.english: Novel : ‘In reality, however, the swordsman's blazing desire for vengeance was intensifying, and certainly not cooling down at all.’

example.japanese: 多(おお)くの人(ひと)にとって、その奇妙(きみょう)な現象(げんしょう)は驚(おどろ)きこそすれ、恐怖(きょうふ)を感(かん)じるほどではなかった。
example.english: The strange phenomenon was surprising for many, and certainly not terrifying.

example.japanese: 魔法使(まほうつか)いへの恋情(れんじょう)は、強(つよ)めこそすれ弱(よわ)めるものではなかった。
example.english: Her love for the sorcerer strengthened, and certainly didn’t weaken.

example.japanese: 感謝(かんしゃ)こそすれ、憎(にく)しみを感(かん)じるなんてちゃんちゃらおかしいよ。
example.english: I feel gratitude, certainly not something as ridiculous as hatred.

english_grammar.title: 並み
english_grammar.explanation: as, on par with, worthy of
english_grammar.structure: Noun + 並み + だ Noun + 並み + の + Noun Noun + 並み + に + Phrase
english_grammar.about: (A) 並み is a suffix indicating that something is ‘standing shoulder-to-shoulder with (A)’, in other words, ‘on the same level as (A)’. When 並み is not attached to a noun, it conveys the meaning of ‘ordinary’ or ‘average’, and in these cases, is often written as 並.

example.japanese: 私(わたし)の妻(つま)の歌(うた)はプロ並(な)みだ。
example.english: My wife's singing is on par with pros.

example.japanese: アトランタの年間(ねんかん)日照(にっしょう)時間(じかん)は、ローマ平均(へいきん)並(な)みである。
example.english: Atlanta's annual daylight hours are on par with Rome's average.

example.japanese: チタンは鋼鉄(こうてつ)並(な)みの丈夫(じょうぶ)さだが、はるかに軽量(けいりょう)である。
example.english: Titanium is as strong as steel, yet much lighter.

example.japanese: この映画(えいが)はアカデミー賞(しょう)並(な)みの功績(こうせき)でした。
example.english: This movie was an achievement on par with the level of an academy award.

example.japanese: 統計(とうけい)から推測(すいそく)すると、中国(ちゅうごく)の経済(けいざい)は先進(せんしん)国(こく)並(な)みになってきている。
example.english: Statistics suggest that China's economy has come to be on par with with that of other developed countries.

english_grammar.title: に先駆けて
english_grammar.explanation: first, prior to, pioneer, ahead of
english_grammar.structure: Noun + に先駆け(て)
english_grammar.about: (A) に先駆けて (B) is a phrase used with nouns like 世界, 全国, 全市, 業界, 他社, 他◯, indicating that the subject of a sentence has done something first, prior to others, and therefore is a pioneer in some respect. In certain contexts, it can also simply mean ‘prior’ or ‘before’.Often used by politicians, local governments, and companies on their websites or in advertisements.

example.japanese: １７６３年(ねん)に、プロイセンは他国(たこく)に先駆(さきが)けて近代(きんだい)的(てき)な義務(ぎむ)教育(きょういく)を導入(どうにゅう)した。
example.english: In 1763, paving the way for other countries, Prussia introduced the modern compulsory education.

example.japanese: コンサートのサイト： ファンクラブでは、一般(いっぱん)発売(はつばい)に先駆(さきが)けて、チケットの販売(はんばい)を行(おこな)います。
example.english: Concert website : ‘The selling of tickets via the fan club will take place prior to offering them to the general public.’

example.japanese: 広告(こうこく)： 世界(せかい)の人々(ひとびと)に先駆(さきが)けて、楽(たの)しみながら学(まな)ぶ体験(たいけん)型(がた)博物館(はくぶつかん)を訪(おとず)れてみてはいかがでしょう。
example.english: Advertisement : ‘How about paving the way for the people of the world and visiting an interactive museum, where you can learn and have fun at the same time.’

example.japanese: 我(わ)が社(しゃ)は他社(たしゃ)に先駆(さきが)けて世界(せかい)初(はつ)となる海流(かいりゅう)発電(はつでん)の実証(じっしょう)実験(じっけん)を成功(せいこう)させた。
example.english: Pioneering for other companies, our company was the first in the world to succeed in demonstrating ocean current power generation.

example.japanese: スプートニク１号(ごう)は世界(せかい)に先駆(さきが)けて打(う)ち上(あ)げられた人工(じんこう)衛星(えいせい)です。
example.english: Pioneering for the rest of the world, Sputnik was the first artificial satellite to be launched.

english_grammar.title: を機に
english_grammar.explanation: opportunity, occasion
english_grammar.structure: Noun + を機に(して)
english_grammar.about: A phrase used to express a time or circumstance that led to something beginning or changing.

example.japanese: 小説(しょうせつ)：３ヶ月(かげつ)目(め)にやっと病気(びょうき)が完治(かんち)し、これを機(き)に、入院(にゅういん)後(ご)初(はじ)めて退院(たいいん)することができた。
example.english: Novel : ‘In the third month, she was finally completely cured of her illness, and this opportunity allowed her to leave the hospital for the first time since hospitalization.’

example.japanese: 伝記(でんき)：大学(だいがく)卒業(そつぎょう)を機(き)に大阪(おおさか)へ移(うつ)り、プログラミングの職(しょく)を得(え)ることができました。
example.english: Biography : ‘On the opportunity of graduation, I moved to Osaka and was able to land a programming job.’

example.japanese: 演説(えんぜつ)： 今回(こんかい)の訪問(ほうもん)を機(き)に、より多(おお)くのアメリカ人(じん)が日本(にっぽん)で働(はたら)くことに興味(きょうみ)を持(も)つことを願(ねが)っています。
example.english: Speech : ‘We hope that this visit will provide an opportunity for more Americans to be interested in working in Japan.’

example.japanese: 小説(しょうせつ)：結婚(けっこん)を機(き)にたまひこは東京(とうきょう)を離(はな)れ、千葉(ちば)の町(まち)でゆずきとふたりの新(しん)生活(せいかつ)を始(はじめ)じめた。
example.english: Novel : ‘On the opportunity of getting married, Tamahiko left Tokyo and started a new life with Yuzuki in the town of Chiba.’

example.japanese: 伝記(でんき)：ひろしは56歳(さい)の時(とき)故郷(こきょう)へ戻(もど)ったのを機(き)に、両親(りょうしん)の墓参(はかまい)りに行(い)った。
example.english: Biography : ‘When Hiroshi returned to his hometown at the age of 56, he took the opportunity to visit his parent's graves.’
